column2: Army camp teams and the forty defending State champions will qualify for the 1941 State championship tournaments of the National Semi-Pro Baseball Congress without having to earn their places in district qualifying tourneys, it was announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

VICHY, France, April 27 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, will remain in Vichy until after the celebration of May Day, which this year, according to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's plans, will be observed as a festival of social concord.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- Ernest W. Gibson Jr., national chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, urged tonight the use of American convoys in the Atlantic and said he believed the step would bring no declaration of war from Germany.

Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, has been renominated for the presidency of the New York State Chamber of Commerce for a one-year term, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the nominating committee. The election will be held at the annual meeting on Thursday.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Wheat prices dropped early last week to the lowest level in about a month, with many recent buyers going out of their holdings on the way down. At the low, prices showed a decline of 5 1/8 to 6 1/4 cents a bushel from the high point early in the month, with the May the least affected.

NEW ORLEANS, April 27 -- Sagging tendencies ruled here in the cotton market most of last week as the result of negative war news and the further delays in Congress on the new farm policies. In spite of these factors, however, selling pressure at no time was pronounced.

Two of the highest scholastic honors given to Columbia College seniors, the Henry Evans Traveling Fellowship and the William Mitchell Fellowship for graduate study in Columbia University, have been awarded to William T. deBary of Leonia, N.J., and Donald A. Dike of 423 West 118th Street, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- It was one man against two as N.Y.U. wrestled Indiana for major honors in the Penn Relay Carnival that came to an end under threatening skies yesterday. And the one man did rather well for himself as Leslie MacMitchell anchored three Violet teams to victory and another to second place.

SOME time ago there was a hipper-dipper play in pro football that confused this innocent bystander no little. Art Rooney sold his Pittsburgh club and joined up as a partner with Bert Bell in Philadelphia. The new owners of the Pittsburgh club then went into a huddle with the Bell-Rooney pair and came out with a big shift play.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The White House was reported today to have Urged House conferees to stand pat against a $238,000,000 increase in farm "parity" payments voted by the Senate.

The recent metropolitan Miami fishing tournament, which had no less than 242,000 official entries, instead of settling the argument as to the comparative fishing skill of men and women, has only supplied the weaker sex with additional fuel, for some of the major prizes are going to women.

AMSTERDAM, via Berlin, April 27 -- Last week's securities markets in the small Continental European countries displayed increasing activity, monetary abundance all around creating a basis for an upward movement. This tendency, however, sometimes was crossed by local counteracting influences.

Acquisition by the Navy of Floyd Bennett Field next month will fulfill a manifest destiny for that great airport. Since its opening ten years ago it admittedly has been one of the best flying fields in the nation -- clear of approach, supplied with long and well-arranged runways, and fitted with complete control and radio aid facilities.

Last September, prior to the opening of the schools, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Magee of New Jersey asked the motorists "To apply themselves just a little bit more to the business of driving while operating a motor car." The fact that more than 900,000 children would soon be going to and from school occasioned the appeal.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A House battle over regulation of labor relations in the national defense emergency and a Senate committee fight over convoys face Congress this week. Investigations of the defense program will continue on both sides of Capitol Hill and the House Ways and Means Committee will begin public hearings tomorrow on the program to increase taxes by $3,600,000,000.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 (AP) -Tonight's R.A.F. Middle East Command communique follows

The School of Architecture and Allied Arts of New York University has been ordered to close its doors. In the fifteen years since it was founded with thirty-three students it has grown continuously through the depression until its registration in September, 1940, was 500. Of there more than half are evening students employed in professional offices during the day.

Eight of twenty-one contestants survived the metropolitan qualifying round yesterday at the Salle Santelli and thereby gained the semi-finals of the national epee fencing championship meet to be held in June. Three of those coming through, Leo Nunes of the New York A.C. and the de Capriles brothers, Jose and Miguel, both of the home organization, are former national titleholders.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Leaders of American business tonight prepared their most optimistic reports in years for presentation at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, opening here tomorrow.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 27 -- With the running of the Orange County Stake, the thirtieth anniversary meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club was concluded today before the largest gallery of the three days of sport on the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 27 -- Overseas comments, including even some in the United Kingdom and certainly many in America, suggest the circumstance that Australia's reaction to the reverse in Greece has been fundamentally misapprehended.

Miss Lorraine Fischer, Women's Swimming Association star, captured the women's 100-yard free-style event on the A.A.U. program at the Park Central pool yesterday. Miss Jean Booth, unattached, offered considerable opposition through the race, and held the lead for the first fifty yards.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to Soviet Russia and to France, declared here tonight that the Chinese were fighting our battle on what is "literally -- in a strategic sense -- our Western front" and called on the American people, "for our own salvation," to give all the aid in their power not only to the Chinese but to the British.

St. John's victory over Fordham, putting the Redmen a little closer to their objective of three straight intracity baseball championships, provided the college diamond feature of a week which saw every metropolitan nine drop at least one decision.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Governor Lehman announced today his signing of the Peterson bill (Assembly Introductory No. 1221) setting up, for the first time, standards for determining degrees of intoxication in connection with automobile accidents.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27 -The barrier of war is being removed for astronomers of England and Germany by an exchange service established by the American Astronomical Society, according to Bart J. Block of Harvard Observatory, chairman of a committee which serves as a medium for the exchange of data.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals pounded Bill Lee and Rookie Paul Erickson from the mound with an extra-base barrage today and went on to sweep the two-game series from the Cubs, 8 to 5, before 18,678 fans. The defeat was Chicago's fifth in six games.

City College players, although defeated by 7 1/2 -- 2 1/2, made a brave showing against the champion team of the Manhattan Chess Club in the semi-finals for the Metropolitan Chess League title yesterday, and their play was favorably commented upon by the many members present.

Only ten gunners took part in a special shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The winner of the high-over-all scratch cup was A. Mullhaupt, who broke 98 out of 100 targets. The handicap shoot went to B.D. Hannish, the only gunner to have a full card of 100 targets.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- While lard failed to establish a new high price for the season last week, good buying was in evidence on minor declines on the Board of Trade. However, the buying was not aggressive and holders of contracts who had bought at lower prices showed a rather pronounced disposition at times to accept profits, prices having risen more than 3 1/2 cents a pound from recent low levels.

We can think of few things more delightful these bright, Spring mornings than crisp, buttery breakfast toast, piping hot and spread with an entrancing new cinnamon jelly. This is only one of the myriad uses for this admirable invention of a woman from Syracuse -- and her chemist son and nutritionist daughter -- but we, who nurture a life-long love for cinnamon-toast, find it our favorite.

Steel production, which in March reached a high record, equivalent to 100 per cent of capacity as rated at the end of last year, and which exceeded by 63 per cent the output of March, 1940, has fallen back, by the Iron and Steel Institute's weekly reckoning, to 96 per cent of capacity.
CLEVELAND, April 27 -- The Indians swung into first place today as Bob Feller, aided by Jeff Heath's seventh-inning homer, tamed the Tigers, 2 to 1, before 31,728 fans in Cleveland Stadium.

Emphasizing that every minute is precious in "this fateful hour," John D. Rockefeller Jr., in a letter made public yesterday, urged that President Roosevelt take immediate action to see that American war materials and foodstuffs are "laid down at Britain's door," and that Nazi and Communist fifth columns, which he blamed for some recent disputes between industry and labor, are eliminated from our defense program.

BERLIN, April 27 (UP) -- Master of one-third of Europe, Reichsfuehrer Hitler tonight held ancient Athens as his latest prize of conquest and from his field headquarters "somewhere in the southeast" proclaimed the end of the war in the Balkans.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The Greek campaign is rapidly approaching its definitive and -- for the remaining British forces there -- catastrophic conclusion, judging from today's High Command communique and several special announcements released during the afternoon and evening.

America has come through many struggles in its history, but rarely, if ever, has it been so gravely threatened from without as it is today, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott Director of Selective Service for New York City, warned 7,000 persons yesterday at the twenty-first annual patriotic celebration of May Day in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

Sales of two sites in Newark, N.J., for improvement with commercial buildings have been announced. Both parcels were bought by the Williamburg Trading Corporation, representing out-of-town investors, according to Louis Schlesinger, Inc., broker in the transaction.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (AP) -- Bill Posedel, making his first start this season, held the Phillies to four hits and rapped three himself today to give the Bees an 8-to-3 triumph.
Jacque A. Salz has been elected president of Salz Brothers, Inc., manufacturers of fountain pens and pencils. Mr. Salz was formerly vice president. I. Salz has been named chairman of the board.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 27 -Chelsea Ruscus, an aged gelding belonging to the Nydrie Stable of Virginia, won the hunter championship in the eleventh annual Harrison horse show, curtain-raiser of the metropolitan outdoor season, in the ring of the Kentucky Riding Stables today.
THAT Oceans of the World series which Whittlesey House is getting out begins to look like something this morning with the publication of the second volume: Russell Owen's "The Antarctic."*

The military balance sheet of the Balkans campaign, still to be completed by the final casualty lists of both sides, adds up to a considerable, though preliminary, German victory, the week-end reports showed.

VICHY, France, April 27 (UP) -- France must step from economic collaboration with Germany to "political cooperation," the Nazi-dominated press in Paris asserted today in suggesting the contents of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's latest proposals to the Vichy Government.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's broadcast address yesterday as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Monday, April 28 -- Hamburg got its first taste of the powerful new British bombs over Saturday night when Royal Air Force planes dropped them on Germany's greatest port. Big areas in the industrial and dock sections were reported blasted.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 -- As the German forces were approaching Athens various legations there spent some frenzied days and nights evacuating their nationals and dependents. Many of these had lived in Athens for years, while some had recently arrived from other parts of Europe that progressively had come under Nazi domination.

The sharp increase in public concern over the outlook for prices has been reflected in many developments lately, according to the Guaranty Trust Company'of New York in discussing war-time price tendencies in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

LONDON, April 27 -- Unseasonal expansion in the Bank of England's note circulation continues. Last week's increase of 247,000 contrasted with a decline of 663,000 in the same week of last year and raised the total to a new record of 622,500,000.

ROME, April 27 (UP) -- Italian quarters tonight generally regarded the speech of British Prime Minister Winston Churchill as primarily aimed at whipping up the flagging British spirit, believed sent to a new low by Balkan reverses. At the same time, Italians say, Mr. Churchill aimed to increase proBritish sympathies in the United States by plain and flattering tribute to the supreme importance to Britain of United States aid.

BERLIN, April 27 -- On Friday the German air force is reported to have "destroyed" three merchantmen totaling 27,000 tons and to have damaged two other merchant vessels in waters around Greece. Two of the three ships destroyed on Friday are said to have been large transports.
CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- Bucky Walters evened accounts today with the Pirates, who had knocked him off the mound in his first start of the season, by twirling the Reds to a 3-2 victory.

The tradition that a country will not be kept back from war because of financial problems is amply confirmed by Japan's experience during the past few years. Even before the Manchurian "incident," the Japanese budget was not fully balanced, but since then the annual deficit has grown rapidly.

MANILA, April 18 -- The Commonwealth government wants help from America, mainly financial. With five and a half years remaining before independence, war conditions and world conditions have made it impossible, the Filipinos say, to carry out the program designed to make them economically self-sufficient.

The last dispatch from the correspondent of The Associated Press in Athens, telling of the German occupation of the city, was filed only five minutes after the Nazi vanguard appeared. It was assumed that German censorship had immediately clamped down on outgoing news dispatches.

A BRITISH PORT, April 27 -- Thousands of Canadian fighting men and the largest force of Canadian-trained Imperial fliers yet to reach Great Britain have arrived from Canada to take their posts in the war against Germany.

The threat of a strike affecting $21,000,000 in defense orders was averted yesterday when officers of the Fairchild Aviation Corporation and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O., reached a tentative agreement on terms of a new contract.

A greater percentage of questionable advertisements appear in newspapers of cities with 250,000 to 499,999 population than in any other population classification, according to an analysis by the Federal Trade Commission of newspaper advertising which it reviewed in the year 1949.

BUFFALO, April 27 -- Three thousand physicians from this State and other sections of the country are expected here for the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York, which will hold sessions tomorrow through Thursday.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, suggested yesterday that to prevent Hitler or the Communists from "getting" our youth, we adopt here a policy of youth indoctrination similar to Hitler's, but with God as the object of devotion.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 27 -- The 212th Coast Artillery will be the first of the three New York National Guard regiments to go on firing manoeuvre in the Okefenokee Swamp in Southern Georgia.

With the occupation of Athens yesterday the fourteenth nation to come under the domination of Germany in a little more than three years fell to Adolf Hitler. He has now become master of 767,305 square miles of "Lebensraum," or more than three times the 182,471 square miles that compose the German Reich.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, said tonight that this country could control inflation if it took the necessary steps in time. The steps, he said, are: first, to increase supplies; second, to curtail demand for goods, and, third, to control the price of goods.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- The Spring furniture and home furnishings market, opening here May 5 for one week, is expected to shatter all previous records for sales and attendance. The Merchandise Mart expects a minimum increase of 20 per cent in attendance; the American Furniture Mart announced that "forecasts of a record-breaking attendance are heard in all branches of the industry and many leaders place attendance as high as the 3,500 mark."

Strong appeals for national unity and confidence in the Roosevelt Administration were made yesterday by James A. Farley and Senator James M. Mead at the twentieth annual communion breakfast of the New York Postoffice Holy Name Society at the Hotel Astor.

PIKESVILLE, Md., April 27 -- Capturing the honors for best in show and best American-bred in the Baltimore County Dog Show, Champion Overture of Mazelaine, owned by Mrs. L.A. Slesinger of Cedarhurst, L.I., added another triumph to the credit of her sire, Champion Utz v. Dom of Mazelaine, one of the leading boxers, who died recently.
BERLIN, April 27 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this special communique today:

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, suggested yesterday that to prevent Hitler or the Communists from "getting" our youth, we adopt here a policy of youth indoctrination similar to Hitler's, but with God as the object of devotion.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., April 27 -- The 212th Coast Artillery will be the first of the three New York National Guard regiments to go on firing manoeuvre in the Okefenokee Swamp in Southern Georgia.

With the occupation of Athens yesterday the fourteenth nation to come under the domination of Germany in a little more than three years fell to Adolf Hitler. He has now become master of 767,305 square miles of "Lebensraum," or more than three times the 182,471 square miles that compose the German Reich.

PIKESVILLE, Md., April 27 -- Capturing the honors for best in show and best American-bred in the Baltimore County Dog Show, Champion Overture of Mazelaine, owned by Mrs. L.A. Slesinger of Cedarhurst, L.I., added another triumph to the credit of her sire, Champion Utz v. Dom of Mazelaine, one of the leading boxers, who died recently.
BERLIN, April 27 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this special communique today:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the arrest of three men and a woman charged with hiding 12,000 dressed muskrat skins worth $20,000 that were rightfully assets of a bankrupt company. The furs were recovered, mostly in a warehouse at Nyack, according to B.E. Sackett, special agent in charge of the FBI here.

The foreign exchange market showed a firm undertone last week, buttressed as this was by the economic and monetary agreements which this country has arranged with Canada and China and which expands by several the number of alien currencies now within the orbit of official support.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 -- German and Italian light mobile forces crossed the Egyptian-Libyan frontier yesterday, carrying out operations similar to those that presaged the Italian drive to Sidi Barrani last September.

Blankets for Britain are to be made free by prison labor at the Wyoming State Penitentiary at Rawlins, out of fleeces contributed by 2,000 members of the Wyoming Wool Growers and Wyoming Wool Marketing Associations from their Spring shearing.

The new Nathan Straus Library, 348 East Thirty-second Street, the first branch of the New York Public Library to be devoted exclusively to children and young people, will be dedicated Wednesday and will be open for registration shortly after May 1, it was announced yesterday by Frank L. Polk, president.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 (UP) -Dimitri Capsalis, Greek Minister to Egypt, asserted tonight that Greece would continue to give Britain all the aid within her power and that the huge Greek merchant marine remained at Britain's disposal.
ROME, April 27 (UP) -- The Axis victory in Greece is a defeat for the United States as well as for Britain, the newspaper Popolo di Roma said today in a front-page editorial.

A new course for the Fall semester, in which virtually every phase of defense financing, wartime shipping and mobilization of man power and industry will be studied, will be offered to students in the College of Arts and Science of St. John's University. Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Dr. Edward J. Walsh, president.
CHICAGO, April 27 (UP) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana reiterated today that President Roosevelt had destroyed American neutrality and prepared the nation "for a declaration of war."

BERLIN, April 27 -- The German stock markets continue to grope in the dark regarding the final shape of the government's regulations restricting dividends, publication of which now is expected early in May.

The demand for labor in defense industries has proved an indirect spur to unionism and higher wages for workers engaged in the manufacture of women's apparel, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L., declared yesterday.

ATHENS, April 27 -- Adolf Hitler's conquering forces occupied ancient Athens at 10 o'clock this morning, just three weeks after the launching of Germany's Balkan Blitzkrieg, and hoisted the Nazi swastika over the crumbling columns of the Acropolis.

ROME, April 27 -- The American press was attacked today in Italian newspapers, which contrast their self-styled freedom of the press with the shackles they say bind American and British journalism. They declare that while the Anglo-Saxon press tells lies the Italian press tells only the truth.

Despite a post-Easter letdown in some of the major apparel lines, the insistent demand for home furnishings, domestics and some other merchandise lines last week provided a good deal of business, which would have been much larger if manufacturers had been able to offer reasonably nearby deliveries.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The German stock markets continue to grope in the dark regarding the final shape of the government's regulations restricting dividends, publication of which now is expected early in May.

ROME, April 27 -- The American press was attacked today in Italian newspapers, which contrast their self-styled freedom of the press with the shackles they say bind American and British journalism. They declare that while the Anglo-Saxon press tells lies the Italian press tells only the truth.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh resigned yesterday his colonel's commission in the United States Army Air Corps Reserve, saying that he could see "no honorable alternative."

Ira X.aupt Co., members of the New York Stock Exehange. have issued their ninth annual Statistical Hand Book: for New Jersey Municipal Bonds. It contains an analysis of Jan. 1, 1941, debt statements of more than 200 New Jersey municipalities, 1940 census figures and mother pertinent data on the financial condition of those communities.

Three small boys returned to their native United States yesterday unaccompanied by parents or guardians, after traveling together from Paris, where they were brought together by the American consul. They came on the American Export liner Exeter, which docked at Pier F, Jersey City, with 192 passengers, including ninety-four United States citizens.

At meetings of the boards of directors of Loft, Inc., and of the Pepsi-Cola Company yesterday, a plan for the merger of Loft, Inc., and Pepsi-Cola Company was approved for submission to stockholders of the respective companies.

A former acting superintendent in the Ford Motor Company plant at Edgewater, N.J., told the National Labor Relations Board here yesterday that Ford spies planted tools on employes suspected of union activities with the object of having them dismissed.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Passenger fares in the Hudson Tubes between the downtown terminal in New York and New Jersey points will remain at the existing 8 cents charge under a Supreme Court ruling issued today.

This letter is from an isolationist -- but with a difference. This one considers what the world will be if the powers that have chosen war, destruction, slavery as national policies win this struggle. Obviously, there is but one way open unless we are to hand on an endless cloud of fear to a world darkened by the final success of Hitlerism.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Four makers of gray-iron and malleable iron castings who did 19 per cent of such business in this country in 1939 had a combined net income of 7 per cent after providing for income taxes, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

OUT of the West came Commissar McKechnie of the baseball Reds. He was flanked by Sergeant Hank (Old Goldenrod) Gowdy and Corporal Jewel Ens. They were talking baseball, as usual. Asked about conditions in their part of the country, Corporal Ens said:
ROME, April 28 -- Italian aeronautical units and Blackshirts occupied the Greek island of Corfu this morning, while a battalion of infantry drove down to Preveza, on the Gulf of Arta.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 28 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs made it two straight over the Jersey Giants by capturing a 2 -- 1 decision today behind Walter LanFranconi's effective ten-hit hurling.
ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- The Browns displayed their potent batting power again today -- and let it go at that -- as the White Sox took their third straight game of the series, 2 to 1.

It seems that the President has reached a point of indecision at the very moment a large part of the country waits for him to act. He has put himself on record as declaring that the Administration will build and maintain a bridge of ships to England and see to it that the materiel made possible under the lend-lease act is carried safely across.

Yehudi Menuhin, noted violinist, will make his first appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium as a soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on July 21, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, announced yesterday.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the organization of a Youth Counsel Bureau, to be maintained by private support and directed by a committee of five, to aid boys and girls of the ages of 16 to 20 who have been accused o crimes and dismissed or acquitted in the courts to avert future contact with crime.

National advertisers would make greater use of newspapers if they were given some inducement on a discount basis for quantity, such as retail advertisers receive, according to J.O. Carson, H.J. Heinz Company, chairman of the newspaper committee of he Association of National Advertisers.

Puccini's one-act comic opera "Gianni Schicchi" was presented in an English version last night at Carnegie Hall. It was the third experimental "music play" to be presented this season by the National Orchestral Association under Leon Barzin.

The daily double form of betting was inaugurated at Jamaica yesterday, with 349 winning tickets that paid $72.90 for $2 each sold on the combination of Tetra Rock, who returned $11.70 straight in the first race, and Cuckoo-Man, $11.60, in the second.

CAIRO, April 28 (UP) -- The fall of Dessye, 140 miles north of Addis Ababa, left only a few pockets of Fascist resistance in the crumbled Italian East African Empire and hastened the release of thousands of battle-hardened British troops for service in the northern desert.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -The United States Supreme Court held today that "there is nothing in the history of bankruptcy or reorganization legislation to support the theory that Congress intended to set the Federal courts up as super-assessment agencies over State taxes."
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- The Ministry of Information issued the following statement today:

The general technical committee of the American Iron and Steel Institute made public yesterday the results of two years' work on standardization of steel mill products with respect to alloy steels and pig iron to increase efficiency in production by encouraging a sharp reduction in specifications sent to mills by consumers.

LONDON, April 28 -- The stock markets closed in a cheerful state today, with prices firm in most sections. Dealers were pleased with Premier Churchill's speech and the news of the fall of Dessie in Ethiopia. The principal business was in gilt edge and war loan securities which, although not wholly maintaining the early rise, finished higher.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 28 -The official organ of the Swedish Communist party puts on the front page today under a four-column headline a manifesto of the German Communist Youth party, violently denouncing the German aggression against Yugoslavia as contrary to the national interests of the German people, calling "lies" the German contention that Britain began the attack in the Balkans and saying that "the German Government will not let any free people exist in Europe."

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. in the first quarter of the current fiscal year were 29 per cent ahead of a year ago, and profits before taxes were up 80 per cent, Robert E. Wood, chairman, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.
Four appointments to the faculty of Columbia University and fifteen promotions were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Roosevelt signed an order today freezing all Greek credits, investments and cash holdings in the United States, estimated to amount to between $40,000,000 and $50,000,000.
The 150-year-old remodeled Colonial dwelling at South Salem, Westchester County, formerly owned by Mrs. Sarah Lord Murphy, was sold to R.G. Aitchison through Thomas C. Grimes, broker.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Southern soft coal operators agreed tonight to increase wages $1 a day and to reopen the mines tomorrow, it was announced by Stephen Early, White House secretary, tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Orders for non-defense goods are continuing to increase, while shipments of durable goods -- mostly for defense -- are not yet catching up with orders, according to a Commerce Department report for March.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Absolute opposition to taxing the "poor man's table" was expressed today by Secretary Morgenthau in commenting upon the proposal of Colin F. Stam, chief of staff of the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, to impose excise duties on certain foods.

In forgetting domestic differences and uniting all forces in an effort to defeat the enemy, Palestine is setting an example to the rest of the world, Major Victor A Cazalet, Conservative member of the British House of Commons, declared yesterday.

PORTSMOUTH, England, April 28 (AP) -- Many homeless persons left this bomb-blasted southern port today to find a place to sleep, but authorities said the exodus was only a temporary movement and that those with jobs would be back tomorrow for work.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The first experimental evidence that genes, the factors inside all living cells controlling heredity, and viruses, organisms which produce some diseases in plants and animals, can produce similar effects in plants was presented today before the annual Spring meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Dr. Albert F. Blakeslee and Dr. A.G. Avery, of the Cold Spring Harbor (N.Y.) laboratory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 28 -- Enemy allegations of a rift between the United Kingdom and Australian Governments have importantly influenced the internal political situation. Present indications are that there will be neither a national government nor an opposition attempt to embarrass the government such as the censure motion that a few Laborites threaten to launch when Parliament reassembles.
VICHY, France, April 28 -- "Free French" forces of General Charles de Gaulle, supported by British motorized units, have started efforts to win over French Somaliland, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The American Trucking Association today won the annual bronze medallion of the American Trade Association Executives for special achievement "in the field of effectively combating discriminatory legislation, and the carrying on of a national advertising and public relations campaign which was tied up with the recently awakened public interest in interstate trade barriers."

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -The United States Supreme Court denied today the petition of six railroads for review of a lower court action dismissing their claims for $11,269,082 in New Jersey taxes for 1934, 1935 and 1936. The carriers contended that property assessments for those years were so arbitrary and excessive as to deprive them of property without due process of law in violation of the Federal Constitution.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Supreme Court Justice Bergan dismissed today without costs a petition of the Board of Higher Education of New York City which challenged the jurisdiction of Dr. Ernest E. Cole, State Commissioner of Education.

With the old agreement in the anthracite coal industry expiring at midnight tomorrow, the joint committee of operators and representatives of the United Mine Workers resumed their negotiations for a new contract at the Hotel Commodore last night.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- The two old masters were back together today and Whirlaway's stock in the Kentucky Derby market came out of its nose dive.

TRENTON, N.J., April 28 -- The Republican-controlled Senate adjourned late this afternoon until Wednesday afternoon without acting on Governor Charles Edison's nomination of William L. Dill, Democrat, as successor to State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner, Republican, whose term expires tomorrow.

CAP STEWART, Ca., April 28 -Troops of the 102d Brigade, comprising the 207th and 212th Coast Artillery Regiments of New York City and the 209th of Buffalo, will start firing .30 caliber rifles tomorrow for qualification on ranges here.

A vacant lot at Sixth Avenue and Eighth Street became an outdoor sculpture gallery yesterday afternoon when the Sculptors Guild opened its third outdoor exhibition. After a luncheon given by the Sixth Avenue Association at the Enrico Paglieri Restaurant, 66 West Eleventh Street, officers of the association and exhibiting sculptors walked to the Village Square for a preview of the show.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 28 -Army Minister P.C. Spender announced today that the evacuation of certain Australian troops from Greece had begun and thus far had proceeded successfully.

The first of a fleet of new streamlined police emergency trucks went into service at the West Fiftyfourth Street Station yesterday following its acceptance by Commissioner Valentine at Police Headquarters and an inspection by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

Dismissal of the city's condemnation proceeding on the old Sixth Avenue Elevated Line, in which tentative total damages of $12,519,063 have been fixed, was asked yesterday by the Bowery Savings Bank, Union Dime Savings Bank and 200 others among the property owners who have been assessed $4,754,001.
Panzer used three pitchers in recording a 7-6 victory over the Brooklyn College nine yesterday on the Kingsmen's diamond.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 28 -The eleventh annual Eastman School festival of American music opened tonight in Kilbourn Hall with a performance by the Rochester Civic Orchestra, Dr. Howard Hanson conducting.

The latest in a series of recent leasing transactions arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., in the Times Square area calls for occupancy by the Ninth Federal Savings Loan Association at an aggregate rental of about $1,000,000 of the quarters being vacated by Weber Heilbroner, in 1457 Broadway, between 41st and 42d Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The vital role of ships in the defense program prompted the opening here today of two major conferences designed to prevent strikes and lockouts in shipbuilding and to develop man power for the "bridge of ships" involved in the policy of aid to the nations which are resisting aggression.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 23 aggregated $9,972,000,000.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 28 (AP) -The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -Ellen Drew was named today to play the lead in Paramount's "The Silver Queen," which Harry Sherman will produce. The studio has held options on the property, a short story by Forrest Halsey and William Allen Johnston, for nearly a year, but concluded the purchase only this week.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Establishment in the Palais Wilson of the old League of Nations Building in Geneva of the recently organized European branch of the World Woman's party was announced here today by Miss Alice Paul, on the eve of her departure for Canada, where the first meeting of members of the Continental Committee for North America will be held in August, probably in Montreal.

Southern canners have been naming prices on new packs of several vegetable lines in the last few days, while those in other sections continue generally out of the market, so far as new packs are concerned. Brokers said yesterday, however, that some Northwest packers have been in the market briefly, taking a little business on the new pack and then withdrawing.

A call to war if necessary was drawn up here yesterday by a group of notable liberals, progressives and partisans of economic and social reforms that have caused most of them to be considered heretofore as left-wingers.

OTTAWA, April 28 -- Answering statements in the House of Commons by R.B. Hanson, Opposition leader, regarding Canada's man-power contribution to the war, Defense Minister J.L. Ralston today revealed that Canada has now 70,000 men overseas and 118,000 men enlisted for overseas service, in addition to her home defense militia.

Only one conclusion is possible concerning convoys: they must be granted, and quickly. The lease-lend bill passed by an overwhelming majority, as even its opponents admitted. As for what must inevitably follow, let those who have been the most out-and-out isolationists themselves bear testimony:

A Spring Festival will be held on the afternoon and evening of May 15 in tthe Recreation Hall of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, to raise funds for furthering the women's work of the church. A fashion show and tea will be features of the afternoon, as well as a bazaar.

An increase of 10 cents an hour for factory workers in the major plants of the General Electric Company was announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by W.R. Burrows, vice president of the company, and Julius Emspak, secretary-treasurer of the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O. affiliate.

Once the big gate crashes behind you at the Camp Fire Club you are on your own, and when you have penetrated 200 yards into the club grounds, you would refuse to believe that by climbing one of the tall trees in the hill it would be possible to see the Empire State tower on a clear, day.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- In a British answer to Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, Sir Gerald Campbell declared tonight that Great Britain would not make a "negotiated, false, inconclusive peace" because to do so would be "yellow."

Liquor importers were advised by cable yesterday of an advance of $2 a case on Scotch whisky, applicable immediately to all unshipped orders. The advance applies to all Scotch brands and is slightly above the $2 mark in the case of some of the older brands.

Greece still has a king and a government operating on Greek soil. Nobody knows how long Crete will be left uninvaded, but to the Greeks on the mainland there must be a gleam of consolation in the thought that the Premier who speaks for them in this dark hour.

Miss Mary Patricia Richter heads the recently organized debutante committee of the Episcopal Actors Guild that has arranged a Spring Tea to be held on May 8 at the headquarters of the organization in the Guild Hall of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Tranfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Resumption of work on the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel will be the principal feature of today's observance of Port Preparedness Dedication, a four-day celebration marking the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the Port of New York Authority and establishment of the Port District.

The firm of Donald Blackwell and Raymond Curtis has agreed to buy for presentation next season a play by Richard McCracken entitled "Two and A Prayer Remain." Most of the action takes place aboard a freighter plying waters patrolled by German submarines.

KANSAS CITY, April 28 -- Thomas Hart Benton, who recently said that art was "being ruined by museums," disclosed today that he would cease being head of the painting department of the Kansas City Art Institute when his contract expires next month.

Mrs. Henry R. Caraway, former president of the Women's National Republican Club, denounced yesterday the present Administration and particularly its leader and praised England's Prime Minister as the "only man in the world today who isn't afraid to tell the truth."

CAIRO, Egypt, April 28 -- Persons listening to the Athens radio now hear German songs and world news as it comes from fountainheads chosen by the German Propaganda Ministry -- Berlin, Bucharest and Sofia.

Taking exception to the statement by William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union, that the city's suit for a declaratory judgment on the labor contracts with the Transport Workers Union presented the simple question whether the closed shop was compatible with public employment, Michael J. Quill, international president of the union, yesterday declared:

ARMONK, N.Y., April 28 -- A survey of airport sites and other preparedness potentialities of Westchester County was made by air this afternoon by thirty county officials and civic leaders, flying from the Westchester Airport here. The program was arranged by the Port of New York Authority as part of its port preparedness dedication.

Sunday regatta dates on Long Island Sound, following by one day the championship events, were filled in yesterday after negotiations with the yacht clubs, by Fred Horton, rear commodore and race committee chairman of the Horseshoe Harbor Club of Larchmont, who did such a splendid job of the difficult task last year that he was called upon again.

There are three main ways in which an excessive rise in prices and the cost of living can be prevented. One is to cut down the volume of purchasing power in the hands of the public; another is to fix prices and ration consumption; the third is to increase production.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Men seeking work cannot be discriminated against because of union connections, and workers in a single plant of a company cannot choose their own bargaining agent, but must join a unit selected by the majority of employes in widely scattered establishments, the Supreme Court ruled today in two opinions broadly enlarging the scope of the Wagner act.

BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP) -- Sassy Lady, a 5-year-old chestnut mare owned by Mrs. C.E. Nelson, scored an upset victory in the Baltimore Spring Handicap today before a crowd of 10,000 as Pimlico's twelve-day meeting opened.

ST. PAUL, April 28 (AP) -- The big week-end in which leaders were given a general shake-up in the American Bowling Congress tourney was followed by a drought in high scores today, and the "Big Ten" board remained unchanged.

Among the 14,000 youngsters who swarmed into Madison Square Garden yesterday morning to attend a special performance of the circus for underprivileged children were fifty-five boys and girls who could not see the show, but enjoyed it heartily.

ALBANY, April 28 -Governor Lehman signed today, without comment, the Condon bill making givers as well as receivers of bribes in connection with horse-racing guilty of a felony, punishable by a prison term of one to five years and a fine of not more than $10,000.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to move within a narrow range in quiet trading. After opening 1 to 5 points up, prices held generally firm and closed unchanged to 5 points higher. Trade buying, influenced to some extent by strength in Worth Street, was the chief source of support for the market.

This season's series of Coffee Dances was concluded last night with a Spring dance at the Cosmopolitan Club. Net proceeds from the party will be directed to Bundles for Britain. Miss Constance Curtis is chairman of patronesses for the dances and Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, treasurer.

A paradoxical situation presented itself yesterday when three women received $100 apiece and appeared vague as to how they could spend it. Winners of an essay-writing contest on "What I Should Most Like to Own From the Art Collection of William Randolph Hearst," the women received their awards from Frederic A. Gimbel, vice president of the Gimbel store at Broadway and Thirty-third Street, which has the display on its fifth floor and sponsored the contest.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- An unusually distinguished audience attended the opening tonight of the Theatre Guild's "Somewhere in France," a melodrama by Carl Zuckmayer and Fritz Kortner about the collapse of France less than a year ago.

BERLIN, April 28 -- Occupation by the German armed forces of the few strategically vital positions in Greece not yet in their hands will be completed in a few days, it is confidently predicted in Berlin tonight. In the German view, the strategic operations in the Balkan campaign have ended with the taking of Athens and the establishment of bridgeheads on the Peloponnesus at Corinth and Patras.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 28 -The continued Spring drought has created a serious menace in the woodlands and brush areas of Suffolk County, officials said here today.

ALBANY, April 28 -- In a sharply worded memorandum, Governor Lehman cast aside today the $7,300,000 "windfall" discovered by Republican fiscal experts in the last legislative session, vetoing the Rules Committee bill (Assembly introductory 2245) which would have made the money available, half to the City of New York and half to the State.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- James O'Neil, former West Coast publicity director for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, denied from the witness stand today, in the deportation hearing of Harry Bridges, the accuracy of statements concerning Bridges's Communist party membership that he purportedly had given to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that it had distributed $15,000,000 of defense savings bonds to authorized banking agencies in the New York Federal Reserve District, which now number more than 1,000 institutions. The amount, which is calculated on the maturity value of the bonds, consists of 141,000 bonds ranging in size from $25 to $1,000.

They said it was too early to go overboard on the Dodgers, that Brooklyn's work against the other Eastern teams should be discounted, that the meetings with the Western power outfits must be awaited, and that the latter would offer the first real test.

Not all the private businesses being favored with orders from governmental bodies have the rosy prospect of profits ahead of them, the Tax Institute of the University of Pennsylvania warned yesterday, disclosing ruefully that it, too, had received a bulky package in the mail from a government purchasing agent's office acting in behalf of an unnamed governmental unit.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 28 (UP) -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden, after a meeting today of the War Cabinet, cabled to Prime Minister Winston Churchill in London an expression of Australia's full support of the empire's war effort.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 28 -- Canada will still buy much more from the United States than she sells across the border, and therefore, there is little prospect of relaxing any of the existing foreign exchange conservation restrictions, Prime Minister Mackenzie King told the House of Commons this afternoon when he reported on the "Hyde Park declaration" issued by President Roosevelt and himself after their meeting, April 20.

Conferences between representatives of the securities industry and the SEC on the proposed amendments to the securities acts are slated to be resumed tomorrow. It is hoped that a final draft of the joint recommendations for changes in the laws may be drawn following this week's meeting.

The new tobacco building at the New York foreign trade zone, at Stapleton, S.I., where Sumatra tobacco valued at more than $9,000,000 will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder during the next six months, was dedicated and officially opened yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a Circuit Court decision which New York officials contended would "in large measure nullify" the purpose of the State's "Blue Sky Law" to aid small investors who "become victims of fraud in the sale of securities."

Another Fifth Avenue corner site is to be improved with a large apartment building, according to plans filed yesterday by Sylvan Bien, architect, who submitted to the Department of Buildings what he said were preliminary data for a nineteen-story and penthouse project costing $1,500,000 which the Excelsior Savings Bank is to put up on the northeast corner of Sixty-ninth Street.

An exhibition of arts and crafts by children in New York private schools will be held on the first floor of the American Museum of Natural History from May 10 through 25. Approximately 1,500 items will be shown. The thirty-four schools represented will be grouped alphabetically.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 28 -- Governor General Sir Cyril Newall today warned New Zealanders that the war had moved nearer as a result of recent events and urged further enlistment in the Home Guard, which, he said, did not have enough men.
DETROIT, April 28 -- Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co., advocated "all aid" to Great Britain and China in a luncheon address today before the Economic Club of Detroit.

VICHY, April 28 (UP) -- In support of the British and "Free French" forces massed near French Somaliland's borders, British warships were said tonight to have appeared off Jibuti yesterday, blockading the port.

Changes in the pastorates of three Manhattan Methodist congregations and of three in the Bronx, and the addition in each of the boroughs of a congregation formerly belonging to the recently dissolved Eastern Swedish Conference, marked the announcement of charges for the coming conference year in the New York Conference of the Methodist Church, made yesterday by Bishop Francis J. McConnell.

BOSTON, April 28 -- Harvard's power-laden varsity crew combined its winning efforts with those of the jayvees and 150-pound varsity to retain the Dr. Allan Winter Rowe Memorial Cup today in the sunset on the Charles River. The Crimson's opponents, Massachusetts Tech and Boston University, both were strong in hopes but incapable of meeting the broadside sweeps of a smooth swinging Harvard eight that surprised its coach, Tom Belles.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- American business leaders today heard about business booming under the stimulus of billions of defense dollars, applauded a demand for the resignation of Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, and were told by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister, that Great Britain expected by the end of this year to be "coming up toward the crest of the wave as our enemy starts to go down."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 28 -- A new circular letter sent to all Norwegian priests and religious organizations by Major Vidkun Quisling's Ministry of Church and Education throws new light on the struggle between the Norwegian church and the Quisling authorities, which is continuing in Norway.

Good news indeed is the fact that asparagus is especially plentiful. The California season is nearing its height, South Carolina in full production, and last week the first big shipments from Pennsylvania and New Jersey arrived in market.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended April 26 in comparison with the like week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ATLANTA, April 28 (AP) -- For the third successive season, Nick Tronsky of Willimantic, Conn., emerged kingpin of the national duckpin tournament ali-events class today.

BUENOS AIRES, April 28 -- The Central Bank has approved the plan drawn up by a committee of American business men for the creation of an export corporation whose purpose will be to create additional exchange for financing Argentine purchases in the United States by promoting the sale in the United States of Argentine goods that hitherto have found a very reduced market there or none at all.

Neither the City Government nor the Transport Workers Union is the determining factor in our rapid transit situation. Another union entered yesterday in the role of what the lawyers call amicus curiae -- a "friend of the court." This is the Citizens Union, a nonpartisan body which in this instance, as in many others, succeeds admirably in representing the public interest.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Members of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission conferred today at the offices here of the SEC with representatives of the regional stock exchanges regarding proposed amendments to the Securities Act to be presented to Congress in May.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Textiles and textile products purchased at the Army Quartermaster Corps' general depot here have cost approximately $500,000,000 since the defense program buying started early last Summer, according to information received today at the depot. Actual expenditures, or "directives" as they are called, totaled $475,254,053.11 for the first nine months of the current fiscal year, which began last July 1.

The words of Winston Churchill's Sunday evening broadcast are as brave in print as they sounded in the air: brave in facing unhappy truths, brave in the faith expressed in Arthur Hugh Clough's beautiful verses:

Urging amendment to the National Labor Relations Act to "restore the God-given right of every man to work without paying tribute to a labor union," Representative Howard W. Smith of Virginia told 200 members of the Chamber of Commerce of Queens yesterday that "90 per cent of the workers in the United States do not want to strike."

LONDON, Tuesday, April 29 -Royal Air Force planes, great and small, reached out during the daylight hours yesterday farther than ever over the Continent, bombing and machine-gunning their way through a broad sweep that included the German naval dockyard at Emden.

VICHY, France, April 28 -- When repatriations are resumed on May 15, eleven months after the great exodus of June, 1940, there will be 550,000 refugees in the unoccupied territory of France, it was announced today. Jews cannot be repatriated and there are still 250,000 refugees from the forbidden zone in the North of France whose return will not be authorized.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 28 -- The public health in America is a Federal and not a local problem, Jess W. Hair Lafayette, Louisiana president of the Society of State Directors of Health and Physical Education, said today before the society's annual meeting.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 28 (By The Canadian Press) -- The Hyde Park agreement will increase the effectiveness of Canada's war effort and assistance, but the self-imposed burden upon the Canadian people will remain as great as ever, Prime Minister Mackenzie King told the House of Commons today.
CANEA, Crete, April 28 -- Emmanuel Tsouderos, the Greek Premier, declared today that Greece's fight must be continued unflinchingly "in our little islands."

No opposition ticket having been introduced yesterday, which was the final date on which members of the New York Stock Exchange could bring in a slate rivaling that presented by the nominating committee for 1941, it is now certain that Robert L. Stott will be elected chairman of the Exchange at the annual meeting on May 12.
CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) -- A 7-to-2 victory over the champion Tigers -- their third straight -- gave the Indians a tighter grip on first place today. It was their fourth successive triumph.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28 -Yale today announced 180 awards for athletic competition during the indoor season. The list reflected a gain in the number of Winter sports squads and an increase in membership.

BERLIN, April 28 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's week-end speech received belated consideration in German quarters today, not only for what was described as the note of "gloomy resignation" read into it, but because it was regarded as a "limping" admission that allied Anglo-American diplomacy and military strategy had suffered a catastrophic defeat in Southeastern Europe.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 28 (AP) -- Major Robert Reece Neyland, University of Tennessee athletic director and one of the highest paid football coaches in the country, will report for active duty with the United States Army Engineers May 26. He will be district engineer at Norfolk, Va.

Gains of 10 per cent or more in sales during the second half of this year over the comparative 1940 period were predicted yesterday at the beginning of the annual convention of the National Association of College Stores at the Hotel Commodore.
ALBANY, April 28 -- The State has set in motion an expanded program of civilian defense, it became known today, under a vote taken Wednesday at an executive session of the State Defense Council.

Add to the list of films opening this week "That Uncertain Feeling," arriving at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. The comedy, which was directed by Ernst Lubitsch and produced by Sol Lesser, features Merle Oberon and Melvyn Douglas.

Many of the difficulties in which real estate men in New York City find themselves now were brought about by over-building in the past and not by acts of the city government, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick told a meeting of the Citizens Housing Council at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

A gift of $31,000 was handed to the British War Relief Society yesterday by the Jewish section of the Interfaith Committee for Aid to the Democracies at the formal opening of the section's new offices at 57 William Street.
In the raids of recent days there has been discernible a new pattern in the German war of bombs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- "More organizing and less reorganizing of the government's administration of the defense program was called essential to the promotion of national unity by Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, who spoke at a "defense clinic" and regional conference of the association here tonight.

Declaring that the medical and educational professions had a joint responsibility to the great group of persons of all ages who, as "border line" health cases, are neither ill nor well and who have not received sufficient attention, Dr. Josephine L. Rathbone, Assistant Professor of Health and Physical Education at Teachers College, urged yesterday that they be cured and taught good health for the benefit of the nation and the two professions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The C.I.O. American Federation of Hosiery Workers adopted a resolution today barring members of the "Communist party or of any Nazi, Fascist or Communist organization" from holding office in the union.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The British knew, said Mr. Churchill on the radio yesterday, that they alone could not send to Greece forces sufficient to repel the Nazi invasion. But there was "very real" hope, he continued, that British intervention would draw "the neighbors of Greece" into a successful line of defense.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -Arthur Bliss Lane, the United States Minister to Yugoslavia, reached Budapest, Hungary, today to arrange for a Danube ship to evacuate the about 200 Americans remaining in Yugoslavia, it is learned here.
DETROIT, April 28 -- Federal Judge Charles C. Simons of Detroit was elected president today of the biennial Council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. About 1,200 delegates are present.

The beneficent work that the tuberculosis and health associations have been doing in the last generation has robbed what used to be called "the white plague" of much of its old terror. Yet the alarming discovery that approximately one out of every hundred men examined by draft boards must be rejected because of incipient tuberculosis indicates plainly enough that the nation is not yet thoroughly aroused to the need of periodic physical examination.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes urged the Federal Power Commission today not to permit private electric companies in Northern California to "fester an uneconomic and archaic power market by constructing spite plants."

Suit to compel Bella V. Dodd as legislative representative and Robert K. Speer as president of the New York College Teachers Union to turn over minutes and other records of the union was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate the Educational System of New York State, known as the Rapp-Coudert committee.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- Bob Montgomery stopped Nick Peters of Los Angeles in the third round of their scheduled ten-round fight at the Arena tonight.
The time has come to call the roll. There are now only two kinds of people in this country -- those who are for the United States and those who are against it. There is no middle ground.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Negroes are entitled to Pullman accommodations and other first-class services equal to those which white passengers receive on railroad trains, the Supreme Court unanimously decided today, ruling in favor of Representative Arthur W. Mitchell, Democrat, of Chicago, the only Negro member of Congress.

Despite the earliness of Spring that brought many flowers to bloom ahead of season, the annual Narcissus Show of the Horticultural Society of New York opened yesterday at 598 Madison Avenue with a fine display.
BERLIN, April 28 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique said:
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 23:

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 28 -- The Japanese Minister, Tatsuo Kawai, commenting today on a warning by War Councilor J.A. Beasley that Australia should guard against a possible Japanese move following the Japanese-Russian neutrality pact, said Japan had no intention of acting against Australia by military force.

Our news columns yesterday had a summary of Adolf Hitler's conquests from Austria in March, 1938, to Greece at the present moment. It shows him master of fourteen hitherto independent states with an area of more than half a million square miles and a population of more than 150,000,000.

GRAND RAPIDS, April 28 -- Although the 1941 Spring furniture market sponsored by the Grand Rapids Furniture Exposition Association, does not open until tomorrow, 160 buyers registered today for the showing of Spring furniture.

Three developments at widely separated points indicate that the conflict just ended in Greece is to be resumed immediately in Africa in a struggle for the Suez Canal. The British have just taken Dessye, the last important Italian stronghold in Ethiopia. Free French forces are massing on the frontier of French Somaliland.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A bill giving the government broad powers to impose priorities and ration all materials needed for the defense program was reported to the House unanimously today by the Naval Affairs Committee.

Trading was good on veal hindsaddles and lamb, mostly fair to slow on other classes yesterday. Veal hindsaddles were mostly $1 higher; lamb, 50c to mostly $1 higher; hinds and ribs and pork were steady. The kosher market opened mostly 50c higher on lamb foresaddles, about steady on veal foresadddles and steer chucks and plates.

The Climax Molybdenum Company reported yesterday in its report for the March quarter this year a net profit of $1,844,925 after charges for depletion, depreciation and full provision for Federal income taxes under existing statutes and other deductions.

An attempt to reach the United States that started last month aboard a British vessel that was sunk by a German submarine when three days out of England, ended yesterday for Barbara Constantopoulos, a native of Athens, and Marian Dothwell, a British subject, when they arrived here aboard the Atlantic Clipper.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 29 -- A German air attack on a town on the southwest coast of England, which began late last night, developed into a heavy raid, according to reports here early today.

SUFFERN, N.Y., April 28 -- Three months ago the residents of this village, under the leadership of Anthony Cucolo, who came to this country many years ago as an Italian immigrant and worked his way up to a position of wealth and influence in the contracting field, decided to form the Rockland Volunteer Aid Society to help needy persons in the community who were not qualified for public relief.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The House refused today to sanction a "blackout" of Washington and vicinity, as training for the civilian populace against air raids, on the ground that it would add to an already serious traffic problem in an overcrowded city and would foment a "war hysteria."

General Medina Angarita, a soldier by training and profession, was Minister of War and Navy in the Cabinet of President Lopez Contreras, whom he succeeds. As Minister of War he visited the United States last year and received special attention from the War Department.

The British have just taken Dessye, the last important Italian stronghold in Ethiopia. Free French forces are massing on the frontier of French Somaliland.

"Berlin Diary: The Journal of a Foreign Correspondent, 1934-41," by William L. Shirer, has been taken by the Book-of-the-Month Club for July distribution. Knopf, which had planned to publish this chronicle by the Columbia Broadcasting System's Berlin representative on June 9, will fix a date later in June.

Officials of North Bergen Township, N.J., will consider tenders today on $15,015,000 of general refunding bonds bearing interest at the rate of 3 3/4 per cent. The bonds, to be dated May 15, 1941, are to mature serially on Dec. 1, 1942 to 1967.

LONDON, April 28 -- Australian sources were announcing today the evacuation of Greece by Imperial forces, but the British still maintained utter silence on the subject and are likely to remain silent until operations have been completed.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company and subsidiaries for the first three months of this year, made public yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $14,112,855. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 99 cents a share on 11,471,527 common shares, and compared with $15,428,237, or $1.10 a common share, in the March quarter of 1940.

HAVANA, April 28 -- Cuban Navy headquarters tonight announced the seizure of a small yacht, the Easygoing, flying the American flag, off the south coast of Cuba near Batabano on Saturday afternoon when the Captain was unable to exhibit the proper papers.

Awards were made by the Rotary Club of New York at the club's swimming classes for underprivileged crippled children at the Evangeline Residence swimming pool, 123 West Thirteenth Street, yesterday afternoon.

An ownership of close to half a century was terminated when the six-story loft building at 2 and 4 West Thirty-second Street was sold by the estate of Maria H.D. Polk to the Times Square Realty Corporation, Samuel Kaufman, president, in a deal reported yesterday by L.J. Phillips Co., brokers.

While Cornell's defending champions are setting the pace in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League, Yale, which is tied for second with Pennsylvania, one game behind the Ithacans, is on top of the statistical heap, according to the first official team and individual figures, released yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., April 28 (AP) -- The Bears strengthened their hold on first place in the International League by defeating Buffalo today, 4-1, to take a lead of two games to one in the series. The triumph was Newark's eighth in the last nine engagements.

After weathering a considerable budget of unfavorable news during which the stock market kept its balance prices moved moderately higher yesterday when it was revealed that steel operations had not been curtailed by the soft coal tie-up to the extent expected.
State rebuttal witnesses in the murder trial of William and Anthony Esposito gave testimony against the defense insanity plea yesterday in General Sessions Court, after the defense had rested.

Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court yesterday declared a mistrial in the case of George Joseph Cvek, 23-year-old hitch-hike robber, for the murder of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, Greek Sunday School teacher, because of articles that appeared in the Sunday issues of two newspapers -- The Daily News and The Bronx Home News.

The hope that Greece will regain her "rightful place in a future world of justice and freedom under the leadership of Great Britain and the United States" was expressed yesterday by Cimon Diamantopoulos, Greek Minister to the United States, at a benefit luncheon of the Near East Foundation at the Hotel Pierre.

Several million dollars' worth of diamonds, including a few of the historic jewels once the property of the French Crown, were previewed yesterday at Cartier's in a special exhibit that will remain open until May 17.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 28 -Mayor Frank Hague's campaign pledge to safeguard the residents of this city against an "invasion" was driven home graphically tonight when 1,500 policemen and firemen, members of the municipality's "disaster brigade," paraded through two miles of streets and past a reviewing stand in Journal Square.
BERLIN, April 28 (UP) -- The official D.N.B. news agency reported tonight that eight British planes were shot down today in a series of encounters on the English Channel and North Sea air front.

The hope that Greece will regain her "rightful place in a future world of justice and freedom under the leadership of Great Britain and the United States" was expressed yesterday by Cimon Diamantopoulos, Greek Minister to the United States, at a benefit luncheon of the Near East Foundation at the Hotel Pierre.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 -Sophomore Roy Talcott pitched his fourth straight victory for Princeton as the Tigers eked out a 2-1 victory over the barnstorming Duke nine on University Field today. Princeton collected only three hits off Bortz in the tight hurling duel, while the visitors registered five.

A total of $18,000,000 of the new Series E Defense Savings Bonds has been distributed to agency banking institutions in the New York Federal Reserve District, an increase of $3,000,000 over the previous day, according to an announcement yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, acting as agent in this district for the United States Treasury.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith and former Mayor James J. Walker joined in a WOR radio program last night to appeal for contributions to the Greater New York Fund's 1941 campaign for the support of its 400 private welfare and health agencies.

In an address to the nation tonight President Roosevelt will open the campaign to mobilize the nation's savings behind the national defense effort. Tomorrow at thousands of postoffices, banks and other institutions the new defense savings stamps and bonds will go on sale.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The United States is likely to deliver a substantial number of transport airplanes now in the possession of commercial airlines to countries fighting the Axis, it was revealed today by President Roosevelt. They would be delivered under the lease-lend program.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Sales of independent retailers were 12 per cent higher this March than in March, 1940, the Census Bureau reported today. The figure is based upon reports from 23,083 firms in thirty-four States in most kinds of business except department stores.

The final benefit cocktail matinee in the series held under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society for their fund for the relief of air-raid victims will take place Friday afternoon in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 29 (AP) -- Eugene E. Wilson, president of United Aircraft Corporation, announced today that 1,200 aircraft engines and 2,000 propellors a month had been delivered to the United States and to British agencies here for shipment abroad.

If the new constitution which has been proposed by H. Jamison Swarts of the University of Pennsylvania and William H. McCarter of Dartmouth is adopted, a drastic change in the set-up of the I.C.A.A.A.A. will take place. Announcement of the proposed new code was made yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive officer of the I.C.A.A.A.A.

JERSEY CITY, April 29 (AP) -- Hal Feldman, 21-year-old right-hander, stopped the Toronto Maple Leafs with eight hits today as the Jersey Giants salvaged the final contest of a three-game series, 9 to 3.

The General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $2,204,675 after expenses and charges. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.93 a share on the cor-poration's outstanding common stock and compared with a net of $1,771,617, or $2.51 a common share, in the twelve months ended on March 31, 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Largely as a result of the registration of $154,350,000 of installment certificates by The Investors Syndicate of America, Inc., $761,625,000 of securities was registered effectively under the Securities Act in the first three months of 1941, compared with $467,410,000 in the corresponding period of last year, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

VICHY, France, April 29 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, Vioe Premier, again has changed his plans and will not remain for the May Day fete of social peace in unoccupied France. Instead, it is learned tonight, he is going to Paris again -this time to confer with Otto Abetz, Adolf Hitler's representative, who is expected to return there from Berlin in possession of important proposals.

The seventh annual convention of the American Booksellers Association will begin Monday morning in Washington at the Willard Hotel with a promotional clinic. Tuesday will be given over to round table discussions on trade problems and a book and author night at which Carl Sandburg, Isabel de Palencia and others will speak.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The House Ways and Means Committee was asked today to let the individual taxpayer have that same deductible business expenses that are accorded the "gambling houses" of Reno, Nev.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The second successive award to Luigi Lucioni of New York of the "Popular Prize of $200," determined by vote of visitors to the Corcoran Art Gallery's biennial exhibitions of contemporary American oil paintings, was announced by the gallery today.

DETROIT, April 29 -- Rabbi George Zepin of Cincinnati, secretary of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which is holding its biennial council, was eulogized at an executive session today following the announcement of his retirement after thirty-five years with the union.

Starting next week, seventy-five New York City teachers, reported by their supervisors to be physically or mentally unfit to continue in service, will be called before the Board of Education's medical staff for examinations, Dr. John E. Wade, Acting Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.
Despite the frantic efforts of the hitters, the fielders and some 7,000 equally helpless onlookers, the alarming descent of the Giants continued in full swing at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Vast holdings of the Standard Oil Company of Bolivia, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), were confiscated by the government during the Presidency of the dictator, Colonel German Busch, on March 15, 1937.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 29 -- Virtually all members of the American colony in Athens, the remnant of a far larger body that had been urged by the legation to return home, remain in their residences in the occupied territory. Because of the prohibition on travel in belligerent ships none has sought passage on outgoing ships in the past few days.

A scrap of a hat achieved the same artistic level as a super-clipper yesterday when Lord Taylor gave its four design awards for 1940. Fifteen hundred guests at luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria applauded enthusiastically as checks for $1,000 were placed in the hands of Mme. Lilly Dache, Major Alexander P. de Seversky, Harold Van Doren of Toledo, Ohio, and Glen Lukens of the University of Southern California.

A program designed to maintain exports so far as possible under present conditions is being put into effect by the Westinghouse Electric International Company, export subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, it was stated yesterday by D.C. Brooks, market development manager, in an address at the annual meeting of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., at the Midston House.

Behind the fine hurling of Mike Santora, unbeaten in six starts, the undefeated Grover Cleveland High baseball team chalked up its tenth victory by downing Richmond Hill, 8 to 2, at Farmers Oval yesterday. It was the fourth straight Queens P.S.A.L. success for Cleveland.
