Under the chairmanship of Thomas E. Dewey the United Service Organizations will shortly make an appeal to the nation for about $11,000,000 to provide badly needed recreational facilities for the young people in military training, naval and defense establishments throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A registration statement to cover the issue of 58,710 shares of 4 3/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock with a par value of $100 each was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Wisconsin Electric Power Company of Milwaukee.

In New York Harbor, on an island close to the steamship lanes, stands the most famous statue in the world. It is not the most beautiful statue, but to many millions of passengers coming up the bay it has seemed to be. It stands for one of the dearest dreams in human history -- Liberty.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Louisville, Ky., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the issue of 780,792 shares of 5 per cent, cumulative, preferred stock of $25 par value, and for the reclassification of its common stock.

Denouncing the leaders of the United May Day Committee as representing "the fifth column in labor's ranks," the Joint Council of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes Union, C.I.O., with a membership of 50,000, rejected yesterday the committee's invitation to participate in the May Day parade being planned under its direction.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Further progress in growing embryos of living creatures in test tubes, shedding new light on the chemical processes of embryonic growth and development, and bringing nearer the day of the "brave new world," when children will be brought into the world by chemicals in glass jars, were reported here today before the annual Spring meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Professor Gregory Pineus of Clark University, Worcester, Mass.

ROME, April 29 (UP) -- Britain lost 285.000 tons of shipping in the evacuation of the British expeditionary force from Greece up to April 27, more than in the withdrawal from Dunkerque. Italy asserted today through the controlled Fascist press.

The Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $3,307,892 in the first three months of 1941 after Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, development costs and retirements, according to a report issued yesterday.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 30 (AP) -Koh Ishli, director of the official board of information, described today the new Atlantic patrol system of the United States as "but one step from war."
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Foreign trade of the United States in March registered a marked expansion in volume and value over the levels of recent months, the Department of Commerce made known today.
MOSCOW, April 29 -- Shipments of war materials across the Soviet Union were forbidden tonight by a decree promulgated by A.I. Mikoyan, Foreign Trade Commissar.

WHILE those who know more about it are discussing the Kentucky Derby candidates, this innocent bystander would like to point to a recent AP paragraph out of San Francisco, the first and last sentences of which were vastly amusing.
Both sides rested yesterday in the murder trial of William and Anthony Esposito in General Sessions Court. The case may go to the jury late this afternoon or early tomorrow.
I believe the weakest weapon in the English armory is the propaganda department. It has not found and utilized the darts that would touch and penetrate the German morals.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- With the object of obtaining a permanently balanced Federal budget, except in certain emergencies, a special Senate committee today offered a bill and two constitutional amendment proposals which would enforce the automatic imposition of taxes to meet annual appropriations.

The American Rolling Mill Company reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a consolidated net profit of $3,599,241 after depreciation, depletion, interest, amortization, Federal income and excess profits taxes. After allowing for dividend requirements on the preferred stock, the profit was equal $1.08 each on the 2,869,560 shares of $25 par common stock.

"Charley's Aunt" will bid farewell to the Cort Theatre on Saturday night. By that time the revival will have achieved something of a feat, a run of 280 performances for the Brandon Thomas farce, which has been flourishing for almost fifty years.

The last of the valiant Anzacs were evacuating the Peloponnesus yesterday as British soldiers, sailors and fliers prepared the natural stronghold of Crete as a base for offensive operations against the Germans.

The fact that individual transactions in department stores have not risen as sharply as the 13 per cent sales advance for the country as a whole since the first of the year would imply, may account for the small rise in department store newspaper linage, according to one suggestion yesterday in retail circles.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Increases in British deposits here offset heavy withdrawals of funds from the United States by most foreign countries, including Germany and Italy, in January and resulted in a net capital inflow of $21,996,600, the April bulletin of the Treasury Department revealed today.

Verne Marshall, Iowa editor who served as chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, announced the dissolution of that organization yesterday. He bequeathed its purpose to the America First Committee and kindred organizations that have taken the isolationist side in foreign policy debates.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The national defense savings program, designed "to give every person in the United States an opportunity to buy a share in America," will go into action Thursday, following a broadcast by President Roosevelt tomorrow night, a broadcast which will be rebroadcast over a special chain of foreign-language stations.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Associated News Photographic Service, Inc., and Blackstone Studios, Inc., both of 20 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York, and Leo Fried and William Shapiro, officers and principal stockholders, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease misrepresentations in the sale of photographs.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 30 -- Children, young mothers and the aged will be evacuated from Plymouth under a decision taken yesterday by the Ministry of Health and the Plymouth Emergency Committee. This victory for the German Air Force came while big guns of the German Army were hammering at Dover in the severest shelling of that city since last Fall.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 29 -- Racing to complete $600,000,000 worth of Navy contracts in record time, the New York Shipbuilding Corporation is virtually tripling the capacity of its shipyard here through a $12,000,000 expansion program now under way, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- The National Safety Council served notice tonight that the 1941 traffic death toll in the United States would reach an all-time high unless motorists applied the brakes of caution immediately.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 29 -- John S. Thorp, Democratic leader of Nassau County and Commissioner of Jurors, announced today that he had written to Governor Lehman asking that District Attorney Edward J. Neary, Republican, be superseded in his investigation into an alleged pinball racket in the county.

The executive council of the American Bankers Association met yesterday at Hot Springs, Va., and most of its session was devoted to a report prepared by the Economic Policy Commission of the association. The central idea of the report was that unless the nation is unusually wise and courageous, the defense effort will be financed by inflation, if, in fact the country has not already started down that road.
BERLIN, April 29 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this Lcommunique today:

Cotton broke away yesterday from its two weeks of indecision and dull trading and futures moved up sharply, with the new-crop months setting the pace. At the close, prices on the Cotton Exchange here showed gains of 13 to 16 points.

The general death rate for New York City dropped last week to 9.6 per 1,000 population, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was told yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department. This compares with an "expected" rate of 10.8.
Charles C. Auchincloss has been elected a director of the American Can Company to fill a vacancy.

The tie-up of the American Export liner Siboney, which forced cancellation of the vessel's departure for Lisbon last Saturday, spread yesterday to three other ships of the company and threatened to extend eventually to the line's entire fleet of two dozen vessels in various trades.

Even in real life virtue is occasionally rewarded, and "Texas Town" is a case in point. As acted last evening in an informal theatre at 108 West Sixteenth Street, it does considerable honor to a group of tenacious players dubbed the American Actors Company.

A plan to provide all the Army and Navy encampments throughout the United States with stage entertainment was disclosed last night by Billy Rose, night club impresario. The project, under the auspices of the Joint Army and Navy Committee on Welfare Recreation, is scheduled to start on May 15 and continue until July 1, when Summer manoeuvres are slated to begin.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A vague statute and a difference in thinking are responsible for an impasse in the defense program that has held up, it is estimated, more than $1 billion in new armament contracts. The statute is the defense plant tax depreciation, or amortization, law.

Evacuation of at least one-third of the civilian population of New York City is envisioned in a "war emergency" plan now being studied by the American Red Cross together with Army and Navy authorities, it was disclosed last night by Dr. William DeKleine, medical director of the American Red Cross.

It was standing room only for the program of Russian music presented by the American Russian Institute at Carnegie Hall last night. Every seat was filled, with 250 persons seated on the stage and a good many standees on hand to hear Paul Robeson, Benny Goodman, the Roth and Stuyvesant String Quartets, Vivian Rivkin and others, and throughout the evening there was unstinted enthusiasm.

A kindlier day when "no more stumbling blocks are placed in the path of the blind because the light of brotherhood will have spread through the air" was forecast yesterday by Helen Keller, blind author, in whose honor a dormitory has been named at the Jewish Institute for the Blind in Palestine.

ZOE AKINS'S first novel, "Forever Young,"* is a first-class piece of work. I don't imagine that anybody will be tempted to call it "significant," and some one, I am told, has already come out and called it "pretty thin." Well, maybe and possibly; but if this is thin and insignificant, then perhaps thin and insignificant fiction is one of the things we need.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey assumed the chairmanship yesterday of the United Service Organizations' national campaign to raise $10,765,000 to operate recreational service clubs in 300 centers for soldiers, sailors and defense workers.

Buzzing over the world's busiest airport like a swarm of oversized mosquitoes, forty-eight Piper Cub light planes that have been dubbed "Flitfires" put down at La Guardia Field yesterday morning to launch the day-long program of the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund of the United States to raise funds for dependents of R.A.F. members killed or disabled in action.
BERLIN, April 29 (UP) -- Germany warned the United States today that any attempt to convoy or carry war supplies to Britain could result only in the "rapid sinking of American ships."

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 29 -The formation of a committee of 100 that will begin immediately a campaign to obtain thousands of signatures in Bergen County to a petition to President Roosevelt urging that American naval forces convoy war materials to Great Britain was announced here today by the group's chairman, Mrs. Gordon Lamont, wife of the nephew of Thomas W. Lamont.

Stock trading broke yesterday out of its narrow confines and, with market sentiment bolstered by the end of the soft-coal tie-up, prices made some major gains, only to lose part of the increases in the last hour of business. While transfers on the Stock Exchange were the heaviest in three weeks, amounting to 511,990 shares, against 310,810 shares on Monday, activity was still restrained by the war news and tax uncertainties.

Two six-ton Army scout cars from Fort Devens, Mass., smashed through a wooden barrier inside the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday in connection with Port Preparedness dedication ceremonies and marking the resumption of work on the project.

HAMILTON, N.Y., April 29 -- A single by Bobby Wood, sophomore first sacker, drove in Harold (Bud) Bartlett with the winning run today and enabled Colgate to defeat Cornell, 4 -- 3, in one of the most exciting finishes seen here in years. It was Colgate's seventh straight victory over Cornell.

More men are being declared unfit for general military service today than in the World War draft, chiefly because of defective teeth, rejections for which are four times as high as in 1917-18, George St. J. Perrott, chief of the division of public health methods of the United States Public Health Service, said yesterday.
BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- Backfires and shifting winds saved the small town of Marlow, N.H., from possible destruction tonight as a forest fire swept both sides of the community but left it undamaged.

The body of Cornelius G. Vanderbilt Jr., 53-year-old head of Staten Island's largest contracting concern, was found floating yesterday in Richmond Creek on Staten Island three hours before he was to have appeared before a grand jury in answer to a subpoena issued in Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's inquiry into a $1,000,000 city-wide paving construction racket.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 (AP) -The league-leading Newark Bears completed their first home stand today by taking their third straight decision from the Buffalo Bisons in a free-hitting contest, 9 -- 7. It was the ninth triumph in the last ten starts for the Bears.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Organization of the National Science Fund, a foundation to receive and administer gifts for the advancement of science, was announced today by Dr. Frank B. Jewett, president of the National Academy of Sciences, during the second day's program of the academy's annual Spring meeting.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday that on March 31 it had net assets equivalent to $48.62 for each share of $3 convertible preferred stock, which is entitled in liquidation to $50 a share. This compared with $50.30 at the end of last year.

Record sales increases of 40 to 50 per cent over the previous year were chalked up in the first quarter of 1941 by major electrical appliances, such as refrigerators and ranges, figures released yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association showed.

Stockholders of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., at their annual meeting yesterday approved a readjustment in capital account through which goodwill, previously carried at $7,000,000, was written down to a nominal value of $1. In connection with this change the corporation's capital of $57,959,427, represented by 1,659,939 issued shares of common stock without par value, will be reduced to $41,498,475.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 29 -- If an opponent can be found to agree to it, Yale is going to give football back to the boys who play it for at least one game next Fall.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, April 30 -- A crowded day of formal calls and social engagements, highlighted by an air raid alarm, was passed here yesterday by Captain James Roosevelt following his arrival in Chungking in the morning by plane for a four-day stay in China en route to fill an assignment as military observer in Africa and the Near East.

Assurance that there will be no stoppage in the anthracite industry, affecting more than 100,000 miners, mostly in Pennsylvania, pending conclusion of a new agreement now in process of negotiation was given yesterday when the negotiating committee of operators and the United Mine Workers of America announced that the old agreement, which expires at midnight tonight, has been extended for ten days.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Another verbal attack upon Charles A. Lindbergh was made at the White House today as Secretary Stimson accepted his resignation as a colonel in the Air Corps Reserve.
Scoring his second victory of the meeting, R.C. Thatcher's Spanish Duke was up in a driving finish to annex the Class C Springboard Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

Trading was active yesterday on veal hindsaddles and lamb: fair to good on steer hinds and ribs and fair on pork. Hind and rib prices were steady; veal hindsaddles mostly $1 higher; lamb fully steady and strong; pork steady. Kosher market opened mostly steady on steer chucks and plates and lamb foresaddles but barely steady on veal foresaddles.

Operations of the Union Oil Company of California in the quarter ended with March resulted in a net profit of $1,273,006 after Federal income taxes, depletion, depreciation, abandonments and other deductions. This was equal to 27 cents each on the 4,666,270 shares of capital stock and compared with $766,148, or 16 cents a share, in the quarter in 1940.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -The Agriculture Department announced tonight that prices of farm products advanced 7 points between March 15 and April 15, indicating that higher consumer prices impend.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 29 -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden, speaking today at a rally in Town Hall to launch a 35,000,000 (Australian) war loan, strongly justified the empire's decision to help Greece.
ST. LOUIS, April 29 -- The Yanks got off in reverse today at Sportsman's Park, where they began their first Western trip of the season. The Browns, who had dropped six straight, beat them, 3 to 2.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,726,850 barrels daily, a decrease of 25,800 from the 3,752,650 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 17,550 barrels more than the calculation of 3,709,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for April.

CLEVELAND, April 29 (AP) -- The league-leading Indians finally broke out with the hits they've been hunting for two weeks and downed the Athletics in the series opener today, 8 to 3, for their fifth straight triumph.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19 -- Bordering upon Panama, now probably the greatest overseas defense position of the United States, and being one of our nearest South American neighbors, Colombia has a more immediate and vital interest for America than most of the countries of this continent.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -Earnings of Class I railroads, before interest and rentals, amounted to $201,503,219 in the first three months of 1941, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This compared with $115,903,566 in the corresponding period of 1940 and $173,060,112 in the same period of 1930.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 29 -- Local representatives and high officials of the Standard Oil Company are to be tried for "offenses committed against the security of the State during the Chaco war," it was announced today.

Members of the Democratic majority in the City Council moved openly yesterday against the La Guardia Administration's plan to put a county reorganization referendum on the ballot this Fall when they sought to block distribution of county reform petitions by city employes.

LONDON, April 29 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill took the bit in his teeth in the House of Commons today and asked for what amounts to a vote of confidence in the government's conduct of the war in Greece, the Middle East and "all other theaters."

A long range view of the Summer and its fashions was had yesterday afternoon at Altman's where, in the Charleston Garden, the store introduced the cream of its warm-day costumes. There were bathing suits ready for mermaids who want to swim or even those who don't want to go near the water.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- The House today approved the conference report on the $3,415,521,750 naval appropriation bill. In accepting Senate changes in the big Navy supply bill by voice vote, the House acceded to a Senate compromise amendment in the controversy over Argentine beef and Australian wool.

Sparked by Captain Mickey Rutner, who enjoyed a perfect afternoon at bat, St. John's University thumped the offerings of two N.Y.U. twirlers for thirteen hits at Dexter Park yesterday and handily achieved a 13-7 victory to continue unbeaten in intracity competition.

The Transport Workers Union called a strike early yesterday morning of drivers and mechanics of Jamaica Buses, Inc., inconveniencing the 40,000 daily riders of the company's three lines and taking company officials by surprise.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29 -- The national defense potentialities of Westchester County, only land approach to New York City for armed forces, was surveyed today by State officials, Army officers, industrialists and members of thirty-one Westchester defense councils, who made a ninety-mile tour of the county's terrain and shores and participated in conferences here and at North Tarrytown.

Most moderns are denied the joy of sniffing with mounting anticipation the wonderful aroma that drifts from an oven while bread is baking and the sheer delight of the first warm piece, on which the butter melts before it can be spread.

A preview of the midsummer and Fall hats, many of them marked by "patriotic" suggestions in the decoration, was given last night at the Hotel Astor for the benefit of British war relief. The showing was arranged by Bundles for Britain, Inc.
Wooldon Manor, one of the most imposing Summer places on Long Island, has been placed in the hands of wreckers for demolition to save taxes, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -Pierre S. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., repaid 10,000 more shares of common stock of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., worth around $1,400,000 at the current market, in February on a loan made in 1929, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt saw Dr. Isaac Herzog, Chief Rabbi of Palestine; Dr. Quo Tai-chi, Foreign Minister of China; William S. Knudsen and Leon Henderson. He lunched with Bernard Baruch and held a press conference at 4 P.M.

For three innings the Dodgers and Reds were locked in a tense duel at Ebbets Field yesterday. A first-inning homer by Lonnie Fray sent Cincinnati off to a 1-0 edge and excitement was in the warm Flatbush air. After that, however, all the tenseness vanished, though the excitement did not.

Colonel Lindbergh spent yesterday at his home at Huntington, L.I., working on a speech he will deliver Saturday night at St. Louis. This will be his first public appearance since his resignation from the Air Corps Reserve.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 29 (Canadian Press) -- New taxes and heavy increases to those now existing, designed to reach deeply into Canadian pockets to meet unprecedented war costs, were announced by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley in his Budget address to the House of Commons today.

Eighteen Bronx families, tenants in a ninety-six family apartment house at 3851 Gouverneur Avenue, were ordered from their homes and not permitted to return until 9:45 o'clock last night, following the breaking of a 48-inch water main at 5 A.M. yesterday at Sedgwick and Gouverneur Avenues.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 29 (AP) -- The British Middle Egypt General Headquarters issued this communique today:
BERLIN, April 29 (UP) -- German authorized quarters again today sharply attacked the Swiss press and individuals for anti-German statements and warned that "one day our patience will come to an end."

Net profit of the United States Steel Corporation in the first quarter of 1941 amounted to $36,559,995, equal after preferred dividends to $3.47 a share on the common stock. This was the best quarter since the final period of 1929, when $5.37 a share was earned, and the best March quarter since 1929, when profit was $42,185,447, or $5.04 a share on the common stock.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Light weight hogs declined 10 cents, yearlings and light steers were strong and fed lambs closed weak to 15 cents lower in today's livestock market. Swine prices continued their retreat dropping to the lowest price in more than three weeks In spite of comparatively moderate receipts.

BERLIN, April 29 -- The German drive to occupy all strategically vital positions in Greece continues. German troops whose job is officially declared to be the "cleansing" of the Peloponnesus are reported to have passed through Tripolitza in their drive to the south.

TOKYO, April 29 -- With special emphasis on Emperor Hirohito's glorious reign and military power, 100,000,000 Japanese subjects throughout the empire today celebrated his fortieth birthday with prayers and parades and with enthusiasm that was not dampened by heavy rain.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Buying of wheat was stimulated by reports that action would soon be taken on a bill providing for mandatory loans of 75 per cent of parity on this year's wheat and corn crops and carried prices up about 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.
The State owes August Heckscher a great debt of gratitude, and I feel that public attention should be drawn to it. People forget very quickly.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The transfer of additional American warships to Great Britain and a major increase in the size and speed of the country's $40,000,000,000 defense program were indicated today in speeches of governmental officials before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- The Phillies climbed out of the National League cellar today by defeating the Pirates, 6 to 2, as Bill Crouch turned in a four-hitter in his first start of the season. The setback dropped Pittsburgh from seventh to last place.

Another move in the procedure whereby the United States government is expected to take over the foreign ships recently seized in United States harbors was indicated yesterday when it was learned that the Coast Guard has been ordered to cooperate with the Maritime Commission in transferring sabotaged Axis vessels to shipyards for repairs.
BELVIDERE, Ill., April 29 -Circuit Judge William L. Pierce told an applicant for citizenship today: "If Senators Wheeler or Nye send literature to your house, tear it up. It's subversive."

WILMINGTON, Del., April 29 (AP) -- Payment of accrued bonus awards to certain employes drafted into the United States Army was approved today at the annual meeting here of stockholders of the General Motors Corporation.

Visiting buyers reported in the market last week numbered 794, as against 1,152 in the previous week and 646 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's buyer registrations were 313, which compared with 519 for last Tuesday.

MONROE, N.Y., April 29 -- Two years ago we contacted several farmers in this area who were considerably annoyed at the depredations of woodchucks and crows, so we returned to this section early this morning and set out with a stuffed owl, several profile crow decoys, a shotgun and the .220 Swift.
During National Employment Week President Roosevelt intends to direct the special attention of employers to the situation of many thousand workers over 40 who are being discriminated against.
ALBANY, April 29 -- Conservation Department officials planned tonight to ask Governor Lehman to close New York's forests if there was no relief from the forest fire hazard within a few hours.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 29 (AP) -- Georgia, Michigan and Ohio each won two of the ten "Pacemaker" awards in the Associated Collegiate Press competition for 1940, Professor Fred L. Kildow of the University of Minnesota, announced today.

New business of the International Business Machines Corporation thus far in 1941 is 166 per cent above that in the same period last year in the United States and Canada, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders by Thomas J. Watson, president.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- The White Sox rolled into second place in the American League today on Thornton Lee's seven-hit, 3-to-2 victory over the Senators before a scant crowd of 2,994.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 30 -After careful study of President Roosevelt's plan for a far-flung air and sea patrol wherever necessary, the British view expressed today suggests that United States fighting ships and planes soon will be operating in the North Atlantic spot where there is the highest mortality among merchant ships from submarines and raiders.

The new $2,550,000 Forest Hills High School, hailed as an architectural masterpiece representative of the forward-looking educational objectives of the New York City administration, was formally dedicated yesterday morning at ceremonies attended by Mayor La Guardia and representatives of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt has refused to reappoint Hugh S. Johnson, who headed the National Recovery Administration, the New Deal's first major spearhead against the depression, as a brigadier general in the Army Reserve Corps, it was learned today.

Now that the anthropologists have decided that America's original inhabitants came from Asia across Bering Strait about 10,000 years ago, they might take up another interesting problem. Among later arrivals, why are Italian names so prominent on the big league baseball teams and the Slavic names on the big college football teams, but not vice versa?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -Samuel Bronston, who has been inactive since he and James Roosevelt severed their partnership last October, signed with Columbia today for the production and distribution of his property, "Martin Eden," by Jack London.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A letter from the Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose of Great Britain thanking the young people of the United States for their aid to British children was made public today by Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, national chairman of the "Young America Wants to Help" organization.

BERLIN, April 29 -- The increased activity of the British Royal Air Force against the Continent apparently continues. Again today the R.A.F. is reported to have attempted raids on the English Channel coast in full daylight. The raids, however, according to the German report, were highly unsuccessful.

The board of directors of the American Association of Engineers recently passed a resolution directing the attention of the Federal Government to the serious results which may follow if immediate revision is not made to the Selective Service Act so as to conserve the use of the professional engineering talent of the country for essential technological requirements of the defense program instead of drafting it for routine camp duty.
BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- Sebby Sisti's first home run of the season, a drive over the left-field fence with two on base, today enabled the Bees to gain an eleven-inning victory over the Cubs, 6 -- 3.

The Greenwich House Camp Fund will benefit from the Carnival Quiz Party to be held tomorrow at One Fifth Avenue. Some of the contributors of questions in the various fields of the ten quizzes are Wendell Willkie, Alfred E. Smith, Mayor La Guardia and Ralph Ingersoll.

BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP) -- Crispin Oglebay's Preakness candidate, Ocean Blue, won the $2,500 added Rennert Handicap at Pimlico today by a nose. Coming into the wire, lapped on the outside of Mrs. A.B. Letellier's Handy Tom, the son of Blue Larkspur was declared the winner only after the judges had consulted the camera.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 30 -- Morning newspapers today quoted Cairo reports that 100 German Junkers-52 troop-carrying planes were at Benina, in Libya, and speculated that many others probably were ready at other Axis-occupied airdromes in North Africa, for a mass assault of parachute troops on the British forces defending Alexandria and the Suez Canal.

Assurances that ail ports in the United States are in "a liquid condition" were given yesterday to 150 representatives of shipping and affiliated organizations at a meeting sponsored by the steamship and railways committee of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, 80 Broad Street.

MADRID, April 29 -- During the last week the Madrid press has resumed its task of preparing public opinion for certain contingencies. Apart from the joy that the Axis victories are producing, one of the Madrid newspapers this afternoon prints a front-page article demanding the return of Gibraltar as well as the fulfillment of other "less well-known claims."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Resumption of mining will begin in the Northern Appalachian bituminous fields tomorrow after a 28-day strike shutdown, but efforts to arrange details for resumption in the Southern fields have thus far failed.

The Edison Electric Institute, which recently was required to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a service organization under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, has been notified by the commission that such registration will not open the way to regulatory supervision by the commission over member companies of the institute, particularly those engaged wholly in intrastate commerce, it was learned yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 29 -- British headquarters here related today the story told by the crew of a Royal Air Force reconnaissance plane that spotted a large number of German Junkers troop-carrying planes lined up on the Benina Airdrome, near Bengazi, in Libya, and subsequently attacked them.

TOKYO, April 29 -- The Japan Times Advertiser, Foreign Office organ, today presents what it calls "exploratory" peace terms to end the present war and establish a new world order and submits them for the consideration not so much of the belligerent powers as the United States, in whose hands, it says, lies "the momentous decision of war or peace."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- The high speed Blue Pair nipped Whirlaway in the mile Derby Trial Stakes today, but the "preview" to Saturday's Kentucky Derby didn't prove a thing except that Whirlaway still could come like the wind when able to steer a straight road home.

The Art Directors Club will open its twentieth annual exhibition of advertising art with a preview Friday afternoon at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition will be open to the public from May 3 to 24.

BUFFALO, April 29 -- A new test for diagnosing trichinosis in human beings was reported today by Dr. Ernest Witebsky, Associate Professor of Bacteriology and Serology of the University of Buffalo Medical School, at the 135th annual meeting here of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

Republic's musical, "Sis Hopkins," which will open at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's sole film newcomer. Judy Canova is starred in the comedy, which also features Bob Crosby and his orchestra, Charles Butterworth, Susan Hayward, Jerry Colonna and Katherine Alexander. . . .

Banks and dealers in foreign exchange received yesterday from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York copies of the Treasury's general license authorizing banking institutions in the United States, pursuant to the "freezing" order covering Greek funds in this country, to make payments from Greek accounts, provided the checks and drafts were issued before April 28, the date of the "freezing."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- The government amended today the warrant under which Harry Bridges, West Coast maritime labor leader, was arrested in February to determine whether he should be deported. It included a charge of membership in the Industrial Workers of the World and rested the case after reading into the record admissions which he made in the deportation proceedings two years ago as to I.W.W. affiliation.

The distribution to be paid on the City of Cordoba (Argentina) 7 per cent bonds due on Aug. 1, 1957, amounting to $15,712, will be at the rate of $6.57 for each $1,000 deposited bond, it was announced yesterday by the Bondholders Committee for those obligations.

OTTAWA, April 29 -- To meet an estimated total war and normal expenditure during 1941-42 of $1,768,000,000, Canada's 12,000,000 citizens were told today by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley, when he introduced the budget, that they would have to pay a more than doubled national defense tax and a more than doubled income tax in addition to many other levies.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 29 (AP) -- The United Gas Improvement Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that separation of gas and electric properties in the Eastern Pennsylvania and Delaware area would result in an increased annual cost of $1,577,369 to utility customers.

DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -- Old Lefty Grove's charm over the Tigers, whom he has beaten sixty-odd times over a stretch of fifteen years, failed to operate today and the Red Sox went down, 5 to 3, in the series opener.

WASHINGTON , April 29 -- Spokesmen for a group of American Federation of Labor unions in Atlantic Coast shipyards complained to President William Green of the federation today that as a result of the initiative by the C.I.O. Marine and Shipbuilding Workers Union they have no representation on committees to negotiate a zone agreement between shipbuilders and organized labor on the Atlantic Coast.
The Rev. George A. Stott, a chaplain of Auburn prison, told the First Eastern Regional Conference Chaplains Association here yesterday that the inmates of Auburn were not interested in religion.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt reiterated today his intention to extend the American neutrality patrol to whatever limits he deems necessary for the defense of the Western Hemisphere.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 30 -- An editorial in the conservative Svenska Dagbladett allows the controversy between the Swedish and Finnish press to be placed in its true perspective.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Representative Harry Sauthoff of Wisconsin, proposed today that the government print "tax stamps" in denominations of $1, $3 and $5, which would be sold through postoffices. Taxpayers then could turn them in on March 15 in lieu of cash.

CAIRO, Egypt, Thursday, May 1 -- British Middle East headquarters announced last night that 80 per cent of the original British Expeditionary Force in Greece had been safely withdrawn. [As the original force was 60,000 men this apparently means that 48,000 got out.]

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- While scolding Britain for her failure to supply adequate assistance to Greece, the Turkish press stoutly affirmed Turkey's friendship with the Allies today and said that any German threat to Turkey's independence would mean war.

Topics of The Times notes that "there are not very many private enterprises that compare for longevity with newspapers." Two outstanding examples among the few are commercial banks and fire-insurance companies, many, which are still in existence, antedating the oldest newspaper.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Dominance of New York underwriting firms in the flotation of securities again is indicated in a summary by the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the first quarter of the current year. Of the $405,324,000 of underwritten issues registered under the Securities Act, New York City firms in sixty-eight reported participations of $262,766,000, or 64.8 per cent of the total.

It was announced yesterday, following a meeting of the State Racing Commission, that the presence of caffeine had been found in the saliva test made on the horse High Blame, and that the owner, trainer and groom had been indefinitely suspended as a result.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 30 (AP) -- Back in the claiming ranks, Glenn Felkner's Advocator today accounted for the mile and seventy yards Revere Purse at Narragansett Park. Closest to this 7-year-old son of Sickle in the field of five was the Rivermont Ranch's The Rage, who trailed by a length.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- "Du Barry Was a Lady," the last of B.G. De Sylva's three Broadway musicals of the season to find a film purchaser, has been bought by Metro as a probable vehicle for Ann Sothern, and Albert Mannheimer has been engaged to adapt it to the screen.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced yesterday a moral victory in the British evacuation of Greece as Finland -- which fought the good fight last year only to succumb to the mass strength of aggression -- again came into the news.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 30 -- A survey of the present and potential social and economic resources of the State of New York which can be adapted to the purpose of national defense was made public today in a report of the State Planning Council concerning the activities of the Division of State Planning from July 1, 1940, to April 30, 1941.
LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 30 -- For the first time since the conclusion of the British-Turkish agreement Britain today has a bad press in Turkey. The ground on which a number of Turkish newspapers simultaneously begin to criticize the policy of their ally is the insufficiency of the forces sent to Greece.
Several private homes in Manhattan passed to new owners in deals reported yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., April 30 (AP) -- The properties of the Norfolk Southern Railroad Company, in receivership since 1932, were sold for $2,000,000 today to Carrol M. Shanks, reorganization manager of the new company which will operate the line.

Dividends declared in April by 873 corporations aggregated $208,384,003, including $5,185,593 for 121 banks and insurance companies. The total was the largest for any April since 1937, when it was $232,449,421 with 806 corporations, ninety-six of which were banks and insurance companies, authorizing dividends of $10,171,669.

The Friends of Democracy, Inc., informed Secretary of State Cordell Hull by telegram yesterday that a Nazi program of movie propaganda soon was to get under way in the United States. The telegram raised the question whether the government should permit the German films to be shown.

With emphasis on every phase of safety for New York's children, the Boys Athletic League, Inc., opened yesterday a four-day exposition entitled, "Safety in Recreation," in the large auditorium of the Church of All Nations, 9 Second Avenue. The lessons of safety held the attention of 500 youngsters at the first session.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 30 (AP) -- An official bulletin tonight denied a report printed in the Moscow Communist organ Pravda to the effect that 12,000 German troops, with artillery and tanks, had arrived at the Finnish port of Abe last Saturday.
BOSTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Cubs, who had dropped six of their seven previous starts, ruined the Braves' rechristening party today by belting three of their pitchers for a 9-4 triumph.
HONOLULU, April 30 -- American President Lines agents reported today that a Canadian auxiliary cruiser, the Prince Robert, had stopped the liner President Garfield and removed four German aviators.

Detroit, Mich., will be in the market on May 7 with $51,157,000 of non-callable refunding bonds, Series G, it was announced officially yesterday. Plans for the huge refunding program, which will be the largest single operation undertaken by the city, have been under way for months.

VICHY, France, April 30 -- Since Otto Abetz, Adolf Hitler's representative, has failed to return from Berlin, Admiral Francois Darlan, Vice Premier, postponed today his trip to Paris and was planning tonight to accompany Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, on his May Day visit to Montlucon and Commentry.
Thousands of evergreen trees and shrubs in the suburbs are withering and dying as the result of a combination of unfavorable Winter and Spring weather.

Heading the roster of film openings in Broadway theatres is Orson Welles's first production, "Citizen Kane," which will have its world premiere at the Palace tonight. Mr. Welles and George Schaefer, president of RKO, arrived by plane from the Coast yesterday for the premiere.

The Giants forgot to change the script. Again their pitcher bogged down for one big inning; again they came through with a late rally and again they lost. The Cardinals beat the New Yorkers for the second day in a row at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 6 to 4.

Exhibitors reported good activity yesterday at the conclusion of the exhibit period at the annual convention of the National Association of College Stores at the Hotel Commodore. Sales representatives of firms making automatic pen and pencil sets, notebook binders, stationery and college insignia made favorable comment on orders booked.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- James O'Neil, former West Coast publicity director for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today was sentenced to sixty days in the county jail by Federal Judge Harold J. Louderback on his plea of guilty to ignoring a court subpoena to appear as a witness in the deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges.
In connection with this discussion of war and convoying I should like to ask one question. Specifically, just what has Germany done to the United States that would justify our making war on Germany?

MOSCOW, April 30 -- Soviet Russia reported today that Germany had landed 12,000 troops with tanks and big guns in Southwestern Finland, within fifty miles of the Hangoe military base that the U.S.S.R. won in her conqueror's peace with the Finnish Republic.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 30 -- Serbian officers who took part in the resistance in the Strumitza Valley on the Yugoslav-Greek frontier say that the Germans employed sixty-ton tanks. How many has not yet been ascertained, but the number is described as "tremendous."

Irving Tell, lawyer for William and Anthony Esposito, pleaded in his summing up in General Sessions Court yesterday that the jury insulate itself against public clamor for conviction of the brothers. He asked they be found not guilty on the ground they were insane.

Six additional all-night schools offering national defense training courses to 2,000 trainees will open this evening, James G. McDonald, chairman of the Board of Education's special committee on defense training, announced yesterday. Two of the schools are in Manhattan, two in Brooklyn, and one each in the Bronx and Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- American business leaders gave a rising ovation today to a Methodist Bishop who called upon them to quit fighting organized labor, and applause to one of their own number who outlined a six-point program for voluntary cooperation of labor and capital as preferable to anti-strike legislation in meeting national defense emergency labor problems.

It is not new for Antoine, the coiffeur, to design hats -- he has done it often in Paris for his customers. It was, however, a departure for him to create an entire collection of hats and present them, as he did yesterday afternoon at Saks Fifth Avenue, to a group of style experts.

One can imagine historians of the twenty-first century studying, with the omniscience of historians, the state of this country in the Spring of 1941. Why, they will ask, did the richest country in the world hesitate and temporize when its continued existence as a free State depended upon united and immediate action?

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The grain markets opened on a strong note today, but the impetus faded with the session. Wheat was run up 1 1/2 cents a bushel and soy beans 1 1/4 cents in the early trading, but there was no zest in the buying, and the upturn was attributed as much to light offerings as to anything else.

THE rise of Rizzuto with the Yankees has added to the chatter about shortstops. There are some good ones around. The esteemed Casey Stengel might be pardoned for barking that he has the best with the Braves, the same being Edward Robert Miller, 5 feet 9, 165 pounds and owner of "a great pair of hands."

DURAZZO, Albania, April 29 (delayed) -- Ronald Ian Campbell, British Minister to Belgrade, and all members of his staff who left the Yugoslav capital shortly before the capitulation of the Serbian Armies, were awaiting here tday official permission for their repatriation to Britain by way of Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Cuba may get a loan soon, according to Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, Ambassador George S. Messersmith, Mr. Jones explained today, was here from Cuba and has been discussing Cuba's requirements with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The first direct experimental evidence that factors other than those directly involved in the transmission of hereditary characteristics play an important role in embryonic development was presented before the closing sessions today of the annual Spring meeting of the National Academy of Science by Dr. K.R. Porter of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, New York.

President Leonard Carmichael of Tufts College urges all highly trained American engineers, physicists and chemists to register with the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel at Washington, which is primarily concerned with supplying highly trained men to the defense agencies.

Shortages of sheets in single-bed sizes, the difficulty of keeping prices down in the face of unusually heavy defense calls on certain textile equipment, and the question of collection of inventory statistics by the OPM or by its authority will be among problems discussed at tomorrow's round-table on textiles to be held as a part of the conference of consumer-goods industries at Washington called by the Department of Commerce, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today at his press conference that he approved the new rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission that there must be competitive bidding by underwriters for issues of securities of public utilities and that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was prepared to participate in bidding for such issues if bankers could not handle them.

Net profit of the Standard Oil Company of California for the first three months of this year amounted to $4,799,184 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 30 -- While activities on the Libyan-Egyptian front were confined to patrol activities, British troops pushed ahead on various East African fronts. A force that had been moving southward toward Dessye, Ethiopia, left the main road from Asmara to Dessye and captured the Italian post of Socota last Sunday.

ALBANY, April 30 (AP) -- New York closed its tinder-dry forests to the public today, apprehensive of additional destruction from fires which already have burned about 25,000 acres at an estimated $60,000 loss.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30 -- The Assembly passed today a bill empowering the governor in council to grant permission under such conditions as he might deem advisable for the use of automobiles in connection with the work on the United States defense bases.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Bill Hasslinger's home run with the bases full gave Columbia a sensational ten-inning victory over Penn today, 13-10, after the Lions had staged a six-run rally in the eighth.

While net sales of $17,929,511 of the Douglas Aircraft Company in the quarter ended on Feb. 28 were 40 per cent above those of $12,920,905 in the same period the year before, net profits were only $15,000 higher at $1,819,535, against $1,804,877, the concern announced yesterday.

The management of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is considering a large-scale financing program which will involve issuance of approximately $150,000,000 of new securities, it was learned yesterday. More than $50,000,000 is expected to be used for new construction and expansion to meet the increasing demands of national defense on Bell System facilities.
The Faculty Club of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, will give a tea in honor of the new and retired members of the staff this afternoon from 3:30 to 5:30.

BUFFALO, April 30 -Stricter physical examination of America's Selective Service army to weed out those likely to break under the strain of military duty because of possible development of neurocirculatory asthenia, commonly known as "soldier's heart," was urged here today before the 135th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

Individual weaknesses cropped out yesterday in several selective issues, and the tendency in the stock markets quickly spread to the remainder of the share list, with final prices showing reductions of as much as 3 points. The session brought to a close the severest in-roads to values for any month since last May, while the month itself witnessed trading volume which was the smallest in twenty-three years.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Elimination from the military roster of all senior Army Reserve officers deemed incapable of active service because of physical condition, age and, perhaps, holding views believed prejudicial to loyalty was forecast at the White House today.
I heartily endorse your editorial exposing the short-sighted policy of the city with regard to the voluntary hospitals.

Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., has taken over the realty business of Capen Zerega, and John B. Capen has again become associated with the former firm, with which he entered the real estate business in 1924. John W. Zerega of the dissolved partnership is now with J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., woolen merchants.

The Museum of Modern Art, which seems to be eyeing the world of music with increasing interest, began a series of what it called "Coffee Concerts" last night. There was coffee, too -- hot coffee at intermission time, and if the warm weather continues, there may be iced coffee on succeeding Wednesday evenings.

LONDON, April 30 (UP) -- Britain's evacuation of troops from Greece was described today as even more difficult than the withdrawal from Dunkerque. In Greece the German Panzer divisions and air force blasted ceaselessly at the retiring British forces, heavily outnumbered, all the way from Mount Olympus to the Peloponnesus.

A painting by Jean Honore Fragonard, "Blind Man's Buff (Le Colin-Maillard)," brought $12,500 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the auction sale of the art collection of Mrs. Henry Walters. The picture was bought by a New York dealer.

BERLIN, April 30 -- The Greek campaign is now "concluded," it was stated in authoritative military quarters here this evening. It is believed the occupation of all strategically vital positions on the Peloponnesus by the German armed forces must be but a matter of very short time, if it has not already been accomplished.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 30 (AP) -- Realignment of the companies publishing The Minneapolis Star Journal, The Minneapolis Morning Tribune and The Minneapolis Times-Tribune, to "insure the continued existence of all three Minneapolis dailies," was announced today.

The Executive Council of the American Bankers Association voted unanimously yesterday at its annual Spring meeting in Hot Springs. Va., to make permanent the enlarged program of A.B.A. activities which was started last year, and adopted a resolution providing for a special assessment of $250,000 to carry on the work, it was announced at the association's headquarters here.

A memorable anniversary was celebrated yesterday in New York. On April 30, 1789, George Washington was inaugurated President of the United States in Federal Hall, Wall Street. He had had to borrow money in Virginia to pay his traveling expenses Broad Street and Wall Street were packed.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month continued dull and, although the volume of business was slightly larger than in March, sales were the smallest for an April in twenty-three years, or since 1918. Transactions for the first four months of this year were also the dullest since that time.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 30 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Hogs advanced 10 to 15 cents, cattle declined 10 to 25 cents and fed lambs closed steady to 10 cents lower in today's livestock market. Hog receipts were less than either a week or a year ago, encouraging commission men to hold out for higher prices. Efforts to regain all of the loss of the first two days in the week were not successful, however.

For the first time in New York State an employer was fined yesterday and ordered imprisoned for six months' for failure to comply with a court order of the State Labor Relations Board directing him to cease unfair labor practices in refusing to bargain collectively with his employes and requiring them to quit their union.

The percentage of net profit of large retail furniture stores in 1940 was considerably lower than that for medium-sized and small stores, although the net direct time selling cost was much less for the large stores, according to the annual report of the control and management division of the National Retail Furniture Association which was released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The possibility of a shortage of storage space for the new wheat crop is leading the Department of Agriculture to arrange for movement of upward of 80,000,000 bushels of government-owned grain from the Midwest and Southwest into eastern and gulf terminals.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- The Yankees went on a rampage today at Sportsman's Park and put the lowly Browns right back in their place. Irked no end by their defeat yesterday, Joe McCarthy's clubbers smacked Johnny Niggeling for fourteen blows and, in the gloom of a cloudy afternoon, won from the St. Louis club by 7 to 1.

The nation-wide sales effort for the new defense savings bonds will begin today. In this part of the country the Federal Reserve Bank in New York is the focal point from which more than 1,200 banking offices in this Federal Reserve district will sell to the investing public.

An investing client of Michael P. Curnin, Inc., bought from the Brooklyn Trust Company the four-story apartment and store building at 4702 Fourth Avenue. Brooklyn. The structure contains eight apartments and two stores, occupies plot 25 by 100 feet, and is assessed for $30,000.
Mayor La Guardia gave clear indications yesterday that he would not reappoint City Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill when he reappointed four other Magistrates whose terms expire today.

Francis I. du Pont Co. of 1 Wall Street, members of the New York Stock Exchange, will take over immediately the business of Granberry Co. Nine branches and no partners will be added to the du Pont organization. C.K. Reynolds, senior partner in Granberry Co., will retire.

George H. Williams of 81 Nichols Court, Hempstead, L.I., has been elected president of the Pre-Bar Association at the New York University School of Law, Dean Frank H. Sommer announced yesterday. Other officers of the student governing body are Leo Selesntck, vice president; Miss Paula Cholst, secretary, and Jose DeCapriles, treasurer.

Seven ships, six British and one Yugaslav, most of them carrying food to England, have been destroyed recently by Axis raiders operating in the Indian Ocean, marine circles here disclosed yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

Although "Somewhere in France" has been deferred to next season, the Theatre Guild will experience the novelty of giving three benefit performances of the play next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday nights at the Guild Theatre. Last week the attraction received three previews here before starting its tryout week in Washington on Monday.

May Day, the annual labor holiday instituted by the International Socialist Congress of 1889, will be celebrated here today by a parade condemned in advance, as usual in recent years, by many important unions and labor leaders who characterize it as an instrument of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- While his leaders in Congress were beating down all efforts to restrict by law the use of American naval vessels for convoy purposes, President Roosevelt ordered the acquisition by the Maritime Commission of 2,000,000 tons of existing merchant shipping, domestic and foreign, for operation "in such a manner as will make their cargo space immediately effective in accomplishing our objective of all-out aid to the democracies."

DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- The Tigers' batting power, in hiding most of this season, broke loose today to smash the Red Sox, 12 to 8, and carry Buck Newsom to his first victory after he had been beaten three times in a row.

Summarizing results for 1940 in the company's thirteenth annual report, J.T. Trippe, president and general manager of Pan American Airways Corporation, told stockholders yesterday that under the handicap of disturbed world conditions and enhanced competition from European lines in South America the corporation had completed the most successful year in its history and vastly improved its financial position.
Following is the transcription of the text of President Roosevelt,s address last night in connection with the defense savings campaign as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ALBANY, April 30 -- Governor Lehman, in the presence of representatives of retail merchants and consumer interests, today signed the thirteen Feinberg-Holley bills which are intended to reform the business of installment selling. The bills carry out the recommendations of the Conference on Installment Selling, in which business interests worked with representatives of the Legal Aid Society, the Russell Sage Foundation and the Better Business Bureau to end evils in the installment selling business.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- The White Sox, winners of four straight games by one-run margins, were headed for another close finish today until wildness in the eighth inning by Washington's pitcher, Ken Chase, helped them to four runs and a fifth-straight triumph. The score was 5 to 1.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- The Phillies rallied in the seventh inning today to score four runs and take their second straight game from the Pirates, 8 -- 4.

Three recently reported deaths in the Royal Air Force must have come home to at least a few American newspaper readers: the son-in-law of a well-known American author, Ernest Poole; the son of an actor who has his large following here, Lionel Atwill; the son of a witty English cleric, Dr. W.R. Inge, famous in happier times as the "gloomy Dean" of St. Paul's.

CLEVELAND, April 30 -- The fans were walking out because the league-leading Indians were two runs behind, had nobody on base and two were out in the ninth. But the Athletics never got that last man and the Tribe won, 6 to 5.

VICHY, France, April 30 -- Losses of the "unbeaten" French Navy in the war to date have reached thirty vessels, including one battleship and one cruiser, according to statistics published today by the Paris-Soir.

More than 2,000 babies who die unnecessarily in New York every year during the first month of their existence, can and will be saved in the future through the facilities of existing medical and health agencies, Dr. Leona Baumgartner informed members of the Child Welfare Federation yesterday.

The Down Town Glee Club. directed by Channing Lefebvre, gave its annual Spring concert last night in Carnegie Hall. As always, the accomplished ensemble of male singers was heard by a capacity audience, which left no doubt as to its hearty approval of the varied offerings on the elaborate list presented.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- The field for Saturday's sixty-seventh running of the Kentucky Derby shrank to eleven probable starters today while holiday bunting and pennants broke out on all main thoroughfares. Hotel lobbies were jammed and food and drink prices began their yearly climb as the vanguard of an expected crowd of 100,000 poured into the city.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 30 -- Army won from the Colgate nine on Doubleday Field today, 7 to 5.

The final step in the program announced by the Republic of Panama in April, 1940, in an endeavor to adjust its defaulted external securities and place its debt structure on a sound basis, will be taken today when the republic announces an offer to holders of its arrears certificates, which were issued under a service readjustment plan in 1933.
Day by day the ice is leaving the Northern New England lakes, and the next few days should see every important trout and salmon water in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont producing some good catches.

In an address on the present situation abroad Allen W. Dulles, attorney and authority on foreign affairs, last night suggested to the Young Women's Republican Club that it might be advisable for the United States to move into North Africa with troops and machines and to establish there a base from which to send future supplies to England.

TOKYO, April 30 -- The proposal that Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka should visit the United States in an effort to ease the tension in the Pacific received official cognizance today when Koh Ishii, spokesman of the Cabinet Board of Information, told correspondents at his press conference that he would approach the Foreign Minister himself to ascertain whether the latter was willing to make a statement of his own views on that question.

Mayor La Guardia urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to rescind its acceptance of a nine-acre park from the trustees of Sailors Snug Harbor on the ground that the organization had proffered the park site merely to avoid taxes and maintenance charges on its property.
The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company declared yesterday dividends of $1 each on the common and preferred stocks and announced its operating results for the first quarter of 1941.

A breach developed yesterday in the solid front presented for the last six days by two maritime unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, with the result that the strike against three vessels of the American Export Lines in Jersey City is expected to be broken and the ships released for sailing within a day.

BOSTON, April 30 -- The Boston Evening Transcript went to press at 3:21 o'clock this afternoon for the last time. The paper was 111 years old and its last edition run was 31,000 copies; the total for three, 35,500. Sixteen linotype machanes set 114 columns of news and eight more of the battery of twenty-nine set the type for the advertising.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, April 30 -- The British High Command, which is forever alert against invasion of this country, has learned new lessons about methods of repulsing any enemies who attempt to land in force in Britain as a result of large-scale exercises just completed in East Anglia.

LONDON, Thursday, May 1 -- While Plymouth was being attacked here, British bombers on Tuesday night made a raid in force upon Mannheim, key commercial and industrial city in Southwest Germany. A layer of incendiary bombs preceded many tons of high explosive bombs, including "some of the largest and most powerful types."

The statue of George Washington in the background and the history of the patriotic devotion of the first President to the cause of independence inspired pleas yesterday for the utmost aid to Britain and all possible preparation for the defense of the United States against foreign aggression at exercises on the steps of the Subtreasury in Wall Street.

BALTIMORE, April 30 (AP) -- R. Sterling Clark's Saguenay II, French-bred son of the imported stallion Aethelstan II and Precious Stone, qualified handsomely for next Wednesday's $20,000 added Dixie Handicap when he proved best of five topflight routers that raced a mile and a sixteenth in the Gittings Handicap today.

Conflicting viewpoints on the success of the recently enacted State law that permits children in the public schools to attend religious classes one hour a week during regular school periods, were presented yesterday at a special conference arranged by seven educational and civic organizations.

A group of invited guests, including Army, Navy and Marine Corps representatives, made a two-and-one-half-hour inspection cruise in upper New York Bay as part of the Port Preparedness Dedication program before the luncheon celebrating the Port Authority's twentieth year yesterday.
HARRISBURG, Pa., April 30 -- John L. Lewis charged here tonight that the defense administration itself, and not labor, was the "bottleneck" in the production of defense materials.

Were it not for a freak home run by George Byam in the fourth inning, Bob Anderson would have pitched the Fordham nine to a shut-out victory over the touring Blue Devils from Duke yesterday at Fordham Field. For that blow, a bounder through the infield that got away from the outfielders, produced the losers' lone tally as Jack Coffey's Rams hammered out an 18 -- 1 triumph.

Three leading steel companies reported yesterday their best first-quarter earnings in four years despite considerably higher taxes for the current year. The National Steel Corporation showed a rise in net profit of 37 per cent, the Inland Steel Company reported a gain of 49 per cent and the Wheeling Steel Corporation had an increase of 200 per cent, compared with the first quarter of 1940.

TRENTON, April 30 -- The New Jersey Legislature recessed today until May 19 after passing the $36,455,023 annual State appropriations bill and with indications of a new controversy developing between Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, and the Republican-controlled Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The American Navy needs every ship it has afloat at this time and contemplates no further transfers to Great Britain, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said at a press conference today.

The general belief that bankers are "stuffy" people may ring true when they are professionally engaged, but what they do in leisure time is far from dull as evidenced yesterday by the hobby show display on the tenth floor of the City Bank-Farmers Trust Company Building, 20 Exchange Place.

LONDON, April 30 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill reported to the House of Commons today that at least 45,000 men of the British Expeditionary Force had been successfully evacuated from Greece. He said they had suffered 3,000 casualties.

The clack of wooden shoes in the spacious lobby of Holland House gave notice yesterday of Dutch merriment that drew hundreds of office workers to windows overlooking the tulip-banked terrace on the second floor of 10 Rockefeller Plaza.
Baseball history repeated itself at Ebbets Field yesterday and the 21,148 Flatbush fans who sat in on the recording still were a little dazed as they wended their several ways homeward.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Roosevelt talked with Anna Rosenberg, Budget Director Harold Smith, Charles. Palmer, Administrator of Defense Housing; Maritime Commissioner Rear Admiral Emory S. Land and Harry Hopkins.

In the history of the Devon port of Plymouth is much pride, much power and much conscience. With it are associated the names of Sir John Hawkins, Sir Humphrey Gilbert and Sir Francis Drake. Our own Pilgrims left it behind for freedom's sake, but they loved it enough to christen in its honor a settlement far away in the New World.

As the Port of New York Authority celebrated yesterday the completion of twenty years of progress in improving harbor and transit facilities in the metropolitan area, Mayor La Guardia suggested that it now undertake the task of coordinating civilian defense preparations in the same zone.

William Oliver, 63 years old, who has walked 150,000 miles in Stapleton, S.I., delivering letters three times a day to stores and homes in the last forty-three years, retired last night amid a spontaneous ceremony that stopped traffic in front of the postoffice in the island's busiest community.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Senator Barkley of Kentucky, delivering the keynote address at a dinner tonight marking the formation of the American Palestine Committee, called for encouragement and cheer "to those who are manning the rampart of freedom which Palestine has become today."

Governor Lehman's action yesterday in signing a bill for the purchase of Knapp estate timberlands on the eastern shore of Lake George will be welcomed by conservationists throughout the State. Coming at a time when great stretches of the State forest preserve are threatened by fire, it will serve as a reminder of how precious are the woodlands that still remain to us.

Although the volume of the Spring book season is slacking off publishers have reserved a number of titles for the new month. Fiction will have a numerical edge throughout May, but among the titles in which the publishers exhibit most interest there are many books on today's issues as well as other nonfiction books on a range of subjects.

BERLIN, April 30 (AP) -- Ships traveling in the war zones defined by Germany "do so at their own risk and no distinction will be made between merchantmen and warships," Dienst aus Deutschland, a commentary with close Foreign Office connections, said today.

While about thirty of the scores of playing and yelling children in East Thirty-second Street near First Avenue -- as many as could possibly crowd onto the narrow window ledge -- put soiled, interested faces to the panes, a group of public, civic and church representatives formally dedicated yesterday afternoon the Nathan Straus Branch Library for children and young people.

WASHGINGTON, April 30 -- The Army and Navy awarded contracts totaling $6,562,251 today, including one to the Aberthaw Company of Boston for a dry dock at the Portsmouth Navy Yard which is expected to cost $2,500,000 on a cost plus fixed fee basis.

The opera company for young singers that Mrs. Lytle Hull plans to launch this Autumn will be called the New Opera Company, Mrs. Hull announced last night at a benefit concert for the enterprise which was attended by 500 persons at the Hotel Pierre.
Realty activity in Manhattan in which operators and investors participated yesterday was featured by the sale of a row of buildings in the wholesale produce district on the lower West Side.
CAIRO, Thursday May 1 (AP) -- A communique issued early today by the British Middle East command follows:

The 1940 pamphlet report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, made public yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, president and chairman of the board, show that the system had a consolidated net income of $5,403,290, compared with a revised net of $3,610,155 in 1939, an increase of $1,793,135.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Sales of wholesalers during March were 26 per cent ahead of the corresponding month last year, the Census Bureau reported today. This gain was the second largest over the year before recorded by the study since it was begun in 1936.

"MANY people," says James Burnham, "seem to be offended by definite statements about what is going to happen in human history. It is felt to be a kind of sacrilege. They say: Nobody really knows what is going to happen."

MADRID, Spain, April 30 -- The press, which yesterday embarked upon another meaningful campaign, suddenly abstained from all political comment today. The people of Madrid were left free to concentrate their attention upon new regulations drastically curtailing the amount of food that can be served in restaurants.

LONDON, April 30 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler will loose a mammoth pincer offensive against the Suez Canal within six to ten days from Libya on the west and French-controlled Syria on the east, the authoritative British Press Association said today.

ALBANY, April 30 -- State aid for public housing, both for low rental and defense projects, was increased today as Governor Lehman signed the Page and Thompson bills, both backed by State Housing Commissioner Edward Weinfeld.

Transfers of telephones from one address to another within the city during the Spring moving period from April 15 to May 15 will involve many more changes than were recorded during the same period last year, the New York Telephone Company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Permission to operate a service between Manila and Singapore in connection with its trans-Pacific service was granted the Pan American Airways today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Surety bonds amounting to $10,000,000 to cover work on the Panama Canal have been written by the Maryland Casualty Company, with the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company as joint originator, it was announced yesterday.

Adoption by the House of Representatives late on Tuesday of the Fulmer bill, which provides for non-recourse loans on cotton at 75 per cent of parity, inspired buying from all directions in the cotton market yesterday. All the active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange ran up to new high levels for the season, and the close was at net gains of 16 to 20 points for the session.

Eddie Arcaro left yesterday to ride Warren Wright's Whirlaway in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday after the unusual performance of booting home four winners at Jamaica. Arcaro capped his riding by bringing in Mrs. H.T. Archibald's Boston Man in the Class C Inquisitor Handicap, a race that saw the 1941 debut of Mrs. Parker Corning's 3-year-old, Attention.

Offerings of new securities to the public in April showed a sharp drop from the previous month and a year ago. Bond flotations were the smallest for any April since 1938, and stock offerings the smallest for the month since 1939.
Price advances on men's furnishings developed or were threatened yesterday in several cases. Final increases on glove prices came through, while additional rises on shirts and robes were predicted.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Bituminous coal operators of the Southern Appalachian area and officers of the United Mine Workers of America notified their representatives today to reopen the mines which have been closed by a strike since April 1.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Germany is strongly reinforcing her forces in North Africa, according to reports received here. The movement is of sufficient strength to lead to conjectures in official circles as to whether the next Nazi movement may be concurrent drives toward Suez and westward toward the Atlantic.

With every passing day the stand of the Senate farm bloc in demanding a record-breaking $1,340,000,000 appropriation for agriculture becomes more indefensible. The Senate farm leaders are insisting upon Government expenditures of $450,000,000 to bring farm prices up to "parity."
BERLIN, April 30 (UP) -- Authorized sources said today that "nothing is known here" regarding Moscow reports that 12,000 German troops with heavy equipment had moved into Finland.

At the first signs of Spring the chef begins to eye his cookstove with nonchalance. The artist who all Winter mounted eight-hour guard duty over steaming cauldrons of terrapin stew no wtakes his cue from the sunshine and devises a sparkling green turtle madrilene.

DETROIT, April 30 -- Acting to avert a threatened strike of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., which would throw 250,000 men out of work, many of them engaged in the national defense program, the General Motors Corporation made public tonight an offer to give employes wage increases totaling $15,000,000 a year.
