The suggestion that a responsible government agency call together a representative group of finance company executives and manufacturers to discuss the possibility of restricting installment terms was made last night by Arthur O. Dietz, president of Commercial Investment Trust Corporation.

LONDON, May 9 -- Today's announcement in Moscow that the Soviet Union would no longer recognize the Belgian, Norwegian and Yugoslav Legations causes some concern here largely because of the inclusion of the Yugoslavs.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 -- A thunder shower interrupted the Princeton-Cornell baseball game on University Field after five innings today, leaving the Tigers in possession of a 2-0 victory over the Eastern Intercollegiate League leaders.

At the height of the pedestrian rush outside the Empire State Building on Thirty-third Street yesterday morning at 9:45 o'clock, Stanley R. Korzynski, 27-year-old armed guard of the Burns Detective Agency, was kidnapped and robbed of a $6,084 payroll.

Officers and committee members of the fifteen units comprising the recently organized Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies gave a reception and tea yesterday in the Carlton Suite of the Ritz-Carlton for James Wood Johnson, who organized the American Ambulance Corps in 1939.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- The City Council at a caucus today by unanimous vote selected Drexel Co. and their syndicate of thirty-seven members to refinance $131,064,000 of Philadelphia municipal bonds. Two ordinances necessary for formal acceptance are expected to be introduced at the Council meeting next Thursday.
Sales of properties in the downtown area featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

LONDON, May 9 (UP) -- New American-built bombers and the biggest bombs were used by the R.A.F. in the assault that heaped 1,000 tons of explosives on objectives in Germany last night and this morning, it was stated here today.

While some spottiness was noted in retail trade here this week, the recent rate of sales increases over a year ago was fairly well maintained. Department store volume was estimated as running 8 to 9 per cent ahead of the comparative 1940 period.

The medal awarded by the Drama League of New York since 1935 for "the most distinguished performance of the season" was presented yesterday to Paul Lukas, who is appearing in the current prize-winning play, "Watch on the Rhine."

LONDON, May 9 -- The War Office announced today that, "in pursuance of the policy that younger general officers should hold principal operational commands," Lieut. Gen. Laurence Carr had been appointed Commander in Chief of the Eastern Command, succeeding Lieut.

A concert scheduled to be held at Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon under the auspices of the Associazione Combattenti Italiani, Federazione Stati Uniti d'America, the branch of the Italian World War veterans' organization here, for the benefit of the Italian Relief Fund, was called off last night.

Danger to British-borne commerce in the Indian Ocean, hunting ground in the last war of the notorious Emden and Seeadler, is lessened by the sinking of a raider believed to be the former German liner Hansa. Equipped with 5.9 guns, torpedo tubes and supposedly with mine-laying facilities, the Hansa has been preying on merchant shipping there, perhaps since soon after the outbreak of war.

Droll fellows, the dictionary-makers. There was Dr. Johnson, with his sly "Lexicographer: a harmless drudge," and here is the latest Webster defining Spring fever as "the lazy listless feeling which comes to persons with the first warm days of Spring," and waggishly adding, "Humorous."

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, who once ruled a $1,000,000 industrial rackets empire in the city, was arraigned in Kings County Court yesterday on a first-degree murder indictment arising from District Attorney William O'Dwyer's inquiry into the activities of the Brooklyn murder syndicate.

Following Wednesday's arrests of 151 German seamen, immigration inspectors and the police began yesterday afternoon a round-up of about 100 Italian aliens also charged with violating the immigration laws by entering this country illegally or overstaying their permits.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Increasing emphasis within President Roosevelt's Cabinet on the importance of assuring safe delivery of lease-lend aid to Britain heightened the belief at the capital today that a showdown is near on this important subject, known here by the word "convoys."

The American people are urged to call on the President and Congress for immediate enactment of six measures that admittedly "may lead to armed conflict" in a new statement of basic policy issued last night by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, 8 West Fortieth Street.

Interest in securities contracted further yesterday as plans for putting the nation on a more warlike basis were revealed in Washington. Foremost among the proposals advanced was the announcement that the Federal Reserve Board is prepared to conserve industrial resources and prevent inflation by placing a curb on installment buying of consumer goods, mainly such articles as automobiles and refrigerators.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 9 -- Rather than disappoint about 1,000 supporters of the organization's Class A Eastern League club here, the Yankees played an exhibition today against the Binghamton Trips and lost, 4 to 3. The struggle was limited to five innings.

The cotton futures market resumed yesterday its movement into new high ground and quotations on all months on the New York Cotton Exchange touched new peaks for the season except the May, which equaled its previous high. At the close prices showed net gains of 19 to 26 points, making the total advance in the last ten days 116 to 133 points, or $5.80 to $6.65 a bale.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 (UP) -- The Emir Abdullah of Trans-Jordan, pro-British Moslem leader, was reported tonight to have been shot and seriously wounded by his son, Talal, in a dispute over the hostilities in neighboring Iraq.

Plans for a pilgrimage of 1,000 women to Washington to ask the President whether he intends to keep his campaign promises of peace were completed yesterday at a rally of the newly incorporated peace organization, Women United.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 9 -- The Australian Government has decided to establish a squadron of fighter planes for the defense of Britain. It will be manned by Australian air crews and ground staffs trained under the empire scheme and will be equipped with Spitfires.

Warners "Singapore Woman" will open today at the Central Theatre. The melodrama features Brenda Marshall, David Bruce, Virginia Field, Jerome Cowan and Rose Hobart. . . . "The Girl in the News" enters its second week today at the Globe.

Maurice U. Schappes, suspended English tutor at City College, won from the Appellate Division yesterday a stay of proceedings brought against him before the Board of Higher Education until after the trial of a perjury indictment naming him.

From time to time Japanese fliers manage to bomb the Burma Road and Tokyo jubilantly announces that China's lifeline to the outside world has been cut. The reliability of such reports may be judged by the statement of John Earl Baker, American administrator of supply over this vital highway, that traffic in April broke all records and increased by fully a third.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in April amounted to $29,978,891,949, a decline of 1.5 per cent from the preceding month but a gain of 15.1 per cent over the returns in April, 1940.

The old notion of Hitler as a reckless gambler, acting on sudden impulses, following "hunches," is not borne out by the record. Why such a legend ever gained currency is puzzling, for since the beginning of his career in Munich he has suffered agonies of indecision in making up his mind to a course of action.

Sermons on motherhood and family life will be heard tomorrow in many Protestant churches that have followed a suggested program of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, centered on the past week as "Christian Family Week," with the aim of leading up to a new emphasis tomorrow on the celebrating of Mother's Day.

Since the landed cost on future imports of better hooked rugs from North China will be almost double what it has been in recent months, as a result of the latest manipulations of the federated dollar in Tientsin by the Japanese Government, importers said yesterday that they would confine most of their business in the future to lower grades.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 -- One subject on which virtually all sections of American public opinion are agreed today is that the United States should fight if Canada, close neighbor to the north, should be invaded.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Samuel H. Kress of New York gave away about $3,800,000 of S.H. Kress Co. common stock in March, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

ALL aboard for Baltimore. That's where the Preakness will be run today, rain or shine. The fun will take place on the old hilltop course, Pimlico, under the august sponsorship of the Maryland Jockey Club, to which an operating charter was granted by the Congress of the United States away back in 1830 when Andrew Jackson, quite a turfman when at home, was President of the United States.

YONKERS, May 9 -- The Rye Country Club, which defeated the Century C.C., 3 -- 2, and Knollwood, 5 -- 0, at the Hudson River C.C. today for 8 of a possible 10 points, climbed into second place in the annual women's Westchester interclub team golf series.
ROME, May 9 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

ALL books about Mexico by foreigners should pay three royalties: one to the author, one to Mexico and one to the foreign colony there. The reason for the first is clear. The reason for the second is obvious. The reason for the third is simply reasonable. What book about Mexico by a visiting foreigner could be considered complete if it did not contain a few pretty devastating remarks about the foreign colony in Mexico?
Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont forecast last night that some form of state socialism would evolve under President Roosevelt's national emergency powers.

LONDON, May 9 -- Reports of marked improvement in the situation in Iraq and the further heavy toll of enemy bombers over Britain gave encouragement to the stock markets today. The outstanding feature was a recovery in Middle-east Oil shares.

A capacity attendance of almost a thousand persons, including Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre, who was present as the personal representative of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, and delegates from forty-five Eastern Colleges, witnessed the opening performance of the Sophoclean tragedy "Oedipus Tyrannus" presented last night in the original Greek by a cast of forty students of Fordham College at Collins Auditorium on the campus.

Murray I. Gurfein, assistant District Attorney, spent three hours yesterday in his opening address to the General Sessions jury relating details, most of them heretofore concealed, of the bribery charges against William (Billy) Solomon, Tammany leader in the Seventeenth Assembly District, North, and Charles H. Mullens, former assistant State Controller.

In Topics of The Times you write about youth and a new faith to fight for. It's a vital problem -- not the faith itself but how to rephrase the ancient verities so that youth can see that they are worth fighting for.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Treasury's plan for a revised excess profits tax will be presented next week to the Ways and Means Committee, the chairman, Representative Robert L. Doughton of North Carolina, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Commitments by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation aggregating $1,634,449,340 to finance defense operations were shown today in a report made public by Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator.

A year ago this morning Germany invaded the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. She made no demands and issued no ultimatum. As late as Thursday, May 9, the Berlin propaganda machine was still trying to divert attention to "the crisis in the Balkans."

The Alcoa Steamship Company will ontinue to operate its vessels in' regular serzices between United States, West Indies and Canad/anl ports as in the past, officials aid yesterday in denying reports that twenty-five of its ships were to be turned over to Canadian companies under charter.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- E.K. Bryson's Joe Ray whipped two outstanding 2-year-olds today to capture the Pimlico Nursery Stakes over a muddy track.

It was a moist beginning that the ninth annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships had at Baker Field yesterday. With rain pattering and lightning flashing in the distance, varsity and freshman hammer throwers competed to clear the decks for the main show at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today.

The first public showing of large-screen theatre television, utilizing apparatus developed recently in the RCA Manufacturing Company's laboratories, was staged at the New Yorker Theatre here last night before more than 1,400 invited guests.

ROME, May 9 (AP) -- An official tabulation tonight of 98,928 killed, wounded and missing in April brought to 212,641 the losses listed by Italy's armed forces since this country went to war June 10, 1940. The totals were 20,251 killed, 50,413 wounded and 141,977 missing.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The National Defense Mediation Board labored unceasingly all day and met again tonight in an effort to adjust the dispute that threatens a strike involving 165,000 employes in sixty-one General Motors Corporation plants.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 8 (Delayed) -- American-built planes have been flown by both sides in the Iraqi conflict, according to Captain James Roosevelt, who arrived here this afternoon as a military observer for the United States Marines. He explained that the British were using new Tomahawk fighters, while the Iraqis had older American models bought before the war.

The official opening of the 1941 Daily Vacation Bible Schools in the metropolitan area begins today with the start of a training school for workers in these centers. The first session will be at the Friends Seminary, 226 East Sixteenth Street, from 9:15 A.M. to 3:15 P.M., today.

City officials and civic associations gave their support yesterday to the tentative plan prepared by the Borough President's office and the Park Department for beautifying Columbus Circle and reorganizing traffic into landscaped lanes and a pedestrian mall.

The time has come to ask whether, under the United States Constitution, it is lawful for the papers to print so many income-tax tables showing in parallel columns what we have been paying under the present law and what we shall be paying next year.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 9 -- Oil, copper and crude rubber are the essential raw materials which comprise the "trump cards in the hands of freedom," and the control of most of their sources by Great Britain and the United States constitutes a challenge to those who doubt the ultimate collapse and defeat of Hitler, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, declared here today.

Twenty thousand fur workers in the metropolitan area will receive wage increases averaging about 12 per cent under the terms of an agreement reached yesterday by representatives of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers and the Furriers Joint Council, a C.I.O. affiliate.

Quarters have been leased in the recently completed apartment house at 785 Park Avenue by Willis H. Taylor Jr., attorney and partner of Pennie, Davis, Marvin Edmonds, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., who also rented suites to Dr. Milton E. Eisen in 111 East Eightieth Street and Mrs. James C. Ayer in River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street.

At a special meeting of the governors of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, George P. Rea, president, read a twelve-page memorandum covering a plan for providing the dealer market with an interest in Exchange securities. After discussion, the plan was put over for further study.

A group of water-colors, prints and drawings, by artists of the New York City WPA Art Project, is on exhibition at the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, and will remain on view through July 7.
BERLIN, May 9 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Setting new Easter volume records in more than a few instances, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 26.2 per cent in April, in comparison with the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ROME, May 9 (AP) -- The British Fleet and Air Force, in an assault similar to their combined bombardment of Tripoli on April 22, shelled and bombed the Libyan port of Bengazi on Wednesday night, but caused few casualties and "unimportant damage," the Italians announced today.

VICHY, France, May 9 -- The creation of what is picturesquely described as "raw materials money," but are in reality coupons for the purchase of materials. was announced today by Henry Fayol, chief of the distribution service for the French steel industry.

SHANGHAI, May 9 -- The entire Netherland population, both official and commercial, of the Netherlands Indies are confident that they will be able to give a good account of themselves in the event of an outbreak of hostilities with Japan, according to reports reaching Shanghai from the islands.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in a four-to-one decision upheld yesterday an order of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins requiring the Southern Railway Company to make dividend payments "in perpetuity" on its Southern Railway Company-Mobile Ohio stock trust certificates, although the Southern no longer controis the Mobile Ohio.

Ability of the United States to survive the present attack on the democratic way of life depends on "effective cooperation" between the Administration, organized industry and organized labor, Dr. Carter Goodrich, Professor of Economics in Columbia University, declared last night at the annual initiation dinner of the Columbia chapter of Beta Gamma Sigma, national honorary fraternity of business school students, at John Jay Hall.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation reports for the first quarter of 1941 an estimated consolidated net profit of $4,880,020 after reserves, income and excess profits taxes at current rates, and all charges together with a provision of $4,212,094 for estimated prospective increased taxes and contingency reserves, equal after Class A dividends to 58 cents a share on 7,432,023 common shares.

James J. Rothenberg, chairman of the women's dress division in the Greater New York Fund campaign, set yesterday a quota of $48,000 for his trade, an amount 400 per cent greater than was contributed last year, and increased the contribution of his own firm from $150 to $1,000.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 9 -- Maurie O'Connor and Mike Cestone of Branch Brook, defending champions, today won the qualifying medal in the sixth annual New Jersey State pro-amateur golf championship. It was the third time the public links sharpshooters had taken the medal in six years.

In view of the fact that THE NEW YORK TIMES has the largest number of chess readers of any newspaper in the world and the coverage of chess news in the columns of THE TIMES is the most complete, accurate and interesting of any publication in the world, I submit the following matter of interest to chess readers:

Your editorial "Regardless of Race" has moved the Colonel Charles Young Post No. 398, American Legion, New York County, at a regular meeting, to resolve unanimously to send you a letter of commendation.

LONDON, Saturday, May 10 -- Early this morning the British Government announced shipping losses for April as 106 British, Allied and neutral ships, totaling 488,124 tons. [This is the heaviest shipping loss in any month of the war except that of June, 1940 -- 528,744 tons -- which included the Dunkerque losses.]

MOSCOW, May 9 (UP) -- Saved from death before a Soviet firing squad by the United States Ambassador, Laurence A. Steinhardt, a 23-year-old American girl will sail from Vladivostok for the United States tomorrow after being released from Moscow's Lubyanka prison.

The Pied Piper of the Bronx blew mellow notes on his bugle yesterday while he led 100 children between 7 and 14, dressed in multi-colored costumes depicting vegetables and animals, including a number of "rats" chased by a tyke with a flit gun, through the Bronx House at 1637 Washington Avenue, a settlement house affiliate of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and the Greater New York Fund.

For 5 cents high school students of this city will be able to see a special Decoration Day matinee of "The Doctor's Dilemma," which has a price scale ranging from $1.10 to $2.75 for afternoon performances. The Shaw revival at the Shubert Theatre, headed by Katharine Cornell and Raymond Massey, will be the initial production to be offered by the School Theatre Program.

It is interesting and somewhat pathetic to note that some of the profound sophistries advocating that America stay clear of the European conflagration emanate from teachers of philosophy in universities.

Warren T. Godfroy, 60-year-old attorney and former resident of Louisville, Ky., admitted in Federal Court yesterday that he had concealed taxable income of as much as $93,000 for one year, in filing his income tax returns for the years 1930, 1931, 1933 and 1934.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., May 9 -- Mrs. Gwladys Hopkins Whitney won a divorce from Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney on grounds of mental cruelty in Ninth Judicial Circuit today.

MANILA, Saturday, May 10 -- High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre said today that there were undoubted evidences of increased cooperation among democratic territories in the Far East since the visit last month of high British and Netherlands officials in Manila.

Groups of students offering petitions on both sides of the convoy question competed for signatures yesterday at separate locations in front of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue. Passers-by kept the student solicitors busy for more than one hour after noon, before the rain came.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Concern over hemispheric solidarity and a desire to avert any serious controversy between American republics has led the United States to join with Argentina and Brazil in offering friendly services to Peru and Ecuador for a final settlement of their century-old boundary dispute.

VICHY, France, May 9 -- That negotiations between the government in Vichy and the German authority are proceeding normally seems proved by the fact that Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, left for Paris this morning.

The trustees in bankruptcy of the Central Railroad of New Jersey have charged $3,249,666 for depreciation of securities held and $1,855,152 to cover certain other stocks and bonds held and advances made to profit and loss surplus, Edward W. Scheer, president, said in his report for 1940 issued yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday that the United States Conference of Mayors, of which he is chairman, had under consideration for action, when the defense and war emergency ends, a $3,000,000,000 rehabilitation program of public improvements.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 9 -- In a total defense against total war, disease is a national liability, Federal and State medical officials said tonight at a meeting here in which the coordinated work of the Westchester County Health Department was praised as a model for other communities.
LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Billy Soose became the middle-weight champion of the world by defeating Ken Overlin, the ancient mariner, in a fifteen-round fight at Madison Square Garden last night. At least, Soose received the decision and, after all, that's what they pay off on.

Industry returned to capacity operations this week as the shortage of coal was relieved, while both retail and wholesale trade remained unchanged, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Retail activity was sustained by promotions and a strong demand for homewares, while seasonal business was off slightly in a number of cities.

BALTIMORE, May 9 -- Can Warren Wright's sensational Derby winner, Whirlaway, take his second step toward the triple crown by victory here tomorrow in the fifty-first Preakness Stakes? This is the question which stirs all in Baltimore following the entry of eight horses for Maryland's greatest horse race.

Since we have finally been called upon to face the dangers that confront us, should we not stop trying to evade issues which have long been staring us in the face and look squarely into the teeth of the two alternatives set forth clearly and logically by Mr. Stimson?

Tenders will be considered on June 3 by officials of Montgomery County, Md., on $800,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated June 1, 1941, are to mature serially on June 1, 1946 to 1961.
Williamsburg and Greenpoint properties were taken by a number of the buyers in Brooklyn realty sales reported yesterday by brokers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- "Angels in Furs," by W. B. Courtney, which Paramount acquired in 1937 for Florence George but never produced, will be used as a vehicle for Dorothy Lamour, the studio announced today. Lester Cole is preparing the new scenario, which deals with a nurse in the Arctic who falls in love with an aviator trapper.

Mayor La Guardia carried the controversy with the Transport Workers Union over the city's renewal of contracts covering the employes of the unified transit lines into the union's own camp yesterday with the assertion that it was "almost unbelievable" that the T.W.U. had "brought" to the city contracts that permit an estimated 6,000 employes of the BMT and IRT divisions to work from fifty-six to seventy hours a week.

Elsie Anderson, soprano, made her third New York appearance in a recital given last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Her carefully devised program began with a classic group comprising arias by Bach, Handel and Mozart. It contained further the "Shadow Song" from Meyerbeer's "Dinorah"; French lyrics by Hahn, Boulanger, Auric, Fourdrain, Moret and Chaminade; a sheaf of German Lieder by Trunk and a final dispensation in English.

LONDON, Saturday, May 10 -- Royal Air Force raiders pounded Hamburg and Bremen Thursday night and yesterday morning in what the Air Ministry here termed the heaviest attack yet made on Germany. It was unofficially estimated that 300 to 400 planes carried out the assaults.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Hogs scored gains ranging to 10 cents in a moderately active market today as receipts fell considerable under a week ago. Shippers showed only a moderate interest in the swine market, but small packers were relatively active. Receipts of 10,000 head compared with 18,400 last Friday.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 9 (AP) -- One new meet record was established in the only event completed on the opening day of the annual Middle Atlantic Collegiate Association track and field championships on Muhlenberg Field today.

Stricken with measles, Helen Craig, star of "Johnny Belinda," has been unable to appear in the play since Thursday night, at which time her understudy, Valentine Vernon, stepped into the part. It was not known yesterday when Miss Craig would return to the cast.

For the first time in thirty-seven years members of the Actors Fund of America, which held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the National Theatre, in West Forty-first Street, elected a new president: Walter Vincent. The election of a new head was necessitated by the death last December of Daniel Frohman, who since 1904 had been president of the organization.

The Doctors Orchestral Society of New York, composed entirely of physicians, surgeons and dentists of this city, gave its third annual concert last night in Town Hall under the auspices off the Physicians Wives League of Greater New York. Fritz Mahler conducted and Mishel Piastro, violinist, was the soloist.

Trading continued active on veal hindsaddles, cow and pork loins. The demand for hinds and ribs was uneven, mostly slow to good, and the market uneven, steady to 50 cents lower on choice, strong to 50 cents higher on good. Other classes were mostly fair to good. Veal hindsaddles were mostly $1 higher, pork loins steady to 50 cents higher, cow mostly 25-50 cents higher, lamb hindsaddles mostly $1 lower.

With the arrival in New York yesterday morning of the American Mother of 1941, Mrs. Dens Shelby Diehl of Danville, Ky., the title, for the first time, became more than just a symbol of a one-day reign in honor of Mother's Day.

OTTAWA, May 9 -- Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario has forwarded to the Dominion Minister of Finance, J.L. Ilsley, a vigorous protest against the provision in the Canadian budget that imposes an increase from 5 to 15 per cent on income taxes derived by non-resident bondholders from investments in Ontario.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 9 -- Acting Foreign Minister Guillermo Rothe in notes to Peru and Ecuador has extended the good offices of Argentina, jointly with those of the United States and Brazil, to solve the frontier dispute that for more than a century has caused tenseness in Peruvian-Ecuadorian relations.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's Winter wheat crop would be 653,105,000 bushels, as indicated by conditions on May 1.

BERLIN, May 9 -- With the political-military situation in Europe in a temporary state of quiescence, the German press seizes upon editorial comments from many world centers for inspiration. Developments in the United States claim first place in day's news budget, and German readers are kept fully informed of the supposed state of the public mind there.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Defense contracts amounting to $22,785,845.83 were awarded today by the War and Navy Departments. Of the Army awards, only one, the largest, went to a firm in the New York area. Amounting to $1,781,107.20, the contract called for engine overhaul and maintenance parts and went to United Aircraft's Pratt Whitney Division at Hartford.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took today jurisdiction over the charges by fourteen stockyard companies for loading and unloading livestock.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Germany will unquestionably attempt an invasion of England, because she cannot win the war with England unconquered, Australia's Prime Minister, Robert G. Menzies, declared in an interview here this afternoon.

The four-story building with stores at 570 East 136th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York to the Caravella Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by the Mohr Realty Co., Inc. The buyer paid cash above a first mortgage of $20,000.

TOKYO, May 9 -- The Foreign Office announced today that a general commission under the Triple Alliance of Japan, Germany and Italy had met for the first time in Tokyo this afternoon under the chairmanship of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka and had "fully discussed questions relating to cooperation among the three powers under the Tripartite Pact."

Mrs. C.H.A. Armstrong of Toronto, official representative of the six Junior Leagues in Canada, reported yesterday at the last session of the five-day meeting of the board of the Association of Junior Leagues of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that the league members in Canada were sacrificing their leisure and prolonging their work day to maintain the league's community service program while answering the war appeals.

The Greek War Relief Association mobilized its resources yesterday to continue sending relief to free Greece with unabated vigor, concentrating its aid to the civil population of the unoccupied portion of the country by setting up an administrative committee in Crete.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today marketing quotas for twenty-four beet-sugar processors entitled to share in the 1941 marketing allotment of 1,589,100 short tons, raw value, of sugar set for the domestic beet area.

LONDON, May 9 -- The British now are hopeful that the backbone of Iraqi opposition has been broken. The Royal Air Force announced from Cairo today that Premier Rashid Ali Beg Gailani's planes were driven from the sky in a series of raids carried out yesterday.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 9 -- Pomonok, the Women's National second team and Plandome scored 7 points each in the opening round of play in the Long Island Class B interclub team matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

The Greek War Relief Association mobilized its resources yesterday to continue sending relief to free Greece with unabated vigor, concentrating its aid to the civil population of the unoccupied portion of the country by setting up an administrative committee in Crete.

A medium-priced group of canned vegetables, bearing a seal of approved from the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, is being introduced to us. Stamped with a registration number signifying that they have received a certificate of good quality, all of these vegetables have passed the standards set up by the Western State's Department of Agriculture and Markets.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- With Maurice J. Cannalonga, the elusive seaman still unavailable as a witness today at the deportation hearing against Harry Bridges, West Coast maritime labor leader, the defense offered testimony regarding the character of three government witnesses.

New York State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-nine municipalities aggregates $12,311,254, as compared with $64,196,365 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $41,380,283.
ROME, May 9 -- The preparation of the Italian people for America's entry into the war continued in the Italian press today.

A medium-priced group of canned vegetables, bearing a seal of approved from the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, is being introduced to us. Stamped with a registration number signifying that they have received a certificate of good quality, all of these vegetables have passed the standards set up by the Western State's Department of Agriculture and Markets.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- With Maurice J. Cannalonga, the elusive seaman still unavailable as a witness today at the deportation hearing against Harry Bridges, West Coast maritime labor leader, the defense offered testimony regarding the character of three government witnesses.

New York State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-nine municipalities aggregates $12,311,254, as compared with $64,196,365 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $41,380,283.

NEW HOPE, Pa. -- Members of the New Hope Public Health Association expect a record crowd for their second annual Open House Day on Saturday, when ten historic homes of Bucks County, in the immediate vicinity of New Hope, will be open to the public.

Sales of the new defense stamps and bonds have brought out both contrasts and parallels with the World War program of similar nature. On the earlier occasion, the stamps were not issued until December of 1917, seven months after the United States declared war.

A glance at the floor plan opposite the title page of this book will explain what the author means by "Too Many Doors." It is a plan of the ground floor of the house occupied by the head of the Crane family -- or perhaps it would be better to call it a clan, since it consists of brothers, sisters, nephews, nieces, cousins and in-laws.

'Teen-age boys looking for trouble, which in fiction means adventure and suspense, will find plenty of it in this story of a young fireman, and they will also find out a great deal about how a big city fire department operates.

MR. DOWDEY, who was born in Richmond, has for the third time taken the Virginia capital as the scene of a successful novel of the past. Returning to the vivid and vigorous realism of his first book, "Bugles Blow No More," he has written a readable, well-constructed and entirely credible account of the life of a man in the colorful Eighties and Nineties of the last century.

Your editorial of April 30, "Let Us Face the Truth," recognizes that this war is our war and calls upon us to act wholeheartedly. The means are clear: sinews of war delivered, if necessary, in our ships, under escort by our Navy, wherever they can best be used to stop Hitler from coming our way.
LAKELAND, Fla., May 10 -- Pending before the Florida Legislature is a bill to increase the number of grounds for divorce from nine to thirteen.

Brahms: Symphony No. 3, in F, Op. 90. National Symphony Orchestra conducted by Hans Kindler. (Victor, four twelve-inch records, $4.50.) This is Victor's feature album of the month. There is nothing new about Brahms's Third, but this is the first major work recorded by our capital's orchestra since it joined the Victor list.

BOSTON, May 10 -- For the first time since the American League pennant campaign got under way nearly a month ago, the Yankees wre stopped by the elements today. Rain continued almost until play was scheduled to start at 2 o'clock and forced a postponement of the game with the Red Sox in Fenway Park.

LONDON, Sunday, May 11 -- British fliers blasted at Mannheim, carried out a minor raid on Berlin and struck at other enemy objectives in Germany, Norway, the Netherlands, Belgium and France in a widespread series of air attacks Friday night and early yesterday.

SWITZERLAND has issued eight air-mail stamps illustrating some of her beauty spots. Values, colors and designs are: 30-centimes light blue, the Jungfrau mountain peak; 40c gray, town in the Valais Canton; 50c olive, "Le Leman" (Lake of Geneva); 60c yellow-brown, a view of the Alps; 70c violet, a glimpse of the Ticino valley; 1-franc blue-green, "Vierwaldstattersee" (Lake of the Four Forest Cantons, otherwise, Lake Lucerne); 2fr red-brown, Engadina valley; 5fr dark blue, Churfirsten mountains.

A preliminary authorization of $300,000 has been earmarked by the British War Relief Society to establish hostels for bomb-shocked and evacuated children in Britain, it was announced yesterday by Samuel A. Salvage, honorary chairman of the organization.

THE Metropolitan Opera last week finished the longest tour in recent history. In five and a half weeks it gave forty-one performances of twenty operas in ten cities and was heard by about 183,300 persons. Cleveland alone accounted for 67,000 during the week at the Municipal Auditorium there.

ROME, May 10 -- The British convoy that was reported in yesterday's war bulletin to have been attacked by the Axis Air Force near the Sicilian channel made up of eight merchantmen strongly protected by several warships, the Stefani news agency asserts today in a dispatch date-lined Tangiers.

The Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit will begin its tenth year next Friday when it opens its nineteenth show in the streets around Washington Square. As in recent years, the display this week will be under the patronage of the Washington Square Association, but, unlike the system in other Spring outdoor exhibitions, no prizes will be offered.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 -- Princeton beat a favored Yale track team in Palmer Stadium today, scoring its winning margin in the closing event, the 220-yard dash. The final score was 70 -- 65.
SWAN QUARTER, N.C. -- Diversified programs will be held in different parts of Hyde County today in commemoration of the 230th anniversary of the founding of the county.

Young women headed by Miss Catharine Reiley are serving on the junior committee for the performance of "The Doctor's Dilemma," with Katharine Cornell and Raymond Massey in the leading roles, on Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the Catholic Center for the Blind.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, May 11 -- The National Defense Mediation Board averted early today a collapse of negotiations in the face of a threatened strike of 165,000 General Motors Corporation employes, and succeeded in continuing the conferences.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, May 10 -- Four Ohio colleges are participating in a comprehensive plan of library cooperation. Officials of Mount Union College, Alliance, Ohio; Akron University, Hiram College at Hiram, and Kent State University, Kent, have agreed that the libraries of the four institutions will exchange information regarding their holdings of titles and cooperate in the expansion of bibliographical and source materials.

Visibly and audibly impressed with the size and modernity of the new Hunter College building, but refusing to admit that it could take the place for them of the building the school occupied when it was known as the Normal College of New York, twenty members of the class of '78 met yesterday afternoon for their annual reunion as guests of Dean Hannah M. Egan.

Despite everything that the communities are doing for the military forces and the defense workers, an "urgent and desperate" need exists for additional recreational and social facilities, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, national campaign chairman of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, reported yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 10 -- As the eleventh annual convention of the Hoboes of America opened here today, Jeff Davis, the 59-year-old king, was all set with a sheaf of resolutions to help America and a defense program for his fellow-members.
The fishing in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, seems to be improving every day, according to letters and telegrams covering scores of lakes and streams.

THE United States Navy is engaged in the most ambitious shipbuilding program ever undertaken by any nation at pence. Huge hulls of fighting ships are shaping quickly in their skeleton cradles, even as finished dreadnoughts and destroyers and other men-of-war put to sea months ahead of schedule.

LONDON, Sunday, May 11 (AP) -- Swarms of Nazi bombers hurling reprisal bombs on London for two successive R.A.F. attacks on Berlin spread wide patches of destruction and fire through the heart of the British capital early today in one of the most savage raids of the war.
THERE comes in every May that soft, warm and gentle day, a preview of Summer, when the only thinkable thing to do is to pack up a picnic.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- The Belgian Embassy said today, on the first anniversary of German invasion of that country, that Belgians still were fighting Germany from without and resisting by sabotage from within.

DETROIT -- Possible further reductions in car and truck output during 1942 under demand for an all-out effort of the automobile industry to speed production of bomber parts is not altogether unexpected here, although it is hoped that reductions will be less drastic than the 40 to 50 per cent suggested.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10 -- Army defeated Penn State in a dual track meet today, 66 1/4 to 59 3/4, stopped Harvard in an intercollegiate polo game on Howze Field, 11 -- 2, and turned back Columbia at tennis by 7 to 2.

WASHINGTON, N.Z., May 10 -- Reviewing the lessons learned in the Greek campaign, the New Zealand official war correspondent declares that New Zealanders, after their clash with the Nazi war machine, know they can master it if they get equal equipment.

NATIONAL defense and aid-to-Britain sidelights on activities of the automobile industry crop up constantly. Troops, equipment and kitchens of the Fourth Division recently moved 200 miles in ten hours from Fort Benning, Ga., to Panama City, Fla., in Chevrolet 1 1/2-ton trucks.

THE newspaper and the radio are great and fascinating instruments of communication. Particularly in these days of crucial and lightning-like events it is difficult to think them away from our daily lives.

A year ago yesterday, when Nazi planes and tanks suddenly roared over the frontiers of Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg, it was not merely the land defenses of those countries and of France that crumbled. There crumbled with them a whole world of comfortable illusions.

ALBANY, May 10 -- A conglomerate fleet of outboard and inboard speedboats lined the floating docks and runways of the Albany Yacht Club tonight. Some are shiny with factory newness, others are home-made, haywire outfits fashioned somehow in a barn or back-yard with earnest but unskilled hands.

NEARLY every one is pleased by the award of the Pulitzer Prize to Robert E. Sherwood for "There Shall Be No Night." As acted for more than a year by the incomparable Lunts with great skill and personal sincerity, that play expresses the convictions of an American man of letters about the gravest moral problem in the world today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Six government loans to as many corporations for the acquisition of defense-manufacturing facilities were announced today by the Federal Loan Agency and the War Department.

A REPORT from London last week stated that British Imperial Airways would resume bi-weekly transatlantic flights between Foynes, Ireland, and New York on May 23. Last year the line operated over the same route on a more or less regular schedule, usually carrying British Government officials.

The thunders of the conflict that began in Eastern Europe a little more than twenty months ago echoed sharply last week throughout the length and breadth of the United States. Americans debated the gravest issue that the war has brought: How far should the United States go in aiding Britain?

With the stock market making gains ranging from fractions to 2 points and closing at the best levels since mid-April, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that two seats had been sold at $27,000 each, up $7,000 from the last preceding sale.

A branch of income tax law which has remained constant since its adoption two decades ago is that dealing with involuntary conversions of property. If property, as the result of its destruction, seizure or condemnation, is compulsorily or involuntarily converted into money which is used to acquire other similar or related property to take the place of the old, gain or loss is not recognized beyond the amount of money not so expended.

BOSTON, May 10 -- With the exception of Boston University, all the favorites came through the qualifying round of the two-day Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's fifth annual national dinghy championships for the Henry A. Morss Memorial Bowl on the Charles River Basin today.

The national observance of Mother's Day is being celebrated in society here, as well as all over the country, with the divers personal expressions of sentiment traditionally used to pay particular homage to mothers on this day. Dedicatory church services, radio programs, parades, pageants and meetings will claim public attention; florists, greeting card and gift shops, the telephone and telegraph companies will receive their due share of patronage.

While issuance of non-reimbursement certificates by the National Defense Advisory Commission to defense contractors last week after a long period of delay was encouraging to business, engineers and accountants warned yesterday that the vagueness of the original, hastily-drawn legislation slows down the granting of these certificates and delays were bound to ensue in many cases.

THIS is not a war book. Thomas Burke, who knows his city so well and has written of it so tellingly in other forms than the historical and descriptive, has now turned his knowledge and talent to a vivid recreation from the Middle Ages to our own day.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Economics Bureau of the Department of Agriculture has issued a report that government crop-control programs have operated to the disadvantage of American growers and to the advantage of foreign growers of cotton in world markets.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 10 -- Grave developments last week in Syria, renewed pressure on Vichy for further concessions, notably in the French-African Empire, and a continued advance of British forces in Ethiopia have all banded during the past few days to knit the French-African possessions -- at least those not yet "conquered" by General Charles de Gaulle -- into a relatively compact group for their mutual protection.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Some backers of the Tobey anti-convoy resolution conceded today that it faced almost certain defeat and undertook to dissuade the author, Senator Tobey of New Hampshire, from pressing it to a Senate vote.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 10 (AP) -- Sixty-nine awards were presented to representatives of secondary and preparatory school newspapers and magazine staffs at the closing session of the eighth annual Scholastic Press Conference today at Lehigh University.

Cooperation will solve the problem of censorship. The press of this country set an excellent example during the World War. Requests were frequent, but I do not recall a solitary instance where one was disregarded or where a confidence was violated.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- For the first time since 1933 Pennsylvania defeated Cornell in a dual track meet on Franklin Field today, 90 to 45, doubling the score with point sweeps in four events and twelve of the fifteen first places.

JEANNE BEHREND, American pianist, who is also a composer, discovered that her music was unplayed "because of a general lack of interest in American music." It occurred to her that her own problem could be multiplied many times over and "that there must be plenty of good piano music written here."

Activity was fair in the wholesale market last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. While several departments were very busy, action in most lines started to ease off for Summer.

Cutting off a Manhattan rally in the ninth inning, the New York University baseball team managed to register a triumph over the Jaspers on the latter's field yesterday. Aided by two home runs, the Violet athletes slammed their way to a 6-to-4 victory over their metropolitan rivals.

"It is nice to think that in this topsy-turvy world there's one spot left where a little girl from among the ranks of the people can be crowned a queen," Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs commented yesterday as he presented the first prize award to the "Queen of Dolls" in Hearns Auditorium, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

About 650 college graduates between the ages of 20 and 27, inclusive, are to be enrolled in New York, Connecticut and Northern New Jersey in the special officer-training course which leads after four months of study to Naval Reserve commissions as ensigns.

TRAVEL Lines: Louisiana's pirogue race, highlight of the bayou district, where live the descendants of the original Acadians, will take place May 25. . . . The sixth year of so-called "dude cruising" aboard one of Captain Swift's windjammers starts May 19 (out of Camden, Me.), a month earlier than former year. . . .

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 10 -- Champion Giralda's Ulla, a German sheperd dog from Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge's Giralda Farms of Madison, N.J., gained her second best in show award today at the twelfth annual exhibition of the Delaware County Kennel Club on the Bryn Mawr polo field.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentine, May 10 -- The Argentine Government has decided to proceed immediately with the creation of the first nucleus of a mercantile marine by the "acquisition of all available ships at present lying idle in her ports, according to an announcement made today by, Marine Minister Rear Admiral Mario Fincatti at a luncheon organized by the Argentine Naval League.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 10 (UP) -Charles A. Lindbergh declared tonight that "the principles of democracy'' were denied to the American people in the 1940 national election and said he doubted that "any country in Europe has been less informed about the intentions of its government than we have been here in America."
DUBLIN, May 10 -- With the Battle of the Atlantic now assuming an intensive stage, Americans may ask themselves if there is any hope of Eire's abandoning her neutrality and opening her ports.

ONE of the more engaging subjects for speculation which this critic business periodically affords concerns the whys and the how-comes English melodramas almost invariably turn out to be such devilishly fascinating things.

BOYS and girls around town can bring their parents up to date on Norse voyages (and, incidentally, Greenland's place in the Western Hemisphere), now that the Brooklyn Children's Museum has installed a new diorama showing a Viking ship carrying Leif Ericsson toward America.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- Commissioner Edwin N. Atherton swung the Pacific Coast Conference axe yesterday in the toughest crackdown on record in intercollegiate sports.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System are about to square off with the Federal Communications Commission before Congress and the courts over the FCC's chain broadcasting order which is so subject to varying interpretations that James Lawrence Fly, FCC chairman, regards it as a 'tmagna carta," while Villiam S. Paley, Columbia Broadcasting System president, views it as the "first paralyzing blow at freedom of the air."

ANKARA, May 10 -- Suddenly and dramatically, with only the vaguest sort of forewarning, that indefinite and largely undeveloped area known as the Middle East again finds itself projected into public attention as a potential scene of another World War.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- To all Navy men at sea and ashore went word today that Secretary Knox had decided to call the $18,000,000 333-aere fleet operating base on Terminal Island in the harbor of San Pedro, Calif., "Roosevelt Base" in honor of the President.

Many younger members of society, comprising the junior and debutante committees, are aiding the executive committee headed by Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell, Mrs. Ellinger Warwick and Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour, in the plans for the dinner dance at the formal opening on Wednesday of the garden of the Ambassador in behalf of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc.

A series of forums on the papal encyclicals "De Rerum Novarum" and "Quadragesimo Anno." under the auspices of the Catholic Youth Orgnization, has been arranged to start Thursday. They will be held in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the encyclical of Pope Leo XIII on labor and the tenth anniversary of the encyclical of Pope Pius XI on reconstruction of the social order, both of which were published on a May 15.

MASON WADE, whose biography "Margaret Fuller: Whetstone of Genius" appeared last year, has edited a large volume of the writings of his heroine as a huge annex, to speak, to his distinguished life of a unique woman whose place in the American cultural scene had never been properly set until he put his hand to the task.

THIS book is both an expression of a lifelong interest and an account of the formative period in Amerian history. The world was moving from the handicraft age into the period when steam and water power were beginning to replace man power in industry.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 10 -- A Japanese proposal for the purchase of all tungsten ore produced in Bolivia is receiving "careful study," according to Edmundo Vasquez, Minister of Economy.

WASHINGTON -- President Roosevelt has acted to make a reality of a spectacular but difficult plan -the linking of the Panama Canal and the United States by road. Last week he asked Congress to appropriate $20,000,000 to finance two-thirds of the construction cost of the 1,550-mile Central American stretch.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 10 -- Syracuse's varsity crew nipped Cornell by two feet today, powering through to victory in the final quarter-mile in the semi-darkness that had settled on Onondaga Lake.

HAVING followed the tobacco road in all its ramifications, George Arents came to the logical conclusion and published a catalogue of the fruits of his journey. But it is not enough to have issued a monumental record of one of the world's most famous subject collections.

MELBOURNE, May 10 -- Australia is now the keystone of the British Commonwealth's supply system east of Suez. In a few months 170,000 Australians will be directly engaged in producing armaments, which is substantially more than was anticipated at the start of the war.

City College's Summer session, which was established in 1917 as an emergency war measure, will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary this year with a curriculum once again influenced by the war abroad and defense activities in the United States, it was reported last week at the college.

LYONS, Kan. -- After 400 years Coronado rides again in Kansas. The entire State has dedicated 1941 to celebrating the coming of the first white man to the heart of the continent. Almost eighty years before the Pilgrims landed at Plymouth Rock, Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, with a party of thirty picked horsemen, and a priest, Fra Padilla, crossed the Arkansas River on June 29, 1541, in search of Quivira, the fabled city of gold.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 10 -- The German order to clear the entire foreign diplomatic corps from Belgrade before the end of May is the first step in a characteristically thorough German plan to exterminate Serbian guerillas, seek out and destroy or imprison their families, eliminate the few remaining Serbian political leaders and unleash a ruthless anti-Jewish pogrom throughout Serbia, Bosnia and Macedonia.

A PORTRAIT by Sargent shows a majestically handsome lady under the sweeping picture hat of 1911 as the frontispiece and jacket decoration of this book. But in the book's first paragraph the children are being wakened before dawn to help load the covered wagons as the family begins its trek from a farm in Wisconsin to a log cabin on a bleak Minnesota prairie.

In his active 98 years of life, William Henry Jackson, Civil War veteran and first official photographer to the United States Army, has often dedicated his services and his ever-ready camera to many causes.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Brainard B. Rorison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ned S. Rorison, and Miss Pauline Bourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Bourne, all of Asheville, have been chosen as King and Queen to rule over the fourteenth annual Festival of the Rhododendron Gardens here the week of June 16.

Two State employes were called by the prosecution as witnesses yesterday in the Court of General Sessions at the trial of Tammany District Leader William Solomon and former Assistant State Controller Charles H. Mullens of Albany, accused of having accepted bribes in connection with the award of State printing contracts.

The seventh airline serving New York City at La Guardia Field began operations yesterday. Carrying Clarence D. Howe, Canadian Minister of Munitions and Supply, who was on a "routine" defense mission to Washington, a Lockheed Lodestar arrived at 1:05 P.M. after a two-hour trip from Toronto.

Cornell took a firm grip on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race yesterday, defeating Columbia, 7 -- 2, on the Baker Field diamond. Walter Sickles notched his fourth circuit triumph with a four-hit performance.

ROME, May 10 -- An important speech is expected to be delivered by the Pope next Thursday, which marks the fiftieth anniversary of the publication of Leo XIII's encyclical rerum novarum in which the Church stated its views on social and economic problems.

LONDON, May 10 (UP) -- The rate of destruction since Adolf Hitler's air and submarine offensive intensified the Battle of the Atlantic in March and April was placed by the Admiralty today at an average of 112 ships a month, totaling close to 500,000 tons, or about 6,000,000 tons per year.

Sponsored by the women's division of the American Peace Mobilization, some 150 women, walking in double file, staged a circuitous parade along the sidewalks from Twenty-seventh Street and Fourth Avenue to Forty-first Street near Broadway, yesterday afternoon in a pre-Mother's Day protest against American involvement in the Euro pean War.

THE American theatre is the only place where the case of democracy versus totalitarianism can still be fought in purely dramatic terms. The plays that deal with this struggle will go down in theatrical history as the valiant efforts of American playwrights to wring from their contemporary reality the perennial drama of human life.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -iyril ] ]Koag's eighth-inning double scored Mike Kreevich with the winning run today as the White Sox defeated the Tigers, 4 to 3, before a chilled crowd of 3,323 spectators, including British Ambassador Lord Halifax.
FIELDS with deep ditches; straight stretches of road with strong, imbedded poles or other obstacles which create narrow lanes; Home Guards everywhere. These things are in a picture of Britain today.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 -- Princeton's varsity crew today won the thirty-sixth race for the historic Childs Cup with an impressive show of speed and drive as the largest crowd in years thronged the green shores of Lake Carnegie.

WITH gigantic cloud formations rolling in from the West these days, the time for sunset photography has returned once more. Each day at all points along the horizon, when the sun is dropping from sight in a fiery crescendo of color, hundreds of striking picture possibilities are open to photographers.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 10 -- The annual award of merit, given by the Alumni Association of Stevens Institute of Technology for distinguished service to the school, was presented tonight to Dr. Franklin deRonde Furman, who will retire on Sept. 1 after having served forty-eight years on the faculty, the last thirteen as dean.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

One of the features of a series of events to be held during China Week, May 18-25, will be the recital by Lily Pons of the Metropolitan Opera on May 20 at Carnegie Hall, net proceeds from which will be donated to United China Relief. The benefit has been arranged by the China Aid Council, one of the seven member agencies of the parent organization.

LONDON, May 10 (Canadian Press) -- Arsenal and Preston North End played a 1-1 draw in the English Football League War Cup final at Wembley Stadium before a crowd of 60,000 today. The match will be replayed on May 24 somewhere in the provinces.
The use of convoys to protect shipments to Britain was urged yesterday by Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, who addressed the Eastern Regional Conference of the Union for Democratic Action at the Town Hall Club.

IN chronicling two decades of European experience as a free lance journalist and author Louis Fischer has pretty closely approximated the ideal of the impersonal autobiography. His story is filled to the brim with the interesting personalities and turbulent politics of Europe between two great wars, and the author keeps himself pretty much in the wings of the crowded stage which he is depicting.

An exhibition of the relief work of the Committee of French-American Wives-composed largely of French women married to Americans -will be held at the Committee of Mercy, War Relief Information Center, 435 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-sixth Street, beginning tomorrow and ending on Saturday.

Decca seems to have endless ideas for jazz albums. Who would think that Shakespeare could be brought into the fold? But here he is in Shakespeare in Swing (two ten-inch records, $1.05). There are four songs of the poet, set to music by Victor Young, and Bob Crosby's Bob Cats play them with snap, and Marion Mann does the singing.

Miss Florence Hoyt Bateson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Farrar Bateson of this city, was married here yesterday afternoon to Loren Curtis Berry, son of Mrs. Gordon L. Berry, also of this city, and the late Mr. Berry, in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

LEADING collectors and dealers from all parts of the country were bidders at the public sale of the first section of the collection of United States stamps, covers and reference material of the late Edward S. Knapp, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LORD HAW HAW delivered the technical radio introduction to Herr Hitler's 1941 Reichstag address. It was the propagandist's job to line up the countless stations, frequencies and broadcasting hours which the Fuehrer's speech would take up for almost twenty-four hours after the original document was delivered.

LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- A clue to Britain's discovery that German battleships were raiding recently in the Western Atlantic was supplied today in announcement of the capture by the Nazis and subsequent recapture by the British of the 8,046-ton tanker San Casimiro.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, May 10 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies commemorated today the "darkest day in Holland's History," the anniversary of Germany's invasion of the lowlands, in ceremonies throughout the archipelago.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Senators staged a four-run uprising in the ninth inning today, but the rally ended with the tying run on base and the Athletics took an 8-T decision. Tte loss snapped the Washington winning streak after three straight victories.

BEAR MOUNTAIN PARK -This vast woodland retreat, an unspoiled wilderness almost within sight of Manhattan's skyscrapers, is all set to receive what officials predict will be the biggest warm-weather crowds in the park's thirty-year history.

Five meet records were shattered and one was matched in the open competition at the third annual Boys High School interscholastic track and field meet staged at Boys High field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The fifteen-event program attracted 840 athletes representing forty-four schools.

UNION CITY, N.J., May 10 -- George E. Wheeler, Pittsburgh school teacher, captured the all-around title in the National A.A.U. gymnastics championships for the fifth consecutive year at the Swiss Turn Verein tonight.

"SOUTH STAR" is the first volume of John Gould Fletcher's poetry to appear since his Pulitzer Prize-winning "Selected Poems." If the latter are the record of his expatriation from Arkansas, of his European and Imagist days, then "South Star" is the spiritual diary of his return from the North Star to his home State, his family and the land of his childhood.

MADRID, May 10 (UP) -- The Falangist organ, Arriba -- now under direct censorship by the new directors of the Interior Ministry -- today abandoned its familiar concentration on Spanish domestic affairs to criticize the attitude of the British press toward Spain.

Plans for the dovetailing of the country's fire prevention activities into the national defense program will be outlined at a two-day convention of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, to be held here May 27-28 at the Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday.

THE Art Students' League, in cooperation with a committee of sponsors, has arranged an exhibition of paintings and drawings by the late Kimon Nicolaides, opening tomorrow at the American Fine Arts Building. The exhibition (continuing until May 24) was arranged to coincide with the publication of Nicolaides's book.

THE subjects nice people don't discuss in Hollywood are scarce. But there is one group of studio employes who have to struggle with more taboos than a Victorian maiden aunt -- they are the press agents. Their problem is that they must write and speak to at least five different audiences and impress all of them favorably without actually saying anything.

THE South Mountain String Quartet will give its annual concert Sunday afternoons, July 6, 13, 20 and 27 and Aug. 24, and Friday afternoons Aug. 1, 8 and 15, at the Temple of Music, South Mountain, Pittsfield, Mass.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 10 -- A nine-day, intensive, tuition-free training course to instruct plant supervisors and foremen in the selection and training of industrial personnel will be conducted from June 21 to 29 by four northern New Jersey engineering colleges.

RICHARD LA PIERE'S new novel about the Chinese might almost be classed as a thrilling adventure story. Certainly Lew Gan encountered a tremendous range of experiences in the fifty or more years between the day when as a small boy he came to San Francisco expecting to find the Golden Mountains and the time when his ashes in a tin container were returned to the Chinese village of his birth.

TOKYO, May 10 -- Japan has presumably paved the way for economic southward expansion by virtue of the Franco-Thai peace pact and trade agreement with French Indo-China. Now Japan is apparently concentrating on what is called here the "disposal of the China incident," which is the most important and most immediate problem confronting the nation.
MADRID, May 10 -- Arriba, organ of the Falange, today gave its comment upon recent events by intoning a hymn of hate against Britain.

ALTHOUGH there has been no falling off in the number of new exhibitions in the galleries, a decidedly lighter tone is evident in the rank and file of shows opening, if the score or more of events on this reviewer's calendar last week may be adduced as evidence.

IT used to be said that one of the troubles with American history was that it was written largely by New Englanders, who gave the story of the past the benefit of their personal prejudices. The charge had considerable truth to it.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 -- A three-run attack in the ninth inning gave Harvard's baseball team a 7-4 victory over Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on University Field today. Bud Waldstein yielded seven hits to the Tigers and Dan Carmichael was nicked for nine by the Cantabs.
The first women's national collegiate golf tournament will be held at the Ohio State University course in Columbus, Ohio, from June 30 to July 3, inclusive.

IT is worth while when there occurs a temporary lull in the varied and feverish musical activities of this center to look outside of New York City and see what the country -- or such small segments of it as can be viewed in a trip of a few days and hours -- is doing in music.

Sinking of 40 per cent of the ships carrying New Zealand dairy products to England via the Panama Canal and the United Kingdom has caused a "pile up" of undistributed food in storage "Down Under," William Goodfellow, managing director of Amalgamated Dairies, Ltd., of Auckland, said before boarding the Lisbon-bound Atlantic Clipper yesterday at La Guardia Field.

Friends and relations of brides ought to sit down and think before they go out on shopping trips looking for wedding presents. It is notorious that brides spend a lot of time during their first weeks of housekeeping trotting back to stores with various wedding presents under their arms, turning in fancy things they don't need for other things they do have use for.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today:

Negotiators in the maritime dispute over payment of war bonuses for serving in dangerous waters announced yesterday that the seamen had agreed to sign on three ships threatened with delays and that discussions would be continued tomorrow seeking a final settlement of the question without holding up important vessels.

THE PAN AMERICAN UNION at Washington last week supplied background information regarding the designs of Dominican Republic's "Estatua de Colon" (Statue of Columbus) 2-centavos and 10c and "Fortaleza Trujillo" (Trujillo Fortress) 1c stamps illustrated in these columns on April 13.

THE first semi-annual convention of the New York City High Schools Photographic Council will be held on June 7 in Macy's Little Theatre. John Hutchins and Alan Fisher will be the speakers. There will he in addition a photo quiz for those attending and a demonstration of the Kodatron speed lamp.

AS Winston Churchill begins his second year as Prime Minister of Great Britain and head of an empire which is at grips with attacking forces as that empire has never been at grips with any foe before, he is rapidly becoming almost a legendary figure for the British.

DESIGNED for the promotion of pedestrian safety on the streets and highways, "Steps to Safety," a sound film has been produced by the Motor Vehicle Department of New Jersey and is available for exhibition before adult gatherings. Governor Edison recently previewed the film, and predicted that it would be most helpful in the pedestrian safety campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Associated Shipbuilders of Seattle, Wash., notified the Navy Department today that it would return about 50 per cent of its original estimated profits on a $1,750,000 contract for converting a passenger liner into a troop transport.

VICHY, France, lay 10 -- The first anniversary of the great German offensive of May 10, 1940, finds former Premier Edouard Daladier and General Maurice Gustale Gamelin, former Commander in Chief, busily preparing their defense to the charge of being primarily responsible for the disaster.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A thirteen-story brick and concrete apartment building will be erected within the next 160 days to furnish home space for 200 of the workers at the navy yard at Brooklyn, under a contract approved today by the United States Housing Authority.

In spite of fire and Blitz, the journals of the two English gardening societies continue to arrive. Some flower shows have been given up, but London "carried on." The pages of the Journal of the Royal Horticultural Society and the Quarterly Bulletin of the Alpine Garden Society are as full of meaty plant information as ever.

Some of the city's children are acquiring early gardening habits and skills through the efforts of women's organizations and committees. Young gardeners who look upon a growing plant as a thing of wonder are learning to raise their own flowers and vegetables in tiny plots of soil atop a roof or in a sparse back yard.

FEW of the many refugee novels, written during the past eight years, will be remembered for their literary merits. Yet all of them will live as important documents, historically and psychologically, reflecting the misery and confusion of our time.

BERLIN, May 10 (UP) -- German air attacks on Britain last night were said here today to have centered around port objectives shipping in the waters around the British Isles and various airfields and munition plants. According to D.N.B., German reconnaissance planes late today reported that fires started over night were still burning.

The will of Joseph Pulitzer, the newspaper publisher, set aside a fund for the annual distribution of "prizes or scholarships for the encouragement of public service, public morals, American literature and the advancement of education." The trustees of Columbia University were made the administrators of the fund, and the advisory board of the university's School of Journalism, which Mr. Pulitzer founded and endowed, was charged with picking the yearly prize winners.

The Army's eleventh call under the selective service system marks the smallest quota for New York City since inductions of men for a year's training began last November, it was disclosed yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 10 -- Two men were asphyxiated this afternoon by poisonous gas in the hold of a ship that was being fumigated, one collapsing as he tried to rescue the other. They were Arthur J. Hanna, 48 years old, of 327 Oakland Avenue, West New Brighton, S.I., and Joseph A. Billings, 34, of 149 Grayson Place, Teaneck, N.J., president of the Steamship Sanitation Company of New York City.

A strip of four stamps on cover of "the renowned ten-cent 1847" from the Edward S. Knapp collection of Philatelic Americana was sold yesterday for 2,175 at the closing session of the first part of this large collection. The total for the eleven sessions held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, was $80,729.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Juicy, tender steaks can be made with an extract obtained from the osage orange tree, according to a patent (No. 2,240,518) awarded to John M. Ramsbottom of Chicago.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) -- The executive board of Carnegie Institute of Technology refused permission today for former Governor Philip La Follette of Wisconsin to address students Monday under auspices of the America First Committee on the grounds that no opposition speaker could be obtained.
