LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 11 -- Taking the first race yesterday, the second this morning and finishing third in the final this afternoon, J.L. Merrill's International sloop Feather, sailed by Bill Cox, won the James D. Sparkman Trophy, the opening regatta prize at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
CAIRO, Egypt Monday, May 12 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East command early today issued the following:

Expressing confidence in the ultimate victory of Great Britain in the war, Dr. M.L. Perlzweig, head of the British section of the World Jewish Congress and a member of the British Labor party, declared yesterday that newspaper reports giving the impression of imminent danger to Suez and Palestine and of their possible early occupation by Nazi forces were highly exaggerated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Negotiations for Jean Arthur to play the lead in Paramount's "Miss Susie Slagle's" reached final stages over the week-end. The studio disclosed that Sam Wood, who will produce and direct the film, has obtained her approval of the scenario, and that she will be available for the assignment under a one-picture deal independent of her Columbia contract.
ST. LOUIS, May 11 (AP) -- The league-leading Indians won the first game of a double-header from the Browns, 7 to 5, and were sailing along smoothly toward a twin victory today when trouble started.

MANTEO, N.C., May 11 -- You just can't discourage a surfcaster, it seems, for although the channel bass have not come into the beach north of Oregon Inlet, scores of anglers from various parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are now roaming the beach waiting for those copper-colored fighters to begin the inshore feeding.

Frank Bowden of New York, ranking favorite in the Brooklyn tennis championship, came from behind with a characteristic exhibition of sustained hard hitting to wear down and defeat Chauncey Depew Steele Jr. yesterday at the Knickerbocker Field Club.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Names of 592 Naval Reserve midshipmen to be graduated at the Naval Academy at Annapolis on Thursday were announced today By the Navy Department.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 11 -- Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America for two consecutive terms and fulltime salaried chairman of the association's public information committee, will relinquish both positions at the expiration of their respective terms this Fall.

LONDON, May 11 -- The stock markets continue to suffer from the extreme paucity of business which followed the Greek defeat, but the good tone prevailing the greater part of the week is a manifestation of the cheerful faith which permeates them.

Cotton prices continued to surge upward last week in active trading on prospects of an increased Federal loan rate for this year's crop. Both spot cotton and the active futures contracts adavnced to above the twelve-cent level for the first time since the 1936-37 season.

With the strike at the shipyards of the San Francisco area constituting a major handicap to defense production, there were twenty-four other strikes in progress in the nation, according to a round-up last night by The United Press. The number of workers idle was put at 40,000.
I could not help thinking back a few years, after reading your article apropos the reduction to France in the cost of occupation by the Germans.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 10 (AP) -Newark and Syracuse split a doubleheader today and each lost a player through injury. Frank Secory, hard-hitting outfielder of the Chiefs, fractured his right leg sliding home as his team was winning the opening game, 7 to 1, and Ed Levy, big first baseman of the Bears, suffered a broken wrist while Newark was taking the nightcap, 2 to 0.

BOSTON, May 11 -- For past indignities suffered at the hands of the Yankees the Red Sox got a full measure of revenge today when the ex-champions paid their first visit of the year to Fenway Park. Tom Yawkey's hired hands really gave the Bronx clan a going over, while 34,000 fans chortled with glee.

A year of destructive warfare has passed. The inauguration by the Nazi forces of the invasion of the Low Countries of Western Europe dealt the stock market a stunning blow, after which the market evidenced some recuperative powers, but after twelve months of juggling the share list has relapsed to the approximate levels of last mid-May.

The American Citizenship Committee of the New York County Lawyers Association urges all citizens and institutions to display the American flag on May 18, which is being observed throughout the country as "I am an American Day."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 11 -- Timid youngsters fondled snakes, falcons, hawks and owls, more intrepid ones played with a skunk, and camera enthusiasts of all ages had a field day today when the Trailside Museum staged its first animal show of the season on the lawn of the Bear Mountain Inn.

HANOVER, N.H., May 11 -- Dr. Zeeb Gilman, oldest living graduate of Dartmouth College and Columbia Medical School, and also a veteran of the Civil War, will celebrate his 100th birthday at Redlands, Calif., Tuesday.
LONDON, Monday, May 12 -- The sun rose red over London yesterday after one of the worst air raids that London had experienced.

MADRID, Monday, May 12 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco early today named General Carlos Asensio Cabanillas as Chief of the General Staff of Spain's Army, replacing General Carlos Martinez Cantas Serran in a series of nine changes among the highest army posts.

Representative Hancock of New York would have Thanksgiving Day fall by law on the fourth Monday of November each year throughout the land. His optimism is commendable; his constituents will feel cheered no end to know that some one in this troubled world is confident of blessings to be thankful for in the years to come. Nevertheless, the proposal startles.

The report of the New York Central Railroad Company for the first three months of this year, released for publication today, shows a net income of $6,383,656 after taxes and charges, equal to 99 cents each on the 6,447,413 capital shares. For the same period last year the company reported a deficit of 8527,616.
Barring a hardening in the Argentine peso and an upturn in the Chinese currencies, business in the other foreign documents passed over without incident last week.

After a declaration by Senator D. Worth Clark of Idaho, a non-interventionist, that war is a racket devised by racketeers and a plea for tolerance between isolationists and interventionists, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that racketeering must be destroyed and that the United States could hot let any country, no matter how powerful, come within striking distance of our shores.

Despite the blockade and a shortage of shipping, refugees from war and oppression abroad continued to find refuge in lands overseas in the first three months of 1941, it is pointed out in the quarterly report of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society made public yesterday.

IT was no surprise to find a big football man, Earle (Greasy) Neale, peering intently at a big league baseball game. Greasy is, at the moment, the new coach of the refeathered Philadelphia Eagles of the professional football circuit. He has a wide football background. He was a corking player and later coach at West Virginia Wesleyan. He coached a W. and J. squad that went to the Rose Bowl and got a tie.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 11 -- Cornell psychologists stated today that they had found the solution of what constitutes the so-called "sixth sense" in the blind which enables them to avoid obstacles. The blind avoid obstacles through the sense of hearing, according to the psychologists.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Senator Byrd, Democrat, asked today that the government make public figures on the dollar value of lease-lend supplies sunk on their way to Britain.
CHUNGKING, China, May 11 (AP) -- Heavy fighting continues in Central China, where the Japanese have thrown 10,000 troops into an offensive on the Honan-Hupeh border, Chinese reports said today.

PANAMA, May 11 -- A contract has been awarded to Panama Constructors, Inc., for excavation for the third set of locks at the Pacific end of the Panama Canal for $22,436,086. It was signed yesterday by Lieut. Col. Thomas B. Larkin, supervising engineer, in the office of Governor Edgerton.

BERLIN, May 11 (AP) -- In swift reply to the wave of admittedly destructive R.A.F. raids on Berlin, Hamburg and other cities, Nazi airmen began pounding London at twilight Saturday and kept it up by the light of a bright moon until dawn today, the official news agency D.N.B. asserted.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 11 -- For his initial title-winning achievement in two seasons of trapshooting, Mahlon F. Schwar today captured top honors in the distance handicap contest, concluding event of the thirty-sixth annual national amateur championships held on the New York Athletic Club's picturesque Travers Island layout.
PITTSBURGH, May 11 (AP) -- Ira Hutchinson turned in a fine relief pitching chore today and guided the Cardinals to a 7-4 victory over the Pirates.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 11 -- Maurrie O'Connor and Mike Cestone of Branch Brook successfully defended their New Jersey State pro-amateur golf championship at the Montclair Golf Club today when they defeated Vic Ghezzi and Walter Jacobs of Deal, 2 and 1, in the final.

The thought expressed in your editorial "When to Convoy" is timely. It is reckless gambling with the future of the United States to wait until it is demonstrated conclusively that Britain cannot win without the aid of our Navy in convoy duty.

While forty or more planes, mostly privately operated, flew over the treacherous Alleghany Mountain region of Pennsylvania yesterday seeking a trace of the missing Beechcraft plane in which Benjamin Brewster, New York investment broker, and his wife left Roosevelt Field Friday afternoon, a reward of $1,000 was offered for its discovery.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 11 -- Priority export licenses for basic materials for Latin-American countries, after United States war needs are filled, and the cancellation of German-affiliated agencies of United States concerns are to be among the salient recommendations in the report of Edward H. Robbins, special assistant to the Coordinator of Cultural Relations Between the American Republics, who is making a study of trade developments here.

FERNANDINA, Fla., May 11 -- Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer of the 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh Regiment, will shoot the first shell from the regiment's three-inch anti-aircraft guns tomorrow when the unit begins its first actual firing practice.

To avoid waste in the government's training program for defense workers, State and Federal authorities will recommend that local communities provide tests of physical fitness for workers entering the program, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Federal Defense Coordinator for New York State, disclosed yesterday.
The Maritime Commission has ordered twenty-four more C-2 cargo vessels aggregating 145,000 gross tons of shipping, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Nazi propagandists and their agents and helpers in the United States and in Britain are preparing now for a "peace offensive" and if appeasers have their way a peace with Hitler would enable him to make greater conquests, according to a pamphlet written by Livingston Hartley and published here today by the American Council on Public Affairs.

PULASKI, Va., May 11 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor iron workers voted today to ask permission of their international headquarters to call a strike at the $11,000,000 bag-loading plant being constructed near here in conjunction with the $44,000,000 Hercules powder plant near Radford, if negotiations do not yield satisfactory results by Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 -- More than 500 San Francisco police were ordered to strike duty tomorrow as 1,900 striking machinists of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations prepared to throw picket lines around eleven shipbuilding plants in the Bay area to implement a strike called at midnight Friday. Similar precautions were being taken in Oakland, where six of the plants are located.

BERLIN, May 11 -- The interest with which Germany is watching the economic situation in Latin America is evidenced by the fact that the Berlin Institute for Business Research devotes the whole of its latest weekly bulletin to an analysis of the difficulties experienced by the Latin-American nations as a result of the loss of their European markets through the British blockade.

The freighter Sea Witch, operated by the United States Lines, sailed yesterday with a valuable cargo for the Far East from Pier 60, North River. Seamen employed on the ship agreed Saturday to sign on for the voyage after a dispute over war bonuses had threatened to tie up the vessel indefinitely.

New controls for tuberculosis as a national defense measure were urged by Dr. Edgar Mayer, Assistant Professor of Clinical Medicine at Cornell Medical School, at a testimonial dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for Harold Stanley Marcus, executive vice president of the Neiman-Marcus Company of Dallas, Texas, on behalf of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver.
BERLIN, May 11 (AP) -- The German High Command's regular communique follows:

It means something to business, to defense and to those who have a disinterested love for statistics that freight-car loadings are running more than 19 per cent ahead of May, 1940, and nearly 39 per cent ahead of May, 1939. In a specimen week this month 794,301 cars were rumbling over the rails where only 536,149 were in motion two years ago.

"Old Acquaintance" once again announces its retirement, this time or keeps, it says, on Saturday Night, May 17, after its 162d performance. It will not tour this year, but may go out for a time in the all.

Children babbled happily in the sparkling sunshine at the Bronx Zoo yesterday, but, in one corner of the zoo, there was nothing but black gloom and anxiety, for Pandora, the famous giant panda, was gravely ill with mysterious convulsions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11 -- Princeton for the second year emerged victorious in the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's fifth annual Morss Trophy regatta for the dinghy championship under M.I.T. auspices on the Charles River today in light airs.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- While the one-week May furniture market was shattering sales and attendance records here last week, the National Retail Furniture Association put quietly into operation a new merchandising section which promises to have far-reaching effect in the furniture industry.

The report for 1940 of the United Light and Railways Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $6,198,479 after all charges and taxes, compared with $5,710,080 in 1939. On a corporate basis, excluding the undistributed net income of subsidiaries, the net income last year was $3,754,658, compared with $3,860,995 in 1939.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- A rookie's mistake gave the White Sox a 2-to-1 victory over the Tigers today, the decisive run coming in the ninth inning.

VICHY, France, May 11 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain left the Riviera tonight to return to Vichy, where he is due tomorrow morning. This news was released to the French press tonight, although the departure of the Chief of State for his estate on the Riviera was never made public.

The Belmont Park meeting which will open today is expected to see new glory for Whirlaway, who did so well in winning the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico. Whirlaway's smashing second stride Saturday toward the triple crown was regarded as his most difficult, because of the sharp turns at the Baltimore track.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 11 -- "Do you want graft and corruption?" demanded Mayor Frank Hague here today as he called upon members of his colorful Democratic machine to defeat the Citizens' ticket in Tuesday's municipal election.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 11 -- The peculiar determination of former King Carol of Rumania not to pose formally with Mme. Elena Lupescu "under any circumstances" was made plain here this morning.

Tomorrow Jersey City will have another opportunity to unload its remarkable Mayor, Frank Hague. The commission form of government, as practiced across the Hudson, provides for the popular election of five Commissioners, one of whom is chosen by his four fellow-Commissioners to be Mayor.

A newly widened and improved two-mile stretch of Cross Bay Boulevard across Big Egg Marsh at Broad Channel, Queens, opens officially to the public today, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday.

VICHY, May 11 -- Taking advantage of the abundance of money and the decline in interest rates, the government has effected an important new conversion and at the same time issued a small loan. The conversion operation concerns Treasury bonds and bonds issued by the National Credit Organization, whose amortization had been assumed by the Treasury.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Speculation over the United States' ability to speed up its war machine and enhance production continues to occupy German military experts and economists, and the concurring conclusion appears to be that the "technical" lead now commanded by Germany can be overtaken neither now nor in 1942 or 1943, and that Germany does not propose to relinquish that lead after the war in the domains of technical and economic achievement.

Justice and liberty shall not perish from the earth, because the spirit of man cannot be conquered, the Rev. John J. Hiemenga, pastor of the Third Christian Reformed Church of Paterson, N.J., declared yesterday afternoon before 1,000 persons at the West End Collegiate Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 11 -The keen eye and archaeological knowledge of a 13-year-old school-boy from Fort Montgomery, N.Y., has resulted in the discovery in a centuries-old cliff shelter near here of rare specimens of Algonquin Indian pottery, arrowheads and fishing equipment that antedate Columbus and definitely establish that the Algonquin tribe preceded the Iroquois as inhabitants of the Hudson River Valley, officials of the American Museum of Natural History revealed today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Canada and the United States are all represented on the bureau or permanent governing body of the Inter-American Statistical Institute, according to an announcement made here today by the temporary organizing committee.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A showdown this week on the question of United States naval vessels convoying lease-lend aid to Britain is expected by many members of Congress.

CARBON TETRACHLORIDE, the dry-cleaning fluid and fire-extinguishing agent, did a dramatic cleaning and extinguishing job in the remote South Seas not long ago. Dr. Sylvester M. Lambert, the man who was chiefly responsible, tells the story in the course of his candid and amusing "Yankee Doctor in Paradise."*

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A resolution calling upon Jewish communities in America "to strengthen the inner defenses of Judaism and democracy by providing the necessary moral and financial support for the cause of Jewish education" was adopted at today's annual meeting of the American Association for Jewish Education here.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 11 -- Miss Patty Berg, former women's national golf champion, and Miss Helen Dettweiler, one-time holder of the women's western crown, today defeated Miss Maureen Orcutt, metropolitan titleholder, and Mrs. Laddie Irwin Whitehead, New Jersey Champion, by 2 and 1 in an exhibition match at the Glen Ridge Country Club.

Having an idle Spring night on their hands, the young ladies and gentlemen of the American Actors Company staged what they dub "American Legend" in the studio playhouse at 108 West Sixteenth Street last evening. This is the group that has latterly been playing "Texas Town" to general satisfaction.

No completely successful program of preventive dentistry has been developed yet, it was conceded by Dr. John Oppie McCall, director of the Murray and Leonie Guggenheim Dental Clinic, 422 East Seventy-second Street, in the annual report for 1940 issued yesterday by Edmond A. Guggenheim, president.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 11 -- Blistering heat that reached 119 degrees around Tobruk and Solum yesterday made extended operations in the Western Desert humanly impossible. However, a British patrol with Bren-gun carriers swooped down on an Italian working party near Tobruk, killing and wounding many of the Italians and taking others prisoner before Axis armored vehicles guarding the party could get their motors started.

While buyer attention centered on Summer merchandise in the wholesale market last week, the better woolen dress houses were already busy on Fall lines in anticipation of probable fabric shortages and delivery delays. All types of cottons were bought in quantity, as retailers prepared to feature this fabric during National Cotton Week.

Richard W. Lawrence, long a leader in the civic and business life of this city, has accepted the chairmanship of the New York Committee for the United Service Organizations' $10,756,000 campaign, Thomas E. Dewey, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday.

The preliminary statement of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries for the three months ended on March 31 shows net income of $11,631,722, after charges, but without deduction for the depletion of metal mines. This is equivalent to $1.34 each on 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Today's announcement of the completion of the widening and improving of the two-mile stretch of Cross Bay Boulevard across Big Egg Marsh in Jamaica Bay will be welcome news to all who like to visit the city's beaches. It means that the last obstacle has been removed from a wide traffic artery stretching from Queens Boulevard to the Rockaways.
I read with interest the protests of tobacco growers against an increase in taxes on their product, and, while I agree with them, I should like to discuss the subject from a different point of view.

Five thousand members of the Bronx division of the Diocesan Sodality of the Blessed Virgin, representing every parish and girls' high school and academy in the borough, marched in a mile-long procession and attended benediction of the Blessed Sacrament yesterday afternoon on the campus of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale.

ON BOARD S.S. EXCAMBION at Bermuda, May 11 (AP) -- Dr. Charles R. Joy, European director of the Unitarian Service, protested to the British Minister in Lisbon and the chief censor at Bermuda today against seizure of all his papers yesterday.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- In the stillness of bomb-scarred Westminster Abbey, the Rev. Jocelyn Henry Temple Perkins, sacrist and minor canon since 1899, calmly finished reading his matins today and then solemnly turned to reporters and said:

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 11 -- The German Army of Occupation in Serbia is conducting a systematic campaign of looting and confiscation and unauthorized seizure of homes and property belonging to Serbians and foreigners, including Americans.
LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- A communique issued early today by the Ministries of Air and Home Security said:

PHILADELPIA, May 11 -- Scoring all their runs in one big burst in the fourth inning, but otherwise failing in rather painful fashion, the Dodgers just managed to nose out the Phillies, 6 -- 5, today and extend their latest winning streak to five games.

The significance of Mother's Day provided the topic yesterday for sermons in many New York pulpits. As part of the observance members of the Seventeenth Regiment, New York Guard, marched up Fifth Avenue to Fifty-third Street to take part in the evensong service at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

Lutheran churches throughout the nation conducted a one-day campaign yesterday to raise $250,000 to construct facilities for recreation and spiritual guidance for young Lutherans drafted into the Army.
The text of former President Hoover's address on "The Immediate Relation of the United States to This War," follows:

FORT DIX, N.J., May 11 -- Mothers of the 18,000 men in the Forty-fourth Division were assured today by the commanding general, Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, that if it became necessary to fight in defense of the United States their sons would be capable of taking care of themselves.

With respect to your editorial "When to Convoy," the implication is that those who oppose convoying until it is determined how desperately it is needed are equivocating. The real test to be applied, you state, is "How important is it to us that Britain should survive?"
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 (AP) -- The twelfth Iraqi General Headquarters comnunique, received today from Baghdad said:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Five producers and importers of lecithin, together with certain of their officers, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from monopolistic practices under an arrangement with two European companies.
Syndicates figured prominently over the week-end in the purchase of business properties in Manhattan.

The Nazis' story is that there is now peace in Europe. Since the conquest of Greece they are doing their utmost to convince the occupied countries that as far as they are concerned the war is over. There will be no more fighting on the Continent, they say; conditions are as normal as they can be until the British blockade is finally broken.

Though the possible loss of democracy is a shadow of impending tragedy that darkens the minds of Americans today, a greater loss would be that of the Bible, the Rev. Dr. Stewart P. MacLennan, former pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Hollywood, Calif., said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

M.D. Litman has followed the operations of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law and its developments with generally keen interest, and it was therefore regrettable that an apparent lack of information was the basis of his criticism in your columns on April 30 of the Burney bill recently signed by the Governor.

CINCINNATI, May 11 (AP) -- The Cubs, described only yesterday by Manager Jimmy Wilson as weak in hitting, broke out in a rash of 12 safe blows today to smother the Reds, 9 -- 1. While Chicago was blasting four pitchers Claude Passeau kept the world champions hitless except for the sixth, when they got a run on three singles.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A total of 1,016,964 persons in New York State during the week of March 24-30, 1940, were unemployed, according to a preliminary tabulation issued today by the Census Bureau. This total included persons seeking work and others on public emergency projects of the WPA, CCC and N.Y.A. out-of-school work program.
Closing their home stand with a grand flourish, the Giants regaled 13,495 spectators with an entertaining variety of baseball at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Eight films will arrive on Broadway this week. Today the Rialto will offer a new Jack Holt melodrama. "The Great Swindle," and the Cine Rome Theatre will present a new Italian drama, "Castelli in Aria," featuring Vittorio De Sica and Lillian Harvey.
Miguel A. de Capriles of Salle Santelli regained a championship he last held in 1934 when he won the national open three-weapon tournament at the Fencers Club yesterday.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Indications of the recent past suggest that aerial attacks of the German air force on the British Isles are getting into higher gear. Although with the advance into Spring the nights become shorter and the duration of the attacks appears thus to be increasingly curtailed, the flying weather and therewith the ease of attack appear to become correspondingly better.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Charging that the arrest last week of German and Italian seamen who had overstayed their leave in this country promoted war hysteria and incited unjustified suspicion against foreign-born residents, Hugh De Lacy today sent a letter of protest to Attorney General Robert H. Jackson.
Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York began yesterday the quiet celebration of a triple anniversary in which he will be honored in two ceremonies this week.

FORT LEE, N.J., May 11 -- A bitter argument occasioned by Mother's Day ended in tragedy this morning when Douglas Johnson, 55 years old, chief engineer for the Robert Fulton Hotel in New York for the last twenty-five years, died in Englewood Hospital six hours after arteries in his right arm had been severed by three thrusts of a ten-inch kitchen knife.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 -- President Roosevelt has praised the Mutual Broadcasting System for its "fine telegram" endorsing the Federal Communications Commission's report ordering drastic revision in the broadcasting industry's internal structure and directing the National Broadcasting System to divest itself of one of its two major networks, it was disclosed here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- News that Rudolf Hess, No. 3 Nazi, had landed by parachute in Scotland was felt in diplomatic circles of Washington to have struck a heavy blow at Nazi prestige, capable of more than offsetting the results of the successful Blitzkrieg in the Balkans.

The three apartment houses at 40-02-04 and 40-06-12 150th Street and 40-07 and 40-09 149th Place, Flushing, L.I., were sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to B. C. Estates, Inc. The Foreclosed Properties Company were the brokers.

Fifty unbroken years of religious "military service" were commemorated yesterday when Mrs. Alexander M. Damon, wife of the commissioner of the Eastern Territory of the Salvation Army, received a medal highly coveted by the army's cadets and officers.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The bill empowering President Roosevelt to commandeer foreign shipping lying idle in American harbors as a result of the war successfully cleared its first hurdle in the Senate today when the Commerce Committee reported it favorably by a vote of 11 to 4.

The Port of Astoria, Ore., which completed a refunding of its bonded debt in 1937, announced yesterday a new refunding program involving issuance of $2,500,000 of bonds on which bidders are to name an interest rate not to exceed 3 per cent. The new bonds, scheduled to be sold on May 27, are to be dated July 1, 1941, and are to mature on July 1, 1942 to 1961.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 -- American clothes are now the center of style attention because "Paris has passed" as the source of design inspiration, F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary of the national recovery coat and suit industry board told delegates to that organization's convention today.

Rumors are bruited about among us fire-breathing Southerners and strong, silent Westerners that New York is trying to pre-empt for itself our sectional characteristics. Examination of THE TIMES'S editorial pages of April 27 confirms these rumors.

TOKYO, May 12 (UP) -- The government and public must make a study of the Japanese alliance with Germany and Italy at once to determine Japan's obligations in case the United States enters the war, Retsu Kiyosawa, a leading political commentator, said today in the newspaper Chugai. It was not known whether he had been officially inspired.

LONDON, May 12 -- William Ridsdale has been appointed head of the Foreign Office news department, it was learned today. He succeeds Charles B.P. Peake who went to Washington with Viscount Halifax and who remains there at the special request of the British Ambassador and with the consent of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Estimated needs of the Commodity Credit Corporation for the 1942 fiscal year were put at $1,231,000,000 today by Carl B. Robbins, its president, in asking Congress to increase the corporation's borrowing power by $1,000,000,000 and extend its life indefinitely.

The recently formed group of Netherlands realty investors operating under the name of the Reoco Corporation, whose first purchase Of Manhattan real estate was announced last week, yesterday bought two small apartment buildings from the Bank for Savings through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Decentralization was described as an urgent need in the defense program by several speakers at the opening sessions today of a national conference of planning.

Trading continued active yesterday on veal hindsaddles, but the demand for other classes was mostly fair to good. Hinds and ribs were steady lth Friday's quotations and ,'eal hindsaddles were fully steady to strong. Other classes and cuts unchanged, The kosher market opened at around .steady prices.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 12 -- Ground-breaking ceremonies for a new $1,000,000 Greenwich hospital were held here this afternoon. Actual construction will start immediately on the first unit of the project, a $170,000 power plant and laundry.

Miss Margaret R. White will give a tea today at the home of her grandmother, Mrs. R. Burnham Moffat, 660 Park Avenue, for members of the junior committee aiding in the sale of tickets for the Spring song festival and dance to be given by the People's Chorus of New York on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Greek War Relief Association.

A story without counterpart in history, too fantastic to be believed if it were not vouched for in London, is the account of the arrival in Scotland of Rudolf Hess, the No. 3 man in Germany, Hitler's closest friend and after Goering the heir apparent to the Nazi Empire.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 12 -- The municipal election campaign came to a close today with the Democratic organization of Frank Hague, seeking his seventh consecutive term as Mayor, predicting a heavy vote at the polls tomorrow and the re-election of the Hague ticket by an "overwhelming majority."

The initial tour of a series of six, sponsored by the Citizens Housing Council in cooperation with the New York City Housing Authority to show the contrast between slum living quarters and modern public housing, was made yesterday.

The 105 concerts given this season by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York were attended by 254,899 persons, representing per cent of the capacity of the hall and an average attendance of 2,427 a concert, it was disclosed yesterday when the annual report of Marshall Field, president and chairman of the board of directors, was read on his behalf by Charles Triller, treasurer, at the society's annual meeting at Steinway Hall.

A consolidated net income of $28,389,270, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, was reported yesterday by the United Gas Improvement Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 -- A request from the Office of Production Management that striking machinists in eleven shipbuilding yards in the San Francisco Bay area return to work pending an attempt to settle their wage and hour demands in conference was unanimously rejected today by a mass meeting of those of the strikers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 12 -- German military sources in Serbia informed this correspondent that the German High Command would order Germany's second great Spring offensive through Turkey into Iraq across Syria and against Egypt to seize the immense British petroleum supplies in the Near East and smash the British forces out of North Africa, between June 1 and 10.

The Welsh Women's Chorus of New York, which is made up of fifty-one women who rehearse on Monday nights at the Church of the Strangers, contributed some of the most beautiful choral singing of the season last night at its fourth annual concert at Town Hall under the direction of its leader, Llewellyn Roberts.

A nation-wide call to 40,000 business men and organizations to unite in a vigorous program between now and May 28 to create a stronger national defense through a more efficient fire protection has been started by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, it was announced yesterday.

ROME, May 12 (UP) -- Pietro Cardinal Fumasoni-Biondi was appointed Camerlengo [Chamberlain] of the Sacred College of Cardinals today by Pone Pius, who, in the third secret consistory of his reign, appointed four new Bishops and gave sacred palliums to twenty new Archbishops.

Those who do not quite understand Dodger fans must now realize, if they read the exhaustive analysis of these strange folk in our Sunday Magazine, that the subject is much more complex than they had supposed. It is plain that the follower of the Flatbush team is not like other men.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Aliens in the United States on temporary permits must notify the immigration and naturalization authorities of their whereabouts every three months, Attorney General Jackson repeated today in announcing that more than 4,900,000 receipt cards had been sent to registered aliens in the United States and Territories.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The recent announcement by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would be willing to bid for large security issues was quoted today by the Securities And Exchange Commission as one of the reasons justifying a virtual refusal to permit Morgan Stanley Co. to receive underwriters' fees for participation in the recent underwriting of $120,000,000 of debentures of the Columbia-Gas and Electric Corporation.

PUTNAM, Conn., May 12 -- State police arrested the Police Commissioner of Putnam, a State police radio dispatcher and another man today on charges that they plotted a bank robbery attempt in which shots were exchanged early today.

VICHY, France, May 12 -- There were no indications here today of forthcoming legislation regarding Jews, but the press in Paris contained a number of hints. For instance, the Cri du Peuple had this to say:

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- American "Flying Fortresses" are in successful operation in Royal Air Force raids over Germany, Major Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Corps, made known today. He discussed advances in Army aviation in a speech before the Women's National Democratic Club.

The dignity and elevation of Mr. Hoover's radio discussion of the peace-or-war issue Sunday evening made it a timely contribution to fruitful debate. Surely the great question is to be discussed without rancor, with frankness, and to be decided not by indirection but by duly chosen authorities in the light of informed public opinion.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- One soldier and one Marine tonight broke up a line of eight pickets marching in front of the White House who represented the American Peace Mobilization. This organization has been charged with being a Communist Front group.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 13 -- Nine miles of docks along the River Elbe at Hamburg were laced with heavy British bombs and thousands of incendiaries over Sunday night when the Royal Air Force followed up its attack of the previous night with another vigorous raid on German war ports.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- Newark's bitter City Commission campaign continued full blast until midnight tonight with Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and his principal opponent, City Commissioner Joseph M. Byrne Jr., taking to the radio for the hurling of last minute charges.
Oils and pastels by Jeanne Methot are being shown at the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Representative Crawford believes sugar refiners in the New York area may be using Mayor F.H. La Guardia as a "mouthpiece for their propaganda."
In 1921, when he already was a member of Adolf Hitler's inner circle, Rudolf Hess wrote a pamphlet on the question: "What kind of man will awaken Germany?"

LONDON, May 12 -- Russian recognition of Premier Rashid Ali Beg Gailani's government in Iraq did not cause much surprise here, though undoubtedly it was not in the least to the taste of British officials.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Further evidence that members of Congress are growing more concerned over the political effects of voting a 50 per cent increase in taxes without at the same time slashing non-essential expenditures drastically came today as the House Ways and Means Committee continued to listen to arguments of witnesses against alleged "inequalities" of the proposed defense tax bill.

Dick Bachman, right-handed pitching ace of Manhattan College, stopped the heavy-hitting St. John's nine cold at Dexter Park yesterday. He checked the dangerous Mickey Rutner in particular, and that was half the battle. Thus Johnny Balquist's Kelly Greens went on to achieve a major upset in the form of a 3-1 victory over the Redmen, two-time winners of the mythical metropolitan championship.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 (AP) -- Veteran Lonnie Warneke, the Arkansas hillbilly with the bull-whip pitching arm, pitched a seven-hit game today and the Cardinals defeated the Pirates, 6 -- 2, to sweep the two-game series.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Direct legal authorization to defer from military service the older men registered under the Selective Service Act was requested of Congress today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, deputy director of Selective Service.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Disestablishment of the Employes' Representation Plan at nine plants of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation as ordered by the National Labor Relations Board on the ground that the plan is a company-dominated union was sustained by the United States Court of Appeals today.

FERNANDINA, Fla., May 12 -- The 207th Coast Artillery went into action today with its first anti-aircraft firing practice when Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer, pulled the lanyard on the first shot.
BERLIN, May 12 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

OTTAWA, May 12 -- Declaring that young men from the Province of Quebec had responded to the call for volunteers in larger numbers perhaps than those of any other Province, Defense Minister J.L. Ralston told the House of Commons today that he regarded any demand for compulsory overseas service "as unnecessary and inopportune at this time."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, upholding tentative findings and conclusions issued in February, today refused to grant the application of the American Gas and Electric Company for and order to declare it not a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Federal Government on March 31 had committed itself to pay for $1,915,000,000 of new factory facilities in building "an arsenal of democracy," the Office of Production Management announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Under present world conditions the United States maintains de facto relations with any and all kinds of governments, Secretary of State Cordell Hull remarked today when parrying a question as to whether or not the United States would withdraw recognition from the anti-British regime set up in Iraq after a pro-Nazi coup, or grant it new recognition.

"The Great Swindle," originally scheduled to arrive at the Rialto yesterday, will open this morning instead. Jack Holt, Jonathan Hale, Marjorie Reynolds, Sidney Blackmer and Don Douglas are featured in the Columbia melodrama. . . . "Secret Evidence," a Producers Distributing Corporation melodrama with Charles Quigley and Marjorie Reynolds, and a Republic Western, "Sheriff of Tombstone," starring Roy Rogers, comprise the double feature program current at the New York Theatre.

AMSTERDAM, May 12 -- Trading was at a minimum today though most issues were firm. Royal Dutch was steady at 232 7/8 and some other industrials were a fraction higher, but Amsterdam Rubber was 1 1/2 poirts lower at 267_. and shippings were as much as 5 points down.

A plan to attract to the floors of the nation's securities exchanges an increasing volume of transactions and prepared for the specific benefit of the New York Curb Exchange was described at length yesterday by George P. Rea, president, and Fred C. Moffatt, former president, of that institution.

Under the weight of intensified aerial warfare, the stock market backed water yesterday as the rally of Saturday failed to carry over to the opening of a new week. Significant to Wall Street was the sharp decline experienced by prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange where values were beaten down severely on persistent rumors that the United States was about to become directly involved in the World War.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 12 -- Albert W. Hawkes of Montclair, newly elected president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, called on industry and labor to declare a voluntary moratorium on strikes and lockouts in defense industries in an address tonight at a joint dinner of the Montclair and Oranges-Maplewood Chamber of Commerce at the Montclair Golf Club.

With the immediate object of cooperating with the Army, Navy and Marine Corps in recruiting flying personnel for the expansion of their air branches, the American Flying Services Foundation, Inc., of 60 East Forty-second Street, yesterday opened a membership drive by setting up an exhibit on civil and military aviation at the City Information Center in Pershing Square.

The Nazi fliers have finally succeeded in hitting the monumental centers of British civilization. They call this act a "reprisal," and in one sense it is. It is a reprisal, not for anything that the R.A.F. has so far done to German cities, but against civilization itself for daring to exist.

VICHY, France, May 12 -- For the time being it is not possible to separate the two hemispheres in any discussion here of the world situation. That the situation is tense and is likely to remain so, at least until President Roosevelt has spoken, is admitted.

WASHINGTON, May l2 -- The nation's armed forces will be using all available sources of aluminum in 1942 and there will be none for civilian or "indirect" military requirements, according to W.L. Batt, deputy director of the Production Division of the Office of Production Management.

Wholesale prices on women's shoes for Fall were still uncertain last night after more than 1,500 buyers had spent the day mulling over the price problem with about 600 manufacturers in showings at the Hotel Commodore, the Hotel New Yorker and the Hotel McAlpin.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (AP) -- Refugees from war and oppression in Europe and Asia have but three possible routes of escape and these are practically closed, says Moses W. Beckelman, a European director of the American Joint Distribution Committee of Relief to Refugees.

Although many manufacturers and retailers throughout the nation are unable to provide merchandise in sufficient quantity to meet current demands, there should be "no appreciable trend" toward reducing current expenditures for advertising, members of the Association of National Advertisers said yesterday at their thirty-first annual Spring meeting at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

Mrs. Frederick S. Wildman gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq !Rouge for Lady Morris of London. Among the other guests were Mrs. Tackaberry 2cAdoo, Mrs. Atkinson I Allen, Mrs. Imr de Josika-Herczeg i and Miss 2arie Kahler.

Gratitude for Ethel Barrymore's appearance in "this play, this year" was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as she presented to the actress the third annual Barter Theatre Award for her performance in "The Corn Is Green."

The fact that Commissioner Moses has done so much for New York and its parkways should not cause us to lose sight of the fact that the Bronx River Parkway, as the first important parkway in this section of the country, has had great influence not only in New York but throughout the country, in establishing the principle of good roads and fine planting.

Representing Mayor La Guardia at the silver jubilee dinner of the Women's City Club at the Hotel Biltmore last night, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, inferentially predicted the re-election next November of the present city officials, on the basis of their record as "a team."

TOKYO, May 12 -- As indication that, despite an apparent lull, Japan's diplomacy is continuing to work under high pressure, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka was received in audience by Emperor Hirohito this afternoon. He stayed at the palace for more than two hours.

Seeking to make their ersatz dishes more palatable, Germans have seized available supplies of herbs in the Balkans, and the American housewife will find it increasingly difficult and expensive to get these seasoning materials for her cooking, members of the American Spice Trade Association reported at a round-table discussion of trade problems at the opening of their annual convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

That a degree of concentrated power in business has undermined the capacity of individuals and even localities to maintain themselves economically and politically has been illustrated by the study recently completed by the Temporary National Economic Committee, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, who was chairman of the committee, declared last night at the annual meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Jimmy Hines, veteran Lakeville pro, and Norman Files, one of the last combinations to come in, captured top honors in the inaugural Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball tournament yesterday at the St. Albans Golf Club.

LONDON, May 12 -- David McLean, a Scottish plowman, found Rudolf Hess lying injured in a field and without at any time suspecting his identity, assisted him to his humble farmhouse. There Herr Hess gossiped with Mr. McLean's mother and other relatives for almost an hour before he was taken away by officials.

The Order of Sons of Zion and the Jewish Postal Workers of America each bought a $10,000 defense bond yesterday from Postmaster Albert Goldman in his office at the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street.

BUENOS AIRES, May 12 -- Guillermo Rothe, the Acting Foreign Minister, said today that conclusion of a commercial treaty with the United States was the most important event that could take place in Argentine international economic relations.

CHUNGKING, China, May 12 -- The common character of the external menace facing China and the United States and the essentially united ideals for which the two nations are striving was the theme of the speech that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek delivered at the farewell dinner for Ambassador Nelson T. Johnson on Saturday night.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 12 -- Rumors originating in Washington last week and continuing today indicated that the American Association for Adult Education holding its annual convention here was about to change its form.

Southern bituminous coal operators, employing 150,000 miners, resumed negotiations yesterday with representatives of the United Mine Workers in another effort to reach a final agreement covering their portion of the industry. The conferees met at the Hotel Commodore.

BERLIN, May 12 -- The German press tonight featured accounts of the raid on London Saturday night. The dispatches of correspondents of neutral countries resident in London form the material from which the German accounts are compounded.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 12 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that the effect of strikes on national defense has been "infinitely small," and declared that American labor would fight to protect and preserve democracy.

LONDON, May 12 -- The meetings of Parliament will not be interrupted by the bombing of the Palace of Westminister and the destruction of the chamber of the House of Commons, for the House took the precaution when the intensive air raids began last Autumn of providing an alternative meeting place for both houses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 12 -- Recalled to the stand for cross-examination by government attorneys, a Portland naturopathic physician testified today in the Harry Bridges deportation hearing as the case entered its sixth week.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Congress is likely to face early consideration of additional appropriations under the lease-lend bill, in the opinion of Professor John Maynard Keynes, economic expert and adviser to the British Treasury, who is now in Washington on a two-week visit from London.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The question of further withdrawals of American defense forces from China has not recently been considered, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today in connection with a statement that extraterritoriality for Americans in China still existed.

The National Committee for Religious Recovery, the Purpose of which is "to maintain America's unity of spirit by building up her religious thinking," changed its name yesterday to the Layman's National Committee. Francis Rufus Bellamy, executive vice chairman of the committee, announced the change of name at a luncheon of members of the organization's national committee at the Murray Hill Hotel.

BOSTON, May 12 -- A new law, the purpose of which is to prevent the Shubert theatre interests from engaging in the sale and resale of theatre tickets through its ticket brokers agency, was signed today by Governor Saltonstall.

Naomi Block, an upper junior at Hunter College, was chosen president of the Student Self-Government Association of the college by more than three-fourths of the students voting in the election last Friday, it was announced yesterday by Doris Evans, chairman of the board of elections.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, defending its rates for long distance telephone service, took sharp issue with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, over the commission's order, promulgated April 1, calling for a sweeping investigation of Bell System rate-making practices and directing A.T. T. and its twenty-one associated companies to show cause why their rates should not be reduced.
ROME, May 12 (AP) -- Guns of Italian shore batteries and German Stukas combined to rout British warships shelling Bengazi on Saturday night, the Italians announced today.
United States Senator and Mrs. Ralph O. Brewster have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, leading subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, reaffirmed yesterday its price of $5 a base box on coke tin plate through Sept. 30 for delivery and consumption in the United States. Transportation charges at the time of shipment will determine the delivered price in the period, it was announced.

After an absence of five years from the Broadway stage (her last play was "O Evening Star"), Zoe Akins returns this evening with an item auspiciously called "The Happy Days," a play about puppy love, delineating the heartbreaks, woes and joys of a first romance when all the world was young.

In Widener Library at Harvard there is an exhibition of books now forbidden in occupied France. Mr. Howard Rice of the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures writes in The Springfield Republican of the lists of proscribed works. They include all anti-Nazi writing, historical or otherwise, books by "non-Aryans," famous contemporary Germans.

Telephone and travel vouchers, apparently offered in preparation for later testimony on the transactions at issue, were placed in evidence by the State yesterday at the General Sessions trial of William Solomon, Tammany district leader, and Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, on a bribery indictment.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 13 -- The news of Rudolf Hess's desertion of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and his flight to Britain was broadcast to Germany and Italy by the British Broadcasting Corporation early today.

Increased efforts to put the 1941 campaign of the Greater New York Fund "over the top" were urged yesterday by former Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the drive to raise $5,000,000 from business and employe groups for the 400 welfare agencies supported by the fund.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Hogs were strong to 10 cents higher in active dealings today. Demand in the swine market was strongest for heavy butchers. Bulk of 180 to 330 pound weights brought $8.60 to $8.85, with an extreme top of $8.90. Sows advanced 10 cents, with good 400 to 500 pound weights selling between $8 and $8.25.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Senators bunched eight blows effectively behind the six-hit hurling of Dutch Leonard today to defeat the Athletics, 5 to 1. It was the veteran knuckleballer's third straight victory.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 12 -- Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, Fort Dix commander, announced today that 100 modern apartments will be ready for married non-commissioned officers and civilian employes of the War Department June 1.

Indication of Mayor La Guardia's reliance on the Fire Department as the city's chief bulwark against air invasion was offered yesterday before the City Council Finance Committee when the newly appointed Fire Commissioner, Patrick J. Walsh, said his department would be brought up to full strength soon.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 13 -- Hundreds of German bombers flew over South England and the Midlands Sunday night, attacking airdromes among other objectives, it was revealed yesterday. Nine of the raiders were destroyed before dawn, four each by fighters and anti-aircraft guns and one by undetermined means, it was announced.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 12 -- Jack Sabol of Westchester Hills played midseason golf at the Dunwoodie Club today, carded 33, 33 -- 66, five under par, to lead a field of twenty-one pros and with Joseph A. Mitchell of his club won the pro-amateur best-ball competition with a record 30, 31 -- 61.

No immediate shortage of scrap rubber for reclaiming purposes looms, reclaimers and leaders have determined as a result of conferences with the government, it was learned here yesterday. Current supply is double that which reclaimers have been consuming annually and if necessary can be sharply expanded by more vigorous collecting methods in areas other than those adjacent to the consuming centers, it was said.

Welcomed at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia "as representatives of sister republics in a hemisphere where the smallest sovereign state enjoys equal rights with the largest," high naval officers of eleven Central and South American countries arrived from Philadelphia at 4:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon for a three-day visit to New York.

The Packard Motor Car Company reported for the quarter ended on March 31 net profit of $274,272, after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. This is equal to 2 cents each on 15,000,000 shares of common stock. It compares with a net profit of $38,409, or less than 1 cent a share, in the March quarter last year.

The Widener and Whitney families, so prominently identified with Belmont Park through the years, swept the honors yesterday as America's largest racing ground opened for the Spring meeting before 15,877 persons who wagered $858,051.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 12 -- Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador to Ankara, came back to his post today aboard a large camouflaged Junkers troop transport plane, following a series of last-minute conferences with Reichsfuehrer Hitler at the latter's Obersalzburg retreat.

We are in a perpetual state of amazement these days over the endless parade of culinary shore-cuts constantly coming into view. If things keep up at this rate much longer, filling the water glasses will be the most taxing part of preparing a full-course feast.

BERLIN, May 12 -- Authoritative quarters in Berlin refused to comment late tonight on a British statement that Rudolf Hess, 47-year-old deputy leader of the National Socialist party and Reichsfuehrer Hitler's personal representative, had bailed out of a Messerschmitt plane near Glasgow, Scotland, and was in the hands of the British authorities.

A collective bargaining agreement covering 50,000 men's clothing workers in the New York area and providing for wage increases totaling $6,000,000 annually was signed yesterday between the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., and the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange at the office of the employers' association, 22 East Seventeenth Street.

MADRID, Spain, May 12 -- Spain's foreign policy is completely under the control of Generalissimo Francisco Franco and it is ridiculous to suppose that a "group" should try to monopolize it, the newspaper Madrid declared tonight in an editorial to which great attention is being paid here.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 12 (AP) -- Haskell Coffin, magazine illustrator and portrait painter, died today about an hour after he plunged to the ground from his third-story hospital room where, Coroner John T. Fisher said, he had been undergoing treatment for melancholia.

VICHY, France, May 12 -- Pierre Laval, who remains without any government post, has been maintained in a municipal office as Mayor of Aubervilliers, a suburb of Paris, it was announced officially today.

The North American Light and Power Company, a principal sub-holding company in the $1,000,00,000 North American Company system, is to be dissolved in compliance with the simplification and integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was announced yesterday.
BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- A strike of 925 American Federation of Labor skilled craftsmen today halted a $53,000,000 construction project at the big Navy drydock in South Boston.

Fiorello H. La Guardia, a local amateur conductor of note, will return to the podium on Friday night for a brief engagement as leader of the combined orchestras of the city's four municipal colleges in their first annual music festival at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- In an echo of the political scandals in Louisiana, the Supreme Court today denied a review to Abraham L. Shushan, and four other men, who, with him, were convicted on mail fraud charges.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary Knox told the Society of American Military Engineers tonight that America already has made its choice and that all that is needed is "the word to go forward."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent for the week ended May 10, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- An invitation of the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures to testify on legislation extending President Roosevelt's monetary powers was declined today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Daniel W. Tracy, Assistant Secretary of Labor, today denied accusations made against him by the C.I.O. Councils of San Francisco and Oakland that he had been part of a group which had forced the West Coast unions to accept the shipbuilding stabilization agreement.

If there is any excuse strong enough to justify the strike of 1,200 A.F. of L. machinists and 700 C.I.O. workers which has closed eleven Pacific Coast shipbuilding plants, it is certainly not apparent in the basic facts so far made public. The old agreement under which the machinists worked, which expired on April 1, was for $1 an hour for a 40-hour week and double time for overtime.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 12 -- Led by its star, Miss Kay Byrne, who registered an 83 for the best gross performance, the Rye Country Club kept right behind the pace-setting Century squad in Class A in the third series of Westchester women's interclub matches at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- One of the country's leading psychiatrists said today that lqudolf t:Iess, Adolf Hitler's second lieutenant vho landed from a Iesserschmitt plane in Scotland on Saturday, was probably "much more sane than cra'."

The seizure by Treasury Department agents of more than $100,000 worth of opium on the American-South African passenger liner City of New York was announced yesterday at the Custom House. The raid was made on May 3, when the ship docked at Pier 5, Bush Docks, Brooklyn, on its arrival from Cape Town.

The Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company has purchased from the Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation a parcel of twelve acres on the west shore of the Hackensack River adjoining the Lincoln Highway at Kearny, N.J. The tract has a river frontage of 930 feet and a depth of 917 feet.
BERLIN, May 12 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 7 shows the following changes compared with those of April 7, in thousands of marks:

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Each morning the United Press news-ticker, of which there are installations in many newspaper and government offices in Washington, carries a list of the President's appointments. Because of Mr. Roosevelt's convalescence from a recent minor illness the latest list was brief: Prime Minister Menzies of Australia in the morning, Secretary Hull for lunch.
Every day I hear influential and informed people compare the situation now prevailing in the United States with the situation in France at the time of the Front Populaire.

Mrs. Dena Shelby Diehl of Danville, Ky., who was chosen by the Golden Rule Foundation last month as the American Mother of 1941, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon of the foundation at the Town Hall Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Frank Capra and Robert Riskin have closed a deal and will sign the papers this week for the purchase of "The Flying Yorkshireman" from Frank Lloyd at a price "in the neighborhood of $44,000" Riskin disclosed today.

Steel production is scheduled at 99.2 per cent of capacity this week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a gain of 2.4 points, or 2.5 per cent over last week and 4.9 points above the year's low mark of 94.3 per cent two weeks ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12 -- The Princeton Theological Seminary will hold its 129th annual commencement exercises tomorrow morning in the Princeton University chapel. The Rev. Dr. John R. Cunningham, president of Davidson College, will deliver the address.
Replying to former President Hoover's address in opposition to convoys while urging more aid to Britain, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that "we must see that this equipment reaches England."

Alfred A. Knopf announces that entries can now be made by writers for the 1942 fellowships his publishing house offers annually -- three grants of $1,200 each for writers who have fiction, biography and history work "in progress." The closing date is Feb. 27, 1942.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 12 -- Indian troops advancing from north of Alagi yesterday captured Gumsa in the Efalaga Pass area to the east, taking four pack guns together with quantities of war material. The South Africans, meanwhile, moved north, thus tightening the pincer around the last Italian stronghold on the Asmara-Dessye road.

BOSTON, May 12 -- A.M. Creighton, New England regional director of the Office of Production Management, today announced receipt of word from Washington that the procurement branch of the United States Army, acting as the purchasing agency for arms, ammunition and equipment under the provisions of the Lease-Lend Act, will within a very short time release orders totaling $5,500,000,000.

BOSTON, May 12 -- The speed and power of his pitching arm undoubtedly have been spent in twenty years of fooling batters in organized baseball, but the 41-year-old Robert Moses Grove satisfied 10,963 of his stanch supporters at Fenway Park today he still has skill and cunning.

The drug industry faces some form of priorities or rationing if the raw materials situation gets out of hand, Charles C. Concannon, industrial consultant of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said yesterday in an address before the foreign trade section of the Proprietary Association of America, which began its fifty-ninth annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore.

Dealings in raw furs for the first four months of the present season, ending with March, totaled $17,096,692, an increase of 28 per cent over the volume for the corresponding period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Fur Merchants Association.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Roosevelt will make a "fireside chat" to the nation May 27, but will not make his scheduled speech before the Pan American Union Wednesday night, it was announced at the White House today.

The theories of our diplomatic experts regarding the so-called Russian "enigma" have always been very enigmatic to this simple observer, but most amazing of all is the conclusion or conclusions arrived at by the said experts in their attempt to interpret the replacement of Molotoff as Soviet Premier by Stalin himself.

The approval of the purchase of 120,000 freight cars in 1942 and another 150,000 cars in 1943 by the Association of American Railroads was in exact conformity with an estimate recently issued by the association. Meanwhile, the association has ordered that about 20,000 cars suitable for carrying grain be returned to the West, regardless of whether lading is found for them.

After defeating the challenger on Sunday, Samuel Reshevsky, United States chess champion, maintained his title series lead over Israel A. Horowitz yesterday by drawing the fourth game, adjourned from Saturday, at the Manhattan Chess Club in the Hotel Alamac.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Mediation conferences seeking a settlement of the dispute that threatens a strike affecting 165,000 employes of sixty-one General Motors Corporation plants will be resumed here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- After conferring with President Roosevelt at the White House for more than an hour today, Robert Gordon Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, made a moving appeal for increased American aid against the Axis.

The Women's National Golf and Tennis Club team of five won 8 of a possible 10 points at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday to tie Pomonok for the lead in Class A of the Long Island interclub golf matches. This was the opening round in the class.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Joey Archibald, former featherweight titleholder, won a close decision over Harry Jeffra to gain recognition tonight as ruler of the division in four States outside of the National Boxing Association's jurisdiction. Archibald weighed 123 pounds, Jeffra 124 1/2.

The addition of two acres to Battery Park by extension of the seawall, removal of the historic Aquarium and erection in the park of two ventilation shafts disguised as pylons were among proposals advanced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Several thousand members of society from Long Island, New York and other parts of the East and from Virginia motored, flew or arrived yesterday by special train to attend the opening program of the 24-day Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park, which, because of improvements, had never looked so attractive.

CINCINNATI, May 12 (AP) -- Behind Bill Lee's six-hit hurling, the Cubs again recorded a victory over the Reds today in the strangest exhibition of sandlot baseball the young season has produced. The score was 12 to 1.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Members of the Association of American Railroads accepted today a recom mendation by their officials for a net increase of 270,000 freight cars at an approximate cost of ,$730,00,000 for the two years from October, 1941, to October, 1943.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Reports that the Department of Agriculture has sought to curb speculative trading in commodity markets and less favorable prospects for an 85 per cent of parity loan on the 1941 crop gave the wheat market a heavy undertone today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Navy Department awarded contracts totaling $1,628,402 today, while the War Department announced two agreements of lease by the Defense Plant Corporation.

The fifth annual exhibition of student work from WPA art classes opened yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum. This work has been installed downstairs in the Eighty-third Street foyer and will continue to be on view through May 30.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 12 -- The captain and first mate were fatally burned and four other members of the crew of a 150-foot motor barge were burned seriously early today when fire started on the craft a few minutes after it had taken on a 124,000-gallon load of gasoline at a dock in the Staten Island Sound here.

ON the trip to Baltimore for the Preakness this tourist happened to sit with E. Sande, the Flying Earl of other days and one of the greatest jockeys the turf ever knew. The "Singing Kid from Deep River" has picked up a little weight and lost a few hairs from his Sande (spelling optional in this case) thatch since he quit the saddle and took to training horses.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 12 -- The country has traveled so far toward governmental control of private initiative in recent years that there appears now to be no easy alternative to the prospect of increased participation by government agencies in the financing of the defense effort, according to the report of the Industrial Securities Committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- Haile Selassie declared today that he intended to release British forces from their task of reconquering Ethiopia from Italy and aid them in their defense elsewhere against "cruel attacks."

Passengers, officers and crew members of the American Export liner Excambion, which carried former King Carol of Rumania and Mme. Elena Lupescu from Lisbon to Bermuda, described the couple as highly congenial traveling companions yesterday when the liner arrived at Pier F. Jersey City, with sixty-two United States citizens among her 186 passengers and two stowaways, one of whom said he was a deserter from the German Army.
LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- Tonight's Air and Home Security Ministries' communique said:

A PAIR of admirable little books* from England, by D.W. Brogan of Cambridge and C.J. Hitch of Oxford, point to the fact that at least one thing should be accomplished by the present war. When it is all over, the British people should have begun to understand the American people and the United Kingdom should have discovered the United States.

A PAIR of admirable little books* from England, by D.W. Brogan of Cambridge and C.J. Hitch of Oxford, point to the fact that at least one thing should be accomplished by the present war. When it is all over, the British people should have begun to understand the American people and the United Kingdom should have discovered the United States.
VICHY, France, May 12 (AP) -- The Petain government forbade John Elliott, New York Herald Tribune correspondent, today from sending out dispatches for the next ten days.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate agreed today to vote not later than 5 P.M. tomorrow on the West Virginia Senatorship contest, which has left that State with only one occupied seat in the upper body since Congress assembled in January.

After experiencing the sharpest break in three weeks, price of futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered moderately to close with net losses of 10 to 13 points. The market showed signs of weakness at the opening when prices were down 6 to 8 points, and these recessions were rapidly widened to 18 to 21 points.

The American Guild of Variety Artists, which has had a stormy career ever since it displaced the American Federation of Actors, yesterday announced the results of its first national election. Twenty-five members were chosen to serve on the national board.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House rejected today, 236 to 69, the so-called Overton formula, which vould have decided the amount of the Federal Government's annual contribution to the District of Columbia.

The Board of Higher Education last night declared vacant the position of David Goldway, an English teacher at Townsend Harris High School, who refused to sign a waiver of immunity when called before the Rapp-Coudert Committee last month.

Defense contracts awarded from July 1, 1940, through April 30 reached a total of $14,561,342,981, of which $759,364,851 was awarded in the last half of April, according to data issued yesterday by the Office of Government Reports, 45 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A $44,780,000 registration was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the American Viscose Corporation of Wilmington, Del., the first big British-owned company in the United States to be sold by the British Treasury to pay for the war orders placed here before the lease-lend bill was passed.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 12 -- Appointment of a committee to draw up a program under which building construction could be accelerated in Westchester County was authorized tonight at a meeting at the Labor Temple here under the auspices of the Building Trades and Construction Council of Westchester County, which represents eighty-five A.F. of L. locals.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary Hull announced tonight that the United States would try again to negotiate trade agreements with Argentina and Uruguay.

Robert D. Scott is 13 years old and in the seventh grade of the Fort Montgomery grammar school. At this moment he is the luckiest boy in the United States, having just done what every normal boy in the United States wants to do. He found a hidden cave with a treasure inside.

The new issue of $50,000,000 of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company 3 per cent debentures, due on May 1, 1961, will be offered to the public today at 99 and accrued interest. Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Otis Co., as principal underwriters and leaders of a group of seventy-eight underwriters, will head a nation-wide selling group of about 600 dealers.

The volume of banker's dollar acceptances outstanding showed a further gain in April, partly contra-seasonal, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the acceptance market. The amount outstanding in the United States on April 30 was $219,561,000, a gain of $2,249,000 on the month.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 13 -- Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the German Nazi party and the third-ranking personage in the German State, parachuted to earth in Scotland on Saturday night and is now a prisoner of war.

The bodies of Benjamin Brewster, New York investment broker, and his wife, the former Leonie de Bary Lyon, who disappeared Friday on a projected flight from Roosevelt Field to Warren, Ohio, were found last night in the charred wreckage of their plane on a rugged mountain top forty miles north of Harrisburg.

Two thousand women will be enlisted to assist in the raising of funds for the women's division of the United Service Organization drive, Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich, chairman of the unit, informed a group of women writers yesterday at a tea at the River Club.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 12 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued this communique today:
HATTERAS, N.C., May 12 -- The weather is just right, the wind light, the surf moderate and the sun bright, but, you have guessed it, the channel bass are offshore.

TOKYO, May 12 -- Demands for sweeping reform of the entire administrative machinery as a concomitant of economic regimentation for the construction of a "high-degree defense state and the Greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere" were presented to the government today by representatives of the Japanese business world, who met in a round-table conference with Cabinet members headed by Prince Fumimaro Konoye, the Premier, to discuss the problem.
