WASHINGTON, May 12 -- An important political fact has failed, so far, to be understood in all its implications: Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's absence from Vichy during the Franco-German negotiations for the revision of the armistice signed last June.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 -- Pacific Coast purchasing agents continued to extend their forward coverage of materials last month, with 34.6 per cent buying more than six months ahead, as against 26 per cent in March and 3.2 per cent in April, 1940, the monthly report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Northern California indicated today.

Soap opera, of which we hear more and more as the days pass, not unnaturally makes a person think of soap. Three or four years ago the manufacturer's value of all the soap produced in the country was nearly twice as great as the value of all the books manufactured in the country.

ROME, May 22 -- Former President Herbert Hoover's radio address, in which he is said to have emphasized the United States' lack of preparation for war, received the utmost prominence in Italian newspapers today, while all commentators praised it highly.

Albert Becker, the Fire Department inspector whose exoneration on charges of bribe-taking set the stage last week for Mayor La Guardia's ouster of Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott and Deputy Commissioner George L. McKenna, resigned yesterday from the department after eighteen years of service.

The opening of the Belmont Park Spring season yesterday revealed a smart and gay fashion picture the moment society leaders began to assemble in the restaurant of the Turf and Field Club at noon. Bright sunshine and a promise of pleasant weather brought a brilliant array of styles, particularly in millinery, and hats carried off the color honors of the day.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, expressed the view at his press conference today that it was up to Congress, "which has been complaining about being a rubber stamp," to take the initiative in paring $1,000,000,000 from non-defense expenditures during the coming fiscal year.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- John DunCan Rigney, who is expecting a call momentarily to join Uncle Sam's fighting forces, held the Red Sox sluggers to four scattered hits today as the White Sox triumphed, 3 -- 2, to vault into second place in the American League standings.

Clarence V. Joerndt of the credit department of the National City Bank was elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the chapter's annual meeting last night in the Hotel Piccadilly. Mr. Joerndt was graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1920 and has been associated with the National City Bank since that time.

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen issued a report yesterday declaring that his two-and-one-half-year-old inquiry into official corruption in Brooklyn had become self-supporting through the restitution of money in excess of the total cost of the investigation and that 90 per cent of all completed prosecutions, whether criminal or disciplinary, have been successful.

VICHY, France, May 13 -- Coincidental with the return to Vichy of Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan there was much discussion by the Paris press today of "neutral France," and there is reason to believe that the matter was touched upon when the United States Ambassador, Admiral William D. Leahy, was received by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Expressions were heard in the House today urging embargoes on shipments of oil to Japan and to other countries which might reship it to Germany. The demands came during consideration of the Interior Department 1942 appropriation bill carrying $177,019,078.

The American Power and Light Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28 a consolidated net income of $11,524,426 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. The income compared with a net of $11,494,975 in the twelve months ended on Feb. 29, 1940.

Rallying forces were in the stock market yesterday, but the effort lacked conviction, and in the late trading gave way to a short period of further discounting. This late weakness, especially in some of the steels, left the market in an irregularly easier position at the close.
Lofts, apartments, residences and rooming houses figured in the sales reported by brokers on the West Side and in the midtown sections of Manhattan yesterday.

Five bills granting omnibus pay increases to as many classes of city employes were introduced in the City Council yesterday by Councilman Alfred E. Smith. The measures were referred without discussion to the Council's committee on civil employee.

Contributions and pledges by companies in the jewelry trades division of the Greater New York Fund, totaling far more than the final contribution of this division in the campaign last year, were made yesterday at a luncheon meeting of heads of the industry in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

VICHY, France, May 13 -- Pierre Dominique, who resigned a few weeks ago from direction of the section of information, was appointed today general director of the French Information Office, which has replaced the old Agence Havas, news service.

Twenty-four lots, constituting all of the vacant Manhattan parcels owned by the East River Savings Bank, have been purchased by the Omnibus Realty Corporation, of which Elias A. Cohen is president. The properties carry an aggregate assessed valuation of about $165,000, ranging from $4,500 to $28,000 each.

The eight-year hold of the Ellenstein-Franklin bipartisan organization, allied with Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, was broken in yesterday's City Commission election in Newark, while Mayor Hague's usual majority in his own bailiwick was substantially reduced in the election there as compared with four years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The flight of Rudolf Hess to Britain continued to cause widespread conjectures in official circles today, but no satisfactory explanation was offered.

ALBANY, May 13 -- The April count of new stock formations was 276 fewer than in April, 1940, Secretary of State Walsh revealed today. The four-month aggregate fell 702. The total was 1,310 last month, compared with 1,586 the year before.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has started to move crude oil by pipe line from the Southwest to Bayonne, N.J. The movement began on Monday and arrangements call for 20,000 barrels daily from the East Texas field and 7,500 from Arkansas and Louisiana.
ROME, May 13 (UP) -- The newspaper Popolo di Roma reported from Beirut today that the Iraqi Government was preparing a White Book on events leading up to Iraqi-British hostilities.

A record-breaking attendance was reported yesterday for the second in a series of house and garden tours conducted for the benefit of the School Nature League. Six New York homes with river view, penthouse and backyard gardens were opened to the audience of 450 women.

John Kantor, 62 years old, who had been arrested fourteen times since 1924 for various offenses, but never convicted, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions to a term of two and a half to five years in Sing Sing for defrauding a number of men and women of $30,000 by selling them plots in a mythical cemetery.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., May 13 -- The enlisted personnel of New York's old Seventh Regiment, the 207th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft), will have eight-day furloughs, starting about June 1, if plans of Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer, are approved by post authorities here.

Two suits to compel the Singer Manufacturing Company, world's leading manufacturer of sewing machines, to pay dividends out of allegedly excessive and unwarranted accumulations of surplus and undivided profits were disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.
ALBANY, May 13 (AP) -- Britain's battle-scarred freighters, bristling with machine guns and cannon, are beginning to slip into port for grain after an absence of more than a year.

Breaking up of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system, as proposed in the "destructive interpretation" of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act by the Securities and Exchange Commission, would clearly be harmful to the nation's national defense program, Justin R. Whiting, president of the $1,000,000,000 utility system, declared yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 13 -- Severe criticism of Argentina's passive policy toward the European conflict was uttered this morning by Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda at the national convention of the Radical party, which dominates the Chamber of Deputies.

Quality standards represent any manufacturer's stake in his market and constitute an important asset which should be carefully guarded, Merrill A. Watson, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America, warned the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, Inc., at that group's annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The governments of Ecuador and Peru notified Washington today that they would accept the friendly services of Argentina, Brazil and the United States in seeking a final settlement of their century-old boundary dispute.

Early in June, 1792, Gouverneur Morris, our Minister in Paris, dined with the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dumouriez. He presented a letter of congratulations from President Washington to Louis XVI on the beginning of the latter's career as constitutional king, and took up the subject of relations between the United States and France.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 14 -- Rudolf Hess shortly will be faced by Prime Minister Winston Churchill in a private interview affording him the chance to tell the story of his aerial runaway from Germany and to give up vital secrets that might conceivably affect the future course of the war, it was disclosed today.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 13 (AP) -- Captain James Roosevelt delivered a note from his father, President Roosevelt, to King George II of Greece in Crete and then returned to Cairo tonight.

Grievous indeed is the news that 3-year-old Pandora is dead at the Bronx Zoo, for around her there was always laughter, and of this there is not enough in the world. This child of China was the children's friend, a furry sphere done in black and white who had grown from sixty pounds to 260 without acquiring solemnity, who shared with bear and monkey the pleasant trait of loving to please an audience.

LONDON, May 13 (UP) -- "I have come to save humanity," were the first words of Rudolf Hess when he landed by parachute from a Nazi Messerschmitt-110 fighter ten miles from Glasgow, according to information received by American quarters from the British.

SHANGHAI, May 13 (AP) -- United States Marines were called out to restore order today after a spectacular gun battle on Bubbling Well Road, near their barracks, resulted in the wounding of at least ten persons, one of them an American police sergeant.

SHANGHAI, May 13 -- Predicting that a new future Japanese offensive against Chinese government troops would assume even larger proportions than the offensive at present being staged, the Japanese military spokesman today reviewed the combat situation.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nomination of Harry M. Durning for reappointment as Collector of Customs for New York City and Dr. Carl E. Rice to be Senior Surgeon of the Public Health Service, and signed a bill removing a statutory limitation upon further construction at Governors Island.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House voted today, 275 to 63, to raise the crop loan rate from 75 to 85 per cent of parity on cotton, wheat, corn, tobacco and rice.

Organization of the American Friends of Yugoslavia under the chairmanship of Frank L. Polk, who was Under-Secretary of State under President Wilson, was announced after a meeting yesterday at 45 East Sixty-fifth Street, where the new group opened temporary headquarters.

Reciprocal air raids in the Western European and Mediterranean areas and sharp skirmishing at Tobruk and on the portals of the Western Desert marked the continuation yesterday of the desultory war of attrition that is likely to be replaced soon with the surging fury of another campaign.

GLASGOW, Scotland, May 13 (UP) -- The guns of pursuing British Spitfire fighter planes, stitching the fabric of Rudolf Hess's Messerschmitt with bullet holes, nearly robbed Britain of the war's most sensational prisoner before he parachuted to earth, it was revealed today.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 14 -- Residents of various ports and inland cities got surprise treatment from the German Air Force early today when Nazi bombers made only nibbling raids on the east, southeast and south coasts. No raids were reported anywhere in Scotland.

Charles C. Walsey, president of the defunct Burland Printing Company, testified yesterday in General Sessions as the prosecution's principal witness in the Solomon-Mullens bribery trial. The gray-haired Walsey was not the dapper, figure he presented in the early part of 1940 when he testified before former Judge Frederick E. Crane as Commissioner in the Moreland Act investigation into the State printing scandal.

An active demand for veal hindsaddles was the outstanding feature in yesterday's locally dressed meat markets. The demand for hinds and ribs was mostly fair. Pork loins only fair, other classes and cuts mostly fair to good. Pork loins were weak to 5c lower, other classes and cuts mostly' unchanged.
The fourth annual Perfect Baby Contest at the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn was turned into a howling success yesterday when the judges picked a boilermaker's infant daughter as the winner.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday voiced unanimous approval of its officials and praised their honesty and integrity.

AS far as they have gone, the dauntless Dodgers and the clattering Cardinals are the big boys of the National League. The world champion Reds look as though they needed a basketful of those vitamin tablets that Branch the Non-Alcoholic Rickey was feeding his hirelings in their Florida training camp.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Wool requirements of the Federal Government in the 1942 fiscal year, from next July 1 to June 30, 1942, will total approximately 259,000,000 pounds, grease basis, unless the 1,400,000 man army is increased, the Office of Production Management announced today.
OTTAWA, May 13 -- Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley today announced that a $600,000,000 war loan would be issued on June 2. This would be the largest Canadian loan since the beginning of the war.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- America needs a courage and fortitude "which gives a conviction that beyond material things there are things worth living for, and, if need be, worth dying for," Mrs. Roosevelt said tonight in a broadcast to college students.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines reported today a decrease of 476,000 barrels in March in stocks of all oils. Supplies amounted to 559,047,000 barrels, or 136 days' requirements, on March 31, compared with 559,523,000 barrels, or 139 days' needs, on Feb. 28.

Radio's contribution to furthering the interests of democracy was acclaimed yesterday by the Women's National Radio Committee, which announced the results of its seventh annual survey at a salute to democracy luncheon attended by 500 persons at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- British merchant shipping losses in the Battle of the Atlantic in April -- 301,070 tons out of a total of 488,124 tons sunk in all theatres of the war during the month -- were the lowest in eleven months, it was announced today.
Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Air Brigade, a consistent campaigner this season, captured his fourth race in his last six starts by winning the Hastings Purse for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park yesterday.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday touched the highest levels in four years, all the distant months going above 13 cents a pound, reflecting an overnight announcement that Senate-House conferees had recommended a loan of 85 per cent of parity.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House Ways and Means Committee announced today that the Treasury excess profits tax plan probably would be submitted on Friday, which indicated that the hearings on the defense tax bill might run to late in the next week.

Security in the form of approximately $260,000 group life insurance, supplemented by sickness and accident benefits, has been provided for employes of the Titmus Optical Company, Inc., of Petersburg, Va., according to E.H. Titmus, president.

"Major Barbara," the English picturization of the George Bernard Shaw play, will have its local premiere at the Astor Theatre this morning. Wendy Hiller portrays the title role, and Rex Harrison, Robert Morley, Robert Newton Emlyn Williams, Sybil Thorndike, David Tree, Penelope Dudley-Ward and Deborah Kerr are some of the featured players.

The three five-story buildings at the southeast corner of First Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, known as 980-82 First Avenue and 402 East Fifty-fourth Street, have been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to a client of O'Gara Co., brokers.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 13 -- The Greek Legation here revealed today that German General Headquarters in Athens had decreed the death penalty for any Greek found giving asylum to British soldiers.

VICHY, France, May 13 (UP) -- United States Ambassador William D. Leahy today warned Marshal Henri Philippe Petain against supplying Germany with any military aid, amid Nazi assertions that France may be forced back into the war against both the United States and Britain.

CINCINNATI, May 13 -- The gloom that has shrouded the Reds for the past fortnight was deepened by the exuberant Dodgers today as the league leaders took the opener of the two-game series, 4 -- 3, and dropped the 1940 champions mine and one-half games off the pace.

Public offering of 58,710 shares of the 4 3/4 per cent series preferred stock of the Wisconsin Electric Company will be made today by Dillon, Read Co. and associated underwriters at $96.75 a share. At this price it is estimated that the yield on the stock, after deducting the Wisconsin tax of 3 per cent withheld on dividends, will be approximately 4.76 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Indications that plans are under way for some further step by this government in turning the tide of the Battle of the Atlantic were seen here today when President Roosevelt conferred with Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet, and officers directing the Neutrality Patrol operating off the East Coast.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- Pursuing its policy of consolidating its position by withdrawing behind the Dniester River from Lwow to Odessa, the Russian High Command has just completed the withdrawal of the main body of its forces in Bessarabia and has left only light frontier guard formations there with instructions to withdraw if attacked, according to information in usually reliable diplomatic quarters here tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- Several "flag incidents," some of serious proportions, are reported to have occurred along the French Riviera, particularly in the neighborhood of Nice, last Sunday -- a national holiday in honor of France's patron saint, Joan of Arc.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 13 -- While considerable attention is being focused on this quarter, reports emanating from the Balkans today concerning Nazi troop movements indicate that there is cause for concern on the Soviet-German frontier.
LONDON, May 13 -- The picture in London today regarding Rudolf Hess is a picture of complete, absolute confusion, further confounded by censorship.

A sharp upturn in raw cotton prices yesterday, following Washington action on the proposal for 85 per cent of parity for agricultural prices, led to a new wave of activity and price gains in both gray and finished cotton goods.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 -- Mark Ethridge of Louisville, former president of the National Association of Broadcasters, stated tonight that he was resigning his special appointment by President Roosevelt to make a survey of concentration and control in the radio industry because of the Federal Communications Commission's report ordering drastic revisions in the industry's internal structure.

The British and international headquarters of the Salvation Army have been completely destroyed by bombs, but without any loss of life, according to a cablegram received yesterday by Commissioner Edward J. Parker, national secretary of the Salvation Army in the United States, from General George L. Carpenter, international leader of the Army.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- In the presence of Mayor Robert E. Lamberton, Philadelphia today was described as a "decaying" city by Hugh R. Pomeroy, director of the Virginia State Planning Board. He spoke before the National Conference on Planning.

MONTREAL, May 13 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Herald published today a copyrighted, signed article by Otto Strasser, in which he said that the escape of Rudolf Hess from Germany confirmed his belief that "within the national fabric of Germany there is a dry-rot at work that will bring the whole Nazi system to destruction."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 13 (AP) -- A communique of the Iraqi General Staff received here today from Baghdad said:

Eleven young musicians who have pooled their talents and earnings in a musical cooperative venture known as the National Music League, gave their second annual concert yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Like their concert last year, it was called "Artists of the Future."

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13 -- Production of guns for the United States and British Governments at the Colt's Patent Fire Arms Manufacturing Company, one of the nation's largest armament plants, ceased today when a reported majority of the 5,600 employes went on strike.

BERLIN, Wednesday, May 14 (AP) -- As the German Government formally announced today that the northern part of the Red Sea was an operations zone, it was not known publicly here whether any American ships were in the area or en route there.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Adolf Hitler called all high Nazi figures and government leaders to a conference late today soon after the disclosure of Rudolf Hess's flight to Britain, which aroused the German people as they had rarely been aroused in this war.

Concerning the problem of convoys and other similar issues relative to our foreign policy, there is one question which takes precedence over all others, to wit: Is the defeat of Hitler essential to our national welfare? It strikes me that a tremendously large majority of the American people is thoroughly convinced that it is.

George Joseph Cvek, 23-year-old hitch hiker from Steelton, Pa., was quiet and interested yesterday as the opening testimony was taken in his second trial in Bronx County Court for first degree murder in the strangling of 29-year-old Mrs. Catherine Pappas in her apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, last Feb. 4.

Declaring that words capable of expressing his admiration for the English people and the way they have withstood the German air assault do not exist, Alfredo Benevides, Peruvian Minister to Great Britain, arrived here yesterday aboard the Atlantic Clipper.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 13 -- Lack of defensive positions along the southern coast of New Jersey has prompted Major Gen. Henry C. Pratt, commanding the Second Army Corps, to change the "battle plans" for the Forty-fourth Division's five-day manoeuvre in South Jersey next week.

MAMILTON, N.Y., May 13 -- Colgate's slugging baseball team hammered the offerings of three New York University pitchers to all corners of the field today and behind the good hurling of Ebba St. Clair and Bob Shepard trounced the Violet nine, 17 -- 2.
PITTSBURGH May 13 (AP) -- The Pirates and the Phillies staged a bargain basement baseball game today with the Pirates staggering home in front, 6 -- 3.

A luncheon and fashion show for United China Relief will be hold May 22 on the Roof Garden of the Pierre. Mrs. Artemus L. Gates, chairman of the benefit, gave a tea yesterday for the debutante committee to discuss final plans for the event.
The parked car slaying of Harry V. Maxwell, 41-year-old advertising executive, ten days ago appeared solved last night with the arrest of three more men.

LONDON, May 13 -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare issued a statement today expressing "regret" that Sterling Products, Inc., had been depicted as making Bayer aspirin under a German patent as a result of Minister Hugh Dalton's statement May 1 and that "the preamble to the statement appears to have given rise to the wholly unwarranted impression that an agreement between Sterling and German companies was entered into in anticipation, of the present war."
Many Americans yearn hungrily for the crunchy croissants and buttery brioches they happily devoured on a sunny, Parisian boulevard in what formerly was the City of Light.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -- Backing Jack Knott with a twelve-hit attack, the Athletics defeated the Browns today, 7 to 3. It was the first victory of the year for Knott, who allowed seven hits, one of them a three-run homer by Rip Radcliff.

ALBANY, May 13 (AP) -- The man who led New York's Twenty-seventh Division in smashing the Hindenberg line of 1918 believes the United States should be in this war helping England "give Germany two for one in the bombing."

Nearly six years ago an amendment to the State Constitution, passed by a three-to-one State-wide popular vote, gave this city the right to reorganize its county government. The old Board of Aldermen and the City Council refused to do anything about it. Two attempts to get the proposal on an initiative ballot have failed.

J.W. Randall, vice president of the Travelers Insurance Company and Travelers Indemnity Company of Hartford, Conn., was elected president of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives at their annual meeting at 60 John Street yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The National Defense Mediation Board made a new effort tonight to avert a strike affecting 165,000 General Motors employes, set for Thursday at 7 A.M.

Twelve hundred women attended the annual Hadassah Mother and Daughter Tea, held yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Proceeds from the event are to be used to aid Jewish refugees in Palestine and will be devoted specifically to reforestration of that land.

The coronation of a queen yesterday was the signal for 20,000 children to move out into the sun for the next four months. With the selection of Evelyn Imperato, 12 years old, of 23 Jones Street, as queen of the playgrounds, twelve outdoor recreation centers of the Children's Aid Society were officially opened for the Summer.

Entries for the 1941 United States open golf championship closed yesterday with thirteen former champions in the list of approximately 1,040 golfers who will try to win the big prize at the Colonial Country Club, Fort Worth, Texas, June 5-7.

TOKYO, May 13 -- The flight of Rudolf Hess, third highest German leader, to Scotland -- which the press here generally characterized as an "escape" from Germany and which came on the heels of the arrest of Friedrich Minoux, noted German industrialist in Berlin -- created a sensation in Japan, and further reports are awaited here with some anxiety.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 13 (AP) -- Rallying briskly for five runs in the eighth inning, the Buffalo Bisons triumphed by 6 to 4 over the Jersey City Giants today in the third game of a series of four.

Our country finds itself in a curious situation at this moment. By the decisive vote at the elections for Mr. Roosevelt, by the large minority vote for his opponent, who holds views similar to his on the international crisis, by enactment of measures, from the annulment of the embargo to the adoption of the lease-lend bill, that have brought us ever nearer to cooperation with Great Britain, we have thrown neutrality to the winds.

CAIRO, May 13 -- Reliable Cairo sources here reported today that Iraq was taking advantage of a Turkish offer to mediate in the warfare between the British and Iraqis. Egypt had offered to act as mediator, these sources said, but Iraq replied that Turkey's offer had been received first.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- The Cubs "walked" two flights up into fourth place today when Hank Leiber drew a pass with the bases loaded and the. score tied in the seventh inning for a 4-to-3 homecoming victory over the Braves.

We don't get much of a picture of the McLean family, but it seems to consist of David, who is what we in this country would call a farmer, David's mother and David's sister. We are not informed as to the system of land tenure under which David McLean operates.

In the interests of travel, dining and good hostelry the Garden City Publishing Company has issued "Where To Eat, Sleep and Play in the U.S.A.," a compendium edited by Hilda Robbins who, with her husband, formerly ran a travel bureau in Europe and published a guide there known as "Hand-Me-Down."

The two principal defendants in a $750,000 bootleg alcohol ring pleaded guilty at their trial in Federal Court yesterday, with four others accused on the same charge. At the request of Peter J. Donoghue, assistant United States attorney, Judge John C. Knox deferred sentencing until the end of the trial, at which nineteen men and a corporation stand accused.

Two thousand girls from twenty-six elementary Manhattan public high schools and Public School 122, Queens, gathered in Central Park yesterday afternoon to participate in the annual park fete of the Girls Branch of the Public Schools Athletic League.

Yesterday's front page of THE TIMES provided an interesting illustration of the varied means now existing for the collection and transmission of news. Through seven different channels of transmission the reader learned of important happenings. Details of the tragedy of the Brewsters, killed in an airplane crash in Pennsylvania, were collected locally and by telephone.

Dr. Robert M. MacIver, internationally known educator and Lieber Professor of Political Philosophy and Sociology at Columbia University, has been appointed executive officer of the Department of Sociology, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

For the first time in centuries the House of Commons did not meet yesterday in the historic chamber where it was accustomed to sit until the Nazi bombers struck at the Mother of Parliaments. Nevertheless, it met as usual; what's more, the members "laughed heartily."

The annual benefit luncheon, bridge party and entertainment for the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will take place today on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The net proceeds will aid the maintenance of the five health stations supported in this city by the association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Two new musical comedies were scheduled today at Paramount. The studio acquired an option on "Hula Honeymoon," priced at $15,000 by Martin Gosch and Howard Harris, radio writers, as a vehicle for Bob Hope.

A suggestion that Rudolph Hess, Nazi leader who landed in Scotland, be put on trial before an international court was made here yesterday in a cable message sent to Herbert Morrison, British Minister of Home Security. The message was signed by Victor Riesel, managing editor of The New Leader, and Gerhart H. Seger, editor of the German labor weekly Neue Volkszeitung and a former member of the German Reichstag.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 13 (UP) -- Haj Amin el Husseini, the exiled mufti of Jerusalem, leader of nearly 1,000,000 Moslems, tonight broadcast a proclamation over the Baghdad radio summoning all Islam to rise in armed revolt alongside the Iraqi forces and drive the British out of the Near East.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 13 -- In his presidential address to the American Association for Adult Education, Dr. Harry A. Overstreet declared that revitalizing of community life and development of a new kind of concern for young people were essential objectives of American education.
BERLIN, May 13 (AP) -- The German High Command communique today said:
TORONTO, May 13 (AP) -- Hank Borowy of Newark held Toronto to four singles today while notching his fifth victory of the season, a 5 -- 0 shut-out.

National Maritime Union representatives announced last night that their negotiations with ship operators of the American Merchant Marine Institute over war bonuses for seamen had been broken off after yesterday's conference at the office of the institute, 11 Broadway.

Calling not only for delivery, "at whatever risk," of United States war shipments to aid Britain, the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, declared yesterday that "we should now take our full and open part in this conflict."
In a discussion of American aid to Britain last night, Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia told a nation-wide radio audience that half measures would lose the war.

Trailing by two sets, Proviso Prewitt of Trinity rallied to defeat Robert Mulligan of St. John's Prep yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, and retained the tennis championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools.

The four-story apartment house at 2420 Beaumont Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the 657 Crescent Avenue Realty Corporation, Ralph Scocozza, president, to an investing client of Ennis Brothers, brokers, for cash above a mortgage of $13,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 13 (AP) -- The colors of Joseph E. Widener again were carried to victory as Misty Isle, his crack 3-year-old filly, accounted for today's Seneca Park Purse in a driving photo finish at Churchill Downs.

Following his policy of advancing career men in city service, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Chief Engineer Patrick Quilty of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity would become head of the department to replace Joseph Goodman, who died last Friday.

Since Sept. 5, 1939, the Bank of England has a fixed price for bar gold of 168s per fine ounce, which is the highest on record. Prior to outbreak of war on Sept. 1, high record was 150s 5d on Jan. 4, 1939.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- The Montgomery Ward Co. mid-Summer flyer, put into the mails today, cuts prices as sharply as did the Sears flyer circulated late last week among mail order customers and covers many lines not listed in the competition catalog.

Most of the difficulty an advertiser experiences with the Federal Trade Commission is due to application to words of rigid, narrow meanings and interpretations confined to their strict medical or legal sense, Dr. Frederick J. Cullen, executive vice president of the Proprietary Association, said yesterday in an address before the advertising section of the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures voted today 9 to 7 for a provision limiting to $35 an ounce, the present value, the President's powers to devalue the gold content of the dollar.

QUINCY, Fla., May 13 (AP) -- A.C. Williams, a 22-year-old Negro arrested for attempted assault upon a 12-year-old white girl, was found dead soon after daybreak today on a creek bridge north of here, his body riddled by bullets from a masked band.
The names under which Arnold Constable grouped the styles it showed yesterday -- there were morning and afternoon presentations -- carried the story of their purpose.
BERLIN, Wednesday, May 14 -- In a tersely worded communique the Germans early this morning officially proclaimed the northern portion of the Red Sea a zone of military operations.

The report of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for 1940, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $123,886,346 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $4.54 each on the 27,283,587 capital shares outstanding at the end of the year.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Defense awards announced today by the War and Navy Departments amounted to $7,888,019.62. Contracts in the New York area, not previously published, were:

PURCHASE, N.Y. May 13 -- One of the largest fields to take part in a one-day event of the women's Metropolitan Golf Association gathered today when 101 players teed off over the rolling, well-wooded Century Club course in the association's second tournament of the season.

Three hundred and twenty-five assorted tulips, beautifully arranged in twenty baskets, and exhibited by J.P. Morgan, received the gold award at the Horticultural Society show yesterday afternoon at the organization's headquarters at 598 Madison Avenue.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12 -- The American Hockey League accepted a new team -- the Washington Ulines -- into its circuit today, and drafted a schedule of matches for next Season.

In carrying forward its integration program for the utility industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission is charged by law with protecting many interests, not the least important of which is the interest of consumers of utility services.

PICK some grapes of wrath in Ann Arbor, stow them in a leaky crock from February Hill, add some of the typical frankincense and myrrh of Tobacco Road, and you have approximately the bouquet of an astonishing first novel by 22-year-old Maritta Wolff, which is to say "Whistle Stop,"* which is also to say the winner of the 1940 Avery Hopwood award.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 -- Morton Cooper, the Cardinals' Missouri-born righthander who doesn't mind defying the elements of chance by wearing No. 13 on the back of his uniform, had a bit of luck on this thirteenth day of the month and most of it was good.

Transportation of British troops to Freetown, British West Africa, on the 22,424-ton liner Monarch of Bermuda on April 26 was reported by crew members of the West African Line freighter West Kebar, which arrived at Pier 37, Pioneer Street, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Billy Marquart, Winnipeg lightweight, evened his score with Al Roth last night at the Broadway Arena when he scored a technical knockout in the seventh round, the house physician ordering the contest stopped because Roth had a fractured rib.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 13 -- The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America enthusiastically approved today a report of the public information committee submitted by Emmett F. Connely, president of the association and salaried chairman of the committee.

BERLIN, May 13 -- The mystery surrounding the dramatic flight of Rudolf Hess, who, until he took off from Augsburg for Scotland at 6 P.M. last Saturday, was a Reich Minister, the personal deputy of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and the second in line of succession to the title of supreme leader of the German nation, received no clarification in official quarters today.
PHILADELPHIA, -Iay 13 -- The A'my Quartermaster today awardbid opening on _opril 29 by 50 per cent. This is the ma.xinum increase the government can make under its "increase or decrease" option.

Title plants and equipment of the Fidelity Title and Guaranty Company, formerly at 1 Park Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, and of the Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Sullivan County, formerly in Monticello, have been purchased by the City Abstract Corporation, an affiliate of the City Title Insurance Company.

Resolutions of the New York County Lawyers Association and of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York remind us of an admirable New York custom. That is the union of both parties on judicial nominations or renominations of the highest character. Justice Alfred H. Townley was appointed to the Supreme Court bench by Governor Smith to succeed Robert Wagner, elected to the United States Senate.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market last week numbered 775 as against 533 in the preceding week and 596 in the same period a year ago, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Buyers listed yesterday were 374, which compared with 239 reported last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Sid Hudson held the Tigers to three hits as the Senators connected for eight to defeat the American League champions, 5 to 4, today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Industrial banking companies in the United States lent $137,800,000 to consumers in the first three months of this year, an increase of 8.3 per cent over the first quarter of 1940, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, May 14 -- The Japanese drive in South Shansi has assumed the proportion of major operation that may be the prelude to a drive on Sian or even an invasion of Szechwan Province from the north.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- Support from officers of their international union was announced today by A.F. of L. machinists who are on strike against eleven shipbuilding plants in the San Francisco Bay area, the announcement coming as the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce telegraphed to President Roosevelt urging his personal intervention in the tie-up of more than $500,000,000 of naval and Maritime Commission construction.

Frank Dixon, Monroe's Negro ace, holder of the national interscolastic indoor nigh school and city P.S.A.L. indoor titles, accounted for his fifth important mile triumph this year yesterday when he won the open mile in the superb time of 4:26.3 at the third annual Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades track and field games at McCarren Park, Brooklyn.

After an extensive career in Europe before Blitzkrieg and surrender, Claude-Andre Puget's "The Happy Days" has found its way to Broadway. It was acted at Henry Miller's last evening in an excellent adaptation by Zoe Akins. To avoid rueful political considerations, Miss Akins has transposed Mr. Puget's story of puppy love to an island in the St. Lawrence River, where characters with French names are French Canadians.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- This capital, like this people, has been pining for good news from the war in Europe. A full day's reading of official and newspaper reports (thus far virtually the same) has brought conviction that Rudolf Hess's flight to Scotland is good news.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 13 -- Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador, began his expected talks with the Turkish Government today as Axis circles openly discussed the possibility of sending aid through Syria to help out the beleaguered forces of Rashid Ali Beg Gailani in Iraq.

Operation of the Dyre Avenue-180th Street section of the old New York, Westchester Boston Railroad in the Bronx as part of the city's rapid transit system will start tomorrow with Mayor La Guardia, Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons, John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, other city officials and civic groups riding on the first train, which will leave 180th Street at 11:25 A.M.

Colonel William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan will make his first public speech since his return from war scenes in Europe and Africa when he shares the platform Sunday with Mayor La Guardia and Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes at the observance of I Am an American Day on the Central Park Mall.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Roosevelt signed legislation today which will permit removal of important War Department radio communications from Bedloes Island, upon which the Statue of Liberty is situated, to Governors Island, also in New York Harbor.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,756,100 barrels daily, an increase of 249,000 over the 3,507,100 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 43,600 barrels less than the calculation of 3,799,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for May.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the National Sponsoring Committee of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, and asked the support of other American leaders for the undertaking.

A duplex apartment containing fourteen rooms at 834 Fifth Avenue has been leased to Albert H. Diebold, president of Sterling Products, Inc., through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., one of the apartment rentals reported yesterday disclosed.

GLASGOW, Scotland, May 13 (AP) -- Rudolf Hess told his captors how he secretly fitted an extra gasoline tank to a fighter plane and flew a straight line from Augsburg, Germany, to Scotland with the route marked in blue pencil on a map.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Dr. Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu, the new Foreign Minister of Argentina, and Senora de Ruiz-Guinazu arrived here this afternoon from New York for a four-day official visit. An official reception committee headed by Secretary and Mrs. Cordell Hull met them at Union Station.

BERLIN, May 13 (UP) -- German U-boats attacking a strong British convoy protected by destroyers over a period of several days have sunk thirteen merchantmen, totaling 76,248 tons, the High Command said today, repeating an announcement made last night by the official D.N.B. news agency.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- J.M. Mehl, chief of the Commodity Exchange Administration, warned the heads of eighteen commodity exchanges in a letter today that "excessive speculation" in vital food and clothing materials might lead to the closing of all commodity futures markets.
Leases in buildings along the ave- 1 nues in the Fifties and in the] downtown area predonainated in the reports of business rentals submltted yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 13 -- Charges that "a Communist" employed as investigator for the La Follette Civil Liberties committee had taken documents from the Los Angeles Police Department files were made at the Harry Bridges deportation hearing today.

While Frank Tosa was holding Brooklyn College to two safeties, City College banged out thirteen hits, all singles, off Shanty Cogan to score an easy 7-1 victory at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. Tosa would have had a shut-out if his mates had given him better support in the first inning, when Brooklyn scored its lone tally without benefit of a hit.

Enforcement of Federal regulations against the sale of slack-filled packages will be assumed in part, so far as the spice trade is concerned, by members of the spice grinders group, according to a motion approved yesterday at a meeting of the grinders division at the annual convention of the American Spice Trade Association in the Hotel Astor.

ON BOARD H.M.S. BARHAM, May 13 (Reuters) -- The heaviest and most spectacular night barrage yet seen was flung up by more than thirty warships when enemy planes last week attempted a night torpedo attack at sea against the British Eastern Mediterranean forces.

The dinner dance and entertainment to be given tonight in the Garden of the Ambassador for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., has received such a large advance subscription that the Embassy Suite adjoining the Garden will also be opened for the occasion.

BUXTON, N.C., May 13 -- Last night at the East Hook, a mile or two east of the lighthouse, a few anglers happened to be at the right place at the right time with the right lures. And within fifteen minutes there were fourteen channel bass flapping on the sand above the high-water mark.

James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, and Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president, were re-elected yesterday without opposition to one-year terms. The election was held at the board's annual meeting at its headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

While advertising agencies are showing renewed interest in television, now that the Federal Communications Commission has approved its commercialization, numerous obstacles will hinder its rapid progress as an advertising medium, agency men said yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 13 -- Ante Pavelitch, the President of "Independent Croatia," who plotted the 1934 assassination of King Alexander and who directed the Croat April revolution, which exposed the Yugoslav Army's flank and rear and led to the Yugoslav defeat, will die by assassination, this correspondent was informed in Serbia last week by Serbian and Montenegrin komitaji chieftains.
LONDON, May 13 -- Announcement has been made of the death of the Earl of Suffolk and Berkshire, who was killed by a bomb last Monday.

From London comes the news that an American method of photographing German cities, dockyards and other strategic positions by night has been used with brilliant success by the Royal Air Force. "Brilliant" is the right word because of the illumination that makes the performance possible.

Sol Finger, southpaw, gave only two hits and fanned ten as Washington blanked Monroe, 1 -- 0, in a Manhattan-Bronx P.S.A.L. clash yesterday. In the same loop Morris halted Commerce, 3 -- 2, Norm Keese doubling Tim Seitz home in the last half of the ninth with the winning tally.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- There was no official reaction tonight from the White House or the State Department to the decision of the German High Command to designate the Red Sea as a war zone where neutral shipping is in danger, but neither was there the slightest indication that President Roosevelt would alter his recent decision to permit American merchant ships to enter those waters.

Infant mortality in New York City dropped last week to 26.7 per 1,000 live births, the second time this year that the rate has fallen below 30, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was informed yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the city Health Department.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that she gave a lecture in Los Angeles recently, although she knew that a threat had been made to shoot her if she spoke.

George Selkirk had a good view of it. With his back pressed against a rightfield box, Twink watched Lou Boudreau's fly ball float over his head for a home run that gave the Indians a dramatic 2-1 ten-inning victory over the Yankees at the Stadium before 27,130 spectators yesterday.

The possibility that price fixing may be avoided temporarily on copper and brass scrap was seen yesterday by waste material dealers, following a series of conferences with the government. These scrap classifications have not been involved in runaway markets, such as were experienced in aluminum, zinc and nickel scrap but they have become tighter, indicating some sort of government action may be taken.

Two Archbishops and twenty-four Bishops will be among the prominent members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy attending a solemn pontifical mass to be celebrated by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman at 10 A.M. tomorrow at St. Patrick's Cathedral in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the New York prelate's first mass.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including W.H. Newbold's Sons Co. and the First of Michigan Corporation won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,450,000 Sussex County, Del., highway-improvement refunding bonds. The issue is dated May 15, 1941, and will mature serially from Nov. 15, 1943 to 1973.
Work on $30,000,000 worth of guns for this country and Britain was halted when employes of the Colt's Patent Fire Arms Manufacturing Company went on strike at Hartford yesterday. [Page 1, Column 1.]
With perfect weather prevailing, Hunter College's first all-out field day was held yesterday afternoon at the Bronx buildings of the college, Navy Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate is headed into a show-down fight on convoys when it brings up tomorrow the bill authorizing the President to requisition idle foreign ships in American ports. Senator Tobey still is determined to offer an anti-convoy amendment and force a record vote on it, insisting that it will be "a vote for or against war."

A new high in the monthly output of Cyclone and Whirlwind aircraft engines was announced yesterday to the heads of eleven Latin-American naval general staffs who visited the Wright Aeronautical Corporation's works at Paterson, N.J.

The intercoastal steamship trade has placed forty freighters, amounting to between 300,000 and 400,000 gross tons, at the disposal of the Maritime Commission as its contribution to the 2,000,000-ton ship pool called for by President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the operators to discuss the commission's tonnage request.

Renomination of Justice Alfred H. Townley of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court was unanimously recommended by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its annual meeting last night at which William D. Mitchell was elected president, succeeding Samuel Seabury.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A resolution proposing Senate investigation of recent regulations by the Federal Communications Commission designed to stimulate competition in the radio broadcasting industry, was offered today by Senator White of Maine.

What the Hudson Guild has practiced for many years in its own section of New York, American communities from the Atlantic seaboard to the Pacific Coast have taken up energetically on behalf of the men in the United States Army camps, Mark A. McCloskey, formerly a member of the Guild staff, said yesterday at the settlement's forty-fifth anniversary observance at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Shifted for the first time from New York City, the match for the United States chess championship between Samuel Reshevsky and Israel A. Horowitz was resumed here today when the sixth game was drawn at the Mercantile Library.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in the Western Desert, May 12 (Delayed) -- Three German motorized columns broke through Benito Mussolini's barbed wire along the Egyptian border this morning, advanced roughly thirty miles eastward toward the area southwest of Sofafi and then, after meeting advanced British mechanized forces and being attacked heavily and effectively from the air, withdrew toward the points near Solum from which they had started.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A resolution proposing Senate investigation of recent regulations by the Federal Communications Commission designed to stimulate competition in the radio broadcasting industry, was offered today by Senator White of Maine.

What the Hudson Guild has practiced for many years in its own section of New York, American communities from the Atlantic seaboard to the Pacific Coast have taken up energetically on behalf of the men in the United States Army camps, Mark A. McCloskey, formerly a member of the Guild staff, said yesterday at the settlement's forty-fifth anniversary observance at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Shifted for the first time from New York City, the match for the United States chess championship between Samuel Reshevsky and Israel A. Horowitz was resumed here today when the sixth game was drawn at the Mercantile Library.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in the Western Desert, May 12 (Delayed) -- Three German motorized columns broke through Benito Mussolini's barbed wire along the Egyptian border this morning, advanced roughly thirty miles eastward toward the area southwest of Sofafi and then, after meeting advanced British mechanized forces and being attacked heavily and effectively from the air, withdrew toward the points near Solum from which they had started.

Threat of another tie-up of the nation's soft coal mines, with resultant impairment of national defense production, arose yesterday as a consequence of a deadlock in the negotiations between Southern operators and representatives of the United Mine Workers for a new agreement.

Young men eligible for conscription under the Selective Service Act will receive an opportunity to join the Naval Reserve, where they will be on active duty only for the duration of the limited emergency, it was announced yesterday by Commander F.K. O'Brien, officer in charge of the Navy Recruiting Bureau at 90 Church Street.

Acting on the protest of the membership, the Actors Equity Council yesterday took steps to throw out the exclusive service clause from contracts when the basic agreement with the League of New York Theatres expires on Labor Day. Although the council formally adopted the new policy several weeks ago, it was not made public until yesterday.

Assets aggregating $92,573,000, from which the Electric Bond and Share Company received an income of $5,928,810 in the year ended on March 31, are "threatened" by a recent ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission, should it become effective, C.E. Groesbeck, chairman of the holding company, said yesterday in his quarterly report to stockholders.
TRENTON, N.J., May 14 -- Taxes of nearly $40,000,000 assessed by the State for 1937 and 1938 against railroads operating in New Jersey were upheld today by the State Board of Tax Appeals.

Efforts by both miners and operators to avoid a strike in the anthracite coal industry were seen yesterday when a third extension of the contract covering 100,000 hard coal miners, mostly in Pennsylvania, was announced by the joint subcommittee of mine owners and the United Mine Workers of America now engaged in negotiating a new wage contract at the Hotel Commodore.

Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian evangelist, whose work in behalf of the poor and of world brotherhood has made him a leader of Christians in Japan, expressed surprise in an interview yesterday afternoon in the Japanese Institute, Rockefeller Center, at apprehensions in this country of possible war between Japan and the United States.

Three films new to New York will make their appearance today in local houses. RKO's "The Devil and Miss Jones" will be the newcomer at the Radio City Music Hall. The comedy stars Jean Arthur and features Charles Coburn, Robert Cummings, Edmund Gwenn, Spring Byington, S.Z. Sakall and William Demarest.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Army and the Navy awarded contracts totaling $54,725,775 today. Awards, not previously announced, going to firms in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut follow:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 14 -- The New Jersey State champion, Charley Whitehead, was the only player able to cope with the Garden City Golf Club's par as the amateurs of three districts tuned up for tomorrow's battle for the Stoddary Trophy.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) -- The veteran Bob Klinger pulled a ball game out of the fire today for Pittsburgh with a fine sample of relief hurling and a timely double, enabling the Pirates to beat Philadelphia, 12 to 7.

LOUIS HALLE Jr., author of "Trans-Caribbean," "Birds Against Men" and now "River of Ruins,"* had an exciting vacation several Summers ago in a part of the world that few Americans have seen. There is a large river emptying into the Gulf of Mexico -- or, more exactly, into the Bay of Campeche. It is known as the Usumacinta.

LIMA, Peru, May 6 -- It was learned today that Peruvian officials expect that Japan, which took about one-third of Peru's cotton crop of 1940, will buy as much as one-half of this year's crop. Much will depend upon available shipping.

LONDON, May 14 -- United States Ambassador John G. Winant told the English-speaking Union today that "wise use of the navies of the world will decide the destinies of the world's free peoples," inferentially advocating immediate American convoys.

Despite favorable weather, men's wear business here this week did not have the snap to it that retailers would like to see. Volume ran ahead of last year, but local business is not improving at the rate shown in some other centers. Some stores did a good business on tropical worsteds, promoting them vigorously, but regular Spring clothing demand lagged. Sports outfits and furnishings came in for more attention.
TORONTO, May 14 (AP) -- Newark and Toronto divided honors in a double-header today.

VICHY, France, May 14 (UP) -- Denying any intention of persecuting Jews in France, the Propaganda Ministry announced tonight that with certain exceptions they would be classed as foreigners and hence subject to a new restrictive statute being studied by the government.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- By a vote of 75 to 2 the Senate gave final approval today to legislation which would give to producers of wheat, corn, cotton, tobacco and rice government loans up to 85 per cent of parity prices. The conference report on the bill was approved, 275 to 63, by the House yesterday and the measure now goes to the President.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Navy is turning around the eagle which figures so prominently in its insignia, after discovering that the bird has been facing the wrong way for more than a century.

European dominance of the South American drug market has been broken, and American companies should now proceed with vigorous development of that market, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, declared yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 14 -- The Radical party convention today adopted a resolution reaffirming Argentina's neutrality, rejecting totalitarian ideologies, expressing sympathy for nations that are fighting for democracy and stressing "the urgent necessity for a policy of inter-American understanding."

BUFFALO, May 14 (AP) -- The Railroad Yardmasters of North America urged today that Congress pass legislation forbidding aliens to hold labor union offices, and providing a sixty-day cooling-off period before a strike could be called. In a resolution adopted unanimously the convention declared such legislation "would play a major role in reducing labor troubles to a minimum."

Earnings of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation this year are running about the same as last year, Harold Kingsmill, vice president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. In February the company sold 8,700,000 pounds of its copper stocks in this country for delivery through the balance of the year.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 14 -- A nip-and-tuck battle for top honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association developed today among three of the district champions. Forty-eight players reported scores in the event at the Meadow Brook Club.

Moving with unusual speed, the grand, jury yesterday in twenty minutes returned an indictment of murder in the first degree against three men, charging them with the shooting of Harry Vance Maxwell, 41-year-old advertising executive, during an attempted hold-up early in the morning of May 4.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 15 -- The threatened strike of General Motors Corporation employes, scheduled for 7 A.M. today, has been postponed for twenty-four hours, it was reported just before 3 A.M., today.

The possibility that the flight of Rudolf Hess to Scotland was part of a Nazi scheme to trick Great Britain was decried yesterday by Sir Norman Angell, British economist and Nobel Peace Prize winner, who commented: "He's too expensive to the Nazi people to be used as a Trojan horse."
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- American women spend considerably more for stockings than they spend in the country's 83,071 beauty parlors.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- It is generally expected that Congress will sustain today's excision by a Senate committee of the Cox amendment to the Vinson priorities bill. This amendment transferred from OPM to a legislative agency a number of priority activities of the executive branch, but made the Joint Army and Navy Munitions Board superior to the civil administrator.

Alice Decker will demonstrate wood carving at the Sculptors Guild outdoor show today. She is working on a cherry wood statue called "Flight." On Saturday, at 3 o'clock, Louise Cross will also demonstrate wood carving. Rosine Snyder, French ballet dancer, will pose in costume for Adolf Wolff on Sunday, for a figure to be modeled in clay.

LONDON, May 14 -- Britain has rejected Japanese complaints and has made a new protest to Tokyo over Japanese discrimination against British interests in China, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today. He said the Japanese need expect no consideration as far as trade with Britain was concerned until this dispute was settled.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The active intervention of Speaker Rayburn and Secretary Morgenthau served today to cause the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures to reverse the action of yesterday in voting to recommend that the President's power to devalue the dollar be "frozen" at the prevailing price of $35 an ounce of gold.
Perhaps my reasoning may be termed fantastic and unsound; nevertheless, I desire to advance a theory as to the motive for the flight of Rudolf Hess.

While the Bronx Zoo went into mourning yesterday for the death Tuesday of its four-star attraction, comical Pandora, the female giant panda, officials there started mulling over what could be done about getting a replacement for her.

TOKYO, May 14 -- For the first time since his return from Europe Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today received first United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew and then British Ambassador Sir Robert Leslie Craigie at the Foreign Office for a discussion of the situation.

A charge that strikes were sabotaging the defense program and aid to Britain and that the Labor Department "has done nothing to correct the situation" was followed yesterday at the convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New York by the suggestion that Miss Frances Perkins be removed as Secretary of Labor.

Blind staff members of the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, aided by coworkers no deprived of their sight, completed yesterday the packaging of 200,000 phonograph needles to be sent to blind British users of "talking books," recorded on phonograph disks.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The great movement of gold to the United States which has been in progress since the Munich crisis of 1938 has diminished to the level of new gold production; capital which had been flowing in is now flowing out again as a result of United States Government loans to foreign countries and British liquidation of American assets, and the lease-lend act has meanwhile completely altered the basis of American export trade.

From the clear waters of Tangier and Pocomoke Sounds, on the Chesapeake, come new tins of fresh crabmeat. They are brought to us by a company long famous for the excellence of its oysters, that is now turning its attention to another member of the shellfish family.

CHUNGKING, China, May 14 -- Ending thirty-four years of consular and diplomatic service in China, United States Ambassador Nelson T. Johnson left by plane today for Hong Kong. There he will board a Clipper plane for the United States next Wednesday.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 14 -- Launching another telling raid against the Germans on a scale large enough to be termed a "limited offensive operation," British troops from Tobruk, Libya, destroyed two German tanks and inflicted many casualties, it was announced today.

Former Governor Philip F. Lafollette of Wisconsin last night denounced Secretary Stimson and Secretary Knox as "two Republican jokers running wild in the New Deal" who were pushing the nation "to the brink of war."

Prices of the principal farm commodities skyrocketed yesterday in the the wake of Congressional approval of higher loan rates for this year's crops and crowded securities out of the picture temporarily. While wheat futures in Chicago reached the dollar mark for the first time since May, 1940, stock prices were chilled by the threat of labor disturbances which would vitally affect the coal, automotive and railroad industries.

For eight years the Ellenstein-Franklin Democratic-Republican machine has run the city government of Newark. Tuesday Mayor Ellenstein and Public Works Director Franklin were beaten as candidates for the City Commission that elects the Mayor. The machine elected but two Commissioners.

Seven leading industrial companies received last week direct defense contracts from the government equal to 9.7 per cent of their entire 1939 sales. Defense awards for these concerns in the seven days to May 10 amounted to $21,237,000, compared with 1939 sales of $218,632,000.

Charles C. Walsey spent another session in the General Sessions witness chair yesterday as the principal accuser of William Solomon, Harlem Tammany Assembly district leader, and Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, on trial for bribery.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced 10 cents to a top of $9.10 today, reaching the high for the year established on April 7. Smaller receipts and a firmer dressed pork market were credited by livestock men with stimulating the upturn. Good and choice 180 to 330 pound weights sold between $8.90 and $9.10.

MONTREAL, May 14 (AP) -- Dr. Otto Strasser, the anti-Nazi "Black Front" leader, predicted in an interview today that Germany would attempt to invade Britain as quickly as possible as a result of the flight of Rudolf Hess.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 14 -- Emphasizing the necessity for creating a zeal and an enthusiasm for our national defense program by showing how and why we are preparing "to maintain our liberties and the civilized values we cherish," Dr. John W. Studebaker.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -America's growing big cities accounted for nearly all the nation's population increase in the last decade.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), May 14 -- The strength shown in yesterday's market lasted to carry over into today and the market was listless although it rallied toward the close. Royal Dutch was steady at 2424, Amnsterdam Trading slightly higher at 430, _Amsterdam Rubber down 2 at 271 and Philips off 2 at 219.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed June 14 as Flag Day and, calling for public and private celebrations, declared that the principles of unity and freedom symbolized by Old Glory are under attack.

A year ago next month the Italian Fascists entered the war in the obvious hope of sharing in the loot of France, which was already beaten, and of the British Empire, whose surrender they believed to be imminent. From the Fascist point of view the intervening months have been disappointing.

Sipping tea became somewhat of a problem yesterday for Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie. She had accepted the invitation of two small Britishers, Emi Lou Kinloch, 10 years old, and Valerie Hambro, 11, to join them at tea at the James Robinson Galleries, 716 Fifth Avenue, where she was viewing hundreds of museum pieces of miniature silver on display there for the benefit of the British War Relief Society.

It took Princeton's unbeaten sophomore ace, Roy Talcott, the better part of three hours and ten innings to subdue Columbia's baseball team at Baker Field yesterday and run his record to seven straight victories. Some poor support gave Talcott most of his trouble and he earned his triumph, not alone with his pitching arm, but also with his bat.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved irregularly upward in active trading and the close reflected net gains of 5 to 14 points on the session, The opening was strong and to 14 points up in anticipation of adoption by the Senate of the bill calling for loans of 85 per cent of parity on the basic farm crops, including cotton.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 (AP) -- The fifteenth communique of the Iraqi General Staff, received here today from Baghdad, said:

Warning that anti-labor interest were intent on breaking the Transport Workers Union as an example of what could be done to aggressive labor organizations, John Santo, international secretary and treasurer of the union, declared last night that Mayor La Guardia was being used as a tool by interests that hate labor.

ST. CHARLES, Mo., May 14 (AP) -- The charter of the Union Electric Company of Missouri, $250,000,000 tri-State utility, was declared forfeited and the company was fined $175,000 today by Circuit Judge Edgar B. Woolfolk for violation of the State Corrupt Practices Act. If the fine is paid within 120 days, there will be a stay of execution as to the ouster, the judge said.

Representatives of the leading intercoastal steamship operators will meet today at 80 Broad Street to work out details of the transfer of forty or more intercoastal cargo carriers to the government's newly organized route to the Red Sea.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in the Western Desert, May 13 (Delayed) -- The German columns that lunged toward Sidi Barrani, Egypt, from the Solum area yesterday have been checked. British pilots returning from reconnaissance flights today reported that all five of the German columns had halted or were withdrawing.

BERLIN, May 14 -- Informed quarters in Berlin declared today that Rudolf Hess, who until his precipitous flight to Scotland last Saturday was Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Deputy and second in line of succession, directed numerous writings to various German leaders before his departure.

What was probably the most comprehensive test of the effectiveness of continuity in newspaper advertising ever attempted has been completed by the H.J. Heinz Company and the results have encouraged the company to plan the largest Fall newspaper campaign in the history of the organization, according to a statement released yesterday by Franklin Bell, advertising manager.
The wheels of industry in this State are turning faster and faster to meet the needs of national defense, and new machines daily are going into production to turn out vital goods.

Protests against a proposed increase in the prices to be paid farmers for fluid milk to a year-round minimum that would raise the retail cost of milk 2 cents a quart were made yesterday by representatives of twenty parent, neighborhood and welfare organizations at the opening of a public hearing on proposed amendments to the Federal-State milk marketing orders governing the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Exports of raw cotton by the United States in April amounted to 74,000 bales valued at $4,345,000, compared with 345,000 bales a year previously, and worth $20,653,000, the Department of Commerce made known today. In March outward shipments were 97,000 bales, with a value of $5,813,000.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved today with amendments a House bill authorizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to set up public corporations to build and operate defense plants when private industry is found unwilling or unable to supply the defense products required.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 14 -- Yale won from Wesleyan at baseball today, 12 to 3. A double and a homer by Harrison and Wood, respectively, in the opening stanza gave Yale a 4-0 lead. In the third Kaye doubled for Yale and Riege walked Wood and both came home on Whelan's single.

Although letters requesting their cooperation were mailed only a few days ago, eleven clubs have already signified their intention of aiding the British War Relief Society in its sponsorship of a one-day national handicap golf tourney on June 14.

FERNANDINA, Fla., May 14 -- Completing its first actual firing mission with 3-inch anti-aircraft guns today, the 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh Regiment, prepared to break camp tomorrow morning and move back to Camp Stewart in Georgia, where it is garrisoned.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A unanimous decision to strike from the Vinson Priorities Bill the Cox amendment establishing an independent statutory priorities board was reached by the Senate Military Affairs Committee today after officials strongly opposed it.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- The sudden death of General Taha al-Hashimi, pro-British Premier of Iraq who was ousted in the coup d'etat of Rashid Ali Beg Gailani, was reported in roundabout advices reaching here today. Reuters [British news agency] said the report was received by the Swiss Telegraph Agency in a message from Baghdad via Milan.

Nothing that can happen in this country is better grist for the Nazi propaganda mill than a lynching. Even though the number of such killings has declined in recent years; even though we are, on the whole, a law-abiding nation and, on the whole, give every ac...

ANKARA, Turkey, May 14 -- A personal message of friendship from Reichsfuehrer Hitler was delivered to President Ismet Inonu this afternoon by Franz von Papen, the recently returned German Ambassador. Herr Hitler's words were transmitted to the President in the presence of Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu.

Companies and employe groups are increasing their contributions to the Greater New York Fund this years, James A. Farley, chairman of the fund's 194l campaign, declared yesterday in an address to employes of James McCutcheon Co., Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.

Sam Byrd has quite an ambitious program outlined for next season, having just added a third prospect called "Give a Viva." It is the Erskine Caldwell-Harold J. Rome musical show, formerly entitled "Man from Mexicana," and is intended for October production.

A formal protest to Leon Henderson, director of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, against rising prices of cotton gray goods was sent yesterday by S.L. Hoffman, president of the House Dress Institute, comprising manufacturers of dresses retailing from 69 cents to $1.95, Mr. Hoffman announced.

The League of Young Americans, incorporated four months ago to provide school and college students with arguments against un-Americanism, will form an orchestra to champion American music and to bring national attention and support to the league, it was announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 14 -- Diplomatic quarters here predict France's immediate entry into the "European community of nations" in exchange for a large readjustment of the demarcation line to include Paris in the "unoccupied zone of France," the gradual release of about half of the 2,000,000 war prisoners, the reduction to approximately half of the present 400,000,000 francs daily occupation "tribute" and German frontier control.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Representatives of eleven large shipbuilding yards on the Great Lakes met with the Maritime Commission today to discuss the possibility of using their facilities to build ocean-going freighters as part of the defense program.

PELHAM, N.Y., May 14 -- A resolution favoring the use of the Navy to assure delivery of arms to Britain "when and if the military authorities of the government see fit" was adopted tonight by a two-to-one vote of 600 Pelham town residents at a mass meeting to discuss the aid-to-Britain question at the Pelham Memorial High School.

The report of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., for the three months ended on March 31, released for publication today, shows a net profit of $9,239,709 after all charges, depreciation and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 60 cents a share on 14,584,025 common shares.

Although the weather is favorable to the introduction of straw hats, advertising campaigns will not break until the latter part of next week, agencies and retailers reported yesterday. Some copy is already in newspaper shops, awaiting a release date, and one or two ads may break within a few days but the bulk of the copy is scheduled for next week.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 14 -- Syracuse University's nine reached three N.Y.U. hurlers for thirteen blows today, seven of the extra-base variety, for a 9-to-6 victory. The loss dropped the Violet below the .500 mark, with nine defeats and eight triumphs.

As in the case of Rudolf Hess, now and then the incredible happens. People trying to recall anything comparable in the realm of the fantastic may not have to go very far back.
