To the numerous vessels already taken in custody may now be added the French vessels upon which American Coast Guards were suddenly placed last night.

In a decision unique in regulatory history the New York State Public Service Commission commended yesterday the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company and the New York Richmond Gas Company for the manner in which they had cooperated with the commission in determining the original cost of their property and in adjusting their books and accounts to conform to sound accounting practices.
Word comes of two Englishwomen killed while on duty as ambulance drivers with the American Ambulance, Great Britain.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 15 -- Notwithstanding a large turnout of sixty-nine players, only two contestants were able to break 90 in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association over the hilly Wykagyl course today.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Beginning June 2 the rationing of food in the Third Reich is to undergo several changes. The most important change announced is the reduction of the meat ration by 100 grams [about 3.3 ounces] a week for all "normal consumers.''
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The nation's defense program is taking a toll of lives, figures at the American Red Cross revealed today.

Administration circles are reported to believe that if the United States could soon send to Britain about 200 heavy bombers, capable of flying up to 3,000 miles, these planes could practically eliminate the threat to vital British shipping from Axis surface raiders and submarines.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $5,309,672 for the fifty-three weeks ended on March 29, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes in the amount of $2,114,911, and a provision for excess-profits taxes in the amount of $593,331.

They paid off again yesterday on that honesty-is-the-best-policy business, this time to the tune of $1,000, the payee being Miss Kathryn Los, who on May 6 found $7,500 in two packages on the sidewalk in front of the Empire State Building -- and turned the money over to the nearest policeman.
Frank H. Meischeid, formerly with R.A. Hohfeler Associates, has been appointed controller of Hevlon Products Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Roosevelt was asked in his press conference today to clarify the status of Harry L. Hopkins, who has been ordered to supervise the $7,000,000,000 lease-lend program, with a salary of $10,000 a year, but who has received no publicly announced title.

A small French freighter, one of the eleven taken into custody by Coast Guardsmen Thursday night is expected to force a ruling in Washington within the next few days involving the official attitude of this country toward the Vichy government of France, according to information in shipping quarters.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The United States has fought two undeclared wars, one against the Barbary pirates in the Mediterranean and another against French privateers in the West Indies, President Roosevelt said at his press conference today in recalling that the freedom of the seas represented a long-maintained American policy.

Mr. L. Walter Stephens's recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES outlining his proposed tournament for the chess championship of the world has aroused a good deal of comment. Since I am one of those who would be most directly affected by such a proposal, your readers will doubtless be interested to know why I do not feel that it is acceptable in its present form.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Attorney General Jackson stated today that machinery had been set up for cooperation of the Department of Justice with the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply to prevent price inflation and consumer exploitation as a result of the defense program.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- While the price of wheat held within a range of about 1 1/4 cents a bushel today, most of the business was of a professional character, with rather persistent buying at times which brokers attributed to mills. Prices dipped at one time below yesterday's close, but rallied quickly and closed on the Board of Trade here to 1/4 to 3/5 cent higher.

Opera, ballet and drama presented for the edification of young audiences have been the work of Junior Programs, Inc., a non-profit organization, since its founding five years ago. Miss Gladys Swarthout of the Metropolitan Opera Company and chairman of the sponsoring committee, was the guest of honor yesterday when directors and members of the Programs opera company gathered in the Women's City Club in celebration of their 1,750th performance.

The astonishing All-American Youth Orchestra which Leopold Stokowski has founded and which he conducted last night in Carnegie Hall does not grow old. In fact, it seems to have discovered Ponce de Leon's fountain. That is to say that this orchestra is younger, by an average of two years, than it was last season, the first of its existence, bringing the average age to about twenty-two.
PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- Nine days ago Mace Brown pitched to three Cardinals in the ninth inning and won his first game for Brooklyn. Today he pitched to only one Pirate in the eleventh and lost.

Broadway will not have to wait until June 4 to greet the arrival of "Women Aren't Angels" as the premiere has been advanced to May 29 at the Broadhurst. The Vernon Sylvaine farce, an importation from London, began its pre-Broadway engagement in Boston on Thursday night with Bobby Clark and Melville Cooper at the head of the cast.

As a baseball fan with a profound love for the game, I deplore the growing tendency of the metropolitan press to treat college games with a disdainful levity, ridiculing the number of errors committed by college infielders and the number of hits and passes allowed by the pitchers.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Roosevelt said today that he had neither read nor given advance approval of Federal Communications Commission orders calling for elimination of certain types of radio chain organization.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 16 -- The thirty-fourth Bach festival was opened today in Packer Memorial Church, on the Lehigh University campus, before a large audience of Bach devotees from twenty States.

LONDON, May 16 -- While Cairo announced that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's forecast of bombs on Syria had been fulfilled, the British today took heart of grace from the immediate United States reaction and President Roosevelt's forceful statement on the matter.

VICHY, France, May 16 -- By governmental order French newspapers in the unoccupied zone were sold today at 1 franc, twice yesterday's price. In compensation they appeared on four pages instead of two.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 16 (AP) -- Big Archie Harris, a 210-pound Negro youth from Indiana, did a single-handed and near-world-beating job of handling the "new records" business in the preliminaries of the Western Conference outdoor track and field championships today.

The Appellate Division denied unanimously yesterday the application of Mayor La Guardia for permission to appeal to the Court of Appeals from the unanimous ruling of the Appellate Division two weeks ago directing the Mayor to appear before the City Council committee investigating civil service affairs and to produce documents which he has termed "confidential executive papers."

Action on the New York Stock Exchange's plan for promoting dealer interest in its stocks is scheduled for May 28 at the first meeting of the new board of governors after its organization. The new chairman of the board, Robert L. Stott, is understood to have the system worked out in rough form, ready for presentation to the board.

The eighteenth annual festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music was opened officially late yesterday afternoon with a radio address by James G. McDonald, president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences and former chairman of the executive committee of the Foreign Policy Association, who spoke concerning the orgin and methods of procedure of the society in a broadcast over station WQXR.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Manufacturers, labor leaders and government officials attempted today to thrash out their differences over methods of regulating pay deductions of textile workers for rent and goods purchased at company-owned stores.

In Latin America the United States has a market of great potentialities, capable of absorbing a large part of our manufactured goods but its development, to a great extent, rests with us, A.N. Gentes, assistant manager of the foreign department of the Guaranty Trust Company, pointed out yesterday in a report summarizing exchange conditions in export markets.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The volume of trading in shares in round-lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on May 3 was 2,280,230 shares compared with 2,542,880 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Nineteen hundred khaki-clad cadets, members of the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps, the largest voluntary collegiate unit in the country, held their annual Spring review and decoration ceremonies yesterday in the college's Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The National Defense Mediation Board an nounced late today an agreement to avert a threatened strike of 8,100 workers at the plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, South Bend, Ind. The plant manufactures aircraft carburetors, landing gears, brakes, wheels and other defense equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary Cordell Hull declared in an address today before a special session of the governing board of the Pan American Union that "the present effort to build world mastery by force will be defeated and will end within a reasonable time," but that "we shall have to pass through hardship and sacrifice before the end finally comes."

CAIRO, Egypt, May 16 -- The key Egyptian town of Solum, near the Libyan border, has been stormed and retaken by British troops, the Middle East Command announced today. Halfaya [Hellfire] Pass, in Egypt, and Musaid, in Libya, also were recaptured by the British.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, famous pianist, president of the National Council of Poland and former Prime Minister of that country, appealed last night in a radio address over Station WEAF to Americans to gather all their resources to buy defense savings bonds.

Hitting at opportune moments and profiting on several lapses by the enemy pitchers, Georgetown out-pointed New York University, 17 to 9, in a wild and lengthy baseball skirmish at Ohio Field yesterday.

The Federal Light and Traction Company and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $1,238,424, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, for the twelve months ended on March 31, according to the report made public yesterday

CAIRO, Egypt, May 16 (UP) -- British planes have heavily bombed German-held airdromes in Greece for the first time since the evacuation, it was announced here today. The air fields, from which many Nazi bombers and transport planes are believed to be flying to Syria and Iraq, were raided Wednesday night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (UP) -- Substitute Outfielder Pat Mullin's home run inside Shibe Park, first in the arena in several years, carried the Tigers to a 5-to-4 triumph over the Athletics today. It was Detroit's second victory in a row over Philadelphia.

The Ogden Corporation announced yesterday that it will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan of reorganization for the Interstate Power Company, which operates directly, or through subsidiaries, in Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois, North Dakota and South Dakota.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The House Naval Committee asked the Navy Department today for details on the reported action of a CIO maritime union delegate in blocking the enrollment of seamen by the Navy in the merchant marine reserve.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Creditor approval of the Chicago North Western Railway reorganization plan today left only the pending appeal of stockholders and the dissenting vote of one small group of bondholders separating the road from emergence from bankruptcy.

Opposition to "the mounting burden of Federal and State taxes on tobacco products" was expressed by members of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America at yesterday's session of their ninth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 -- Removal of James Lawrence Fly as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission was demanded by the board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters in convention here in a statement issued today.

This morning's NEW YORK TIMES contains an interesting letter from L. Walter Stephens regarding the possibility of a tournament in New York for the world's chess championship. Although Mr. Stephens paints the project in attractive colors, it is hopelessly impractical for a number of reasons.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Three developments in the Far East are alarming Chungking government leaders who see the possibility of a far-reaching Soviet-Japanese understanding that may not only end Russian aid to China but also bring about cooperation between the Japanese and the Chinese Communist armies.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Three judges are deciding the $60,000 contest to select sculptures for the new War Department building soon to be completed on Virginia Avenue.

The national headquarters of the American Red Cross in Washington has notified chapter chairmen that assurances have been received from the British authorities that navicerts will be issued for bulk shipment of standard food packages and clothing to the International Red Cross Committee in Geneva for distribution among var prisoners of British and Allied nationalities.

A "thoroughgoing study" of new problems complicating higher education in this State, such as conscription of youth, demand for new technical skills in industry, higher taxes on individuals resulting in decreased support for private universities, was recommended yesterday to the State Board of Regents.

Germany as a nation is solidly behind Hitler and there is a general feeling throughout the Third Reich that the war is already won and that nothing the United States can do will alter the situation, Louis Scheel, General manager of the Otis Elevator Company in Germany, Russia and Italy, asserted yesterday upon his arrival here aboard the Yankee Clipper.

Instances of American citizens of Italian or German extraction being barred from work in factories making clothing, glassware and kitchen utensils have been found in New York State by Governor Lehman's Committee on Discrimination in Employment, it was reported yesterday.

Publication and circulation of books by scores of well-known authors is now being prohibited by the Nazi occupying forces in France, it is disclosed in confidential advices received from France by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Roosevelt revealed today that plans for a new civilian defense program are nearly completed and that he hopes to be able to make an announcement on the matter Monday. The program is expected to involve the cooperation of men, women and children in every community in the country.

In laying out Summer advertising plans advertisers and agencies are taking into account the fact that many workers in industrial areas will not get any vacations this year, but will receive bonuses. The pressure for production is forcing plants to continue at top speed during the hot weather months when normally output would taper off.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- Striking C.I.O. and A.F. of L. machinists, who have tied up more than $500,000,000 in naval and Maritime Commission construction in eleven shipyards in the San Francisco Bay area for a week, held stubbornly to their picket lines tonight in the face of almost unprecedented pressure from every interested department of the Federal and State governments.

Retail trade here continued active this week. Department store volume was estimated as running about 8 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year, a figure about equal to that noted since the start of this month. Apparel and accessory trade was brisk, but a large share of the increase continued to be contributed by the home wares sections.

Although nervousness still was evident yesterday, prices of futures, on the New York Cotton Exchange developed moderate strength and closed at net advances of 7 to 8 points. Some encouragement was derived from the President's discussion of the loan bill at his press conference, although he gave no definite indication that he would approve it.
BERLIN, May 16 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

Will it be the "same" Westminster Abbey or St. Paul's or House of Commons when peace comes and the damaged edifices are restored? In essence they will be. The atmosphere of historic continuity in a public monument does not depend on the amount of original brick and stone that lives through the ages.

Much is being said about protecting the wage-earner and the farmer from the proposed taxation for defense. Their economic status must not fall below a certain level. The wealthy, the middle-class -- those earning more than $2,000 a year -- and the corporations are to bear the brunt of heavily increased taxation.
BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

VICHY, France, May 16 -- While political collaboration between France and Germany is still in a state of discussion, there is evidence today to show that economic collaboration has already reached a practical stage.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 16 -- Out of the fifty-six teams to compete in the annual member-guest golf tournament at the Lakeville Club today, only one succeeded in breaking par. That was the combination of Norman Files of the home club and Walter Tynan of Winged Foot.

VICHY, France, May 16 (UP) - Nearly 5,000 foreign Jews of Paris, many of them crying hysterically, arrived at a concentration camp at Orleans today as the government extended its new social measures by withdrawing licenses of hundreds of foreign doctors and druggists.

JERUSALEM, May 16 -- Almost a year has elapsed since Italy entered the war, and the Holy City is still immune to Axis air raids. Though it is hoped the sacred character of this city will continue to be its safeguard against attacks, the authorities are taking no chances and have begun constructing large public shelters in the new city of Jerusalem.

The first published musical composition by Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press, entitled "Dixie Girl," received its broadcast premiere last night over the NBC Red (WEAF) Network, in a half-hour concert beginning at 8 o'clock.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army, which extends from Newfoundland and Maine in the north to Northern Georgia in the south, announced yesterday that the "broad training" program of his command is now well under way. Headquarters of the First Army are at Governors Island.

To commemorate the golden jubilee of the ordination to the priesthood of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of New York, the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South American will hold a special service tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Hellenic Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 317 East Seventy-fourth Street.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16 (AP) -- Each club had a big inning tonight, but the Chiefs got in front and were never headed as they earned an 8-to-5 victory over Newark before 3,500 fans. The result gave the Chiefs a split in the two-game series.

J.J. Shubert unexpectedly capitulated yesterday to the demands of the Theatrical Managers and Agents Union. Receiving two minor concessions, which did not modify the basic agreement, Mr. Shubert made his peace with the union.

Wage disputes and demands for additional war bonuses, which have delayed a dozen American freighters in the last month, were believed settled yesterday, when negotiators for the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute reached an agreement after three weeks of discussion.

lew State and municipal financing scheduled for next veek by forty-nine municipalities aggregates only $5,159,411, compared with $12,961,254 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $39,959,332.

Coming up for their last licks yesterday, the Yankees were a run behind the White Sox at the Stadium, and it looked as if the McCarthymen's losing streak, like the automobile, was here to stay. But up stepped Joe DiMaggio and Joe Gordon, and in a flash the outlook changed.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Senators staged a two-run ninth-inning rally to defeat the Browns, 7 to 6, today. The victory gave Washington an even break in the series.
Slepack Co. dissolved on April 30. Long Co. will be formed on June 2 by John E. Long and H. Ralph Levy.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 16 -- A group of orderlies and maintenance workers at the Elizabeth General Hospital went on strike this morning because, they said, the management refused to bargain with their union on wages and working conditions and also refused to reinstate twenty-five of the employes who allegedly had been dismissed for participation in a one-hour work-stoppage last Tuesday.

The possibility of renewed intervention by President Roosevelt appeared last night to offer the only hope for averting another shutdown of soft coal production next Wednesday. Direct negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the Southern coal operators failed to produce any break in the deadlock over terms of a new contract, and leaders of both groups acknowledged that there was little prospect of progress at another conference called for this afternoon.

LONDON, May 16 (UP) -- Preparing swiftly for the eventuality of war against France, Great Britain tonight proclaimed a new Mediterranean mine zone blocking the coast of French Syria where British planes are bombing air bases used by the Nazi Air Force.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- Discord in the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs over the election of a new president was supplanted by harmony after the choice had been made this afternoon at the organization's forty-second annual convention at the Garden City Hotel, with the loser congratulating the winner and indicating the result was all for the best.

Claire Neikind, who was hired three weeks ago as a $1,200 a year clerk in the registrar's office at City College, was dismissed yesterday after an investigation by college officials of her activities as a member of the American Student Union.

John S. Sinclair, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, has been elected a vice president of the New York Life Insurrance Company, it was announced yesterday by George L. Harrison, president of the company. Mr. Harrison was formerly president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Mr. Sinclair will assume his new post on July 1.
Cotton, cleverly concocted into cool styles at low prices, appeared yesterday at a fashion show at John Wanamaker.

Wholesale trading expanded further this week due to the unusually heavy and early demand for Fall merchandise, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Retail activity held at recent levels and averaged about 15 per cent over last year. Industry was once more operating at capacity, following a brief letdown caused by the coal shortage last month.

The American Export liner Excambion is due to sail today for Lisbon via Bermuda. Her passengers include De Metrie Nicolau, Dr. and Mrs. Manuel Corachan and their daughter, Elena; Theron S. Henderson, Miss Frances E. Willis, John E. Utter and Marcel Y. Le Roux.

Denouncing the collaboration of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's Vichy government with Germany, France Forever, the "Free French" organization in America, issued a formal declaration yesterday giving full approval to seizure of French ships and calling for prompt measures to halt Axis penetration of French possessions, including reprisals against the "misuse" of Syria.

ANKARA Turkey, May 16 -- Turkey is taking all the necessary precautions to protect herself against any threat from the new area of warfare developing around her. Twenty more classes of untrained Moslems from European Turkey were called to Military service today.

The Board of Education, at an adjourned meeting yesterday, awarded contracts for the general construction of three new school buildings that ultimately will cost nearly $6,500,000 and provide accommodations for about 5,000 students.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Reports were circulated today in Republican circles in the House that Charles A. Lindbergh was preparing to reestablish his voting privileges in the Sixth district of Minnesota, in order to run next year for the seat his father held from 1907 to 1917.

The People's Chorus of New York, under Lorenzo Camilieri, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary with a Spring song festival given last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the benefit of the Greek War Relief Association and also as a tribute to Mr. Camilieri, who was born in Corfu, Greece.

Somewhere a connection exists between the Hess affair and the decisions being made at Vichy, and between both and the rapidly evolving policy of the United States. The same interplay of rising forces impelled the official leader of the Nazi party to fly to England, drove Hitler to turn the screws on Marshal Petain and forces the pace of American action.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Contract awards announced today by the War and Navy Departments amounted to $12,475,693.16. Among those not previously published, were the following, which went to firms in the New York area.

Security and commodity markets steadied yesterday after the liquidation of the previous day, but the volume of business was so light that there were frequent lapses of any trading on the floor of the Stock Exchange. It was the smallest session there since early March, with transfers falling.to 287,060 shares from 495,990 on Thursday, and the smallest number of stocks traded since last September.
CHUNGKING, China, May 16 -- Fifty-four Japanese planes carried out a huge bombing raid on this capital this morning, causing extensive damage in the western and northern sections.

A client of Irving Honigsberg, attorney, has purchased from the Brooklyn Savings Bank for cash above a new first mortgage of $25,000 the four-story apartment house on the southwest corner of Henry and Remsen Streets, in the Brooklyn Heights section of the borough. The mortgage runs for five years at 4 and 4 1/2 per cent.

BERLIN, May 16 (UP) -- Authorized Nazi spokesmen gave notice tonight that so far as Germany was concerned the affair of Rudolf Hess was closed, stating in response to correspondents' queries: "We are not interested."

Syria, entrusted to France by mandate of the League of Nations, with which the Vichy Government has now severed connection, can be of immense value to Germany in a drive upon Egypt and the British strongholds in the Near East, if Germany can master it and hold it with or without aid from Vichy.

Friday is a bad day with both charter and party boat skippers, but yesterday those who were docked at both Canoe Place and New Suffolk did a fair business with the opening day chummers, and some really nice weakfish were caught.

Tonight's events: "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," New York La Scala Opera Company, Hollywood Theatre, 8:30. Annette Royak, soprano, Horizon Club, 30 West Fifty-sixth Street, 8:30; Gudrun Ekeland, soprano, American Scandinavian Center, 152 West Fifty-seventh Street, 8:30.

Presentation of plans for revision of the securities acts has been delayed by the manner in which the Securities and Exchange Commission handled the problem with respect to the regional Exchanges. On Monday of last week it summoned the representatives of the small Exchanges, handed 180 pages of printed revisions to them and asked for an agreement on the same day.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had issued a modified order against Gimbel Brothers, Inc., New York City, requiring it to cease misrepresenting the woolen content of products it sells. The modified order, the commission said, is in accordance with the action of the United States Circuit Court of Ap peals, which affirmed the previous order with some changes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- The Army Quartermaster announced today that negotiated contracts have been concluded for the manufacture of 2,120,000 olive drab flannel shirts and 650,000 herringbone twill jackets. The government furnishes the materials and findings, in part, for these supplies.

WHILE reading "The Hero in America"* you are apt, from time to time, to lose track of just what Mr. Wecter is trying to prove, but your interest in the narrative itself, never. For this is, essentially, a chronicle of American history told in terms of outstanding personalities and characters, and written in a smooth, flowing, sympathetically-critical way that suggests elements of Frederick Lewis Allen and Van Wyck Brooks.

While the rising cost of living is attributed by dealers in food commodities in part to the Federal Government's purchase of foodstuffs under the lease-lend law to feed Great Britain, the effects of the law are the subject of a study that the City Department of Markets now has under way.

There was once a France, corrupt, betrayed and cowardly, that was saved by a peasant girl. There was once a France saved by soldiers who were not well armed or well trained, but who were singing a new song that would not let them go anywhere but forward though all hell was mobilized to enslave them again.
Crowds lined Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street yesterday outside of the show windows of The Tailored Woman to observe the latest styles in bathing suits.

Fresh evidence of what happens to the people of a law-abiding and peaceful country when the German Army has crushed out organized resistance and the Nazi Gestapo has taken over control is supplied in the documents seized in the British raid on the Norwegian Lofoten Islands and summarized in a White Paper.

ANKARA, Turkey, May l6 -- Aerial hostilities between France and Britain have now begun over Syria, and it was reported tonight that the Germans and Italians were rushing bombers and fighters to that French-mandated territory.

LONDON, May 16 -- Britain's long series of "war weapons' weeks," which have been running in every city and hamlet for more than seven months, entered their last phase today when Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, asked London to subscribe u100,000,000.

Tomorrow having been set apart by President Roosevelt as "I Am an American Day," pastors will preach on that subject and there will be patriotic services. Tomorrow will mark the opening of annual goodwill week. It will also be observed as National China Sunday under the auspices of the United China Relief.

The text of a cablegram which was sent to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain on his eighty-fifth birthday, April 24, by forty-four Americans who hold the French Cross of the Legion of Honor, urging him "not to yield to Nazi persuasions or threats," was made public here last night.

President Roosevelt was urged to take immediate action to bar Axis penetration into zones endangering hemisphere defense in a statement issued last night by national officers of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.
Mayor La Guardia made an appeal yesterday to New Yorkers to contribute to the Greater New York Fund and designated Monday as Greater New York Fund Day for the city.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- Hogs held steady in a fairly slow market today, maintaining the $9.20 top established yesterday. Good and choice 180 to 330 pound weights brought $8.95 to $9.15, with the extreme top at $9.20. A few 160 to 180 pound offerings sold between $8.65 and $9.10. Good 400 to 500 pound sows went at $8.35 to $8.65.
ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Harry Gumbert, late of the New York Giants, made an auspicious pitching start with the Cardinals today by shutting out Boston, 4 to 0, on six hits.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Overcoming a number of annoying obstacles, including a raw blast of wind from Lake Michigan and intermittent rain, the Giants polished off Jimmy Wilson's Cubs for their second straight triumph today. The score was 4 to 2. A ladies' day gathering of 7,481 drew no satisfaction from the polishing.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Treasury is expected Monday to submit a revised defense tax plan, along with recommendations for increased excess profits taxes to form the keystone of the program to raise $3,500,000,000 by new levies.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 16 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

CAIRO, Egypt, May 16 (U.P.) -- The announcement of the recapture of Solum, Halfaya Pass and Musaid by Britain's reinforced Army of the Nile means that the Italian and German forces have been driven out -- or almost out -- of Egypt for the first time since April 9 when Axis troops swept around Tobruk and reached Egyptian soil.

Robert S. Wallerstein of 1325 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been named valedictorian, and Donald A. Dike of 423 West 118th Street, salutatorian of the Columbia College senior class to be graduated on June 3, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.

TOKYO, May 16 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka conferred at length today with the Russian Ambassador, Constantin Smetanin. Reliable sources said their conversation was concerned with general European affairs.

Abe (Kid Twist) Reles, the blustery Brooklyn gang leader who turned informer to save his life, related in Kings County Court yesterday the details of one of the eleven murders he took part in and then waxed philosophical and softly described how he had always believed in God and had finally become disgusted with a way of life that required killing.

The Jacob F. Schoellkopf Gold Medal of the Western New York Section of the American Chemical Society has been awarded to Dr. Arthur W. Burwell, technical director of the Aloex Corporation, Niagara Falls, N.Y., it was announced yesterday. The company is primarily engaged in manufacturing lubricant aids and corrosion preventives for metals.

" China Week" beginning tomorrow was proclaimed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as the United China Relief organization planned a series of demonstrations aimed at raising $1,700,000 as a New York City quota in the national campaign for $5,000,000 for Chinese relief.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that of the nineteen tankers operating under the British flag four had been lost as a result of torpedoing or bombing and two had been detained or seized in French ports. In addition, Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., owned jointly with the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has lost four of its ten tankers.

A group composed of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Roosevelt Weigold, Inc., and George B. Gibbons Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $325,000 city of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., general and refunding bonds on a bid of 100.28 for 1.10s.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

Pennsylvania, chief hope of the Ivy League to win the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championship a fortnight hence, will be the favorite today when the seven teams of the old guard meet in the seventh annual Heptagonal Games at Princeton's Palmer Stadium.

The course of labor relations and Administration policy toward them raise increasing doubts concerning the near future. A strike in the General Motors Corporation has just been averted -- but at the cost of the corporation accepting a settlement in which most of the far-reaching demands of the workers have been granted.

Fieldston School's senior and junior teams won the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships for the fifth time in as many years yesterday at Fieldston Field. The seniors scored 46 points, while Lincoln and Barnard, other entrants, had 16 and 6. In the junior group the home forces registered 36 markers. Barnard was runner-up with 13 and Lincoln had 11.

The famous Vargas diamond, which weighs about half a pound troy and which is said to have cost Mr. Harry Winston $700,000 in the rough, is now in the skillful hands of Mr. Adrian Grasselly, whose nerve-racking task it is to reduce it to fragments which will eventually glitter on fingers, throats and breasts.

E. Raymond Bossange, dean of the School of Architecture and Allied Arts, 1071 Sixth Avenue, a division of New York University, will retire at the close of the current semester, it was learned yesterday. Dean Bossange has been associated with New York University since 1926 when he organized a department of architecture which later developed into the present division.
The New York publishing house of Frederick A. Stokes, this year observing its sixtieth anniversary, has been acquired by the long-established J.B. Lippincott Company, it was made known yesterday.

There are some things that cannot be stated too often. A man may not like the President. He may dislike and distrust Mr. Churchill and the British people. He may have strong racial prejudices. He may believe half or more of what he hears and reads from Germany. He may hate everything except his own country or himself.
LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Some 600 general chairmen and other representatives of the "Big Five" railway operating brotherhoods settled down in joint sessions today to begin working out proposals for wage increases that would affect about 350,000 of the nation's train service workers.

Following the action of the United States Government in taking French merchant ships into protective custody, there were no developments in Wall Street yesterday as regards French funds here. All French accounts, including French gold under earmark here, were frozen by an executive order of President Roosevelt on June 17, 1940, the day that France sued for peace.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 16 -- France apparently has abandoned efforts to exist as a State independent of Nazi Germany, Secretary Knox said here today. Colonel Knox spoke extemporaneously on the Vichy government's capitulation after delivering a prepared address before the graduating class of the Naval War College.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 16 -- Testimony that New York farmers in forty-four counties face labor shortages this Summer ranging to an estimated high of 20,955 men in September was offered here today at the hearing on ninety-seven amendments to the Federal-State marketing orders regulating the farm price of milk in the New York milkshed.

Bob Montgomery, busy Negro battler from Philadelphia, squared accounts with Lew Jenkins by out-pointing the lightweight champion of the world in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Effectively muffling Jenkins's potent right hand, the Philadelphian fought a well-spaced, cagey battle that earned the unanimous vote of Referee Eddie Joseph and Judges George Le Cron and Charley Draycott.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, although no longer actively engaged in politics, displayed again yesterday the personality that won for him a host of friends when he was one of the leading political lights in the country.

ROME, May 16 -- Italian interest, like German and British, shifted today to the Middle East where the struggle for Iraq is on. This struggle, it was stated, is already spreading westward toward Palestine and other Arab countries, where the Arabs were said to be ripe and well-primed by the Axis. However, there were no signs yet that Italy was playing an active part in the fight.
The recapture of Solum, on the Egyptian frontier, by British forces indicates what may be the beginning of more intensive offensive harassing operations by General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's armies.

BERLIN, May 16 -- United States diplomacy came in for a three-fold castigation in German quarters today. The accused were President Roosevelt, charged with interference in French policy; Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles, accused of inciting Latin-American States against the Axis powers, and, last, John G. Winant, the Ambassador to London, adjudged guilty of misleading British opinion on the attitude of the people of the United States toward the war.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Indians scored their second straight victory over the Red Sox today, getting fourteen hits while Jim Bagby held his former Boston team-mates to seven, three of them by Manager Joe Cronin. The score was 9 to 3.

Today is Grunnlovsdag -- Norgegian Constitution Day. How it will pass in the mother country, her sons and daughters here do not dare to imagine. But they do dare to believe that another day of freedom will come to Norway, and it is to it that day they dedicate the holiday's traditional "Skaals" and feasting.

LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- Sir Nevile Henderson, Britain's last Ambassador to Germany before the war, declared tonight that he did not believe that Rudolf Hess had come to this country either as a Nazi spy or to give away Nazi secrets, but he warned that the Deputy Fuehrer's flight would nevertheless "accelerate Germany's war effort."
The Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition began its tenth year yesterday with a display of paintings and prints that taxed the available space in the streets around Washington Square.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Edgar Rickard, Dr. Homer Folks and Dr. C. Ward Crampton, all of New York; Major J.E.H. Stevenot of Manila, P.I., and the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling of Philadelphia were honored tonight by the Boy Scouts of America with the Silver Buffalo Award for "distinguished service to boyhood" at the dinner session of the annual meeting of the national council today at the Willard Hotel.

Twenty two-family dwellings in the West Farms area of the Bronx have been sold in one parcel by the Bowery Savings Bank to Whitestone Associates through G. Wolkenberg, Inc., and the Eugene J. Busher Co., co-brokers.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Speaker Rayburn indicated today he would be in favor of convoys if such a step were deemed necessary to assure delivery of supplies to Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Senate, by unanimous voice votes, passed bills today giving President Roosevelt and his defense aides far-reaching powers over American industry in the form of priorities controls and the financing of government plants to speed up production of war supplies for the United States, Great Britain and the other democracies.

The last big program of the sprint rowing season is scheduled for today. In the Midwest and throughout the East five regattas will give the water sport a final burst of activity before the tapering off begins for the four-mile climax races of June at New London and Poughkeepsie.

Three entries from the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis have been made for the Storm Trysail Club's ocean race next month down the coast to Hampton Roads on Chesapeake Bay. That was announced last night at what was called a pre-race dinner held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Every effort to give to the public "a fair picture of what the Navy is doing" was promised today by Rear Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn when he assumed the position of director of public relations in the Navy Department.

Flotation of $50,000,000 of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company 3 per cent debentures swelled the total of new bonds offered to the public this week to $60,820,000, the largest volume to reach the market since the week ended on Feb. 7, when offerings were $62,138,000.

BY this time J.J. Dykes, who deliberately scratched his name off the list of active players recently, probably has received a telegram from his former crony, G. Stanley Cochrane, reading approximately: "I always knew you were a quitter." The exchanges between Pudgy -- that's Dykes -- and Grumpy -- that was Cochrane -- were usually of that kindly nature.

NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., May 16 -- Broad revision of the New York City public school curriculum to provide a more flexible course of study and permit more freedom to teachers was recommended by prominent educators at the second annual conference of the New York Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association, meeting at Plum Point this week-end.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -- Delegates to the forty-seventh annual convention of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs were in full agreement today on a resolution favoring Federal legislation to "insure the cessation of strikes," but a large group opposed another resolution approving Governor Charles Edison's proposal for a convention to revise the State's 97-year-old constitution.

WASHINGTON, May l6 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull formally denied reports today that the United States had joined with Argentina and Brazil in extending friendly offices to Peru and Ecuador for bringing about a final settlement of their century-old boundary dispute in order to obtain bases on the Galapagos Islands.

After one day's ownership, the five-story store and loft building at 738 Broadway, just south of Astor Place, was resold by William D. Kilpatrick through the Charles F. Noyes Company. There was a fire in the building recently and as part of the contract of sale the buyer agrees to erect at least a two-story taxpayer on the site.

A plan for broader and more aggressive research in the textile industry was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the United States Institute for Textile Research, with the election of Edward T. Pickard as executive secretary of the institute.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society headed by Mrs. Roosevelt, Mrs. Wallace and the wives and daughters of all the South and Central American members of the diplomatic corps, turned out today for the Pan-American Fiesta given as this year's Spring fete by the Women's National Democratic Club.

SHANGHAI, May 16 -- A definite showdown between Japan and her puppet Wang Ching-wei regime is reported to have followed extensive conferences in Nanking involving high Japanese military and political leaders and high Chinese representatives of the Nanking government.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., May 16 -- A small "raiding party" of enemy soldiers was "captured" near here early this morning after the "invaders" had been put ashore some time during the night apparently from three "submarines," which were "sighted" at sea yesterday afternoon, but which were believed to have been driven off by simulated firing from the coastal defense guns here and at Fort Tilden, across the bay on Long Island.

DETROIT, May 16 -- Wage increases of more than $6,000,000 a year have been given to hourly rated workers in the Rouge Plant of the Ford Motor Company during the past three weeks, it was announced today by Harry H. Bennett, Ford personnel director. This, he added, was in addition to $7,000,000 of increases given the plant since the first of the year.

" Alert Americans" was the title bestowed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday upon five school children whose essays on Americanism were judged best in a field of 160,000 written in connection with the I Am an American celebration on the Central Park Mall tomorrow afternoon.

At the request of the Office or Production Management, the American Petroleum Institute appointed yesterday a fact-finding committee of twenty-two oil men to make a study of the problem of adequate supplies of petroleum products for the heavy consuming areas of the East Coast because of the diversion of twenty-five tankers to British service and probable transfer of others.

A proposal by Connie Mack for increasing the number of night games in the major leagues met resistance from some of his fellow-magnates yesterday and apparently was doomed, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that eighty-eight Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $303,319,059 in April, compared with $264,012,500 in April, 1940. The reporting carriers, the association said, represented 82.1 per cent of total operating revenues of all Class I roads.
ROME, May 16 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, Saturday, May 17 -- The boom of anti-aircraft guns and the sounds of fighter planes in action overhead were heard in London for several hours early today as German raiders staged scattered bombing attacks on Britain, chiefly against the Midlands.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The officers of the Army, of whom there are at present about 80,500, will soon be receiving identification booklets giving them unimpeachable evidence of identity to produce on assignments under all circumstances.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Roosevelt declared today that it was the responsibility of the Senate and House to decide where cuts in non-defense expenditures should be made in order to save the $1,000,000,000 in this field desired by Secretary Morgenthau.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The special Senate Committee Investigating the National Defense Program today called upon San Francisco Bay area shipbuilders and 1,700 striking A.F.L. and C.I.O. machinists to settle their dispute. They announced that the committee would conduct a hearing on the case next Thursday if the strike is not ended by Tuesday night.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 16 -- Gaining ten points through the medium of a 5-0 victory over the Westchester C.C. and the default of Wykagyl at the Century Club today, the Rye Country Club team carried off the Class A championship in the Westchester Division of the women's metropolitan interclub golf tournament.

Pleas of not guilty to first-degree murder were entered in General Sessions yesterday for Morris Mardavich, 23 years old, an ex-convict, of 626 Sixth Street; Vincent Morgano, 23, of 531 East Thirteenth Street, and Frank Alascia, 22, of 322 East Twelfth Street, in the hold-up shooting of Harry Vance Maxwell, 41, advertising executive.

A new plan providing for preliminary examination of prospective trainees one month in advance of the date set for their Army induction, so they may avoid the risk of "making final preparation to absent themselves from civilian activities, only to be disqualified by medical examiners," will be tried during June, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director here.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The RFC's Defense Plant Corporation has authorized lease agreements with four major rubber companies for the construction and operation of synthetic rubber plants to cost about $1,250,000 each, Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, said today.

Mass production of standard diatonic harmonicas, replacing those formerly imported from Germany, is now under way in this country, it was revealed yesterday by a refugee who is serving as technical advisor to the local concern making the instruments.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- The National Hockey League governors today accepted the gift of Art Ross, general manager of the Boston Bruins, of a perpetual trophy to be awarded to that ice circuit's most valuable player, as voted by his competitors.

LONDON, May 16 -- Proof of the search for younger blood is found in further new appointments and changes announced by the War Office today. The chief of these is General Sir Robert Haining, 58, vice chief of the Imperial General Staff, who was selected for a special appointment and replaced by Major Gen. Sir Henry R. Pownall, 53, who gets the rank of temporary lieutenant general.

The demand for cow beef continued active, hinds and ribs only fair to slow; other classes fair to good. Cow was steady to strong, other classes steady. Early trading in Kosher veal was fair, chucks and plates and lamb slow, veal foresaddles were mostly 50 cents higher, lamb steady and chucks and plates steady to 50 cents higher in spots.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16 (AP) -- A communique of the Iraqi General Staff, received from Baghdad today, stated:

Two new films will open in local theatres this morning. At the Rialto the newcomer will be "The Big Boss," a Columbia melodrama featuring Otto Kruger, Gloria Dickson and John Litel.... "Under Age," also a Columbia picture, will arrive at the Central Theatre.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- Rearrangement of Paramount's production schedule resulted in program switches for three leading men today. Fred MacMurray, who had been assigned to "Sing a Song of Homicide," was named for the male lead in "Mr. and Mrs. Cugat," a novel by Isabel S. Rorick which the studio purchased last month.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 16 -- In a talk here today that called for an "all-out" participation by the nation's banks in the country's defense program, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, expressed but one concern -- the continued increase in the number of banks with small capital cushions.

The Greenwich House Pottery will hold an exhibition of work done in the settlement's ceramic school, at the studio, 27 Barrow Street, next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Demonstrations on pottery wheels will be given at 3:30 and 8:30 P.M. each day.

VICHY, France, May 16 -- As there opened to France the capital chapter of the post-war period -- this is the Journal des Debats' description of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's message to the nation last evening -- a capital chapter was being opened also in the United States with President Roosevelt's statement regarding "relations with the French Republic."

Recreation activities operated by the Park Department suffered from the prevalence of rainy weather last Summer and showed revenues of $1,128,000 against a total of $1,260,000 collected in 1939, the finance committee of the City Council was informed yesterday.

The conduct committee of the Board of Higher Education, meeting yesterday at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, announced that the board's trial of John K. Ackley, suspended registrar of City College, on charges arising out of the RappCoudert committee's investigation, will be held at the downtown branch of City College beginning June 9.

Retail trade here continued active in practically all lines last week. Department store volume was estimated as running ahead of last year by 8 per cent or more. Milder weather spurred the call for women's apparel and accessories, while volume in home wares continued to hold the increases of recent months.

JOHN JONES has been drafted. It sounds very simple, but back of every draft number called is a human drama, usually relieved by touches of comedy. Most of these dramas are played out in the thousands of draft board offices scattered over the country. Here are some of them.

A favorite dish of Nelson Trusler Johnson is "jao tze." That is a pastry rolled around meat balls -- a concoction which has been called the Chinese version of the American hot dog. Mr. Johnson has acquired his taste for Chinese food during his career as American diplomat in China.

New York City's social workers as well as representative of private social service agencies presented a hobby show and a dance last night at the Manhattan Center. One thousand persons attended. The proceeds will be used for the support of the professional publication, Social Work Today, which last night celebrated its seventh anniversary.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 17 -- There is considerable diplomatic activity here arising from the increasingly dangerous situation. The Afghan Ambassador saw Turkish Foreign Minister Shukru Saracogiu today. The Russian Ambassador, Sergei A. Vinagradoff, had a long talk with Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey.

I HAVE been asked to write an explanation for "the first closing of the Group's offices in ten years." I did not do so, to begin with, because from the standpoint of the "street" the answer must be pretty obvious. And from another standpoint -- my own and that of the people directly involved in the Group's work -- I sometimes wonder whether we can make anybody really clear care.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17 -- Jim Perkins pitched a two-hit shut-but today as Rutgers handed Manhattan an 11-0 defeat on the Rutgers Stadium diamond.

The United States Maritime Commission announced yesterday that the government's emergency shipbuilding program, under which 200 cargo ships were contracted for beginning two months ago, is well ahead of schedule.

Much has been said and written lately about the greatness of Prime Minister Churchill, but there seems not to have appeared a simple analysis of the fundamental bases of this greatness. Churchill was possessed at birth of a cyclo-thymic temperament and gifted with a brilliant mind.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., May 17 -- One of the two co-medalists was defeated in the first round of the annual Morris County Golf Club invitation tournament today when Dudley Roberts of the Garden City Golf Club defeated P.K. Bartow of the home club, 3 and 1, in an 18-hole match.

MANILA, May 7 (Via Clipper) -American preparations for defense are beginning to have a galvanic effect on the Philippines. Twenty-two measures have been presented in the National Assembly to date for purposes associated with local defense, mostly affecting civilian populations in the forty-nine provinces.

SWEET BRIAR, Va., May 17 -- Students and faculty members on the campus of Sweet Briar College have collected $31,000 as part of their share in the nation-wide campaign, started last week, to raise $500,000, it was announced today. The drive, which will continue through commencement, is for increased endowment and a new building to house an auditorium and the fine arts departments.

THIS is again a collection of very readable short stories. If prizes were to be given, Stephen Vincent Benet probably would again be top man, as he so often is in the prize contests. His story of the threshold of death -"the stop called No Visitors * * * a bare, wintry platform.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 17 (AP) -- The Finance Ministry announced today that, "in a new policy toward freedom in trade," Argentina had allocated $11,700,000 in exchange credits for purchases in the United States of automobiles, farm machinery and spare parts during the remainder of 1941, making the year's total United States imports $14,660,000.
BERLIN, May 17 (UP) -- Nazi sources warned today that continued "interference" by President Roosevelt will unite all Europe in "complete cooperation" behind Germany.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 17 -The eighth contest in the United States chess championship between Samuel Reshevsky, the defender, and Israel Horowitz was adjourned tonight after thirty-two moves.

Long Island Sound's championship yacht racing season will open on Saturday. The initial regatta will be held by the Horseshoe Harbor Club of Larchmont, and from then on through September there will be contests on Saturdays and holidays for the Summer titles in all classes.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 17 (AP) -- A versatile, sixteen-man Duke University squad wrested the Southern Conference track championship from North Carolina's defending titleholders by a 66-to-58 5-6 margin today in a strictly two-way battle which left other competitors hopelessly out of the running.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -Champion Joe Louis stepped through a strenuous training routine today for his fight with Buddy Baer for the heavyweight title here next Friday night, an encounter the Brown Bomber insists he regards seriously.

The final closing date for entries to the fifteenth annual show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club to be held at Madison, N.J., on May 31 has been fixed for next Saturday. Exhibitors are warned, however, that no entries will be accepted unless they can be included in the catalogue.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 17 -- A capacity audience filled the Packer Memorial Church at Lehigh University this afternoon for the Mass in B minor of Johann Sebastian Bach, given by the famed Bach Choir. Standing room was at a premium by the time the Moravian Trombone Choir opened the festival. The singers, the women dressed in white and the men in dark suits, were in their places in the auditorium.

MARSHALL H. ENSOR, 41-year-old radio amateur of Olathe, Kan., will receive the William S. Paley Amateur Radio Award of 1940 at a luncheon to be held in the Hotel Waldorf Astoria on June 2, it was announced last night. Mr. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, will present the trophy.

The usual Summer slump for manufacturers of non-defense or civilian goods will not be experienced this year, but by Sept. 1 a sharp curtailment of production, more severe than most expect, will develop, industrial purchasing agents declared last week.

For aircraft observation duty with the General Headquarters Air Force, civilian volunteers will be enrolled by State and local defense councils in time to begin operations in the Atlantic and Pacific coastal areas not later than June 15, Frank Bane, Director of the Division of State and Local Cooperation, Office For Emergency Management, announced yesterday from Washington.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 17 -- Another notable success in his victory-studded ring career was achieved by the imported pekingese, Ch. Che Le of Matson's Catawba, to culminate the eighth annual Orange Kennel Club all-breed show held at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- White prices of wheat on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in an erratic manner within range of about 1 cent a bushel, most of the trading was of a professional character, with the local Pit element disposed to act with caution as the result of uncertainty over the proposed government loan on the 1941 wheat and corn crops.

ROLLA, Mo. -- Tourists, who of late years have been a somewhat better crop in the Ozarks than sweet taters and ginseng root, more remunerative than cutting railroad ties, have begun to cross the area southwestward on U.S. Highway 66.

Slip covers, instead of being a not especially agreeable device for protecting fine upholstery from Summer dust, have become a welcome part of Summer decoration. Colorful and cool, they unite with gay, light window curtains to give the stay-at-home's apartment or house the holiday air which warm weather ushers in.

CLEVELAND, May 17 -- Industry in Fourth Federal Reserve District has regained about all the ground lost during April as result of the protracted bituminous coal strike. Operations in several of the district's steel-making centers last week were near levels reported late in March, with sales of both new equipment and replacement casings considerably ahead of a year ago.

WATCHING hopefully for sails on the September horizon, Tecumseh last week reported at least one in his logbook, to wit: Robert Lewis and Ella Kazan, a couple of the defunct Group Theatre's likelier lads, are busily preparing to open a dollar-top theatre under their own partnership next Fall.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- American's railroads, with 235,000 miles constituting almost 40 per cent of the world's trackage, believe they can handle the nation's defense traffic smoothly and efficiently.

John F. Mulligan of James Madison won his third fencing competition in three weeks last night when he finished unbeaten in the final round of the annual A.F.L.A. interscholastic championship at Washington Irving High.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 17 -- By a new faculty ruling, students seeking admission to the Summer session of Cornell University this June will be required to make formal application, furnish evidence of good standing in the institution at which they have been studying, and also have approval of a six-hour schedule by an officer of their own institution.

TROUBLE in Iraq has brought German war planes to Syria. Originally Syria was part of the Turkish territory occupied by France during the first World War, and, by the Treaty of Versailles, it was mandated to France. In 1936 Syrian autonomy as substituted for the French mandate.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Mrs. Roosevelt told the Norwegian people in a special short-wave broadcast today from Station WRUL in Boston on the occasion of the Norwegian Independence Day that the American people have "a feeling that it will be impossible to keep the Norwegian people subject to any other nation."

CAMP STEWART, Ga., May 17 -With B-18 bombers of the Twentyninth Bombardment Group from MacDill Field, Fla., participating, this anti-aircraft training center will engage in a special searchlight drill Monday night. Emphasis will be placed upon the detection of sounds made by this type of airplane.

A national center of research and of post-college education for architects is proposed in a report of the Committee on Education of the American Institute of Architects, which is holding its seventy-third convention in the Yosemite Valley, Calif.
LONDON, May 17 (UP) -- Home Security Minister Herbert Morrison, inaugurating War Weapons Week in a speech at Hackney today, said that "the question of the hour is: 'What is your Hess guess?'"

FAMILIAR names and names of newcomers mingle in the list of exhibiting artists whose shows opened last week. And while other periods of the season have produced more shows, no week has offered more variety. The newly opened attractions run the gamut of media and range from ultra-academism to ultra-modernism.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 17 -- Business improvement was credited today by Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, for a $5,000,000 increase in State personal income tax revenue and 20 per cent higher collections of unincorporated business taxes for 1940.

Looking very much the beaten battler, Lew Jenkins visited the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday to pick up a $10,484 check, for his ten-round fight with Bob Montgomery at Madison Square Garden the night before. The lightweight champion of the world, who was decisively defeated by the Philadelphia Negro in an over-the-weight encounter, was cut up and patched about the face.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A world dominated by the totalitarian powers will mean that "there can be no foreign trade of the future on fair terms, under democratic principles," President Roosevelt declared tonight in a statement issued in connection with the observance of National Foreign Trade Week next week.

In an effort to meet the demands of industry, the Board of Education's emergency training program for national defense, now operating twenty-three day and seven all-night schools, is planning to expand its facilities within the next few months, George F. Pigott Jr., administrative director, disclosed yesterday.

Why is it that some blind men and women are able to avoid obstacles without the assistance of a cane or without groping? The experiments conducted at Cornell by Dr. Karl M. Dallenbach and his associates dispose of "facial vision," "warning sense," "distance sense," "telesthesia," "paraoptic vision" and similar cryptic explanations, but not of a "sixth sense."

IN the middle of the night a vision will come to the scenario writer. In this vision he, the scenario writer, will see himself as a god-like creature, who, when he writes something on a typewriter, will later hear it on the screen. But positively.

TOKYO, May 17 -- It used to be a good old Chinese custom under the Manchus, whenever a provincial warlord got obstreperous, for the court to send out two mandarins to bring him to terms -- a "bad mandarin" and a "good mandarin." The bad mandarin breathed fire and brimstone and threatened direct punishment; the good mandarin promised all kinds of rewards for good behavior.

AN interesting post-season event in the Broadway district will take place on Thursday when Antonio Triana, formerly Argentinita's partner, will present a Latin-American program at the Guild with an assisting company of fourteen. Up at the Y.M.H.A. tonight Welland Lathrop and his group of six will make their New York bow.
CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP) -- The Reds lost their sixth straight game today as the last-place Phillies triumphed, 2 to 1, behind the six-hit pitching of John Podgajny, 21-year-old rookie.

LIKE all recreation and vacation spots throughout the country, the varied State parks on Long Island are fast getting ready to welcome the Summer pleasure-seeker. And, as an advantage over most of the country's play regions, the Long Island parks offer New Yorkers, close at hand, unique opportunities for every kind of outdoor enjoyment.

MR. OWEN was the man to write this book. For full year he was with Admiral Byrd in the Antarctic, winning the Pulitzer Prize for journalism, at once competent and courageous. As sisted by a nonchalant humor, he knows how to interest the public.

LAST CAR: Mayor Vincent R. Corrou of Utica, N.Y., last week went for a trolley ride. The Mayor acted as his own motorman, and the ride was a sentimental gesture. When it ended, Utica's last trolley was retired from service. Buses replaced the trolleys that had first been operated in Utica fifty-one years ago.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 (AP) -- A British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:
The reports which are reaching America concerning Croatia are confusing and often contradictory. It seems that the general tendency is to blame Croatians for the quick debacle of the Yugoslav Army.

With herculean effort and determination Spud Chandler yesterday pitched his first complete game in his fourth start of the campaign, but it went for naught as the White Sox beat the Yankees, 3 to 2, in closing their first visit of the year at the Stadium.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Three thousand club women of the Middle West paid tribute to Poland and her people today by conferring a gold medal and an award of $500 for "distinguished service to humanity" on Ignace Jan Paderewski, famous pianist, at the annual May breakfast of the conference of club president and program chairmen.
ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- The Yankees let a good first baseman go when they shipped Babe Dahlgren to the Braves.
BRUSSELS, May 16 (AP) (Delayed; Via Berlin) -- Responsible Belgian leaders, weighing the future of their country, declare there can be no government without the restoration of King Leopold.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sunday, May 18 (AP) -- The Egyptian Government today sought the arrest of a former Chief of Staff of the Egyptian Army, General Aziz el Masri Pasha, known here for his pro-Axis sympathies, after the general and two Egyptian Air Force members had attempted unsuccessfully to flee Cairo in an Egyptian military plane.

NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., May 17 -A. shocking inequality of educational opportunity exists in the United States, and can be corrected only through Federal aid to the poorer States, Dr. Donald DuShane, president of the National Education Association, said today at the second annual conference of the New York Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association.

MEDIA, Pa., May 17 -- Mrs. T. Beatty Brown's Comedienne stayed on the course today to triumph handily in the Gloucester Fox Hunters Plate Steeplechase, feature of the final day's racing at the annual Spring meeting of the Rose Tree Hunt.

BROOKLYN has become one of the most necessary links in the country's defense chain. For the United States Navy, engaged in the task of building the biggest fleet of fighting ships in the world, expects a major part of that task to be done by the New York Navy Yard in that borough.

Let us not be cynical about campaign promises; let us be honest and realistic. No doubt they are sometimes made insincerely, only to be forgotten after election; but when made with all sincerity and good faith, they are often best described in the words of the old proverb, "A bad promise is better broken than kept."

Removal of its principal service bureau from New York to Washington and enlargement of its racing commission from three men to five were unexpected decisions made in recent days by the American Power Boat Association, the national ruling body for the sport of speed-boat racing.

Hundreds of foreign-born persons living in New York City were questioned and required to show their alien registration cards last night as Federal officials, aided by the police, opened a nation-wide drive on persons illegally in this country.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 17 -- More than 300 alumni of Lawrenceville School returned to the campus today to participate in the annual alumni day activities. William Raoul of the class of 1891 was applauded by his fellow-alumni for having pedaled a bicycle all the way from his home in Atlantic Highlands, N.J., a distance of fifty miles, to celebrate his fiftieth reunion with his classmates.

BERLIN, May 17 -- With the German tax and other ordinary revenue estimated at the record sum of 40,000,000,000 marks for 1941 and the war debt considerably smaller than that of Britain, the finances of the Reich are in a healthier condition than ever and there can, therefore, be no question of using the printing press for the financing of the war.

WHILE the petroleum industry stands ready to provide almost any conceivable demand for its products, both for national defense and for ordinary consumption, and to meet its fair share of the nation's tax burden, taxes on gasoline, the House Ways and Means Committee has been told by industry representatives, should be imposed with the greatest care.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- The Office of Production Management has informed Congress that the reserve stockpile program for strategic materials is destined to fail because it was not started soon enough and because of the world shipping shortage.

ANALYSIS of new-car sales to occupational groups reveals 25 to 165 per cent gains, with industrial workers leading and executives of finance and industry trailing, according to Chrysler's statistical department. February was the month studied.

For the first time this Summer Girl Scout officials will offer their training courses to all women, regardless of whether they intend to use their knowledge as Scout leaders or through other mediums. A course to be known as "Training for Today's Needs" will be conducted at twenty-one Scout camps throughout the country during July and August.

I AM an American. The things I shall say about myself may seem at first to contradict one another, but in the end they add up. I am almost always recognized at once wherever I go about the world. Some say it is my clothes that give me away. Some say it is my way of talking. I think it is more than that.
MARIETTA, Ohio, May 17 -Rutgers University won its third straight Dad Vail rowing regatta today, beating six other colleges over the Ohio River course.

BERLIN, May 17 (UP) -- The German High Command reported today that the Axis African Corps had recaptured Solum, Fort Capuzzo and "all other points" taken by the British in a Western Desert assault announced yesterday.

A really comprehensive discussion of escape literature will not overlook the Farms-for-Sale pages that bloom in the metropolitan Sunday newspaper in the Spring of the year. They have as wide and as grateful a reading public, perhaps, as the best-selling mystery tales and Westerns.

ALTHOUGH it is called "Two Million Art Students," the fifth annual exhibition of work from classes of the New York City WPA Art Project is a modest affair, containing 212 items, a great many of which are craft objects. The show has been set up in galleries at the Metropolitan Museum (Eighty-third Street Foyer) and will continue through May 30.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Life for government labor mediators is like a continued movement on a roller coaster. One moment you are at the bottom of a strike wave and the other moving toward the top.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Lee De Forest, noted for his invention of the vacuum tube which makes modern radio possible, is registered as the inventor of a new television camera tube in a patent (No. 2,241,809) just issued by the Patent Office.

BY now every reader must know the sort of justice the Nazis ladle out to the peoples they conquer. And this knowledge must inevitably awaken in him some curiosity as to the nature of the same product meted out to the favored natives, the Germans themselves.

A PARTICULARLY interesting small group of eighteenth and nineteenth century American paintings is now on view (until June 15) at the John Levy Galleries. There are twenty-three canvases, four of them by artists who remain anonymous.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -With the formal opening of the Summer resort season still two weeks away, hotel operators and amusement enterprises at Virginia Beach yesterday reported to the Chamber of Commerce that vacation business during the past month exceeded that usually enjoyed in June.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, May 17 (AP) -- Sources close to the Netherlands Indies Government disclosed today that economic negotiations between the Netherlands Indies and Japan have entered a critical stage, with the exchange of final memoranda.

The National Board of Fire Underwriters, the first nation-wide business association devoted to public welfare, which has 200 capital stock insurance companies throughout the country as members, will celebrate the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding during the week beginning next Wednesday.
VICHY, France, April 24 -- There could be no greater difference than that which exists between the press of the occupied zone and that of the unoccupied.

BERLIN, May 17 (UP) -- The High Command said today that "weak" British air forces "aimlessly dropped explosive bombs and incendiaries on West Germany Friday night, but, with the exception of small industrial works, no industrial objectives were hit."

During Franklin D. Roosevelt's first term the Assistant Secretary of Labor, the Assistant Administrator of NRA and the government's trouble-shooter in labor disputes was Edward F. McGrady. In 1937 he was put in charge of labor relations at the Radio Corporation of America.

THE Germans had broken through at Sedan; Panzer divisions were roaring toward the Channel; France Was doomed; the President of the United States called for "defenses . . . invulnerable, security . . . absolutes."

LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- Britain recognizes control of the Middle East as almost as important as the defense of the British Isles themselves and on a par with the vital Battle of the Atlantic and proposes to defend it accordingly, informed British sources declared tonight.

A LECTURE entitled "Technique of Photography In The Tropics" will be given by Philip Hanson Hiss on Monday at 8:30 in the galleries of the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, New York City. The museum galleries will be open to the public from S to 11 P.M. for this special occasion.

Not so long ago the President sent to Great Britain a National Technogolical Civil Protection Committee to study the effect of air raids on cities. F.C. Horner, highway expert of the General Motors Corporation, summarizes the observations and conclusions of the committee in a report which gives details that hurried correspondents could not be expected to gather.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S chief refuge from the heavy strain of his office in these times of world crisis and war is the Presidential yacht Potomac. In this tragic period even one who, like Mr. Roosevelt, is not given to worrying, needs a change from the burdensome routine of the Executive Office.
