LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 17 -- Splitting up for a team match with four boats to a side, the International Class sloops raced off the Larchmont Yacht Club today. The Red team, captained by Corny Shields, won from the Blue under Arthur Knapp by 19 1/4 points to 17.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Although aimed in the main at uneducated and uninformed people, and designed primarily to create disunity and fear, Nazi radio short-wave propaganda directed to the Western republics has had little or no effect in spite of its gigantic scale and vast cost, says an article by Harold N. Graves Jr., appearing in today's "Headline Book" of the Foreign Policy Association.

The diversion of the first group of twenty-five tankers of United States registry to move oil for the British war effort probably will not result in such serious dislocation in the distribution of petroleum products in the North Atlantic States as was at first expected.

A BOY drops a slug into a turnstile, waits for the next hurrying citizen and says, "I put my nickel in, want to go ahead and give me yours?" It is an old dodge in the subway, yielding its quota of small change for movies and candy, and is one of the acts that land young culprits in the Children's Court.

THERE is something very beguiling about the introduction of a geographer as an Incurable Romantic. Significant, too, as we learn before we reach the end of the autobiography of Professor Roderick Peattie, author of "New College Geography."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17 (AP) -The Iraqi Army Headquarters communique, issued in Baghdad yesterday and received here today, follows:

POCONO MOUNTAINS Pa. -The Foxhowe Association at Buck Hill Falls, which sponsors a Summer program of classes on international relations and the Bible, this week announced the reappointment of Dr. Alexander C. Purdy, Professor of Theology at the Hartford Theological Foundation.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 -- One of the most serious strikes directly affecting the national defense effort, which has tied up construction and repair work on an estimated sixty vessels of the Navy and the Maritime Commission in eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards, moved through its first week in an outward atmosphere of calm belieing the explosive elements underneath.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 17 -St. Peter's College pounded out fifteen hits in crushing Long Island University's baseball team, 17 -- 7, today for the Peacocks' fifth straight victory. Gene Dudek was the big gun in the home nine's offensive, collecting a home run, double and single and also driving in a trio of runs.

Slow deliveries stimulated advance buying in most departments in the wholesale markets last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Early orders for furs were placed in larger volume than last year, although prices were from 10 to 25 per cent higher, the report continued.

Seven outstanding Frenchmen, now in this country, made public yesterday a telegram they had sent to President Roosevelt congratulating him on his recent warning to the Vichy government against military collaboration with the Nazis.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 17 -Five Harvard undergraduates will receive scholarships to spend the Summer in a South American country, living in private homes and studying first-hand the customs, social problems and language of the visited nation.

DURING the past few months an extraordinary situation has arisen in the popular-music field which, while it may have passed unobserved by some, has caused concern among the coterie of swing connoisseurs who still have faith in the integrity of jazz as a minor art form.

YOSEMITE VALLEY, Calif., May 17 -- A warning that the architect in the private practice of his profession was facing eclipse at the hands of Federal Government bureaus was sounded here today at the seventy-third annual convention of the American Institute of Architects.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI and his All-American Youth Orchestra are in the midst of their second tour, this one across the American continent, and Columbia follows the news with a batch of recordings of this ensemble. In the regular release for May, the orchestra was represented by Love Music from Wagner's Tristan und Isolde (three twelve-inch records, $3.50).

Integration of public utility systems, which is being advanced aggressively by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the "death sentence" provision of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, has reached the point where definite action by the commission is necessary to bring about orderly liquidation of holding companies in order to preserve the utmost in values for hundreds of thousands of investors.

INTEREST in Spanish is largely responsible for more tours to Spanish-speaking countries this Summer. Not only students but laymen are joining special parties going to Havana and Mexico, Ecuador, Peru and Chile for study and travel.

The American Export liner Excambion sailed yesterday from Pier F, Jersey City, for Lisbon via Bermuda with forty passengers. She also carried fifty-five tons of cargo made up of grain, steel and construction materials for the new United States Army base at Bermuda.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 17 -- Seton Hall scored its tenth consecutive victory by defeating the City College nine at Setonia Field today, 8 -- 1.

Six-year-old Stephen Homiek of 33 Reed Street, Newark, N.J., a member of the Ironbound Drum and Bugle Corps of Newark, didn't win any prizes but he stole the show just the same yesterday afternoon at the drum and bugle corps contest which marked the opening of the annual fair of the Madison Square Boys Club of 301 Lexington Avenue.
NYACK, N.Y., May 17 -- A "disaster" was staged here this afternoon to determine what emergency resources Rockland County could mobilize in the event of real emergency resulting from war.

Fifteen British-made documentary films depicting England in wartime will be shown in a series of three programs on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons in the auditorium of the Film Library of the Museum of Modern Art.

THE woman had lost her family, home and fortune. She was past 45 and too old, she thought, to begin life all over again. Jobs were scarce and she had no special training. The employment agency, last of many she had hopefully visited, was sorry; it had nothing to offer. The woman started to leave. At the door a man brushed by.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Sales in five major department stores here last week were 10 per cent ahead of last year and 14 per cent higher for the four weeks. Department stores in neighboring cities as well as lesser establishments in the metropolitan area reported sales 12 per cent ahead of 1940 for the week and 24 per cent ahead for the four weeks.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -The verses of the song written by George M. Cohan in honor of Connie Mack follow:

An innovation in women's golf will mark the opening round of the thirty-fourth annual women's Eastern championship at the Westchester Country Club, which gets under way June 10 and continues through June 12.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- An elaborate Decoration Day program is planned for the opening of the Summer season. Piers, theatres and night clubs will offer entertainment features while hotels plan special parties, dances and concerts.

THREE of the shows of the week incline to the "primitive" on folk art vein. Meyer Hiler has paintings at the Raymond Raymond Gallery -- at once quaint, gay bright, decorative. They are landscape and urban vignettes.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 17 -- Harvard's varsity crew rowed through rough water and rain on the Severn today to win the Charles Francis Adams Cup for the fourth straight year. Navy was second, a half-length behind, while Pennsylvania was astern of the midshipmen by two lengths.

The much sought after and greatly hoped for "red" Gentian has finally arrived. Formerly the nearest available approach to it was jamesi, which is violet-red; the new arrival is promised as a true red of great beauty and rarity. As its seeds are protected with an encasing burr, it is suggested that this be opened and the seeds taken out carefully (for they are small) and planted in one-third sand and two-thirds leaf-mold.

KANSAS was the target of German radio manoeuvring an evening or two ago when a wooing cowboy show flashed from Reich aerials to serenade ranchers on the prairies. It was a festival of song, with recorded cowboys whooping it up in American style.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Holding together firmly behind Cliff Melton's glittering five-hit pitching the while their adversaries looked to be falling apart at almost every turn, the Giants today trampled all over Jimmy Wilson's Cubs to win the series final, 9 to 0.

A garden party with a triple purpose will be given on the afternoon of May 29 at the Cafe du Pare, 17 East Sixtieth Street. The fete will serve as a benefit for the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, as a Spring meeting of the group responsible for the White Elephant Cocktail Party given every Autumn for the same cause, and as the formal opening of the cafe gardens.

OUT of war-torn England (the author's drawings were destroyed by one bomb, the publisher's plates removed by another and the proofs lost at sea) comes a new Arthur Ransome story, as fresh in interest, as perceptive and as true in values as all his others.

A SHORT-WAVE S O S from the South American jungle picked up by a "ham" operator on Long Island has resulted in a 5,000-mile air express shipment delivered by parachute five days later in the interior of South America.

WHAT gave to American fiction the vitality which has been so evident during the last decade? The anonymous author of the article on the novel's development in this country which appeared in the special Anglo-American section of The Times (London) Literary Supplement finds the answer in the character of the times through which we had lived.

THE Panama Canal Zone is on the alert in far more than the technical military sense of that term. The alertness is spread throughout the civil administration. It permeates the Army and Navy, whose forces in this zone are now greater in man power than those stationed at any other overseas defensive point of the United States.
Following are excerpts from a letter written by a woman in Paris during the month of March to a friend in the United States:

Labor, in its quest for social justice, is in danger of stressing "the wrong thing -- security," rather than the Christian principle of liberty, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of Catholic University declared last night at the closing services of a solemn triduum commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of Pope Leo XIII's encyclical, "The Condition of the Workingman," and the tenth anniversary of Pope Pius XI's encyclical, "Reconstruction of the Social Order."

The English walnut is worthy of consideration by tree lovers who want a tree that will be both useful and ornamental. Ever since colonial days English walnuts have been planted in our Northern and Eastern States but practically all of them have died by Winter-killing, because they were native to Southern Europe with its mild climate.

Turning the half-century mark in its history, the General Federation of Women's Clubs is calling delegates from 15,000 clubs in every State to Atlantic City this week to celebrate the Golden Jubilee at its triennial convention. Honors will be distributed to pioneers in club work and other activities; but the sessions at Convention Hall also will look to the future by shaping a program for the next three years, and electing a new president.

Because she feared blindness, Mrs. Mary Galilei, 33 years old, strangled her two daughters to death, attacked her son with a knife, and then jumped from the window of her third-floor apartment at 3406 Olinville Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday. She was taken to Fordham Hospital in a critical condition.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 17 -Four meet records were set in the third annual Long Island public high schools' relay carnival despite a fifteen-minute shower which changed the usually fast half-mile dirt track to a sloshy, low runway.

Lord Marley, deputy speaker of the British House of Lords, pleaded yesterday for all possible American aid for "the ordinary people who are in the front-line trenches in the defense of Great Britain." He spoke before a meeting at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street, of representatives of unions and fraternal organizations that are supporting the American Labor Committee to Aid British Labor.

Most home owners agree that a pool, even a small one, adds to the landscape planting a quality that nothing else can give. Many are deterred from attempting to make a pool out of uncertainty concerning the possible cost involved. A home-made pool, however, need involve very little actual cash outlay, and the work can be done at leisure after the rush of Spring planting is over.

Behind the scenes of the war in Iraq, a German agent called Dr. Grobba has been playing an active part. Occasionally his name has been mentioned in the dispatches, but it has never been disclosed who this man is, what he has done in the past, and what he is still doing.

"IN a few minutes, ladles and gentlemen, you will hear a bell ring. A short interval later you will hear two bells sounding. The first will be the signal for the crew of the Yankee Clipper to board their airliner. The second will be the boarding signal for the passengers.
BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- J.U. Gratton's Liberty Franc emerged as the surprise winner of the $5,000-added Plymouth Rock Handicap today before a week-end crowd of 30,000 at Suffolk Downs.

ONE of the more satisfying compensations of being a photographer always has been the ability, when accosted by the uninitiated, to say impressively, "Oh yes, I use filters." However, now that the season of bald blue skies is pretty well past and Summer is here again, the time to actually use filters has come.

A number of English and American lads learned yesterday that British radio censors are uncompromising when it comes to discussions of weather over the air. It all happened as five New York boys and six in London were "warming up" for a ten-minute transatlantic broadcast by short waves.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The first unit of what will ultimately be a 125,000-tree memorial forest to the Confederate soldiers of North Carolina has been completed in Pisgah National Forest in western North Carolina. When completed the forest will comprise 125 acres of spruce trees.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 17 -- The death of Fernando Pinto Sepulyeda, one of the provincial delegates to the Radical convention that began yesterday, and serious injuries to Senator Gustavo Jiron and other delegates in demonstrations by Chilean Nazi mobs has deeply stirred political circles here.

THERE have been a great many books written on the subject of playwriting, and we're not going to enter the field -- our title for this piece ought really to have a subtitle, "How to Write a Play -- In Hollywood."

LONDON, May 17 (UP) -- Great Britain tonight adopted an increasingly stiff attitude toward France, and one commentator suggested that the Royal Air Force be ordered to attack Paris and other French industrial areas if Vichy went all the way in cooperation with Germany.

Preaching on "The Dangers of Premature Optimism" at Temple B'nai Jeshuran, Eighty-eighth Street near Broadway, yesterday, Rabbi Israel Goldstein declared that "whatever may be the true story of the Rudolf Hess incident, it must not be permitted to induce premature optimism regarding the immediate future."
Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday for a huge outpouring of citizens at the I Am an American celebration this afternoon on Central Park Mall.

Four more crack golfers, Lawson Little, the national open titleholder; Victor Ghezzi, Dick Metz and Harold (Jug) McSpaden, were named yesterday to round out the field of fifteen that will see action in the fourth annual $5,000 Goodall round-robin tournaments at the Fresh Meadow Country Club this week.

Several years have elapsed since the banking set-up in the United States has had a going over by means of a new Federal banking act, but if the view of representative banking leaders can be of influence, the matter will remain on the shelf so long as the present defense emergency lasts.

MONTEREY, Calif., May 17 (UP) -- William O. Raiguel, prominent California architect, his wife Bema and their dog were found shot to death today in their home. Notes indicated Mrs. Raiguel killed herself and that Raiguel, finding her dead, shot the dog and himself.

Bernard Leviton, vice president of the Leviton Manufacturing Company, 236 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, where a strike has been in progress since last September, was released in $500 bail yesterday on a charge of felonious assault brought by one of the A.F. of L. strikers.

The problem of impressing upon students the need to write well and to put as great an effort into their composition work in other subjects as they do in required English courses is getting special attention at New York. University's Washington Square College, it was revealed yesterday.
A pilgrimage to three historic houses and gardens will be conducted Wednesday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. by the International Garden Club as a benefit for the British War Relief Society, Inc.

LONDON, May 17 -- British leaders made the most today of Rudolf Hess's presence in this country in an effort to prove a variety of points, but none of them contributed anything toward the Hess story, which is about to come to the end of its first phase.

Another member of the Cincinnati Reds becomes a yachtsman. A few weeks ago Powel Crosley Jr. launched his new cruiser from Julius Petersen's Nyack yard. Now one of his pitching staff. Paul Derringer, owns a 26-foot Chris-Craft cruiser.

RICHMOND, May 17 -- Figures released by United States Bureau of Census and tabulated by the Richmond Chamber of Commerce show that for the 1929-39 decade Virginia's industrial production increased 43.1 per cent to lead the nation in this respect.

The twenty-fourth annual Summer session of Fordham University, marking its centenary year, will open on July 7 and extend to Aug. 14 inclusive with 240 courses, a faculty of 112 and an expected registration of 1,500.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17 -- North Country Community Hospital, an institution in which Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt and her late husband have been major supporters ever since its opening in 1926, will benefit by a two-day garden fete and tea which opened this afternoon at Paradou, the estate of Mrs. John T. Scheepers on the North Hempstead Turnpike at Brookville.

SCIENCE CONGRESS. -- The Sixth International Congress for the Unity of Science will be held at the University of Chicago, Sept. 2 -- 6, 1941. Its purpose is to aid those who are interested in the unification of science. Those who care to submit papers for consideration by the Program Committee are asked to turn in abstracts not longer than 1,200 words to Dr. Charles Morris, University of Chicago, and not later than June 15.

In the copious output of books for boys and girls, so many of them quite unneeded, it is pleasant to come upon a volume that actually enriches child's experience and widens his horizon. Robert Davis, who has visited the Berber tribes in their high tent villages, has drawn out of his experiences a truthful, sensitive and imaginative picture of a little known country.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 -- In raiding and patrol fighting throughout yesterday in the neighborhood of Fort Capuzzo, Libya, the British captured more than 500 German troops and disabled a considerable number of tanks and armored cars, the Middle East Command announced today.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont. -- The final segment of the steel arch of the new Rainbow Bridge, linking the United States and Canada at Niagara Falls, will be placed this week. With this work completed it is expected that the new structure, which replaces the famed Honeymoon Bridge, destroyed by an ice jam on Jan. 27, 1938, will be ready for motorists in August.

IN nothing do American designers excel more than in country clothes. A leader in this field is Clare Potter, who can dress a woman from morning till evening in styles that have casual elegance. She can make as beautiful a bathing suit as she can a dinner dress. She's famous for her slacks.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 17 -- A little band of valiant Indiana Hoosiers staged a smashing upset in Minnesota's Memorial Stadium today by taking the forty-first Big Ten outdoor track and field championship away from Michigan's big squad of Wolverines, holders of the team title the past four years.

It would not be edifying if the citizens of this broad land, being asked today, as they are, to celebrate the fact that they are Americans, should devote any part of the day to admiring their own good qualities or those of their ancestors. Being an American just now is physically more comfortable than being a Briton or a resident of almost any country in Europe or Asia.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Faculty members in several departments of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania are pointing to a research program, under way and projected, as evidence of how the research power of a university can be utilized for the benefit of the community.

A work stoppage by 91,000 Pennsylvania hard-coal miners tied up all anthracite production last midnight, but renewed intervention by the National Defense Mediation Board succeeded in averting at least until next Friday the threat of a shutdown in the soft coal fields.
A 19-year-old Ecuadorian with a two-handed method of stroke production stepped into the tennis spotlight yesterday as a welcome addition to the local tournament talent.

While ready-to-wear and accessories continued to retain their lead in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, the upholstery fabric, china and glass and housewares departments also drew excellent consumer response, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

HOLLYWOOD has a passion for anonymity. This paradoxical situation springs from the fact that when studios use real names for screen characters they occasionally run into trouble. The more anonymous or fictional a character, the safer for the company.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, May 17 -- "You can say for me," remarked L. Ernest Durocher, distinguished pilot of the equally distinguished Dodgers, as he sat comfortably today in a special train speeding toward Chicago, "that we're headed farther west in high spirits, looking forward to putting on a hitting blitzkrieg behind a lot of low-hit pitching."

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 17 -- Cotton and coffee, Brazil's "bread and butter" products, are in the limelight today, worrying both government and growers. The war has shrunk exports of both commodities, but while the coffee crop for 1941-43 is estimated officially as one of the smallest in many years because of drought, the cotton crop will be greater than last year's.

"Today in the Kingdom of Fragrance, the moudan takes first rank; hence, the world considers it the King of Flowers and the shao yao (herbaceous peony) its Prime Minister!" So stated, as early as the sixteenth century, a Chinese botanical treatise known as "The Widely Disseminated Refinement."

Efforts to induce individuals and some State agencies to embark upon commercial production of silk cocoons in the United States have been undertaken by spinners here, it was reported last week, but as yet have not been successful.

"Humus" is one of those undefinables whose value gardeners recognize but the exact make-up of which is likely to remain one of the minor mysteries. When Spring comes any highway through the suburbs or garden country is inevitably dotted with vendors of dark piles of material labeled humus.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Secretary of State Hull struck out sharply at France today in a sarcastic reference during his press conference to the Vichy explanations of the Franco-German "collaboration" agreement. Those explanations have sought to minimize the significance of the arrangements now being made by the two governments.

Succulents have of late become quite the vogue for indoor gardens but are less well-known as subjects for outdoor use, despite the fact that certain members of the clan have for generations been favorites in cottage gardens.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A cotton picking machine that is said to "pick clean" has been developed by John Rust of Memphis, Tenn., according to a patent (No. 2,241,423) awarded to the noted cotton picker inventor, who with his brother, Mack, a few years ago startled the world with their novel plan of softening the impact of the effect of their invention of a cotton picker on the labor of the South.

Britain's giant new aerial bomb, credited with unprecedented destructive power, is a new evidence of British accomplishments with superlatives in explosives. A historic feat in the last war was the setting off of the greatest explosion ever used in combat.

Each year the circus is new to many children but its enchantment is not dependent on its novelty, and perhaps the young spectator who has seen for several seasons "the biggest show on earth" come to town and has had time to ponder on just how the circus is transported, established on "the lot" and kept running smoothly, finds it even more thrilling than does the novice who sees it for the first time.
SCRANTON, Pa., May 17 (AP) -- Civic leaders and merchants' groups asked anthracite conferees tonight to keep the mines working while negotiating for a new contract.
LIMA, Peru, May 7 -- "There is greater support for Roosevelt's foreign policy in Peru than in the United States," said a high official of the government here to this correspondent.

The Holland America liner Noordam arrived yesterday afternoon at Bush Terminal, Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, from Batavia in the Dutch East Indies, coming across the Pacific Ocean and through the Panama Canal.
DETROIT -- Expecting new car production curtailments in excess of the 20 per cent already ordered, the automotive industry is considering plans for pro-rating its available output to various markets.

TRAVEL LINES: "La Noche de las Americas" (The Night of the Americas) will be presented at Carnegie Hall on Friday. The program of drama and music is part of a national movement to build in Washington, D.C., an auditorium which will become the cultural center of the Western Hemisphere.

NOW, to save you the trouble of making it yourself, there is a French dressing to which chutney has already been added. The chutney is ground fine so that the subtly sharp flavor may better permeate the dressing. . . .

TWO awards have been made in Houghton Mifflin Company's new "Life in America" series. Two thousand five hundred dollars goes to Agnes Morley Cleaveland for "No Life for a Lady" and the same amount to Donald Culross Peattie for "The Road of a Naturalist."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 17 -Qualifying medalists Fred Town of Essex County and W.L. Taylor met defeat today in the first round of match play in the fourth annual Rock Spring Golf Club member-guest invitation tournament. Winners of the medal with a six-under-par 65, they were eliminated, 1 down, by Gene Krautter of Upper Montclair and Lee Bulluck.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 17 -- Publication of the first of a series of Princeton University bulletins for undergraduates and their parents on national defense was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university. The issue deals with the latest information concerning the Selective Service Act and describes university facilities for preparation in other defense services.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, May 17 (AP) -- British authorities proclaimed a "state of emergency" and called up additional peace maintenance forces yesterday in the Malay State of Selangor after soldiers and a crowd of Indian rubber plantation strikers had clashed.

DENVER, Col. -- With Spring in the air and Summer just around the corner, the Rocky Mountain country is preparing for the biggest tourist season and is getting ready to offer more to its visitors than it ever has before.

THE works chosen by the Society for the Publication of American Music for publication this year are David Van Vactor's quintet for flute and strings and Ulric Cole's piano quintet, both of which will be issued in the Fall.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Official quarters said that seizure of Martinique or the other Western Hemisphere French possessions probably would be accomplished by the United States alone. After occupation, the United States would confer with the other Latin American republics regarding establishment of a provisional government as provided for under the Act of Havana.

In a program to aid social service agencies throughout the city, more than 200 City College students each year are receiving intensive field training as volunteer social workers on projects arranged by the college's Social Research Laboratory, it was reported last week.

The Rutgers lacrosse team scored a 14-2 victory over C.C.N.Y. at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. City's tenacious zone defense held the Scarlet to one goal in the first quarter and then broke down, permitting the visitors to count seven times before the half ended and take an 8-0 lead.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Declaring that it represents 83 per cent of the American public united against taking part in the war, the Second National Anti-War Congress, which will convene here for a two-day session on May 30, threatens to swamp President Roosevelt with mass delegations if he makes any belligerent statements or proposals.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 17 (AP) -- Billy Brown, the blond Bayou Bullet, wound up his collegiate track and field career with a record-breaking splash today and paced Louisiana State to a fourth straight Southeastern Conference championship.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 17 -- The Dartmouth College golf team today won the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association championship for the first time in twenty years, defeating the Princeton team at the Woodway Club, 6 1/2 to 2 1/2.

A program on Pan-American relations and national defense has been prepared for the Spring meeting of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, which will be held on Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. at the Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 17 -- The thirteenth annual Vassar horse show opened today under a variety of weather conditions. Fog and humidity were swept away temporarily by a high wind and downpour, these being followed by Scotch mist.

CHUNGKING, China, May 17 -- Brig. Gen. Henry B. Clagett, commander of the air force in the Philippines, arrived here today accompanied by his aides, Colonel Harold H. George of the United States Army Air Corps and Commander Edward McDonnell of the United States Navy Air Force.

NELSONVILLE, Ohio, May 17 (AP) -- Five occupants of a twin-motored Army plane who were killed when the ship crashed in the hills eight miles north of here during a violent storm were identified today as members of a squadron from Barksdale Field, La., on a routine navigation flight to Cleveland.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., May 17 -The first project of its kind in Connecticut to be started under the Lanham act, a community of 300 home units for defense industry workers is now under construction here on former picnic grounds off Stanley Street from plans designed by Henry F. Ludorf of this city and Hartford.

In its final rehearsal before appearing in the I.C. 4-A championships on Decoration Day, New York University's track and field team swamped Manhattan's combination at Ohio Field yesterday. The metropolitan champions scored 93 2-3 points to the Jaspers' 41 1-3 and broke two recently established track records.

THE ages of human life on earth are like an interminable serial story, Dorothy Sayers says: at the head of every new installment stands the summary of the past which we call history, and beneath it the new imperative direction, Begin Here.

With all preliminaries of negotiation disposed of two years ago, conclusion of trade treaties by this country with Argentina and Uruguay was taken as a foregone conclusion by foreign traders here last week. They predicted that the two treaties would be concluded before the end of August.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Ripley Gillett will retire as general alumni secretary of Union Theological Seminary when the associated alumni of the school holds its annual meeting this week in connection with the seminary's one hundred and fifth commencement.

The complaint in some quarters that nobody cares about college baseball any more is unfounded. Somebody cares. Proof positive is offered in the form of a State document, signed, sealed and delivered. Through the kindness of Tom McCabe, director of athletics at Holy Cross, there has come to hand a true copy of Senate Resolution S-261 adopted last month by the upper house of the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations.

MANY people who visit British Columbia have looked up the village that floats. It is at the foot of a precipitous cedarstudded wall of rock in the waters of the Inland Passage and its name is Simoon. Far from the familiar world and rich in the romance of the frontier, Simoon has eight houses, during most of the year.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 -- After almost seven hours of conferences with the strike committees of the A.F. of L. and C.I.O. machinists and with the leaders of other unions involved, Governor Olson announced tonight that he was hopeful that the strike at eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards would be settled in the next few days.
WAR has scrapped a whole library full of illusions -- including the illusion that some individual or group of individuals other than Adolf Hitler was the real power behind National Socialist Germany.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 17 -- Bobby Wilson's terrific 400-foot home-run in the ninth inning gave the Lawrenceville baseball team an even break in the home-and-home series with its traditional rival, The Hill School. Going into the ninth inning before an alumni crowd of 3,000, the Red and Black was trailing by two runs when Captain Wilson, son of the Chicago Cubs' manager, provided a story-book finish to give his team a 6-5 victory.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va. -In a setting of beach umbrellas against the marine background of historic Hampton Roads, the Chamberlin Beach Club and the outdoor swimming pool will have their formal opening this afternoon.

Caution toward discussions of war and peace was advocated yesterday in the report of the World Peace Committee of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Church, adopted at its morning session at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 17 -Navy's baseball team extended its victory streak to nine games today by defeating Notre Dame, 5 to 4, in the only mid-Western appearence of the middies this season. It was the thirteenth Navy triumph in sixteen games.

The English people introduced a new principle of compulsory savings advocated for some time by John Maynard Keynes, which is worth our emulation. It will go a long way toward financing the war by savings and taxes on a 50-50 basis without depriving people of the incentive to work hard.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 17 -- As the Harry Bridges deportation hearing proceeds in San Francisco, his influence in the labor movement in the Pacific Northwest is waning rapidly. Elements strongly opposed to Mr. Bridges and his policies have ascended to power in numerous C.I.O. unions in this region.

ASTORIA, Ore. -- After finding what is believed to be the world's largest known standing Douglas fir tree, Les D. Lloyd, Oregon forester, has declined to reveal its location until he is satisfied that it will be spared by woodsmen, who are already cutting down the grove where it stands.

THE Eastern mixed team-of-four tournament will be played at the Park Central Hotel in two sessions at 2:30 and 8:30 today. Unusually vigorous pre-tournament promotion, owing partly to the fact that the British-American Ambulance Corps will share in the proceeds, has encouraged the American Contract Bridge League to estimate that the contest will draw the largest field ever to enter a major tournament.

Flower enthusiasts will have an opportunity to view the latest novelties in garden irises this week at the regional show of the American Iris Society. It is to be held Friday and Saturday under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York, at their rooms, 598 Madison Avenue.

SCATTERED branches, in ancient legend, paid the Greeks' tribute to a Trojan maiden who had died valiantly. So here nine friends -- those "of his own allegiance," as Stephen Gwynn puts it -- bring their personal tribute to William Butler Yeats; and a beautiful, acute and enlightening tribute it is.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 17 -- Answering the national demand for trained specialists and at the same time acting to preserve the nation's cultural heritage, Tufts College has announced a special course relating to work in engineering chemistry and other applied science with work in its School of Liberal Arts.

As a general rule losses sustained in the conduct of a business, not compensated for by insurance or otherwise, are deductible from gross income in determining taxable income; likewise, losses incurred by an individual in any transaction entered into for profit though not connected with a trade or business.

Sixteen international representatives appointed by George Scalise, former president of the Building Service Employes International Union, who is now in jail for stealing union funds, have been dropped from the union payroll, William H. Cooper, secretary-treasurer of the A.F. of L. affiliate, reported yesterday.

A former Governor of Texas is murdered on a Mexican railway train, and Sheriff Peter Bounty undertakes to find out who did it. The sheriff has no authority in Mexico, but he gets along fairly well without it, even though almost every one of the persons he questions seems to act as suspiciously as possible.

LAST week's arrivals include Eire 2-pence and 3p stamps issued on April 12 to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the 1916 "Easter Rebellion." The 2p is in the map design of the 1922 series of the Irish Free State, but is orange instead of deep green.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Many members of the old Seventh Regiment of New York, now the 207th Coast Artillery, and Buffalo's 209th Regiment come to Sea Island each week-end from Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga., to enjoy the facilities of this coastal resort.

The Philippine freighter Dona Nati arrived yesterday at Pier 2, Erie Basin, Brooklyn, from Manila with twelve passengers and 7,000 tons of sugar and manganese. Four of the passengers were from Manila and the others from Panama.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Government officials are becoming convinced that specific price control legislation will be necessary to combat advancing prices and avert inflation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17 -- Fearing that agents of foreign governments might become members of defense councils in Westchester County and sabotage the work of the groups, the Westchester County Defense Council announced today that its members would be fingerprinted and photographed for identification purposes and that members of thirty village and town defense councils were being asked to follow suit.

TWICE within thirty years this venerable seat of learning, one of the intellectual capitals of mankind, has received the staggering blow of a world conflict. But the shock of the present war has been much lighter in nature and effect than that of the last.
IS the easel picture, invented by the Renaissance artists as the most nearly perfect expression of individualism, doomed now to obsolescence because of the rapidly changing social order?

OMAHA, Neb., May 17 -- Taking one thing after another the Middle Western farmer ought to be feeling pretty cheerful, and he would be if he could forget about the war and possible military involvement of America.

IN the heart of England there is a "pub" which has stood little changed since around the time when Falstaff was the pub-keeper's terror. It was there when Spain's Philip II sent his Armada against England. It was there when Napoleon talked of taking the United Kingdom by force.
Perhaps half a century ago somebody wrote a piece of light verse about the difficulty of diagnosis. It described the wrangling of a dozen doctors, each with a different idea, and ended:

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP) -Mauri Rose, a worker in the Allison Engineering Company's airplane engine manufacturing plant here, today won the pole position for the Indianapolis Motor Speedway 500-mile race as an even dozen drivers qualified for the May 30 auto classic despite a high wind and chilling cold weather.

Bill Hasslinger, who hit a tenth-inning home run with the bases loaded when the teams met at Philadelphia recently, drove a 360-foot drive into the Harlem River in the opening stanza at Baker Field yesterday. That blow, which barely missed a passing tugboat, sent Columbia off to a 2-0 lead against Pennsylvania.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. May 17 -- The senior class of Vassar College held its annual promenade in Students Building this evening. A Spring setting was provided by yellow and white balloons festooning the balcony and wall decorations, in which satyrs piped and Disneyish top-hatted fawns and lei-decked lambs, rabbits and squirrels, ducks and suckling pigs gamboled between green balloon trees.

Science is indeed wonderful, especially when the fictioneers attempt to anticipate its discoveries. In this story we have a murder committed by a means not yet known to science, and the author has succeeded in making it fairly convincing except for one little point which he has apparently overlooked.

VICHY, France, May 17 (UP) -The Vichy government decided today, after study of new reports from its Ambassador in Washington, that it would not regard the placing of United States Coast Guard men on French vessels in American ports as "confiscation."

THIS month's notes must be taken as something in the nature of an interim report. There are lots of big films in the offing, only three of any consequence in the studios. "49th Parallel," that marathon film of empire, is actually finished.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 17 -- Finance Minister Walter Nash, explaining the government's budgetary policy, declared today that there was no conflict between the decision to produce the maximum quantity of consumer goods and also to absorb superfluous purchasing power by taxation.
VICHY, France, May 17 -- All was quiet in Vichy today after the rumblings yesterday, which seemed to presage a French-American storm.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Dr. Henry G. Knight, chief of the Bureau of Agricultural Chemistry and Engineering of the Department of Agriculture. received tonight the annual medal of the American Institute of Chemists in recognition of his work in searching for new and wider uses for surplus agricultural products.
AMHERST, Mass., May 17 -- Amherst scored its sixth straight baseball victory today, defeating Williams, 3 -- 2, in a ten-inning encounter and thereby preserving an unblemished home record.
LONDON, May 17 -- The British have gone through worse weeks than this, but it is doubtful whether they have ever gone through a more confusing one.

THE actual day of death of some men means little more than a day of interlude, of transition, as they go on living -- perhaps we should call it a hesitation or a moment for judgment while the world decides whether it will allow him to pass into the gray land of the yesterdays (the used ticker-tape of old fads and emotions), or keep him in the full glare of our contemporary sun.

ROME, May 17 -- President Roosevelt's statements to the press indicating that the United States might follow the same policies it adopted last century against "pirates" and his warning to Vichy against collaboration with Germany are termed by the Stefani agency today "explosions of anger which betray the President's hysterical temperament."

Suggestions that would lead to a wide variety of changes in the curriculum and extra-curricular program, as well as faculty-student relations, are made by many of the 2,500 alumni questioned in a survey made at Brooklyn College during the last year and a half, according to a report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A letter from President Roosevelt paying him a personal tribute and the dedication of a flagpole with a bronze base to commemorate his services to the Boy Scouts of America today made memorable the sixty-fifth birthday anniversary of Dr. James E. West, who for thirty years has been Chief Scout Executive of the organization to which he has dedicated a lifetime of work.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 17 -The medalists and the seeded teams generally had unusually hard going in the opening round of the annual member-guest golf tourney at the Lakeville Club today.

Soviet-German collaboration in the Near and Middle East looms as an important military and diplomatic possibility of the nest future. Every step of Soviet diplomacy since Joseph Stalin assumed the premiership points in the direction of appeasing Hitler.
Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy, who has investigated a greater number of explosions and incendiary fires than any man in the world, marks his thirty-fourth anniversary in city service today.

AN offer by Time and Tide of prizes for the best list of three "entirely happy" books in the English language, with reason for the choice, has produced an interesting competition. The first place was taken by a reader who made the extraordinarily catholic selection of "The Book of Tobit," Waltons "Compleat Angler" and Mrs. Beeton's cookery book.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The training of America's new Army involves the acquirement and development of a vast amount of real estate, frequently land that must meet very special specifications.

Exports of American aircraft and other military supplies to Britain -- that vital link in American no less than in British security -- rose further in March. The State Department's monthly report shows that the value of exports of "arms, ammunition and implements of war" to the British Commonwealth amounted in March to $49,196,000, exceeding by one-third the previous record of last August and by more than one-half the February total of $31,415,000.

Encouraged by the cessation of showers yesterday afternoon, 170 artists flocked to all available vantage points along the south and west of Washington Square Park for the continuation of the tenth outdoor art exhibition that began on Friday.

LONDON, Sunday, May 18 -Strong forces of British Royal Air Force bombers delivered a stepped-up attack on the Germans' invasion shore across the Channel for hours during the past night for the third night in succession.

THE picture of a printing press on board ship, pounding away to the pitch and roll of the vessel, is one to stir the romantic imagination. That there was one with the French fleet at Newport during the American Revolutionary War has been known to scholars, and its elusive imprints are highly prized by collectors.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 -- The war that the Iraqi Government has been waging against Britain since May 2 burst forth furiously today as German warplanes -- fighters as well as bombers -- raced over Iraq and attacked British positions.

AFTER two or three months of discussion, the program for providing theatrical entertainment for the Army camps and Navy stations has begun to emerge from the blueprint stage. About ten days ago Ed Wynn took a small unit of singers, dancers, performers and show girls to Fort Belvoir, Va., and Fort Meade, Md., for experimental performances out-of-doors.

American women physicians are attempting to get military status in order to serve the nation in case of war, but in China, according to a report received at headquarters of United China Relief, hundreds of Chinese women already are at work as doctors, nurses, dressers, and pharmacists with the Chinese forces.

THE most auspicious thing about George Bernard Shaw's "Major Barbara," which certainly was far and away the big screen event of last week, is that it takes for granted that movie audiences have brains. That is a simple concession which films very seldom seem to make, for the higher reaches of the intellect are about as infrequently penetrated on the screen as man, in his aerial ascensions, invades the upper stratosphere.

THE first section, about 3,100 lots, of the late Edward S. Knapp's historical collection of United States stamps, covers and reference material brought $80,729, it was announced last week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., where the auction was held on May 5 through May 10.

This is a tale for 6 to 8 year olds of a Scottie who was born with an adventurous spirit. Whenever he found the front door open Diggery-Dogs was in the habit of starting off, all by himself, without waiting for collar or lead, to seek adventure.

Transformation of a buyers' into a sellers' market, plus widening changes likely to be wrought on consumer demand as the defense program moves into high gear, will demand the utmost in budget flexibility during the second half of this year, according to the consensus in retail circles last week.

A committee of debutantes under the leadership of Miss Stella Richardson will meet tomorrow afternoon at the Cafe du Parc in the interests of the benefit performance of the play "Native Son," to be given Thursday night at the St. James Theatre.

THE NEW YORK TIMES recent editorial, "The Need for Economy," stressed both the need for economy and the limitations under which economies can be made. It stated that in the $17,486,000,000 Presidential budget, the items from which the billion-dollar reduction proposed by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau could be realized amounted to only $4,059,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- For the fifth straight year Hun School of Princeton, N.J., won the Stotesbury Cup race on the Schuylkill River today before 4,000 spectators.

TORONTO -- You can find scarlet-coated Mounties in almost any part of Canada. But you have to look for them; they are not present on every street, or entirely confined to the last frontier. A small force, fewer than 3,000 at the outbreak of war in 1939, they are distributed throughout the Dominion, from Atlantic to Pacific, from the United States border to within 800 miles of the North Pole.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Whatever thoughts the heads of the warring nations are giving to the political rearrangement of the world and the gigantic economic readjustments that will have to follow the conflict, there is already intensive study of these problems in diplomatic quarters here.

As evidence of their willingness to make "any reasonable sacrifice" in the interest of national defense, C.I.O. members employed at the Ford Instrument Company plant in Long Island City have notified the management that they are ready to work sixty hours a week to relieve a shortage of skilled precision mechanics, it became known yesterday.

FORTUNE GALLO, founder and director of the San Carlo Opera Company, has been appointed general manager of the Chicago Opera Company. He has already taken over his duties and is in Chicago now discussing with the trustees his plans to "democratize opera in the grand manner."
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers helped celebrate Connie Mack Day today by beating his Athletics, 8 to 5, to sweep the three-game series, their only road victories of the season.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17 -- Valdina Myth, hard-running daughter of Sortie and Sweet Myth that races for the Valdina Farm of Emerson F. Woodward, Texas sportsman, took a long stride toward the championship among the 3-year-old fillies as she accounted for the sixty-seventh running of the $5,000 added Kentucky Oaks at Churchill Downs today.

"I MEAN, your 'ome's your 'ome," said a Londoner to Jan Struther, trying to explain why a regular "moving day" simply "didn't seem natural." And now, Miss Struther asks in her unaffectedly eloquent introduction to this book of letters from women of Britain, "What is your home?"

Early settlement of the week-old shipyard strike at San Francisco, which has tied up $500,000,000 of defense construction, was forecast by Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, on his arrival at La Guardia Field late yesterday afternoon from Chicago.

DIMITRI MITROPOULOS will conduct a special concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Sunday, June 15, at the Lewisohn, Stadium under the joint auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802.

THE question raised by the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League as to whether the German war film, "Sieg Im Westen" (Victory in the West) is a newsreel or a "feature film which should have been submitted to the State Board of Regents for censorship" is indeed a puzzler.

BRITAIN, wrote Robert P. Post in THE TIMES of May 4, "can best be pictured as one vast fortress, beleaguered in the greatest siege the world has ever known" -- a fortress whose people have had to "learn new ways and adjust themselves to conditions that they never though they would have to face."

THE central thesis of Florence Horn's book "Orphans of the Pacific" is that the "Philippine question," far from being answered, is only beginning to be posed. It is a book about a problem, and Miss Horn makes it very plain that a ready-made solution to that problem has net yet been offered.

LIMA, Peru, May 17 (UP) -- The newspaper Comercio today criticized Secretary of State Cordell Hull for his explanation of the motives behind United States participation with Argentina and Brazil in an offer to mediate the Peruvian-Ecuadorian boundary dispute.

Not one of the several films devoted to arousing America against Germany has been more than a casual success at the box office and as a result pictures which deal with world conditions now are of the old fashioned cops-and-robbers stripe.

The Great Depression brought about profound changes in established monetary systems and policies. The current war is speeding up and intensifying those changes. Under the title of "The Torrent of Liquidity" the most recent issue of The London Economist to reach this side offers an interesting and provocative discussion of current monetary developments and their possible outcome.

THERE is a decided taste among the French public for sea novels or stories of adventure in distant lands. To some readers they afford relief from complex problems or sophisticated manners; to others they are a compensation for the monotony of everyday existence.

Since the first of the month the upward movement of commodity prices has taken a sharp spurt sufficient to carry many staples to the highest levels since the outbreak of the war and to lift the general average of commodity prices a full point to the highest figure in more than three and one-half years.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- High-ranking War Department officials have approved plans for training "several thousand" British civilians annually for service in the Royal Air Force, and the first group will arrive in this country early next month.

LONDON, May 17 -- The International Tin Committee, restriction control body, met in London on Thursday. The meeting lasted for several hours, but no official statement was published. No date for a new meeting was fixed.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Treasury, simulating British salesmanship in war finance, began telling the American people tonight how many bullets could be bought for the price of a defense savings bond.

LINCOLN KIRSTEIN'S American Ballet Caravan, which has been inactive since its engagement at the World's Fair last Summer, has been brought very much to life this Spring and will set out early next month on the most ambitious project of its five-year-old career.

JAMESTOWN, Tenn., May 17 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler "can, will and must be beaten, and all the medals pinned on the chest of so-called heroes can not avert it," Alvin C. York, World War hero, declared tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 17 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies, speaking in London last February, pointed out that Australians engaged in the fighting forces and munition making exceeded 400,000 and would reach 600,000 before the end of the year.

Setting at rest all doubt of his ability to stay a mile, King Cole yesterday captured the historic Withers Stakes by four lengths after being made an odds-on favorite with 31,613 racegoers who remembered his second place to Whirlaway in the Preakness a week before.

A distinguished gathering representative of society, diplomatic circle and the British and Canadian colonies in this city is expected to throng the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night when the May Ball will be given for the benefit of Bundles for Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Connie Mack, 78 years old, who quit a job in a Massachusetts shoe factory fifty-eight years ago to enter organized baseball, was honored today by the game to which he has devoted his life.

MIAMI, Fla., May 17 (AP) -- Philip F. La Follette declared tonight that "the two Republican jokers running wild in the New Deal, Colonels Stimson and Knox, are pushing the nation to the brink of war."

With the emphasis on the friendship between the children of the Pan-American countries and this nation, a group of youthful virtuosi, members of the New York State Federation of Music Clubs, yesterday afternoon presented a musical festival in the Wanamaker Auditorium in honor of fifty Latin-American children.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 17 -- Yale scored six runs in a fourth-inning rally today and defeated Cornell, defending Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League champion, 8 -- 6, on rain-swept Hoy Field.

NOT so sensational as a recent book and movie, which purported to expose the lives of migrant workers, but full of surprises are the facts concerning the growing class of skilled and semi-skilled workmen who, liking an occasional change of scene, travel regular routes of seasonal occupations in comfort, via trailers.
With the fundamental tenets upon which it was founded being called increasingly into question in many parts of the world, Queens College is making plans for its first commencement on June 16.

Another chapter in the struggle for the Mediterranean, particularly the Eastern Mediterranean, was opening last week as Germany forced a new agreement with Vichy and Axis planes landed in Syria and Iraq. The stage apparently was rapidly being set for a full extension of the zone of war and for resumption of military operations on a large scale.

INWOOD, L.I., May 17 -- Plans have been completed for an intensive search to be conducted tomorrow for Wesley Meserole of Lord Avenue, Inwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Meserole who vanished while on a hunting trip on North Dome Mountain, Spruceton, N.Y., on Nov. 26 last.

WHEN you open your can of large, ripe olives and find them disappointingly less impressive than you had expected, don't think the grocer was trying to take you in. Olives labeled "large" or even "extra large" according to the California Ripe Olive Standardization Act are after all not such very big olives.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the smallest and narrowest in nine months or, more exactly, since Aug. 24 of last year. Prices drifted narrowly and closed firm on a volume of 140,540 shares, compared with 377,170 on the previous week-end.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 17 -- The chief battle was for second place. Favored Pennsylvania moved into the lead at the third event and was never headed, making a runaway of the seventh annual Heptagonal Games in Palmer Stadium today. The weather was capricious, there being showers and sunshine, but the Quakers were as steady as could be.

THE food stamp plan celebrated its second birthday on Friday amid national applause. Farmers and housewives, public officials, welfare administrators, chambers of commerce sing its praises. A Senator suggests that similar mechanisms might be helpful in the inter-American trade.

A MAN is never too old and seldom too young to love the sun and the water -- the skies, the seas, the lakes and streams. And of all the seasons, Spring is the time when thoughts turn most strongly to these eternal forces. Spring is the sun's season, and the rain's. A Spring sunrise is full of new leaves, new flowers, new songs and awakening life.

Wessman, chairman of the Department of Civil Engineering, and Professor William A. Rose, at New York University's College of Engineering.

An assertion that "production of vital drugs in America is being held up because of the lack of raw materials" was made yesterday at La Guardia Field by Dr. Henry De Laszlo, home-bound British physician, who left aboard the Atlantic Clipper for Lisbon.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 17 -- George Woods, Holy Cross ace, bested Bill Grey, Dartmouth sophomore, in a pitchers' duel today to score a 4-2 triumph. Woods fanned seven and allowed five hits, Grey striking out two and allowing five blows.

After three years of work Leon Kroll has completed the World War memorial murals in the Municipal Memorial Auditorium, Worcester, Mass. They are to be presented formally to the city of Worcester on the evening of May 28.

TUBERCULOSIS can be diagnosed in incipient stages, diphtheria can be prevented, no child need develop rickets -these are just a few of the advances in public health which are well-known. Individually we do very little about them.

FROM the moment Laura Sarelle first came to Leppard Hall she hated the place and all its surroundings. Yet the ancient house standing near the banks of the Avon had every luxury known to the time. There were great rooms with heavy, handsome furniture and heavy, handsome hangings; there was gold plate and silver, fine china and crystal, the regiment of servants thought appropriate to a noble establishment in 1840.

Fur buying got off to a good start in the wholesale markets here last week. Buying interest centered in the popular price lines, as the showings of the high-grade style lines will not be held before another week. The proposed fur tax was regarded in the trade as the sole cloud upon the brightest sales prospects for any season in many years.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Shipbuilders are "well ahead of schedule" in constructing 200 "ugly duckling" cargo vessels for the United States and 212 merchant vessels for Great Britain, the United States Maritime Commission reported today.

The United Service Organizations for National Defense will hold a rally in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night for parents and friends of the 45,000 young New Yorkers who have been inducted into the armed forces through the Selective Service Act.

The first step toward introducing the "Sword of the Spirit Movement," founded by English Catholics, in the Americas as a religious counter-offensive against totalitarianism has been taken in Canada, where leading churchmen are circulating a statement, "The Sword of the Spirit in Canada.

AURORA, Ind., May 17 (UP) -- Five members of a family -- their bodies scattered over the grounds of a lonely farm near Aurora -- were found shot to death today after a seven-hour search by neighbors and police.
BERLIN, May 17 -- The Boerse had an active and firm session today, with most of the principal listings gaining as much as three points in the week's final trading.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Four Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee -- Clark of Missouri, Reynolds of North Carolina, Pepper of Florida and Murray of Montana -- suggested today that the United States take over French island possessions in this hemisphere.

BENTZ PLAGEMANN, a young author from Ohio, has made writing the theme of his novel. It is a first novel, notable for its well-built and clear characterization. Though autobiographical in its basic problems it is written with an artistic discipline rarely to be found in a first novel with so personal a theme.

Fifteen members of the hundred Associate Alumnae of Hunter College attended the annual Spring reunion yesterday in the new college building at 695 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Demands for skilled labor in the metal working trades will soon outrun the supply, Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, advised Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, deputy director of Selective Service, in requesting today the cooperation of local draft boards in making certain that "trained workers, so urgently needed, can serve their country most effectively at their factory benches."

THE significant inscription "Nederland Zal Herrijzen" (Netherlands Shall Rise Again) is on 5 cents plus 5c, 10c plus 10c and 1-gulden plus 1g semi-postal stamps issued by the Netherlands Indies to raise funds to buy bombing planes for the Dutch airmen fighting with the R.A.F. in Great Britain.

Leading American naval builders and ship engineers are expected to attend the Spring meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in Washington on Friday to discuss technical aspects of the present record shipbuilding effort in the United States.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- Harvard's 150-pound varsity crew retained the Joseph Wright Trophy and its Eastern intercollegiate lightweight title by defeating the Princeton eight by a length and a quarter today in the five-crew feature event of the American Henley regatta on the Charles River.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 17 -- In silent sorrow and grim determination the Norwegian people today celebrated their independence day.

A Spring fete that has received a large advance subscription is the dinner dance to be given Thursday in the Garden of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Brazil committee. The party will feature a Pan-American motif and divertissements and its net proceeds will be directed to St. Margaret's School at Pelotas, Brazil, which provides training in various crafts and professions and aids indigent families in the locality.

A meeting featuring community problems has been scheduled for Saturday by the Connecticut branches of the American Association of University Women, with delegates holding an all-day session at the Woodrow Wilson High School in Middletown. Mrs. William T. Grumbly will preside.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 17 -- Answering the call for cooperation of civil authorities in the Forty-fourth Division's campaign to defend the South Jersey seacoast against theoretical invasion next week, six members of the State Defense Council and representatives of the American Legion conferred with Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, division commander, this afternoon.

BERLIN, May 17 -- It is not improbable that since Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's transoceanic flight to France and the abdication of King Edward VIII no carefully planned resolve of any one man has created such a world sensation as the airplane flight of Rudolf Hess to Scotland and the enemy camp.

MADRID, Spain, May 17 -- The mixed feelings with which Spain looks on the surrender of the Vichy Government to Germany could be detected today in the prominence given by the press to President Roosevelt's declaration to the French people.

AMERICAN designers are very busy with America these days. Their own, their native land is finally being recognized as the varied, colorful and even exotic country it is. Time was when the designers of prints and patterned cloth derived their inspiration almost entirely from Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application covering an issue of $35,393,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1971 and $12,000,000 par value of preferred stock, which will be the first utility issue proposed to be offered under the commission's new rule for competitive bidding.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 17 -- Two runs in the eighth Brought the Princeton nine from behind and another in the ninth assured it of a 6-4 victory over Harvard in an Eastern Intercollegiate baseball game on Soldiers Field today.

BOSTON, May 17 -- Bob Teller was not his usual self today, but he didn't have to be, as the Indians let loose with four homers to give their pitching ace his seventh victory of the campaign, a 12-to-9 triumph over the Red Sox.

The twenty-fifth annual meeting and anniversary of the Conference Board, whose speakers will discuss the subjects of national defense and economic reconstruction, will be held Wednesday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With three mighty strokes of his bat, Mickey Rutner, St. John's second baseman, wrote the downfall of New York University's nine at Ohio Field yesterday. His two home runs and triple accounted for seven tallies and propelled the Redmen to their second victory of the season over the Violet, 14 to 3, in a game called at the end of seven innings by agreement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17 -Mrs. Charles S. Maddock Jr. of Trenton was installed today for a three-year term as President of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs at the final session of the forty-seventh annual convention which opened Thursday.

INFORMATION PLEASE will turn the tables on Clifton Fadiman, the WEAF show's acid-tongued quiz-master, this week. In celebration of the program's third anniversary broadcast, on Friday, Deems Taylor, versatile "guest expert," will swap places with Fadiman who on that occasion will be expected to answer questions -- or else! Taylor, who has faced the Fadiman barrage some fifteen times, is expected to show little mercy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18 -- A national conference on "Science and Engineering as Allies of Medicine" will be the highlight of the Alumni Day activities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on June 9 when more than 2,000 graduates from all parts of the country return here for their annual reunions.

The approaching end of the club season is the signal for many presidential gavels to change hands. The shift of officers in New Jersey affects State as well as city organizations. Among the former, the New Jersey League of Women Voters at its annual convention in Newark last week elected a new president for the first time in seven years.

Two gunmen were killed and a civilian and a policeman were wounded last night when three bandits and two policemen engaged in a pistol fight in a small room at the rear of a grocery store at 401 East Thirteenth Street, where the three bandits attempted a hold-up.
BOSTON, May 17 -- Sales in Boston department stores for the week ended May 10 were 4.6 per cent above the comparable week of last year and for the month to date show a gain of 9.2 per cent.
The events that took place on the world stage last week were momentous -- so momentous that even the startling flight to Scotland of Rudolf Hess, the third-ranking Nazi, was overshadowed.

THIS is a prizefight story with a difference. To begin with, the hero does not come from city streets or the small-town tough element. He is a high-school, Y.M.C.A. gym kid when the tale opens, clever with his dukes and beyond that gifted with a streaking left that is a natural.

THE day is fortunately passing in education when music was regarded as an art isolated from any other and when the musician himself, student or professional, was an isolationist. It was of course vaguely apprehended that all the expressive arts had a sympathetic relationship, if nothing more, and that the perception of beauty in various expressive forms would broaden and ennoble the life of the community.
HONOLULU, May 17 -- The threat of a strike tie-up of Hawaii defense industries appeared to be diminishing today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Government officials here are less concerned today about the anthracite strike call issued by the United Mine Workers, C.I.O., than they are about the possibilities of another soft-coal stoppage due to inability of the U.M.W. and Southern operators to agree on elimination of a forty-cent daily wage differential as demanded by the union.

New York University's School of Architecture and Allied Arts, 1071 Sixth Avenue, the largest school of its kind in the State, will hold its last regular classes Tuesday. The university decided on Nov. 27 to close the 15-year-old school to save a $30,000 to $50,000 yearly deficit incurred in its maintenance.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Retail trade moved ahead at a steady pace this week under the stimulus of warmer weather, with leading stores reporting gains of between 10 and 12 per cent over last year. While house furnishings were still active, comment was that the demand was more evenly distributed throughout all departments.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -Washington hammered four St. Louis pitchers for thirteen hits today to register a 12-7 victory, producing six runs in a hectic sixth inning to take the lead for the first time. The Browns mauled a quartet of Washington pitchers for fourteen hits.
LITTLE change in recent trade trends was noted in the week although the peak of appliance buying may have been passed. Home ware volume, however, continues to be a feature of current business.

For forty years I have tried to serve my country by my pen, and today I would like to say a few words to all the Frenchmen who are living in the United States, and -- if I may -- to the American citizens of French descent.

LONDON, May 17 -- "Hitler has announced that he did not recognize as belligerents the officers and men of the 'Free French' naval forces, but we have retained our French uniforms and I have conveyed to the enemy that if any of our men should be treated as francs-tireurs, for every one who was shot I would hang two Germans and three Italians."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Roosevelt's defiance of Germany yesterday to make its blockade of the Red Sea effective is accepted in many quarters here as a vivid indication that the Administration is veering back toward the traditional American policy of freedom of tile seas, with all that might mean in connection with this. country's pledges of all-out aid to the anti-Axis powers.

ISTANBUL, May 17 (UP) -- The Turkish press today scoffed at French contentions that German planes had made only "forced landings" in Syria. Many newspapers accused Vichy of "treachery" in granting the Nazis airdromes in Syria and Yeni Sabah said "the agreement between Germany and Darlan is the heaviest blow yet to France's honor."

The railroads and the manufacturers of railway rolling stock are producing equipment at the highest rate in twenty years, but their progress is threatened by a shortage of steel. Lack of this material would seem to be an impossibility in a country which produces more of it than any other.

Members of society arrived at the Turf and Field Club for luncheon yesterday long before the first race. Many had tables, reserved long in advance, on the new Roof Garden facing the terrace, where the fashion revue was held. The large restaurant of the club in the enclosure, beneath the boxes adjoining the track, was filled to capacity and persons who had failed to reserve tables were disappointed.

This is coach George Eastment's thirteenth year at the helm of track at Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, but his luck as regards winning team championships has been nothing but good. Eastment's charges captured the twenty-fourth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools senior team crown at Baker Field for the fourth straight year yesterday by rolling up a total of 71 1/2 points.

The sizable pine tree that stood by itself in a hilly pasture had a good deal of company and heard a good deal of talk from the rabbits and squirrels, the birds and the sheep. As all these creatures mentioned the delightful things to be seen on the other side of the hill, the pine tree grew restless and longed to see them, too.
BERLIN, May 17 -- The Siemens company has announced the discovery of an instrument for locating metals and other foreign bodies in the human organism.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN he was filling teeth for a living, Dr. Edgar Buchanan was unhappy, unhealthy and did not give a hoot about anything. Now that he is filling film roles, he is happy, healthy, and exudes joy of living from every pore.
THE blitz attacks on London come and go with increasing discomfort for the attackers; but still a gradual process continues bringing back to the West End its wandering successes of the pre-blitz era.

YOSEMITE PARK, Calif. -- Exploration of the mountain-studded upland country in Yosemite National Park will get under way soon, when thousands of Eastern tourists take to the saddle and hiking shoe on rambling jaunts into the park's little-traveled interior.

QUEBEC, May 17 -- Adelard Godbout, Premier of the Province of Quebec, said in a statement yesterday that in reply to recent articles appearing in the United States press concerning the attitude of French Canadians toward the war, he desired to place once and for all before the American public the exact status of French Canadians.

SUMMIT, N. J., May 17 -- The high quality of entries made double triumphs difficult during the first day's judging of the fifteenth annual horse show of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club in Watchung Reservation today. That was especially true among the saddle classes, where only one horse took more than one blue.

These are confusing days for adult education. The two major problems involved in a work, the importance of which is generally conceded, were stated last week by Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, when he said that a sound program must prepare us for united action and at the same time strengthen devotion to democracy.

MAZATLAN, Mexico. -- Mazatlan, once the haunt of pirates, today offers the tourist unusual beauty and a refuge from the world. The west coast peninsula on which Mazatlan is located has been inhabited by native Indian tribes since time immemorial, as proved by the pottery discoveries in excavations during the last twenty years.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., May 17 -Mrs. Carver Havemeyer of New York and Dr. Seth A. Von Brumm of Philadelphia were married today at Kelvedon Farm, the home of Colonel and Mrs. John C. Butler, near here.

ONE of the many things that puzzle Assistant District Attorney Lyle Curtis in the case with which this story deals is the peculiar costume worn by the young woman found dead in her Pullman compartment as the train is pulling into Grand Central Station.

THE first loan exhibition to be held in the new National Gallery of Art at Washington opened with a preview last Thursday afternoon and to the public Friday morning. It is composed of 200 water-colors selected from some 10,000 entries submitted by artists in a competition conducted by the Section of Fine Arts, Federal Works Agency, Public Buildings Administration.

INTENDED to synchronize with the posthumous publication of Kimon Nicolaides's book, "The Natural Way to Draw," an exhibition of that artist-teacher's work opened last week and is current through May 24 in the Print Room of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 17 -- For the second time in as many weeks, Syracuse's green but inspired varsity crew came from behind in the home stretch to triumph on Onondaga Lake early this evening, beating a surprising M.I.T. eight by a mere foot and a half.
