CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- With new blood showing its still potent effect, the Reds cut loose with a fourteen-hit attack against the Braves today and, with a great defense, gained their second straight victory, 7 to 3. Cincinnati thus tied Boston for fifth place, the Braves falling from the fourth notch.

R.G. LeTourneau, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on April 30 net income of $2,305,238, equivalent to $5.12 a share on 450,000 common shares, compared with $1,914,998, or $4.25 a share, for the twelve months ended on April 30, 1940.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- George P. Rea, president of the New York Curb Exchange, and three other authors of new exchange trading plans designed to bring off-the-exchange trading back to exchange floors will confer with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday regarding adoption of an ideal plan of this character.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- The solution to a series of campus thefts at Yale, Cornell and Princeton was believed to have been found by the Princeton borough police today with the arrest of three youthful suspects following a burglary in one of the university dormitories last night.

JERUSALEM, May 19 -- American, British and Palestinian residents of Lebanon today began leaving the country on the advice of their consuls. Tense expectation prevails in the French-mandated territory owing to the speed with which events are developing after Nazi agents opened headquarters in a Beirut hotel, where they were visited by many German and Italian "tourists."

Members of the Finance Committee of the City Council questioned the propriety of a number of salary increases yesterday when they held a public hearing on the budgets of the Finance and Hospital Departments in City Hall.

ROME, May 19 -- The outlines of the new Kingdom of Croatia became somewhat clearer today, but the clarity only proves even more that the Croat State will be a helpless dependency of Italy and to a lesser extent of Germany. Even the Italian armed forces are not to be withdrawn from Croat territory.

LORAIN, Ohio, May 19 (UP) -- Union and company officials agreed tonight that a strike at the local plant of the American shipbuilding company, which is working on $10,000,000 worth of defense orders, may spread to other Great Lakes yards.

Warren Wright's Whirlaway, Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner, will make his 1941 metropolitan debut when he goes to the post in the mile and a sixteenth Henry of Navarre Purse at Belmont Park today.

A $100,000 libel action filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court against William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, by Ralph K. Jacobs, former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, was withdrawn yesterday after Mr. Herlands had explained in a letter to Mr. Jacobs that the subpoening of the bank accounts of Mr. Jacobs and forty-three other members of the prosecutor's office did not imply that there was anything improper about Mr. Jacobs's bank accounts or conduct.

TOKYO, May 19 -- The domestic news in Japan has been dominated lately by the visit of Empress Nagako to the shrines and mausoleums in the Kat Sai district, where she paid homage and offered prayers to the imperial ancestors.

This is a story about a housewife out in Jackson Heights who felt that every American ought to be doing something about making the world unsafe for Adolf Hitler. So she cut corners on her weekly budget, saved up $40 in pennies, and took the pennies to the neighborhood postoffice to buy two defense bonds for her baby.
Construction of the first large-scale commercial tin smelter in the United States will start soon at Texas City, Texas, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Complete mystery continued today to surround the disappearance of the Egyptian liner Zamzam, with several score of Americans aboard, so far as official Washington was concerned. The State Department kept a long vigil hoping for some word but none had come until late tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- Pageantry provided the highlight here tonight at the opening of the golden jubilee celebration of the General Federation of Women's Clubs. Quaint bonnets and hoop skirts, lace mitts and Paisley shawls were prominent in the stately processional that opened the fiftieth annual meeting in Convention Hall, dedicated to the heroines and the pioneers of half a century of activity in the far-flung organization, now more than 2,000,000 strong.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 20 -- Eight German planes were destroyed in and around Britain between dusk Sunday and last evening -- five of them during combat over the English Channel yesterday afternoon between four Spitfires and ten Messerschmitt 109's that lasted a scant five minutes.

The Alcoa Steamship Company, 17 Battery Place, announced yesterday the purchase of two more freighters to meet demands for cargo shipments to Trinidad and other West Indies islands where United States military bases are now being established.
LONDON, May 19 (UP) -- Britain is paying the closest attention to the possible passage of German materiel from Syria to Iraq "by whatever route," including Turkey, it was said officially today.

TOKYO, May 19 -- Official quarters and the press are jubilant over recent victories reported by the Japanese forces in North China. It is declared that they converted a Spring offensive contemplated by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek into a rout, destroyed his last defenses north of the Yellow River lifeline and exposed some 2,000,000 of his best troops, which had been concentrated for the offensive, to annihilation.
BERLIN, May 19 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

SAN FRACISCO, May 19 -- Counsel for Harry Bridges offered at his deportation hearing today the first of a series of witnesses called to show that the California director of the C.I.O. did not follow the Communist party's line but frequently went against it in his trade union activities.

CAIRO, May 19 -- Surrender of the entire Italian force in the Alagi area took place today after the Italians had spent yesterday in collecting wounded, as agreed upon in the armistice. The British granted a request of the Italian commander, the Duke of Aosta, that he be the last to leave. He will surrender with General Trezzani and his personal staff at noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- John L. Sullivan, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, suggested to the House Ways and Means Committee today a revision of the Excess Profits Tax Act of 1940 to recapture at least $1,096,000,000 excess and other profits from the defense program. The Treasury seeks an additional $3,500,000,000 in revenue to help finance the rearmament drive.

Twenty-six young English evacuees were guests of the New York Zoological Society yesterday at a preview of the new Bronx Park Children's Zoo, where boys and girls will be permitted to play with the animals, and adults are not admitted unless accompanied by a child.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 19 -- Russia and Germany appear to be arranging some sort of joint action in the Middle East, according to diplomatic reports received here as the Soviet Army began Spring manoeuvres with a considerable concentration of troops at Tashkent, near the Iranian frontier.

Seven hundred women have volunteered to work for the drive of the United Service Organizations for National Defense to raise $1,000,000 of the $3,000,000 quota for this area to operate service clubs at camps and defense centers, Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich, chairman of the New York City women's division of the U.S.O., announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House received today two reports from the Coinage, Weights and Measures Committee on President Roosevelt's request that his power to reduce the gold content of the dollar and maintain a $2,000,000,000 Stabilization Fund be continued for two years.

Boys Club Week, marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Boys Club of America, began formally yesterday in thirty-eight States. Locally, it be-began when Kate Smith served chocolate ice cream and cookies and Grover Whalen had his shoes shined.

There were 700 sorely disappointed young men left behind when the Egyptian steamship Zamzam sailed from New York on March 20 with a unit of the British-American Ambulance Corps bound for Lake Chad in the tropical vastness of French Equatorial Africa.
CRETE, Ill., May 19 (AP) -- The Lexbrook Stable's Potranco, 11-to-5 favorite, won the opening day's feature event at Lincoln Fields today. The track has a thirty-day meeting.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., May 19 -- New York's old Seventh Regiment's musical comedy, "Who Is Leslie?" burlesquing. Army life, had its premiere tonight with the attendant full dress of a Broadway first nighter

The Bankers Foreign Exchange Committee, headed by R.F. Loree, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, announced yesterday receipt of cabled advices from London that British special pound-sterling account procedure applied to Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama (excluding the Canal Zone), Salvador and Venezuela.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 19 -- Westchester County would require 180,000 persons for local defense work in case of a grave national emergency, the County Defense Council announced today in beginning a registration of all men, women and children between the ages of 16 and 65 who are willing and able to serve as air wardens, firemen, policemen, first-aid specialists, guards at military objectives and workers in other fields.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- American transport airplanes are being used by the British to carry water to troops operating in desert regions in North Africa and the Near East, according to authoritative reports that reached Washington today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Early placement of United States orders for Canadian-made munitions and materiel was indicated in authoritative quarters here today.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The 1942 appropriation bill for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments was passed today by the Senate after it restored, 35 to 21, a $750,000 reduction made by its Appropriations Committee in the funds for the Justice Department's anti-trust division.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Judge J. Warren Davis, 74-year-old former member of the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, went on trial in Federal District Court here today, accused of exchanging judicial favors for financial gain.

JERUSALEM, May 19 -- The prompt action taken by Britain against the Germans in Syria, coupled with the measures announced by President Roosevelt opening the Red Sea to American ships, has made a profound impression upon Syrians. At most the masses had preferred to limit the show of their feelings toward Iraq to the collection of contributions to the Red Crescent organization.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated yesterday that it would make public today its tabulation of the sales of Defense Savings Bonds and Stamps made in the Second Federal Reserve District from May 1 to May 17, inclusive.

The New York Football Giants will play seven games at the Polo Grounds in the Fall, it was announced by President John V. Mara yesterday. The Philadelphia Eagles will be first to appear on the local gridiron, on Oct. 12. The Brooklyn Dodgers will be the final opponent on Dec. 7.

Actors Equity is expected this afternoon to announce formally the continuance of stage performances on Sundays as a means of prolonging employment for actors. A special Equity committee, consisting of Maida Reade, Alfred Harding and John Alexander, will recommend such action on the basis of its study of the effect of Sabbath showings on employment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- In his second story purchase of the month, Frank Capra acquired "Tomorrow Never Comes," a modern comedy by Hugh Wedlock and Howard Snyder, and engaged the authors to write the scenario. The price and the nature of the plot were not disclosed.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he would be a candidate to succeed himself in the municipal elections this Fall. He is the second major official of Mayor La Guardia's administration to make such an announcement, Council President Newbold Morris having declared ten days ago that he would seek re-election.

BERLIN, May 19 (UP) -- Six British vessels, including a submarine surprised near Weymouth this morning, have been sunk by German bombers around Britain during the past twenty-four hours and nine others damaged, some so severly that "further losses must be regarded as certain," Nazi sources claimed tonight.

Trading in both combed and carded yarns was virtually suspended yesterday, and hardly any business went through in cotton gray goods, following announcement by the OPACS of intention to set ceilings on combed cotton yarns. While carded yarns and gray goods were not affected by the action, traders awaited details of the combed yarn ceilings, in the belief that their own position would be clarified.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 19 -- A committee of ten Williams College undergraduates today mailed to over 1,000 alumni in fifteen Western States a request to help public opinion in the Midwest "catch up" with the rest of the nation in supporting the President's foreign policy.
OVER a four-day stretch recently the rich Red Sox scored twenty-one runs and lost four games. Connie Mack wasn't altogether wrong when he spoke favorably of good pitching.

LONDON, May 19 -- Civilian defenders of London marched with members of the Home Guard today as part of the capital's War Weapons Week which has been bolstered by a number of large subscriptions, including one for 5,000,000.

VICHY, France, May 19 (AP) -- Newspapers in German-occupied Paris are continuing their bitter personal attacks on President Roosevelt and United States Ambassador. Admiral William D. Leahy, as well as on American policy.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he would be a candidate to succeed himself in the municipal elections this Fall. He is the second major official of Mayor La Guardia's administration to make such an announcement, Council President Newbold Morris having declared ten days ago that he would seek re-election.

DETROIT, May 20 -- A milestone in the history of the Ford Motor Company's labor relations will be passed tomorrow when 80,000 employes at the River Rouge and Lincoln plants cast their ballots in an election on the question of union representation supervised by the National Labor Relations Board.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- All deliveries of soy beans sold today at the highest prices since July, 1937, as a result of steady commission house buying which found relatively little pressure on the market. This was noticeable particularly in the May, which soared later in the session on the filling of a moderate sized buying order to $1.14 3/4 a bushel, or 5 cents above the early low.

NEWARK, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Harold Feldman, 21-year-old right-hander, limited the league-leading Newark Bears to five scattered singles tonight before a crowd of 6,833 and the Jersey City Giants romped to a 6-to-1 victory in the rubber" of a three-game series.
VICHY, France, May 20 -- To the accompaniment of developments in foreign policy, the government is applying measures to tighten its hold upon the internal situation, it was learned today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 20 -- The Pensylvania Securities Commission issued today a "cease and desist" order against the Hansa Securities Corporation. dealer in foreign bonds at 141 Broadway, New York, which it accused of urging German Americans in Pennsylvania to turn their savings into German bonds.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 20 -- The Forty-fourth Division was "ready for any eventuality" tonight with all 16,000 troops disposed along the New Jersey peninsula awaiting an "invasion" by the "enemy," expected some time tomorrow. Foot soldiers are scattered along beaches of Atlantic City, Ocean City and Wildwood with observers maintaining lookout posts on the top floors of shore hotels.

LONDON, May 20 (UP). -- British and Greek defenders of the island of Crete battled desperately tonight to wipe out thousands of German parachute troops, at least 1,500 of whom were said to be disguised in New Zealand uniforms. The air-borne invaders, reliably reported to number between 10,000 and 12,009

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Official figures showing that the Treasury's plan for an increased excess profits levy, corporation surtaxes and higher individual income taxes will provide $2,617,100,000 of the proposed $3,500,000,000 increase in defense revenue were disclosed today by the Ways and Means Committee.

The number of out-of-town buyers reported in town last week was 714 as against 775 in the preceding week and 694 in the like period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Buyer registrations yesterday totaled 327, which compared with 374 for a week ago.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Authoritative German quarters declared this evening that it was not impossible that German parachute troops had landed upon the island of Crete. More than that statement, made in reference to the Reuters agency report that German troops had begun an invasion of Crete from the air, could not be elicited, however, either from German military or other quarters.

To those who had expected, certainly without much justification, that the sales of defense savings bonds and stamps would be accompanied by great fanfare and with resultant huge distribution of these securities, the sales campaign seems slow and dull.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20 -- Thirty-two members of the Popular Socialist Vanguard organization, formerly known as Chile's Nazi party, were held tonight on charges of plotting a second Putsch against the government.

The Greater New York Fund's campaign has resulted in the collection of $3,002,286, an amount that "we hope will continue to grow until we have $5,000,000," it was announced yesterday by former Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the drive, who spoke at the fund's second report luncheon held at the Hotel McAlpin.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- Public sentiment in favor of using the United States Navy to guard ships carrying war supplies to Britain shows an increase in the latest nation-wide public opinion survey by the American Institute.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 20 (AP) -- The Iraqi High Command issued this communique today at Baghdad:

A dispatch from our correspondent Mr. Callender, now in Bolivia, reports that German firms and individuals still represent some important American corporations in that country. Some of them are active Nazi agents. And Mr. Callender's previous dispatches from South America have indicated that Bolivia does not stand alone in this respect.
BERLIN, May 20 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

When the Egyptian liner Zamzam fell prey to German naval forces in the South Atlantic, she carried a cargo of 5,344 tons similar in make-up to the cargoes she had carried to Egypt in peacetime, but a large amount of it was contraband under German definition, it was learned yesterday.

We thought that the Florida ship canal project was dead. It comes to life again in a bill which has been reported by the Rivers and Harbors Committee of the House. As might be supposed, the reason for the resuscitation is "national defense," and this though at least ten and possibly fifteen years will be required to do the necessary digging.

Shelling the opposition's pitchers for sixteen hits, Manhattan Prep subjected Mount St. Michael to its first Bronx-Westchester C.H.S. A.A. setback in eight starts, 19 to 8, at Manhattan Field yesterday. It was Manhattan Prep's seventh triumph in nine loop games.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation sold the following five New Jersey properties: The two-story store building at 6019 Broadway, Union City, to Leonard Brody; the two flats at 113-15 Second Street, Harrison, to Vincent Smolski; the two houses at 300-02 Third Street, Harrison, to Robert McCann; the two-story house at 153 Sandford Avenue, Kearny, to Anthony Vernier; and the two-story home at 40 Sixty-second Street, West New York, to John Franciscovich.
WASHINGTON, Nay 20 (UP) -- Attorney General Robert H. Jackson appealed to Congress today for authority to "deal vigorously with disloyal aliens."

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), May 20 -- After a slightly higher opening on the Bourse today a reaction set in under the lead of Royal Dutch which lost 3 3/8 points to 241. Philips was 2 points lower at 212 1/2 and fractional declines were in evidence elsewhere.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- It was a bitterly disappointed but fighting mad bunch of Dodgers that boarded a train for St. Louis early this evening. They had come to Chicago in first place and with a record of not having lost two games in a row since their fourth game of the year.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,784,450 barrels daily, an increase of 28,350 over the 3,756,100 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 15,250 barrels less than the calculation of 3,799,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for May.

Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, was yesterday re-elected president of the Sales Executives Club of New York at its weekly luncheon meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- British subjects as well as Americans are concentrated for protection in the United States Legation in Baghdad, according to reports received here. Other Britons are in the British Embassy, some distance away.

Trading in general yesterday was only fair to slow on all non-kosher meats. Hinds and ribs were mostly steady, veal hindsaddles were barely steady with a weak undertone, other classes mostly unchanged. The kosher market opened slowly, chucks and plates barely steady, veal foresaddles barely steady to 50 cents lower, lamb foresaddles steady to firm.

BERLIN, Wednesday, May 21 -- All 312 passengers and crew members of the Egyptian steamer Zamzam, including 138 Americans, are safe and sound in "a Western French port," presumably between Bordeaux and Brest, after the sinking of the vessel by a German warship, it was announced last night.
It is gratifying to find one's convictions given such solid clarification as that by Arthur Krock in his column of last Friday morning and again in THE TIMES this morning.

Why does the President continue to mollycoddle us? He knew his appeal to the French people could be of no avail. Then it must have been addressed to us. But why? It can only add to the confused state of mind of the average citizen, already bewildered by the lack of leadership which only the President can give.

ONE thing that the losers in sport gain is the rare privilege of some degree of privacy. Let a horse trainer win a big race, a fighter win a championship or a baseball manager win a pennant, and fair-weather friends rally around to ask the master how he does it. Everything the successful gent says takes on added importance, even if it is something casual like: "Here today, rain tomorrow."

Charles C. Walsey finished his testimony under cross-examination yesterday in the General Sessions trial of William Solomon, Harlem Tammany Assembly District leader, and Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, for allegedly compelling the concern to give them $28,000 in bribes in return for $750,000 in State printing contracts.

First returns on the national referendum being conducted by the American Federation of Teachers on its move to oust two New York City and one Philadelphia local on the charge of communism show an overwhelming vote in favor of revocation of the locals' charters, Mark Starr, member of the executive council, disclosed yesterday.
MADRID, Wednesday, May 21 -- The Falange party today took control of the newspapers, magazines, radio, moving pictures and all other types of propaganda in Nationalist Spain.

The arrival of the Atlantic Clipper from Lisbon at La Guardia Field yesterday on the second anniversary of Pan American Airways' trans-Atlantic service joined and tore apart a young couple married by proxy eight months ago and brought word that only fifty Americans to be repatriated remain in all of France.

Prosperity in the United States and an increased demand for cigars are considered synonymous by the Cuban Government, which looks for a sharp rise in sales of Havana cigars here this year, Oscar A. Hernandez, representing Cuban tobacco interests, said yesterday.

In an article entitled "Reaffirmation," published by The Atlantic Monthly yesterday, Anne Morrow Lindbergh, wife of Charles A. Lindbergh, said her "heart" urged her to aid Britain but her "mind" questioned the wisdom of such a course and warned of its dangers to this country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- A newspaper with $12,500 hidden in the fold was passed from William Fox, bankrupt motion picture producer, to Judge J. Warren Davis, former senior member of the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, as the two stood in the hallway of a midcity building here in the Fall or Winter of 1936, Fox testified today in the conspiracy trial of Judge Davis and Morgan S. Kaufman, a lawyer, of Scranton.

Seventy-five members of the Boston College Alumni Club of New York sat down at dinner in Midston House last night with the Rev. William J. Murphy, S.J., president of the college, and Dennis E. (Denny) Myers, their new football coach.

It is no trouble at all to find things to write about that get away from the war entirely. For instance, there are the new Summer shirts for men, in the windows along Times Square and in the advertising pages. The days and temperature are moving on toward vestless time along with straw hat time.

Within a period of fifteen minutes early yesterday afternoon the busy midtown section near the Grand central Terminal and the area on Forty-second Street just west of Fifth Avenue had two bomb scares that sent emergency trucks, the bomb squad and several radio cars, sirens screeching, to the scenes.

Representatives of the city and national administrations may get together soon to thresh out the problem of rising prices of dairy products and other foodstuffs along with the whole program of government buying for the British under the lease-lend bill, to which the present rise in the cost of living is largely attributed.

TOKYO, May 20 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech in defense of free trade and freedom of the seas aroused Japanese press charges that the United States and Great Britain had killed both, thus precipitating the present war.
Leases calling for industrial space in Long Island City and Brooklyn led the business rental reports yesterday.

The Laetare Medal, conferred annually since 1883 by the University of Notre Dame on a member of the Catholic laity, was bestowed yesterday upon Dr. William Thomas Walsh, Professor of English Literature at Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Today's High Command communique reports that a German submarine has sunk 33,000 tons of enemy tankers from various convoys. Thus, the Germans declare, a round 85,000 tons of enemy tankers have been sunk since May 1.

Because of the expanding activities of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, the directors decided recently that it was necessary to have a president. Yesterday afternoon they elected at the Hampshire House Mrs. William Francis Gibbs, daughter of the late Paul D. Cravath and for the last two years vice chairman of the guild.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- The Athletics mauled the league-leading Indians again today, 6 -- 5, to sweep the three-game series.
The trading in Manhattan realty reported yesterday by brokers was well distributed throughout the city. A number of corner properties changed hands.

John F. Naughton, the retiring president of the Student Council of Manhattan College, after announcing that James E. Foley was to be his successor, yesterday gave out the following results of the school-wide elections recently held:

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- Earl Johnson, youthful Red Sox left-hander, ruined Hal Newhouser's twentieth birthday party today, letting the Tigers down with four hits as his team snapped its five-game losing streak with a 4-2 triumph.

CAIRO, May 20 (UP) -- The capture of Feluja, about thirty-five miles west of Baghdad, means that the British forces have surmounted the natural barrier of the Euphrates River and opened up the main highway leading to the Iraqi capital.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A record crowd of reporters and foreign correspondents at the White House offices today in the expectation of hearing President Roosevelt make an announcement on foreign policy learned that in 1942 the President plans to change Thanksgiving back to its traditional date, the last Thursday in November.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted permission to General Puplic Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiary, the Southwestern Public Service Company, both holding companies, to issue and sell $5,914,000 of bonds and notes for refunding and to sell to the Washington Gas and Electric Company four subsidiaries of Southwestern in Arizona.

Sales of United States Defense Savings Bonds from the opening of the nation-wide campaign on May 1 to May 17, inclusive, by agency banks in the Second Federal Reserve District amounted to $82,300,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday.

The New York Committee to Aid Britain by Reciprocal Trade, 572 Madison Avenue, explained yesterday that the purpose of "Buy Something British Week," beginning next Saturday, was to help Britain build up dollar credit in the United States.

The four-story tenement at 779 Fortieth Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Hilel Wilner to the 862 Fiftieth Street Corporation. Sale of the property, which contains five stores and eighteen apartments, was subject to a mortgage of $28,750. Abraham Schoenfeld, David Applebaum and Rae I. Liebert were co-brokers.

The trout fishing seems to be improving in the Catskill area, at least so far as the fly fishermen are concerned, and the late reports indicate that the water conditions are excellent on most of the popular streams.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company in the twelve months ended on April 30 had a net profit after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges of $8,804,419, against $6,672,683 in twelve months to April 30, 1940. Net sales were $84,905,389, against $60,576,467.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Metro acquired two film properties today, the agents who negotiated the deals disclosed, though the studio would not confirm the purchases. Lyons Lyons announced the sale of "Red, Hot and Blue," Broadway musical comedy of 1936, written by Cole Porter, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse and produced by Vinton Freedley, with Ethel Merman, Bob Hope and Jimmy Durante.

The Sinclair Crude Oil Purchasing Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, yesterday increased the price of crude oil of 33 gravity and above by 10 cents a barrel throughout Oklahoma and Kansas. Postings below that grade were increased to a parity with other companies.

I have your letter of May 17, 1941, which came after our talk here in my office. Your letter does not indicate the understanding of the situation which you personally displayed in our talk. Your letter suggests that the City of New York is refusing to do something that it can do.

The estate of Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, was valued at $10,095,812 gross and $8,732,833 net in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. The appraisal papers disclosed that between 1921 and his death on Oct. 11, 1937, Mr. Mills gave away more than $1,800,000, which was not included in his estate.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 20 -- British troops marching toward Baghdad from the Habbania region, it is announced, met Iraqi rebel troops at Feluja and drove them out after a brief skirmish yesterday afternoon. They captured intact a bridge across the Euphrates which affords the only means of crossing the river for miles in either direction, apart from the crude Iraqi ferries.
LONDON, May 20 -- The following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's address today to the House of Commons:

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot today on 400,000 yards of osnaburg and 6,000,000 white cotton handkerchiefs. The quarter master announced that contracts have been awarded for approximately 1,627,000 pairs of first-class privates' sleeve chevrons and for the manufacture of the following items for the Civilian Conservation Corps: 304,982 spruce green coats, 439,318 spruce green mackinaws, J51.500 lair ou prno green 'L.ousers and for 125,537 rubberized raincoats.

The United States Maritime Commission has requisitioned from Moore-McCormack, Inc., the four unfinished passenger liners Rio Hudson, Rio Parana, Rio de La Plata and Rio de Janeiro, it was announced yesterday.

Final decision on ceiling prices for nickel, copper and brass scrap will be reached this week at conferences in Washington between members of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, buyers such as foundries and brass mills, and representatives of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 20 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday sanctioned a fifteen-round meeting between Lew Jenkins, recognized here as the lightweight champion of the world, and Sammy Angott of Louisville, Ky., who is the title nominee of the National Boxing Association.

Dorothy Thompson, organizer of the Herschel Grynzspan Defense Fund for the defense of the young Polish Jew who assassinated Ernst vom Rath, secretary of the German Embassy in Paris in 1938, announced yesterday that the final $3,000 of the fund had been presented to the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., in London for the rehabilitation of children injured during air raids.

A philanthropically inclined St. Louis woman has been carrying on her own highly individual relief program for some months. She is looked upon as a reincarnation of the fairy godmother by destitute widows and children to whose rescue she comes with money earned by the sale of a creole spiced vinegar that she makes in her own kitchen.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt announced appointment of Mayor La Guardia of New York to head the Home Defense program. His callers included Secretary Stimson, W. Bostrom, Swedish Minister; Senator George, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Bernard Baruch.

In his statement to the House of Commons yesterday Mr. Churchill told a dramatic tale of invasion by plane and parachute of the Island of Crete, but he failed to satisfy public curiosity in regard to the lone parachutist whose flight from Naziland to the island of Britain has been the nine days' wonder of the world.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Arthur Bliss Lane, the American Minister to Yugoslavia, informed the State Department today that he had arrived in Budapest, en route to the United States for consultation.

TRENTON, May 20 -- Overriding not only the objection of Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, but also that of Senator George H. Stanger, Republican, the three other members of the State House Commission, all Republicans, adopted today a resolution providing for obtaining bids on installation of voting machines for Hudson County, New Jersey's principal Democratic stronghold.

Trading in cotton yarns and gray goods was still dormant yesterday as both buyers and sellers awaited details of the plans of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply to fix ceilings on combed yarns. Meanwhile, there was some among gray goods buyers of asking sellers to insert clauses in contracts for future delivery guaranteeing them against invoicing of goods at prices higher than any ceilings which may be set.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 20 -- According to reliable information reaching Istanbul from Bucharest, Germany has concentrated thirty army divisions in Rumania, twenty-five of which are in position along the Russian border. Several units in this force have recently come from Germany and France.

"Tobacco Road," the Jack Kirkland dramatization of the Erskine Caldwell novel about life among the Georgia Crackers, is announced to close again, this time on May 31. If the run is not "unexpectedly" extended in the meantime, the show will have played a total of 3,180 performances, according to Michael Goldreyer, spokesman for the management, who submits that figure as the official count.

Stressing the importance of health among defense workers, Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon-General of the United States Public Health Service, declared here yesterday that loss of time due to physical disabilities was "the single greatest factor slowing up the production schedule."

Inspired by a report received from Washington that a revision of the steel price-fixing order would be made soon to permit higher prices, the stock market staged yesterday a vigorous rally in the last half hour of business. The turnover in the final hour on the Stock Exchange topped the trading for any of the three previous sessions and transfers were enlarged to 471,050 shares from Monday's total of 223,010.

LONDON, May 20 -- In the first two days of London's War Weapons Week 23,300,000 has been raised. Receipts are regarded as highly satisfactory, and yesterday a further large sum was received for investment in savings certificates and bonds.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 20 -- British forces surrounding Alagi have completed arrangements for the surrender of its Italian forces, including the Duke of Aosta, viceroy of East Africa.
ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- The Cardinals retained the National League lead by a fractional margin over Brooklyn today after losing to the last-place Phillies, 6 to 4, in eleven innings.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Charles A. Lindbergh will deliver his first Philadelphia speech under auspices of the America First committee at 8:30 P.M., on May 29 in the Arena, it was announced today, simultaneously with the disclosure that the committee had been unable to hire the Academy of Music for the meeting.

Lily Pons, Metropolitan Opera soprano, and Dr. Lin Yutang, Chinese author, appeared together last night in Carnegie Hall, one singing and the other speaking for China. They attracted 2,600 persons to the benefit for United China Relief, which was arranged by the China Aid Council and the American Committee for Chinese War Orphans.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Speculation over the next foreign-policy move of President Roosevelt continued at high pitch tonight after the President had gone through another press conference without disclosing more than his plan for civilian defense in the United States.
VICHY, France, May 20 -- The British Consul General in Beirut has been requested to leave, and it is probable that this measure will extend to other consular officers in the Near East.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- Banking and business problems under the national defense program will be discussed here this week at separate meetings of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association and the New Jersey Bankers Association.

The American Gas and Electric Company intends to take the Securities and Exchange Commission to court over the legality of a recent decision by the commission which held that the company is a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company by virtue of the letter's 17 per cent voting control over the American Gas System.

After a hearing yesterday, Martin C. Epstein, United States Commissioner, in Brooklyn, ordered the removal to the Federal District of the Panama Canal Zone of four officers of the Italian steamship Conte Biancamano for trial on the charge of committing sabotage on the vessel while it was tied up at Cristobal.

NEWARK, N.J., May 20 -- Headed by Vincent J. Murphy as Mayor, the five victors in this city's Commission election last Tuesday, took office today amid discord, with Commissioner Ralph A. Villani threatening to support a recall or change of government movement if his complaints about unequal distribution of patronage and departmental functions went unheeded by the majority faction.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2O (UP) -- The Saturday Evening Post, which previously has followed a non-intervention policy, in an editorial this week gives its support to the Administration in the "American crusade" against totalitarianism.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 21 -- An air-borne attack in great strength -- at least 1,500 German troops in New Zealand soldiers' uniforms took part -- was launched against Crete early yesterday and a "serious battle has begun and is developing," Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The following is the official Treasury table, released by the Ways and Means Committee, showing the probable yields of the proposed excess profits tax plan, corporation surtaxes and individual income taxes, and their interrelated effects:

Export traffic through the Port of Now York last year was valued at nearly $2,000,000,000. the largest figure for any year since 1920, according to a bulletin released yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 20 -- Although the unanimous decision of the 1,000-year-old Parliament of Iceland, the Althing, to terminate the Act of Union of Nov. 30, 1918, between Denmark and Iceland does not have any serious practical importance, it made a deep and sorrowful impression in Denmark today.
Crete, fabled island of the Mediterranean, became the war's newest battleground yesterday as the flame of war flared throughout the Middle East.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The Minister of Labor today announced important changes in the National Sickness Insurance, which benefits all Germans enrolled. The increased benefits ensue without any increase in the premiums payable by the insured.

MANILA, May 20 -- The resolution .adopted by the United States, Congress applying the export licensing system to the Philippines will have if it becomes law the greatest effect on Japanese residents having large investments in hemp plantations. Their exports to Japan presumably would be cut off entirely through application of the control system.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Army Medical Corps has decided on maroon, its official color, as the color to be used hereafter in convalescent suits and robes issued to patients in military hospitals. The color was found to be "cheerful" and also durable from a laundering viewpoint. The suits and robes will be made of standard khaki cotton cloth.

V/ASH!N6TON, MaY 20 ...) -- T.he White Sox shelled Dutch LeonaFd from the hill .today and beat Veal_h= ington, to 2, tp swe.ep a threegame series. Southpaw Thornton Lee let t.h_e .S.e. nat0rs down with_ .Ix_ hits in registering his fourth victory?

A banking group headed by Glore, Forgan Co. received yesterday the award of $1,750,000 general public improvement bonds of Pittsburgh, Pa., on a bid of 100.345 for 1 1/2s. The bonds, to mature on May 1,1942 to 1961, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.20 to 1.45 per cent for the 1942-1955 maturities and at prices ranging from 100 to 99 for the 1956-1961 maturities.

The American Red Cross is sixty years old today. It has every right to expect and without doubt will receive warm birthday congratulations from all the world, for the whole world has benefited by its far-flung operations. Since the outbreak of this war alone, it has distributed in relief to stricken lands money and goods to the amount of $35,075,599, more than half of which it has itself collected.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 20 -- There are now nearly five divisions of German troops in Finland, according to information from a usually well-informed diplomatic quarter here.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- Princeton's varsity and freshman crews today accepted an invitation from Harvard University to compete in the Harvard-Cornell-Syracuse regatta on the Charles River Saturday, it was announced by R. Kenneth Fairman, 34, graduate manager of athletics.

Persistent buying by mills gave steady tone to the cotton market yesterday. After opening at gains of 3 to 7 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to work gradually higher but eased moderately near the close and finished at advances of 7 to 10 points on the day.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., May 20 -- Praising the work of the soldier truck drivers in his command, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer of the 207th Coast Artillery, last night told more than 200 drivers that the anti-aircraft regiment "would have no value if the motor transport fails."

The High School of Commerce, although taking only one first place, captured plenty of the other positions to retain its open team championship at the annual Manhattan P.S.A.L. track and field meet at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 20 -- With more than 1,200 Democratic leaders, public officials and followers present, Mayor Frank Hague and four associate City Commissioners who were re-elected last Tuesday were sforn in here today. The ceremony was held in the flower-banked assembly chamber at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Eire, a neutral in the war despite Britain's attempt to obtain the use of vital bases there, can buy or charter two merchant vessels in the United States to transport food for the Irish civilian population, President Roosevelt announced in his press conference today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- In a special message to Congress today, President Roosevelt called for a reduction of $109,000,000 in his original budgetary request of $995,000,000 to operate the Work Projects Administration during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, speaking yesterday at the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York City Bus Conference declared that increased attention to the traffic control problem would be paid by "the third Fusion administration from 1941 to 1945." The luncheon was held at the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- By a 39-to-18 vote closely following party lines, the Senate today approved a House bill giving a permanent status to the Office of Government Reports, after repeated warnings from minority members that the measure contained the threat of possible governmental propaganda and censorship.

The conflict in the soft-coal industry, with its threat of another stoppage that would paralyze the defense industries and cripple the nation's transportation system, reached a new stage yesterday when representatives of the Northern operators and of the United Mine Workers of America met at the Hotel Biltmore and formally approved the contract concluded by their joint negotiating committee on April 21.

The motion picture, mystery, pulp, radio, romance and comics magazines continued to make greater circulation gains in 1940 than did other general magazines, according to "A Circulation, Rate and Linage Study of 336 General magazines issued yesterday by the magazine committee of the Association of National Advertisers.

The New York State Banking Department notified yesterday banks under its jurisdiction of amendments to the State Banking Board's Resolution No. 324, designed to facilitate bank loans to defense industries. Jackson S. Hutto, secretary of the banking board, said in a letter of transmittal that the amendments are designed to clarify uncertainties in the original resolution.

VILLANOVA, Pa., May 20 -- Billy Woods's airtight pitching and timely clouting by his team-mates enabled Villanova to defeat Manhattan College today, 4 -- 1, for the Wildcats' fifteenth victory in nineteen games this season.

Seeking its fifth pastor in ninety-four years, Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, historic religious center of Brooklyn, has extended a call to the Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield, pastor of the Plymouth Congregational Church of Seattle, Wash., to serve in the pulpit from which Henry Ward Beecher delivered his denunciations of slavery.

At least sixty golf clubs from the New York and New Jersey areas are expected to take part in the one-day coast-to-coast Empire Day tournament, to be held Saturday, for the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., it was announced by Chairman Theodore Merseles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House adopted today a drastic new emergency program for United States shipping. The lower chamber passed and sent to the Senate a bill empowering President Roosevelt to control the movements, cargoes and rates of all ships registered or doing business in this country.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 20 -- Despite the official German-Russian friendship, Germans seldom lose an opportunity to wave before the Scandinavian peoples the specter of danger from Russia; on Saturday a German historian, speaking at Copenhagen, tried to stress this danger and the safeguard against it in German protection.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- The gardens on thirteen estates here will be open to the public tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. as a benefit for the British War Relief Society. In the event of inclement weather they will be shown Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The President's reduction of $109 millions from his 1941-42 budget estimate for WPA is a decrease of only about 7% in the total relief sum he has requested. Contrasted with the gigantic percentages of increase in government costs for all purposes, including defense, it is a very thin slice indeed.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Use by the German Army of gliders to land troops on the island of Crete, as announced today by Prime Minister Churchill, represents probably the first application of a technique studied theoretically for the last twenty years, according to aviation experts here.
Health Commissioner John L. Rice described his plan for a new public health research agency to be operated by the city to the finance committee of the City Council in City Hall yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 12 -- The Bolivian Government has lately been considering two steps of strategic and economic importance both for continental defense and for Bolivia's future. One is to put an end to the sale to Germany via Japan of about one-third of the country's output of wolfram (tungsten).

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Frank Shields, the tennis player, who leased a maisonette apartment at 1120 Park Avenue through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., brokers, and Brown, Wheelock Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents. Other rentals follow:

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Hogs moved actively upward In early trading today to a new high for the year, but late dealings were recorded below early quotations. Initial gains ranged from 10 to 15 cents and a top of $9.40 was established, equal to the price on Sept. 6, 1939, at the outbreak of European hostilities.

A Summer schedule of twenty-five books, a list strong in fiction but including a fair share of more serious reading, was announced yesterday by Little, Brown. There will be several mystery novels and Westerns. Emil Ludwig will be represented by a history of Germany.

Republic's "Rookies on Parade," which opens at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's sole screen arrival. The comedy with music, which is concerned with Army life, features Bob Crosby, Ruth Terry, Gertrude Niesen, Marie Wilson, Eddie Foy Jr. and Cliff Nazarro.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 20 -- A field of fifty-eight players was led home by Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood, who had a score of 39, 38 -- 77, on the hilly Shackamaxon course today in the weekly one-day Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Nineteen hundred A.F. of L. and C.I.O. machinists who have been on strike since May 9, tying up more than $500,000,000 of naval and Maritime Commission construction in eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards, met tonight in Civic Auditorium to hear Governor Olson's plea that they waive their demands and return to work as a national duty.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The educational system in the United States is faced with the greatest crisis in its history, prominent educators declared today at the forty-fifth annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

Earl Coleman, the former lunch room counter man who sold between 400 and 500 theses to college students aspiring for degrees, although he was never graduated from college himself, escaped with a suspended sentence yesterday in Special Sessions.

BERLIN, May 20 (UP) -- The Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung will say tomorrow in a special article that German victories in Greece and the Aegean Islands, instead of handicapping the Axis, have provided "new starting points."

Mayor La Guardia, who was named by President Roosevelt yesterday Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, told a rally of the United Service Organizations for National Defense in Madison Square Garden last night that he was "one hundred per cent behind its drive" to raise funds for service clubs for soldiers and sailors, but warned that the "mistakes of 1917 and 1918" must be avoided.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Relations between the United States and the Vichy government were the subject of plain talk during an hour's conference today between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt urged Congress today as a defense measure to enact into a law a bill providing for condemnation of rights of way across ten States for construction of a pipeline which would supply the Middle Atlantic refineries with crude oil for finished petroleum products.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- According to a statement issued by an anonymous diplomatic source here, "wanton murdering of Poles by the Gestapo under the pretext of legal passing of death sentences" has not ceased in that Nazi-occupied country.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- John McDonald, traveling secretary of the Brooklyn baseball club, announced today that the Dodgers had written proof that the Chicago Cubs were over the twenty-five-player limit Sunday and Monday when they defeated the Dodgers. Manager Leo Durocher of Brooklyn has protested the games.

VICHY, France, May 20 (UP) -- The German-controlled French press in Paris today asserted that the presence of United States Ambassador Admiral William D. Leahy in Vichy had "become delicate and even impossible" because of President Roosevelt's hostile attitude toward France.

CRETE, Ill., May 20 (AP) -- Valdina Groom, owned by the Valdina Farm Stable of Texas, slipped through on the rail in the stretch and rambled to a neat victory in the Kensington Purse at Lincoln Fields today.
CHUNGKING, China, May 20 (AP) -- A continuing battle in South Shansi Province has cost "tens of thousands of Japanese casualties," the official Chinese Central News Agency declared tonight.

A speedy demonstration of how a lawyer was enabled to listen in on official conversations between Securities and Exchange Commission investigators was performed yesterday in Federal court. The demonstrator was Elizabeth Miller, former telephone operator for the SEC here, who has pleaded guilty to assisting Jacob Gruber, the lawyer, in the wiretapping scheme, for which he and his woman secretary are on trial.

A police guard set over chain bakeries on Washington Heights for two weeks as a result of a series of hold-ups in such stores resulted last night in the capture of two men, one of whom, detectives said, admitted twelve of the robberies. The second man was shot in the leg as he fled and was taken, a prisoner, to the Cabrini Memorial Hospital.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 20 -- Turkey would be forced to intervene in Syria if the Germans occupy that territory with military forces, it was stated today in the leading newspaper, Yeni Sabah. This is the first open talk of intervention in the Middle Eastern campaign which has been heard here.

Night before last Senator Taft, speaking over the radio, referred unpleasantly to newspaper columnists and college professors as men who were ready to urge the nation into war but were always unwilling to participate in the fighting. I resent this insult.

The Yankees and the Browns handled yesterday's game at the Stadium as if it was a greased pig at a county fair. Whenever one of them would grasp it, off it would dash again. In the ninth, however, the Bombers caught the wild-eyed and crazy ball game with a stranglehold right atop home plate.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- W.J. (Buddy) Hirsch's Tragic Ending, a heavy choice in the mutuels, romped to a four-and-a-half-length triumph in the Marblehead Purse of $1,300, mile event for 3-year-olds that featured today's program at Suffolk Downs.

A police guard set over chain bakeries on Washington Heights for two weeks as a result of a series of hold-ups in such stores resulted last night in the capture of two men, one of whom, detectives said, admitted twelve of the robberies. The second man was shot in the leg as he fled and was taken, a prisoner, to the Cabrini Memorial Hospital.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 20 -- Turkey would be forced to intervene in Syria if the Germans occupy that territory with military forces, it was stated today in the leading newspaper, Yeni Sabah. This is the first open talk of intervention in the Middle Eastern campaign which has been heard here.

Night before last Senator Taft, speaking over the radio, referred unpleasantly to newspaper columnists and college professors as men who were ready to urge the nation into war but were always unwilling to participate in the fighting. I resent this insult.

The Yankees and the Browns handled yesterday's game at the Stadium as if it was a greased pig at a county fair. Whenever one of them would grasp it, off it would dash again. In the ninth, however, the Bombers caught the wild-eyed and crazy ball game with a stranglehold right atop home plate.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- W.J. (Buddy) Hirsch's Tragic Ending, a heavy choice in the mutuels, romped to a four-and-a-half-length triumph in the Marblehead Purse of $1,300, mile event for 3-year-olds that featured today's program at Suffolk Downs.

While President Roosevelt was outlining the organization of his newly formed Office of Civilian Defense in Washington yesterday, Mayor La Guardia swung into action in his new role of director of the agency by ordering 314 employes of the Markets Department to keep food distribution going under all emergencies.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- From the vantage of its half century of existence, commemorated in the golden jubilee feature of the convention that opened here last night, the General Federation of Women's Clubs looked back today to measure how far it had come, and forward to see whither it was going.

In his radio speech on county reform, Governor Smith said in his arrowy way that this city needs five elective Sheriffs and four elective Registers as much as a bulldog needs five tails. He has been a Sheriff. He has long been an advocate of county reform. These nine offices stuffed with political underlings cost some $450,000 a year.

Repeating his warning that the city could not tolerate a strike of its transit workers, Mayor La Guardia defined the issues at stake between the Transport Workers Union and the city in a letter yesterday to Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 20 (AP) -- C.I.O. workers voted tonight to strike against the Carborundum Company, manufacturer of abrasive wheels and materials which, it said, were used in "practically every defense industry in the nation."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 (AP) -- Relevancy of defense testimony that Harry Bridges was a good trade unionist was disputed by the government today at the C.I.O. leader's deportation hearing.

A late fifteenth century French Gothic limestone doorway has been presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by John D. Rockefeller Jr., and has been installed in the museum's medieval branch, The Cloisters, in Fort Tryon Park.

CAIRO, May 20 (AP) -- British military sources said tonight that the British Imperial and Greek forces on the Island of Crete were considered strong enough to deal with any air-borne force of invaders. They said also that the German invasion By glider, troop-plane and parachute was fully anticipated by Major Gen. Bernard C. Freyberg's command.
LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- The lull in the air war continued during the night, with German activity over Britain limited to the East Midlands and a few other areas.

Having found their association mutually profitable with "There Shall Be No Night," the Theatre Guild and the Playwrights Company have entered into another contract, which calls for the presentation of Helen Hayes in a new work by Maxwell Anderson entitled "Candle in the Wind."

HANOVER, N.H., May 20 -- In a hair-raising baseball game that kept 2,500 spectators on edge until the last batter was retired, Dartmouth today eked out a 3-2 victory over Harvard. The triumph enabled Dartmouth to gain first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League, a few percentage points ahead of Cornell.
ROME, May 20 -- Dalmatia today officially became Italy's "fifth shore" by a royal decree announcing the creation of a governorship composed of the three provinces of Zara, Split and Cattaro.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Construction of Federally owned aluminum plants to bring United States production above 1,500,000,000 pounds annually is essential to defeat the Axis powers, R.J. Reynolds, president of the Reynolds Metal Company, said today in revealing that his company had offered to manage government-owned plants to treble present planned production of 100,000,000 pounds annually.

In response to many requests, the Sculptors Guild has arranged special accommodations for groups of school children to visit the outdoor show, current through June 8, at Sixth Avenue and Eighth Street. The groups, of twenty or less, accompanied by instructors, may attend the exhibition for 5 cents, half of the admission fee.

Whirlaway, generally accepted as the 3-year-old champion, stepped out of his class in the Henry of Navarre Purse yesterday and defeated Mioland, hailed on the Pacific Coast and elsewhere as the leader in the handicap division.

Captain Alexander Collie, veteran transatlantic ship master of the Anchor Line, well known to thousands of Americans who traveled with him to Glasgow and out of New York in the cruise trade, has been lost at sea through enemy action. Word of his death reached friends here yesterday from correspondents in England.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The Germans officially announced today that all members of the crew and all passengers of the Egyptian liner Zamzam were safely ashore somewhere in "the occupied territory," which suggests France.

VICHY, France, May 20 (AP) -- The French Air Minister, General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret, landed at Beirut last night to organize the defense of French-mandated Syria against British aerial bombardments, it was announced here today.

Three of the eight Union Theological Seminary students now in the Federal penitentiary at Danbury, Conn., on account of their refusal, for reasons of conscience, to register for selective service last Fall have applied for readmission to the seminary upon their release.

Walter E. Frew was a typically old-fashioned American banker and his career was typically American. Shrewd, quick-witted, with an eye like a gimlet, he had that deep-rooted, intuitive common sense that is the basis of all financial success. Yet for all his keenness he was a kindly man, intensely loyal to old friends and associations.

Last week, for the second time this year, the general death rate in New York City fell below 10 per 1,00O population, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was informed yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Newspaper and other channels of public information today were requested by the Maritime Commission to extend a voluntary censorship on movements of merchant vessels which are aiding the democracies in the same way that it is applied to ships of the American and British Navies.

In Mayor La Guardia the President has found the ideal man to direct the new Office of Civilian Defense, which has been created to protect and prepare private citizens against a possible war emergency. The executive order establishing the new agency is long and legalistic, but in essence it represents an effort to carry defense to the national grass-roots.

The Brazil Committee is sponsor of a dinner dance to be held this evening in the Garden of the Ambassador, the proceeds of which will aid the fund of St. Margaret's School, Pelotas, Brazil, for vocational training and care of the needy.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins directed a jury verdict yesterday dismissing the divorce action brought by Edward E. Spafford, former national commander of the American Legion, against Mrs. Lillyan Mercier Pierce Spafford. Earlier in the day, Justice Collins dismissed all charges as against Rex Cole, distributor of electrical appliances, who was named by Mr. Spafford as co-respondent, and completely exonerated Mr. Cole.

Inadvertent violation of rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission on short selling has resulted in circulation of an educational letter by the department to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Samuel Reshevsky, the defender, and Israel Horowitz played to a draw tonight in the tenth game of their match series for the United States chess championship. The contest lasted twenty-five moves and was the eighth time the masters had split a point.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 (AP) -- Vince DiMaggio's fifth home run of the season started an assault today which brought the Pirates from far back to an 3 -- 4 victory over the Braves. The triumph, with Cincinnati's loss to the Giants, put Pittsburgh in fifth place.

HONOLULU, May 21 (AP) -- Lights were blotted out in the Hawaiian Islands shortly after 9 P.M. last night (3:30 A.M. Wednesday, daylight time) as residents, warned of the approach of "enemy bombers," tested a protective blackout.

The New York City League of Women Voters, in annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Astor, applauded the statement of Benjamin J. Buttenwieser that this country has a place in the battle between dictatorships and democracy, and later voted to endorse whatever measures the government might decide upon to make aid to England effective.

Heralding a major change in higher education, between 400 and 500 liberal arts colleges in this country are planning to offer a three-year program as well as the regular four-year one beginning this Fall, to enable students to finish their academic careers before being called for military service, Dr. Guy E. Snavely, executive director of the Association of American Colleges, disclosed yesterday.

CAIRO, Eygpt, May 21 -- The Duke of Aosta, Viceroy of Italian East Africa, accompanied by five Italian generals and a number of senior staff officers, formally surrendered at Alagi, Ethiopia, the British announced today. The number of prisoners taken by the British during and since the battle at Alagi approached 19,000.

LONDON, May 21 -- War Weapons Week hit high gear today when a flood of subscriptions -- some districts more than doubling their quotas -- brought the total to 70,000,000 and the goal of another 30,000,000 within relatively easy reach.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- A back-to-work movement of metal shades craftsmen of the American Federation of Labor, intended to break a twelve-day-old strike of A.F.L. and C.I.O. machinists in Seven San Francisco Bay area shipyards, apparently fizzled out tonight after an estimated 500 to 1,500 workmen of a normal day shift of 1,000 had gone through the union picket lines this morning.

OUR ambitious friends the Japanese, if they happen to have an extra merchant ship lying idle anywhere, might dispatch it to the nearest American port at the first opportunity and pick up a sizable consignment of copies of a new book by Captain W.D. Puleston, U.S.N.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 21 -- The largest gift of land ever made to this community, which will be known as the Gerard Beckman Memorial Park, was announced today by Arthur Snouder, president of the Oyster Bay Planning Association.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The five members of Draft Appeal Board 1-A today by unanimous vote refused to exempt from the selective service Dr. Hans Carl Heinz Sennhenn, 28, an aide at the German Embassy in Washington.

McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., operator of gold-bearing properties in Northern Ontario, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on March 31 a net profit of $3,819,032, after depreciation, all taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $4.78 a share on 798,000 common shares.

Two new farces will be presented the week of June 2 on Broadway. The first, "Women Aren't Angels," will arrive on Monday of that week at the Broadhurst; the other, "Snookie," will follow, at a date not yet set, at the Golden.

For forty years equality of women has been a meaningless phrase at the Columbia University Club. Women guests of the club's 1,590 male members traditionally were allowed in the Club House at 4 West Forty-third Street only on Washington's Birthday. Since 1938 they have been permitted in the dining room at stipulated hours on Saturdays and Sundays.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- During March 28,685 more civilian workers were employed by the Executive Branch of the Federal Government than at the end of February, the Civil Service Commission announced today, bringing the total to an all-time high of 1,202,348, as compared with 949,229 in March, 1940.

A syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $3,000,000 of bonds of the Westchester Cross-County Parkway Authority. The successful bid split the issue into $1,200,000 of serial bonds due on June 1, 1942 to 1953, and $1,800,000 of term bonds due on Juno 1, 1953.

The committee representing twenty-two commercial banks in the United States holding German "standstill credits" expects to hear soon from the authorities in Berlin in the matter of a renewal of these credits, under which Germany would continue to pay the interest and pay off part of the principal.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 21 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

Metropolitan district golf fans will get their preview of the national open championship when some of the leading lights in that event warm up in the annual Goodall $5,000 round-robin on the Fresh Meadow course in Flushing.

The Yanks gave it a Whirlaway finish at the Stadium yesterday, storming madly from the rear to draw even in the ninth and then sprinting to victory in the tenth. They beat the Tigers, 5 to 4, and dropped the Detroiters from third place to fifth.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- This capital today called 7,000 citizens to practice the repulse of parachute troops in special drills Saturday and Sunday, while the organ of the Young Communist League declared, "The present international situation compels us to prepare seriously day by day for war."

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 21 (UP) -- Members of the State Arbitration Board arrived here tonight in an effort to settle a jurisdictional dispute between two American Federation of Labor groups which threatened to result in a general strike of 14,000 to 20,000 textile workers.

Mandatory priorities for plates and shapes, required to an increasing degree on national defense projects, will be next in line in the tightening official control over steel supplies, according to Iron Age, which finds that many of the steel companies no longer are opposed to such action.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave their annual "newspaper dance," attended this year by more than 1,400 newspaper men and women, their wives, husbands and friends.

Cartoons and caricatures of the war are featured in a one-man show of work by the Polish artist, Arthur Szyk, which will be opened in the second-floor galleries at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, today.

Recognizing a change in the status of the Vichy government since French indication of closer collaboration with the Reich, cargo war-risk insurance underwriters yesterday withdrew all published rates for shipments to France and her colonial possessions.
Senators Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota and David I. Walsh of Massachusetts accused the Administration last night of leading the country to the brink of war through "fear' and "emotionalism."

Going into the eighth inning trailing by 7 -- 1, Holy Cross was apparently thoroughly beaten by N.Y.U. at Ohio Field yesterday. It was not hopeless, however, because the Crusaders went to work with a vengeance, tallied six times to tie the score and then put over four more in the ninth to win an 11-8 verdict.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- Rutgers emerged victorious from a thirty-two-hit slugfest with Princeton on University Field today, trouncing the Tigers, 13 -- 6, with nineteen blows off two pitchers. Princeton punched out thirteen safeties from the offerings of Jim Perkins, but failed to bunch them for more than two runs in any inning.

Upper Second Avenue's population lined the sidewalks last night from Sixty-first to Ninety-first Street and cheered from windows and fire-escapes as the demolition of the elevated structure was celebrated. Stores and tenement houses were decorated with flags and bunting and a parade marked the event.

Retail credit collections in April showed an increase of 0.17 per cent, according to the twenty local store Index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 48.06, against 47.89 a year ego. Eight of the stores had increases and twelve decreases.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21 (AP) -- The Iraqi High Command said in a communique issued in Baghdad and received here early today:

BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- The lowly Browns hit four homers to one for the Red Sox today, but the latter came from behind to gain an 8-6 victory. This success returned Boston to third place over the heads of the unsuccessful Tigers.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local and suburban public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown from tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise, specified.

Mayor La Guardia left the decision on whether he would be Mayor for a third term to the voters of the city last night in a twelve-minute radio address delivered on the eve of his acceptance in Washington today of his new post as Director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

DETROIT, May 21 -- Employes of the Hudson Motor Company, who had been on strike since Thursday, ratified today an agreement negotiated earlier in the day by James F. Dewey, "ace" conciliator of the United States Department of Labor.

The market on most classes of traefer meats yesterday was weak. Steer ribs and loins were weak, with many sales of short loins $1-S2 lower, ribs mostly $1 lower. Veal hind saddles were mostly S1 lower, pork loins unevenly 50-$1.50 lower, other classes about steady. Prices of kosher steer chucks and plates as well as veal and lamb fore-saddles were steady.

ORANGE, N.J., May 21 -- Cracking par by one stroke, young Eddie Foy toured his home course in 37, 34 -- 71 to win low-gross honors in a Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament on the hilly Crestmont course today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt discussed the sending of food to Eire with Norman H. Davis, chairman of the Red Cross, conferred with Secretary Wickard and Representative Cannon of Missouri on farm problems and talked with a group headed by Leon Henderson on legislation to fix price ceilings.

Directors of the American Viscose Corporation at a special meeting yesterday declared a dividend of $1.25 a share on the preferred stock and one of 50 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Aug. 1 to holders of record of July 15.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 21 -- President Getulio D. Vargas signed a decree today creating a bureau of imports and exports to operate as a department of the Bank of Brazil. The bureau is designed as a controlling body to foster exports and also is authorized to take measures regulating imports, the decree indicates.

The Brazzaville radio in French Equatorial Africa reported yesterday that forces of "Free French" troops had invaded French Syria and that a regiment of General Henri Fernand Dentz's Syrian defense forces was believed to have gone over to the "Free French."

Asserting that "this is not a holy war," sixty-four students and faculty members of the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, declared yesterday in a letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES that there is "real misunderstanding" among lay people about the attitude of Episcopalians who favor the entry of the United States into the war.

The members of the Big Five Railroad Brotherhoods comprise about 350,000 workers, equal to about one-third of all railroad employes. On the basis of the pay they received last year the 30 per cent increase they have demanded would add slightly more than $200,000,000 to the operating expenses of the Class I roads.

Hospital executives were urged to check the quality of goods and commodities affected by current price fluctuations and to guard against waste as a price factor, at the opening session of the annual convention of the Hospital Association of New York State held yesterday In the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CAMP STEWART Ga., May 21 -- The 212th Coast Artillery Regiment of New York City, one of the first anti-aircraft units in the country, will be brought up to wartime strength during the next week when 609 selectees will augment the present total of about 900 enlisted men.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- What was described privately by members of Congress associated with the economy bloc as "probably the greatest grab" in the history of the American Congress was reported today to be in the making.
This writer listened with complicated feelings last night to the concert of chamber compositions given in the New York Public Library by the International Society for Contemporary Music.

The Department of Justice yesterday increased its efforts to force the great German dye trust to answer to Federal charges of conspiracy to monopolize the magnesium industry in this country. Department attorneys obtained an order restraining General Dyestuff Corporation, a United States concern, from paying $24,000 owed to the German organization, I.G. Farbenindustrie.

BERLIN, May 21 -- The approval by a Congressional committee of a $30,000 outlay for the creation of a secure and secret repository for British and American documents of State prompts the Boersen Zeitung to suggest that the Reichsbank undoubtedly would deem it an honor to place ts bomb and burglar proof vaults at the disposal of the United States in the event the impregnability of Fort Knox should be considered inadequate.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., May 21 -- Lieutenant Robert L. Little twice prevented a crack-up of a crippled Army bomber he was piloting here today, making a skillful "belly skid" landing the second time after the three members of his crew had bailed out on orders from the radio control tower.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Pronounced strength in soy beans, which advanced today around 4 cents a bushel following an upturn of about the same amount yesterday had considerable influence on the grain markets.
