Bound for England, where he will make a brief study of the military uses to which civilian aviation and all its facilities have been put since the outbreak of the war, Robert H. Hinckley, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aviation, was one of twelve transatlantic passengers aboard the Dixie Clipper when it left here yesterday morning for Lisbon.
ROME, May 22 -- The shortage of gasoline and rubber for tires today led to a measure of the Ministry of Communications, severely limiting the use of taxicabs throughout Italy.

Further withdrawal of the Mitsubishi interests of Japan from the American insurance market occurred yesterday with sale of the Standard Insurance Company of New York, which does a fire, marine, earthquake and other insurance business in thirty States, and of the Standard Surety and Casualty Company of New York.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 22 -- A blazing sun shone down on the opening of the annual Wilmington Horse Show today at the ring on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Rood at Meadows-on-the-Brandywine. The scene was more festive than it had been for many seasons.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- Dismissal from the Swarthmore College faculty of Miss Josephine Truslow Adams, chairman of the committee for People's Rights in Eastern Pennsylvania, was revealed today.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 -- The Rev. Dr. Herbert Booth Smith of Los Angeles was elected Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today, defeating the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin of New York City, president of Union Theological Seminary. Three ballots were taken and the final vote was 461 to 404.

CHUNGKING, China, May 22 -- Communist headquarters here reported last night a successful guerrilla attack in Shansi Province in reply to charges that the Eighth Route Army was not fighting the Japanese.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 -- Eight days ago Leo Durocher's Dodgers were leading the National League by two and one-half contests after sweeping a two-game series with the Reds, and were heading toward Pittsburgh with the pennant bee buzzing merrily about their ears.
A full-fledged heat wave arrived yesterday, with the thermometer registering a high of 90.7 degrees at 3:10 P.M. -- a record for the date.

Hitler was impaled yesterday on an iron fence fronting the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street. Only symbolically was he stuck there, painted with a death's head grin by Esther Silverberg, 10 years old, of 376 Madison Street, New York.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a net profit of $3,069,541 after depreciation, Federal income and excess-profits taxes and other charges. This is equal to $1.46 each on 2,105,013 shares of common stock.

Hitler was impaled yesterday on an iron fence fronting the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street. Only symbolically was he stuck there, painted with a death's head grin by Esther Silverberg, 10 years old, of 376 Madison Street, New York.

Cooperation between the United States and the British nations will be as essential after the war as it is now, to prevent post-war chaos, members of the Advertising Club of New York at their weekly luncheon were told yesterday by Robert Gardiner Casey, Australian Minister to the United States.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 22 -- Business and professional women will seek a larger part in organizing defense activity as well as a program on which to act, board members of their State Federation indicated here today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Labor peace is, of course, essential even to a fair rate of speed and efficiency in defense production. But if work stoppages were eliminated there would still remain the problem of labor supply.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 22 -- Amid cheers for President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Roberto M. Ortiz, enthusiastic support of continental solidarity and the democratic principles for which Britain is fighting were expressed today by large crowds in numerous public meetings organized in various parts of Buenos Aires by Accion Argentina, an organization claiming 800,000 members, belonging to all parties but united by a common love of democracy.
Meat prices for the second weekend in succession show little change, the Bureau of Consumers Service of the Department of Markets reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Army reached a peacetime record of 1,324,800 officers and men today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased the screen rights to "Comin at You," a magazine short story by Borden Chase to be published next month. The yarn deals with ship yard work, and Ann Sothern will have the lead.
WASHINGTON, Del., May 22 -- Two brilliant performers pulled away from the field in a light battle for the championship of the tenth annual Wilmington horse show today.

After proctoring 500,000 final examinations taken by more than two generations of Columbia College students, Professor Frederick W. Hehre's familiar bellringing will be heard no more in Columbia's University Hall gymnasium where the current classes have taken or are now engaged in their end-term tests.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Leaders of government, capital, labor and management opened a two-day conference today to help build national morale in the emergency. The meetings are sponsored by the Washington chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management.

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on a motion by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., to dismiss the suit in which the city and the Board of Transportation are seeking a declaratory judgment holding that the board cannot legally enter into the kind of collective bargaining contract sought by the union in behalf of its 25,000 members employed on the unified transit lines.

Mrs. Joseph Cookman, New York managing editor of the Ladies Home Journal, has leased a suite in 570 Park Avenue through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc. Other rentals have been arranged by the same firm with Winifred Warren, in 410 Park Avenue, Sidney Cashman, Sylvester Freund and Jerome Holt, in 343 East Fifty-first Street; Francis O. Noble, in 1356 Madison Avenue; Walter F. Wise, in 15 East Thirty-sixth Street.

A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $14,625,000 of Southern Pacific Company equipment trust certificates. Three other bids were submitted. The winning tender was 99.568 for 2 1/4 per cent obligations.

LONDON, Friday, May 23 -- A filldress air battle took place between the raiding British bombers and escort fighters and the defending German aircraft in the Royal Air Force offensive over Calais into Nazi-occupied France during daylight Wednesday, British officials said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- A wave of liquidation swept over the grain and soy bean markets today and with soy beans in the lead prices dropped sharply. The break in soy beans had considerable influence on grains, as did reports that the Administration was planning to institute price controls.
Sixty-five golfers will tee off Monday at the Ridgewood County Club, Ridgewood, N.J., in the metropolitan district's sectional qualifying round for the United States open golf championship.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 22 -- Imperial forces in Ethiopia, operating in the lake area south of Addis Ababa, attacked the Italians' main position, then repulsed a Fascist counter-attack, killing 100 and capturing 600 prisoners, ten guns and five medium tanks, British headquarters here announced today.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- A modest supply of hogs met current requirements on the livestock market today and prices held steady in moderate trade. Good and choice 180 to 330 pound weights brought $9.30 to $9.50, with the top at $9.50. Weighty swine sold largely at $9.40 and up. A few 160 to 180 pound offerings went at $8.85 to $9.40.
Four broadcast programs will receive awards for merit from the Woman's Press Club of New York City at the club's annual meeting this afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Federal Trade Commission today made public a twenty-five-page mimeographed copy of the rules and regulations adopted by it under the Wool Products Labeling Act which becomes effective on July 15, or nine months after final approval of the law, as the measure provided. Copies of the document are available from the commission.

Now and then, though not too often, there appears some one strong enough to resist Hollywood's golden lure. The task is made easier by the Federal and State income tax bureaus. A rising young star has just told the reporters that in two years he could earn $150,000 in Hollywood.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Battling back from the depths of the National League, the world champion Reds beat the Cubs today, 8 to 4, before a ladies' day crowd of 11,729.

The railroad brotherhoods have announced, by way of a supporting argument for the demand for an increase of 30 per cent in their wage scales, that "The productivity of railroad men has increased by 43 per cent during the past four years without any increase in compensation."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Reduction of production for civilian consumption, with the shifting of all possible facilities into operation on defense orders, was urged today at the closing sessions of the Society for the Advancement of Management, combined with criticism of the progress of the procurement program and a demand that Washington "make up its mind and tell us what it wants."

The hotel business in 1940 earned 1.88 per cent on the value of the property, compared with 0.41 per cent in 1939 and 2.33 per cent in 1937, according to the annual report on hotel operations issued yesterday by Horwath Horwath, hotel accountants. The report based on figures for 100 hotels of various sizes in fifty cities, doing about one-sixth of the total hotel business of the country.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout hurled the first shutout of his three-year major league career and enabled the Tigers to divide a double bill today with the second-place White Sox. Trout won the nightcap, 9 to 0, after Ted Lyons had dominated the opener for a 7-to-1 victory.

The extortion of at least $550,000 from four big movie producing organizations, under threats to foment strikes in picture theatres throughout the country, was charged to George E. Browne and William Bioff in a Federal indictment yesterday.
RAVENNA, Ohio, May 23 (UP) -- Company officials and union representatives agreed today to resume construction work Monday at the strike-bound $35,000,000 government ammunition loading plant.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Defense contracts awarded today by the War and Navy Departments totaled $20,093,662.07. Among these were the following, not previously published, to companies in the New York area:

DETROIT, May 23 -- Bitterly attacking the National Labor Relations Act as making possible the overwhelming victory of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. at the employe elections in the Ford Motor Company's Rouge and Lincoln plants, I.A. Capizzi, company counsel, declared today that his client would deal with the union merely "because the law says it must."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 19 -- One of the most serious of the many problems posed by the transformation of these once-idyllic islands into a major defense outpost of the United States stems from the forced evacuation of more than 300 persons from property to be part of the 520 1/4-acre base.

After deliberating only eighteen minutes a blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court returned a verdict of guilty of first-degree murder yesterday against Irving (Knadles) Nitzberg for the underworld slaying of Albert (Plug) Shuman on Jan. 9, 1939.
The texts of the addresses of Charles A. Lindbergh and Senator Burton K. Wheeler at the Madison Square Garden rally under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the American First Committee follow:

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- Bankers should search their own communities for plant facilities which are not being fully used and which, with financial aid, could be made available for defense production, Dr. Alfred H. Williams, dean of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania, said today.
ROME, May 23 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

UNION, N.J., May 23 -- Playing spectacular golf, Miss Gaff Wild of Baltusrol and Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont added 36, 37 -- 73, two over men's par, to their first-round 77 for a total of 150 to win the two-ball, best-ball tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the hilly Suburban course today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, proposed today the use of Federal forces, if necessary, to bring about a resumption of work in San Francisco Bay area shipyards, where 1,700 A.F. of L. and C.I.O. machinists are on strike.

SEWAREN, N.J., May 23 -- A violent gasoline explosion, followed by intense though short-lived flames, killed two workmen and injured eleven others, thre critically, at the Shell Oil Company plant here this afternoon.

Eight Thirty, rated the handicap division champion by his admirers, and Haltal, the Dixie Handicap winner, are the two main contenders among nine entered for this afternoon's Metropolitan Handicap, famous mile feature which will be renewed for the forty-seventh time at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- One Defense Mediation Board panel strove today to avert a second soft-coal stoppage, which all groups agree would have a disastrous effect on the national defense program, while another put forth a plan for industrial peace in the lumber industry of Washington and Oregon.
DUBLIN, May 23 -- It was indicated late tonight that factional strife had been forgotten in the controversy over conscription in Northern Ireland.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- The Bears made a clean sweep of their three-game series with the Syracuse Chiefs by registering a 10-to-2 victory tonight. Outfielder Frank Kelleher again stole the batting show while Russ Christopher scattered seven hits.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Dr. Edward A. Doisy of the St. Louis University School of Medicine, widely known for his researches on Vitamin K, received tonight the 1941 Willard Gibbs Medal awarded annually by the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society in recognition of "conspicuous contributions to chemistry."

Every one at the present time is interested in the national defense program. To further this purpose is the aim of every right-thinking American. A thought has come to me how we might help to carry this through and at the same time give a boost to baseball.

Three members of the Lincoln Hospital Alumni Association refused to testify on specific cases involving the care of Lincoln Hospital patients before a committee of the City Council in City Hall yesterday on the ground that professional ethics made such testimony impossible.

Hearty prates for the British war effort during the last two years was voiced yesterday by Commander Norman R. Hitchcock, U.S.N., upon his arrival aboard the Yankee Clipper from London, where he served as assistant naval attache for air.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-nine municipalities aggregates $21,501,025, compared with $10,635,411 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $38,562,954.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Accumulation of a "blood bank" of 200,000 half-pint units will be started by the Army and Navy, cooperating with the Red Cross, soon after July 1. Under the program, as announced by the War Department, civilians will be asked to contribute this supply.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, director of civilian defense, will open a nation-wide drive to mobilize civilians with an address in Philadelphia's Convention Hall May 28 which will be broadcast nationally.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 23 -- Reports urging Presbyterians to give more liberally to the church's general benevolences, showing progress in the proposed union with other churches and recommending a revision of the church's pension fund system with a 10 per cent cut in pension payments after October, 1942, were submitted today to the commissioners attending the general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

Major letter H's will be presented to thirty-one members of the varsity teams of the Hunter College Athletic Association at the annual dinner tonight at 7 o'clock in the Hotel Dryden. Basketball, hockey, fencing and swimming awards will be given, and for the first time an award in archery will be made, to the newly organized archery team.

AMSTERDAM, Via Berlin, May 23 -- There was more activity on the Bourse today, and stocks after opening lower rallied slightly to end with net losses of about 2 points. Royal Dutch lost 2 1/2 points to 238 3/4, Phillips was off 2 to 205 3/8 and Unilever declined 1 1/2 to 116 1/4.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Efforts of professional speculators to follow the varying reports from Washington as to the status of the 85 per cent of parity bill kept the wheat market in an uproar today. Prices fluctuated nervously within a range of 2 1/2 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Department of the Interior has given the North Star, which has been to the Arctic and Antarctic, to the Coast Guard for defense purposes. Since 1932, with time out for trips to Antarctica, the North Star has served the Office of Indian Affairs of the department, which is now left without a "navy."

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- Ken Keltner's triple with the bases full in the first inning powered the Indians to a 4-to-2 victory over the Browns tonight in Cleveland Stadium. Ray Mack's single drove in the other run in the same inning.
VICHY, France, May 23 -- Following is the text of Vice Premier Darlan's broadcast today to the French people:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 -- College sprint rowing for the season comes to its close here tomorrow. In a three-event regatta, scheduled to start at 5 o'clock with the freshman race and continuing at fifteen-minute intervals with junior varsity and varsity tests, the eights of Harvard, Cornell, Syracuse and Princeton will ring down the curtain on the 1941 sprint campaign.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 23 -- Empire Day was celebrated here today by a spectacular appeal for recruits. Headed by tanks and Bren gun carriers, 2,300 Australian Imperial Force reinforcements and 1,000 Royal Australian Air Force trainees paraded through crowded and beflagged streets with empty lorries bearing the inscriptions "Let your conscience be your guide" and "Join your pals in the A.I.F."

OTTAWA, May 23 -- It was reported here today that King Peter of Yugoslavia is coming to reside in Canada. If the report proves true his arrival will raise to five the number of royal houses represented here. The others are the Netherlands, Austria, Norway and Luxembourg.

PHILADELPHIA May 23 -- Dartmouth and Pennsylvania broke even in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League double-header on River Field today. The Red and Blue gained its first victory over the Indians since 1936 in the opener, 8 -- 3, but dropped the second contest, 4 -- 2.
The "strange, grim" battle of Crete continued its seesaw course yesterday, accompanied by perhaps the greatest aerial-naval struggle of the war.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- Members of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. voted all day today, beginning at 2:30 A.M., to decide whether to call a strike Wednesday at the plant of North American Aviation, Inc. The company has orders of more than $200,000,000 from the Army and the Royal Air Force for training and fighting planes.

Hot weather spurred the demand for Summer apparel and accessories last week. Department store volume was estimated as running 10 per cent or more ahead of the corresponding week last year, an increase better than that recorded during the preceding two weeks. In addition to the activity in women's merchandise the call for men's wear showed to good advantage during the week.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 -- Captain James Roosevelt returned by air to Cairo from Iraq today after having been bombed and machine-gunned for four days in forward British positions that he was inspecting. It was Captain Roosevelt's first time under fire.

Because next Friday is Memorial Day tomorrow will be observed as Memorial Sunday. Military and patriotic societies will attend special services. Memorials will be dedicated in several churches. "Buy Something for Britain Week" to be opened today, "Empire Day," will be commemorated.

Admiral Darlan's address to the French people yesterday has to be translated, not only from French into English, but from the Berlin-Vichy dialect into those of the free peoples. Its three important statements are, of course, plain enough. Hitler did not demand the French fleet, the French colonies or a French declaration of war against Britain.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 23 (AP) -- Republican legislative majority leaders, defying Governor Lehman's veto of the appropriation, acted tonight to supply more than $44,000 to the legislative committee investigating subversive activities in New York City schools.

Charles A. Lindbergh, making his second anti-war address in New York under the auspices of the America First Committee, joined with Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana last night in attacking President Roosevelt's foreign policy and in demanding leadership at Washington to keep this country out of war and to return to isolationism.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Colonel Henry H. Arnold, young chief of the Air Corps and an acting major general, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for promotion through the grade of brigadier general to the permanent rank of major general.

There was no improvement in demand for most classes of traefer meats in yesterday's market. As a result the lower trend in prices continued. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to 50 cent lower; traefer full chucks were about 50c-$1 lower. Veal hindsaddles were barely steady with the previous day's prices.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 23 -- Five thousand or more Nazi soldiers bent on a surprise landing on Crete were drowned when a British naval squadron smashed into the center of their hodgepodge convoy and blasted to the bottom an Italian destroyer, two mer chantmen and forty sailing vessels, British naval officers related tonight.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- The Cardinals increased their National League lead to two games tonight, defeating the Pirates, 2 to 1, in a pitching duel between Mort Cooper and Max Butcher. It was the first St. Louis night game of the season, drawing 18,555 spectators.

For the second time this week, brokerage circles yesterday witnessed business in stocks drop back to the smallest volume since last August, and on such a meager turnover the price changes were meaningless. Major movements throughout the list were confined to the preferred issues, and only in the railroad common shares was there any semblance of strength.

It was graduation from Kindergarten yesterday afternoon for eleven East Side children, and special distinction for twenty others. While the sweltering sun beamed and the assemblage mopped dripping perspiration, the youngsters cavorted for two hours on the roof of the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

New York will be promoted as a vacation center this Summer more vigorously than ever Before, as the result of an appeal by Robert K. Christenberry, president of the Broadway Association, Inc. More than 300,000 lines, carrying the association's slogan "Make New York Your Vacation City," in their out-of-town advertising, has been pledged by members such as Gimbel Brothers, Saks-Thirty-fourth Street and General Outdoor Advertising.
VICHY, France, May 23 (AP) -- An Iraqi communique from Baghdad today, a reported by the Havas news agency, said:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A forthright appeal to the nation to center all its energies on defeat of the Axis powers was made today by Secretary Knox, and he coupled it with a warning that this would be a long war.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Employment in non-agricultural pursuits has jumped past the 1929 peak to the highest levels in United States history, preliminary estimates by government experts indicating that, due to defense efforts, there now are more than 37,500,000 wage-earners at work.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A stormy dispute, punctuated by charges of "robbery," raged in the dressing rooms at the conclusion of tonight's heavyweight title fight over whether Champion Joe Louis hit Buddy Baer after the bell ending the sixth round.

The first legal test in this State of whether a pari-mutuel ticket holder can collect when his horse is in the money, although he has destroyed or lost the ticket, was resolved in favor of the bettor yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

LONDON, Saturday, May 24 (UP) -- German transport planes carrying reinforcements and munitions were reported early today to be landing at the rate of one every five minutes on the Island of Crete, off which raged what was called "the greatest aerial-naval battle of all time."
Curtis and La Salle Academy clinched titles in their respective divisions yesterday as play in the various schoolboy baseball tourneys throughout the city neared its close.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Joe Louis was successful in the seventeenth defense of his heavyweight championship of the world when he defeated the ponderous Buddy Baer in Griffith Stadium tonight.

CAIRO, May 23 (UP) -- British Imperial forces were reported tonight to be massing for a drive on Baghdad after crushing an Iraqi counter-attack that succeeded in seizing and holding temporarily the outskirts of Feluja.

C.I.O. members employed at the Ford Instrument Company plant in Long Island City, Queens, have voted to reject a request that they give up their vacations as a means of speeding up the defense program, it became known yesterday.

VICHY, France, May 23 -- Desertion across the Trans-Jordan frontier of the famous "Lawrence of Syria," Lieut. Col. Collet, is admitted in a press announcement in Vichy tonight. Colonel Collet is the organizer of the famed Circassian cavalry units of Syria, composed of desert nomads and hard-riding Slavs, who have done notable service in keeping order for the French armies for many years.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Joe Louis weighed 201 3/4 pounds and Buddy Baer 237 1/2 for the fight in Griffith Stadium tonight. The bout by rounds:
IT is a critical point well taken to suggest, as the scholarly jacketeer has suggested, that Arthur Kober, the laureate of the Bronx, is one of our more notable regional writers.

The Democratic party may be split wide open as a result of the suggestion of Assistant Secretary of State A.A. Berle Jr. that the Affiliated Young Democrats enter Mayor La Guardia in the Democratic primary, it appeared yesterday.

As an outgrowth of a controversy with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, the Theatrical Teamsters Union has threatened to establish picket lines today outside all theatres employing union musicians, the League of New York Theatres announced last night.

ALBANY, May 23 -- Quotas for local boards outside of the City of New York in the thirteenth selective service call were revealed by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown. The total Army requisition is for 2,330 registrants, of whom 1,363 are from the New York City boards and 962 from up-State.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 23 -- The rural townships of Northern Westchester County will attempt to secede from Westchester and establish a new county if the Westchester charter is amended to strip the northern area of its present representation on the Board of Supervisors, Ralph O. Ellsworth, president of the Poundridge Property Owners Association, declared today.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- "I never extorted a dime from anybody," Willie Bioff, union labor leader, declared today at the office of his attorneys after being informed of his indictment by a New York Federal grand jury.

The Bronx Zoological Park has embarked on another interesting venture with the opening of the Children's Zoo. This is an area near the elephant house where, in small-scale buildings and corrals reminiscent of cherished passages from fairy tales and Mother Goose, docile animals and birds give reality to many a child's day-dreams.

The Mitchel Field Athletic and Recreation Department has recently organized a post baseball team, and arrangements are being made to set up an adequate baseball diamond so that this sport can be utilized in promoting healthful recreation for the men of this post.

ROME, May 23 (AP) -- Diplomatic circles heard rumors tonight of an imminent move to bring Switzerland into the Axis and an effort to gain Soviet permission to move Axis troops across Russia to the Persian Gulf for the German-Italian assault on the British in the Middle East.

Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company painted yesterday an optimistic picture of defense production progress in the United States and disclosed that General Electric was a full month ahead of schedule in its deliveries of certain propulsion-equipment materials for the United States Navy.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 -- Entries of the Springsbury Farm of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Greenhalgh, Berryville, Va., dominated the second day's program of the tenth annual Wilmington horse show at Meadows on the Brandywine, scenic estate of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Rood, today.

The long-continued dispute over the need for a large additional expansion of the country's steel-making capacity is typical of much of the confused thinking that seems to attend our defense effort. A number of economists within the Government have calculated that a rise in the national income to around $100,000,000,000 would result in a demand for steel far in excess of the present or immediately expected capacity of the industry.
BERLIN, May 23 -- The High Command announced today that the submarine of Lieut. Comdr. Guenther Prien had failed to return from its last voyage and must be considered lost.

VICHY, France, May 23 -- Declarations made in Paris by Jean Achard, Secretary of State for Supplies, on the food situation and the measures for attempting to deal with it have centered attention again on what is becoming the crux of all politics in France.

Railroad equipment trust financing featured the new-issue market this week and swelled the total bond offerings to $23,808,000. This compared with $60,820,000 in new bonds marketed last week and with only $2,915,000 placed during this week last year.

The surviving men in blue will not march in this year's Memorial Day parade in Manhattan on Friday, but will ride in automobiles over the line of march, Captain Julius Isaacs, adjutant general of the parade, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Henry S. Waterman, United States Consul at Bordeaux, France, sent the State Department a list of the Americans from the Zamzam who are at Biarritz and said he would send as soon as possible the names of eight others who were en route to Bordeaux.

Attempts of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., to divest themselves of a material interest in Morgan, Stanley Co., Inc., were described yesterday at a hearing before Richard Townsend, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, at 120 Broadway.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 23 -- A thunderstorm played havoc with many rounds of golf in the annual Walter J. Travis memorial tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today, but it failed to spoil a fine 74 that won the medal for Charles Whitehead, New Jersey amateur champion.

TRENTON, May 23 -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz disclosed today that the Legislature would be asked to revoke the charter of the German-American Bund Auxiliary and order the trustees to dispose of the corporation's property and terminate its business in New Jersey.

Cooling thunderstorms moving in from the west broke the three-day heat wave in the New York area early last night and brought some relief from premature Summer and drought conditions to most sections along the Eastern seaboard from Boston to Washington.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
"You can't do it," is the chant from the armchair boatmen at Miami, Bimini and Cat Cay, when some one says he is going to try for the giant tuna in the Gulf Stream with twenty-four-thread line.

Before this strange battle for Crete has been finally won or lost, it cannot fail to throw added light on the respective roles of air, sea and land power. But its lessons may be difficult to interpret correctly because of the almost unprecedented discrepancies in equipment.

W.R. Boyd Jr., executive vice president of the American Petroleum Institute, at a meeting yesterday was elected chairman of the Fact-Finding Committee of representative oil men appointed last week by the institute at the request of the Office of Production Management to make a study of the oil supply problem on the Eastern seaboard.

Four thousand children representing the Sunday School of every church in the Episcopal Diocese of New York are expected to attend the annual service for the presentation of the missionary offering of the boys and girls at 2 P.M. today in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

A tremendous leap by Paul (Little Poison) Runyan from way down near the bottom rung of the ladder up to within a point of the lead was the highlight in yesterday's play in the $5,000 Goodall round-robin golf tournament at the Fresh Meadow Club near Flushing.

VICHY, France, May 23 -- The United States does not seem to understand the true economic situation in Europe, Henri Clerc, former Deputy and Mayor of Aix-les-Bains, declared tonight in a lecture in Vichy sponsored by the Ministry of Information.

In a meet which saw no new records established but five standards closely approached, Newtown High accomplished the hat trick last night by winning the team championship for the third straight year at the thirty-eighth annual running of the City P.S.A.L. senior track and field games at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

An increase of 14 per cent in sales by dollar volume enabled the Holly Sugar Corporation to show a gain of 17 per cent in net income for the fiscal year ended on March 31, Wiley Blair Jr., president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- Various phases of the "economics of war" were discussed today at the closing session of the forty-seventh annual convention of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association, held in the Hotel Traymore here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Judge Joseph Buffington, who was appointed to the Federal bench forty-nine years ago by President Benjamin Harrison, testified today in the conspiracy trial of his Circuit Court colleague, Judge J. Warren Davis, that Judge Davis's was the controlling voice during the time the William Fox bankruptcy cases were before the court.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate, by a vote of 35 to 25, approved today and sent to the White House the conference report on a bill giving the government power to impose priorities on American industry in the interests of national defense.

PELHAM, N.Y., May 23 -- Champion Heather Criterion, an imported dog owned by Edward F. Maloney of the Bronx, today won the highest place in the annual Summer specialty exhibition of the Scottish Terrier Club of America. Handled by his owner, he was judged by Theodore W. Bennett of Minneapolis as best of sixty-three individuals shown, one of the largest entries in recent years.

Governor Lehman pledged his full cooperation yesterday to Mayor La Guardia as the Mayor spent the day in Washington on his new Federal assignment as Director of the Office of Civilian Defense. In a telegram to the Mayor the Governor said:

William B. Joyce, president of W.B. Joyce Co., surety brokers of 115 Broadway, yesterday wrote Attorney General Robert H. Jackson to urge him to find a way "to draft labor leaders into government service or enjoin them from interfering with defense work."

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Thomas E. Dewey, New York District Attorney and national chairman of United Service Organizations, painted a gloomy picture today of the reception given selectees by civilians in towns and cities near training camps.

The officially declared purpose of the Wagner act is "to diminish the causes of labor disputes * * * obstructing * * * commerce." The question may well be raised, however, whether the Wagner act, instead of diminishing strikes, does not constitute a strong encouragement of them.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 23 -- The Forty-fourth Division's 16,000 troops returned here today, tired and sunburned, after a five-day field exercise to defend the South Jersey coast marred by only one casualty.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 -- Preparations have been completed for a blackout of Newark for a make-believe air raid Sunday night, the first to be staged in a large city on the Eastern seaboard of the United States.
The pictures of the two new schools which appeared in THE TIMES this morning are a distressing commentary on the apathetic, unimaginative type of mind that apparently makes up our Board of Education.
LONDON, May 23 -- The speech of French Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan today is regarded here as another example of the speed with which Anglo-French relations are deteriorating.

LONDON, Saturday, May 24 -- The Battle of Crete raged fiercely throughout yesterday, according to reports here, with the Germans incessantly raining fresh supplies of men, tommy guns and trench mortars to hold the one place they have successfully invested -- the airport of Maleme, which is about ten miles southwest of Canea and is strategically important.

Railway equipment manufacturers expressed yesterday apprehension at the lack of steel for their industry, saying that this lack had prevented the completion of 5,000 freight ears in April and May. These cars, they asserted, were necessary for the defense program.

Today, on the anniversary of the birth of their beloved Queen Victoria, Great Britain is celebrating -- however solemnly -- her Empire Day. Canada and the other Dominions pledge their allegiance. And here in America new shipments of British goods are pouring into importers' warehouses to prove that Britannia still rules the waves.

"Snookie," the Thomas A. Johnstone farce, will have its premiere on June 3 at the Golden Theatre, it was said yesterday by Lee Shubert and C.P. Greneker, representing the three producers, Ole Olsen, Chic Johnson and Edward Choate. Among the important members of the company are William Harrigan, Eddie Nugent, J.C. Nugent, Jack Hartley, Julie Stevens and Florenz Ames.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 23 -- Russo-German relations undoubtedly constitute the greatest diplomatic puzzle of the day, and, while Stockholm observers detect a certain easing of the strained relations between the two countries, new evidence appears to give weight to the belief that this condition is only temporary.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Official Washington waited eagerly today for signs of approval or disapproval from President Roosevelt of proposals to repeal or change the Neutrality Act as a way to tilt the scales in favor of the democracies in the Battle of the Atlantic.

James J. Bambrick, 52 years old, who stole $10,000 of the funds of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, of which he was the organizer and president for eight years, was sentenced yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions to a Sing Sing term of one to two years.

The sudden and sharp wage rise in the steel industry, obtained by threats of strikes in one of the most critical moments of the present emergency, and the ensuing similar movements in other industries may, if not counteracted, become the starting point for a lamentable development leading toward a complete collapse of our present price structure and living costs, with unending hardship and misery for an overwhelming majority of us.

VICHY, France, May 23 -- The devaluation of the franc in successive stages paid for the World War, the French economic writer A.L. Jeune says today in the Paris Soir, but he predicts that this "worn-out system" will not be used to pay for the war of 1939-40.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on May 10 was 3,340,190 shares, compared with 2,280,230 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

President Roosevelt's "fireside chat" to the American people Tuesday night -- his first this year and his fifteenth since entering office -- is scheduled to be broadcast nationally through the three major networks and overseas by short waves, beginning at 10:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nomination of Colonel Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Air Corps, to be a major general, and of seven brigadier generals to be major generals. He conferred with William S. Knudsen and other callers.

Recovering from an opening drop of 7 to 12 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday worked slowly upward and in the final hour touched the highest levels in the last four years. At these levels quotations were up 21 to 27 points, but a sharp reaction in the last few minutes of trading reduced the gains to 12 to 21 points on the day.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 23 -- The German Ambassador, Franz von Papen, called at the Foreign Office this morning and it is believed in diplomatic circles that he initiated conversations leading to a trade agreement between Turkey and the Reich.
BERLIN, May 23 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's air force continued today to rain bombs on British warships operating in the Eastern Mediterranean, Nazi sources reported.

CAIRO, Saturday, May 24 (AP) -- Allied defenders of Crete violently stormed the Nazi-held airport of Maleme early today after recapturing the towns of Candia and Rethymno. British and Greek troops tightened a ring of tanks, artillery and machine-gun units around Maleme, the single Nazi foothold left on the island as the battle roared into its fifth day.

The new investment market has scheduled one of the most active periods in some months for next week when at least two major security flotations will appear. In the equity field, the long-awaited public offering of American Viscose securities will take place on Monday, providing the initial participation by the American public in the ownership of the largest producer of rayon in the United States.

The concert of chamber music by American composers given last night at the Museum of Modern Art as one of the events of the present festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music was also a disappointment. "Also" means that earlier festival programs of music by Europeans were disappointing because of the prevailing artificiality and sterility of the music.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- In what is viewed here as the beginning of competition with Axis-controlled airlines in Latin America, the Civil Aeronautics Board granted today to the Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc., authority for the immediate establishment of commercial airline transportation to and from Oruro, Bolivia, on its existing route to Corumba, Brazil, via Cochabamba, Bolivia, and other intermediate points.

THIS tourist went out to see how Corporal Porky Oliver was doing in the round-robin golf romp at the Fresh Meadow Country Club on Long Island yesterday. They had the corporal in the barrel at the end of the first day's firing, but he climbed out of it yesterday and struck a few resounding blows for the prestige of that great outdoor club for which he now plays, the United States Army.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. A Metro offering, "Washington Melodrama," will be the attraction at the Rialto. The melodrama, which has the national Capitol for a background, features Frank Morgan, Ann Rutherford, Kent Taylor, Dan Dailey Jr., Lee Bowman and Virginia Grey.

With many other track fans, I am looking forward with interest to the forthcoming I.C.A.A.A.A. championship meet at Randalls Island next Friday and Saturday. For some reason or other, outdoor track meets never have seemed to have the appeal to New Yorkers that the indoor meets do.

BERLIN, May 23 -- Germany's submarines and bombers have inflicted devastating tolls on British shipping in the last few days by sinking 115,300 tons in Atlantic waters, according to claims in the High Command's communique today.

In furtherance of a program for compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the North American Company declared yesterday a dividend on its common stock in the form of one share of capital stock of the Detroit Edison Company for every fifty shares of North American stock held.

VICHY, France, May 23 (AP) -- A dawn shelling that spelled doom for the Egyptian liner Zamzam and wounded two of her 148 American passengers was followed by a thirty-three-day voyage for the entire ship's company as enforced guests aboard a Nazi merchantman, the survivors related today.

BICKNELL, Ind., May 23 (AP) -- The Bicknell Coal Company's Panhandle mine two miles southwest of here, gave up the blackened bodies of fourteen miners today, victims of a terrific explosion which dropped them in their tracks 325 feet underground.

Louis Untermeyer has signed a contract with Simon Schuster to prepare a "basic" poetry anthology that will be entitled "A Treasury of the World's Great Poems: English and American." Mr. Untermeyer says he plans to furnish through a running narrative a background for the selections that are included.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- Frances Farmer and Preston Foster will play the leads in "Prison Widows" at Paramount, the studio announced today. The story by Louis Pollock deals with the life of a convict's wife in a prison town, and Jonathan Finn is writing the scenario.

The Contemporary Arts Gallery will open an exhibition on Monday of "Paintings of the Hudson River," by a sponsored group. A hundred years ago the Hudson River School of painters held an important position in the field of art and with this in mind the gallery will present an exhibition showing what today's painters do with the same subject.
ELMIRA, N.Y., May 23 -- Plans for an "Empire Youth State" for girls were adopted today by the convention of the State Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

For his "Spring at Coventry," Richard Avedon, 17 years old, of 55 East Eighty-sixth Street, a senior at De Witt Clinton High School, the Bronx, yesterday won first prize from thirty-one/other high school poets at the eighteenth annual inter-high school poetry contest at Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Stocks of cotton now under government loan would be kept out of normal market channels under a bill passed today by the Senate and sent to the House.

LONDON, May 23 -- British submarines striking at Axis convoys moving troops and equipment to the Libyan battle front have sunk a 9,000-ton troopship and two supply ships and torpedoed an escorting Italian destroyer, probably sinking her, the Admiralty announced tonight.

For his "Spring at Coventry," Richard Avedon, 17 years old, of 55 East Eighty-sixth Street, a senior at De Witt Clinton High School, the Bronx, yesterday won first prize from thirty-one/other high school poets at the eighteenth annual inter-high school poetry contest at Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Stocks of cotton now under government loan would be kept out of normal market channels under a bill passed today by the Senate and sent to the House.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 23 -- The Women's National Golf and Tennis Club Class A team blanked Plandome by 5-0 on the North Shore links today to win the championship in the Long Island division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub tournament.

SHANGHAI, May 23 -- All indications reveal that the Chinese forces will become increasingly active soon, defending Chinese cities against Japanese raiders and attacking Japanese-held points in China, Formosa, and perhaps even Japan.
What happened yesterday at the Yankee Stadium was so much wasted effort -- 3 hours and 5 minutes of it.
The past weeks have seen a series of interesting letters appear in THE NEW YORK TIMES debating the merits of a tournament to decide the world's chess championship.
BERLIN, May 23 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from William G. Finucane to Robert L. Coleman Jr., from Alexander J. Robertson to Norman F.S. Russell, from the late Frederick H. Mindermann to Barets O. Benjamin and from Gilbert Ottley to Jerome Lewine, Bergen B. Rapalyea Jr. has been approved as an alternate for Harry Hurt and Charles H. Worthington as an alternate for Nathaniel S. Howe.

Evidence concerning the relation of the American Metal Company, Ltd., to the formation of the Climax Molybdenum Company at the time of the first World War was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag at the trial of a stockholder's action against officers and directors of American Metal.

CHUNGKING, China, May 23 -- Hailed here as an envoy who will be the agent for large-scale American aid to China, Clarence E. Gauss, the new United States Ambassador, arrived in Chungking yesterday by plane from Hong Kong.

An advance of 20 cents a hundredweight in the price to be paid next month to dairy farmers for milk was announced yesterday by N.J. Cladakis, Administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area. Unless the retailers absorb the increase it may result in an increase of one-fourth to one-half cent a quart to the consumer, it was suggested.

Today has been set by the Committee to Aid Britain by Reciprocal Trade as the first day of "Buy Something British" Week. The committee rightly points out that even under the most liberal interpretation of the lease-lend act there are still a large number of American goods and services essential to the British Empire which cannot be given directly to the empire under the terms of that act.
BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 -- The back-to-work movement among non-striking union men in eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards gained some momentum today as the Navy again provided trucks to carry them through picket lines of the striking machinists at two of the more important yards on the east side of the bay.

VICHY, France, May 23 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, told the French people in a broadcast address today that Reichsfuehrer Hitler had not demanded the French Fleet, colonial territory or a declaration of war on Britain in the talks leading to Vichy's decision to "collaborate" with Berlin.

ROME, May 23 -- Once again Italian newspapers are full of great air-naval activity in the Eastern Mediterranean, but there still is not a word about Crete. Commentators are beginning to hint at it, but so carefully that without previous knowledge their indications would be meaningless.

A "sellers' market" on Scotch whiskies, a situation for which importers have been looking in vain since the early months of repeal, will develop before the end of next month, according to trade opinion here. The threat of increased taxes here and abroad, increasing shipping and insurance costs and the reduction in reserve inventories, executives of import houses said yesterday, will lift the case price of Scotch to consumers to $45 or more.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 -- Iraqi forces were driven from Yeluja by Royal Air Force bombs a second time yesterday after they had counter-attacked and gained temporary positions on the outskirts of the town, British Middle East headquarters here announced today.

Though the original terms of the Neutrality Act have been substantially modified in some respects, there are still certain sections of that unwise law of 1937 which greatly handicap the efforts of the United States to defend its own shores and its own vital interests in this time of crisis.

LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- Great Britain seized the French tanker Sheherazade "because of the imminence of a definite break in the relations between Great Britain and Vichy," a Ministry of Economic Warfare spokesman declared today.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 23 -- A French colonel and some 200 of his native cavalrymen have fought their way through their own frontier forces to the British territory of Trans-Jordan, French officials acknowledged tonight.

The third outdoor rally of the Greater New York Fund's 1941 campaign took place yesterday afternoon on the steps of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, in the presence of 5,000 persons. Audience and performers alike mopped their brows as they shared in another appeal for what a message from Mayor La Guardia called "a city institution."

A consolidated net income of $5,226,494 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges was reported yesterday by the United Light and Power Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to 47 cents each on 3,476,768 combined shares of Class A and B common stocks.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- As the Army enters "the high school phase of military training" with manoeuvres, begun Friday, which will involve this Summer and Fall more than 550,000 men, General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, outlined the aims and concepts of the force being built. By July 1 more than 1,400,000 officers and men will be on active duty.
When Dodger losing streaks become unbearable, there are always the Phillies.

Though this story is a happy reminder of a tranquil Britain there is, fortunately for 8 to 12-year-old readers, nothing tranquil about the four children who spent a Summer holiday on an island off the coast of Scotland.

Fresh evidence is seen daily at Washington that "the great mass of the American people are in heart" supporting the British in their desperate fight for their own survival and for the liberation of the subjugated nations of Europe, Sir Willmott Lewis declared last night at the Empire Day dinner of Ye Beefeaters Society of America at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

The Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund was enriched by $688 yesterday when the drawing was held for a Wedgwood bowl, once the property of the Duchess of Fife, sister of King Edward VII. The bowl was declared to be one of the most beautiful Wedgwood pieces ever made.

MUCH is being written nowadays about music and migration. Recently there was an intensified discussion in THE NEW YORK TIMES as to whether the many musical immigrants-some of them outstanding -- are an advantage for this country.

APPARENTLY still smarting from Frank Capra's suggestion in "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" that even Senators are not always above reproach, the House of Representatives sat fifteen minutes overtime last Monday while Representative Donald S. McLean lambasted "Adventure in Washington," forthcoming Columbia picture about Senate page boys, as "a ridiculous and silly stretch of the imagination."

THE two things always remembered by any one who has been to Dakar are the vultures and the lizards. The vultures are forever wheeling overhead, looking for carrion, and the endless thousands of little lizards, red, yellow and blue, overrun the town, climbing walls and trees, darting through the streets.

SOMEWHERE in prewar writings now probably banned in his own Paris (like the work of Duhamel, Giraudoux, and the rest) Paul Valery said that the weakness and shortcoming of France lay in the fact that its politics had not kept up with its thought.

As a post-convention tour, a number of delegates to the General Federation of Women's Clubs who met last week in Atlantic City will visit Rockefeller Center tomorrow. Three hundred women are expected to attend the program arranged for them, including guided tours of the center, the Museum of Modern Art and the New York Museum of Science and Industry.

The most important celestial event this month is the Summer solstice. On Saturday, the 21st, the sun enters the sign of Cancer at 2:34 P.M. (E.S.T.) and we say that Summer begins. On that date the sun rises farthest north of east and sets farthest north of west.

It is iris time and parks and gardens assume a delicate loveliness they will not have again till another month of May rolls round. Iris lovers attain the peak of their annual ecstasy this week. They are a cult all by themselves, an army in number, rich and poor, with eyes that see a thousand separate variations of color and form where ordinary eyes see just flowers.

ATLANTA, May 24 (AP) -- Joseph P. Kennedy, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain, said tonight that this country should not become a belligerent "just because we hate Hitler and love Churchill."

MACLEOD, whose childhood was spent largely on the Atlantic back and forth between here and Europe, whose early young manhood was that of a juvenile expatriate in Paris in the halcyon days when transition and This Quarter (to which he contributed verse and prose) were flourishing, has reverted, at the ripe age of 35, to the scene of his boyhood upbringing, the city of Missoula, Mont.
HONOLULU, May 24 (AP) -- Annihilation of invading forces ended the battle of Oahu today, involving 35,000 soldiers in mimic warfare for possession of the key to America's defense of the Pacific.

PAUL ELDRIDGE, poet and co-author of "My First Two Thousand Years," here tries his hand at the light comedy novel of domestic life. It is a tale that Justice Holmes would have enjoyed, for its echoes of the Gallic comic writers, its surface frivolity and zestful irony, the artful commingling of gayety and deep seriousness, and especially for its color and warm humanity.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Forcing a reduction of about 20 per cent, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, set today a maximum price schedule for ordinary commercial quality combed cotton yarns, based on a rate of 42 cents per pound for 30's single and ranging from 32 cents per pound for 10's single to $1.63 per pound for 120's two-ply, effective May 26.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 24 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Syracuse in the opener of a three-game series today, 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In the so-called Neutrality Act (1937-38) the United States abandoned its traditional insistence on "freedom of the seas" in favor of a precautionary measure against involvement in war. The movement began among what were. then called "the Senate isolationists" who have become the "non-interventionists." Finally the Administration took over the policy and sponsored the final measure in Congress.

Four thousand brilliantly dressed children from the Episcopal Diocese of New York gathered yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to present their missionary offerings at the annual presentation service. The Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the cathedral, conducted the ceremony.
ROME, May 24 (AP) The Italian High Command said in a communique today:
The Government of Eire has started to accumulate a merchant marine that will make the country independent of foreign transportation services for its urgently needed food supplies and other materials.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 24 -- The State of New Jersey was warned today by Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, Forty-fourth Division commander, that it was neglecting its duty to its citizens in failing to provide funds for the State Defense Council to build an organization to coordinate civil defense.

Dresses and sports wear drew the best consumer response in the three mayor test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Evidence that the German-American Bund was organized to create a militarized organization capable of the same functions which were performed by Nazi groups in European countries conquered by Hitler was offered in a 200-page report today by the Dies Committee Investigating Un-American Activities.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The baby-aircraft industry is trying desperately to preserve itself in the face of American national defense priority regulations that threaten it with extinction.

PRIORITIES Forty-five items have been added by the OPM in its May revision of the all-important Priorities Critical List. This list, now totaling some 250 items, covers the things which are needed for defense and which can be certified automatically as such by contracting officers of the Army and Navy.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- If Martin W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, takes a defense job it will not be in the tank corps, according to his associates.

"THE REVEREND BEN POOL" is the story of a very good young man sincerely sniffing about for the odor of sanctity and having a very hard time finding it. The novel picks Ben up at the age of 31, a big, ugly chap -- muscular, capable and hard-working: not at all the mooning, namby-pamby type that most of us are too prone to associate with extreme goodness.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Memorial Day week-end will be this resort's busiest Spring holidays. On Friday Miss Elizabeth Macfarian of Ridgewood, N.J., will be crowned Queen of Greenbrier on the campus of near-by Greenbrier College for Women.
New York University's baseball team went fifteen innings against the New York Athletic Club at the windswept Travers Island field yesterday to win, 6 -- 5, and snap a five-game losing streak.

THE Naumburg Orchestra will give the first of a series of four Summer concerts on the Mall in Central Park Friday night. Ignace Strasfogel will conduct and the soloist will be Benjamin De Loache, baritone.

CONSTRUCTION of two additional audience-type studios in Radio City has been begun by NBC. Seating 450 persons each, the studios will incorporate the most advanced radio studio design with the atmosphere of an intimate theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- After months of incubation the nation's home defense program was started by President Roosevelt this week when he designated Fiorello La Guardia, New York's volatile Mayor, as the director who must induce American men, women and children to organize for possible attack on this country.

DETROIT, May 24 -- Are we making any real progress in solving labor-industry disputes or are the settlements which follow current strikes temporary truces? Are we likely to have a great deal more of labor unrest?

Here is Simon Brade again with his little ivory cubes. Simon hates detective work, but he has to do it because he knows no other way of earning the money he needs for augmenting his collection of rare ceramics. The little ivory cubes are the tools he uses in his detective work, and he always carries them about with him just in case he should run across a murder.

SANDS POINT, L. I., May 24 -- Dinner parties are being planned by many members of the Sands Point Bath Club for the opening dinner dance to be given next Thursday in the dining casino and outdoor terraces of the club, overlooking Long Island Sound and Manhasset Bay.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Wheat traders, through their operations in the Pit here, continue to express seemingly conflicting views as to the ultimate effect on the grain market of the government's loan program. While the signing of the bill is considered simply to be a matter of hours, there was a noticeable absence of aggressive buying today and prices on the Board of Trade were held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel.

Enough corpses come to light in Mrs. Meyer's rooming house to furnish forth half a dozen mystery stories, and determined efforts are made to fasten the guilt upon Jane Robbins, who is by far the nicest person in the entire book.

JERUSALEM, May 24 -- Two hundred Americans, Britons and other nationals, including members of the teaching staff and students from the American University in Beirut, Lebanon, and missionaries reached Palestine in the past week.

As part of its policy of continually strengthening its health protection program, the Queens College medical office announced this week that henceforth each student would he required to have a yearly X-ray of his chest to detect at their incipient stages tuberculosis and other respiratory disorders.

I have read with a good deal of interest the dispatches from Harold Callender about the political atmosphere of Ecuador. The country has been accused of being a hotbed of Nazi propaganda, with definite national leanings toward totalitarianism.

TO countless Americans, both New Yorkers and tourists from the interior, New York City's Battery is the point where the United States officially ends and the Atlantic Ocean begins. This seaward-pointing prow of Manhattan Island is a grandstand where visitors are treated to close-ups of great ships moving to and from the piers of the North and East Rivers.

DUBLIN, May 24 -- In the principal streets of Dublin gray-cemented, flat-roofed air-raid shelters have been erected, but civil authorities are keeping the doors locked until such time as they will be needed, which Dubliners fervently hope will be never.

CHUNGKING, China, May 24 -- General defense actions of Communist troops in relation to the new Japanese clean-up drive in Southern Shansi are described in a letter written by General Chou En-lai, chief Communist representative here, published yesterday in the newspaper Ta Kung Pao.

HERE'S hoping you will meet with success in your efforts to have the New York theatres see the wisdom of catering a little to us would-be playgoers who can't afford over a dollar for a seat. Seems to me it could be managed, even with present inflated costs.

A late Spring event of signal importance to members of society will be the ball to be given June 4 at 640 Fifth Avenue, the residence of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, under the patronage of the officers of the Seventy-seventh Division and for the benefit of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc.

The resignation of John ft. Halleran, long a power in Queens politics, as Commissioner of Borough Works, was announced yesterday by Borough President George U. Harvey. The resignation, which Mr. Harvey said is voluntary and caused by ill health, will be effective Aug. 1.

Visitors at The Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park, found the herb garden flourishing in the warm Spring weather, and further advanced than usual for this time of year. This garden is one of the few places where Americans can find a collection of the plants cultivated in medieval times before the present-day flower gardens were developed.

Mayor La Guardia returned yesterday from Washington, voicing confidence that his task as Director of the Office of Civilian Defense would be less arduous than he had expected because of the flood of offers of cooperation that have poured into his Washington office from all over the United States.

ZAGREB, Italian-Occupied Croatia, May 21 (delayed) (AP) -- Dr. Ante Pavelitch, facing his first test as Porlavnik, or leader, of the new State of Croatia, today convinced his followers in the Ustachi party that acceptance of an Italian Prince as King of Croatia would lead the little State to new heights and won their support.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The Civilian Pilot Training Program, which was started as a peacetime project for young men and women, has become an invaluable asset in national defense, Grove Webster, director of the Civil Aeronautics Board's program, told the annual aviation conference of New England at its closing session today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., May 24 -- Charged in a New York Federal grand jury indictment with extorting money from four major film studios, William Bioff, agent for the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, surrendered here today and was released on $25,000 bond.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.,. May 24 -- Committees sponsoring the eighteen cottage homes at the Children's Village here will give their annual box luncheon, fashion show and bridge party June 17 on the grounds of the historic home school for underprivileged children.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- Although they got only eight hits each, the Pirates and the Cardinals managed to score a total of seventeen runs today, with the National League leading Redbirds winning, 10 to 7.

DESPITE the varied and even contradictory accounts of what happened when J. Shufflin' Louis and Buddy of the Big Bad Baers collided in the District of Columbia the other night, it's the opinion in this corner that there's no doubt who won the fight. It was Uncle Mike Jacobs, away off.

THE British War Relief Society has recently sent $4,040 to the Musicians Benevolent Fund in London, but the fund needs far more money than this, according to Mrs. Rex Benson of the society who has recently returned from London.

TECHINICAL fare offered by Society of Automotive Engineers at its 1941 Summer meeting at White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., June 1-6, covers in twenty-five papers the entire range from trucks to aircraft and from fuels and lubricants to automotive power plants, according to John A.C. Warner, general manager of the society.
A new freight service between Houston, Texas, and West Coast ports of South America will start on June 2, it was announced here yesterday by the Grace Line.

Stocks drifted aimlessly yesterday in one of the dullest sessions of the year on the New York Stock Exchange and closed steady and mixed. Sales there totaled 160,260 shares, compared with 140,540 in the previous week-end market, and 420 different issues were traded.

Most gardeners take it for granted that Summer maintenance of an established lawn includes mowing, sprinkling and perhaps the digging out of a few weeds. But the rest of the story of effective lawn maintenance is usually not even considered, though it is just as important.

MAX WERNER'S instructive and copiously documented book is a historical survey and analysis of the current war. It covers the first nineteen months of the great struggle, from its beginning up to March last, also the years immediately preceding, and probably presents the first critical account of the military and diplomatic events in that period, based on as much source-material as is available under the circumstances.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Senator Mead of New York suggested to Secretary Hull today that the United States, perhaps in association with other American republics, should ask the Vichy government for temporary bases on its Western Hemisphere possessions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 24 -- The Harvard track and field forces swept as thoroughly over Yale today as a gale swept over Yale Field when these traditional foes clashed in their forty-eighth annual meet. The Cantabs, closing with a tremendous rush in the last four events, upset the Elis, 70 1/2 to 64 1/2, for their twenty-first victory in the series to twenty-seven for the Blue.

EFFORTS to bring Pacific Coast bridge tournaments into the regular schedule of the American Contract Bridge League have been generally unsuccessful during the last few years, despite the fact that the players and the league are similarly anxious to find some basis for doing so.

LONDON, Sunday, May 25 -- The Air Ministry reported today that the Royal Air Force carried out a blazing attack on Cologne over Friday night, the first big-scale British air attack upon Germany since last Sunday's raid on Kiel.

TO RUN AGAIN: The Controller of the City of New York announced last week that he would run for re-election this Fall. Dr. Joseph Daniel McGold rick, native of Brooklyn and "professor in politics" ever since he turned from teaching to electioneering in 1933, declared that there was still a big job to be done to preserve the city's credit in the next fiscal year.

The huge tonnage of scrap metals, on which many civilian goods industries were relying to supply part of their metal needs during the emergency, will be rationed and controlled by the government as strictly as the virgin materials, waste material dealers predicted here last week.

WITH June miraculously round the corner, a few words on the perennial subject of Summer reading may be in order. Time was when the convention held that only books of featherweight content were possible, from the viewpoint of both publisher and reader, in the months from June to September.

MANILA, May 24 -- The Second National Assembly has ended its historic session by voting to ask Congress to suspend the export tax provisions of the Independence Law by which a gradual application of United States tariffs was to be made to condition the Philippines for independence in 1946.

French military authorities loyal to the Vichy regime are strengthening the French base at Dakar, in West Africa, closest point to the Western Hemisphere, by using the forced labor of foreigners in the Foreign Legion, Jewish refugees and Spanish republicans, it was reported by refugees who arrived last night aboard the Spanish steamer Magallanes at the Columbia Street pier, Brooklyn.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -- Miss Fay Ann Albrecht, 17, Columbus, Wis., was selected today as the "Color Girl" for the June Week exercises at the Naval Academy by Midshipman William Edward Heronemus of Wisconsin, commander of the First Company.

The campaign of the United Service Organizations for National Defense will receive the support of Army and Navy posts in sixteen large cities of the country on June 2, when a flying demonstration will be given in those areas preliminary to the opening of the campaign on the following day.

THE Governor of Connecticut has recommended that his State buy a monumental record of North American bird life, generally regarded as the greatest since Audubon. It is a collection of 874 original paintings by Rex Brasher, the well-known naturalist-artist. The purchase, together with provision of a suitable home for the collection, would bring to a proper close a half century of such work as few naturalist-artists have ever done.

THERE are still stocks of Spanish and Italian olive oil in America, but day by day they are growing smaller and the ships that once brought in as much as 150,000 quintals (a quintal is 220.46 pounds) a year are tied up by the war.

THE revision which each generation makes, with brain and heart, of the major exponents of its own culture would have no value for the furtherance of that culture if it were not enclosed in documents to be preserved, re-examined, compared and studied.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 24 -- Rosario Chirillo, 64-year-old cobbler, head of a family of relief recipients "deported" last Monday to its native Ohio as the climax to seventeen months of litigation by the State of New York, was back at work today in his shop at 139 Halstead Avenue here.

WILLIE SNOW ETHRIDGE is the wife of a distinguished Southern newspaper man, the mother of four children at various ages of lively appeal, the chatelaine of twenty-six acres and an old house just outside Louisville, and a writer whose mind achieves a distinct and delightful combination of candor and mirth.

AN additional link of the Storm King Bypass on Route 9W, on the west side of the Hudson River, will be opened to motorists next Saturday. The new section completes the northern part of this scenic highway which provides travelers with magnificent views from a number of vantage points in the rugged hills above the Hudson River.

THE dudes are heading for the hills again, Cowboys (and cowgirls) from Brooklyn, the Bronx and other similarly rustic communities in the East are dusting off their ten-gallon hats, polishing up their jodhpurs and their jewel-studded belts, acquiring the latest in candy-striped shirts and flaming kerchiefs, and otherwise getting ready to ride range on one or another of several score dude ranches scattered among near-by hills and mountains.

Good manners, ability to follow instructions, responsibility, intellectual honesty and a pleasing personality are characteristics demanded by business of high school or college graduates who apply for office or clerical positions, speakers declared at the twenty-first annual convention and luncheon of the Commercial Education Association, held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

THE wandering pedestrian who goes into the wilds of the Ramapo Mountains, and especially into the Palisades Interstate Park, will soon find himself pursuing a worn foot-path. "A short cut used by the natives," he may say to himself.

ABOARD THE SANTA ROSA EN ROUTE FROM BERMUDA TO NEW YORK, May 20 (Uncensored) -- The important American defense base in Bermuda is proceeding as well as could be expected, in the face of several non-technical handicaps which were at most only partly foreseen when the preliminary work began in November.

Skippers out of Long Island ports, frequently favored by Federal, State, county and township officials who have brought them a succession of inland waterway improvements over the years, are now about to benefit by an ambitious new program.

LONDON, May 24 (UP) -- Anglo-Irish relations, always delicate, appeared endangered tonight as the mire Government at Dublin acted to counter possible application of conscription to the six counties of Northern Ireland.

WICHITA, Kan., May 24 -- A young student who risked his life to save another youth bent on suicide in a light Waco cabin plane was killed instantly today when the 20-year-old pilot, following a fight for control of the craft over the municipal airport.
ADELAIDE, May 24 (UP) -- Dr. Archibald Grenfell Price, Government candidate, today won the Boothby seat by a large majority over Thomas Edgar Lawton, the Labor candidate.

For imperial Italy the war last week brought varying fortunes. In the wild and remote hinterland of Ethiopia a Fascist colonial army laid down its arms, thus symbolizing the loss of the nation's most treasured overseas possession. In Rome an Italian nobleman was created King of Croatia and an Italian Governor was appointed for Dalmatia, thus symbolizing the extension of Italian influence in the Balkans.

Funds for the purchase of tractors to be used for rescue work after bombing attacks on London will be raised through a Tractor Dinner Dance to be given Tuesday at the Copacabana by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association in affiliation with the British-American Ambulance Corps.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 24 -- Severe measures against the fifth-column danger were demanded by Accion Argentina, a nonpolitical association with 800,000 members scattered throughout the country, at a session of its meetings yesterday.

College educators are divided on the question of a three-year course for students who may reach the draft age before their regular four-year academic program has been completed. Several local colleges, however, notably Columbia University, will permit young men to take the three-year plan.
