BERLIN, May 24 -- The official secrecy that continues envelop to the personal visit of Admiral Francois Darlan, Vice Premier of the Vichy regime, to Adolf Hitler a fortnight ago has not discouraged speculation over the extent to which that visit has contributed to the solution of the vexed problem of Franco-German post-war relations and, in a deeper sense, a lasting rapprochement.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) May 24 -- A keen demand for bonds developed in trading on the Bourse here today, and all-round modest gains were registered on a fairly large turnover. Shares, however, were irregular, Royal Dutch losing 2 pounds to end at 236 7/8, whereas Amsterdam Trading gained 1 1/2 to close at 428; Amsterdam rubber, 1 1/2 to 267 5/8; Philips Lamps 1 to 206 3/4, but most other changes, either way, were fractional.

BECAUSE of a shortage of stocks of the 3-cent stamp of China, owing to war conditions, five overprinted provisionals have been issued. The figure "3" and four Chinese characters have been placed on the Sun Yatsen 5c olive.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 24 -- Voluminous evidence of Communist, Nazi and Fascist activities in Westchester County gathered during the last thirteen months by the Westchester Sheriff's office was subpoenaed today by the Dies committee.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- For the first time in American history a full-strength "Panzer" division of American troops, the Second Armored Division, will take the field for full combat manoeuvres on June 16 in the Camp Forrest area in Tennessee. The "battle of Tennessee" will continue for about twelve days and will terminate about June 28 with the Fifth, Sixth and Twenty-seventh Divisions of infantry also participating.

It is of pre-war England that Mrs. Belloc Lowndes writes in this sentimental tale of love against a background of sordid crime. At a time when most Englishmen still cherish the illusion that Hitler means no harm to England, there are some, like Wing Commander Mervyn Lynch, who read the portents aright and are doing their utmost to be prepared for what is to come.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 24 -- Emir Abdul Illah, the Regent of Iraq, uncle of King Feisal and friend of Britain, has returned to his country under the protection of British and loyal Iraqi troops and is preparing to set up a new government.

DURHAM, N.H., May 24 -- Fourteen State, sectional and national organizations will sponsor meetings and another twenty-eight will cooperate in the climaxing celebration of the University of New Hampshire's seventy-fifth anniversary June 17 through June 27, according to announcement made by Henry B. Stevens, program chairman.
AMERICAN readers of Leo Lania's adventures will receive an arresting and definite warning against bureaucratic muddling such as enabled the Nazi army to achieve an easy victory over the French.

AS a token of their devotion to this country, ten American authors have just published ten brief radio dramas about the meaning of America. "The Free Company Presents --" is the title of their book; Dodd, Mead is publishing it.

The appeal which antique furnishings have for the home decorator may derive partly from the fact that they suggest a tranquil past and thus suggest a refuge from our disturbed and uncertain present. That this is an illusion, is granted, for even the good old days had their periods of storm and stress; nevertheless fine antiques do recall periods when beautiful craftsmanship seemed as important as the latest war news.

Some people adore the gadget. They are born that way. In extreme cases the gadget doesn't have to be particularly useful to satisfy them. The true gadget expert, however, cherishes the little object because it is fun to use, and it cuts corners on tedious jobs.

WE walked, as the sun went down, through the company streets in Fort Meade. The day's work was ended. Mess was done. Long shadows retreated from the grass toward the surrounding woods to sulk until daybreak.

The lack of any definite foreign policy here is a cause for grave concern. The course the government pursues is of tremendous importance to me, a young man of 30. A new world is in the making. What is the role to be played by the United States? Where are we going and why?

The Yankees knocked the props from the left-handed Earl (Stretch) Johnson and the Red Sox in one big inning yesterday at the Stadium as they thrilled 20,935 fans with their fourth straight victory. The score was 7 to 6. Each game in the Yankee streak has been decided by one run.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- An addition to the program for the first pan-American games, to be held Nov. 21 through Dec. 6, 1942, at Buenos Aires, was announced today by Avery Brundage, president of the United States of America Sports Federation.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Roosevelt in his "fireside chat" to the nation Tuesday evening will deal vigorously with opponents of democracy abroad and at home, according to Stephen T. Early, Presidential press secretary, who gave the first intimation today of the character of the coming address.

Characterizing the proposal of A.A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, for the nomination of Mayor La Guardia by all three legal political parties as a conspiracy to continue a pro-war Mayor in office with no fair opportunity to vote against him, leaders of the left wing group of the American Labor party announced yesterday that an anti-war candidate would be entered in the Labor party primary.
LAST week was an important one for West End managers, for it gave them their first real chance of testing the effect of the double Summer time, which was established just over a fortnight ago.

SUMMER temperatures brought an early call for lightweight apparel and accessories to stores last week with the likelihood that ebbing gains over last year would be reversed. Through the farm country, as well, passage of 85 per cent parity legislation improved agricultural prices and will mean more trade.

A LIFELIKE composite portrait of the man who repsents the Royal Air Force type is given in this diary of a sky-fighter, and the effect is dramatic and satisfying. By it is revealed a young Briton who is sensitive but not too introspective, who believes thoroughly in himself and the cause he is fighting for, who hates war but loves adventure, and who, in the best British tradition, holds sportsmanship high among the virtues. "

LAKE GEORGE -- The first annual Lake George Lake Trout Derby will be held here over the Decoration Day week-end under the sponsorship of the Lake George Chamber of Commerce and cooperating fish and game clubs.

IN the realm of Hollywood, Florence Bates is unique, being one of the few women who launched a screen career after a fiftieth birthday. She faced a camera for the first time in "Rebecca," and followed this up with parts in "Kitty Foyle," "Strange Alibi," and more recently as the mother-in-law in Metro's forthcoming "Love Crazy," co-starring William Powell and Myrna Loy.

VICHY, France, May 24 -- More than ever the word "collaboration" is on every French tongue on both sides of the line of demarcation. Yet its exact definition still remains to be determined. In his broadcast to the nation yesterday the Vice Premier, Admiral Francois Darlan, declared the choice for France was between life and death, but he did not enter into details.

Francois Darlan, Admiral of the Fleet, Minister of the Navy, of the Interior, of Foreign Affairs, Vice Premier of France, shares with Marshal Petain the supreme power in the government at Vichy; and his name is linked more closely than that of the aged Marshal to "collaboration" with the victor.

"CITIZEN KANE" was the first motion picture on which I had ever worked. I had heard of the many handicaps that exist for a composer in Hollywood. One was the great speed with which scores often had to be written -- sometimes in as little as two or three weeks.
ROME, May 24 -- New restrictions on the Catholic press in Germany have exasperated still further the relations between the Holy See and Berlin, it was stated in high Vatican quarters today.

THE sudden enormous expansion of aircraft plants in this country has brought about a shortage of aeronautical and tool design engineers, inspectors, technical experts and other skilled personnel. Many of the aircraft manufacturers, in cooperation with the National Defense Council, are conducting educational experiments in various universities to assure a steady flow of trained men.

LIMA, Peru, May 24 (UP) -- The Foreign Office has refused a suggestion that conversations be started between Argentina, Brazil, the United States, Peru and Ecuador as a step toward settlement of the Peruvian-Ecuadorian boundary dispute.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 -- The machinists' strike, which has tied up eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards and more than $500,000, 000 worth of Navy and Maritime Commission construction for two weeks, threatened today to spread to a twelfth plant.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 -- A "strike" of night clubs, the first ever heard of in these Far Western parts, is under way here in powerful protest against the most extraordinary closing of the town San Francisco has known since the Argonauts used to come in from the diggings to spend their gold dust on wine, women and whoopee.

Many flags have waved over American troops since a Pine Tree flag was raised at the Battle of Bunker Hill. When the British first saw the Union Jack of the Grand Union flag on New Year's Day of 1776 they thought it was a sign of surrender until they colunted thirteen stripes and knew the war was not over.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 24 -- Following up a fine performance in the qualifying test with a convincing 5-and-4 triumph in the first match-play round, John E. Parker Jr. of Essex County and Philip B. Harris of the host club led the way into the semi-finals of the Montclair Golf Club invitation tourney today.

HANOVER, N.H., May 24 -- Ed Beetem was outstanding today as he paced the Pennsylvania track team to a 72 1/2-to-62 1/2 victory over Dartmouth. The Penn champion took first places in the shot-put and discus throw, as well as a third place with the hammer, to give his team 11 points.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 24 -- Jorge Gonzalez von Maree, energetic leader of the Chilean Nazi party now rechristened the Popular Socialist Vanguard, was seized and placed in a lunatic asylum today on orders of the Minister of the Interior, where he will be examined by mental experts, who will decide if charges of insanity are confirmed.

LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- Headquarters of General Charles de Gaulle's "Free French" forces allied with Britain pledged approval today of "any action taken by the British Government which would frustrate plans of the French Quislings."

As might be expected, the psychologists and psychiatrists have given their opinion of Hess's dramatic flight from Germany to Scotland. To us the most convincing of these analyses is that of the distinguished Dr. J.L. Moreno, whose business in life it is to dispose of inner conflicts and take out of life worries and obsessions of which even their possessors are not aware.

At least 60 per cent of the persons who attended the anti-war rally sponsored by the America First Committee in Madison Square Garden last Friday night were members of or sympathizers with the German-American Bund, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, declared last night.

IGNACIO, Col. -- There is a legend in the lonely foothills of the San Juan Mountains that the son of Ouray, the Ute chieftain, and of Chipeta, the Tabeguache maiden, some day will come back to lead his people.

BERLIN, May 24 -- Although the invasion of Crete from the air began last Tuesday, the German High Command acknowledged for the first time in a special communique this afternoon that such an operation was in progress. The western and most important portion of that Greek island, according to the Germans, is securely in their bands and their forces have now begun to attack.

RAIL excursions, both one day and week-end, will be more numerous than ever this Summer with rates in many cases as much as 50 per cent less than the regular fares. The trips will take in a wide range of territory in all directions from New York.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- The Long Trail, extending along the peaks of the Green Mountains for 250 miles, is again in readiness for hikers. The Green Mountain Club has been busy clearing windfalls and placing shelters in readiness for the season.

Eight vested choirs from the metropolitan area competed for cups at the Protestant Church Junior and Senior Contest Festival, held yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, under the sponsorship of the Music Education League in cooperation with the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

INVESTIGATIONS by legislative and other committees and excitement over subversive textbooks have brought teachers and teaching into the news again. Teachers as teachers generally do not make the headlines. The layman remembers with vague affection or contempt two or three teachers among all those he had at school or college.

New York City acquired almost a year ago at a cost of about $326,000,000 the rapid-transit and surface lines of the IRT and BMT systems and began to operate them, in conjunction with its own Independent Subway, as the New York City Transit System.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 24 -- The German Government has decided to give Chile the 3,185-ton four-masted merchant training vessel Priwall, Ambassador Wilhelm von Schoen told the Foreign Office today.

THE first corpse is discovered by a phantom secretary named Vivian Sanderson, and a very charming phantom she is, not a bit like those who scare people out of their wits by walking through solid walls, uttering sepulchral warnings and then vanishing into thin air.

The second Saturday of the four-week meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park brought out yesterday a record number of members of society from their Summer homes on the North and South Shores of Long Island, Westchester, New York, New Jersey and Maryland.

Harness horse racing under the floodlights is slated to return to Long Island on Wednesday evening when the forty-night Spring meeting of the Old Country Trotting Association will open at the remodeled and improved Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 (AP) -- Four drivers qualified today for the Indianapolis motor speedway Memorial Day 500-mile race, increasing the certain starting field to twenty-five.

FROM Bennington, home of many Summers of modern dance activity, comes the first word of what is to be done there this year in the way of new productions. Three leading dancers will be in residence -- Doris Humphrey, Martha Graham and Charles Weidman -- but only two of them will present new works.

Alumni and teachers of Public School 2, which has stood since 1811 at 116 Henry Street and is the city's oldest public school building now in use, gathered at a luncheon yesterday at the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- If Nazi troops attempt to take the British Isles, "it may easily be some weeks before the invader has been totally destroyed," Prime Minister Winston Churchill warned Britons today in a message accompanying an official "beating the invader" leaflet.

Five prizes to members of the senior class, to be awarded in the annual Columbia College Class Day ceremonies at 10:30 A.M. on June 2 in the Van Amringe Quadrangle, were announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.

TOKYO, May 24 -- Behind an impenetrable curtain of silence and an anti-spy campaign the political leaders of Japan are engaged in a series of conferences on the outcome of which is likely to depend the future of American-Japanese relations and peace in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The gravity of the blow to British naval supremacy entailed by the sinking of H.M.S. Hood could be measured here today by the stunned silence with which the news was received, not only in the British Embassy and naval circles but also by the officials of the United States Navy Department.

Hot weather spurred consumer demand for Summer apparel and accessories in retail trade here last week. Department store volume was estimated at better than 10 per cent ahead of 1940. Food sales continued to gain, and trade reports indicated turnover was about 12 per cent ahead of last year.

It seems to me that a great many people in the United States are wondering exactly what to think and what to expect of the French situation. Henry Bernstein's letter, published recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES, was an excellent defense of the true France and its courageous defenders.

DETROIT -- With May's retail sales entering the stretch and headed for an all-time record in the industry's history, observers continue to be amazed at the consistent demand for cars displayed during the past seven months.

Following the Spring elections, several women's clubs in Westchester County and Connecticut have named new leaders, while others will continue their present executives in office for the coming season.

IF you bring up baby with an iron hand, regiment his feeding, train him early, deny him such infant pleasures as sucking his thumb or playing in dirt, and keep on with more of the same, he may turn out all right.

More than 32,000 irises belonging to seventy varieties are in full bloom on the Columbia University Campus on Morningside Heights. The Columbia collection is the largest in Manhattan and is displayed against a background of privet hedges, flowering shrubs and lawns.

As one way of aiding Britain to build up dollar exchange to buy in America farm and factory necessities she may not hope to obtain under the lease-lend act, "Buy Something British" week was opened here yesterday -- British Empire Day -- with the cooperation of department stores and specialty shops throughout the city.

GENERAL JAMES WILKINSON is one of the most fascinating characters in American history, though rather because of his faults than his virtues. No one with a drop of biographical blood in his veins could rend of him without wanting to write of him. He wrote voluminously, and with high approval, of himself.

Going behind the figures that reveal an alarming increase for the first quarter of 1941 in the national total of traffic deaths, the National Safety Council finds that proved methods of accident control can curb fatalities despite the new risks created by the defense program.
Four runs in the eighth inning, although only one hit was made, gave City College a 7-4 triumph over Springfield at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday in the Beavers' closing home game of the year.

SURROUNDED by quite as much secrecy, as enveloped the memorable making of "King Kong," Hollywood this week finally launched "This Changing World," the revenue from which will be divided equally between British and American charities.

TWENTY months ago Gontran de Poncins was in an igloo in the Arctic. He went back to France in time to witness France's fall. Now he lives in a room at the Ritz. He lighted two cigarettes for his companions, then extinguished the match with great thoroughness.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 24 -- In view of the increasing difficulties in supplying food to the nation the government has taken new and drastic measures. Henceforth only twenty kilos of flour for each person may be kept in each household.

Because of the extreme pressure in Lisbon, where thousands of prospective passengers are clamoring for passage between Europe and the United States, the American Export Line has been trying to charter a transatlantic passenger liner to operate with its fleet of four ships.

ROME, May 24 -- King Victor Emmanuel had a narrow escape from death last Saturday when a man, stated to be of Greek nationality, fired several revolver shots against the car in which he was driving with Albanian Premier Shevket Verlaci just outside Tirana, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- The Reds, after losing the first game, 4 to 2, earned an even break in a doubleheader today on Whitey Moore's six-hit, 4-to-1 victory over the Cubs before 19,055 wind-chilled spectators.

Women, unless they are willing to say good-bye to Summer looking like reasonable facsimiles of the ruins of Carthage, realize that now is the time to Take Steps -- time to stock up with tanning lotions and creams.

DUBLIN, May 24 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valets regards the fact that the British Government is contemplating conscripting Irishmen in Northern Ireland of as such grave moment to the peace of Ireland as a whole that he has instructed the Speaker of the Dail Eireann today to summon a special session of Parliament for Monday at which he will make a statement to Daft Deputies and the country.
ROME, May 24 -- Two more British cruisers have been sunk by Italian destroyers in the great aero-naval battle now going on in the Eastern Mediterranean, it was asserted in today's war bulletin.

LESS than fifty miles from Manhattan is one of the fastest-growing communities of New Jersey. In six months its population has risen to nearly 11,000 men, an increase of about 1,000 per cent, and the trend is still upward.

The National Travelers Aid Association moved yesterday into new quarters at 425 Fourth Avenue, which afford more than double its former office space.

Where one remains, it should, perhaps, be made a note of, all the more, as in this instance, when the ivory tower happens to be a supreme example of its kind, all lovely and shining on the outside and fittingly furnished within.

Gardeners who are making a Memorial Day week-end visit to New York will be able to hear an illustrated lecture of special interest to them. Dr. A.P. Saunders, one of the country's leading breeders of peonies, is scheduled to speak on Hybrid Peonies Saturday at 3 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 24 -- Discussions during closing sessions of the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs were concentrated today on the quest for equal opportunity of service for women in the country's emergency program.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 24 -- Army was buried under a 23-to-4 count by Penn State today. Four Army pitchers were used during the contest. State base runners were much in evidence throughout, fifteen of them getting on by walks and eight of these scoring.

NANTUCKET is the subject of Eleanor Early's latest scrapbook of jaunty gossip and guidance; and if this "patchwork" is not the best book which has appeared for the information and delight of island- bound tourists, it is certainly one of the gayest.

A DOWN-AND-OUT writer of popular songs who died in Bellevue Hospital seventy-seven years ago last January comes into his own on Tuesday with the unveiling of his bust in the Hall of Fame. He might value more the fact that one of his melodies has probably been heard by more millions of people during this past Winter than any other popular song in our history.

NOT long after the name of Dionne attained a worldwide celebrity Lillian Barker, a journalist in New York, made up her mind to write the biography of "the world's most famous mother," and journeyed to Callander for that purpose.

THE stars of the evening mode are shining brilliantly. Long undulating tunics and full, long peplums are striking innovations. Two of New York's most skilled designers have found challenging ways of introducing the styles. The tunic with a dropped shoulder emphasized by an inset band of hand-crocheting is exciting. It's all in white, as frosty as an ice cube.

IT was in the pages of The New Yorker that young Judy Graves made her bow to the public -- capturing at once a sizable quota of admirers. Though they lacked her usual bite and venom, Sally Benson's stories of a 12-year-old's adventures were both touching and inimitably comic.

DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- Lefty Edgar Smith's wild pitch with the bases full and two out in the ninth inning gave the Tigers a 1-to-0 victory over the White Sox today and boosted the American League champions back into fourth place.

A new type of dahlia for the small garden now meeting with an enthusiastic reception seldom grows more than two feet high, but blossoms just as freely as the larger kinds and over as long a season. The new type, called Mignon or Bedding, includes one especially charming variety that goes under the name of Peter Pan.

"KAREN ELLIS" is the exhaustive and thorough history of a career woman in New York. Born in the Eighteen Nineties in a small Connecticut mill town, she had no silver-spoon heritage. Her father was a ne'er-do-well and disinherited member of the town's big mill family, and her mother a colorless, weak personality.

FROM all German radio fronts America is getting a general pasting. The United States is planning a systematic military occupation of Canada "when the time is ripe," according to one recent German short-wave broadcast aimed at South Africa.

Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, accompanied by Lady Halifax, will be present at the Solemn Pontifical Mass for the "Suffering People of Great Britain" to be celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral Wednesday, June 4, at 10 A.M., it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the committee sponsoring the mass, 843 Madison Avenue.

Pets ranging from a well-groomed French poodle to a pair of tame rats were entered by children and adults yesterday in the annual pet show conducted by the Park Department's playground at Seventy-fourth Street and Riverside Drive.

Iceland has just severed her century-old ties with Denmark and is preparing to transform herself into an independent republic. At the same time, British reports tell of the concentration of large numbers of Nazi troops and transport planes in Northern Norway, believed to be massing for an invasion of Iceland.

THE Alfred A. Knopf Literary Fellowships, first offered for 1940, and again for 1941, are now announced for 1942. There are three Fellowships, each consisting of an outright grant of $1,200 followed by book publication on a royalty basis.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 24 -- Led by two craft in the first two divisions of the Handicap Class, a fleet of twenty-six yachts competed today in the initial regatta of the twenty-two that will make up the championship series of the Yacht Racing Association.

THIS slender volume carries much weight. Upon a subject of great literary importance it brings to bear both copious learning and unerring critical penetration. Using these invincible weapons, Mr. Smith conducts a brave and victorious defense by means of a bold and brilliant offensive.

A bronze portrait bust of Stephen Collins Foster, the seventy-third addition to the Hall of Fame for Great Americans on the Bronx campus of New York University, will be unveiled Tuesday at 3:15 P.M., Dr. William Lyon Phelps, director, announced yesterday.

TORONTO -- Route signs are now in use on an annually increasing number of waterways for canoe trips in Canada as part of the Dominion's policy to popularize canoe trips, not only in the settled regions but even in the remotest parts.

THE POSTOFFICE DEPARTMENT'S stamp-production program well be resumed on June 25 with the appearance of a 6-cent air-mail item which is to be the first in a series to comprise 6c, 10c, 15c, 20c, 30c and 50c, all to be in the same design.

MANHATTAN, Kan., May 24 -- Major Gen. James G. Harbord, U.S.A. retired, speaking tonight to graduating seniors and alumni of Kansas State College, his alma mater, expressed doubt that Great Britain could weather the storm without American intervention.

"YOU'VE done wonders," said a friend who looked over Don Rose's house and garden not long ago, "on a very short shoestring." Well, he has stretched the shoestring, the Philadelphia newspaper columnist admits.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The world's largest warship, the 42,100-ton Hood of the Royal Navy, was hit directly and destroyed by a shell from the German battleship Bismarck today in the first major engagement of this war between capital ships of the British and German naval forces, the Germans announced.

INASMUCH as this is the season for awards in the theatre, it seems to me that no time should be lost in making a quadruple award to Orson Welles for the distinct services he has rendered the authorities, the theatregoing public, the theatre operators and the program advertisers at the St. James Theatre, where his production of "Native Son" is now holding forth.

TWO autogiros, recently transferred from the War Department to the National Park Service, will be used to ferret out forest fires. The machines can hover over treetops, lakes and streams. Under favorable conditions they are capable of maintaining themselves in the air at a virtual standstill over a chosen spot.

Edith Anisfield Wolf announced yesterday through The Saturday Review of Literature that she had established a new annual award of $1,000, in addition to the one of the same amount that has been made since 1934, for books published in the field of race relations.

VARIOUS aspects of the modern movement, especially as it has developed in Germany and France, are stressed in an exhibition called "Masters and Vanguard of Modern Art," which opened last week at the Nierendorf, to remain current until June 7.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 24 -- Eugene (Red) Littler, defeated in his pet event, the 440, and again in the 220, came back today to run a thrilling last lap of the one-mile relay and retain for Nebraska by a point and a half over Missouri the Big Six track and field championship the Huskers have held for the past two years.

IRWIN STARK'S letter (May 11) in these columns epitomizes perfectly the attitude of the authentic creative writer toward his material "There is," he reminds us, and what a commentary on the times that we should need reminder, "there is only one compulsion for the artist.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America voted today to petition the Federal Government to pay the cost of keeping conscientious objectors in the work camps they must go to when drafted.

LONDON, May 24 -- The International Rubber Regulation Committee decided this week to maintain the export quota in restricting countries for the third quarter at 100 per cent of standard tonnages. The quota allows annual exports of 1,554,700 long tons from restricting countries, supplemented by about 45,000 tons of outside exports.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Much of the speculation this week over the possibility of President Roosevelt sending an early message to Congress dealing with the international situation originated with the Administration's congressional adherents who hoped the Chief Executive would take this course to help clarify an increasingly confused state of mind on Capitol Hill.

Our native Calico-bush or Mountain-laurel is probably the most satisfactory of all broad-leaved evergreens, especially for Northern gardens, large and small. It is more beautiful in habit of growth than its first cousin, the rhododendron, more prolific of bloom, and it is found in the wild from Alabama almost to the Canadian border.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 24 -- After exactly four months' absence, Prime Minister R.G. Menzies ended a 42,000-mile journey this afternoon with a rough crossing from Auckland. Royal Australian Air Force planes dipped in salute as his flying boat arrived, and cheers greeted Mr. Menzies as he stepped ashore to receive the warm greetings of Mrs. Menzies and of Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden, Minister of Navy W.M. Hughes and other Cabinet members and notables.

PROFOUNDLY interested in the doings of the younger set, this corner seasonally dusts off the accumulated academic nonsense of the cinema graybeards by chatting with a Hollywood starlet. Herewith we tender one Marjorie Woodworth, and if that name is as yet not too deeply embedded in the public's pate there is good reason.

ON THE FRENCH-SPANISH FRONTIER, May 24 -- According to stories told by the survivors of the Zamzam, the Germans were reported to have been surprised to find passengers aboard the Egyptian steamship that, from its lines, they had presumed to be a British troop ship.

A black week for Britain -- a week in which the Germans secured their foothold on Crete and inflicted considerable losses on the British Mediterranean Fleet -- ended yesterday in a sea tragedy of Homeric proportions.

THE American westward movement was not a coherent chapter in our history but an almost infinitely varied social experience; the most important thing about the frontier is that it was an ever moving frontier.

Miss Lorraine Fischer of the Women's Swimming Association turned in the outstanding performance at a swimming meet in Ravenhall Bathing Park at Coney Island yesterday to win the Ohrbach Trophy. It was the first outdoor A.A.U. meet in the metropolitan area.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The German High Command, for the first time since the war began, today announced the death in action of a German commanding general -- Col. Gen. Ulrich Grauert, one of the Reich's most famous _Air Force commanders.

THE opinions of the dean of American booksellers on the values of books are always worth hearing. Lathrop C. Harper is an outstanding authority on incunabula and Americana, he is a conservative, and his excellent catalogues with descriptive notes and prices have a stabilizing effect upon the market.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 24 -- J. Kevin Newman of Akron, Ohio, received today the Choate School's seal prize, the highest general honor the school confers, in recognition of "outstanding contribution to his school in his sixth form year." The award was one of the thirty-two academic and general prizes presented in the chapel at the annual prize day exercises.

THE big bronze dinner bell that rings in one of the most popular of the nation's radio discussion hours goes on the shelf after next Thursday's meeting at 9:35 P.M. over WJZ, and will be silent until Fall opens a new broadcasting season.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -- Pitt scored four unearned runs today to defeat the Naval Academy, 4 to 3, and break the middies' nine-game winning streak.

Back in the Eighteen Eighties it was not only downright unladylike for a girl to think of being a doctor but impractical, especially if her father was a minister with ten other children. When Maggie McArn at 13 announced her decision at New Year's dinner there was shocked disapproval and some rather raucous laughter, but Maggie had inherited the spunk which had sent her Scottish ancestors to North Carolina and refused to be discouraged.

THE week's program contains two debuts, though not by unknown dancers, and both of them are booked for the studiotheatre of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, which has rapidly become an institution in the chamber dance field.

Mrs. Artemas L. Gates will give a tea on Tuesday at her home, 36 East Seventy-fourth Street, for members of the British War Relief Society's committee active in behalf of the professional round-robin tennis tournament to be held on June 6, 7 and 8 at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, L.I., to aid the society's fund for the relief of war victims in the Borough of Wimbledon, England.

BUTLER, N.J., May 24 -- Harry A. Cozzens Jr., superintendent of the Butler plant of the American Hard Rubber Company, and William Wanklin, president of Local 36, United Rubber Workers of America, C.I.O., issued today a joint statement in which they said that the officials and employes of the company have agreed to forego usual Summer vacations this year to provide for maximum production of national defense orders.

Radio's contribution to the religious and historical culture of the nation and the world, as well as its influence on the education of children, was honored yesterday afternoon by the Women's Press Club of New York City, which awarded four certificates of merit to as many programs it had selected as outstanding during the last year.

LONDON, May 24 -- The 42,100-ton battle cruiser Hood, pride of the British Fleet and the world's biggest fighting vessel, was blown up today by an "unlucky hit" scored on a munitions magazine by the new German battleship Bismarck in an engagement off Greenland, the Admiralty announced.

WHEN the American Navy entered Santiago Harbor in 1898 it was led, not by the admiral's flagship, but by a hospital supply ship with Clara Barton in command. She had earned that honor, and a more permanent honor, which should last as long as charity, through three wars and more than thirty years of selfless service.

With Samuel Reshevsky, united States chess champion, holding a lead of 2 -- 0 with eight games drawn, over Israel A. Horowitz, the eleventh game of the match for the national title was begun last night at the headquarters of the Staten Island Chess Club, St. George.

A parked automobile, left unattended on the steep grade of Amsterdam Avenue between 132d and 133d Streets yesterday afternoon started rolling down the hill and before it crashed to a stop killed a 7-year-old boy, injured a 36-year-old man and wrecked the front of a stationery store.

CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) -- The Indians stretched their American League lead to four and one-half games today by taking the second of their three-game Stadium series from the Browns with a four-run first inning, repeating their 4-to-2 victory of last night. Elden Auker was the victim in one-third of the Tribe's half of the first inning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 24 -- It was ideal golf weather on the pleasant greens of the Dutchess Golf and Country Club today, but mental anguish ran high in the locker room, where the case of the missing golf clubs was being widely discussed.

DETROIT, May 24 -- The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick of New York told 2,500 persons at a ministers' no-war rally here last night that America's true role in the war was that of mediator and peacemaker, and that she would lose that opportunity if she became "an all-out belligerent."

The union of ten Canadian university alumni associations in New York was disclosed yesterday with the announcement of their first formal dinner, to be held June 4 at the Hotel Biltmore. Douglas S. Cole, Canadian Trade Commissioner in New York, who is honorary president, will be the presiding officer.

Through a clean performance in the touch-and-out sweepstake, the chestnut gelding, Lew Dunbar, clinched the jumper championship to highlight the eighth annual Staten Island horse show, held yesterday at the Todt Hill Stables in Dongan Hills.

The wholesale markets were generally active last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Slow deliveries and rising prices caused serious concern, particularly on some of the home furnishings lines.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A rematch of Joe Louis and Buddy Baer looms as a possibility for this city this Summer, in the light of developments following last night's battle between the champion and his surprisingly potent challenger. Mike Jacobs, the promoter who has exclusive call on Louis's services, indicated today that he would be willing to stage the return bout here if he can see his way clear to do so.

Complete cooperation with the Federal Government and compliance with the minimum training standards of the United States Army are required in new regulations for State Guards about to be issued by the War Department.
The women golfers of the metropolitian area are facing a strenuous program this week, as two events of importance are listed that will involve most of the players with high as well as low handicaps.

The La Malls Academy team, powerful in both track and field events, piled up an overwhelming margin to annex the Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester outdoor crown of the C.H.S.A.A. at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx yesterday. Putting together a total of 671-9 points, the team dethroned Mount St. Michael, which finished second with 38 17-18.

Early and frequent market visits will mark the Fall operations of buyers, according to the consensus in retail circles here last week. Considerable optimism is expressed about overcoming delivery delays, at least for the early part of the season, because the showings scheduled by manufacturers during the next three weeks should afford adequate leeway for shipments up to the Labor Day period.

EVEN as Helen Judson read through a hundred somewhat melodramatic clippings about the English nurse whom the Germans had executed in occupied Belgium in 1915, she knew that her question remained in its essence unanswered: Who was Edith Cavell? Fact had already dissipated, to be sure, the foggy impression that she had been a spy.

AMONG the projects listed by the League of Composers for next season are the commissioning of three chamber operas, the presentation of two programs of film music by leading contemporary American and European composers, the development of an educational library of contemporary music, and the establishment of branches in key cities throughout the country for the furtherance of local programs of contemporary musical works.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 24 (AP) -- British General Headquarters today issued this communique

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, called upon industry and labor today to settle their differences around the conference table and accept mediation in advance of strikes or lockouts.

A COVER flown by Hawker and Grieve on the first trans-atlantic non-stop air-mail a-tempt from Newfoundland in 1919, brought $625 at the public sale of the Normal Serphos collection of pioneer airpost covers and other aviation material at the Collectors' Club last week.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- This week the wild azalea, or swamp apple blossom, display will be at its zenith in the Berkshires. Formerly abundant along main highways, these aromatic pink blooms may now be seen covering entire hillsides along the woodsy trails and back roads where the old-time spirit of unspoiled Berkshire still prevails.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The United States and Canada, it was learned today, will establish early next week two closely collaborating economic planning boards to speed the mobilization of American resources for aid to Britain and defense of the Western Hemisphere.

THE streamlined civilization of 1941 -- the civilization of high speed and high pressure, of easy living and labor-saving gadgets, the civilization which we take so much for granted -- has beech disrupted in Britain. Bombs from the air not only have drastically interfered with conveniences once considered necessities but also have wiped out some of them.

George D. Widener's Eight Thirty, winner of the Toboggan on the opening day of the meeting, came right back at Belmont Park yesterday to capture the $13,750 Metropolitan Handicap in smashing style despite top weight of 132 pounds and keen opposition.

ELECTRIC EYE JOB -- To the versatile "electric eye" has been given the new task of determining the protein content of wheat, grain specialists of the United States Department of Agriculture report. In making tests with the new apparatus the wheat is ground and the proteins extracted by chemical means.
BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -- A pair of veterans stood out prominently as Baltimore defeated Newark, 5 to 3, today.

THIS book is the incredible story of Ali Pasha, bloodthirsty tyrant of Greece and Albania who as the enthroned despot of Yanina, in Epirus, Greece, threatened the Sultan in his Byzantine stronghold, oppressed his subjects and has emerged as the most horrifying character to come thus far from legendary Levant.

I was the more surprised that this argument should be used by my friend, because he was known for his pacifistic and liberal views.

CANTON, Ohio, May 24 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor union officials ordered a "work stoppage" beginning Monday in twenty-eight Ohio, three Pennsylvania and two Indiana sewer-pipe factories, to support their demands for a new contract and wage increases.

A witness for the prosecution testified in the Court of General Sessions yesterday that Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, was consulted regarding legislation that would make it easier for the Burland Printing Company to obtain State printing contracts and know what competition it would have to meet.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 24 -- To a certain extent there is a potential parallel between present developments in the Middle East and the history of the Balkans immediately preceding the outbreak of war in that area.

A German aerial invasion of the British-held island off the Greek coast was raising once more the issue of airpower against seapower, was posing problems for Britain's navy and for the British command in the Middle East.
AUDEN has found lines in Montaigne that express what has generally been felt in his poetry:

THE controversy between the Federal Communications Commission and the broadcasters over the agency's recent order affecting chain broadcasting has boiled over on Capitol Hill and an early Senate investigation is in prospect.
