Ah, me, the nostalgia that accompanies the reading of the "Farms for Sale" editorial! What a tremendous appeal the classified columns exert, what vicarious enjoyment is possible for the reader!

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 24 -- Coincident with the expropiation of Bolivian Air Lloyd, it was officially announced today that the Pan American-Grace Airways is immediately taking over the important air service between La Paz and Oruro, Conchabamba, Santa Cruz and Corumba, linking interocean air traffic with Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and Arica, Chile.

MAJOR EDWARD BOWES, whose cheery "all right" has been a feature over the air waves these many years, will take a vacation from his Sunday chores for the first time since 1925, following the broadcast of June 1.

The "strange, grim" battle for Crete, as Prime Minister Churchill called it, ushered in a new era in warfare last week and again underscored air power as the arm of the future. In detail the German use of parachute troops and air-borne infantry against Crete was not essentially different from previous operations of those troops.

If the Goodall round-robin golf tourney were decided on the basis of scoring, the cup and the $1,000 first prize money would be in possession of stalwart Vic Ghezzi right this minute. The last two rounds at Fresh Meadow, near Flushing, today would not be necessary.

Praising New York as "more beautiful than London" and Tennessee as "like rural England," Mrs. Mary B. Worth, 29-year-old British housewife, boarded the Atlantic Clipper for Lisbon at La Guardia Field yesterday. She said she was home-bound "to do my bit." She brought her two children here ten months ago and left them with friends in Memphis, Tenn.

LONDON, May 24 -- Coincident with the first German High Command communique on the Battle of Crete, in which the Nazis claimed possession of the western end of the island, the British made known that since yesterday long-range bombers and fighters of the Royal Air Force had been attacking Maleme airfield, where the Germans are entrenched.

While fifteen years is well beyond the average life of a dog, it is brief span in human affairs. Fifteen years ago the Morris and Essex Kennel Club gave its first exhibition. In many respects it was just another dog show, with fewer than six hundred specimens benched.

AS United States Naval authorities went ahead last week with their plans for commissioning Floyd Bennett Field on Monday, June 2, as a full-fledged Navy Air Station, some changes in the airport's physical plant and equipment already became apparent.

A distinguished attendance of high-ranking officers of the various branches of military service, city and county officials and members of society in this city and on Long Island, is expected at the event entitled "A Gala Night at the Trotting Races," which will be given as a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York on Memorial Day night, next Friday, at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I.

Planting seeds indoors or in a frame is simple enough, but the test lies in the several weeks of care involving pricking out, maintenance and hardening off of seedlings before weather permits their being transplanted into the garden.
Under the budget adopted by the City Council last week the city will spend $1,827,470 a day during the fiscal year that begins on July 1, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick said yesterday.

Foremost among the new trends in the Summer employment situation brought about by the national defense program is a concerted drive to place Columbia College juniors in "tryout positions" with industrial and business concerns, according to a survey made by Miss Mary A. Wegener, assistant secretary of appointments at Columbia University.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The Memorial Day week-end will find the Pocono resorts well filled and Summer schedules of activities inaugurated. A golf tournament and the first lawn bowling tournament of the season will be held on Saturday at Buck Hill Falls.

The rate of increase of motor traffic into central and lower Manhattan below Sixty-first Street is slowing down, the Regional Plan Association disclosed yesterday. Its report was made after consultation with official and civic bodies cooperating in a survey of traffic and parking facilities in the central congested districts of Manhattan and Brooklyn.

If one is 6 a subway ride is an experience, but if you are 7 and grown-up enough to be riding all the way downtown alone, that is an adventure. So Louise thought, and her contemporaries who follow her on that birthday treat will undoubtedly agree with her.

THOROUGHBRED racing, sport of kings and two-dollar bettors, is in town. Until the end of October, with time out for the traditional meeting at Saratoga in August, the sleekly groomed geegees will be running in Gotham. And, once again, to their tympanic hoofbeats is heard the daily wail of the losers, affirming the sagacious bettor's dictum: "It takes more than a horse to win."

After again being run up to new high levels for four years in the first few minutes of trading yesterday, the prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased off under the impact of profit-taking, and a renewal of selling by the South in the final hour. Closing quotations, as a result, were irregular, being up 2 to off 2 points on the day.

WITH more and more amateurs turning to color photography and synchroflash, the Wabash Photolamp Corporation has just introduced two new, small-size, blue color bulbs, which are suitable for use with all types of cameras, including those with focal-plane shutters.

Scoring early and often until little doubt remained regarding the outcome, the Fordham nine routed Manhattan College by a 10-0 count at Fordham Field yesterday. Big Alex, running his string of consecutive scoreless innings to twenty, blanked the Jaspers with three singles in seven stanzas.

MAXWELL ANDERSON is thinking of expanding the radio play he wrote for the Free Company -- "The Miracle of the Danube" -- into a full-length play for Broadway. This would give him two plays for the coming season, as he has just completed "Candle in the Wind" for the use of Helen Hayes.

A fuchsia which is claimed to be hardy, and a shrub to boot, caused a stir and a bit of an argument in the horticultural world a few years ago. This is fuchsia magellanica, highly recommended by some plant experts, shrugged off by others. Nevertheless, it is dainty, if not spectacular, either as a shrub or as a fuchsia, flowering bravely all Summer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 24 -- Yale defeated Dartmouth with a two-run ninth-inning rally today, 9 to 8, after some of the freakiest baseball witnessed here in years. Wind and dust raised havoc with both teams and blows that ordinarily would have been easy outs became hits.

BRUCKNERITES have cause to cheer this month's record news, and those who have reservations on or downright antipathy for the music of Anton Bruckner have a point of departure for discussion. Victor has done the composer a distinctive service by issuing the Symphony No. 5, in B flat (two volumes totaling nine twelve-inch records, $10 for both).

FOR that multitude of New Yorkers who think that burrowing in the sand and splashing in the surf are the ultimate in fun, Summer arrives well before the Summer solstice. It comes in on Decoration Day, three weeks ahead of time, with the opening of the public beaches, and goes on until Labor Day, when the skins of beachgoers show a tawny glow that only a long Winter can bleach out.

THE Cummington School, Cummington, Mass., will hold master classes Aug. 1-24, devoted to the preparation of a selected chamber music program, culminating a public performance. The special program of music study this Summer will include conferences led by Harold Bauer and David Diamond.

MILLINGTON, N.J., May 24 -- An attendance of nearly 4,000 guests from thirty Northern New Jersey communities is expected at Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys here, from Monday through Wednesday, for the eighth annual Spring benefit bridge series aiding the farm's scholarship fund.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 24 -- The Hungarian army of occupation in the Northern Yugoslav Bachka and Banat districts is conducting a violent campaign to stamp out Serbian resistance and destroy active bands of Serbian guerrilla fighters.

Public activities of the newly organized Mothers Health Organization of the Lower East Side will commence on the night of June 6 at a mass meeting in Cooper Union that will be addressed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. The organization plans to raise the health standards on the Lower East Side by educating mothers in nutrition.

THE long Memorial Day weekend will provide an excellent opportunity for metropolitan motorists to visit the boys in camp. Highway connections with all camps throughout the East are good, Uncle Sam smiles on the idea of visits from the folks back home, and the soldiers themselves certainly are not averse to an opportunity to display their uniforms and their newly acquired tans for the admiration of girl friend, mother, brother or even casual sightseer.

WHETHER some theatrical folk are born great or achieve it, this is the season when greatness is thrust upon them, the season when September's anguished rehearsals are apotheosized, the producer's sweat sanctified.

Defending the principle of released time in public schools for religious education, Father William A. Scully, director of Religious Education, of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday that it is a "figment of a wild imagination" to charge that the program is an opening wedge to public support of parochial schools.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore, new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, urged today that women organize to avoid conscription in wartime.

Every time a British merchant ship is in port, a group of young men may be found in a clubroom down in West Twenty-third Street arguing about the respective merits of being hit by a bomb or a torpedo.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 24 -- Seton Hall scored its twelfth consecutive victory and its second this season over Long Island University when it defeated the Blackbirds at Setonia Field today, 9 -- 4. Half of the Pirates' fourteen hits went for extra bases. Ken Pine did a good job on the mound.

VICHY, France, May 24 (AP) -- The French Government is protesting to London, through the United States State Department, against British seizure of the French tanker Sheherazade while she was crossing the Atlantic with a British navicert, it was stated today.

HOT SPRINGS, N.M. -- This Southern New Mexico resort town, famed for its curative mineral waters, is pushing preparations for one of the Southwest's outstanding speedboat events -- the annual Elephant Butte Regatta on June 7-8.

A COMPETITION for posters for National Defense is announced by the Museum of Modern Art, to close at midnight on June 28. The competition is divided into two sections with a $500 first prize in each: posters for army recruiting purposes and posters to aid in the sale of defense bonds and stamps.

VICHY, France, May 24 -- Lieutenant Jean Montezer was sentenced in absentia to death and eight persons appeared other who in court received long prison terms on charges of plotting to betray Dakar to another Anglo-de Gaullist attack.

THE ancient art of illumination is brilliantly exemplified, in terms of present-day accomplishment, by miniatures placed on view last week at Knoedler's. They were painted by Arthur Szyk, a Polish artist who has thoroughly mastered the technique peculiar to this art form.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 24 -- The future of women in business rests with their learning to approach it in their own way, as opposed to the methods established by men, according to Mrs. Viola C. Billings, executive vice president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hempstead.

THE second volume of Gershon Ephros's Cantorial Anthology, devoted to the chants of the Yom Kippur, companions his first of earlier date, in the distinction of the material and the manifest scholarship, sincerity and taste with which it has been assembled.

MORE than twenty art museums will participate in an exhibition opening at the Boston Museum in June. It is being arranged in recognition of the annual conventions of the American Library Association and the National Education Association, which will meet in Boston during the last two weeks of June and the first week in July.

The question of whether, even without the influence of government action as to price ceilings and increased margin requirements on commodity futures exchanges, the period is close at hand when both the increased buying and rising prices of the last several months may be coming to a halt was actively discussed last week among traders in several of the primary markets for consumer goods materials.

The two hundred and sixteen members of the graduating class at Barnard College will begin their senior week festivities on Thursday with an open house party to the college at 2:30 P.M. The party, which is being held for the first time in two years, will consist of games and dancing on the campus.

Entering its eighteenth year of operation, the Amtorg Trading Corporation, official buying and selling agency here for the Soviet Government, will decide next month whether or not to discontinue operations in the American market, according to those in close touch with Russian trade.

With Mayor La Guardia absent for the first time in eight years, the annual memorial service for the 162 members of the Police Department who have lost their lives in the performance of duty and the eighteen who perished in the World War was held yesterday morning by the Police Honor Legion in the main rotunda of police headquarters.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- The New Jersey Bankers Association called today upon President Roosevelt and the Administration to settle differences between labor capital in an effort to speed the defense program and also effect strict economy in non-defense expenditures.

Not far from the Michigan farm where Henry Ford was born seventy-eight years ago stands the River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company. The world's largest single industrial unit, it covers 1,200 acres of closely integrated steel furnaces, glass factories, foundries, docks, railways, roads, offices and assembly lines.

BERLIN, May 24 (AP) -- The High Command's first communique on the fight for Crete asserted that the Luftwaffe had driven the British fleet from the waters north of the island and established supremacy in the air "over the entire battle area."

THE San Francisco Opera Association, Gaetano Merola, general director, will open its season Oct. 13 in San Francisco and continue performances until Nov. 1. A regular subscription series of ten events and a popular series of four are announced.

Three hundred and forty employes of the United States Customs Service are now taking courses in first aid at the Custom House and at the Appraiser Warehouse, 201 Varick Street, under the instruction of eleven representatives of the American Red Cross, it was learned yesterday.

HERE, in a splendid novel, is an effective explanation of the riddle of the Moscow treason trials. It is the sort of novel that transcends ordinary limitations, and that may be read as a primary discourse in political philosophy.

ALMOST in the lap of the Fulton Fish Market is a century-old hostelry, which dispenses sea food of surpassing succulence to the weary moguls of Wall Street and to sailors and fishermen home from sea. Sufficient explanation for a hundred years of prosperity is the delicate and sweet-meated fish, whisked fresh from the sea to your plate, whence it disappears deliciously in the wink of an eye.

BOSTON -- During all the years they went stravagin' around Provincetown Harbor tearing up the fishermen's weirs they were just "pesky hoss-mackerel," but within less than five years they have become the pride of Massachusetts -- giant bluefin tuna that last season were breaking rod-and-reel records almost faster than the scorekeeper could follow.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The sales record during the last three months has shown the fallacy of the fear that the draft would react seriously on sales of younger men's clothing, M.J. Kestnbaum, president of Hart, Schaffner Marx, said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Priorities are a means of short circuiting the laws of supply and demand, and Congressional sanction was given last week to a far-reaching extension of these preference-rating controls by President Roosevelt and his defense aides.

A CELEBRITY'S brother has a pretty hard row to hoe. The mother or father or even the uncle of a famous figure often can get credit for his relative's success, but the brother, nine times out of ten, will get a quick-brush-off or will be accused of trying to coast on his next-of-kin's coattails.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Tennis, golf and a flower show will fill a varied week at the Homestead. Today and tomorrow an Empire Day tournament for the benefit of the Maple Leaf Fund will be played on the Homestead course. The fund, which furnishes medical aid and relief for the bombed, areas of Britain, has arranged such tournaments for today all over the United States.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- Employes of North American Aviation, Inc., have voted 5,829 to 210 to call a strike Wednesday at the Inglewood plant of the corporation, which is engaged in producing bombers, pursuit planes and training planes for the United States Army.

Beginning in September a complete program of guided but independent research leading to a special honors degree will be introduced for the first time at Hunter College for leading students in the English Department, Professor Hoxie N. Fairchild, chairman of the department's committee on honors, announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- The 42,100-ton British battle cruiser Hood, largest warship in the world, was blown to bits in the waters between Greenland and Iceland today by the new German battleship Bismarck during a battle of grave historic import.

The sixty-fifth annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. will be held at Triborough Stadium on Friday and Saturday with a record entry of forty-one colleges competing. Six teams rank as favorites for the all-important team title -- Pitt, the defender; Penn State, the runner-up; Fordham, the indoor ruler; N.Y.U., the metropolitan champion; Penn, the Heptagonal leader, and Rhode Island State, the New England champion.

SEVERAL months ago, in the course of one of his pep talks to keep the English people alert to the danger of invasion, Prime Minister Winston Churchill warned that Germany might use gliders to land troops in Great Britain.

It was gratifying to have Henry Steele Commager focus critical attention on my proposed solution of our constitutional troubles in his review of my book "Our Constitution: Tool or Testament?" (March 30, 1941.) My solution was offered not dogmatically or in detail but as a bare hypothesis for analysis and discussion.
A GROUP of paintings by fifteen contemporary American artists has been placed on view at the Milch. It will continue to be shown until the end of next month.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 24 -- More than 450 seniors in all departments of Princeton University wrote the final words on their required senior theses this week, to bring to a close a year-long period of research on a wide variety of topics, ranging from the works of Michelangelo to an investigation of bacteria which live in gasoline.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Princeton came through with a spectacular seven-run rally in the thirteenth inning today to defeat Pennsylvania, 14 -- 7, and improve its Eastern Intercollegiate League title chances. It was the sixth triumph in nine league starts for the Tigers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 24 -- After having spent less than two full days in Berlin, Major Vidkun Quisling returned today to Oslo and all Norway is anxiously awaiting the result of the trip he undertook on the advice of Heinrich Himmler, chief of the German State Police.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Twelve of John Powers's models are coming here to help to inaugurate the 1941 Summer season. The girls will travel on two fast sea-going cruisers from New York City down the coast to the resort, arriving Thursday evening.

VIGO, Spain, May 24 -- All but two of the 140 Americans who sailed on the Egyptian steamship Zamzam from New York are uninjured and, in the words of the communique issued tonight by the American Embassy in Madrid, "well lodged, well fed and well attended."

A number of men who have admittedly taken up woodchuck shooting for the first time have written us to complain of the lack of 'chucks in areas where these animals were reported to be plentiful. Several of them explained that they had spent hours driving along old country roads, scanning every field with binoculars, but had not sighted a single 'chuck.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 24 -- Showing in his top form, alert to every sight and sound, that vivacious and impressive smooth-coated foxterrier, Champion Desert Deputy, today took his fourth best-in-show title, capturing the highest honors in a great field of finalists in the thirty-eighth all-breed show of the Ladies' Kennel Association of America.

The mystery of a foreign tongue will not be the only one confronting students who will study from "Noche Oscura en Lima" (Dark Night in Lima), a new Spanish textbook written by Professor Joseph Barlow, chairman of the Spanish Department at New York University, and Rudolph Kagey, assistant professor of philosophy, and just published by F.S. Crofts Co.

HAVANA -- Experienced gourmets who love to experiment with exotic dishes will find Cuban restaurants a happy hunting ground. The most common dish of the island is "arroz con pollo," fried chicken and cooked rice mixed together and spiced with yellow saffron, green peas and Spanish red peppers.

The battle between the British battle cruiser Hood and the German battleship Bismarck brought together as adversaries one of the most spectacular of German naval figures of the present war and a British gunnery specialist credited with having invented improvements of importance to anti-aircraft fire control.

ON ACTIVE SERVICE: Navy regulations provide that officers reaching the age of 64 shall automatically be retired. Last week an exception was made. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced that Admiral Thomas C. Hart, commander of the Asiatic Fleet, would continue indefinitely at his post despite the fact that he was within a few weeks of the retirement age.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- Wilson Dee Miles's third straight hit as a pinch batsman gave the surprising Athletics their sixth victory in seven games as they swept a double-header with Washington today, 13 to 5 and 6 to 5.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Six young leaders of city, State and national Christian Youth movements addressed an open letter to President Roosevelt today, urging that in his Tuesday fireside chat he allay the fears of Americans by announcing that the United States will not enter the war.

Developments in the oil industry moved last week with unusual rapidity. Prices of crude oil throughout the country were advanced on the average about 10 cents a barrel. On Friday, leading oil executives of the country were called to Washington to discuss prices of gasoline with the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

The New York State Bankers Association will begin its forty-eighth annual convention today in Buffalo in the Hotel Statler, a meeting which will continue through Tuesday. Due to the importance of the many banking problems to be discussed, particularly those relating to financing the defense industry, it is expected that the attendance will be one of the largest in recent years.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 24 -- Charles Whitehead, the New Jersey amateur champion, today was the only guest remaining to compete for top honors in the Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament at the Garden City Golf Club.
LONDON, May 24 -- This week ends with the British confused, worried and speculative.

RIDING horseback along high trails in the wilderness country is not the sort of vacation the average person could casually plan by himself. It would take too much organizing. But with the assistance of the Trail Riders of the Wilderness such a vacation becomes a practical way to spend leisurely Summer days moving through pine forests on high mountain slopes.

BOSTON, May 24 -- Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Air Brigade, acquired via the claiming route in Florida last Winter, rushed through the slop to beat Miss Carrie Hardin's Johnnie J. by a half length today in the $5,000 added Governor's Handicap at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 25,000.

WHEN reading the lectures and literary criticisms of Matthew Arnold one is always conscious that one is listening to a profound scholar; a sincere, straightforward teacher who never startles one by an overestimated glow of his powers or by any disregard for the intellect of his readers.

Five aircraft companies that received defense contracts week before last now hold government contracts equal to 1033 per cent of their 1939 sales, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Defense awards received to date by these five concerns -- Beech Aircraft, Curtiss-Wright (including Wright Aeronautical), Fairchild Engine and Airplane, Ryan Aeronautical and Vultee Aircraft -- amounted to $551,503,000, including $68,410,000 announced last week, compared with 1939 sales of $53,281,000.

Union truck drivers posted pickets outside a dozen midtown theatres yesterday to enforce a demand that members of their organization be hired to carry musicians' instruments. The picketing was an outgrowth of a controversy between Local 817 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, both A.F. of L. affiliates.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Joe Louis hit Buddy Baer at the bell -- and not afterward.

ANOVEL laid in London and Paris during the period of Napoleon's rise and fall need not be exciting and filled with adventure. This one is as quiet and idyllic, pastoral in feeling despite its urban setting, as if the fortunes of the Corsican and the Bourbons had not controlled the fate of its serene heroine.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- An invention developed at the University of Minnesota may free this country from its dependency on foreign purchases for its supply of tung oil, the most powerful drying oil known. Tung oil, although more expensive, is widely used as a substitute in paints, varnishes and lacquers for linseed oil because it dries faster and gives a more resistant and glossier finish.

THESE are the days of gardens gloriously abloom. With a movie camera, color film, care, thought and a few inexpensive accessories, a garden in all its loveliness, with all its little inhabitants -- grasshoppers, caterpillars, bees, beetles, butterflies -- can be preserved forever, the only loss being the fragrance.

IT is philatelic history that the creation of new governments results in new postal paper. This suggests that three political developments which were prominent in last week's news will soon have philatelic repercussions. These have to do with Croatia and Dalmatia, carved out of conquered Yugoslavia; and Iceland, which canceled its union with the Danish crown and resolved to adopt a republican constitution.

In the belief that this country's future welfare, peace and security are closely allied with that of our South American neighbors, New York City school leaders have embarked upon an intensive campaign to make the 1,000,000 children and 40,000 teachers in the system pan-American conscious.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 24 -- The major force of two Italian divisions in the Lakes region of Southwestern Ethiopia has now been completely surrounded by British Imperial troops, according to official reports here today. Soddu, an important road junction north of Lake Abaya and about 110 miles south of Addis Ababa, is in British hands.

Dr. Kurth Rieth, German diplomatic agent, denied yesterday that he was in the United States on an official mission of "economic appeasement,'' saying that he was here only on "a purely personal financial mission."

An entertainment reminiscent of the huge charity carnivals given here years ago will take place in Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, when the Bandwagon Ball will be given under the sponsorship of the Committee of Mercy and the Greek War Relief Association.

The annual report of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation, issued yesterday by Sidney W. Winslow Jr., chairman of the board, shows a net income for the year to Feb. 28 of $8,204,130, after taxes. This amount, after a deduction of preferred dividends paid, is equivalent to $3.40 a share on the common stock, based on the average number of shares outstanding during the year.

Manhattan's track and field team closed its dual-meet season yesterday afternoon at the Van Cortlandt Park Stadium with a 90-45 victory over Temple. The Jaspers' first triumph in three meets was featured by three firsts for Johnny Quigley, sophomore sprinter, and double decisions for Co-captain Tom Garland, hurdler, and George Mathews, weight thrower.

On the Skyline Roof of the Hotel Gramercy Park a garden fete and cocktail party will be given on Wednesday afternoon in aid of the Lord Mayor of Manchester Fund. The beneficiary functions under the auspices of the Committee of Mercy in giving assistance to victims of air attacks in England.

A NOVEL accomplishment of radio engineering is represented in the two-way communication system just completed for the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the 161-mile high-speed toll highway which links Harrisburg with Pittsburgh.

THE Summer exhibition of work by members of the National Association of Women Artists has opened at the Argent Galleries and will be current through June 27. Among the hundred examples of oils, water-colors, prints and small sculptures are a number of excellent things.

To bring order out of chaos the National Board of Fire Underwriters was formed in 1866. Today, when the board celebrates the seventy-fifth year of its existence, it no longer seeks to control what was once a wildcat business, but restricts itself to checking fire hazards. It maintains records; collects statistics and interprets them; concerns itself with legislation; combats arson; disseminates information on the causes of fires; frames building codes; tests materials and structures.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 24 -- The lowest tax rate since 1930 for the town of Fairfield was announced today by the Board of Finance for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The reduction in rate is a result of a $2,500,000 increase in the town's grand list and a material decrease in the cost of relief.

Although a final report is still some distance in the future, fundamental work of the special New York Stock Exchange's committee on reorganization is practically done. Broad policies have been decided. The board of governors be reduced in size, although perhaps not to the sixteen members suggested by the former president, William McC. Martin Jr. All save two standing committees -- arbitration and admissions -- probably will be eliminated.

The Americans, a group of nautically minded boys from East Harlem, coached by a former rear admiral in the Imperial Russian Navy, outsailed all competition yesterday in the Park Department's annual model sailboat regatta in the Conservatory Lake of Central Park, near Fifth Avenue and Seventy-second Street.

The theory that "religion may have converted Rudolph Hess away from the program of violence to the policies of peace and brotherhood" was advanced by Rabbi Louis I. Newman in a sermon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

The high rate of earnings attained by the steel industry in the first quarter of 1941, virtually duplicating the return shown in the final quarter of 1940, will not be attained again during the national defense emergency. This is a conclusion from a study of cost-price factors in effect now.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Pennsylvania closed its rowing season today by defeating a crew from the U.S.S. Prairie State in a special eight-oared race on the windswept Schuylkill before 3,000 chilled spectators.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Leaders of the Office of Production Management, key agency of the country's accelerated defense program, which will be one year old next Wednesday, reported today that they were not satisfied with defense progress to date but that "production should increase with every month from now on."

In any period of extraordinary demand for the products of labor and material, heavy taxation plays a twofold beneficial role. It yields large revenues to the government and it tends to prevent inflation. Both of these effects are necessary and desirable.

WE have yet to find any comment that sums up our sentiments about strawberries as well as what Dr. William Butler, an English physician, wrote over 300 years ago. "Doubtless God could have made a better berry," the doctor said.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- A balmy Spring, plans for sesqui-centennial celebrations and the fact that Memorial Day falls on a Friday this year, offering the opportunity for a long week-end, has decided a number of resort proprietors in the Green Mountain area to open for business earlier than usual.

IN several respects the late George Grey Barnard was a very remarkable man. The work he himself produced as a sculptor might reasonably be supposed to represent a full-time job. Yet in addition to creating art, Mr. Barnard collected, on a very large scale.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The National Defense Mediation Board won today deferment for at least a few more days the threat of another soft coal stoppage which might have disastrous effects on the national defense program, but reported that Southern operators and the United Mine Workers of America, C.I.O., were still deadlocked on elimination of a forty-cent daily wage differential.

Three power boat races at long distances, one of them new but likely to become a popular annual fixture, were announced last week. This means that over many a living room floor or bridge cabin today yachtsmen will be unfolding their government charts, laying courses and studying their tide and current tables.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) -- Two world records went by the boards today as a hand-picked array of the nation's finest track and field athletes displayed their wares in the inaugural Los Angeles Coliseum Relays before a roaring throng of 25,000.

To enable union van drivers to take part in patriotic exercises and parades, no moving will be done in Brooklyn on Memorial Day. Plans for the one-day stoppage have been approved by Local 814 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L.; the Affiliated Moving Van Owners and the American Institute of Warehousing.

The fear that work on building one of the largest spectroscopes in the world, which has been in progress at Townsend Harris High School for twenty years, would have to be curtailed because of the proposed abolition of the school, was voiced yesterday by Dr. Reinhard A. Wetzel, chairman of the Department of Physics.

BUENOS AIRES, May 24 -- It is understood the basis for an understanding has been reached between the Argentine Government and the Italian Government and shipowners for the purchase of Italian merchantmen that are idle in Argentine ports.

A former newspaper correspondent in the Balkans and Central Europe, R.H. Markham, has written a little book which ought to be read by every confused American. Mr. Markham calls his book The Wave of the Past. The gist of its well-stated argument is that the thing that has happened to Europe is not new.

THE Battle of the Books, won last August by a combined force of publishers, booksellers, authors and readers, turns out to have been no more than a single engagement in what may be a protracted campaign. That victory was worth a great deal, but it was not final and decisive.

Three power boat races at long distances, one of them new but likely to become a popular annual fixture, were announced last week. This means that over many a living room floor or bridge cabin today yachtsmen will be unfolding their government charts, laying courses and studying their tide and current tables.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) -- Two world records went by the boards today as a hand-picked array of the nation's finest track and field athletes displayed their wares in the inaugural Los Angeles Coliseum Relays before a roaring throng of 25,000.

To enable union van drivers to take part in patriotic exercises and parades, no moving will be done in Brooklyn on Memorial Day. Plans for the one-day stoppage have been approved by Local 814 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L.; the Affiliated Moving Van Owners and the American Institute of Warehousing.

Wetzel, chairman of the Department of Physics.

Mr. Markham calls his book The Wave of the Past. The gist of its well-stated argument is that the thing that has happened to Europe is not new.

BRAVING insects, sand and heat, a crew of 275 actors and technicians have worked three weeks in the heart of Florida's "big scrub," making technicolor scenes for Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings's Pulitzer Prize winning novel.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Bill Tilden, Karel Kozeluh, Fred Perry and Lester Stoefen, all veterans of international competition, advanced easily today to the second round of the national professional tennis tournament.

THERE hasn't been a lot of talk lately about the part which the film industry is to play in our bustling national defense program -- not as much talk as there was last Winter, anyhow -- so one might reasonably question whether the part as originally projected has been cut.

For nearly two years this country has been debating what we ought to do about the World War. So far the isolationists have lost every round. We began, in September, 1939, with an embargo on the export of munitions. In November, 1939, we repealed the embargo in favor of the cash-and-carry plan.
A home run by Hal Firkser with the bases loaded in the fifth inning gave Brooklyn College a 9-6 victory over Queens College yesterday on the Kingsmen's diamond.

IT is readily understandable why E.M. Delafield has elected to return to her chosen field of the psychological analysis of human character in her latest novel. The Provincial Lady could and did serve her talent and her country's need of the moment by a wartime journal that refused to yield an iota to totalitarian solemnity.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Of the fifty men and women who gathered in the parlor of Clara Barton on May 21, 1881, sixty years ago this week, to found the American Red Cross, only one still lives.

The thirteen blighted areas in Manhattan designated by the City Planning Commission for reclamation constitute a burden on all taxpayers in the city and are "ripe" for redevelopment, according to the results of an economic study of the sections announced yesterday by the Citizens Housing Council.

The House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures has split on the question of extending the life of the $2,000,000,000 Exchange Stabilization Fund and the President's power to devalue the dollar. A majority of the committee has tendered a report calling for the extension of both powers unimpaired for another two years from next June 30, when the present authority expires.
Those who have watched Germany closely since Versailles have noted a significant sequence of events:

A description of the difficulties that have beset France in recent months was given yesterday by Mme. Elsa Schiaparelli, famous clothes designer, and a Franch Senator, when they arrived with forty other passengers on the Dixie Clipper, coming from Lisbon.

LONDON, May 25 -- The British Board of Trade's index for commodity prices in April, based on the 1930 level as 100, was 150.9, compared with 150.8 in March and 132.2 in April, 1940. In August, 1939, just before the war, the index was 98.1.

VICHY, France, May 25 -- Although the Cabinet held no formal meeting last week there is reason to believe that the Ministers concerned discussed the wage problem and that the principle of increases has been accepted. Some sources have it today that there will be an early announcement to this effect.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- No official comment on Grand Admiral Erich Raeder's threat was forthcoming in Washington tonight. When its text has been received from diplomatic sources President Roosevelt will probably consult Secretary of State Cordell Hull about it, it is learned.

Condemning "extreme pacifism" opposed to all wars regardless of the issues that may be involved, the Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft declared yesterday in his sermon in All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, that this type of pacifism was not Christian but anti-Christian.

The United States Army has arranged to buy the old passenger liner Siboney after the liner docks here this morning, and will assign her to transport duty along with other merchant vessels acquired since the war began.

The Slick-Shine Company, manufacturers of polishing fluids in Newark, N.J., since 1901, bought from the estate of George J. Crosman the industrial plant at 207-15 Astor Street, Newark, consisting of a plot 125 by 100 feet with a three-story brick building, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, boiler house and a warehouse on a lot 25 by 100 feet.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- The Athletics knocked Dutch Leonard out of the box with a five-run rally in the eighth inning today and scored a 7-to-3 victory for a sweep of the three-game series with the Senators.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Senator Norris proposed today that the United States transfer immediately a substantial number of war vessels to the British or Canadian Navies for use in the North Atlantic convoy service.

LONDON, Monday, May 26 (AP) -- British bombers attacking German shipping off the Netherland coast Saturday sank a vessel of about 2,500 tons and set another afire, leaving it listing to port, the Air Ministry reported. A third vessel was declared hit and probably sunk and still other Nazi craft were bombed and machine-gunned.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Price fluctuations in the wheat market last week were unusually violent, and while there was an upturn to a new seasonal high level early, the market receded sharply later as the result of stop-loss selling induced by general weakness in other commodities.
Memorial services for the men who have fallen in defense of this country since its birth were held yesterday in several places in and near the city.

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- A strike against the Packard Motor Car Company was threatened today to enforce a demand of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers for a pay raise of 10 cents an hour. Present wage rates were not disclosed.

CEDARHURST, L.I., May 25 -Champion Foxcatcher Merrymaker, owned by the Liseter Beagles of Mrs. J. Austin duPont of Newtown Square, Pa., was crowned best of nearly 700 dogs in the fortieth annual show of the Long Island Kennel Club today.

Official Argentine foreign trade returns for the four months ended with April, according to the Argentine Information Bureau here, show that imports for that period, computed in real values, amounted to 312,447,650 pesos, against 583,051,201 pesos in the same period last year.

Any national defense program will fail to reach its objective unless supported by a vigorous offensive that will arouse the public conscience, Dr. Nathan B. Van Etten, president of the American Medical Association, declared in an address last night to the American Jewish Physicians Committee, which commemorated its twentieth anniversary with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, May 25 -- Queen Mother Mary comes to her seventy-fourth birthday tomorrow with heart saddened by war and older wounds, but with the certainty she is more than ever firmly enthroned in the affections of her people.

AMSTERDAM, May 25 -- The small Continental European markets last week again displayed rather marked stagnancy of trade, for which expectation of measures curtailing speculation and restricting dividends was partly responsible, while generally the public is hesitating to enter fresh commitments, preferring to entertain considerable liquidity, and speculators have withdrawn almost entirely from the market.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 (UP) -- Units of the British Navy, pushing up the Tigris River from the Persian Gulf, aided British Imperial troops in wiping out Iraqi forces entrenched about six miles north of British-held Basra, a communique said tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Because of the possible imminence of a national emergency and the hundreds of thousands of men in the training camps for whom they transmit messages free of charge, the 2,400 "Hams" of the Army Amateur Radio System will stay by their instruments this Summer for the first time in fifteen years instead of recessing their activities until September.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Violent price fluctuations featured trading in soy bean futures last week on the Board of Trade, prices dropping the permissible limit of 8 cents a bushel on Thursday, when a wave of liquidation swept the market and disclosed a lack of support.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States chess champion, recorded his third victory over Israel A. Horowitz yesterday morning in the eleventh game of their series for the title. Eight of the meetings have been drawn.

Activity on mid-season and current Summer styles was brisk in the wholesale market during the past week. Reorders for Summer goods were heavy and deliveries slow. Warm weather brought further demands on an already over-worked cotton dress market.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The highest prices for lard since 1937 were reached last week on the Board of Trade here. There was a good class of buying at times, but the upturn was retained only partly as general selling came into the market on Thursday and carried prices off around 50 cents a hundredweight from the top.

HANOI, French Indo-China, May 25 -- Japanese Soldiers broke down the doors of two Haiphong warehouses today and removed $10,000,000 worth of United States products belonging to two American companies. The goods had been blocked from reaching the Central Chinese Government.

OTTAWA, May 25 (UP) -- Well-informed political sources in the capital tonight predicted the immediate resignation of James G. Gardiner as Minister of War Services and said an announcement of his resignation was withheld only at the last moment on May 22.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Formation of a giant power pool bringing together the generating facilities of more than a third of the States in an effort to assure a continuous power supply for defense industries in the Southeast, where an unprecedented drought occurring simultaneously with rapidly rising defense power needs has created a grave emergency, was announced today by the Federal Power Commission.

An investor bought from the Lafayette National Bank the four-story loft building at 10-27 Forty-sixth Avenue, running through the block to 10-28 Forty-fifth Road, Long Island City. The building, on a plot 80 by 200 feet, is fully occupied and was sold through Frank R. Fischer, broker.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 91.7 to 92.4. Outstanding among the week's price changes was the 3.0 per cent gain in the fuel and lighting group, where petroleum took a jump in price and gasoline rose 1/2 cent for the third successive week.

Day by day devotion to the kind of religion expressed by the Christian Gospel and the will of God is the way of overcoming the new "religion" engendered by totalitarian philosophies, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

In a fervent plea for the restoration of liberty and peace throughout the world, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver, pastor of the John Street Methodist Church at 44 John Street, declared yesterday in his sermon that he favored unequivocally the use of American convoys to aid Great Britain and "limited participation" in the present war.

In his final annual report as president of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church, William Fellowes Morgan Sr. said yesterday that low interest earnings were the most serious problem confronting the trustees.
Evil may seemingly win every battle but God will win the war, declared the Rev. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Dr. Philipp G. Frank, who succeeded Albert Einstein as Professor of Theoretical Physics at the University of Prague, has been appointed Visiting Professor of Philosophy at City College for the Fall semester, Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of the college, announced yesterday.
Organizations opposing American involvement in the European war addressed further appeals to President Roosevelt yesterday.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 25 -- With its usual dress of flags flying from the tops of the stands along Jericho Turnpike, Bostwick Field staged the opening of another polo season today with Pete Bostwick, the popular host, putting together a team than won easily from a Westbury side, 13 to 7.

The report of the Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiary companies for the fiscal year ended on March 31 shows a net income after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, of $2,981,049. The report was released for publication today by John D. Reilly, president.

TOKYO, May 25 -- A warning that a United States convoy system or any United States naval aid to Great Britain would constitute "a plain act of war" to which the German Navy would reply has been voiced by Grand Admiral Erich Raeder, Commander in Chief of the German Navy, in an exclusive interview with the Domei [Japanese news agency] correspondent in Berlin.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, May 25 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- One of the world's fastest motorships, the Dutch Line vessel Oranje, soon will be a luxurious floating hospital succoring the Allied war forces in the Middle East.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 25 -- American bombing and fighting planes have been flown into Iraq by the Royal Air Force and are being used to harass Premier Rashid Ali Beg Gailani's forces as the British slowly push the zone of operations east of the Euphrates River despite the inconvenient floods.

A nation-wide underwriting syndicate of 152 investment firms, headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Dillon, Read Co., will offer today to the public 228,480 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 1,568,000 shares of common stock of the American Viscose Corporation.

Christian principles of morality and brotherly love constitute a bulwark protecting humanity and democracy from world-wide totalitarian victory, James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, declared yesterday morning.

NEWARK, N.J., Monday, May 26 -- For fifteen minutes this morning the things that civilized men live by -- the sparkling, familiar lights of the main street of town, of the theatres and friendly restaurants and taverns, the lamp in the window at home -- went out in Newark.

LONDON, May 25 -- It is quite evident that it is the government's intention to keep the Nazis guessing concerning what may, or may not, have been disclosed by Rudolf Hess, but this attitude also keeps the British public guessing.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 25 -- Hunters owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of Scarsdale shared the spotlight with the veteran jumper Socks, belonging to Mrs. Oscar Ehrhorn of Orangeburg, in the ninth annual Rockwood Hall Horse Show today at Fox Hill Farms.

BELFAST, May 25 -- Amid the boiling wrath of many thousands of those who oppose conscription in Northern Ireland, while at the same time favoring a British victory in the war, Prime Minister James M. Andrews arrived here late today with a noncommittal view regarding his recent conversations with Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

Five stained-glass windows depicting the story of the Old Testament in 123 scenes were dedicated yesterday in the tower of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street. The Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the church, officiated at the ceremonies and delivered the sermon at morning services.

Cotton prices continued to advance into new high ground last week. The movement was somewhat irregular in the first half of the week, but it was definitely upward in the later dealings. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices at the close of trading on Saturday reflected net advances of 18 to 28 points for the week.

In contemplating the purchase of space in shopping papers, some national advertisers have recently begun to take into account two considerations which previously had little influence. One is the need for maintenance of a free press and the other is the character of the ownership of some shopping publications.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 -- That the policy of absolute neutrality followed hitherto by the Swedish Government must and will continue was stated today by King Gustaf when he spoke at Norrkoeping during the celebration of Children's Day.

THE boxing commissioners of the District of Columbia will gather in executive session this morning to hear Ancil Hoffman, manager of Buddy Baer, demand that they declare his Buddy the heavyweight champion of the world. The esteemed boxing commissioners are in for some fervid oratory. He's an eloquent chap, that Ancil. Not loud, but fluent.

Representative William P. Lambertson of Kansas has intervened in the forthcoming election of the Actors Equity Association to urge defeat of Alan Hewitt, incumbent councilor, who seeks re-election on an independent ticket, it was revealed last night.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Deferred deliveries of corn sold last week on the Board of Trade here at the highest levels since 1937 and, while the market dipped in sympathy with other commodities at one time, closing trades yesterday showed gains of 1 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel for the week, with the July position at 73 7/8 cents, September at 75 1/4 and December at 74 5/8.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 25 (AP) -- Ten thousand Arabs rioted and looted in Basra yesterday, a telegram to the Turkish Agricultural Bank said today, amid reports that the pro-Axis government of Iraq was breaking up. The telegram said the disturbances endangered $2,000,000 worth of American farm machinery purchased for Turkish cooperatives, which was on the Basra docks.
ROME, May 25 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The total present program for national defense expenditures exceeds $41,000,000,000, or about $310 for every man, woman and child in the United States, the Office of Production Management estimated today.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Top-flight contenders for the national professional tennis championship enjoyed another field day today, Vincent Richards, Joe Whalen, Dick Skeen and Keith Gledhill gaining easy first-round victories.

Both at home and abroad, financial markets seemed last week to rest at slack water. Business on one five-hour day was smallest since last August. This was not because things were not happening; on the contrary, new turns in the war have followed one another so rapidly that what was challenging every one's attention a week ago has today given place to something in an altogether different field.

Referring to the recent attacks on the religious released time law, Mgr. James H. Griffiths, vice chancellor of the Diocese of Brooklyn, said yesterday morning at a communion breakfast in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, that "it was amusing but alarming to hear the law called clerical fascism, to read of persons highly placed in the councils of education declaring that the law does not 'represent the will of the public.'"

BIARRITZ, France, via Paris, May 24 (Delayed) (UP) -- Blacked out, her radio silent, the Egyptian liner Zamzam was plowing through the South Atlantic in the gray dawn of April 17 when two shells arched from a German sea raider and sent up geysers near the Zamzam.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 (UP) -- The British and Greek defenders of Crete tonight were described officially as putting up a grim struggle, particularly at Candia and RethymI , contu- r v I

VICHY, France, May 25 (AP) -- General Maxime Weygand, Generalissimo of France in the days of her defeat and now Commander of all Vichy forces in North Africa, has thrown the weight of his approval behind the Petain government's plan for collaboration with Germany, it was declared today.

BERLIN, May 25 (UP) -- One of Britain's new 35,000-ton battleships of the King George V class was damaged in yesterday's sea battle off Iceland in which the British battle cruiser Hood was sunk, it was stated officially today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- In all manufacturing operations, whether these involve baby buggies or bombers, there is one essential requirement for mass production. That is machine tools.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 25 -- Bolivia will be "the focus of the fourth Nazi Putsch in America" unless the government acts energetically, last evening's Ultima Hora warned in a sensational editorial that aroused widespread comment.

A month ago Pete Reiser was skulled by a pitch thrown by Ike Pearson of the Phillies and wound up in the hospital, his career in jeopardy, his life in danger. Fortunately, Pete came out of it, apparently none the worse for his experience.
VICHY, France, May 25 -- Free bread was distributed throughout the unoccupied zone of France today as a gift of the United States Government.

There is reason to doubt whether the return of the Emir Abdul Illah, deposed Regent of Iraq, will be of effective advantage to the British in their conflict there. The royal family in Iraq has never enjoyed great popularity among the native population.

Representatives of the railroad brotherhoods and officials of the New York Central and New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads will meet in the Hotel Commodore tomorrow afternoon to arrange a program for solicitation of the 14,000 union employes of the two railroads on behalf of the current Greater New York Fund drive, it was announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 25 -- The finding of $2,500 in gold certificates in a garage on the abandoned property of the late Lieut. Col. Bennett Tobey on Highland Road in Glen Cove has prompted George Mulry to start a search for more of the yellowbacks.

We have only the official Italian version of what happened when King Victor Emmanuel narrowly escaped a terrorist's bullets at Tirana. We do not yet know as a certainty whether the attack was directed against Italy's King or, as Rome implies, against the Albanian Premier, Shevket Verlaci, the other occupant of the royal automobile.

BERLIN, May 25 -- The extent to which German bankers are following in the footsteps of the German armies in their drive for the financial infiltration of occupied territories is shown in the tabulation of German bank participations in European countries, compiled and published by the leading Berlin banking magazine, Bank Archiv.

Once the Nazis have won in Europe they will have won the world, Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, declared in an address at the annual meeting yesterday of the National Refugee Service in the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

PARIS, May 24 (Delayed; via Vichy) -- Pierre Laval, swarthy son of the Auvergne soil, stood today on a balcony overlooking the Champs Elysees down which a column of German infantry marched behind a blaring military band.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 25 -- Sixty-one enlisted men and one Fort Dix officer were confirmed in picturesque Catholic ceremonies conducted this afternoon on the Forty-fourth Division parade grounds by Bishop John F. O'Hara of New York City, Military Delegate of the Armed Forces of the United States.

ROME, May 25 -- This morning's newspapers printed the first German communique on Crete and gave accounts of the fighting. At 1 o'clock this afternoon came the Italian war bulletin, announcing that Italian naval and air forces were taking part in the attack and that a destroyer and a torpedo boat had been lost.

VICHY, May 25 -- In financial circles as well as on opinion in general a painful impression has been made by the reproaches addressed to France by a friendly nation on the subject of French negotiations in progress for economic collaboration with Germany.

CHUNGKING, China, May 25 -- Many divisions of Chinese troops have broken out of a Japanese encirclement in the Chungtiao Mountains in South Shansi Province and now are counter-attacking the Japanese from new positions in Southwest and Southeast Shansi.

LONDON, May 25 -- King George of Greece, who narrowly escaped falling into the hands of German parachute troops in Crete when the attack was opened Tuesday, left the island with his government advisers for Egypt Friday, it was announced in Cairo today.

News from the Vatican that the Nazi Government has decreed the suppression of all Catholic publications in the Reich can only arouse a new wave of resentment the world over. Suppression of individual Catholic journals has hitherto been justified by the excuse that they were acting politically, but this order applies to the whole press.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- West Coast deck officers of the merchant marine gave their voluntary pledge to President Roosevelt today to sail American ships and carry aid for democracies to any port in the world the government directed.

BERLIN, May 25 (UP) -- Fleet Admiral Guenther Luetjens, commander of the new German battleship Bismarck and hero of the sinking of the British battle cruiser Hood, today observed his fifty-second birthday "at sea" while all Germany hailed his feat.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week failed todevelop any significance either in the way of turnover or price changes and for a parallel matched the sluggish trading sessiors of preceding weeks

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Less than one-half of 1 per cent of all the food shipped into German-occupied Poland for relief by the Polish American Council's Commission for Relief has been lost, according to a formal report made to the council at the annual meeting here Saturday.

Walk down Wall Street to a place where the roadway seems to narrow and dip suddenly, and a mingled aroma of warm tar, salt air and freshly roasting coffee eddies about. Turn to the left on Pearl Street, and presently you will come to the doorway of a gayly-decked shop that traffics in tropical delicacies from distant lands.

MADRID, May 25 -- All arrangements for the evacuation of American survivors of the Zamzam have been completed, with the exception of visas for their passage through Portugal en route to New York, United States Embassy officials here said tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Public interest in the national emergency and in the defense program has resulted in setting new records for incoming mails and telegrams to Washington.

Fire Commissioner Patrick J. Walsh urged a need for harmony in the Fire Department in brief remarks he made as guest of honor at the annual communion breakfast of the Brooklyn and Queens branch of the New York Fire Department Holy Name Society yesterday morning. Two thousand three hundred firemen attended at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Trading in oats last week was relatively light on the Board of Trade. Scattered liquidation in May contracts devel oped on Thursday, the final day for trading in that future, which went off the board at about the same price as the July.

The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies made public yesterday the text of an open letter to President Roosevelt, signed by 2,000 Americans and pledging support for leadership in "strong action" to hasten defeat of the aggressors. Timed to reach the President in advance of his radio address tomorrow night, the letter said:
BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -- Roy Johnson's homer in the final inning of the nightcap gave the Orioles a 5-4 victory over the Newark Bears today after Newark had taken the opener, 9 to 1.

HAVANA, May 25 -- A proposal for the establishment of obligatory military service in Cuba was approved early this morning by the Committee on Military Affairs of the House of Representatives. The project will be submitted to the lower chamber in the near future.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 25 -- Another fine breeze, not up to yesterday's blow but with enough strength in it to make fast going, greeted forty-two starters today in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club regatta. This time it came from the northwest and averaged fifteen miles an hour, making a second day of sailing in contrast to the many calm spots last Summer.

Pleas for support of the Administration's foreign policy and for American aid to China's 40,000,000 war refugees were voiced by Wendell L. Willkie and Governor Lehman yesterday afternoon in Columbus Circle as China Week ended with a colorful parade sponsored by the United China Relief.

The battle of Crete, the intensification of the struggle for Iraq and Syria, indications of a new drive in North Africa and the surrender of the Duke of Aosta in East Africa last week presaged a quick crisis in the campaign for the Eastern Mediterranean, a crisis that may to all intents and purposes decide that campaign within the course of the next three to six weeks.

Eva Le Gallienne, who for six years operated the Civic Repertory Theatre, has been engaged by the Theatre Guild to serve as general director of its series of revivals next Fall, it was announced yesterday by Theresa Helburn and Lawrence Langner, Guild administrators.

JERSEY CITY, May 25 (AP) -- Jersey City solidified its hold on fifth place and pushed Syracuse deeper into sixth today by taking both ends of a double-header for a clean sweep of a three-game series. The scores were 4 to 0 and 7 to 0. The double defeat stretched the Chiefs' losing streak to six straight.

The drastic increases in Federal tax rates proposed by the Treasury Department have confronted the American people with the first definite indication of the scope of the sacrifices that must be made in meeting the cost of national defense, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, published today.
PITTSBURGH, May 25 (AP) -- Billy Conn steps on the spot here tomorrow night when he battles Buddy Knox of Dayton, Ohio, for fifteen rounds or less.

Only one film was scheduled definitely as of yesterday to arrive this week on Broadway. The lone entry is "Power Dive," a Paramount aviation melodrama with Richard Arlen, Jean Parker, Roger Pryor and Helen Mack, which Loew's Criterion will show on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Loans made by national banks in the United States reached a ten-year high in April of this year and were 14 per cent higher than a year before, it was announced today by Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 25 -- With "national defense" the keynote, what promises to be one of the greatest annual conventions in the long history of the New York State Bankers Association began here today with registration and committee meetings preliminary to the business sessions to be held tomorrow and on Tuesday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 25 (UP) -- The Court of Appeals decreed today that Deputy Jorge Gonzalez von Marees, leader of the Popular Socialist Vanguard [former Chilean Nazi party], be released from a Santiago insane asylum, where he was taken for observation yesterday after exchanging pistol shots with the police when they sought to arrest him at his suburban home.

The rumble of battle around Feluja and the iron bridge that spans the Euphrates on the desert road to Baghdad, only forty miles away, emphasizes the close approach of the British to the capital of Iraq. Plainly they mean to take it if they can; but this may not be as easy as it looks on the map.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 25 -- Despite a last minute rally on the part of Johnny Riddell, Charles Whitehead, the New Jersey amateur champion, won the Walter J. Travis Memorial tourney final at the Garden City Golf Club today, 1 up.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The Supreme Court will meet tomorrow to hand down decisions which may include some of the most important of the 1940-41 term. The court will adjourn for the Summer after a brief session on June 2.
BERLIN, May 25 (AP) -- Today's communique of the German High Command follows:
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Charley Root, the Cubs' 42-year-old right-hander, won a 3-to-2 ninth-inning decision over Paul Derringer and the Reds before 18,663 fans today.
PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- Signs are multiplying in the steel industry that some form of government mandatory priorities are in the offing for at least plates and structural shapes.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 24 (delayed) -- Widespread dissatisfaction in Hungary over the Hungarian invasion and occupation of Northern Yugoslavia, the apprehension and alarm caused by Germany's altered attitude toward the Magyars and the steadily tightening restrictions on the purchase of food and everyday necessaries are creating an atmosphere of uneasiness and discontent among the so-called "ruling clasess" throughout the Hungarian capital and the provinces.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Fears that the strike of machinists that has tied up eleven Bay area shipyards since May 9 would spread to a twelfth yard tomorrow were declared by union men today to be groundless.

BOSTON, May 25 -- Paced by Johnny Rucker, who clicked off four hits, one a triple, and Babe Young, who exploded his sixth home run of the campaign, the Giants deftly polished off the Braves today, 6 to 2.

HAMBURG, Conn., May 25 -- Although several of the larger streams in this general area are somewhat discolored as a result of the brief but heavy downpour of Friday, the smaller streams and ponds are giving up some nice trout, and the striped bass are occasionally rewarding the presistent anglers who fish the Niantic at its mouth.

A $1,200 gift of vitamins for the children of Britain was presented in the presence of several hundred pupils from Jewish religious schools throughout the city at the Keren Ami Conference yesterday afternoon at the Park Avenue Synagogue. The money was collected by the Keren Ami, a Jewish children's fund operating in many Hebrew schools and Sunday schools of America.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Roosevelt will sign the Farm Loan Bill providing for wheat, cotton, tobacco and rice loans up to 85 per cent of parity prices, and in return Congressional farm leaders will cut the fund for direct parity payments to farmers from $450,000,000 to $212,000,000 in the incompleted appropriations measure of the Department of Agriculture, it was learned today.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a letter to Mayor La Guardia, signed by 420 leading citizens, calling on him to reduce the cost of city government by 10 per cent and asking that he seek a special session of the Legislature to authorize opening of the 1941-42 executive budget for that purpose.

The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, making his second official visit to Harlem since he became the Archbishop of New York two years ago, blessed and dedicated yesterday afternoon the new $100,000 school building connected with the Roman Catholic Church of St. Aloysius at 219 West 132d Street. The building has been in use since Easter.

The possibility that the British Government would conscript Irishmen in Northern Ireland was termed a "monstrous outrage" by Frank Aiken, Eire's Minister for Coordination of Defense, in an address last night before delegates of the twenty-second annual New York State convention of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic.

Debt service was paid in full in 1940 on $3,459,307,606, or only 58.06 per cent of the total of $5,957,896,433 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31 last, according to a bulletin entitled "Statistical Analysis of Publicly Offered Foreign Dollar Bonds" issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 (AP) -- Major Gen. Heywood on his arrival here described some of the early German action in Crete.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 25 -- Furnished from cellar to attic and its pantry stacked with canned foods, an eight-room stucco house at 114 Doremus Avenue here is awaiting the arrival later this week of a Viennese refugee family that has been adopted by the Ridgewood Council of Churches.

LONDON, May 25 -- More German air-borne troops landed in Crete yesterday, according to the British General Headquarters communique issued in Cairo, Egypt, but they were said to have been "substantially reduced" in scale compared to the previous two days.

Sir William Craigie, who is editing at the University of Chicago the "Dictionary of American English on Historical Principles" -- a work that after several years has progressed about to the letter G -- has published in England some tracts on the growth of American English.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 25 -John E. Parker Jr. of Essex County and Philip B. Harris of the host club won the Montclair Golf Club's invitation tourney today by defeating last year's winners, Steve Berrien of Upper Montclair and Fred C. Witsell, by a margin of 3 and 2.

LONDON, May 25 -- The City's attention last week was concentrated almost exclusively on its all-out campaign for the raising of funds for war weapons. This effort, which resulted in the raising of more than 100,000,000 naturally had repercussions elsewhere in financial quarters.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Columbia Broadcasting System have completed plans to televise in color the museum's priceless collection of paintings, prints and other art objects, it was learned yesterday. Experimental televising (in lack and white) of the Metropolitan's masterpieces is scheduled to begin soon after July 1, the date fixed by the Federal Communications Commission for the start of commercial television program.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 25 -- Secretary Jesse Jones called on the country's industries and labor tonight to cast aside selfish interests "for the protection of American democracy."

Adolph S. Ochs Memorial Post, 1207, of the American Legion, conducted a memorial service yesterday morning for Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, 1896-1935, at Temple Israel Cemetery at Mount Hope in Westchester County. The post, created in 1938, has established the custom of visiting Mr. Ochs's grave on the Sunday before Decoration Day.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- The Cardinals lost another rookie star to the injury list today but went on to take a double-header from the Pirates, 6 to 4 and 4 to 3, and sweep a four-game series.

NEWARK, Monday, May 26 -- Newark's fifteen-minute blackout early today was termed a "complete success" by Governor Charles A. Edison and a "very fine job" by official observers of the War Department in the first reaction by members of the official group who witnessed the demonstration from the thirty-third floor of the National Newark and Essex Bank Building, Newark's tallest structure.

The New York Athletic Club baseball team gained its first victory of the season at the home field on Travers Island yesterday, blasting four Long Island University pitchers for fourteen hits and a 15-2 triumph. Pat Brescia, who went seven innings and allowed five hits, was credited with the verdict.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Eddie Bracken and June Preisser will be starred at Paramount in "College Mystery," a story by Robert Lively, which has been retitled "Sing a Song of Homicide." The latter title has been appropriated from a novel by James R. Langham, which the studio bought some weeks ago.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Swift transformation of wholesale merchandising into a sellers' market was reflected in a sharp upturn in sales of the 1,980 lines represented in the Merchandise Mart during April. The total of all sales ran 31 per cent ahead of a year ago and 17.3 per cent ahead of March.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 25 (UP) -- Argentina today celebrated the 131st anniversary of the revolution leading to her independence with thanksgiving services, historical pageants, mass meetings and patriotic parades throughout the country.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Faced with the pressing problems of procurement of adequate supplies of materials to keep plants operating at full capacity on national defense orders and minimizing of shortages of consumer goods, a large proportion of the country's industrial buyers assembled here today for the annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- All-out government price fixing would place consumers, employers and employes alike in an economic straitjacket, the executive committee of the National Association of Manufacturers warned today as it met on the eve of a national defense preparedness clinic.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 -- In the event the United States enters the war the churches should arouse public opinion to prevent the wholesale internment of refugees, the Rev. Dr. Conrad Hoffman Jr. of New York, a member of the staff of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions, declared today.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 25 -- Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, R.R. Bogie won the Long Island open skeet championship over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Charles P. Taft, assistant coordinator of Health, Welfare and Related Defense Activities, speaking before the annual meeting of the Jewish Welfare Board tonight, declared that the national defense program was America's answer to the call of "a great destiny of service to mankind."

In these days when much emphasis is being placed on national defense, and quite rightfully so, we are apt to forget the innocent victims who have fled from the ruthless aggression which makes this defense necessary.

LONDON, May 25 -- Over many weary and wallowing miles of sea the hunt for the German battleship Bismarck was pressed all today and tonight. The British threw every naval weapon they had in the North Atlantic into the search for the Nazi man-of-war that sank the British battle cruise Hood off Greenland yesterday.
