LONDON, Saturday, May 31 (UP) -- German bombers made a sharp attack on a West England town early today, the second raiding in force on Britain this week after an almost unbroken lull that began May 11.

Record or near-record crowds were reported yesterday from virtually all beaches and resorts in the metropolitan area. A bright sun combined with gentle breezes to make the day ideal for holiday making.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- With the campaign, in the Eastern Mediterranean reaching a turning point and Japan pressing the Netherlands Indies for a showdown on trade negotiations, Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, ignored the holiday by spending several hours in their offices today, going over reports and keeping abreast of latest developments.

VICHY, France, May 30 -- From Paris came the news today that the French Government had decided to increase wages in the lowest brackets in view of the rising cost of living. The announcement was made to reporters there by Yves Bouthillier, Minister of Finance and National Economy.

TOKYO, May 30 -- Denying reports in the United States that Japan had become indifferent to the German-Italian-Japanese treaty, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka issued a formal statement through the Foreign Office tonight reaffirming Japan's loyalty to the triple alliance.

Extraordinary precautions were taken throughout the country yesterday to protect factories producing Army and Navy equipment, shipyards, docks, navy yards and other key points in the defense program against sabotage, as a result of information obtained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that large-scale sabotage was planned for the Memorial Day week-end.

Two members of the board of directors of the Institute for Propaganda Analysis disclosed yesterday that they had resigned because they believed the institute was too critical of the defense policies of the Roosevelt Administration. The resigning members were Professor Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School of Social Work and Professor Paul H. Douglas of the University of Chicago.

TORONTO, May 30 (Canadian Press) -- Gold-mining shares were generally strong today on the Stock Exchange but other index groups closed with narrow losses. Trading was dull and volume was off to 57,000 shares, 30,000 fewer than in yesterday's turnover.

ANDOVER, N.J., May 30 -- Acting on the authority of Attorney General David T. Wilentz, Sheriff Denton J. Quick of Sussex County raided the German-American Bund's Camp Nordland here this evening and closed it as a public meeting place under New Jersey's statute empowering the authorities to close "every building or place where the law is habitually violated."

Breeders, exhibitors and admirers of the pure-bred dog -- unnumbered thousands of them -- will meet today at the world's greatest dog show. They will come from all over the country and the far ends of Canada to watch the competitions among 3,874 dogs of all breeds at Giralda Farms in Madison, N.J.

Reports from yesterday's fourteen matinees indicated that only three shows -- "Panama Hattie," "Hellzapoppin" and "Louisiana Purchase" -- enjoyed capacity houses plus standees. "Arsenic and Old Lace," which does not sell standing room, also sold out.

LONDON, May 30 -- Orphans of the "blitz" over Britain and other young sufferers of modern war are to be aided by thousands under a new plan for spending 100,000 in their behalf, it was announced today by the British War Relief Society of America at its headquarters in Berkeley Square.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Apparently authentic reports reached Congress today that twenty-eight ships loaded with war supplies in United States ports have been sunk en route to Britain since the European war began in September, 1939.

Madison Square Garden, normally the cave of the Brown Bomber and Gargantua, sheltered last night the shy muse of Benny Goodman. The occasion was the opening of the dance carnival which Monte Proser, promoter, is offering for the Summer.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Stimulated by President Roosevelt's declaration of an unlimited national emergency to avert domination of the world by Hitler, the Office of Production Management is putting pressure on the Army and Navy to award immediately another $10,000,000,000 in contracts for which funds have been appropriated or authorized by Congress, and urging President Roosevelt to step up the tempo of the original armament delivery program.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 30 -- Southern Brazil as hit today by the hardest storm in years, with winds of hurricane force at sea and intense cold and heavy snowfall in many areas.

In the Summer, when a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of foaming, frosted glasses, it is nice to know about a new pretzel. One that we have encountered recently is an especially crisp, slenderized variety in the traditional pretzel pattern -- a sort of streamlined pretzel.

LONDON, May 30 -- Lord Woolton, Food Minister, issued an urgent appeal today to the people of the United States, asking them to reduce their normal consumption of milk, cream, sugar, cheese, canned salmon and meat so that these foods can be sent to Britain, where they are vitally needed.

STANTON, Del., May 30 -- Ben Shaba, sporting the colors of Mrs. R.D. Patterson, Dayton, Ohio, sportswoman, raced to an impressive victory today in the fourth renewal of the $5,000 added Dover Stakes, which featured the opening of the Delaware Steeplechase and Race Association's thirty-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- In the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's first nation-wide referendum, wheat farmers will vote tomorrow on the question of applying marketing controls to the bread grain.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 30 (UP) -- British Imperial forces are hemming in Italian troops in the Gondar region of Ethiopia, north of Lake Tana, the last important pocket of Italian resistance in East Africa, after an Italian withdrawal from Debarech, it was stated authoritatively today.

Abroad, the effect of the President's speech will be more clearly visible as it is translated into action. Americans listening to the historic broadcast had no doubt that it was an announcement and a program of action, to be realized gradually or quickly according to the pace of events.

The forty-eighth annual convention of the New York State Luther League began yesterday morning at the Park Central Hotel, with 700 delegates and 100 visitors appearing for the opening of the three-day program. The delegates come from 400 Lutheran churches in seven districts that cover the State and overlap into bordering States.

The House Ways and Means Committee has completed hearings on the $3,500,000,000 defense tax program. Next week its members will sit down to write the bill. Out of the mass of testimony they have heard, one thing is certain. Nearly everybody is in favor of higher taxes -- for the other fellow.

Many of us think that if the city were to reduce the taxes on real estate we would get better buildings and lower rents. What we do not realize is the fact that lower taxes would mean a greater return to the landlords and no improvements in the buildings.

Frank Campbell's uncanny skill in light-weather sailing was never more convincingly demonstrated than yesterday. He picked up where he left off a year ago, this time in a new Star boat, also named Rascal, ran away from his rivals like an eel through grease and won the Ben Bates Trophy for the Larchmont Yacht Club in the fifty-ninth annual regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club.

BUFFALO, May 30 (AP) -- A move "to reconcile" the Roman Catholic, Greek Catholic and Protestant churches will be started at the North American Ecumenical Conference which meets at Toronto, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., May 30 -- New York's 102d Coast Artillery Brigade, comprising three regiments garrisoned here, was started today on a sixteen-week advanced course in anti-aircraft tactics.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 30 -- The House of Representatives adjourned today to June 18 following a two-day secret session that had been held to hear statements by Prime Minister R.G. Menzies and by service Ministers. Heads of Federal departments and high defense officers attended the session.

DUBLIN, Saturday, May 31 -- Three bombs dropped here early today by unidentified aircraft killed at least thirty persons and injured between 100 and 200, the police of this capital of neutral Eire reported. Two bombs struck northside residential areas, demolishing homes and burying their occupants. The third struck about a half mile from the center of the city and destroyed many shops.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., May 30 -- A house pet this evening was awarded the highest honors in the sixty-sixth specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club, which was held on the grounds of the Old Mill Inn in this town.

WINNIPEG, May 30 (AP) -- Prices of flax continued today their precipitous plunge in the coarse grain pit on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, when crushers withdrew early support and left the high-priced commodity to the mercy of anxious sellers.
BERLIN, May 30 (AP) -- The German High Command communique said today:
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- The British Air ad Home Security Ministries issued the following joint communique today:

Major Gen. Bernard Cyril Freyberg was a legendary figure as far back as the World War, and his activities since then served to keep vivid the picture of a man who might be every boy's hero -- soldier, swimmer, boxer, commander, and scoffer at red tape.

Washington made two important defense announcements on the same day. In one, issued by the Office of Production Management, manufacturers were told that they must cast about for materials which will take the place of aluminum hitherto used for kitchen utensils and other nonessentials.

ROME, May 30 -- Today's communique of the Italian High Command reports the loss of the liner Conte Rosso, sunk by a British torpedo south of Syracuse, Sicily, while she was carrying troops in a convoy, apparently bound for Libya.

LONDON, May 30 -- Memorial Day, in which since the Civil War Americans have remembered their compatriots who died for freedom and justice, was observed today in London in the bomb-scarred Church of Saint Margaret's, Westminster.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The Athletics found Washington pitching to their liking and triumphed, 7 to 4 and 14 to 4, in a holiday double-header today. The double loss stretched the Senators' string of defeats to twelve.
ST. LOUIS, May 30 -- The winning streak of the Cardinals, National League leaders, came to an end today.

Is the grip of Joe Louis on the heavyweight title beginning to loosen? The champion does not seem to be knocking over his opponents with the same ruthless regularity that marked the first few years of his reign.

VICHY, France, May 10 (UP) -- A French column has driven across the Sahara to the western shore of Lake Chad, base of General Charles de Gaulle's "Free French" forces, it was reported tonight as the German radio announced Nazi consent for the strengthening of French Empire defense forces.

HYDE PARK, May 30 -- Speculation centered today upon whether President Roosevelt would confer here over the week-end with John G. Winant, Ambassador to Great Britain, who returned to the United States by clipper.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Paramount has purchased "The Lady Has Plans," a modern comedy by Leo Birinski, as a vehicle for Madeleine Carroll. Harry Tugend will prepare the scenario for production after Miss Carroll's "Her Perfect Mate," formerly "The Lady in Pursuit," in which she will be co-starred with Bob Hope.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 30 -- After a rapid advance for the last forty-eight hours, a British army moving from the Euphrates bridgehead of Feluja had almost reached the Iraqui capital of Baghdad tonight and was reported to be sweeping around the city from the west and north to cut off an escape toward Mosul by Premier Rashid Ali el Gailani's forces.

With popcorn and peanuts aplenty, the Bronx Zoo had a gala day as it played host yesterday to the largest Memorial Day crowd in forty-two years of existence. It was the third largest attendance in the Zoo's history. More than 73,000 men, women and children seeped into every nook and cranny of the park and at the end of the day thirty-four "lost" children had been safely returned to their parents.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The National Railway Mediation Board announced today a decision that the New York Central Railroad Company and its operated subsidiaries constituted a single carrier under the Railway Labor Act and that all the yardmen employed by the carrier constituted a proper basis for collective bargaining representation.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 30 -- A triple tie for the medal featured today's qualifying round of the annual best-ball invitation golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- While his sister listened at the end of an open telephone line, Albert G. Roberts, 43 years old, a motion-picture camera man, shot himself dead with a rifle today in the same chair in which Peggy Shannon, his actress wife, died about two weeks ago.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 30 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The rollicking White Sox lambasted the league-leading Cleveland Indians in both ends of a double-header today, 7 to 1 and 5 to 2, behind the sterling pitching of Ted Lyons and Thornton Lee.

All the lessons of the amazing German victory in Crete will not be known until more details have been revealed and the whole story has been pieced together; but it is possible to draw one or two lessons of the first importance from what is already known. It is the most dramatic and clear-cut victory ever scored for air power.

The May volume of milk produced in the New York City milkshed will be of record size and value and the dairy farmers of the six States will receive $12,000,000 when they are paid on June 25, it was forecast yesterday by N.J. Cladakis, administrator of the New York metropolitan milk marketing area.

A bust of Stephen Collin Foster was unveiled this week in the Hall of Fame. In his last years he was a New Yorker. Much posthumous honor has been showered upon him. Busts, statues, memorials, museums in a number of States honor his memory. His most famous songs have been translated into many languages.

The Naumburg Orchestra was heard in the first of a series of four Summer concerts last night on the Mall in Central Park, where it attracted a large and responsive audience. Ignace Strasfogel conducted and Benjamin de Loache, baritone, was the soloist.
CAIRO, May 30 -- The situation of the British troops in Crete was described today as increasingly serious.

A bust of Stephen Collin Foster was unveiled this week in the Hall of Fame. In his last years he was a New Yorker. Much posthumous honor has been showered upon him. Busts, statues, memorials, museums in a number of States honor his memory. His most famous songs have been translated into many languages.

The Naumburg Orchestra was heard in the first of a series of four Summer concerts last night on the Mall in Central Park, where it attracted a large and responsive audience. Ignace Strasfogel conducted and Benjamin de Loache, baritone, was the soloist.
CAIRO, May 30 -- The situation of the British troops in Crete was described today as increasingly serious.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 30 -- Dartmouth defeated the University of Vermont, 10 to 9, today. Although the hits were evenly divided, the Dartmouth blows were well bunched and the Indians did some heads-up base running.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., May 30 -- Movement of the 101st Signal Battalion, one of two New York organizations stationed at Camp Shelby, to Camp Beauregard in Louisiana, to participate in war games is expected to be completed Monday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30 -- More than 3,500 men, women and children of the Archdiocese of Newark of the Roman Catholic Church participated here today in the eighth annual archdiocesan demontration of liturgical music at a solemn pontifical mass.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Sergeant Alvin C. York, hero of the World War, spoke today before the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington cemetery and called for immediate, all-out aid to England, including convoys if necessary.
Nine young men who hope, by next Friday, to be ensigns in the United States Navy, bade a pleasant farewell to the sport of rowing yesterday.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 30 -- Signal Corps requirements and the highly specialized duties of signal work forced the Army to draw heavily from New York City selectees, it was revealed by Fort Monmouth authorities today as plans were made at the post to graduate a class of 219 men from the replacement training center Monday.

Whitsunday will be observed tomorrow in churches of all faiths. In temples and synagogues the Jewish Feast of Pentecost will be celebrated. At the request of the Interfaith Committee for the Aid to the Democracies prayers will be offered "for the triumph of justice and righteousness throughout the world."

OTTAWA, May 30 -- Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King, in a telegram to Ontario Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn tonight, offered to withdraw the new 15 per cent tax imposed on non-resident holders of Canadian securities on condition that the Ontario government accept the income-tax deal offered in the budget.
Sport, as is to be expected, is joining wholeheartedly in the effort to assist with the training and preparation of the country for the present emergency.

Continuing a trend of recent years, books of all kinds will be published in substantial numbers in the Summer months ahead. The notion, popular for many years, that June to August is a time only for light books is now in virtual discard. Publishing lists for the next three months contain many strong titles, potential best sellers in some cases.

With no definite assurance that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will run for re-election, friends of John Harlan Amen have approached leaders of the Fusion movement and suggested him as the Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County.

OTTAWA, May 30 (AP) -- A large liner loaded with hundreds of British military personnel bound for Canada and the United States narrowly escaped the guns of the German battleship Bismarck in the North Atlantic, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Notable additions to defense plants and to freight-car facilities to haul the output were reported today by the Office of Production Management and the transportation division of the Office for Emergency Management in a survey of accomplishments in the year since the beginning of the national defense program.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 30 -- Unification of court systems and an "administrative headship" to assume responsibility for justice were urged here today by Roscoe Pound, dean emeritus of Harvard University Law School.

LONDON, May 30 -- It was officially confirmed in London today that Premier Rashid Al el Gailani of the rebel Baghdad government had fled to Iran. This announcement accompanied official reports that British mobile forces had reached the outskirts of Baghdad and that other units advancing up the Euphrates from Basra had occupied Ur.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 30 -- Eight thousand dejected soldiers returned to Fort Dix tonight in motor convoys after participating in Memorial Day celebrations in fifty New York and New Jersey communities. Several thousand more whose leaves expire at reveille tomorrow also swarmed into camp.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Mauri Rose, diminutive Indianapolis driver, and Floyd Davis of Springfield, Ill., accomplished a two-man job in winning the 500-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race today -- an event that was delayed an hour by fire and marred by three wrecks.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., May 30 -- Brooklyn Guardsmen of the 245th Coast Artillery, who were mustered into Federal service in September and the 586 selectees from New York City assigned to the regiments since then are "ready for anything," according to Brig. Gen. Phillip S. Gage, commanding officer of the harbor defenses of Sandy Hook.

COSTA RICA released on Friday some of its current airmail stamps overprinted "Costa Rica-Panama Arregio Limitrofe -- Mayo 29, 1941" (Costa Rica -- Panama Boundary Adjustment-May 29, 1941) in commemoration of settlement of a longstanding border controversy with Panama.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I was interested in a note published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, May 4, regarding a book soon to be published about Baja California, "Forgotten Waters," by Randolph Leigh.
President Roosevelt's fireside address in which he proclaimed an "unlimited national emergency" was praised by rabbis here in sermons yesterday.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- British war casualties have reached the 100,000 mark for all three fighting services in twenty-one months of war, it was disclosed today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 -- Naval Academy athletes won two of three sports events with West Point today before huge June Week crowds that sat under unbrellas as a drizzling rain fell much of the time.

BOSTON, May 31 -- The Simmons College School of English has acquired a "publishing workshop" through the action of an undergraduate board of editors in voting themselves out of office. They turned over their publication to the college so that it might be of broader value to the student body, Dr. Robert M. Gay, director of the school, announced today.

THERE are times when one almost approves of murder, and one of those times comes with the unfolding of the story of old Mrs. Stanford and her family. The family consists of three grandchildren, all dependent upon the old lady, who gives them everything they want excepting liberty to live their own lives.

TOKYO -- Despite the current tension between Japan and the United States and Britain, Japanese crowds filled the top floor of one of the capital's largest department stores recently to see the first -- and probably the last -- full-sized public exhibition by members of Tokyo's foreign community of their skill at arranging flowers in the Japanese style.

Mechanized Army units, such as the hard-hitting German panzer divisions, are not invincible if opposed by well trained, properly equipped troops. And discipline is indispensable to superiority in battle, it was declared here yesterday.

How often the gardener comments, as some of his loveliest plants bloom, "I wish I had more of this or that." And how often, after a Summer such as last year's, or after a hard Winter, many of the garden's choicest treasures have "gone with the wind."

Having successfully defended the national chess championship and for the first time in match play, Samuel Reshevsky, victor in the United States tournaments of 1936, 1938 and 1940, and conqueror of Israel A. Horowitz by a score of 3 -- 0. and 13 draws, left for Boston on a vacation trip.

THERE is an air reminiscent of "My Sister Eileen" about this book of amusing incidents of family life. The humor is not so sharp nor the viewpoint so sophisticated, since the story purports to be told by 9-year-old Helen Marsden. The telling is simple and straight -- with no unedited childish errors, thank Heaven -- and the humor, sometimes slanted from the child's angle, is more often inferential, as it seems to an adult bystander.

OF course the title tells you that this is a book about children. And you will be quite right in your further assumption that it deals with the sufferings of parents at their offsprings' hands, in a mood of quite excruciating mirth.

Sweeping irresistibly onward while the Opposition appeared to be resting irresolutely, the dashing Dodgers battered the Giants once more at the Polo Grounds yesterday to record a clean sweep of the three-game series.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 31 -- Stroked by John Miller, Hun School won the championship eight-oared race, featured event of the seventh annual regatta of the Schoolboy Rowing Association over the new Cooper River Parkway Course today before 5,000 spectators.

IN 1728 John Gay's The Beggar's Opera was produced in London and ran for sixty-three days, which was a sensational success. With a score by a Dr. Pepusch, Gay's play poked fun at the ridiculous excesses of Italian opera of the time, and in addition, commented satirically on the politics and society of the day.

A maximum amount of natural light, cross-ventilation, rooms for psychiatric examination, barracks where men may sleep if they miss their trains to camp, and other features are incorporated in the new induction station, Fort Jay, Governors Island, which will be opened tomorrow at 7:30 A.M. to facilitate the movement of men into the armed forces under the Selective Service Act.

With Germany's "Drang nach Osten" apparently in full swing, attention again is focused on the Near and Middle East. Today this old battleground of empire is important not only for its strategic position but for its vast oil resources.

THEY are making no bones about it in film industry circles hereabout: business is generally off -- alarmingly off -- in picture theatres throughout the country. Trade journals are shouting bloody murder and exhibitors are wringing their hands.

The thirty-fourth annual Women's Eastern Golf Association championship will be held at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y., on June 10, 11 and 12, and will be followed by the Griscom Cup matches among New York, Philadelphia and Boston on Friday, June 13, at the same club.

SINCE the war the sale of monocles in America has risen more than 50 per cent. No statistics are kept on the total number sold, but opticians say it is not large. Somehow the monocle has never caught on very widely in the United States.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Language, we are told, grows by feeding from below father than above. The slang of yesterday is the accepted speech of today, and terms and phrases that a decade ago were anathema to the purist today resound from pulpit and platform, and grace the stateliest printed page.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A.M. June 1. PATROLMEN -- James H. Markley, from Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, to 18tn Division, designated as Third Grade Detective. Assignment to duty with Midtown Squad discontinued.

THE American Theatre Society now has thirteen cities on its list, Indianapolis and Toronto being added for the Fall, and estimates that some 60,000 subscribers will be seeing the offerings in the new season. Each subscriber is promised six shows, plus certain advantages in the Theatre Guild's revivals, which are to tour also.

Country clubs in "Westchester and on Long Island are cooperating in plans for the 1941 Federation Fete, annual festival sponsored by the women's division of the New York Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Federation of Charities.

IT is June again and history, reaching out a hairy paw, has taken unto itself the Theatre Season of 1940-1941. Perhaps it is more than that this time, for "Tobacco Road" closed last night along with the season and that practically ended a decade.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 31 -- Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, has been appointed as the Papal Legate to the ninth National Eucharistic Congress to be held in the Twin Cities June 23-26. The appointment was made by Pope Pius XII and the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate in Washington, D.C.

Tre Gannon Council of Debate of the Fordham University School of Education presented a report this week to the student body on an educational survey conducted during the last year. The report, based on a series of interviews with leaders in three major fields of employment, is expected to be of considerable aid to the college graduate seeking his place in the competition of gaming a livelihood after his college career is ended.

The strain of longer hours and night shifts under the defense program has left many workers too tired to participate in traditional sporte activities and has made it necessary to foster new types of play in up-State industrial centers, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Regional Defense Coordinator, disclosed yesterday.

THE British Imperial Army of the Nile is fighting desperately for the second time within a few months to save Egypt and the Suez Canal from the Axis powers. Since the Nazi armored divisions have trampled down Europe and the Balkans, now only the courage, endurance and skill of this army can prevent the Germans similarly from crushing Egypt and all the countries of the Middle East.
Bundles for Britain, Inc., announced yesterday that it had cabled to London $84.517 to assist in rehabilitation of non-government, volunteer hospitals and for emergency relief.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- An industrial revolution that has not had an American counterpart since the early days of the automobile in Michigan is sweeping over the Pacific coast.

MADISON, N.J., May 31 -- Champion Nornay Saddler, one of the greatest and most famous dogs in the world, this afternoon was crowned as best of 3,883 competing in the fifteenth annual show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, held on the polo field of Giralda Farms, the country estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge.

Higher taxes and other costs resulted in a less favorable showing by the chemical industry in the first quarter of 1941 than in the same period last year, a survey of twenty-two principal companies in the field indicates. Combined profits were $46,970,408 in the quarter, against $45,972,665 in the final quarter of 1940 and $47,689,355 in its first quarter.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With reference to Arthur Krock's column in THE TIMES today, it has occurred to me for quite a while that red tape is making almost impossible any intelligent procedure. Reciprocity in international relations seems to be an almost forgotten principle.

A patriotic theme has been chosen for the sixth annual "Young America Paints" art exhibition to be opened to the public next Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. Paintings by more than a thousand children in public, private and parochial schools in forty-four States and Canada have been sent to the exhibition, all illustrating what the young artists love most in America.

SUMMER group exhibitions of work by contemporary American artists began to make their appearance in numbers last week, no less than six falling in that category. Most of the events include both recent work and paintings which have been seen during the season in the respective galleries.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. will be the principal speakers at the ninth annual convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs at Glens Falls on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Rapid growth of the consumer cooperative movement on the Eastern seaboard was reflected yesterday in figures, issued by the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, distributing agency for the area, at its twelfth annual meeting, attended by 350 delegates representing 200 cooperatives in a dozen States.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Fortunately for the two weeks' mid-season market opening here tomorrow, the concentration of buyer interest la on apparel and other soft goods lines where the impact of defense demands and priorities has bean felt only slightly.

Today's towering skyscraper districts of Manhattan were made up of low buildings, mostly four and five stories in height, and the Hall of Records was housed in the old jail at the northeast corner of City Hall Park when Thomas R. Phillips entered the title insurance business here.

Columbia University's 187th commencement will begin with the baccalaureate service today at 4 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel and continue until Tuesday evening, when Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will confer between 5,300 and 5,500 degrees and certificates at outdoor exercises in front of the Low Memorial Library.

BEETLE SUICIDES -- Preparations for a systematic, large-scale bacterial offensive against the Japanese beetle in Connecticut are progressing at the Agricultural Experiment Station at New Haven, under the direction of Dr. Philip Garman.

The tenth annual conference of the National Association of Seamen's Welfare Agencies will be held in Philadelphia for four days beginning next Thursday, it was announced yesterday by the Seamen's Church Institute of New York. The Rev. Harold H. Kelley, director of the institute and chairman of the conference, will preside.

Reorganizations of the Chicago Western Illinois and the Chicago Great Western lines would seem to have vindicated the judgment of the framers of the law that extended the privileges of bankruptcy to the railroads. This law, enacted in 1933, would seem to have provided a reasonably prompt method for recapitalizing railroads and certainly is an improvement over the old equity receivership.

NOW that the colleges are telling us which of their graduates are the wittiest, the prettiest and the most likely to succeed; now that the best plays have been chosen by all the groups of choosers, and Summer is virtually upon us, it would be merely coy to withhold any longer the annual selection by this department of the season's finest new composition, most promising debutante and outstanding dance event outside the bounds of esthetics.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A $3,557,000,000 increase in the nation's budgetary deficit for the next fiscal year over the $9,210,000,000 deficit estimated in January was predicted today by Harold D. Smith, Director of the Bureau of the Budget, as a likely result of the stepping up of the defense program since the regular annual estimate was made.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 31 -- War relief activities and a well-filled round of sports events feature the most active season here in years. There have been many visitors this Spring and the Park will be filled with week-end guests next Friday and Saturday for the annual Tuxedo Horse Show.

Nearly forty years of service with the Fire Department, ended one minute after last midnight for Deputy Fire Chief John E. O'Keefe, commander of the department's activities in the Bronx. He retired on an annual pension of $3,200 at the age of 68.

A small "university press" has been developed at City College during the last five years because of the increasing number of publications prepared by members of the staff for the use of students in individual courses, it was reported last week at the college.

LONDON, May 31 -- Men's and women's clothing, footwear, cloth and knitting wool will be strictly rationed beginning tomorrow along lines similar to food rationing. As in the case of food, those wishing to buy clothes will be required to furnish appropriate coupons before making purchases.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Our people are not united." This cry, so often uttered by those who counsel inaction in this critical hour, is worth analyzing.

As far back as 1921 Anthony Fokker suggested at the International Aeronautic Exposition that gliders could be towed in trains. The aeronautic experts were skeptical. To lift even a single glider with an airplane would require more ground than is usually available, it was argued.

MOST timely, and in many respects of absorbing interest, is the exhibition called "Britain at War," which opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art. It will continue there through the Summer months and later will be sent to other cities in this country and in Canada.

A Miner Hulls Wheat Theodore Earle, a mining engineer of Los Angeles, has discovered how to peel the outside hull from grain. As a mining engineer he was thoroughly acquainted with the flotation process for separating values from their ores.

CINCINNATI, May 31 -- The hotand-cold Reds cut the Cardinals' hold on first place in the National League to a single game today by winning from St. Louis, 5 to 2, for an even break in the four-game series, while second-place Brooklyn beat the Giants by the same score.

ONCE there were Emperors in this Western Hemisphere and one of them retained his throne until Nov. 16. 1889. It seems curious now; it is almost forgotten; and yet that last Emperor was one of the kindest, most considerate and profoundly intellectual of all the chiefs of State who have governed in South or, for that matter, North America.
THE publication of "Religions of Democracy" advances the cause of the interfaith movement in the United States from one of mere tolerance and good-will to that of education and understanding.

Peru is entitled to preferred consideration as the location for developing tropical products for which the United States desires Western Hemisphere sources, the National Foreign Trade Council declared yesterday in a report analyzing Peru's possibilities as a source of raw materials.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Public sentiment concerning America's-in-the-war in this section has taken on a split personality. Almost universally one finds in the same individual opposing viewpoints, the tug and pull of which seldom fail to develop mental and emotional strain.

Dr. Frank Kingdon, chairman of the Emergency Rescue Committee and the Joint Appeal for a $100,000 Rescue Fund, discounted yesterday testimony before the Dies Committee by Richard Krebs (Jan Valtin), author of "Out of the Night," that the Nazis have sent Gestapo agents into this country in the guise of refugees.

Baccalaureate With a Difference Men and women of the Class of 1941: It is my intention this afternoon to upset as many precedents as I can, manage in the short time at my disposal. And I propose to start right in by giving you my parting injunctions and counsel at the very beginning of my address instead of holding back the secret until the very end, as is customary on such occasions.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, May 31 -- Leaving behind twenty-one members of the British-American Ambulance Corps -- a name that helped to supply the final unlucky climax to an ill-starred voyage -- 119 American survivors of the Egyptian steamship Zamzam were released by German authorities today and set out across Spain on their way to home and freedom.

An important program, designed to arouse greater interest in the use of cocker spaniels in the field, has been undertaken by the field trial committee of the American Spaniel Club, of which A.M. Lewis of Stamford, Conn., is chairman.

FEATURED among the score of choral groups from all parts of the country to be heard at the biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs, June 18-25, in Los Angeles, will be the North Carolina Symphonic Choir and the Apollo Boys Choir of Birmingham, Ala., both of which have appeared at the White House.
BLACKBURN, England, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Preston North End defeated Arsenal, 2-1, today to win the War Cup soccer final.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 24 -- The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, administered by Tufts College with the cooperation of Harvard University, is carrying on an experiment in an advanced course of study, which seeks to combine in one program of research and discussion all the various fields of international affairs with the object of clarifying contemporary world events in such a way as to contribute to intelligent leadership in any future period of reconstruction.

One of the finest country places in the metropolitan area ever subdivided for small suburban estates was formally opened last Friday when the former Otto H. Kahn estate at Huntingdon, L.I., was launched as a community of colonial-style homes by Realty Associates, Inc., builders.

PRESS comment from the early morning editions at Rome newspapers are read in the Pacific transmission of Rome Radio at 1:15 A.M. D.S.T. The Italian ahort-wavs loudest at this hour has lately been on the 9.64 megacycle position.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 31 -- When the nearly 18,000 New Jersey and New York Federalized National Guardsmen comprising the Fortyfourth Division moves to Virginia early next week they will be under the observation of the highest ranking officers of the War Department.

COLUMBUS is generally credited with having discovered the American mainland in 1498. His first two voyages netted him nothing but islands, but on his third he reached the shores of South America itself, exploring the Gulf of Paria and following the coast of Venezuela westward for over a hundred miles.

Five men and a woman are threatened with death by a man whom they have once betrayed. They do not know where the avenger is, but they know that he is clever and resourceful. For mutual protection, the six have taken refuge in the strongly guarded home of John Bodkin, who is one of them and whose son Leslie has been warned that he will be the first to die.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 31 -- Two hits in the ninth inning gave Princeton a 3-2 victory over Penn on University Field today, and lifted the Tigers into a tie with Cornell for first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race.

HENRI TROYAT is best known here as a recent winner of the Prix Goncourt. His new novel -- which is His firth -- is set against the background of the early months of the war and was written during his own service as an officer with the French Army; but it is not a reflection of experiences in fighting.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -- While unrest continues to spread throughout French North African possessions, it is learned here that another element of complication is about to be introduced with the drafting of an Italian demand on Vichy expressing the "desire" for concessions in Tunisia similar to those granted the Germans in Syria.

HOLIDAY: May 25 is Argentina's Independence Day. It marks the anniversary of the revolution that brought the nation freedom from Spanish rule 131 years ago. Last week echoes of the war in Europe marred Argentina's celebration. In La Plata, Italian Consul Renato Citarelli gave the fascist salute while watching the city's parade.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 -- Religious services in all local churches will mark the opening tomorrow of the two-week observance of the 300th anniversary of the founding of Stamford. A pageant, musical events, athletic contests, an industrial exposition, a colonial ball arid a governors parade will be features of the celebration.

"Two dollars, who'll make it two-fifty . . . twofifty, who'll make it three . . . three. . . ." The auctioneer stands under the cloud-touched Summer sky before a backdrop of white clapboard house, red barn, silo, whitewashed sheds, rail fences, green pastures and rows of waving corn.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The National Defense Mediation Board today summoned to Washington leaders of 12,000 striking Puget Sound C.I.O. lumber workers who have rejected board recommendations for ending their twenty-three-day-old walkout.

Isolationists and pacifists in this country today represent the "same intellectual and moral confusion that played so tragic a role in the collapse of European democracies," Dr. James Loeb Jr., executive secretary of the Union for Democratic Action, declared yesterday in a statement made public at the Union's headquarters, 202 West Fortieth Street.

J.C. Nichols, chief of the supply section, production division, in a recent address before the national conference in Washington, declared that a wide decentralization of production is essential and not a concentration of activity into one or a few areas.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved narrowly in featureless trading, price fluctuations being within an 8-point range. Opening quotations were unchanged to 4 points down and further losses were recorded as liquidation appeared in the market.

"That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet," may have expressed the poet's feelings, but when a gardener has a rose bed or a rose garden, he is pretty certain to want roses, real roses, that line up to the catalogue pictures, and in as great profusion and over as long a period as possible.

The result is that a surprising number of people, including many who were rattled at the unknown of last May, are now prepared solemnly to die in their tracks to stop Schickelgruber. Heroism? After this war there will be, of course, statues of the Unknown Citizen with a bucket in one hand and a sandbag in the other.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 31 -- It would be foolish to deny that the continued series of German millitary successes is rapidly raising Nazi prestige in the troubled Middle East, and Arab unrest may be expected to continue on a scale directly proportionate to the extent and geographical nearness of Nazi victories.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Is history repeating itself in the arrival of Hess in the British Isles? According to Herodotus, in the reign of Darius there was a Persian of high rank by the name of Zopyrus, who washed to help forward the siege of Babylon by the Persians.

NEWARK, N.J., May 31 -- Newark Airport, which was closed to commercial aviation on May 30, 1940, by the Civil Aeronautics Board, will spring to life again tomorrow at 6:40 A.M., when a twenty-one passenger plane for Eastern Airlines, first of about sixty carrier flights scheduled for the day, will land at the field.

Reports reaching London have confirmed the arrest of Professor Karl E.K. Haushofer, associate of the fugitive Rudolf Hess and prominent theorist of the National Socialist party in Germany, the British radio announced yesterday in a broadcast heard here by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Ten years ago large and valuable street, lawn and park trees in a Rhode Island area were affected with a serious and unknown trouble. The trees were manifestly unhealthy. The foliage was off color and decidedly scanty and still there was no evidence of insect attack or of any known plant disease.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER is undertaking production of the first comprehensive motion picture survey of the nation's far-flung network of defense activities, it became known the other day. Working quietly in Washington for the past several days, Herbert Morgan, Eastern head of the company's short subjects department, has been enlisting the cooperation of the Office of Production Management and other agencies to expedite production of the film.

COMMANDER Edward Ellsberg is blessed with fury, which is a great advantage for a writer. He is haunted continually by sacrifices and heroisms performed by men too little known. Soft-voiced but aggressive, calm in appearance but emotional in speech, his books and stories have one theme -- the remembrance and recognition of strength, courage and hardihood.

In Iraq the spearhead of the British thrust has been formed by Indian troops equipped by India's military production. In the campaign in Ethiopia Indian soldiers, especially adept at mountain fighting, formed an important part of the imperial force which wrested a great African colony from Italy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 31 -- Yale won is seventh straight baseball game today by turning back Fordham, 10 -- 3, before 2,800 spectators. Fifteen hits, mainly grouped in the first, second and seventh innings, accounted for the visitors' downfall.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Capitalism, or private enterprise, as it is now fashionable and more accurately descriptive to term it, is fee system of individual or group action in supplying the wants of man. In collectivism every one is a stockholder in each and every activity.

CLEVELAND, May 31 -- Dr. William E. Wickenden, president of the Case School of Applied Science and former official of the Office of Production Management, today sharply criticized President Roosevelt's conduct of defense production and suggested that Wendell L. Willkie should be drafted as chief coordinator of America's defense efforts.

VICHY, France, May 31 -- Upon returning to Vichy today after five days in Paris consulting with the occupying authorities on French-German collaboration, Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, tonight took the occasion of the British bombings at Sfax, Tunisia, to direct a violent broadside at Britain.

WASHINGTON. WARTIME Washington is finally fulfilling the dreams of its founders. The small town on the banks of the Potomac is growing up. The "Federal City" of Major Pierre Charles L'Enfant's imagination is here at last.

A RECENT announcement of the German High Command that a torpedo boat had heavily damaged a British "submarine trap" suggests that some of the anti-submarine devices of the last war are again being employed in the present conflict.

NATIONS early resorted to convoys to protect their shipping in time of war. The ships of the Hanseatic League and of Venice were required to sail in convoy. The British called convoys wafts and the warships on convoy duty were wafters.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 31 (AP) -- Today's communique of the British Royal Air Force Middle East command follows:

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced in a letter today to Dr. Quo Tai-chi, the newly appointed Foreign Minister of China, that when peace is restored in that country the United States would move for the relinquishment of her special extraterritorial rights in China.
BERLIN, May 31 -- In the last session until Tuesday, trading on the Boerse here today opened on a strong note, with the turnover on a larger scale than at any time in recent weeks.
BERLIN, May 31 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

SEATTLE, May 31 -- O.M. Orton, president of the International Woodworkers of America, whose strike has tied up lumber and logging works in Western Washington, said today the strike would end only if their original demands were met.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 31 -- Long-gaited Grover Klemmer of the University of California tied the world record in the 440-yard run and claimed individual honors today in the Pacific Coast Conference track and field championships.

WASHINTGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A bipartisan movement to scrap President Roosevelt's emergency monetary powers developed in the Senate Banking Committee today and its leaders planned to call on Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, for testimony in their support.

Converging now on Fort Worth, Texas, by train, by automobile and by airplane are most of the country's star golfers, amateurs as well as pros, each one of them nursing a private hope that on him alone the gods of golf will smile.

TOKYO, May 31 -- All American and all European maps of the world show Alaska at one end and at the other Japan. All Japanese maps show Japan in the center of the world with Britain at one end and Washington and New York at the other.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The United States, it was reported in authoritative quarters today, will notify the Petain government within a few days that Vichy's future acts, rather than its words, will be basis for American judgment of Franco-German "collaboration."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 31 (UP) -- George Whitefield D'Vys, who claimed to have written "Casey at the Bat," is dead at the age of 81. The white-haired little man who fought for fifty years for the rights to the ballad died yesterday, less than a year after the death of his rival claimant, Ernest L. Thayer, a West Coast newspaper man.

New York City is the most God-fearing community in the United States today, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, declared last night at the annual fellowship dinner of the New York State Luther League at the Park Central Hotel.

Emulating propaganda flights of air forces abroad over hostile territory, a squadron of four Navy blimps will drop leaflets on Times Square tomorrow announcing the opening Tuesday of the United Service Organizations campaign for funds to finance the operation of more than 360 service clubs for soldiers, sailors and defense workers.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- The so-called isolationist Central States are ready to fight to the limit if the United States gets into the war. But these States, nevertheless, do not want to go into the hostilities. This attitude is evident throughout Illinois, Wisconsin, Michigan and Indiana.

DR. LOTHAR WALLERSTEIN, who before the Anschluss was the chief stage director of the Vienna State Opera and the Salzburg Festivals, is now a refugee in this country living in a furnished room on Riverside Drive.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24 -- Students from twenty-one States and five foreign countries hold forty-five traveling, foreign and graduate fellowships awarded by the Radcliffe Graduate School for 1941-42, according to an announcement made today by Dean Bernice Brown Cronkhite.

Yesterday's reports which told of the last hours of the German battle ship Bismarck now make it quite clear that last week's naval battle, like the World War Battle of Jut-land, will have a revolutionary effect upon the art of naval architecture and design.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The White Sox, playing just well enough to make their winning streak four games, advanced within a game and a half of first place today with a 4-to-3 victory over the Browns. It was Chicago's sixth triumph in eight games with St. Louis and its fourteenth triumph in the last 19 games.
EXETER, N.H., May 31 -- Exeter beat Andover in baseball today by 11 -- 2, one of the largest margins in the series between the academies, which was started in 1878.

Misleading reports about the ability of various ferrous and nonferrous metal industries to take care of both government and civilian needs have caused some companies to jump from "the frying pan into the fire" in their switches from metals in short supply to substitutes, reports here yesterday indicated.

AT A BRITISH PORT, May 31 -- Bringing a welcome cargo of more than 4,000,000 eggs, 120,000 pounds of cheese and 1,000 tons of flour, the first foodship to ferry across the Atlantic from the United States under the terms of the lease-lend act has arrived here.

Past presidents of the real estate boards in the metropolitan district and in other parts of the State will be guests of honor at the "presidents' dinner" on June 26 as a feature of the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at Bolton Landing, N.Y.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- Under the clothing rationing plan announced today, the most costly gown, for instance, calls for the same number of coupons as the cheapest frock.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The $3,300,000,000 emergency rearmament program went ahead at full speed today as President Roosevelt revived the Council of National Defense.

Formation of an Institute of Adult Education through a $350,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation, announced by Teachers College last week, will help raise the standards in the entire field of adult education and permit the training of leaders, Dr. Morse A. Cartwright, director of the institute, asserted yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 31 -- Driving through beflagged streets from the railway station to the Town Hall in an open car that was followed by a large crowd and escorted by mounted police and a band of pipers, Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies received a rousing reception today upon his return to his home city.

LONDON, May 31 -- An armistice signed in Baghdad late this afternoon brought to an end the rebellion in Iraq against Britain, London learned tonight. Indian fighters of the British forces took up positions in the outskirts of the capital city, from which Premier Rashid Ali el Gailani, leader of the revolt, and all his followers able to do so had fled.

JUNE to most of us, is the month of brides, but June in the Fulton Fish Market is the month for crabs. All through June the Soft-Shell Crab Express rushes its spiny passengers to the New York markets, where some 50,000 of them are sold in an average day.

American transport planes bought since April 29 for British use may have contributed to Great Britain's victory in Iraq, the British Press Service indicated here yesterday in releasing a report bearing a London dateline.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- German airmen who went belatedly to Iraq to bolster the Axis-inspired war against Britain were reported to be fleeing the country tonight as Iraqi resistance collapsed.

A CRUSADE for American music is being organized by Eddy Brown, musical director of WQXR. Many people and many organizations have tried this before, but Mr. Brown is one of the first to attempt it through the use of radio.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- College and university endowment funds as a class are earning a higher rate of income than the portfolios of life insurance companies, according to a study soon to be released by J. Harvey Cain, director of the Financial Advisory Service, American Council on Education.

SABRINA is 11 years old, her brother James is "nearly 9," and "I Go by Sea, I Go by Land" is Sabrina's diary through three months in 1940, as the children come from their home in Sussex to stay with Aunt Harriet in America.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The radio broadcasting industry took in $154,823,787 last year from the sale of time alone, a 19 per cent increase over 1939, resulting in a gain in operating profit of more than $9,000,000, or about 39 per cent, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

President, National Farm School The National Farm School, located in the fertile, picturesque county of Bucks in Eastern Pennsylvania, occupies a rather unique place in the educational field. The school's special claim to distinction lies in the fact that it is one of the few institutions of learning offering post-high school instruction in vocational agriculture to city boys.

The largest war games in the nation's history are now in progress with almost 200,000 troops moved from cantonments and camps all over the country to field manoeuvre sites in Tennessee, Texas and California.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- British naval losses in the engagement that resulted in the sinking of the German battleship Bismarck totaled twenty-five killed and thirteen wounded in addition to the 1,300 or more who went down with the battle cruiser Hood, the Admiralty said today.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- The letter of President Roosevelt to Secretary Ickes designating him as petroleum coordinator for national defense was as follows:

HOLLYWOOD. POVERTY ROW and the shoestring movie producer have supposedly been squeezed out of Hollywood. But there is one survivor -- Irving Applebaum. In 1939 he made $8,000 as a film cutter; in 1940 he made $347.50 as a producer.

Outstanding graduates of the medical schools in the Latin-American republics will receive special interneships in university hospitals and clinics in the United States for the coming academic year, it was announced yesterday by Nelson Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations Between the American Republics.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 31 -- A total of 671 patients, the second largest number in its history, was treated in 1940 by the New York Hospital-Westchester division completing its 120th year, according to the annual report issued today by Dr. Clarence O. Cheney, medical director.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- Si Johnson of the Phils and Manuel Salvo of the Braves hooked up in a pitchers' duel today, and although the Phils were outhit, six to four, they won, 1 to 0, to give them the rubber game in the series. The score came in the fourth when Outfielder Joe Marty smashed a double and came home on First Baseman Nick Etten's single.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 31 -- Riverhead's well-balanced track squad carried off the Class A Suffolk County interscholastic championship today with a total of 38 points. Sayville, last year's victor, was runner-up with 29 1/2 and Amityville, with 15 1/2, took third place ahead of Port Jefferson, whose total was 15.

The largest whaling ship in the world, the 16,966-ton Kosmos II., flying the flag of Norway, arrived in New York Harbor recently and is now moored at Bayonne, N.J. Ship news reporters visited the vessel last week as the guests of her master, Captain Einar Gleditch, and two representatives of the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission, Captain Milliam Kihl, former master of the Kosmos II, and Bjarne Braatoy.

The Foster Parents Plan for War Children, 55 West Forty-second Street, cabled $5,000 to England last week tor the opening of its eleventh children's sanctuary. The organization's chairman, Mrs. Edna Blue, appealing for additional funds to give still more aid to young English victims of German air raids, said more than 4,000 children now were being cared for.

Evidences of the rising national income are indicated, according to officials of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, from the fact that collections are approximately 100 per cent of the current monthly billings.

William J. Dougherty, director of audits and accounts, State Department of Audit and Control at Albany, blamed to many cocktails for his inability to remember all that occurred during a visit to New York City on June 23 and 24, 1937.

TO the traveler who feels that his style is badly cramped by the two-week limit set on most vacations the airlines are holding out new inducements. For his benefit they have extended the all-expense tour, until very recently an innovation in air travel, to nearly every part of the world where vacations are still possible.

HOLLYWOOD. GILDING the lily, a standard Hollywood achievement, has just reached a new high. Some five to ten thousand feet, to be exact, for at that noble altitude camera men have been filming Technicolor aerial manoeuvres for Warners' chromatic account of naval aviation, "Dive Bomber," starring Errol Flynn and Fred MacMurray.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 31 -- Combining the features of a seminar with an all-expense tour of the tidewater Virginia historical area, an adult education project at the College of William and Mary will give to 150 persons from a score of States a week's observation and study of colonial society in Virginia.

TOKYO, May 31 -- The Japanese note submitted to the Netherland Government regarding Japan's demands for raw materials from the Netherlands Indies is "final and Japan expects nothing less than acceptance as a reply," Kenkichi Yoshizawa, head of the Japanese trade mission to Batavia, declared according to a report published here by Domei, Japanese news agency.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM, having completed a tour of over 60,000 miles since leaving his native England in November, 1940, makes his first radio appearince of the present whirl through the United States, Canada and Mexico, this afternoon at 3 when he conducts the Columbia Broadcasting Symphony Orchestra, over WABC.

Declaring that their mission has "something to do with the question of provisions," Harry A. Woodruff of Bedford Village, N.Y., and Franklin Canfield of Washington, both vice consuls, left La Guardia Field yesterday for Lisbon, en route to Casablanca, French Morocco, aboard the Atlantic Clipper.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 31 (AP) -- With Crete all but lost to Britain, the war rocketed toward a new phase today in a running battle between strong Royal Air Force forces and a cloud of German warplanes high above the sapphire waters of the Eastern Mediterranean.

A series of Summer manoeuvres of unprecedented size that started last week and are tentatively scheduled to continue until Nov. 30 will put more than 550,000 soldiers in the field, as shown on the map. The exercises will be held at first by divisions and corps and will culminate in the Fall in giant war games in which field armies will oppose field armies.

DETROIT, May 31 -- The Detroit Free Press will say in a first-page "statement of policy" in its Sunday editions tomorrow that it is prepared to abandon an isolationist stand and pledge its complete support to President Roosevelt in the foreign policy he defined in his national emergency radio address Tuesday.

WASHINGTON -- The proprietor of some 165 national parks and "national monuments," Uncle Sam, expects in the vacation season just beginning, a record number of visitors to these spots of scenic beauty and historical association.

Fears that official ceilings may spread rapidly to many consumer goods materials swept through the markets last week after the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply had announced its intention of naming maximum prices for hides.

AFTER months of preparations the National Philatelic Auctions for Refugee Relief, organized under the chairmanship of Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University, will hold a public sale of choice stamps and philatelic material at the Hotel Astor on Tuesday evening.

To what extent do team sports, the necessary backbone of any college athletic program, "carry over" after college? Practically not at all, according to a questionnaire recently sent to 800 Antioch College graduates since 1920 and returned by 437 of them.

Gadgets which banish household drudgery are largely responsible for higher building costs, M.H. Furbringer of Memphis, Tenn., told the members of the American Institute of Architects at their recent con- vention in California.

BOSTON, May 31 -- While a large majority of New England's adult population listened attentively to the President's radio talk Tuesday night, with the response of newspaper editorials the next morning uniformly favorable, it is doubtful, in the belief of experienced students of public opinion, if the President achieved completely the end he deeired.

SHANGHAI, May 31 -- Germans and Italians in Shanghai make no efforts to hide their consternation on being named outspokenly by President Roosevelt in his Tuesday broadcast. Japanese financiers, politicians and business men believe that his failure to mention Japan might herald better relationships with the United States.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley's Third Covey captured the $5,000 added Paul Revere Handicap today at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 28,000. Gustave Ring's Ringle, 3-2 favorite, ran second by a half length.

SO often has the amazing story of John Paul Jones been narrated in biographical and fictional form that in choosing the outstanding hero of our infant Navy as central figure for a novel. Commander Ellsberg deserves credit for audacity.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- Even without the lure of an international tournament as a climax this year, members of society, who play and watch polo as their major outdoor sport, show no slackening of enthuisiasm as the season opens with the Sunday afternoon matches at Bostwick Field on the Jericho Turnpike, here.

Emancipation sets in early with the young of this land, if the clothes they wear are any sign. The new things in the stores for small fry to wear for play during their Summer vacations, being designed by older girls who no doubt suffered with hot pleated serge bloomers and middy blouses with ridiculous silk neckties in their own youth, are simply wonderful.

MUSIC has reached a low ebb in France, where conditions are such that it can no longer flourish, according to Isidor Philipp, the eminent French pianist and pedagogue, who has come to this country at the age of 78, a refugee, forced to begin life over again in a foreign land.

AT the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival at Tanglewood, between Stockbridge and Lenox, Mass., which opens Thursday night, July 31, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, will be assisted by the chorus of the Berkshire Musical Association, Horace Hunt, director, and the Berkshire Festival Chorus.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Asserting that the Federation Internationale de Ski, the world ruling body of the sport, is "a German-controlled organization," the National Ski Association of Ameri- ca has decided to withdraw its allegiance to this unit. This was made known yesterday by Roger Langley, president of the National Ski Association.

NATIONALLY known illustrators who have been preparing sketches of their conceptions of how future United States postal paper should look to measure up to world standards are frankly critical of the designs which the Postoffice Department has selected for the coming regular series of air-mail stamps and the air-mail stamped envelope.

DUBLIN, May 31 -- Premier Eamon de Valera and other officials of neutral Eire today sternly but silently inspected the devastation caused by four heavy-caliber bombs dropped upon Dublin by unidentified war planes early this morning.

Perhaps no garden literature holds more profound interest than that of herbs, for many of these plants have been cherished down through the centuries for their manifold uses and lore. And, perhaps, no bit of garden news is more thrilling than the account of a long lost herb being found or reintroduced.

Dress, sportswear, millinery and handbag departments were well patronized last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Calling attention to the growing scarcity of structural steel for building operations, Lawrence B. Elliman, head of the Pease Elliman realty firm, predicts a shortage of apartments, particularly those of the better type on the East Side, in the near future.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 31 -- Increasing resistance of the Norwegian people to the Nazi regime of Vidkun Quisling, despite an equally increased repression, is reported by the Stockholm Tidningen's special correspondent in Norway.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 31 -- British troops entered the outskirts of Baghdad today as the special fourman national defense committee created by Premier Rashid Ali el Gailani before he fled from Iraq sued for an armistice.

TO all the other articles of import that the war has reduced to the vanishing point, add published music. Whereas printed music, new and old, once came to America in abundance from Germany, Austria, France and Italy, there are now only two "open'' areas from which foreign editions can still be had.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- Lloyd Bissell, Buffalo, won the 20-gauge title in the New York State skeet championships today in a shoot-off with two rivals who tied him in regular competition, each with 98 targets out of 100.

LONDON. THE surprise with which the world has received the behavior of the British under bomb raids is itself rather surprising. How were we expected to behave? Ask the Irish Ambassador to convey our congratulations to Goering? Fly a bedsheet from Buckingham Palace flagpole?

Crispin Oglebay's Level Best proved herself an unusually good filly at Belmont Park yesterday when she led from end to end of the mile and three furlongs of the Coaching Club American Oaks to establish herself more than ever at the top of her division.

Dividends declared in May by 1,156 corporations amounted to $521,381,031, including a total of $4,011,701 by sixty-five banks and insurance companies. Aggregate distributions authorized last month were the largest for a May since 1937, when $524,198,349 was voted by 993 companies, of which $3,115,920 represented disbursements by forty-two banks and insurance institutions.

POLICIES: War Issue Clear Cut Your correspondents who bemoan the lack of a clear decision on war or peace in the last election and seek a referendum now upon that issue are oversimplifying the problems that confront us. Both President Roosevelt and Mr. Willkie advocated policies last November that could conceivably involve us in war.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 31 -- The United States will move nearer its goal of a two-ocean Navy next Saturday when the South Dakota, third powerful 35,000-ton battleship, will be launched four months ahead of schedule, it was announced here today.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- W. Neal Fulkerson Jr., former Long Island junior champion, and his partner, Everett (Red) Hoyt, two Garden City Golf Club members, who tied for the medal in yesterday's qualifying round of the Meadow Brook Club's invitation best-ball tourney, came to a sudden and somewhat unexpected halt in today's first round.

CHICAGO. LILLIAN GISH, by virtue of sixty-six weeks in "Life With Father" at Chicago's Blackstone Theatre, now takes her place beside the Lunts, Helen Hayes and Katharine Cornell as a truly national star.

John G. Winant, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, said yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt, where he is staying, that he had talked by telephone with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park and would report to the President in Washington on Tuesday.

A detailed report on the oil transportation situation will be made in Washington on Tuesday by a factfinding committee named by the American Petroleum Institute, W. P. Boyd, executive vice president of the institute, announced last night.
This year for the first time the Hunter College Summer session will be held in the new college building at 695 Park Avenue, beginning July 7, Director Broderick Cohen announced yesterday.

SEARCH for new art forms and techniques by radio's showmen soon will be further reflected in a new opera for the microphone. Randall Thompson, American composer, has just been commissioned by the Columbia Broadcasting System, acting jointly with the League of American Composers, to write a chamber opera of about thirty minutes' performance time.

MEXICO CITY, May 31 (AP) -- President Manuel Avila Camacho, answering a question concerning Mexico's position should the United States declare war on the Axis, declared tonight that the American nations form a "democratic unit" and if necessary Mexico "will take whatever measures are necessary to assure its sons a future of honor and independence."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 31 -- Racing will be revived at the Piping Rock Club here on June 14, when the United Hunts Racing Association will hold its Spring meeting on the historic club course, which was opened in 1912. The mile turf track, which was last used for racing in 1917, encircles the polo fields to the north of the clubhouse, in a setting reminiscent of picturesque pre-war English country-sides.

BERLIN, May 31 -- Unified British-Greek resistance on the Island of Crete has been broken on all fronts, German reports state, and the German forces are now engaged primarily in cleaning up scattered remnants of the defenders there. This is the picture of the progress of Axis operations on the Greek island, painted by official army and authoritative German quarters in Berlin tonight.

Yachtsmen would know there was a war abroad and a defense program at home if their only source book of information were Lloyd's Register. This annual stand-by, now in its thirty-ninth year of publication and due to make its appearance this week, is as indispensable on most pleasure craft as a steering wheel. It is a "must," a Who's Who, a dictionary, a cyclopedia.

Along comes June, serene and lovely as ever; so lovely that she puts out of mind for a moment the totalitarianism now defacing her earth and makes it seem far away on another planet, where it belongs.

More than eighty of the top women golfers of the district will set out tomorrow over the excellently groomed fairways of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club course at Mamaroneck, N.Y., in quest of the women's metropolitan championship now held by this writer, who took the trophy to White Beeches for the seventh time in 1940 after winning the final from Miss Grace Amory of Women's National.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Groups of Army flying cadets have been formed quickly among students of seven universities, the War Department reported today, raising official hopes of obtaining thousands of additional fledgling fliers from college campuses.

At 11 A.M. tomorrow Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, U.S.N., will take command of the navy yard in Brooklyn, where in the early days of his varied service he was stationed as a junior lieutenant in the ordnance department. He relieves Captain H.V. McKittrick, who has been acting commandant since the recent retirement of Rear Admiral Clark Howell Woodward.

An exhibition of flower arrangements will be held in the Rotunda of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on Tuesday at 5:15 P.M. The thirtytwo exhibitors are members of the flower-arrangement class organized by Matilda Rogers, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Teachers Association.

DETROIT, May 31 -- Lee Pressman, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today attacked the Congress of the United States and the "commercial press" as aiming, in their criticisms of strikes in defense projects, at the destruction of the rights of labor.

LONDON, May 31 (UP) -- The British Labor party assembles on Monday for its important annual conference which may direct attention to the party's loss of about 25 per cent of its active membership since the decision last year to enter the coalition government of Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- Before a crowd of 5,136, the Old Country Trotting Association's first Saturday harness horse racing program was held tonight at the welllighted Roosevelt Raceway. The program was the fourth of the Spring meeting which opened Wednesday and will resume Monday.

The remodeling work on the United Charities Building, 105 East Twenty-second Street, is nearing completion and plans are under way for a fiftieth anniversary celebration of the dedication of this structure.

SHERIFFS New York City's five Sheriffs are held by advocates of county reform to be an unnecessary burden on the taxpayers. Alfred E. Smith has compared them to "five tails on a dog." They are, like many other fixtures of our legal system, a hold-over from ancient English practice.

Manhattan College will open its commencement week-end activities next Friday night, when the annual senior dance will be held at the Park Central Hotel. This dance marks the end of examinations and is the closing function of the undergraduate extracurricular program.

Plans for work on 8,499 buildings were filed in the New York City Department of Housing and Buildings during the first four months of this year, according to Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports. The total estimated cost represented $67,379,201.

AFTER twenty years in the Hollywood gold mines, Carey Wilson is still one of the most colorful prospectors ever to stake a claim in those parts. To-day, as one of Louis B. Mayer's ministers without port folio, he is a many-sided fellow-liaison man and general "bug" eradicator for a production unit, occasional commentator for short subjects and, not too infrequently in the past, a "bootleg" writer on his own pictures.

LONDON, May 31 -- Aside from a British War Office bulletin this afternoon announcing that Major Gen. B.C. Freyberg, commanding in Crete, was alive and with his troops, there was no official news from Crete today. There was, however, an enigmatic statement that was believed to contain a reference to Iraq.

A report showing a higher percentage of physical fitness for military service in the age group ranging from 18 to 25 years than in the group ranging from 26 to 35, was submitted yesterday by Colonel Samuel J. Kopetsky, chief of the medical division, New York City Selective Service, to Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director.

AT a time when the entire world's interest is centered on military aircraft, another small private plane with built-in safety features and simplicity of operation has made its bow to the public and put in its bid for the title "Every man's plane of tomorrow."
