RYE, N.Y., May 31 -- An even half-dozen skippers took advantage of the holiday week-end to fortify their positions in the Y.R.A. championship standing today in the regatta held by the American Yacht Club by giving encores on yesterday's performances.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In this time of unlimited national emergency, are we as a people great enough not only to reach a decision but a decision based on reasons high enough to carry freedom through to victory?

CANAAN, N.Y., May 31 -- The fifty-fifth annual report of the Berkshire Industrial Farm, just published, shows in words and pictures how the institution works to make constructive citizens out of problem boys. The thirty-two page booklet is entirely the work of boys who are learning the printing trade.

ONE of the most momentous musical events of the season now closing was undoubtedly the festival given in this city by the International Society for Contemporary Music. It was momentous for its lessons, if not its creative results.

ACTIVITIES of the initial season of the New Opera Company, Mrs. Lytle Hull, president, will embrace performances by the Glyndebourne Company as well as its own productions. The schedule for the six-week series, which opens Oct. 14. at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre will comprise two operas by the Glyndebourne Company, as many by the New Opera Company itself, and two evenings of ballet presentations by an organization as yet unannounced.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 31 -- Analysis of President Roosevelt's "national emergency" speech Tuesday night in the light of recent public opinion measurements, shows a majority of the American people supporting Mr. Roosevelt on virtually every item he discussed.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- Another of the visiting players here for the Meadow Brook polo tournaments joined in the preliminary games today when Charles M. Armstrong rode with Mike Phipps's Westbury team against Laddie Sanford's Wheatley Hills four on Belmont Field.

Developers in many of the Long Island residential centers, not merely satisfied with erecting attractive homes at reasonable prices for prospective buyers and tenants, are showing a keener interest than in former years in providing various recreational features for the enjoyment of their community residents.

The New York Stock Exchange was open officially yesterday but traders were not impressed. Trading was the dullest and narrowest in nine months. Sales totaled only 107,100 shares, compared with 160,260 on the dull preceding Saturday, and of the 345 issues traded ninety-three rose, 127 fell and 125 were unchanged.

There are four quick-growing vines -- so quick-growing that the first season will see them covering porches, walls or trellises. They are the Kudzu-vine, the Hyacinth-bean (Dolichos lablab), the Japanese Hop and the Variegated Japanese Hop.

AS Summer approaches, the Park Department is rushing completion of recreation centers fashioned out of "leftover" bits of land, originally acquired with the right-of-way of the Belt Parkway. The new play areas add to the enjoyment of recreationminded motorists who use the scenic parkway and increase the benefits to be derived from the artery by communities along its route.

IF a desert were actually a place where nobody is and nothing grows, it could be described for the general reader in something less than the space of a book. But Mr. Corle truthfully remarks about his own medium-sized volume that it is "merely a brief glimpse" and that "a half dozen books of sim- ilar length could be written about the same subject without overlapping one another."

NEWTON, N.J., May 31 -- Paul Huissel, arrested yesterday evening when Sheriff Denton J. Quick closed the German-American Bund's Camp Nordland at Andover under the State's so-called nuisance law. was questioned for four hours this afternoon by two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and an immigration inspector at the Sheriff's office here.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- On July 1 some 820,000 young men who have attained the age of 21 years since Oct. 16, 1940, the first Selective Service registration day, will file into the offices of their local draft boards and add their names to the list of potential trainees.

LONDON, May 31 -- Following recent meetings of the International Tin and Rubber Regulation Committees, the International Tea Committee met here this week. Unlike tin and rubber, for which export quotas are fixed quarterly, fixing of the tea quota is taking place for the season running from April 1 to March 31.

If the plans of Mr. Francis H. Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and of the Columbia Broadcasting Company are realized the works of Rembrandt, Reynolds and other great masters will some day be seen on the television screens of hundreds of homes in all their fullness of color.

A four-day study of comments on the President's fireside speech, together with a re-examination of the speech itself, reinforces the conviction that the first and simplest interpretations were the correct ones. Deliberately, in carefully chosen words, the President stated the essential requirements of the defense of America.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 31 -- When President Roosevelt, now resting at his Hyde Park home, proclaimed an "unlimited national emergency" this week he placed himself in a position to employ extraordinary powers for the safety of the country.

OMAHA, Neb., May 31 -- From the start of the war the Middle West has been caught in the eddy of two violently conflicting emotions, a passionate desire to keep out of it and an almost equally passionate desire to see Adolf Hitler stopped on the eastern side of the Atlantic.

BOSTON, May 31 -- Frans van Cauwelaert, exiled President of the Belgian Chamber of Deputies, today broadcast an appeal from Boston to compatriots abroad. He warned against membership in Germany's "new order," which, he said, would sign Belgian defeat in advance.

A preliminary hearing was held at Ellis Island yesterday in the deportation proceedings against Dr. Kurt Heinrich Rieth, former German Minister to Austria and alleged No. 1 Nazi in this country, who was arrested at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel Thursday on four charges of violating the immigration laws.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 31 -- Cleveland will become America's medical center next week with the gathering here of thousands of the country's leading physicians and surgeons for the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

BECAUSE it breaks all the rules, "Deadline Dramas" is a fascinating radio program. Forgotten are rehearsals, script writers and directors. When the show goes on the air Sunday evenings at 10:30 over WEAF not even the cast knows what will happen next.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The 1941 Legislatures in several States enacted new measures to improve the administrative organization of public education at the State and local levels.

SELDOM has any contract bridge bidding method achieved widespread acceptance without first having been incorporated in a popular instruction book on the game. The outstanding exception is the slam-bidding convention devised by Easley Blackwood of Indianapolis.

Although the industry had no advance notice of the appointment of Secretary Ickes as petroleum coordinator on national defense, many oil executives have been of the opinion, especially since the transfer of fifty tankers from the domestic trade to move oil for the British war effort, that some such step had to be taken to assure proper allocation of petroleum products in the North Atlantic area of this country.

As the Summer season comes the insects that fly and crawl and creep, the water strider striding along the surface of the pools, the flashing dragonflies. blundering beetles, the bees, grasshoppers, crickets and the rest, provide for the patient and interested observer glimpses into a miniature world as beautiful as it is amazing.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Antitrust suits brought by the Department of Justice against twenty-two major oil companies and 344 subsidiaries will not be permitted to conflict with any regulatory program for the oil industry which Secretary Ickes may set up as Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense, Attorney General Jackson said today.

Society has outdone itself at Belmont Park during the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association which tomorrow enters the last week of its twenty-fourday program. Not only have all attendance records been broken at the gate but an all-time high has been set by the Turf and Field Club, which has been taxed beyond capacity several times to accommodate members and their guests.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator Byrd asserted today that practically no lease-lend equipment had been shipped to Great Britain in the two months since Congress approved the $7,000,000,000 appropriation implementing the British aid bill.

CLINTON, Conn., May 31 -- What would have been a real yacht race, with seventy starters, was turned into a hopeless drift in the main when the Off Soundings Club held its second and final run today, from Shelter Island to Duck Island Roads.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 19 -- "The policy of the Popular Front is peace and strict neutrality," said Carlos Contreras Labarca, Chilean Communist leader, to this correspondent today. "But the Socialists are trying to prepare Chile for entrance into the war."

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity continued its advance in the week ended May 24 and reached a new high at 128.4. It was 127.8 for the previous week and 104.4 for the week ended May 25, 1940.

In a week crowded with dramatic events throughout the world the most Significant was President Roosevelt's proclamation of an unlimited national emergency for the United States. What the emergency proclamation implied for the American future had yet to be revealed, but the step taken last Tuesday night appeared to indicate that the Roosevelt Administration was readying for action against the threat of worldwide totalitarian aggression.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Following are the texts of the letters exchanged between Dr. Quo Taichi, the new Foreign Minister of China, and Secretary of State Cordell Hull:

THE Peten, a broad rainsoaked jungle district lying partly in Mexico and partly in Guatemala, called the traveler Louis J. Halle Jr. to the glories of a vanished civilization. Here the archaeologist, "poking among roots and falling leaves, finds everywhere the magnificent remains of the Mayan Golden Age."

While millions of Americans celebrated yesterday the second day of the Memorial Day holidays there came from all parts of the country terse police reports of death in automobile accidents, fires and while swimming.

The government has notified the American President Lines that two more transpacific liners now in service would be requisitioned for use in the national defense program, it was reported here yesterday. It was considered likely that the two ships would be turned over to the Navy Department for use as naval auxiliaries.

THIS is the book of photographs from Herbert Kline's motion picture of life in a Mexican village, with John Steinbeck's story and explanatory foreword. That it is beautiful and evocative almost goes without saying: but a feature to be pointed out is that it is a simple transcript of individual reality.
Mayor La Guardia, widening his activities on the national scene, has at the same time added new complexities to the New York City political picture.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) -- Qualifying as a major threat for the $25,000 Hollywood Derby in July, Edward S. Moore's Battle Colors defeated eight rival 3-year-olds today in the $10,000 Will Rogers Memorial Handicap before 30,000 at Hollywood Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Hoped-for developments which would end the three-week strike of 1,900 A.F. of L. and C.I.O. machinists in eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards failed to materialize today as San Francisco and adjoining cities faced the prospect of a strike of 4,500 C.I.O. warehousemen on Monday.

IT takes such a book as this to make most of us realize what is involved in a defense program such as that on which the United States has embarked. After billions of dollars have been appropriated there are tremendous industrial problems to be solved, and it is of these that Mr. Finney, editor of The American Machinist, writes with illuminating clarity.

Although retail trade in New York early last week ran far ahead of a year ago, with some stores making gains of 25 per cent or more, yesterday's volume was disappointing and the average for the week was only up about 10 per cent, according to store executives.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Early returns from a nation-wide farmer referendum today gave a large margin for a Department of Agriculture proposal to establish rigid marketing quotas on this year's wheat crop.

Final examinations were completed yesterday by 4,500 New York University seniors, it was announced by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university, who made public the annual program of traditional social events that will end with the 109th annual commencement exercises June 11 on the Bronx campus.

There may seem to be an unbridgable gulf between the humble junkman with his spavined nag and battered wagon loaded with debris, and the giant industrial plants that are turning out war materials. But the gulf is more apparent than real and today the collector of waste materials has become one of the most important cogs in our colossal armament machinery.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- "Immediate and substantial increase" in the rate of pay for the enlisted men in American armed forces was urged upon Congress today by the annual delegate conference of the American Association of Social Workers.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Faced with "a serious shortage of copper," amounting to about 400,000 short tons this year, S.R. Stettinius Jr., Priorities Director of the Office of Production Management, set up mandatory, industry-wide controls today and ordered all copper refiners to pool each month an amount equal to 20 per cent of their April production, which will be available for emergency defense needs.

In spite or all efforts to maintain an academic balance in school life, education becomes increasingly preoccupied with the defense of the nation. Not long ago there were syllabi of peace in use in the schools; they gave way to syllabi for defense, and these are being supplanted to a considerable extent by programs of vocational training for the defense industries.

THE sixteenth annual session of the Bread Loaf Writers Conference, sponsored by Middlebury College, will be held from Aug. 18 to Aug. 30 at Bread Loaf, Vt., with Theodore Morrison as director. The staff will include Robert Frost, Louis Untermeyer, William Carlos Williams, Bernard DeVoto, Frances Woodward Curtis, Helen Everitt, John Marquand, John W. Gassner, Walter Prichard Eaton, Fletcher Pratt, Philip Cohen, Barbara Fleury, C. Raymond Everitt and Alan Collins.

NOW look out! The second big swing in baseball is on. The first big swing each year is merely what a seagoing man would call a "shakedown cruise." But the second swing -- East vs. West in both, leagues -- is for business purposes. That's when the rival clubs figure to give one another "the business." Consider the festivities starting at Ebbets Field today.

KENT, Conn. NEXT Thursday will be Prize Day at Kent School. The students and their families, as well as the old boys, will be seated on the grassy slope that stretches in front of the colonial dining hall, listening to addresses by some of the masters and trustees at the closing exercises.

Acting in his capacity of Federal Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, Mayor La Guardia appointed Governor Lehman yesterday to the post of Federal-State Director of Civilian Defense, to serve as a liaison officer to coordinate the State's defense program with that of the Federal government.

To the Drama Editor: A FEW years ago the government, through the WPA theatrical project, purchased several trucks which were well equipped for the presentation of musical shows and dramas. These trucks were moved around to the various parks and open spaces in New York City and afforded hundreds of thousands of citizens an opportunity to witness stage productions.

RIP VAN WINKLE loved to leave his little village and climb the Kaatskill Mountains with his dog, Wolf, and his trusty flintlock rifle. Rip had a better reason than to escape Dame Van Winkle's shrewish tongue and the blighted monotony of Nicholas Vedder'a opinions.

Reports from all of the popular lake resorts in the metropolitan district indicate that the demand for Summer homes this year is considerably larger than was the case one year ago at the present time. Evidences of a material increase in the families occupying vacation cabins was apparent in the recent Memorial holiday period in the large number of new cottages that had their first opening for the season.

Having completed yesterday the most active month of the year so far relative to flotations of new securities, the investment community looks forward with unusual interest to the first major tests of the compulsory competitive bidding rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission in the sale of public utility securities which is slated to take place this month.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Should you ask any one in Washington, outside of the rankest partisan, what the net effect of President Roosevelt's Tuesday night "fireside chat" was at the capital city, he would likely hesitate several moments before answering.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 31 -- The winning streak of Francisco (Pancho) Segura was brought to an end by Sidney B. Wood Jr. today as the former Wimbledon champion came from behind to defeat the 19year-old Ecuadorian in the invitation tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

OUTLINING in detail for the first time the work of the new Defense Short - Wave Listening Service, James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Comunications Commission, told the committee on communications of the American Bar Association that the service will prepare confidential daily summaries of foreign overseas broadcasts to keep United States officials informed of the objectives other countries are pursuing and their attitude toward this country.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 29:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 31 -- Philadelphia's first team and Baltimore remained the only undefeated entrants in the intercity tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association after the second round of play at Adelphi College today.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the second smallest of the year and the dullest for a corresponding month in twenty-seven years, or since 1914, just prior to the outbreak of the World War. The volume of 53,216,389 shares for this year to date is the smallest since 1915 for a corresponding period.

TRADE figures for the week will probably show less gain over last year as a result of the long holiday week end. Memorial Day fell on Thursday last year. Merchandise business, however, has seen a halt in the postEaster slackening.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 31 -- An Elbert County Negro, struggling over his questionnaire, has epitomized the predominant sentiment of the Southeast about the war. Scratching his head and perspiring profusely, he reached the conclusion that he could not in a year's time fill in the blanks with the proper answers, so he turned the sheet over and wrote on it:

SPEAKING recently before the convention of the American Booksellers Association in Washington. A A. Berle Jr. Assistant Secretary of State, concluded his address with some reflections upon the power of the written word which have a special pertinence for oui time.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Further expansion of inventory and price curbs was foreseen as inevitable by industrial buyers of the nation as the annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents closed here. They struggled valiantly during the week with the problem of adjusting purchasing policies to meet defense needs and forestall a runaway price inflation, while at the same time seeking safeguards against threats to production because of shortages and delayed deliveries.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The University of Michigan won the Big Ten tennis championship as expected today, but its ace player, Jim Tobin, fell before defending Champion Seymour Greenberg of Northwestern in the competition for the singles crown.

There has been a sudden rise in the last two years in the vehicular movement of vehicles to and from Manhattan south of Sixty-first Street, following a leveling off with only minor gains from 1930 to 1938, the Regional Plan Association disclosed yesterday.
After an absence of eleven years, professional tennis returns to the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, this week.
NEW YORK Mrs. Potter Palmer is expected at the Pierce today from Washington.

LONDON, May 31 -- The British Navy wrote "Finis" to Germany's newest and biggest battleship this week when the guns of the King George V and the Rodney silenced the Bismarck -- a success obviously offset by the severe British losses in Crete.

MAX REITER, conductor of the San Antonio Symphony Orchestra, recently received a letter from Sir Henry Wood thanking him for conducting the first American performance of the British conductorcomposer's "Fantasia on British Sea Songs."

GERMANY'S use of gliders for troop transports in the invasion of Crete has proved that motorless planes can play an important role in war. Gliders have many advantages over parachutes. They are harder to detect; eight men in a glider can slip silently in where eight men in parachutes would be spotted.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The following Foreign Service changes since May 10 were announced by the State Department today: Donald R. Hath of Topeka. Kan., first secretary of the embassy at Berlin, has been designated first secretary of the embassy and consul at Santiago, Chile.

JERSEY CITY, May 31 (AP) -- The Newark Bears made a clean sweep of their series with Jersey City today by handing the Little Giants a 3-to-0 defeat in the third game of the set. Young Tommy Byrne outlasted the veteran Bill Harris in a brilliant pitchers' battle.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 31 -- The Columbia Lions were beaten, 9 to 1, by Harvard in their final Eastern Intercollegiate League game today.

ONE day in early March, at Svolvaer, within the Arctic Circle, the local newspaper had a paragraph in English on its front page: "Welcome to Lofoten! Today Svolvaer and the Lofoten Islands have the great pleasure to see Her Excellency Mrs. F.J. Harriman, the Minister of America, here" -- so on, with the rest of the hearty greeting.

LONDON. MENTION has previously been made in these letters of the handicap British book production is suffering through the rationing of paper supplies. The immediate and obvious effect of this shortage is to limit the output of new publications.

THE firm toehold that Germany and Italy have obtained in South America through their commercial airlines may soon be lost. And the more than 20,000 route miles they have flown back and forth across the continent to the south, without regard to traffic demands or the lack thereof, may soon be covered ay airlines owned and operated by the United States and the various Latin-American countries.
LONDON, May 31 -- In the last few weeks there ware only occasional violent squalls to disturb the dead calm of Anglo-French relations, but today storm clouds hang over the two nations.

A CAVALCADE of American Song," for the benefit of the New York Committee for Aid to Agricultural Workers, will be presented by Earl Robinson and Will Geer at Town Hall Wednesday night. Complete programs for the current week follow:

Beginning tomorrow, the New York Stock Exchange bond tape will carry occasional bids and offers on bonds. When necessary, size as well as price will be indicated. This information will appear on the lower line of the tape in this form: ".S.10.5," meaning, "Size, 10 bid for, 5 offered."

A CAVALCADE of American Song," for the benefit of the New York Committee for Aid to Agricultural Workers, will be presented by Earl Robinson and Will Geer at Town Hall Wednesday night. Complete programs for the current week follow:

Beginning tomorrow, the New York Stock Exchange bond tape will carry occasional bids and offers on bonds. When necessary, size as well as price will be indicated. This information will appear on the lower line of the tape in this form: ".S.10.5," meaning, "Size, 10 bid for, 5 offered."
TO melt the too, too solid flesh of the ink-stained and grease-painted great who frequent its dining rooms, a hotel noted for its following among the literati has inaugurated a special menu.

THE interior decorators are all set to take care of big country houses, or beach cottages, but few of them give much thought to people spending Summer in town in an apartment. A lot of perfectly well-washed citizens do stay right on during the Summer without minding too much; they would probably mind it even less if their apartments could be more of an oasis and less of a hot dustbin.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- For the past few months Washington has been asking whether the United States would go to war with Germany. It is perhaps significant that this question is now being turned around. The experts are asking this week-end: Will Germany go to war with us?

DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- Overcoming a slow start, Alas, bay mare owned by Charles C. Harrison 3d of the Chuckswood Farm of White Horse, Pa., closed with a rush to be crowned champion hunter of the Devon horse show, which came to a close this evening.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 31 -- Army-Navy Day at the historic Point was a tremendous success for United States Military Academy teams. The nation's service schools clashed in baseball and track and field today, and in both sports the cadets came from behind to sink the middies from Annapolis.

In the mountains of Crete, where snow lies the year round, on the Iraqi plain where the Garden of Eden may once have flourished, and across the flinty wastes of Western Egypt, the Battle of the Mediterranean raged last week. In the first of the three theatres of conflict the Nazi military machine scored a triumph.

DALLAS, Texas, May 31 -- An atmosphere of calm determination to halt the Hitler war machine by use of every means available to the United States prevails in the Southwest, whose people have been made more and more aware of the gigantic task facing the nation by continued British disasters.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- One of the resort's most beautiful displays, the Atlantic City Flower Mart, will be held Friday and Saturday in City Park at Indiana Avenue, just off the Boardwalk.

WENDELL, WILLKIE, private citizen, gets an average of 2,000 letters a day. He is now a partner in the law firm of Willkie, Owen, Otis Bailey, but this mail has nothing to do with his legal practice. He makes about two personal appearances a week at big dinners and similar functions, and he has made, on request, some twelve speeches since last November.

A survey of housing conditions just completed by the Bergen County Chamber of Commerce, N.J., indicated very clearly that private developers are showing their ability to cope with all home needs created by the shifting of population in the county due to the industrial expansion caused by the Federal defense program.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A re-examination of the competitive situation between American and foreign ocean shipping lines operating out of the United States to determine whether American-flag lines need further Federal subsidies under present conditions was announced today by the United States Maritime Commission.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- A woman news photographer, an industrial designer and a motion picture leader were honored by Syracuse University at its annual alumni dinner tonight.
The free distribution to all Army training camps in the United States and possessions of the books issued by the Book-of-the-Month Club is announced by Harry Scherman, president of the club.

IT is the season when the old grads flock back to dear old Siwash. There being some 1,700 dear old Siwashes in the land, including 650 of the four-year, liberal-arts sort, and their living finished product numbering close to three million souls, not counting the thousands who didn't reach the finish line, this annual going-back takes on the magnitude of a folk movement.

JERSEY CITY, May 31 -- A spectacular fire, endangering an estimated $25,000,000 in defense materials, laid waste an area one-fourth mile square on the waterfront here tonight. Federal and local investigations were begun at once.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 -- A total of $29,985 was laid tonight in the laps of three men who shared in the first-place spoils of yesterday's split victory in the twenty-ninth annual Indianapolis Motor Speedway 500mile race.

NOTHING in town just now is grander than the sight and sound of Bernard Shaw in a brief prologue to the film version of "Major Barbara." In his eighty-fifth year the foremost man of letters in the modern world sits down for a chat with distant Americans.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: IN your edition of May 11 you carry a review of my book, "Big Business, Efficiency and Fascism," over the signature of Elliott V. Bell. No economist dedicated to the bard way, the statistical way, and no liberal critical of anything in these good United States can afford to cavil over particulars when his work is noticed in the literary review of our leading conservative newspaper.

WHEN President Roosevelt, in his historic address to the world last Tuesday night, predicted the eventual disruption of the Nazi system of domination in Europe through uprisings of the conquered peoples -- including the German and Italian peoples -- he did more than express a pious hope.

STANTON, Del., May 31 -- Taking the lead at the drop of the flag, the Brandywine Stable's fleet 3-year-old Madigama led throughout today to win the fourth running of the $5,000 added Wilmington Handicap at Delaware Park. He paid $11.30 for $2.

LONDON. TWO more additions have been made this week to the short but now most solid battle line of the West End stage. The Sadler's Wells Ballet opened a season at the New Theatre, and "Up and Doing," a first-rate musical show with Leslie Henson and Binnie Hale in the leading roles, returned to the Saville from exile.

RYE, N.Y., May 31 -- Hillbrook, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. George Arents here, will draw hundreds of visitors from New York and throughout Westchester on the afternoon of June 19 for the second in the series of Spring garden parties given for the benefit of the WestChester County Children's Association.

Three ships of the Eastern Steamship Line have been tied up by strike action in Norfolk, Va., since last Wednesday because the seamen on board did not know that an agreement had been reached between the operators and their union temporarily settling differences, it was disclosed yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- Amassing 19 1/2 points in seven events, Nott Terrace High School of Schenectady captured top honors in the city's first annual interscholastic track and field carnival today.

Those miraculous new plastic materials which modern designers delight to work in are now putting in a smart appearance as a sheathing or paneling for furniture. Sheets of plastics, to which various patterns and colors are given by means of a new photographic process -- some of them surprisingly like fabrics -- are used to panel the front of a chest of drawers or to cover the top of a dining table.

It was a long time in coming, but the championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. finally returned to New York City yesterday for the first time since Columbia won the crown back in 1879. New "York University slammed through to a rather easy victory in the sixty-fifth annual title show before 10,000 in Triborough Stadium.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The mountain laurel is due to begin its blooming season in the Poconos about June 10 and for ten days thereafter will present an attractive display of delicate bell-like blooms in the woods and along the trails.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 31 (AP) -- The Worcester Chamber of Commerce disclosed today what happens to an industrial center when a flood of defense orders hits. Since this day a year ago, approximately $50,000,000 in defense orders have been placed in this city of 200,000 in a wide variety ranging from gun barrels to wire for submarine nets.
Changes in sailing schedules for Grace Line Santa ships, affecting those engaged in both the Caribbean and South American services, were announced yesterday by the management of the line.

TWO of the group shows of the week are essentially modern in complexion. At the Lilienfeld Gallery still-life by French and American artists is the theme and a Vlaminck with all the dramatic vigor of the landscapes, together with flower and fruit pieces by Derain, rather carry off the honors.

The part being played by the electric power and light industry in aiding the nation's industrial establishments to meet the ever-increasing demands of the national defense program is the keynote for the ninth annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute, which will open tomorrow in Buffalo and will continue through Thursday.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 31 -- President Roosevelt today made Secretary Ickes virtual czar of the $10,000,000,000 American oil industry when he named the Secretary of the Interior as "Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense" and ordered him to make certain that in this emergency "the supply of petroleum and its products will be accommodated to the needs of the nation and the national defense program."

BROADCASTING is celebrating its first anniversary of operating in the interest of national defense. Enlisted "100 per cent" behind the rearma ment program of Uncle Sam, the microphone is now tackling the biggest job in all its twenty-odd year of history.

To THE EDITOR or THE NEW YORK TIMES: Tom Ireland's letter in THE TIMES is not unlike other letters written to the American press in having the common ailment of thought in refusing to grant Eire's declared policy of neutrality per se any validity.

To the Screen Editor: As "Fantasia" nears the end of its sixth month we at the office of the Broadway Theatre, in recapitulation, feel that many of the incidents which have taken place here at the theatre might be worthy of seeing the light in print.

AN improvisation of considerable virtuosity, often entertaining but frequently offending, a medley of stunt passages, occasional scherzos of imagination, bits of mad waggery, stretches of crudeness and thunders on the left, echoes of everything from everywhere, witty and tender, blatant and blah by turns, at the same time by no means without serious intention, Mr. Batch's first opus shoots the works.
TULSA, Okla., May 31 (AP) -- News of the appointment of Secretary Ickes as Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense was received with widespread expressions of disappointment today in Tulsa.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here closed on a strong note today after some sharp declines early in the session. Commission house bids on the set-back, with short covering for the week-end, changed the trend, and at the finish the list registered net gains of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel.

THE author of "New Hampshire Neighbors" has named his third book about them by way of quite uncalled-for apology. It used to be said of one of them, in tones implying he must be slightly touched in the head, that "Loveland Mines be haying till snow falls," to which Loveland invariably countered.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 31 -- Public opinion in the Pacific Northwest, once strongly isolationist, now is weighted heavily in favor of all aid to Great Britain short of war, and many voices advocate belligerent action short only of an American expeditionary force.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said tonight that the Battle of Crete demonstrated that the British Isles were vulnerable to air invasion, which some responsible British circles expect in August.

WHEN a 2-year-old steps about on your feet as you're trying to button him, walks off unfinished if the notion takes him, licks out with his tongue at a washcloth, says, "Uh," with a vigorous shake of his head, meaning, "No" -- he may be hard to put up with, but he is running true to form.
Now that the surf fishing season is really under way the mail is filled with letters from men who want to try this sport but seem baffled by the problems of tackle, equipment and places to fish.

ROME, May 31 -- Italian troops were yesterday moving westward in Crete to make a junction with the German forces, it was announced here today. Nothing is stated about the meeting of any opposition and it seems that the battle is considered here to be virtually all over, with the problem being one of preventing as many Imperial and Greek forces as possible from getting away.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A record total of taxes paid by the liquor industry in 1940 was claimed today by the Distilled Spirits Institute, which said the national and local Treasuries received $1,140,110,006 in revenue from alcoholic beverages last year. The Federal Government's share was $753,364,607, according to a report of an annual study by the institute. The over-all total exceeded 1939 by $130,000,000.

MILITARY MAN: Another commencement came last week to the campus of Hobart and William Smith Colleges on the pleasant shores of New York's Lake Seneca. President William Alfred Eddy bade farewell to the graduating class; it meant farewell to the institution he has headed since 1936.

THE building of the Erie Canal furnishes the background for this well-written, interesting story. When in 1823 the yellow fever epidemic raging in New York City made Emeline and Stephen Davis orphans, an aunt, their only relative, offered them a home with her in Albany.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- Dr. Augustus H. Shearer, one of the nation's foremost librarians, who was in charge of the Buffalo Grosvenor Reference Library and its 350,000 volumes for nearly a quarter of a century, died today after an illness of two months.

BRIELLE, N.J. -- Since deep-sea fishing for sport from boats was first established as a part of the Summer program of outdoor activities at New Jersey resorts little more than a decade ago it has become one of the coastal section's favorite recreations.

After four weeks of sharp gains, the cotton market turned easier last week and closed with moderate net losses for the period. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 10 to 19 points.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 1 -- Preservatlon and strengthening of social gains and services through governmental and group action at essentials in national defense and the struggle for the maintenance of democracy were stressed as the National Conference of Social Works opened for a week's sessions here tonight with an address by Jane M. Hoey, president of the conference.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn sold to the Higger Neon Sign Company the one-story brick building on a plot 50 by 95 feet at 1253 Atlantic Avenue, between New York and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn. The building, which is assessed at $20,000, will be altered and occupied by the new owner, according to the Bulkley Horton Company, broker in the sale.

The gold medal and $1,000 cash prize of the Theodore N. Vail Memorial Fund, highest national honor given to employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has been awarded to a woman who was its first recipient twenty years ago and whose recent courageous service was practically a repetition of her previous experience.

MANCHESTER, Term., June 1 -- Within a 600-square-mile triangle of Northeastern Tennessee and on the scene of one of the fiercest engagements of the Civil War 77,000 troops of the Seventh Army Corps, under Major Gen. Frederic H. Smith, are poised tonight for training exercises that signal the first large-scale Army manoeuvres of 1941.

LONDON, June 1 -- Heavy and sad, though not unexpected, was the news that the War Office announced of Crete tonight. It said that 15,000 British troops had been withdrawn after twelve days of the most furious fighting of this war. "It must be admitted that our losses have been severe," the War Office said.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 1 -- The inauguration of the new Panagra air service from La Paz to Corumba, Brazil, about 1,200 miles, with stops at Cochabamba and Santa Cruz, Bolivia, is definitely fixed for Tuesday at 9 A.M. The first flight will be made with aviation officials and Panagra pilots to get acquainted with the route.

DUBLIN, June 1 (AP) -- Early today foreign planes that eluded searchlights of Eire's home defense, and that may have been responsible for the Arklow bombing, flew over Kingstown [Dun Laoghaire], on Dublin Bay, but dropped no bombs there.

LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- When British torpedoes sent the German battleship Bismarck to the bottom of the Atlantic on Tuesday morning they "frustrated important enemy designs," the First Lord of the Admiralty, A.V. Alexander, said tonight.

Warning that the danger of prosperity is arrogance, but that the danger of adversity is cowardice, the Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Sizoo, the pastor, pleaded yesterday in his sermon in the St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, for "a finer and more adventurous faith which has no room for self-pity, and which does not surrender to despair."

PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP) -- The government sought today by conciliation to end a strike of 3,200 freight truck drivers and helpers which threatened the movement of defense materials in thirteen Eastern States.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 1 -- Two craft that sailed today in the first of five special Summer regattas of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club scored; their third triumphs of the season in as many days. They were Freeman L. Meinertz's Atlantic Class sloop Bobkat and Frank E. Campbell's new Star Rascal.

My favorite hard case of the season is that stubborn 6-year-old named Joe Marsden, a brat whose woes have been hinted at from time to time in magazines and are now surveyed in book form. Frances Eisenberg, his champion and discoverer, says blandly, "There's One in Every Family."* Well, not in mine, but perhaps among the families of Knoxville, Tenn., where both Joe and Miss Eisenberg hail from.

Flight Lieutenant Richard H. Hilary, 22-year-old fighter pilot of the Royal Air Force who was shot down in a fight over the English Channel, arrived here yesterday with a group of 190 visitors from Great Britain, including fifty-five young women who will work in the British Embassy in Washington.

A procession of seniors representing eleven colleges and schools of Columbia University marched in cap and gown yesterday afternoon from the Low Memorial Library to St. Paul's Chapel to attend the annual baccalaureate service marking the opening of Columbia's 187th commencement program.

People Per Square Mile Density of population per square mile in the United States jumped from 41.1 to 44.2 in the 1930-40 decade. To the pioneer spirit the country may seem to be getting alarmingly crowded; but the latest available figures from other lands -- France, 196; Japan, 349; Germany, 360; Italy, 433; England, 742; Holland, 610 -- assure us that we have nothing much to worry about yet.

VICHY, France, June 1 -- Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan's broadside against Britain had pride of place in every newspaper this morning, illustrated in what now has become classic style with a portrait of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, on the left of the page and one of the admiral himself on the right.

So far as concerned our own financial markets, the President's so-called "fireside chat" fell flat. This may have been because no fresh information as to the Administration's purposes was contained in it, or possibly because of the obscurity in which the whole position was placed by the next day's press conference comments on Tuesday's broadcast.
BERLIN, June 1 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1 -- Yale today announced awards to 153 members of Spring sports teams. Point winners in the track meets with Harvard and Princeton gained the major insignia.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Offer of mediation in the European and Asiatic wars, nationalization of defense and other industries and the banking and credit systems and Pan-Americanization of the Panama Canal were some of the measures advocated today in resolutions adopted at closing sessions of the second National Anti-War Congress.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1 -- To fifteen working newspapermen, including five connected with newspapers, news services or magazines in New York City, have been awarded Nieman Fellowships for study at Harvard University on leave of absence from their posts during the academic year starting in September.

LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill told Canadians tonight that the British Empire, "with the Old World and the New World together," would see the war through to a victorious end and that Canada would "play her just part in the laying of the foundation of a wider and better world."

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Weather and crop reports have temporarily displaced the government loan on the 1941 wheat crop as the dominating influence in the Pit here. Signing of the loan bill had little effect on the market, nor did imposition of import quotas on wheat.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 1 -- A large proportion of the more than 700 members of the Society of Automotive Engineers, who are expected to register for the Summer meeting, arrived here today in time for the annual dinner this evening.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., June 1 -- Water from scores of fire hoses played constantly over docks of oil companies at Los Angeles Harbor today, on advice of the Coast Guard.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- House action this week on the largest military appropriation bill offered since the World War is expected to be the leading subject before Congress this week, although other matters, chiefly affecting the defense program, will be up for consideration.

TOKYO, Monday, June 2 (UP) -- The Japan Times Advertiser, which often reflects the view of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, in a long editorial Sunday denounced Mr. Roosevelt's extension of United States export control regulations to the Philippines as "highly provocative" and urged Filipinos to "brook no artificial measures of blockade."
As the bitter battle of Crete raged last week several Important steps to solve what is rapidly becoming a shipping shortage of grave proportions were taken in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A series of special conferences on the power situation will begin this week between Chairman Leland Olds of the Federal Power Commission and the country's electric utility officials it was announced today.

Because our civilization rests on a spiritual and religious basis, we must look to our spiritual defense while we arm against physical invasion, Herbert E. Gaston, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, declared yesterday at the first annual communion breakfast of the St. George Association of the United States Treasury Department at the Hotel Biltmore.

ALBANY, June 1 -- The fourteenth and final requisition of the Army for the first year of the selective service has been announced today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State director. The call Is for 4,910 men, to be delivered in the two weeks from June 16 to 27, inclusive, at the Buffalo and Fort Jay (Governors Island) induction stations.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- All deliveries of corn sold last week on the Board of Trade were at the highest prices since 1937. Much of the buying, however, was professional, and late in the week bullish sentiment was dampened by a forecast of general rains over the main producing areas within the next few days.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 1 -- Future winners of the Spring invitation member-guest best-ball golf tournament at the Tamarack Club will have a real mark to shoot at to match the performance of Emil Talman and Neil White, who routed Larry Elliott and Jerry Warren in the thirty-six-hole final today.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 1 -- Albert C. Bostwick, the noted horseman, proved his versatility today when he and his partner, Richard Myers, gained top honors in the annual best-ball invitation golf tournament staged at the Meadow Brook Club, scene of the famous international polo matches in past years.

Giving away thirteen seconds by handicap, Miss Marilyn Sahner of the Women's Swimming Association, starting from scratch, lost by a yard to her team-mate, Miss Barbara Yodice in the 100-yard freestyle event at the A.A.U. outdoor swimming meet in the Ostend Beach Baths in Far Rockaway yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A saltsprayed, slogging freighter plowing through the North Atlantic swell suggests none of the drama of war, but in the current struggle one such freighter is as priceless as a silvery bomber and perhaps more essential than guns themselves.

T.J. Carlyle Gifford, special agent of the British Treasury in charge of sales here of British-owned United States securities, issued yesterday his monthly report on liquidation. He stated that in May eighteen stock and twenty-three bond issues had been liquidated in their entirety.

Although the arrival of the Dixie Clipper was enjoyed yesterday by several hundred spectators standing patiently on the roof of the Pan American Airways marine terminal at La Guardia Field despite a cold, moist breeze, the "I am not talking" attitude of its forty-two passengers resulted in a vocal void.

Alexander Kirkland announced over the week-end the acquisition of "Flight Into China," by Pearl S. Buck, Miss Buck's drama, tested about two years ago at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., deals with the absorption of some Jewish families who fled Germany for China in the last century.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force's Cairo communique follows:

Higher prices and slower deliveries continued to trouble the wholesale markets last week. Interest in the early purchase of Fall merchandise gathered momentum, as retailers found it impossible in many lines to get deliveries on reorders for current selling.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has "adopted" her third child war refugee, it was disclosed yesterday by Mrs. Edna Blue, executive chairman of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, 55 West Forty-second Street. The 3 1/2-year-oId British boy, Thomas Maloney, is one of nine children in rural refuges maintained in the British Isles by the Foster Parents Plan.

The Reds, looking rather woebegone for world champions, and the Giants, who do not appear to be as fresh as daisies either, tugged at each other for about four hours under a leaden sky at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 -- The British Army's reluctant decision to break off the desperate battle in Crete, which had steadily gone against them ever since the first German parachutists landed on the morning of May 20, was announced in a special communique of the Headquarters of the Middle East Command here this evening.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- An extensive increase in American Red Cross service to the nation's armed forces, including the trebling during the past year of trained staff workers assigned to the military establishment, was reported to the 3,700 Red Cross chapters today by Chairman Norman H. Davis in his annual report.

Hugh Walpole never quite took the place of John Galsworthy. But he stood solidly beside him and kept alight the torch which fell from Galsworthy's hand. Indeed, Walpole always believed he anticipated his friend in the introduction of those saga series which flowered so perfectly in the generations of the Forsyte family.
DUBLIN, June 1 -- The Irish Government announced tonight that a strong protest was being made at Berlin, as it formally accused the Germans of the bombing of Dublin early yesterday.

OTTAWA, June 1 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Prime Minister W.L. MacKenzie King and Justice Minister Ernest Lapointe figuratively clasped hands across the seas tonight in a two-nation broadcast send-off for Canada's $600,000,000 Victory Loan Campaign which opens tomorrow.

Government employes have no right to strike or to demand a closed shop, in the opinion of a special committee appointed by the National Civil Service Reform League to study government employe relationships. In a report made public yesterday the committee said striking civil service workers should be ousted from their jobs "with loss of all benefits that the merit system implies."

The dedication of a stained-glass window yesterday during the morning service of the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, completed a project begun forty years ago. Dedicated to the memory of Carl Pickhardt, a founder of the church, by his family, the thirty-foot panel is the eighth and final one in a series started with the founding of the church.

BERLIN, June 1 -- It was said in Berlin tonight that the invasion of Crete had now successfully been completed. With the joining of hands between Italian and German forces at Ierapetra, which occurred yesterday, the single harbor at all navigable on the otherwise precipitous southern Cretan coast is in Axis hands.

THE last time the Pirates were in Boston the umpires thumbed Managers Frisch and Stengel off the field during the same afternoon. They met in the clubhouse and talked things over. They discussed their own clubs and their rivals and talked of possible trades and purchases. They talked of umpires, too. Not favorably.
DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -- Manager Joe Cronin and his Red Sox mates squared the season's accounts at four victories each with the Tigers today by taking a pair of close games, 7 to 6 and 6 to 5.

BERLIN, Monday, June 2 (UP) -- Germany today jubilantly hailed her air-borne conquest of Crete as "Britain's greatest defeat of the war" and said that great numbers of British troops were trapped while trying to escape by sea under a final fury of German bombings.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CARLSTADT, N.J., June 1 -- Freddy Jacoby Jr., the country's point scoring champion, today picked up where be left oft last Fall and stole nearly the whole show on the Hackensack River in the twelfth annual regatta for the New Jersey outboard motorboat championships.

The New York American defeated Brooklyn Hispano, 5-3, and Brookhattan downed St. Mary's Celtic, 5-2, in the round-robin soccer tournament for the Duffy Cup at Starlight Park yesterday before 3,000 fans.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 1 -- Triple victories attained by Law Dunbar and the imported Dalchoolin, both owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll and piloted by Gordon Wright, were among the highlights of the Professional Horsemen's Association, horse show today at the Lawridge Stables.
ROME, June 1 -- The official English text of today's broadcast by Pope Pius XII follows:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The War and Navy Departments announced the award yesterday of defense supply contracts totaling $9,047,574.16. The firms in the New York area which were among those receiving awards, not previously published, are as follows:

VICHY, June 1 -- There is no attempt to conceal the fact that the government's plan to reconstruct the national economy on a new basis offers great difficulties. That is why the central power, while reserving the sole right to make decisions, is seeking to inform itself on all questions to be settled by consulting the persons considered most competent in these matters.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 1 -- Two breed organizations combined forces today with their specialty shows to give a most successful exhibition in the Westchester County Center. The Poodle Club of America staged its tenth annual event, while the Boston Terrier Club of Westchester held its seventh annual show.

Time alone will reveal the comparative strategic effects of the British disaster in Crete and the collapse of the Nazi-inspired revolt in Iraq. By a dramatic and unexpected conjunction in time one coincides with the other. As the British defense of Suez is suddenly imperiled from an island front they had thought their own, so the fire set in their rear is extinguished.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 1 (AP) -- "It is not America as it is that ought to be saved, but America as it ought to be," the Right Rev. Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America declared today in his baccalaureate sermon before the graduation class of the University of Notre Dame.
BUFFALO, June 1 (AP) -- Two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents killed a 27-year-old bank robber suspect at noon today in a gun battle near Buffalo's downtown district.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale prices remained at the previous week's level of 92.4. This is only the second time within the past three months that the all-commodity index failed to rise. Moreover, the net effect of the week's price changes was to leave each of the major commodity group price indexes at the same level as a week ago.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- The British War Office issuea this statement today:

Confirmation services were held in many synagogues yesterday as the first day of Shabuoth was observed. Sermons pointing out that the ancient Jewish faith in the fatherhood of God and the brotherhood of man was one of the principal roots of democracy were preached by many rabbis.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 1 -- With his best early season performance in recent years, Sidney B. Wood Jr. defeated Frank Bowden today to win the invitation turf court tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

BERLIN, June 1 -- Stocks advanced along the whole line of the Berlin Boerse last week in one of the busiest periods since the scare resulting from the announcement of dividend restrictions by Economics Minister Walther Funk on March 12. The stock index rose 5 points in the week to 193.06 on Friday for one of the biggest weekly gains since the outbreak of the war.

VICHY, France, June 1 -- The fate of France's captive soldiers, of whom there are nearly 2,000,000, is close to the heart of the nation, and all communiques regarding them are read avidly. The latest one issued by Georges Scapini, "Ambassador for Prisoners," was no exception.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Jimmy Dykes's White Sox sneaked into first place in the American League today, splitting a double-header with the Senators while the Indians were losing twice to the Yankees.

LONDON, June 1 -- Although sentiment on the stock markets was of a subdued nature toward the end of the week as a result of the increasingly precarious situation of the British forces in Crete, and reflecting the influence on business of the near Whitsun holiday, the net result was a further modest appreciation in security values as a whole.

Admiral Hermann Boehm, German Naval Commander in Chief in Norway, who was reported a suicide in dispatches from London on Saturday "is full of health at his post," according to a dispatch by the German Transocean Agency received here yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 1 -- The Social Democratic Federation of California has issued a public statement declaring that Norman Thomas, "Socialist leader," does not represent the once influential American Socialist movement of Eugene V. Debs, Victor L. Berger, Benjamin Hanford and their modern followers.

CHUNGKING, China, June 1 -- The declaration of Secretary of State Cordell Hull that the United States intends to negotiate for the abolition of American extraterritoriality in China, together with his pronouncement last week that United States policy toward Japan is unchanged, has done much to reassure China that the American attitude remains firmly pro-Chinese and opposed to Japanese aggression against China.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1 (AP) -- Shattering 100 straight targets for the first time in his competitive career, Jack Kerr, Buffalo aircraft engineer, today won the New York State all-bore skeet championship.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., June 1 -- This anti-aircraft training center, comprising more than 13,000 troops, was under intensive guard today as regimental sentries were doubled and some of the units ordered to stand by on "alert."

HOLLYWOOD, June 1 (UP) -- Jenny Dolly, 48, who with her twin sister, Roszika, formed the once internationally famous dance team, the Dolly Sisters, was found dead in her Hollywood apartment late today hanging from a noose fastened to a curtain rod.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 1 -- Animal experiments showing how a combination of two dietary factors can prevent degeneration and cirrhosis of the liver, as well as degeneration and hemorrhage of the cortex (covering) of the kidneys, were demonstrated here today.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- Among comments which Sir Hugh had made on his literary work were the following:

PORT WORTH, Texas, June 1 (AP) -- An impressive platoon of golfing celebrities tried to find some "soft touches" in the Colonial Club course today, but when they were through they merely had strengthened a growing impression that the forty-fifth United States open golf championship will be as much of a scramble as any of its predecessors.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 1 -- There were persistent rumors in diplomatic quarters here today that the Vichy government is actively preparing to withdraw its "frontier authorities" a further twenty-five kilometers [a kilometer is .621 of a mile] eastward from the strip of occupied territory along the Atlantic coast.

With millions of Americans clogging highways and taxing transportation facilities throughout the nation as they ended their Memorial Day week-end yesterday, it was reported that more than 400 persons had been killed in automobile and other accidents.
CLEVELAND, June 1 -- By way of entertaining the largest American League crowd of the season, the Yankees submerged the Indians twice today and crept nearer the circuit lead.
VICHY, France, June 1 -- France today has sent a second protest to Great Britain which Ambassador Francois Bietri in Madrid has delivered to the British Ambassador, Sir Samuel Hoare.

Pentecost Sunday, which ranks after Easter as the second most important liturgical feast on the calendar of the Roman Catholic Church, was observed yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a pontifical mass celebrated by the Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 (AP) -- Thousands of British and Imperial soldiers and their Greek allies, worn by the strain of thirteen days of fierce but unavailing fighting to hold Crete against the most furious attack yet launched by the Nazi air might, were in Egypt tonight.

The need today of a more wellknitted fellowship within the Christian Church was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robbins Wolcott Barstow, president of the Hartford Seminary Foundation, Hartford, Conn., who occupied the pulpit of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew as guest preacher.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 1 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles took both games of a double-header from Jersey City today, rallying for five runs In the eighth inning of the opener to win, 8 to 7, and grabbing the nightcap, 2 to 0.

JERSEY CITY, June 1 -- While weary, smoke-begrimed firemen continued tonight to pour water on the smoldering embers of what was described as "the worst fire in Jersey City's history," Fire Chief Frank Ertle officially estimated the damage from last night's disastrous waterfront blaze at $25,000,000.

The number of men, women and children dependent on public relief in this city has declined 55.6 per cent since October, 1935, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson disclosed yesterday in making public his annual report for the fiscal year 1939-40.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- An increase in the placement of ship plates for defense purposes, an exceptionally heavy prospective demand for oil line pipe for the same ends, and an even tighter situation relative to commercial steel deliveries were the principal features in news of the steel industry last week.

The retirement of Daniel Willard from the presidency of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad will remove from the active railway scene a highly interesting figure. Mr. Willard has passed his eightieth birthday, after an experience with railway operation which stretches back to 1879.

The United Fruit liner Chiriqui arrived here yesterday afternoon from Port Limon, Costa Rica, completing her last voyage before being turned over to the United States Navy for use as a military auxiliary.

On balance this seems to be one of the most indecisive moments of the war, a moment full of action yet heavy with suspense. The military scale jumps up and down -- Iraq against Crete, the Bismarck against the Hood, something strangely like a truce in the bombing raids over England and Germany.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 1 -- Trading volume was smaller in the smaller Continental European markets last week, and was mostly much restricted. Both operators and public are showing hesitation and are refraining from entering fresh commitments over the Whitsun holiday.
NEW YORK Mrs. John Howard Child of the Savoy-Plaza has gone to Pasadena, Calif.
Yesterday at Ebbets Field the skies were gray, the air was damp and chilly and rain threatened, but in the hearts of 21,354 Flatbush fans all was sunshine and warmth.

Although the public schools of the city already have contributed far more to the Greater New York Fund than last year, former Postmaster General .James A. Farley, chairman, issued yesterday another appeal to teachers and school employes, urging increased effort to reach a quota of $100,000.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, charged yesterday that the refusal of the La Guardia Administration to recognize the validity of collective bargaining contracts between the Board of Transportation and labor unions representing the 32,000 employes on the unified transit lines was a repudiation of promises made as far back as 1936.

VICHY, France, June 1 -- The text of a report by the general assembly of the Havas agency, published here today, indicates how its advertising section has been organized under Franco-German "collaboration."

Henry Morgenthau Sr., former United States Ambassador to Turkey and father of the Secretary of the Treasury, asserted yesterday that America must put to use "every ounce of the intelligence, the efficiency, and the industrial resources of which this huge, rich country is capable," if it is to preserve the civilization of which America and Great Britain are representative.
The United States Golf Association will include in the rules of the game a provision limiting the distance qualities of the golf ball, effective Jan. 1, 1942.

LONDON, Monday, June 2 -- Londoners heard the air raid sirens and anti-aircraft guns early today for the first time since the night of May 16-17, as Nazi raiders flew over some parts of the metropolis seemingly headed northward.

More than 1,000 persons attended Baccalaureate Day exercises on the campus of the College of Mount St. Vincent on the Hudson yesterday that included the traditional carrying of the daisy chain by the sophomores on the riverfront lawn at Riverdale and the decoration of the Shrine of the Blessed Virgin.
The upward revision in the Italian lira to 5.26% cents from 5.05 furnished the only diversion in an otherwise colorless market in the foreign currencies last week.

The congregation of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, welcomed its new minister, the Rev. Arthur F. Williams, at the morning sermon yesterday. Mr. Williams succeeds the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20 -- It was learned here today that Japan is now receiving from Chile nearly 4,000 tons a month of copper ores and concentrates, a considerable amount of manganese -- for which she is trying to outbid the United States -- and the production of one cobalt mine.
Awards to 177 members of the Police Department for meritorious service since Jan. 1 will be made public today in a general departmental order by Commissioner Valentine.

"Nothing new under the sun" is an adage that would seem to apply especially well to such a firmly established institution as a loaf of bread. Yet something new has happened to wheat this year -- quite by chance -- that millers have been meditating since the first stone grinder milled the first kernel of wheat some 4,000 years ago in ancient Egypt.

That President Roosevelt has redefined the national policy and goal and in terms upon which all can unite in loyal support and with undivided energies is the view expressed by the National City Bank in the June number of its monthly bank letter.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Wheat farmers in the United States have voted 80.5 per cent in favor of marketing-quota restrictions on the 1941 crop, according to returns from a referendum conducted yesterday by the Department of Agriculture.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- The Cubs moved into the first division today by downing the Phillies, 9 to 5 and 1 to 0, in a double-header played in rain and mist before 4,365 fans. Chicago gained fourth place as Cincinnati dropped to fifth by splitting with the Giants.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 1 -- William Schweitzer of Hillside, N.J., veteran small bore rifleman, annexed two aggregate championships here today in the closing stages of the sixth annual Eastern small bore tournament under the sponsorship of the Association of New Jersey Rifle and Pistol Clubs.

It is exactly twenty-five years today since New York City's Commission on Building Districts and Restrictions turned in a report which was to give this metropolis the first comprehensive zoning system in America. Edward M. Bassett was the commission's chairman, Lawson Purdy its vice chairman, and George McAneny, then President of the Borough of Manhattan, was mainly responsible for its creation.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- After rejecting all proposals to "appease" the Federal Communications Commission, the nation's organized broadcasters met here tonight to perfect last-minute arrangements for the start of their fight with the commission over the future regulation of radio.

NEW ORLEANS, June 1 -- Cotton futures here made a poor response last week to the signing of the 85 per cent parity bill by the President in view of the previous uncertainty whether the measure would become law, and for the greater part of the week they floundered over the narrowest range in some time.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- With the Secretary of War and Secretary of the Navy unalterably opposed to measures which could be used to enforce prohibition within wide but unspecified areas around Army and Navy centers, it appears unlikely that such legislation will pass Congress or be signed if it does pass.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 1 -- President Roosevelt will sign the ship-seizure bill soon after his return to Washington Tuesday and will move administratively to insure permanent acquisition by the United States of Axis ships taken into custody some weeks ago in American ports.

For the best contributions made by workers at the bench to America's defense plans, military and industrial, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., 230 Park Avenue, announced yesterday the award of $10,000 in prizes, including first prize of $5,000 to a young Texan who designed a system of blind landing for airplanes.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 1 -- The British Government may soon officially declare Syria and Lebanon enemy-occupied territory, it was understood here today in neutral diplomatic circles as reports from Jerusalem and Beirut and in Ankara indicated a general belief that Allied action against the mandated territories was imminent.

LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- Photographic reconnaissance over Hamburg, Germany's first seaport, has shown thirty-six "very large" industrial buildings demolished or seriously damaged by Britain's powerful new super-bombs in May, the Air Ministry news service reported tonight.
NEWARK, N.J., June 1 (AP) -- Newark regained first place from Montreal in the International League race today by sweeping a double-header with Toronto.

After an ownership of three weeks, the five-story American basement dwelling on a lot 20 by 102 feet at 25 East Seventy-sixth Street has been resold by Samuel Kilpatrick, operator, in a deal negotiated by O.D. and H.V. Dike, brokers. It is assessed at $68,000 and is between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

President Roosevelt's speech to the nation last week on the dangers that confront it, coupled with his declaration of an unlimited national emergency, must resolve any doubts that may have existed over the paramount importance of national defense. The speeding up of aid to Britain and of the rearming of the United States takes precedence over every other consideration.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt has consented to serve as honorary vice chairman of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, which will launch its $10,750,000 campaign tomorrow to finance service men's clubs near Army and Navy bases throughout the country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Acting upon the request of John Hay Whitney, head of the motion picture division of the hemispheric commercial relations program, Paramount has shuffled its production schedule and has begun preparation of "Rurales," a story of the Mexican constabulary, as a goodwill gesture to the Southern republic.
Alice, the 44-year-old favorite of the elephant house at the Bronx Zoo, broke a cherished tradition yesterday. To an audience of cynical observers she was living proof that an elephant can forget.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Four hundred inspectors will begin a nation-wide punitive and educational drive tomorrow for full compliance by the canning industry with the regulations of the Wages-Hours Law.

LONDON, June 1 -- Hostilities ceased throughout Iraq today as Emir Abdul Illah, the Regent, entered Baghdad. Six-year-old King Feisal II, who had been reported kidnapped by Premier Rashid Ali el Gailani, who fled to Iran, is said unofficially to be safe.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Forty-five hundred warehouse workers in the San Francisco Bay area will go on strike tomorrow morning following a breakdown of negotiations with the Association of San Francisco Distributors for replacement of a three-year contract which expired at midnight last night.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 (AP) -- All fighting in Iraq between the British and Axis-inspired rebel forces of Premier Rashid Ali el Gailani ended at 8 A.M. today under terms of an armistice reached yesterday, Iraqi sources here announced.

One of the most Important guide posts in advertising and selling in the forthcoming year will be the census report on the 140 metropolitan districts, which contain 87 per cent of the entire urban population and 47 per cent of the nation's total population, according to marketing men.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 1 -- After several hours of almost vain trolling in a decidedly choppy sea, Governor Charles Edison looked at the two small bonito that were the reward of his efforts and decided that there was a definite possibility that the fish off Atlantic County were as partisan as the majority of the residents of that county.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 1 -- Fire destroyed the administration building of Boeing's $2,000,000 Sea Island aircraft plant today, but this will not delay construction of flying boats for Great Britain, according to Stanley Burke, president of Boeing Aircraft of Canada.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 1 -- The national tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association ended today with the new All-America team vindicating the selection committee's choices by handing the reserve twelve a decisive 8-1 trouncing.
LONDON, June 1 -- The frayed cuff, the threadbare knee, the outmoded frock have been made badges of Britain's will to win the war.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 1 -- The lowly road map was at a premium today as Forty-fourth Division officers rounded up all available maps of Virginia and Maryland from filling stations within a twenty-mile radius in preparation for an "invasion" of the South early this week.

TOKYO, Monday, June 2 -- "Good commercial morals and shady transaction prevention week" is being observed in Tokyo this week. The observance is under the auspices of prefectural, municipal and police authorities, as well as of the Association for Service to the Country.

The virtual completion of the two-week German conquest of Crete and the collapse of the Iraqi revolt cleared the way in the Middle East for the beginning of what may be the definitive campaign of the Eastern Mediterranean.

Mayor La Guardia joined with other officials, architects, city planning experts and real estate leaders yesterday at a meeting in Hunter College to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of zoning in New York.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 2 -- Prime Minister Robert S. Menzies, commenting on the evacuation of Crete, said today that, while it was a serious blow, the proportion of men taken off was higher than could have been expected, considering the difficulties.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 2 (AP) -- A four-motored British Liberator bomber crashed into San Diego Bay today, carrying four fliers to death.

A one-man show of oils by the Marchioness of Queensberry (the former Cathleen Mann), who arrived from Europe last week, will open today at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street. Twelve canvases have been hung.
The Maemere Farm's 3-year-old Maemante scored handily in the $2.000 added Class C Bonnie Mary Handicap for fillies and mares at Belmont Park yesterday over the mile course before a crowd of 11,145.

In his current report Welfare Commissioner Hodson is able to show a decline of 55.6 per cent since 1935 in the number of persons on public relief in this city, and a decline of 49 per cent in the cost. These figures include direct relief and work relief paid for out of city, State and Federal funds.

A property on lower Broadway opposite City Hall Park, once the site of the town house of Rufus King, early United States Senator and Minister to England, has just passed into new hands in one of the few sales to be made in this area in recent times.

JERSEY CITY, June 2 -- In the aftermath of Saturday evening's disastrous waterfront fire, Commissioner Daniel Casey, Jersey City's Director of Public Safety, issued today a statement censuring employes of the Jersey City Stockyards Company for delaying twenty minutes before turning in an alarm, thus giving the blaze opportunity to spread.

Columbia University will end a three-day celebration of its 187th annual commencement this afternoon at 5 o'clock when 5,051 degrees are awarded at outdoor graduation exercises in South Court. Eleven honorary degrees, nine university medals for excellence and 118 certificates and diplomas will also be conferred.

George Ehret, 29-year-old grandson of the founder of the Ehret Brewery, and Miss Grace L.
