Gunther, 53, a United States citizen who had resided in Italy for twenty years, arrived yesterday from Rome, where they were tried and convicted of illegal dealings in foreign exchange and later pardoned by King Victor Emmanuel.

With a spectacular air show featured by the formation flying of huge Navy PBY patrol planes and the power dives of a squadron of Army P-40 pursuit ships thrilling 30,000 spectators, the United States Navy formally placed Floyd Bennett Field in commission as naval air station yesterday afternoon.

The Celanese Corporation of America in April set a new monthly earnings record, according to Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, who reported the approximated total of $1,200,000 after all charges and taxes except excess profits taxes.

Advancing his local defense schedule by a full month, Mayor La Guardia directed yesterday the formation of a Fire Department Auxiliary Corps and a Corps of Local Fire Wardens to function under the supervision of Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh.
DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- Buck Newsom, no puzzle at all for American League clubs this year, was just as easy for the Red Sox today.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 2 -- Major Edward M. Floroyk, post ordnance officer, taking up Representative Thomas's report of a lack of arms and ammunition here, said today that there is no shortage of ammunition for training purposes.
BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Braves scored their first 1941 shutout victory today when Dick Errickson whitewashed the Pirates, 2 to 0.

About the only bright spot in Aaron Copland's life last week, after thieves took from his car in Manhattan a valise containing just about all of his current musical work, was that a just-completed book manuscript was not among the bag's contents.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Regarding President Roosevelt's recent fireside talk, Germany has officially complained, "Whenever has Hitler said he was striving for world control and domination?" and Mr. Lindbergh echoes this complaint in almost identical words.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

Immediate formation of a union of the United States and Great Britain to preserve democracy from a threatened totalitarian victory and to lay the basis of a permanent peace in the post-war reconstruction period was advocated here yesterday afternoon by Colonel Josiah Wedgwood, English Laborite member of the House of Commons.

INDIANOLA, Ia., June 2 -- Alfred M. Landon, Republican presidential nominee in 1936, said today that h1/2 was convinced that President Roosevelt has not yet made up his mind about the role this country should play in the European war.

An attack on the constitutionality of the Selective Service Act which, It successful, would have confused the status of several hundred thousand young men now receiving military training under that statute, was rejected yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A pledge that the Yugoslav Government and the portion of its Army, Navy and Air Force that escaped before German armies overran the country will continue fighting against the Axis powers was contained in a statement by the exiled government, headed by General Dusan Simovitch, and issued here today by the Yugoslav Minister to the United States, Constantin Fotitch.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -0 The presence of subversive agents at key positions at Army posts and cantonments in the New York and New Jersey area who "could wreck the entire defense of the New York area," was charged today by Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican of New Jersey, who has just returned from an inspection tour in that region.

LONDON, June 2 -- Further proof that ships of the Royal Netherland Navy were playing their part in helping the British Navy to police the seas was provided in a communique issued tonight relating to the capture of the French ship Winnipeg.

The requirements of national defense have called millions of America's young people from their homes to train and work in newly created camps and defense centers in outlying sections of the country. Often the only near-by town to a camp of 30,000 soldiers is a community of a few thousand people.

The failure of fish to appear along a coast on schedule is always a matter that brings a variety of wild guesses as to the reasons for the delay or scarcity, and the tardiness of the striped bass in the Montauk area has proved to be no exception from this rule.

HAMARONECK, N.Y., June 2 -- Five of the first six players in the qualifying round of the forty-first annual women's metropolitan golf championship over the Quaker Ridge course today nailed from New Jersey.

Mrs. Agnes Murphy Mulligan, whose name denotes intelligence, energy and wit and whose portrait was printed in this newspaper a few days ago, is one of our pioneers. From New York University she received in 1892 the first LL.B. degree given to a woman in this State.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 2 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Command issued this communique today:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 2 -- Immediate consultation among the governments of the American Republics so that an emergency would not find this hemisphere as disunited as the Balkans were was urged today by Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Foreign Minister of Argentina from 1932 to 1938.

The rumblings of Third Avenue elevated trains and the bouncing of trolley cars over the intersection combine to make Forty-second Street and Third Avenue the noisest spot in the city, according to a decibel test made yesterday by officials of the League for Less Noise.

BERLIN, June 2 -- Hinting at a possible air-borne invasion of Cyprus or a frontal assault on the British Isles, Reich Marshal Hermann Goering boasted tonight that the swift conquest of Crete "proves that there is no unconquerable island" for the German Air Force.

Plays That Pull It is all the harder to explain nearly 4,000 performances of "Tobacco Road" because its runner-up in the whole history of the theatre is "Abie's Irish Rose." The two plays had nothing in common except the swift and virtually unanimous condemnation of the professional critics.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Contracts totaling $37,602,922.85 were awarded today by the War and Navy Departments. The largest of these, to the George A. Fuller Company and Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation of New York City was for the additional purchase and assembly of materials and equipment for advanced bases and for the construction of an assembly and shipping depot at a total estimated cost of $22,800,000.

Substantial losses in national and automotive linage last month for eight New York newspapers offset a gain in retail and classified advertising copy, with the result that advertising declined 1.5 per cent, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

The sharp contrast with the serene order of the shaded lawn of Van Amringe Quadrangle, where 353 Columbia College seniors and 500 relatives and friends gathered yesterday to celebrate the traditional Columbia Class Day, "this broken world" and the unbridled "force of emotion which is clearly manifest in our time" provided the themes of speeches by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes, and the class valedictorian and salutatorian.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following the proclamation of an unlimited national emergency by President Roosevelt Tuesday night, the Administration asked Congress today for authority to requisition, for just compensation, any private property, real or personal, which may be deemed in the interest of defense during the emergency.

Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, the first flag officer to be assigned to the sole command of the New York Navy Yard since shortly after the World War, took over his new duties at 11 A.M. yesterday at brief ceremonies before the bandstand in the Brooklyn post.
BERLIN, June 2 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 2 -- A record expansion program for the nation's power facilities to meet the ever-increasing demands of national defense is under way and by the end of 1942 nearly $2,000,000,000 of new generating, transmission and distribution capacity will be added to the public and private plants of the country.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Legislation to authorize President Roosevelt to carry out an agreement with Canada for construction of the St. Lawrence seaway was introduced today by Representative Mansfield, chairman of the Rivers and Harbors Committee, which will handle the bill.

ROME, June 2 -- With the Axis forces in possession of Crete, Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini met today at the Brenner Pass for five hours to decide upon their next military and political moves.

Supplies of fresh pork cuts yesterday were uneven, fully normal in some sections and fairly light in others. Supplies of steer hinds and ribs and veal were about normal, lamb foresaddles light to barely normal. Prices were mostly unchanged on steer hinds and ribs. Veal hindsaddles were strong to $1 higher.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Raymond S. Richmond, secretary of the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies, said today that thirty-seven Senators would introduce a resolution urging the State Department to work out a plan, in cooperation with Great Britain, for sending food to conquered European countries.

At the Washington meeting of the Keep America Out of War Congress the president of that organization stirred his audience to enthusiasm with the remark: "It is time we begin to look about for new leadership."

Henry C. Turner, grand master of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York, announced yesterday that Clarence Glass of Brooklyn has been renamed grand marshal, and also made public the list of other officers and committeemen for the ensuing year.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore, the new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, invited the heads of nearly fifty national women's organizations today to meet in New York on June 13 to discuss ways of mustering 40,000,000 women into national defense work.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress recommending appropriations for defense highway purposes was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today ordered Abraham L. Shushan, one-time lieutenant of Huey P. Long, and others, to show by Oct. 1 why Louisiana should not be permitted to bring before it proceedings seeking recovery of more than $1,000,000 on account of alleged fraud and bribery in connection with the construction of a New Orleans airport.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2 -- The first and last pairs to post scores today in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball event at the Gedney Country Club accounted for the best performances. They were Jerry Desio and Mike Tartaglia, the early finishers, and Tony Tiso and Saul Lantzis, each team with a 68.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Two days after the President's announcement at Hyde Park that Secretary Ickes is to be coordinator of the American petroleum industry, to assure that "the supply of petroleum and its products will be accommodated to the needs of the nation and the national defense program," The United Press carried on its news ticker an item reminiscent of one of Mr. Ickes's earlier adventures in oil.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Members of the National Confectioners Association were warned today by Ody H. Lamborn of Lamborn Co., Inc., New York City, that a slow but sure rise in the price of sugar is in prospect, with government price intervention a certainty if the rise becomes too rapid.

Stock Exchange Affairs Another special meeting of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday took up both the special committee's report on reorganization of the Exchange, which adheres in the main to the recommendations of former president William McC. Martin Jr., and the problem of commissions.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Japan's expansionist venture in China, which will have rounded out four full years on July 7, has cost the Empire more than 17,000,000,000 yen [about $4,000,000,000] or a sum equal to the entire Japanese national income in 1936, says a booklet by T.Y. Hu which was issued here today by the Chinese Council for Economic Research.

Broadway's solitary of feting listed thus far for the Summer months makes its bow tonight at the John Golden Theatre under the auspices of John Siguard (Ole) Olsen and Harold Ogden (Chic) Johnson. It is a farce entitled "Snookie," the work of Thomas A. Johnstone.

PORT DIX, N.J., June 2 -- The Forty-fourth Division is "ready and waiting" word from Major Gen. Henry C. Pratt, Second Corps commander, for further orders to evacuate Fort Dix for intensive field training in Caroline County, Va., for the next week or ten days.

A passenger from the Spanish steampship Magallenes who landed here on May 24, died of typhoid fever, the Department of Health disclosed yesterday. Among the other 161 passengers debarked here, three positive and three possible cases have been found, according to health officials.

CLEVELAND, June 2 -- Dr. Frank H. Lahey of Boston, president-elect of the American Medical Association, told the house of delegates at the opening session today of the association's annual meeting that organized medicine must put aside all personal differences with the government and work concertedly for the national defense.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The Western railroads replied today to the demand of the five railroad operating brotherhoods for a wage increase of 30 per cent. Denouncing the increase as unwarranted, the managements of the railroads announced that they would make demands of their own.

IT'S S each man against the field in any open golf tournament, including the fray at Fort Worth for which the sharpshooters of the links are now whetting their blades. But there was a period in golf, and not so long ago, when conditions ran the other way. It was the field against one man. That man was R.T. Jones Jr. of Atlanta, Ga., the Emperor Jones of the far-flung fairways and the buttressed greens.
NEW YORK Sir Louis and Lady Beale have returned to the New Weston after spending a few weeks at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 3 -- Manchester was subjected by German bombers over Sunday night to an attack that was described officially as "sharp" -- a word that in current war definitions here means the city was set ablaze and rocked with high explosives, many lives were lost and property was shattered.

CHICAGO, June 2 (A.P) -- Hogs closed steady to 10 cents higher than Thursday's average in the livestock market today. Good and choice 180 to 270 pound swine brought $9.40 to $9.55 with a top at $9.60, only 5 cents under the high for the year. Most 270 to 330 pound butchers sold between $9.30 and $9.45.

One day back in the year 1935 a man asked his wife a brain-twister: "What is it that nobody makes and that everybody wants? Tell me, and we will make a million dollars." The good woman, being of a practical turn of mind, answered immediately, "Why ready-made hollandaise."

Large stocks of wheat and closed export markets aggravated by serious shortages of shipping space now confront the Canadian farmer, the Royal Bank of Canada states in its monthly bank letter. The bank estimates that in line with the drastic reduction in wheat acreage urged by the government, the 1941 total in wheat acreage will be about 21,500,000, or about 25 per cent less than in 1940.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers will offer today to the public 40,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock of no-par value, of the Flintkote Company. The stock will be priced at $100.50 a share, plus accrued dividends from March 15, this year.

The American Republics liner Argentina arrived yesterday from Buenos Aires and other South American ports carrying 336 passengers, including nine British fashion models who have been displaying British clothes in South America.

TOKYO, June 2 -- A glowing tribute to the heroes of Crete is paid today by the Japan Times Advertiser, organ of the Foreign Office, which suggests the creation of a special order of knighthood embracing every officer and man of the British imperial and Greek forces participating in this "strangest war in history."

Two meetings were held yesterday, one at Vichy between Marshal Petain and General Weygand, the other at the Brenner between Hitler and Mussolini. Both boded trouble; both were concerned with decisions of grave import for this continent, as well as for the coasts that lie in the immediate shadow of advancing war.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 2 (AP) -- Johnny McCarthy's single with two out and the bases loaded in the ninth inning gave the Jersey City Giants a 4-to-3 victory over the Rochester Red Wings in the opener of a three-game series tonight. The victory snapped Jersey City's losing streak at five games.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The philosophy of Chief Justice Hughes is expressed in these passages from his opinions and speeches:
Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN Augustin Bravo, from 34th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office. New York County, for 5 days, from 4 P.M. June 2.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- Federal and State conciliators failed in efforts today to arrange a truce in the American Federation of Labor truck drivers' strike which has curtailed over-the-road shipping from the Great Lakes to the Eastern seaboard, hampering movement of defense articles.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange opened yesterday at losses of 2 to 5 points and then hovered around Saturday's closing levels until a last-hour rally established net gains of 2 to 4 points for the day. Trading activity was the smallest for a full five-hour session since the beginning of the recent upward movement.

BOSTON, June 2 -- The world conflict was pictured to 8,000 Christian Scientists today as a period of "house cleaning" during which the hard crusts of human hatred, lusts for power and greed, and not modern civilization, would be broken into pieces.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Long-awaited details of the new style protection plan of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, proposed as a substitute for that thrown out by the Supreme Court decision upholding the Federal Trade Commission charge of restraint of trade, were revealed here today by Albert M. Post, executive director of the guild, at the mid-year convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The award of twenty-seven scholarships, including seven renewals, in the New York University Graduate Division for Training in Public Service, was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university. The scholarships are for the academic year 1941-42 and have a total value of $3,000.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y. June 2 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided this afternoon at commencement exercises at Marymount College and presented diplomas to fifty graduates. Judge Robert V. Kinkead of Jersey City addressed the graduating class and an audience of 800 persons in the college auditorium.

Lou Gehrig, former first baseman of the New York Yankees and one of the outstanding batsmen baseball has known, died at his home, 5204 Delafield Avenue, in the Fieldston section of the Bronx, last night. Death came to the erstwhile "Iron Man" at 10:10 o'clock.

The Fidelity union Trust Company of Newark, as trustee for the mortgage certificate holders of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company, sold to Morris Breakstone the apartment house at 324 Forty-fourth Street, Union City, N.J.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 2 -- President Roosevelt prepared today for conferences In Washington tomorrow which likely will be of far-reaching importance.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 28: Increases of $34,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $116,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, $60,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $46,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $51,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended May 28 aggregated $10,109,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Chief Justice Hughes adhered to a sort of "balance" doctrine of constitutional thinking in his decisions, analysts pointed out today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- An "astonishing" number of persons connected with un-American organizations have been found employed in defense industries in this area during the last few months and "scores" of workers have been dismissed as a result of activities of the Dies Committee, according to disclosures made here today.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Continued increases in department store sales at least through 1942, featured by substantial gains in "soft goods" and by a switch to better-grade merchandise, were predicted here tonight by Stacy May, Director of the Bureau of Research and Statistics of the Office of Production Management, in an apraisal of the impact of the defense program at the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, gave his annual commencement dinner last evening at his home, 60 Morningside Drive, in honor of those who are to receive honorary degrees at the university's 187th commencement exercises today.

A disturbance by 150 pickets in front of the World Steel Corporation's offices at 448 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, yesterday morning, during which one automobile was overturned, tires of three were punctured, a number of the plant's windows were broken and two patrolmen on strike duty fired their revolvers in the air to summon help, ended in the arrest of nine men for disorderly conduct.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., June 2 -- Wishful thinking which would ascribe inferior materials and poor workmanship to the weapons of the Nazi Luftwaffe, gave place today to the hard realism of the technical expert when the design features and performance characteristics of the Mercedes-Benz DB 601-A aircraft engine, used in Germany's Messerschmitt and Heinkel fighters, were analyzed at the Summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, defended today the commission's order requiring reorganization of the radio industry's internal structure and disposal by the National Broadcasting Company of one of its two networks.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I love New York. I wonder at its vastness; I thrill at its cultural centralization"; I am thankful for being able to participate in its superior educational system; I am proud of sharing one-seven millionth of its importance; and I can even overlook the inconveniences of its hyper-burdened sub-ways in full realization of its entertainment facilities.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 2 (UP) -- German air-borne forces were said reliably tonight to have abandoned Iraq's rich Mosul oil region 250 miles north of Baghdad, where Emir Abdul Illah, the returned Regent, prepared to announce a new British-supported government after the cessation of month-long hostilities.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 2 -- The First Battalion of the 258th Field Artillery, the Bronx, reached Madison Barracks this afternoon in an exchange of posts with the 186th Field Artillery, recently the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The wheat market made a fair response to the endorsement given to the quota marketing plan by the formers on Saturday. Prices on the Board of Trade here gained sharply at the opening, with offerings throughout the session absorbed easily.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 2 (AP) -- Attorneys representing bondholding groups expressed today disapproval of inclusion of the Old Colony Railroad in the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan for reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad at a hearing before Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the United States District Court here.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest your editorial of today entitled "A Bad Sugar Bill," in which you made the statement that "the Philippines are reported to be failing to fill their allotment by on amount that may run into several hundred thousand tons."

It is easy enough for Congress to appropriate funds, but the real economic problem of defense is one of material and labor resources -- and Time. This is what the House ought to bear in mind when the War Department Appropriations Bill, carrying a total for the coming fiscal year of $9,452,000,000, comes before it this week.

ROME, June 2 (UP) -- A large-scale increase in Italo-German operations at Tobruk was reported by the Italian High Command today in a special communique that hinted that the besieged Libyan port would be the next major objective of the Axis campaign to drive the British, from the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The United States Senate's committee to study problems of American small business will meet Friday to discuss its proposed bill aimed at eliminating many of the reports which Federal agencies now require of small business men, Senator James E. Murray of Montana, committee chairman, announced here today.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 2 -- British forces were reported to be consolidating their positions in Western Iraq and Northern Palestine today as the Middle East in general awaited developments in the tense Syrian situation and responsible diplomatic quarters on both sides of the belligerent front concurred that it was a military necessity for Britain to try to occupy the French-mandated territories.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Andrew Jackson Houston of Texas, 86-year-old son of General Sam Houston, became today the oldest person ever to be sworn in as a member of the Senate.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 2 (AP) -- The British Navy destroyed 20,000 Nazi sea-borne troops off the northern coast of Crete in the days before the Mediterranean Fleet received the grim task of steaming to the southern side of the island to evacuate its own troops, British sources said tonight.

The 27,000-ton de luxe United States liner America, taken over last Wednesday by the Federal Government for use by the Navy as an auxiliary cruiser, docked at the foot of West Eighteenth Street at 9 A.M. yesterday with 226 passengers and a crew of 523 officers and men.

Leading producers advanced kraft liner board prices on contract yesterday to the basis of $60 a ton, effective July 1. This was a rise of $5 a ton, and the new levels are expected to be maintained through the last half of the year. The previous price had been in effect since Jan. 1, 1940.

VICHY, France, June 2 -- Coming by air from Algeria, General Maxime Weygand, Delegate General of the French Government in Africa with plenary powers, arrived in Vichy this evening and went straight from the air field to the offices of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, with whom he remained in conversation for nearly two hours.

MADRID, June 2 -- Spain has taken over the representation of French Government and private interests in Palestine, following the enforced withdrawal of Vichy's representatives there, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister and second in rank to Viscount Halifax here, has been selected to reorganize and direct all British publicity in America. Sir Gerald, it was said, will be directly under the British Ministry of Information at London.

A group of labor leaders called yesterday on Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany Hall, and urged him to support former Judge Alfred J. Talley for Mayor. They asserted that Mr. Talley, If nominated by the Democrats, would command more support from labor groups than any of the other candidates yet mentioned for that office.

Architects filed plans yesterday for two large apartment structures in Brooklyn, one in the Grand Army Plaza section and the other in Flatbush. The former will house sixty-two families and is estimated to cost $225,000 and the latter, costing about $200,000, will accommodate fifty-nine families.

The holiday week-end brought a sharp increase in attendance at Broadway motion-picture theatres as contrasted with the unusual slump in business experienced by most houses in recent weeks. Despite the upswing no new attendance marks were claimed, however.

American women "need to know what war is like," Miss Winifred Ashford and Mrs. Pat Macleod, members of Great Britain's Women's Mechanized Transport Corps, warned yesterday. They arrived at the Hotel Pennsylvania in the morning from Montreal, after having traveled by convoyed ship to Canada.

The sixteen-story apartment house on an irregular plot 108.2 by 185.6 feet at 2780-96 Broadway, northeast corner of 107th Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, on a bid of $1,200,000.

The annual struggle for possession of the Morgan Cup will be waged by golf teams representing the Bond Clubs of New York, Philadelphia and Hartford at the twenty-first annual field day of the Bond Club of New York at the Westchester Country Club on Friday.

Fiddler McGee was still slightly off key yesterday, so the Giants dropped a 4-3 decision to the Reds in the comparative privacy of the Polo Grounds. The former Cardinal, who has yet to win for Bill Terry, gave up only four hits in six and two-thirds innings, but two were homers by Eddie Joost and Ernie Lombardi.

Twelve low-flying Army and Navy planes and four Navy blimps "bombed" the midtown area of the city shortly before noon yesterday, dropping 60,000 bomb-shaped broadsides -- "bomphlets" -- announcing the opening today of the national campaign of the United Service Organizations for Defense, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Roundlot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on May 17 was 2.252,350 shares, compared with 3,340,190 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

CLEVELAND, June 2 -- Rapid Robert Feller was just a fellow named Joe to Tommy Henrich today as the Yankees concluded their second visit of the campaign at League Park. To Joe DiMaggio, the Iowa farm boy was the same symbol of mediocrity.

Civic officials joined with baseball executives and players last night in extolling the memory of Lou Gehrig. Mayor La Guardia, who appointed the ailing ball player to the New York City Parole Commission after his retirement from baseball, was among those to pay tribute to him.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 31:

The prosecution rested yesterday in the trial of William Solomon. Tammany district leader, and Charles H. Mullens, former assistant State controller, charged in General Sessions with having accepted $28,000 in bribes in connection with State printing contracts.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2 -- Ultimate triumph for the brotherhood of democracies was predicted today by Leonard W. Brockington of Ottawa, special wartime aide to the Premier of Canada, at the Syracuse University commencement.

WHEN Mrs. E.C. Gaskell was gathering data for her famous life of "my dear friend" Charlotte Bronte (published in 1857), she came across what she subsequently described as a "curious packet" containing "an immense amount of manuscript in an inconceivably small space."

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- The White Sox lasted only one day as the American League pace-setters, falling before the seventh-place Senators, 8 to 3, today. The loss dropped Chicago back into second, place behind the Indians.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., June 2 -- Mrs. H. Everitt Pell of Great Barring ton is chairman of a committee that has arranged for a dance Friday night at the Barn Club on Sheffield Road as an aid to Bundles for Britain.

An "unflinching hope" that a wrong way of life or a wrong idea cannot permanently triumph was expressed last night by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, who delivered the Phi Beta Kappa addresss at the initiation ceremonies for the fifty-three new members of the Hunter chapter.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Ways and Means Committee began in executive session today to consider the terms of the new $3,500,000,000 defense revenue bill at the same time that Secretary Morgenthau was saying that rising costs of defense might mean changes in a plan to finance two-thirds by taxes and the other part by borrowing.

Individual owners are continuing to borrow more heavily for home building and financing from savings, building and loan associations than in many former years, states Paul Endicott, president of the United States Savings and Loan League.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2 -- Breaking with women's clubs and taxpayers' associations of 19,000 members, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors' special committee on charter amendments filed day with the board a 5,000-word report condemning as unsound the three county charter revisions that had been proposed for referendums in the forthcoming November election.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The National Defense Mediation Board telegraphed today to the Bay Cities Metal Trades Council of San Francisco, and the Union Iron Works Division of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, requesting them to take steps at once to resume production in the interest of national defense on the $500,000,000 government shipbuilding program.

LONDON, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- The "Free French" Navy, one year old this month, has grown in that short time from two warships to a fleet of more than 100 vessels, all playing an important role besides units of the hardpressed Royal Navy in the fight against the Axis.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Francis Biddle, United States Solicitor General, told the National Conference of Social Work here tonight that in the emergency now confronting this nation the government would take all measures considered necessary to protect the country against sabotage and other subversive activities, but the essential civil rights would be protected.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 2 -- With about 57,700 officers and men of the Second Army deployed in the central basin of Tennessee, under actual field conditions, the first phase of America's greatest peace-time defense tests developed in this vicinity at 7 o'clock this morning.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Navy will launch on July 1 a new cruiser, the San Diego, named in honor both of the city and a cruiser which was sunk by a German mine off Fire Island in July, 1918.

The Dodgers almost enjoyed sole possession of first place in the National League yesterday, but it was all an illusion. Instead, Leo Durocher's athletes saw not only their winning streak broken at nine games but their chances of passing the Cardinals in the current series go aglimmering.

A better tone persisted through most of the session yesterday in the stock market, but the pace of trading was back to the gait of last Summer. Fractional gains were recorded at the close in the main section of the list, although some key issues such as American Telephone enlarged the additions to two points and more.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued this communique today:

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 2 -- Charles Evans Hughes announced his retirement, effective July 1, as Chief Justice of the United States in a letter sent to President Roosevelt today. He gave as his reasons "health and age." The President, in accepting his retirement by telegraph, expressed deep distress, and added that he was sure the announcement would come as a shock to the country.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Danny Litwhiler's sixth and seventh home runs of the season and Johnny Podgajny's seven-hit pitching gave the Phillies a 3-to-2 victory today, their first over the Cubs this year.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- After more than seven and one-half months of consideration the Supreme Court gave orders today that the contempt cases of Harry Bridges and The Los Angeles Times should be reargued in October, to which date the tribunal took a recess.

An underwriting syndicate consisting of Smith, Barney Co.: Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Phelps, Fenn Co. won the award yesterday of $1,200,000 of bonds issued by Maryland's State Road Commission, on a bid of 101.404 for 1 1/2s.

Fifteen social workers from South American countries, arriving in New York yesterday to begin a month's tour of institutions as far west as Illinois and Indiana, convened for the first time as a group around a luncheon table at the New York School for Social Work.

OTTAWA, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- The national income of Canada in April was $434,700,000, compared with $375,300,000 in April, 1940, and $413,300,000 in March this year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

The new Swedish motorship freighter Venezuela, traveling with a "safe conduct" from the belligerents, is thirty days overdue at Rio de Janeiro and is "presumed lost" in the South Atlantic with twelve passengers who boarded the ship after surviving the sinking of the Finnish steamer Carolina Thorden, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The nature and scope of Nazi propaganda are still a mystery to many Americans. Gone are the naive and obvious methods of paralyzing the American effort to resist the totalitarian drive toward world domination. In their place are subtle techniques, employed often unwittingly by sincere citizens.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Ambassador Winant, who arrived here tonight by airplane from New York after flying from Europe by clipper, has come home at his own request to make personal reports to President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull, it was said at the State Department today.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eighth commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate considered the bill to amend the Sugar Act, received the Reynolds bill for requisitioning of property, received the President's message asking for $125,000,000 authorization for access highways and bridges for national defense, received the resolution of thirty-seven Senators urging food relief for occupied European countries and recessed at 4:29 P.M. until noon tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House began today three days of debate on the $1,155,927,222 appropriation bill for the Labor Department and the Feredal Security Agency.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 3 -- Earnings of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for the first six months of this year will run between $75,000,000 and $80,000,000, W.S. Farish, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 4 -- Starting on what appears to be a general offensive to neutralize the economic pressure that she feels the United States and Britain are exerting against her, Japan has notified the British and Australian Governments that she would like alleviation of the British Empire restrictions on exports to Japan.
Reports were received yesterday of transactions involving a number of residential properties in Manhattan.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 3 -- American tanks are superior in speed, fire power and other important characteristics to those of other countries, members of the Society of Automotive Engineers, gathered for their annual Summer meeting, were told today by Brig. Gen. G.M. Barnes, assistant chief of ordnance.

Breaking a seven-day period of irregularity, the cotton futures market developed yesterday moderate strength in more active trading. Closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were at gains of 10 to 14 points for the day. Strength in the securities market was believed to have been a factor in the price rise.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 3 -- Long columns of olive drab trucks began wending their way out of Fort Dix at 8:10 o'clock tonight as the motorized Forty-fourth Division began moving to the South for a campaign against an opponent known only as the "Red Army."

Inclusion of the needs of South American nations in official priorities established by the United States Government on raw materials was suggested yesterday by A.M. Hamilton, vice president in charge of export sales of the American Locomotive Sales Corporation.
John D. Rockefeller Jr., declared yesterday that the campaign of the United Service Organizations for National Defense belonged to every man and woman in the land.
CRETE, Ill., June 3 (AP) -- The Arcturus Stable's Pink Gal was a surprise winner of the Calumet Lake Purse before a small rainyday crowd at Lincoln Fields today.

LONDON, June 3 -- By a vote of 2,430,000 to 19,000 the British Labor party decided at its fortieth annual convention in London today that a compromise peace or peace by negotiation with Germany and Italy was impossible.
NEW YORK Colonel and Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday for their home in Newport.
VICHY, France, June 3 -- Although not a Cabinet member, General Maxima Weygand attended two extraordinary sessions of the Council of Ministers today.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 3 -- After bitterly contested engagements in which invading Red patrols were fought off by scouts of the Blue Twenty-seventh and Thirtieth Infantry diivsions, the manoeuvres of the Second Army's Seventh Corps, numbering close to 60,000 men commanded by Major Gen. Frederic H. Smith, advanced into a new phase today.

Two new films will open in Broadway houses today. At Loew's Criterion the newcomer will be Paramount's "There's Magic in Music," with Susanna Foster, Allan Jones and Margaret Lindsay featured in the story, which has a music-camp background.

As the nation mourned the passing of Lou Gehrig, tributes to the memory of the Iron Man of baseball continued to stream in yesterday. From outstanding persons in all fields of endeavor came expressions of sorrow and words of praise. Governor Herbert H. Lehman called Gehrig a "fine type of American whose example may well be followed by the youth of our State."

The address by Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States and Chancellor of the University of Oxford, at the annual luncheon of Columbia University yesterday in John Jay Hall was as follows:

Opposition among Democratio members of the City Council to continuation of the city's relief tax program for another year at present levels began to develop yesterday after Council President New-bold Morris had introduced a five-bill program designed to raise $74,000,000 in the fiscal year beginning on July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A Senate study of the advisability of lowering the age minimum under the Selective Service Act appeared to be in prospect today. It was learned that the Senate Military Affairs Committee had asked for a full report on the subject.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Roosevelt held a conference of an hour today with John G. Winant, Ambassador to Great Britain, receiving a first-hand report on conditions in England.

JERSEY CITY, June 3 -- As several engine companies of firemen continued today to wet down the ruins of the granary destroyed in the disastrous fire that swept a quarter of a mile of the waterfront here Saturday night, Fred A. Cassidy, president of the Jersey City Stockyards Company, denied that any of its employes were at fault in permitting the fire to get out of hand.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- In a new move to strengthen Britain's Atlantic lifeline, the Maritime Commission Stated today that United States vessels would henceforth handle all British shipping services from Canada and the United States to Australia and New Zealand.

TOKYO, June 3 -- Japan is supplying Germany with 1,500 tons of essential foodstuffs and commodities every day, informed sources declared today, and efforts are being made to increase this traffic despite a recent 500 per cent advance in freight rates to Berlin on Soviet Russia's Trans-Siberian Railway.

Asserting that "more recent developments make united national action doubly urgent on all fronts," President Roosevelt called upon the nation last night to support the $10,765,000 drive of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, which, through its member organizations, plans to operate 360 service clubs in defense centers throughout the nation.

Although dress manufacturers in volume ranges will be able, by one expedient or another, to maintain price lines for Fall without sacrificing quality, there is no final answer to the problem of fitting a sharply rising fabric market into inflexible wholesale and retail price lines, according to manufacturers who discussed the question yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 3 -- Democracy must meet the challenge of totalitarianism not only with the physical weapons of war but with a mobilization of forces for building a better and more secure social order, the National Conference of Social Work was told here today by speakers who characterized the present war as a contest between the free nations and nazism for social reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A Senate-House conference committee voted today to forbid the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to spend money on the St. Lawrence waterway, the Florida ship canal, the Passamaquoddy tidal project, the Tombigbee waterway in the South, and the proposed Nicaragnan Canal.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- By a vote of 45 to 26 the Senate passed the Adams-O'Mahoney Sugar Bill today, which Administration spokesmen assert is a threat to the "good neighbor" policy.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh called the first meeting for members of the Fire Department Auxiliary Corps yesterday for Tuesday evening at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Little by little, the New York Stock Exchange is moving its departments into the building at 11 Wall Street and the lower floors of 18 Broad Street. Already the building at 24 Broad has been cleared of tenants save on the ground floor, where the department of floor procedure remains.

BOSTON, June 3 (AP) -- Although outhit, the Pirates defended their sixth position in the National League against the Braves today by rallying behind Lefty Ken Heintzelman for a 9-5 victory in the series finale.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 3 -- The French High Commissioner for Syria, General Henri Fernand Dentz, has declared a state of siege in the eastern part of the territory, according to reports received here today. At the same time, it is learned that three important bridges in Syria -- two near Aleppo and one at the frontier in the vicinity of Tel Kotchek -- have been destroyed, presumably by the British.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- Mass indictments returned here today charged 194 corporations and individuals with price-fixing and monopolistic control of a defense industry and many foods carried from California to the nation's dinner table.

According to the New Jersey and Long Island charter captains, you can go offshore for tuna, broadbill, marlin or any species of fish you care to try for, but when you come back to the dock you will still have a fish box full of mackerel.

The impression to be had from a regular reading of English literary journals is that publishing in England, despite an unprecedented demand for books from a public seeking relaxation, is not one of the safest of businesses. The publishing row in London is one of the most devastated of areas; book losses have run into the millions of copies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hope that the local readers of THE TIMES do not have the idea that all of us in the Midwest are swallowing hook, line and sinker the opiated bait of the isolationists.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House made it clear today that it is unlikely to agree to President Roosevelt's request that a billion dollars in non-defense items be cut from the 1942 budget.

"Great Britain is still the great producing power of the world and she's still in business," said Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, who was the presiding officer at the premiere showing of the Women's Fashion Export Group of Great Britain on the Hotel Astor Roof yesterday.

A noonday crowd in Wall Street of almost 3,000 cheered yesterday the name of President Roosevelt and the spirit of national unity at a rally on the steps of the Subtreasury Building. Four speakers urged complete aid for Great Britain and a defeat of the totalitarian nations even if it meant war for the United States.

DETROIT, June 3 -- In Briggs Stadium, where his active baseball career came to a dramatic end May 2, 1939, with an ovation from fans that sent him to the dugout in tears, Lou Gehrig's memory was honored today.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Glowing reports of boom retail trade In cities in defense production areas were tempered today by warnings that promotional steps must be taken by merchants to divert rising consumer purchasing power into goods noncompetitive with the defense program if the upswing is not to prove "more boomerang than boom."

JERUSALEM, June 3 -- Massive blocks of stone quarried from the hilsides around Jerusalem, which formed the main building material adorning the Holy City in past years, are now being used in the construction of air-raid shelters. They will be completed before the end of June.

TRENTON, June 3 -- By votes of 18 to 0 and 54 to 0, respectively, the New Jersey Senate and Assembly passed today and Governor Charles Edison signed tonight a bill repealing the charter and incorporation of the German-American Bund Auxiliary and directing the trustees of the organization to dispose of its property in this State forthwith.
The text of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's address delivered at the commencement of Columbia University yesterday was as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The War Department released the following order today, dated June 2:
Business parcels figured in most of the Manhattan sales yesterday, with a seven-story structure in the insurance center, and ten-story and five-story loft buildings passing into new ownership.

The five-story apartment house with an eighty-car garage in the rear at 443-5 Central Avenue, East Orange, N.J., was sold by the National Commercial Title Company to the Rose Clare Realty Company through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers.

Assailing "twentieth century paganism," the Most Rev. Richard L. Cushing, Auxiliary Bishop of Boston, yesterday admonished members of the 1941 graduating class of the College of Mount St. Vincent to prepare for a new order and be ready to meet its challenge with Catholic leadership.

Despite the "intense efforts" of several American relief organizations operating in unoccupied France, "starvation, want and destitution are rampant" there, Howard E. Kershner, director of relief in Continental Europe for the American Friends Service Committee, reported yesterday when he arrived here aboard the Atlantic Clipper.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A toning down of the Administration's bill to authorize government requisition of any private property, real or personal, in the interests of national defense was generally expected today after a conference at the White House between President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders.

ROME, June 3 -- The Brenner Pass meeting was still a mystery today so far as Rome is concerned, but every one knows that big things are bound to happen very soon and that they must have been discussed if not decided upon. The next move is anybody's guess, although the general opinion is that the Eastern Mediterranean will remain the chief theatre of operations for the immediate future.

STANTON, Del., June 3 (AP) -- Threatening weather kept the attendance down to about 5,000 at Delaware Park today, but those who did turn out for the sport enjoyed an afternoon of rather formful racing. Up to and including the feature, three favorites had captured purses and two second choices had won.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order prohibiting the North American Company from making use of its voting control over the North American Light and Power Company at a stockholders' meeting scheduled to be held tomorrow in Wilmington, Del., to dissolve the subsidiary on terms which the commission maintains are unfair to the minority ownership of the publicly held securities of Light and Power.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- If the Administration could find some means of preventing strikes in defense industries, this would make up and possibly more than make up for losses of defense shipments to Great Britain, as the result of German attacks, Senator Tydings asserted in the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The War Department's bill to empower the President to seize, "for just compensation," personal as well as real property which he may deem needful for national defense is a terrific document. The answer of the Department is that this is a terrific emergency.
Syria, larger than all of England but populated only by some 3,630,000 people, may be the key to the campaign of the Eastern Mediterranean, now entering a new phase.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 3 -- Acting Prime Minister Walter Nash told the country the pre-invasion story of Crete in a nation-wide broadcast last night. Mr. Nash called the Cretan operation a delaying rearguard action of the utmost value in relation to the greater struggle ahead and paid tribute to an extraordinary feat of arms performed there.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., June 3 -- The Thirty-eighth Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft) Brigade today began the mobilization training inspection of three separate battalions at this post.

Consolidated net income of the United Gas Corporation in 1940 was $5,519,599 after charges, compared with $5,030,030 the year before, according to the annual pamphlet report issued for distribution today by Joe H. Gill, president. Gross revenues were $44,719,894, against $41,552,759 in 1939.

HARTFORD, June 3 -- A dozen foreign correspondents in whose ears the sound of enemy planes and crashing bombs is still fresh began a flying tour of defense industries today by visiting the big plant here where almost half the airplane engines produced in this country are being built.

Buyers' Total Declines The number of out-of-town buyers reported in town last week was 508, as against 685 in the previous week and 354 in the same period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Buyers registered yesterday totaled 281, which compared with 254 for a week ago.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 3 -- Two extra-hole contests and a hole-in-one that squared a match featured the opening round of match play in the forty-first annual women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship on the Quaker Ridge course today.
Several leases for space on Park and Fifth Avenues were included in the contracts for residential space announced by brokers yesterday.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve yesterday declared that the policy of the United States today is a policy of action, in her address, in which she also discussed the mobilization of women at the Class Day exercises which preceded the graduation of 108 Barnard College seniors at South Field, Columbia University.
Plans were filed yesterday for many new small dwellings in various Queens communities and for several in the Bronx and Brooklyn. The details follow:

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Those high-priced rods and reels and fancy flies and other feathered lures may be a bit scarce and higher priced, it developed at today's convention of the Associated Fishing Tackle Manufacturers.

RALSTON, N.J., June 3 -- Deceptive quiet brooded over this rural hamlet today, with Postmistress Catherine Groenwegen complaining about the misery in her bones and the village folk holding out for sentiment and the philatelists.

Dr. Harry J. Berger, an interne at the Jamaica Hospital, Van Wyck Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, was ordered suspended for two weeks by the medical board of the hospital yesterday as a result of the death on May 26 of Valentine C. Hoelzer Jr., 21 years old, of 85-06 161st Street, Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The critical need for shipping to replace Great Britain's mounting losses today prompted governmental action in several quarters to squeeze tonnage out of this country's dwindling reserves and to step up production in yards already jammed with government contracts.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- The latest public opinion study on the question of using the American Navy to guard ships going to Britain shows that, up to the time of the President's fireside chat at least, the arguments of non-interventionists such as Senators Nye and Wheeler and Colonel Lindbergh apparently halted the rise of national sentiment in favor of naval escorts in the Atlantic.

MOSCOW, June 3 (UP) -- Russia extended her policy of recognizing Germany's conquests today by withdrawing diplomatic recognition of Greece as the envoys of Yugoslavia and Belgium, previously notified that their status was gone, departed from Moscow.

The imposition of priorities in the use of steel has naturally been interpreted by those who have been calling for a very large expansion in steel capacity as proof of the correctness of their position. It proves, they suggest, that we do not have enough steel to meet the national emergency and should therefore lose no further time in setting about the increase of the industry's capacity by at least 10 or 20 per cent.

American traditions of free assembly and free speech have been and are being so prostituted by communistic and Nazi elements, especially in the school system, that "we have carried some of them too far," State Senator Frederio R. Coudert Jr., warned members of the Republican Business Women's group, at a meeting last night at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Grover Cleveland High School's baseball team scored its twelfth Queens P.S.A.L. success in thirteen contests and was assured of at least a tie for the divisional title by blanking Franklin K. Lane, 5 to 0, at Dexter Park yesterday. Pitcher Dick Scheurer, who went the route for Cleveland, gave five scattered safeties and fanned three.
Jack Dempsey suggests the use of a gun instead of a bell to end a round of fighting.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 3 (AP) -- Rochester evened its series with Jersey City today by taking the second game of the set, 5 -- 2, behind the eight-hit pitching of Hank Gornicki.

Crude Oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,786,100 barrels daily, an increase of 13,250 over the 3,772,850 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 13,600 barrels below the calculation of 3,799,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for May.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Defense Mediation Board conferred today with spokesmen for the Twin District Council of the International Woodworkers of America (C.I.O.) in an effort to win the union leaders over to acceptance of the board's proposal of May 23 calling for a return of the 12,000 strikers on the basis of wage adjustments pending appointment of a commission to study and report on the lumbermen's dispute.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 3 -- Three games were played tonight on Long Island polo fields as players prepared for the opening of the twenty-goal championships. In the most interesting match, played on Phipps Old Field, Stewart Iglehart led his Westbury team to an 8-to-7 victory over Charley Wrightsman's Texas Rangers, paced by Cecil Smith.

From the very start this young Republic has been fortunate in the men who have held the great office of Chief Justice of the United States, Jay, Marshall, Taney, Chase: to the best loved and most respected of them history will add the name of the forthright, able man who now lays aside his duties after a life whose long best years were spent in public service.

Following receipt of a cablegram from two of the twenty-four volunteers with the British-American Ambulance Corps, who were aboard the torpedoed Egyptian liner Zamzam. saying that they had been allowed to reach Lisbon, arrangements were made with Pan American Airways last night to bring them back home on the next clipper.

Trading in traefer meats was uneven yesterday. Some cuts were in good demand while others sold slowly. Lamb prices were strong to unevenly higher, virtually the entire kill being Spring lamb. Veal hind-saddles found a little better outlet at steady prices, with some salesmen asking around 50 cents more in spots.

The increasing numbers of young men who have gone into industrial jobs and other national defense activities have created a major personnel problem for the Navy, which, as a result of the general re-employment of young men in industry is facing a serious shortage of recruits for the first time in its history, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Kneeling on the terraced green lawn of the roof garden atop the British Empire Building in Radio City. Lady Halifax, wife of England's Ambassador, yesterday snipped off blossom after blossom for a large bouquet that tomorrow will be on its way by Atlantic Clipper to Queen Elizabeth.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- The Navy Department was accused today by Darius Kline, national representative of the C.I.O.'s United Federal Workers of America, of "using the national emergency as a cloak and pretext under which to discharge and suspend union leaders in a union-busting program."

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for one of the largest of recent offerings of railroad equipment trust certificates, receiving the award of an issue of $11,250,000 of Southern Railway Company "equipments" on their tender of 100.1779 for 2s, or an interest-cost basis of 1.96 per cent.

Sussex, owned, trained and ridden by the amateur polo player, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick, captured the $6,700 Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap before 11,472 persons at Belmont yesterday. Most of the bettors thought London Town was unbeatable, yet the margin at the end of the two miles and a half was two lengths over the racer who went to the post a hot favorite.
LONDON, June 3 (UP) -- Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal in the inner Cabinet, told the Labor party's annual conference today that the goverenment was unanimously opposed to a negotiated peace.

CLEVELAND, June 3 -- Belief that isolationism was the wrong policy for this country and that "positive commitment" was our best course was expressed tonight by Dr. Frank H. Lahey of Boston, president of the American Medical Association. He expressed these views in an inaugural address before several thousand physicians and surgeons at the opening general session of the association's annual meeting.

So far as 18,967 fervent Flatbush fans were concerned, the Dodgers won the pennant yesterday, even though the race is less than one-third over and the standings at the moment show Brooklyn again in a first-place tie with the Cardinals. It was not so much that the Dodgers beat the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday that impressed the faithful followers of the flock.

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and Democratic National chairman, was guest of honor last night at a testimonial dinner in the Hotel Astor at which the subject of politics was taboo, although a substantial majority of the 1,300 in attendance were Democratic leaders and officials.

BERLIN, June 3 -- The Boerse opened firm today following the two-day holiday, but weakened near the close, which was soft and dull. Stocks fluctuated mostly within limits 1 per cent with small losses predominating. Schubert Salzer lost 4 points, Rheinbraun gained 4, Waldhof 5 and Electrisches Licht Kraft 8.

Fifty years may be a long time for some people, but in retrospect it is just a pleasant memory to Professor Edmund Burke, chairman of the Classical Languages Department at City College. Yesterday he lectured to his last Latin class, thus ending an association with the college that began fifty years ago.

Tempting to teetotalers and topers alike are the shiny new tumblers of real wine jellies, with elegant gold rings about their rims and pure enchantment inside. Six of them are on view in rainbow array: port, sherry, burgundy, tokay, sauterne and sauterne-with-mint.

Moving to evade incarceration for refusal to testify before the Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Paul J. Kern, president of the commission, notified the committeemen yesterday that he would testify at any time they set.

Weschler; standing committees -- Herbert Ferber, Berta Margoulies, Marion Walton, Warren Wheelock, Harold Cash, Alice Decker, Nathaniel Kaz, David Michnick, Minna Harkavy, Margaret Kane, Hugo Robus and Cesare Stea.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 3 -- The present high record power output can be increased 20 per cent if the industrial machine of the nation gears itself to a twenty-four-hour-day, seven-day-week basis of operation, Charles W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute, declared here today at the opening business session of its ninth annual convention.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- The last-place Browns finally exploded tonight and scored nine runs in the fifth inning to pave the way for a 14-to-12 victory over the seventh-place Senators and snap their latest losing streak at six games.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 4 -- British bombers carried death and destruction deep into Germany on Monday with an extensive series of raids in daylight and after dark the Air Ministry reported yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The uninterrupted triumphal progress of Germany to date, taken together with the results of the Battle of Crete and the sinking of the Bismarck, should make clear to any intelligent individual that land and sea forces are at the mercy of the nation which dominates the air, and that this war is going to be decided chiefly in the air.

Alice Remembered Well Perhaps it actually was a case of Alice being unable to remember, as the reporters and the public interpreted it. But perhaps it was an exhibition of moral courage, for which we can imagine no parallel in human annals.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Roosevelt had conferences with John G. Winant, Ambassador to Great Britain; William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, and Congressional leaders.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 3 -- Indications of a recrudescence of Iron Guard resistance to the Antonescu regime and the possibility of a new outbreak in Rumania before mid-June were received here together with the report that Horia Sima had just written Premier General Ion Antonescu boastfully offering to appear in court with his principal lieutenants on June 5, when they come up for trial, if three conditions are fulfilled.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 4 -- The British are still bitter over the Crete episode and most anxious over Syria. That the two should be linked is natural because the British Government is facing not only a foreign military but also a domestic political problem as a result of Near Eastern developments.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 -- An audience of more than 23,000 crowded the city schools stadium here tonight to attend the first of four outdoor Summer concerts of the Essex County Symphony Society's sixth season. The program was all-American.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler told the 5,051 graduates and 20,000 guests at Columbia University's 187th commencement yesterday afternoon that the world was now "awaiting another Waterloo" and had "faith that it would come."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- P.D. Houston, president of the American Bankers Association, said today he does not believe this country is going socialistic "in spite of its long trek down that road."

BERLIN, Wednesday, June 4 (UP) -- Authorized Nazi spokesmen said early today that France probably would receive "full German cooperation" under the provisions of recent negotiations if the French should take up arms to resist a British attack on Syria.

Nearly 1,000 representatives of labor and of the construction industry gathered yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress in the Hotel Astor to hear labor leaders and building executives pledge their cooperation in the national defense effort and call for unity in the emergency as the major means of maintaining American traditions and combating totalitarian doctrines.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 3 -- Fifty-one Columbia oarsmen, coaches, managers, trainers and general helpers arrived here today to begin training for the Poughkeepsie rowing classic on June 25. They proceeded directly to their camp below Krum Elbow.
BERLIN, June 3 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Why did Olsen and Johnson leave town? Can't say positively. But a farce carelessly dubbed "Snookie" opened at the John Golden last evening, and that lamentable episode may throw some light on the mystery. When the proofs of the program were rushed to the newspaper offices two days ago, Olsen and Johnson appeared in neat type as the producers.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Reduction in Sunday automobile driving through restriction of gasoline sales on that day and lowering by five degrees of oil heat in home are suggested by a committee of the American Petroleum Institute as a means of conserving oil for defense needs.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- Twenty-one-year-old Tommy Hughes gave Chicago only one hit -- a single by Lou Novikoff in the eighth inning -- as the Phillies shut out the Cubs, 7 to 0, today.

More people than a multitude of baseball followers will mourn the untimely death of Lou Gehrig in his thirty-eighth year. He was one of the great baseball players of all time -- in some ways the greatest. But still more he was a shining example of manliness to all young Americans.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Ways and Means Committee struggled through another executive session today on the controversial excess profits tax proposals, while the House Banking and Currency Committee prepared to report a farm parity lending bill having a cost estimated at the entire prospective revenue from increased corporate and excess profits defense taxes.

With a capacity audience of 960 and an overflow street crowd variously estimated by the police at 500 to 5,000, the Bay Ridge unit of the America First Committee held its first rally last night at the Bay Ridge High School, Senator Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Chief of Information Division of the Farm Security Administration, John Fischer is under investigation for a memorandum urging his assistants to spread to farmers information on the perilous situation of the British, and to warn that invasion of the Western Hemisphere might be expected within 90 to 120 days if Britain were defeated, officials close to Secretary Wickard stated today.
Trucking, steamship and shipping representatives met yesterday at the Port of New York Authority headquarters, 111 Eighth Avenue, to discuss prevention of motor truck congestion at steamship piers.
NEWARK, N.J., June 3 (AP) -- Billie Eaves baffled the Bears with five scattered hits tonight to give the Toronto Leafs a 7-to-1 victory and terminate Newark's five-game winning streak.

A spokesman for leather glove manufacturers expressed yesterday the only opposition at a public hearing in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, to a proposal to restrict homework in the glove industry in New York State. Frieda S. Miller, author of the proposal, presided.
LONDON, June 3 (AP) --The Air Ministry issued this communique early today:

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Hog prices declined 15 to 25 cents today as receipts on the local market reached the highest level since March 19. The slump completely erased all of yesterday's upturn and brought the top price down to $9.45, 20 cents under the recent 1941 high. Lower swine prices developed despite further firming tendencies in the dressed pork market, where gains ranging to 50 cents were recorded.

Joe Louis and Billy Conn met a the New York State Athletic Commission headquarters yesterday and Billy came away without his world light heavyweight championship. No blows were struck, though, and Louis, who is completely satisfied with his possession of the heavyweight crown, was wholly unconcerned over the fact that the Pittsburgh fighter no longer belonged to the royalty of boxing.

VICHY, France, June 3 -- "In the present state of France social peace is a matter of life or death." Thus writes Charles Spinasse today in the neo-Socialist organ Effort as the conclusion to a discussion of salaries and prices.

For the British commonwealth of Nations there can be no turning back in the present conflict, Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, told the Columbia University Alumni luncheon held in John Jay Hall on the campus yesterday noon, as part of the 187th Columbia commencement.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, has refused to issue a complaint against The Day, Jewish language newspaper, against which the Newspaper Guild of New York has been conducting a strike since Feb, 14.

The 2 per cent cash discount is one of the most discussed subjects in the advertising field at the present time. Hardly had the American Association of Advertising Agencies at its recent convention in Hot Springs reaffirmed the need for the cash discount than the Curtis Publishing Company announced it would discontinue cash discounts with the February, 1942, issues of the Saturday Evening Post, Ladies Home Journal and Country Gentleman.

A struggle "against every wave that is a backwash from the past" was demanded last night by Hamilton Fish Armstrong, editor of Foreign Affairs, in a commencement address at the New School for Social Research in New York.

Two speakers at the Atlantic City conference of social workers on Monday had good advice to offer American labor. One was Solicitor General Francis Biddle, who argued that unions have a primary interest in defending democracy and consequently, in making such sacrifices as may be necessary to make defense effective.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Roosevelt's declaration of unlimited emergency was interpreted today by William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman, co-directors of the Office of Production Management, as "an order for all of us to go still further in our effort to make America the arsenal of the world," and a challenge to American management and labor to prove that the workshops of a free democracy can conquer a dictatorship.
FORT WORTH, Texas, June 3 -- Contestants for the forty-fifth United States open golf championship played the Colonial Club course for the first time today and only two came even close to its par 70.

Two French mining operators who arrived here yesterday from the French Cameroons declared that the Free French forces of General Charles de Gaulle total 250,000 men, including many deserters from the regular French Army.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Railroads of the nation, running at full steam to handle an expanding volume of armament shipments, may experience the boom times of 1926 and 1929, Ralph Budd, who has helped direct the transportation phase of the preparedness effort, predicted today.

On or about next Monday Adolf Hitler will proclaim all of Europe a federation of States under German management, according to information received via Lisbon by Archduke Otto of Habsburg, now a resident of the United States.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Buying by mills appeared in the wheat market today in sufficient volume to keep prices on the up-grade most of the session, although there was no great volume of business for outside account. Traders ignored the bearish private reports for June, which showed an average estimate of 680,000,000 bushels for Winter wheat and 201,000,000 bushels for Spring wheat.

The Maritime Commission continued the requisitioning of merchant vessels for military auxiliary use yesterday and notified the American President Lines that it would require another cargo-passenger liner for assignment to the Navy.

The six-story apartment house at 865 East 167th Street, the Bronx, was sold by the G. Hall Associates, Inc., to the Enes Holding Corporation for cash above a $126,533 first mortgage. The house contains fifty-two suites and two stores and is on an irregular plot 105 by 80 feet.

BEIRUT, Syria, June 3 (UP) -- French officials today accused Britain of seeking a "pretext for invasion" of Syria and denied, in a communique, that any German mechanized troops, armored cars and guns had been landed at the Syrian port of Latakia as reported abroad.

Passing in silent tribute to the memory of one of baseball's greats, 5,000 men, women and children paid their respects to Lou Gehrig last night as the body of the former Yankee first baseman lay in state in the Christ Protestant Episcopal Church at Riverdale.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A faster response is essential if Britain's desperate need for 1,000 young American physicians to aid in healing the wounds of the embattled island's civilians and soldiers is to be filled on schedule.

DETROIT, June 3 -- One bad inning sufficed to sink the Yankees at Briggs Stadium today, as the former champions, saddened by the news of Lou Gehrig's death, launched hostilities against the Tigers. In the very first inning Del Baker's champions fell on the frail-looking Steve Peek for four runs and forthwith had more than enough for the day.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday its regular quarterly compilation of business profits, covering the reports of 441 industrial and mercantile corporations for the first three months of this year. These profits, in the aggregate, showed a gain of 16 per cent over the first quarter of last year and were the highest of any initial quarterly period since 1929.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today in connection with an application by the Virginia Electric and Power Company and the Gulf States Utilities Company that electric utility companies having gas properties operated independently of their electric properties and serving large urban areas could not retain them as "incidental businesses" in integrations under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Roosevelt said today that the request by Chief Justice Hughes for retirement from the Supreme Court came to him as a surprise yesterday, and added that he had no idea when this vacancy and that caused by the retirement of Associate Justice James C. McReynolds in February would be filled.

BERLIN, June 3 (UP) -- Germany tonight claimed to have sunk more than half of Britain's merchant shipping, or nearly 12,000,000 tons, on the basis of a High Command communique reporting the destruction of 746,000 tons of enemy shipping during May.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- David O. Selznick confirmed reports today that he is negotiating a deal with United Artists whereby he and Frank Capra will join the company as producing partners. He said he expects the matter to be decided this week.
