Just by way of variety, the Giants had excellent pitching and robust hitting in the very same ball game yesterday, and the New Yorkers toppled the Reds, 7 to 3, at the Polo Grounds to gain an even split in the series.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee directed the federal Communications Commission today to obtain from the country's 849 radio stations a complete record and copies of all speeches delivered over the air on "the war issue."

Subject to the court's approval, the Forrest Theatre, at 226 West Forty-ninth Street, where "Tobacco Road" rolled up the greater portion of its famous run, will be leased to the Shuberts for two years, beginning Sept. 1, it was said yesterday by Milton C. Weisman, trustee for the holders of the first mortgage.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The White Sox celebrated "Connie Mack night" by beating his Athletics, 6 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Thornton Lee tonight. A crowd of 32,659 turned out for the pre-game ceremony honoring Philadelphia's 78-year-old baseball patriarch.

Continued strength In the Canadian dollar and the Cuban peso featured the foreign exchange market yesterday. The Dominion rate advanced 5/8 cent to 88 7/8 cents, reflecting moderately large purchases in the free market for tourist account. At the day's top the rate stood at 89 cents even, the highest since November, 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The "indignation" of the government and people of the United States "at the invasion and mutilation of Yugoslavia by various member States of the Tripartite Pact" is voiced by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in a note, given out today, to Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 4 -- Early this morning four British bombers flew over the harbor of Beirut, capital city of Lebanon, and dropped high explosives on the oil tanks lining the waterfront. It is officially admitted in Beirut that one tank was destroyed and that several fires were started, but later were put out by the fire brigade.

Putting aside its standard wage of $11.20 for a seven-hour day, the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators, A.F. of L., offered yesterday to sign contracts covering painters doing maintenance work in hotels, office buildings and department stores on the basis of a guaranteed annual wage of $1,500.

Three completed playgrounds, two on Manhattan's East Side and one in Brooklyn, will be opened to public use today by the Park Department. The three new areas bring to 423 the total of municipally operated playgrounds in the city, of which 304 have been added to the system since 1934.

CHUNGKING, China, June 4 -- The details of a whole series of battles during the last two weeks between the Communist Eighth Route Army troops and the Japanese in Shansi, Hopei and Suiyuan, including one engagement only thirty miles south of Peiping, are contained in a communique issued by the local Communist headquarters last night on the basis of reports received during the day from North China.

The twenty-two commercial banks in the United States which are owed approximately $31,000,000 in short-term credits by German corporations under the so-called Stand-still Agreement completed yesterday with the German authorities an arrangement for extension of the agreement for another year.

With a program entitled "Concert Swing" the series of six "Coffee" concerts, arranged by Louise Crane, came to a close last night at the Museum of Modern Art. All of the participants in the final event were Negro cabaret entertainers of repute, who made their contributions among the most compelling of the series in vigor and excitement.
Flying the blue and gold colors of Sweden from her taffrail, the new Swedish motorship Remmaren arrived in New York Harbor yesterday with seventeen passengers from Gothenburg.

A weary little hen pigeon, unromantically designated as SSC 2489, dropped on Samuel Tufano's pigeon cote at 86-25 102d Road in Ozone Park, Queens, at 10:58 A.M. Tuesday, possibly the only survivor of a flight of 1,000 homing birds liberated at 6:10 A.M. Saturday in Spartanburg, S.C., for a 600-mile race to New York.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 4 -- Invasion of the fertile central valley of Middle Tennessee by Red, ("enemy") columns driving toward the Mississippi River has been checked by the Blue ("defending") forces who, counter-attacking along a fifteen-mile front between Fosterville and Short Mountain, tonight occupied the forward northern slopes of the rim of the Cumberland Watershed.

Frederick J. Perry, former world amateur champion from Great Britain, and William Tilden, invincible against all comers from 1920 through 1925, will play the opening match in the professional round-robin tennis tournament which starts tomorrow in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4 -- Plans for cushioning the post-war economic slump that inevitably will follow the end of the present gigantic defense effort were discussed at today's session of the convention of the Edison Electric Institute in the Hotel Statler here.

The funeral service for Lou Gehrig yesterday was as simple and as modest as the man in whose memory it was held. Not more than a hundred intimates of one of baseball's immortals -- relatives, friends and associates -- were in the flowerbanked Christ Church in Riverdale for a last farewell to the renowned Iron Horse.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 4 -- Despite the worst downpour in the history of the tournament, all the favorites came through by comfortable margins in the second round of match play in the forty-first annual women's metropolitan golf championship over the Quaker Ridge course today.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Massachusetts has been chosen as the site for the first major test of civilian defense measures, which will be held this Fall with mock air raids, blackouts and strict pedestrian and traffic control.

Samuel Feldman, who practiced law in the Criminal Courts Building since it was dedicated in 1893 and expected to participate in the dedication of its successor across Centre Street on June 30, died on Tuesday in New York Hospital after a brief illness.

Earl Robinson, the composer, and Will Geer, the actor, last night presented a program at Town Hall entitled "A Cavalcade of American Song" for the benefit of the New York Committee to Aid Agricultural Workers. With Lee Hayes serving as narrator, the program traced the development of American ballads from the songs of the Revolution to the Dust Bowl ballads of today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Navy expects to complete within one year all work on the naval bases leased from Great Britain, Rear Admiral Ben Moreell, Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks, said today.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- A six-point "all-out" program for combating runaway price increases was recommended to retailers today by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at a special meeting held in conjunction with its midyear convention here.

BRIELLE, N.J., June 4 -- Bonito, the fish that met the mortgage payments on many a charter boat last Summer, are now crowding the inshore waters from Shark River to Manasquan River and are being taken by surfcasters as well as anglers fishing from boats.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- All Americans in Baghdad were reported safe and well today by Paul Knabenahue, the United States Minister resident to Iraq. Although he said there was no definite news of Americans outside of Baghdad, he believed they also were safe.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 4 -- With the eyes of Texas and the golfing world focused on them, stars from almost every nook and corner of the United States today were busily engaged in tuning up their games for the national open which starts tomorrow on the woody and watery Colonial Club course.

DETROIT, June 4 -- The Yankees met their third postponement of the year because of inclement weather today. The scheduled second contest of the series with the Tigers was washed out by a downpour which fell through the morning, almost up to game time.
BERLIN, June 4 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Banking and Currency Committee of the House today reported a bill containing an amendment inserted only yesterday by the farm group which would guarantee to American farmers 85 per cent of parity prices for all commodities exported to Britain under the lease-lend program.

LONDON, Thursday, June 5 -- An air-raid alarm was sounded in London this morning and there was a small amount of anti-aircraft fire, after which the raid fizzled off to nothing. But London's people took shelter, remembering the raids of April 16 and May 10.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation and the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of William S. Menden as president and director of both corporations. He is expected to become a consulting engineer for a corporation in the contracting business.

Metro's "Love Crazy,'' which opens at the Capitol, is this morning's lone new film attraction. The comedy, starring William Powell and Myrna Loy, features Gail Patrick, Jack Carson, Florence Bates, Sidney Blackmer and Sig Riumann. . . . "Blood and Sand" at the Roxy and "Penny Serenade" at the Radio City Music Hall enter their third and final weeks today.
A duplex suite of twelve rooms in the cooperative building at 812 Park Avenue has . been leased by J. Townsend Russell through Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.

ARCOLA, N.J., June 4 -- R.P. Blossfeld of White Beeches, competing in Class C, carded 42, 43-85 for low gross honors in the annual Spring golf tournament of the New Jersey State seniors over the rain-soaked Arcola Country Club course today.

BERWICK, Pa., June 4 -- Today, with a dozen other reporters just back from the battle front in Europe, this correspondent visited the plant of the American Car and Foundry Company, which is producing ten light fast tanks a day for the United States Army to share with Great Britain under the lease-lend act.

Sixteen years of successful charitable enterprise warrant a celebration and yesterday founders and sponsors of the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, paused to enjoy a birthday cake. The one-layer flower-decked cake was cut by Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie, who attended as guest of honor and achieved the status of volunteer worker before parting.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Neither guns, tanks nor airplanes will decide the war eventually, Dr. Frank Kingdon assured representatives of more than 300 organizations of Jewish women yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, because wars are won or lost "in the hearts of the people."

"Children love chocolate," said the plump, kindly woman who was mixing for us a milk-shake of the new Vitamin B-1 chocolate syrup. We suggested that we, too, loved chocolate. We especially liked the chocolate drink that she smilingly handed us and we like to think that we were consuming in this pleasant manner some dozens of units of that healthful vitamin.

The New York Guard is about up to full authorized strength and is "way ahead" of any other State Guard in number, training, organization and equipment, Major Gen. William Ottmann, commanding general of the militia, declared yesterday at a joint luncheon of the Military-Naval and Columbia University Clubs at their headquarters, 4 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Office of Production Management has asked the steel industry to make plans for expanding productive capacity by 10,000,000 tons, it was learned in official quarters today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, arrived in Washington today for conferences with officials. It is expected that before he returns to the Pacific he will confer with President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Hog prices firm In the livestock market today, recording gains of 10 to 15 cents on weights under 270 pounds, as salable receipts were cut to half Tuesday's total. Overnight producer cancellation of loadings, following Tuesday's market break, held down fresh runs in most major trading centers.

Capital Needs In line with a suggestion made two years ago by its public examining board, the New York Stock Exchange published yesterday the capital requirements of firms which handle margin accounts in commodities.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The cost of living in thirty-three large American cities, which stood at 99.1 per cent of the 1935-39 average in March, 1940, had risen to 102.2 at the end of last month, according to figures in the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The first reported case of a securities swindle by salesmen who cited the defense program to promote their stock was disclosed yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett.

TOKYO, June 4 -- A new battle, aiming at the annihilation of some 70,000 Chinese who are said to have escaped from the Chungyuan battle, now is under way in the Chungtiao range, according to a statement issued today by imperial headquarters in Tokyo.
BERLIN, June 4 -- Wilhelm II, former German Kaiser, died in exile at his estate in Doorn, the Netherlands, shortly before noon today. He was in his eighty-third year.

One knows worthy persons who lie awake in the silent midnight watches, distressed to hear the colleges and universities growing so fast. Where are the old close friendships? Where are the ties between the mob of students and the faculty? Well, here is City College, of which each graduate can say: "It is a big college, and yet there are those that love it."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 4 -- The gold medal of the American Medical Association, given annually for exhibits based on individual investigations, was presented here today by the A.M.A.'s committee on awards to a team of physicians and chemists headed by Professor A.C. Ivy of the Northwestern University Medical School for their exhibit demonstrating the proper use of bile salts in disorders of the liver and the gallbladder.

Schiaparelli, who was an amateur herself a long time ago, banded yesterday four sizable checks to as many winners in the national sewing contest, as the first such event terminated with a style show of the resultant costumes at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Tense Hughes Moments Charles E. Hughes, in his early public career, was usually described as cold, even by his admirers. In his later, mellower years people will think of him as stern, if kind.

Although the food industry has been aware since last November that the United States Department of Justice was conducting a sweeping investigation of its operations, word from San Francisco yesterday of the indictment of West Coast producers of dried fruits, vegetables and milk and California canners for alleged Anti-Trust Law violations, took the industry here by surprise.

The biggest fleet of varsity crews since 1929 will go away from the stakeboats at Poughkeepsie June 25 when nine crews leap into action at the command of Howard Robbins of Syracuse, who is to be the new referee of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta that day.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Representative M. Michael Edelstein of New York collapsed and died in the lobby of the House today five minutes after making a speech replying to assertions that Jews and bankers were trying to get the United States into the war.

Former Kaiser Wilhelm wanted to die as a "prince of peace," according to his friend and biographer, the 85-year-old writer, Poultney Bigelow, who looks something like the Kaiser, frequently chopped wood with him at Doorn and is an admirer of both the Kaiser and Chancellor Hitler.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A cryptic remark by the Army's construction quartermaster stirred conjecture among members of Congress tonight as to whether the Army would be increased to 2,800,000 men, double the existing goal of 1,418,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 4 -- Baccalaureate degrees were received by 206 graduates of the New Jersey College for Women at the institution's twentieth commencement ceremony in the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Chapel today.

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- Increasing terrorism in Croatia is reported in messages reaching authoritative loyalist Croat circles in the Middle East, to whom it is reported that four military tribunals recently were instituted to try hundreds of cases of alleged sedition, which really is loyalty to the Yugoslav kingdom.

BERLIN, June 4 -- The reaction of the German press today to the death of the former Kaiser Wilhelm II is in substance uniform. It represents the historical judgment that National Socialism, in the midst of another war with the British Empire, passes upon a former Kaiser who was unsuccessful in a similar conflict.

An investing client of Darling McDonald, brokers, has purchased from Enterprise Equities, Inc., the one-story taxpayer building at 4001-5 White Plains Road, on the northwest corner of 226th Street, the Bronx, for cash above a first mortgage of $21,500 running for seven years with interest at 4 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- The pinch being felt by the makers of semiluxury goods as the result of the preparedness effort was illustrated today in the annual report of the Zenith Radio Corporation, issued by Eugene F. McDonald Jr., president. He emphasized that the big problem before his, company was obtaining materials for production, instead of the usual one of merchandising.

In an attempt to anticipate shipping difficulties on exports to Latin-American and other markets, export houses are permitting agents abroad to build up stocks of products for later use, foreign traders said yesterday at the monthly round-table session of the foreign credit interchange bureau, National Association of Credit Men, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Maritime Commission gave orders today to operators of vessels in coastwise Atlantic and Gulf trade to turn over immediately 50 per cent of their tonnage for diversion to transatlantic operation as part of the program for aiding British shipping needs.

Nine days ago President Roosevelt declared it to be this nation's policy to defend the freedom of the seas. He said that "our patrols are helping now to insure delivery of needed supplies to Britain" and that "all additional measures necessary to deliver the goods will be taken."

All Communist party records in this State dealing with membership or dues payments have been destroyed by direct order of national headquarters, four State leaders of the party testified yesterday at the resumption of the Rapp-Coudert committee hearings at the New York County Court House.

Wilhelm Hohenzollern, former German Emperor and King of Prussia, fell from the most exalted heights to a tragic debacle perhaps without parallel in modern history. He died in exile, self-imposed, having fled to the Netherlands the day before the armistice that ended the World War.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- From a reporter's notebook, on a day when -- continuing proof that everything is relative -- the death of the ex-Kaiser reminded his late American foes that in 1917 they thought him the final archetype of German militarism, not realizing they hadn't seen nothin' yet:
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Ways and Means Committee rejected today the Treasury's proposals for a revised excess profits tax law, voting to retain the present two methods of computing tax liability.

Sir Gerald Campbell, as the newly appointed director-general of British Information Services in the United States, held out the promise yesterday that this country in the future would have more complete and authentic news reports of Britain's war effort, rather than the ordinary and statistical communiques of the past.

The last of the famous Vanderbilt mansions of Fifth Avenue -- the imposing three-story brownstone residence of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt on the northwest corner at Fifty-first Street -- was opened to the public last night for the first time in its long and celebrated history for a brilliant military ball arranged to advance the newly instituted campaign of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc.

The number of industrial companies which are placing orders on important materials a year in advance has expanded sharply in the last ten days, purchasing agents reported here yesterday. The President's declaration of an unlimited emergency and the acceleration in the defense program have suddenly awakened some top executives to the seriousness of the supply situation and they have given their buying agents carte blanche on advance commitments.

Several innovations, including the use of additional bells to signal the close of each round, are to be introduced at the Joe Louis-Billy Conn world heavyweight championship fight at the Polo Grounds on June 18, it was announced yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs.

The resignation of the Egyptian Cabinet presents another complication in the labyrinth of events in the Middle East. It brings to the fore once more a question that has been the principal problem of the Egyptian Government ever since the outbreak of war in September, 1939 -- should Egypt declare war against the Axis?

The War Department has made formal request of the Labor Department's public contracts division to suspend the Walsh-Healey law in its application to canned food orders. The reason given is that the Army has had to pay excessive prices for canned foods from speculative holdings, and wishes to save by buying directly from the canners.

Rain cracked down with a vengeance on major league baseball in the metropolitan area yesterday, when both the Dodgers' engagement with the Cubs at Ebbets Field in the afternoon and the Giants' conflict with the Pirates at the Polo Grounds last night were washed on to the postponed calendar.

SOME time when you are out for a drive in New Jersey, take U.S. 9 south across the Raritan River, past Perth Amboy and South Amboy, into Monmouth County. Just over the county line, not far from Matawan, the highway bears right into a village called Freneau. Continuing a few hundred yards farther, you come to a lane or driveway, flanked by rows of trees and leading off to the left.

Local representatives of the French. Line said yesterday that the 4,464-ton liner Due D'Aumale, scheduled to depart for Martinique with a cargo of foodstuffs and supplies, had been held here' as a result of a libel action extended by British interests.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The State Department awaited a report today from Ambassador William D. Leahy in Vichy, France, on his conversation with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain concerning the course the Vichy government purposes to follow in Europe.

The City Planning Commission closed a public hearing yesterday on a proposal to increase population density in the Chelsea section of Manhattan where a $4,138,000 housing project for 2,359 persons is planned.

The Bronx Symphony Orchestra did its part last night to help along the borough's "March of Culture" with a concert in the auditorium of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, East Fordham Road and Washington Avenue.

The New York A.C. games began to take shape yesterday with the entry of athletes from Princeton and Yale for the annual meet at Travers Island on Saturday. But the biggest surprise of all was the discovery of the entry of Ed Burrowes.

Four of the former Kaiser's six sons are living in Germany as private citizens; one is at the front as an army officer, and one is dead, a suicide. His only daughter lives in Germany. Eleven grandsons and one grandnephew are in the German armed forces.

Price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were within narrow limits in quiet trading. After showing moderate strength early in the session, when advances of 4 to 7 points were registered, a gradual recession in the afternoon reduced these to net gains of 1 to 6 points.

The State of New York soon will receive $663,135.22 that several thousand New Yorkers have failed for the past thirty-one years to recover from the gas companies. The State had asked for $1,250,000 interest on the amount, but that demand was rejected yesterday.

Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, expressed last night his ''firm conviction" that the war must be kept from spreading to the Pacific. Admitting that Japanese-American relations are difficult at the moment, Admiral Nomura maintained his confidence that it would still be possible to work out a peaceful solution.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Secretary Knox asked Congress today to prohibit all photographs or sketches of national defense centers or objects anywhere, and said Japanese agents were taking such pictures.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 4 -- Warning his listeners that he had "nothing comforting to say" about the political-economic situation of Switzerland in the Europe of today, Marcel Plet-Golaz, last year's President of the Conferedation and now the equivalent of Foreign Minister as director of the Political Department, reported today to the Council of States on the activities of his department.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Ambassador Winant who again had a long conference wilh President Roosevelt today, is making a detailed report to him on British mistakes in the war so that the full force of United States aid program will be directed into proper channels and insure final victory for the democracies, it was learned tonight.
A large detail of trained men of the United States Coast Guard is being assembled rapidly in the Port of New York for assignment to the Navy's growing transport fleet, it was disclosed yesterday.

Tests of the sampling method used to determine possible future commissions on the New York Stock Exchange are being made this week by the management engineers employed by the institution. They are asking about two dozen member firms to apply suggested schedules for stock and bond commissions to the business actually done in the five days of last week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES was more than justified in questioning Colonel Lindbergh sharply about the "new leadership" of which he has now spoken several times. There has been an unpleasant vagueness about the nature of this "new leadership" and the methods by which it is to be attained.

A distinguished-looking man, born in Logan County, Ohio, in 1861, sat on the dais of the huge grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor yesterday and 'was eulogized by a half dozen speakers before 750 at a luncheon given in his honor by the Electrical and Gas Association of New York, Inc.

Drexel Co., Stroud Co., Inc., and Bioren Co. head a group which will offer today at 105, and dividends accrued from May 1, this year, 4,021 shares of the Luzerne County Gas and Electric Corporation's 5 1/4, per cent cumulative $100 par value preferred stock, of which 39,979 shares are being issued in exchange for an equal number of shares of outstanding $7 dividend and $6 dividend first preferred stocks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- Metro named George Murphy today to play opposite Ann Sothern in the screen version of "Panama Hattie," which will go before the cameras next month with Norman McLeod directing. Murphy's role will be that of Nick Bullett, played on Broadway by James Dunn; Miss Sothern will be seen as Hattie Maloney, Ethel Merman's part on the stage.

DOORN, the Netherlands (by telephone to Berlin), June 4 (AP) -- The death of Wilhelm II came so unexpectedly today that not only had the former Crown Prince, Friedrich Wilhelm, left the bedside, but other members of the ex-Kaiser's family had planned to depart yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -- A Federal district court injunction was asked today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to forestall a proposed dissolution of an intermediate holding company by the North American Company, but Judge John P. Nields set June 27 for argument and, with counsel for the SEC and North American in agreement, directed that a stock-holders' meeting scheduled for today be delayed until June 30.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A declaration that the United States was not arming fast enough to give it a substantial margin over current German military production was made before the special Senate Defense Committee today by Stacy May, chief of the Bureau of Research and Statistics of the Office of Production Management.

Responding to an emergency call flashed on all the call boards and in the nurses' home at noon yesterday, twelve doctors and twelve nurses rushed to the emergency room of Roosevelt Hospital, Ninth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, picked up special cases containing medical supplies and entered two waiting ambulances, ready within four minutes after the alarm to rush to the scene of a disaster.

Joseph W. Carroll, for nineteen years an attache of the State Controller's office, testified in General Sessions yesterday that he was solely responsible for signing a $250,000 printing contract awarded to the Burland Printing Company in 1935. He was a witness in the defense of William Solomon, Tammany district leader, and Charles H. Mullens, former assistant State Controller, charged with accepting bribes to obtain contracts for that concern.

Victor Emanuel's Omission, ridden by Conn McCreary, drove through mud and rain at Belmont Park yesterday to capture the forty-first Swift Stakes at seven furlongs. The victory grave McCreary the riding leadership of the meeting and he later completed a triple to increase his margin.

While one or two manufacturers of outboard motors had foresight enough last year to continue production after the Summer season and to pile up large stocks, output of most makers is now being seriously curtailed by the scarcity of aluminum, it was learned here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Colleagues of M. Michael Edelstein joined in a ceremony of eulogy today when Representative Dickstein brought word of his passing.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Wheat closed a trifle lower today, following a brisk upturn early in the session. Both the September and December sold well above $1 a bushel in the early trade with further short covering being influenced by mill buying and reports of big flour sales.

The action of the House Ways and Means Committee in shelving the Treasury's proposal to base excess-profits taxes entirely on invested capital brought yesterday a late rally in the stock market which extended the recovery movement of Tuesday.

Representatives of Great Britain, the Federal, State and municipal governments and the Army and Navy joined yesterday with the Roman Catholic hierarchy of this diocese at a solemn pontifical mass offered in St. Patrick's Cathedral for the "suffering people of Great Britain."

Paul Lukas has won this year's Variety poll of the drama critics for the season's best performance, it was announced yesterday in the magazine. Of the nine critics whose choices were listed, Mr. Lukas's name appeared on all. The actor is appearing in "Watch on the Rhine."

Scarcity of essential chemical and pharmaceutical supplies, attributed to diversion of the basic chemicals to industrial uses in the defense program, was reported yesterday by both private hospitals and the City's Purchasing Office division of chemical and drug purchases.

Drought conditions prevalent in the Northeast for the past few weeks showed a decided improvement yesterday with the arrival of heavy rains from a low pressure area central over extreme Eastern Ohio. Although there is still a precipitation deficiency, farmers and horticulturists throughout New York and New Jersey welcomed yesterday's rainfall and predicted that it might save a number of crops that had been considered lost.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The War Department today announced defense contract awards in the amount of $15,545,234.61, including one calling for 4-ton cargo trucks and wreckers, valued at $3,717,966.25, which went to the Diamond Corporation of Chicago.

Demand was fair to good for all classes of traefer meats in yesterday's trading. Prices of steer binds and ribs which have had little support the last week recovered to some extent and the market was steady to strong. Some early sales were made at steady prices, but later transactions were around 50 cents higher.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Hans Kindler, conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra, today announced programs for ten Summer concerts by the orchestra at its Summer home, a floating acoustical shell moored in the Potomac River near the Lincoln Memorial.
NEW YORK Mrs. Potter Palmer has arrived from Bar Harbor and is at the Pierre.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- Maurice J. Cannalbnga, a government witness who had been sought by the defense since May 6 in the deportation proceedings against Harry Bridges, appeared this afternoon to deny the authenticity of a statement he allegedly had given a defense attorney in Portland, Ore., on May 4.
Two war clouds are converging rapidly over Syria. One rolls up from Crete. The other looms to the south, where Britain has massed her combat forces on the border.

A German Messerschmitt 109 plane that was shot down several weeks ago by the R.A.F. over England arrived in this city yesterday by rail from Canada to be exhibited for the benefit of the war relief fund of Bundles for Britain, but it had to remain in its crate in the Bronx freight yards above East 138th Street until special authorization can be obtained from Washington to clear it through customs.

Harvey Stevenson, of the firm of Morris O'Connor, 101 Park Avenue, was elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects at the annual luncheon meeting of the organization held yesterday in the Architectural League.

NEWARK, N. J., June 4 -- Testifying this afternoon as a State's witness in the trial here of Charles (The Bug) Workman for the murder of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer. Mrs. Frances Flegenheimer, widow of "The Dutchman," disclosed that she was watching a motion picture in a local theatre while her husband was shot in a tavern here.

Huge stocks of food for Army, Navy and civilian use were tied up yesterday by a strike of 1,450 A.F. of L. warehouse workers. Employer spokesmen and government officials in first-hand touch with the situation said millions of dollars worth of war materials and foodstuffs for Great Britain were stored in the strike-bound warehouses, but the union denied that any British supplies were involved.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- President Don Barnes of the Browns announced tonight Fred Haney was being replaced as manager of the club by Luke Sewell, Cleveland coach. Sewell will take charge of the team tomorrow.

The last of the fashion luncheons for the season was held yesterday on the terrace at Belmont Park in spite of the rain. An amusing overture to the presentation was the lilting tune "I'm Singing in the Rain," played on an accordion.

The Republic of Colombia today will formally announce its exchange offer to the holders of its outstanding 6 per cent dollar bonds, due on Jan. 1 and Oct. 1, 1961. A new issue of government 3 per cent sinking fund dollar bonds, to be dated Oct. 1, 1940, and maturing on Oct. 1, 1970 is being put forward in exchange for the old securities.

LONDON, June 4 -- A declaration of the British Labor party's aims regarding post-war reconstruction was adopted by a vote of 2,413,000 to 30,000 today at the concluding session of the party's convention in London. The declaration follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- While the national defense program and attendant industrial expansion have materially increased employment, it is a mistake to think that the relief problem is no longer serious, F.D. Flanner, spokesman for the American Public Welfare Association, told the National Conference of Social Work here today.

A benefit entertainment to raise funds for a John Philip Sousa Memorial auditorium in Washington, scheduled for next Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, has been indefinitely postponed, it was announced yesterday at committee headquarters in the Hotel Delmonico.
Leading rentals among the commercial leasing transactions reported yesterday called for space in several Fifth Avenue buildings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The rise of active Vichy hostility against America and England is a hard blow for the hundreds of Americans who served in the other war in such French combat units as the Foreign Legion and the Lafayette Flying Corps.

April payments of $231,738,000 to life insurance policyholders and their beneficiaries were the largest month's total this year, according to the report of the Institute of Life Insurance. This is at the rate of $7,725,000 a day, compared with the daily rate of $7,299,000 in 1940.

NEWTON, N.J., June 4 -- The German-American Bund Auxiliary, it became known today, transferred ownership of Camp Nordland yesterday to 217 individuals, all classified as members of the now defunct organization by Sheriff Denton J. Quick of Sussex County, who regards the action as "an attempt to flaunt the law."

LONDON, June 4 (UP) -- The death of former Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany, hated as intensely twenty-five years ago as Adolf Hitler is today, drew general expressions of compassion for the elderly exile, whom the British had come to pity.

FORT MEADE, Md., June 4 -- The "fog of war" hovered over the Forty-fourth Division's bivouac area tonight as the 16,000 troops and 2,000 vehicles under command of Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell awaited instructions to resume their advance to Caroline County, Va., to participate in an intensive three-day manoeuvre.

The start of full preparedness for this nation should be care of the health and welfare of the boys and girls of the country, "the great intangible which makes or breaks nations," James A. Farley declared last night.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The request of the National Defense Mediation Board that 12,000 striking loggers in the State of Washington return to work at higher wages, pending a study of pay rates and working conditions, was turned down today by O.M. Orton, president of the International Woodworkers of America (C.I.O.).

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $104,347,326 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average share price of all listed stocks on May 31 was $25.84, compared with $25.78 at the end of April.

LONDON, June 4 -- The similarity between the British and German systems for rationing clothing was pointed out today by the Ministry of Economic Warfare, which has dug up all its knowledge of what is happening to Great Britain's enemy in this phase of modern life in Europe.

Coat, Suit Label Sales Up 308% A new record of 132,500 consumers' protection labels were distributed by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board in the last three days, F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary, announced last night.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Art Johnson, rookie southpaw, dropped the Cardinals down into second place today by holding them to nine scattered hits as the Braves belted Harry Gumbert for a 4-2 victory. It was Gumbert's first setback in five starts since St. Louis obtained him from the Giants.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 4 -- Major Vidkun Quisling's police, say reports from Norway, are investigating the accounts of scores of factories and shops for evidence of support of the enemies of the Nazi regime.

The shortage of fuel oil, which will have a serious effect on the sale of oil burners, may prove on the other hand a boon to oil-burning: room heaters, which have been coming along steadily in the last year. Oil would be conserved by the use of heaters if only a few rooms, for instance, were kept heated.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Assertions that the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System "dictate" to their affiliated stations to the extent that they decide what non-network programs are in the public Interest and what rates should be charged for some non-network programs were made today by James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
Deals involving loft buildings, tenement and rooming houses in Manhattan were announced yesterday. Savings banks figured prominently as sellers in the activity.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presented the seventy-two Bachelor of Arts degrees to the graduates of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, Convent Avenue and 133d Street, yesterday afternoon. Fifteen Bachelors of Music degrees also were awarded.

VICHY, France, June 4 -- Addressing the opening session of the professional organization committee summoned to study France's new labor statute, Marshal Henri Fhilippe Petain today reiterated that the New French State would be "hierarchical and authoritarian."

Miss Florence Overton, supervisor of branches of the New York Public Library since 1914, has retired after forty-two years of service. She has been succeeded by Miss Esther Johnston, librarian of the central circulation branch of the library since 1924.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4 -- The United States will have to spend at least $100,000,000,000 to match the German war machine and the people of this country will have to plow 25 per cent of the national income into defense production for a successful consummation of the war effort, W.L. Batt, deputy director of the Office of Production Management, declared here today.
LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued the following communique early today:

Approximately 1,000 churches in Britain have been destroyed or seriously damaged by Nazi bombs and many more have been less seriously damaged, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church here, reported yesterday in a broadcast from London over the WEAF red network of the National Broadcasting Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 -- A United States-built Maryland reconnaissance plane spotted a destroyer-escorted convoy of Axis merchant vessels slipping southward along the Tunisian coast yesterday. Royal Air Force bombers then swooped over the quarry, blowing up and sinking an 8,000-ton ship, setting afire a vessel of about 5,000 tons, and damaging several others.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- The Browns gained seventh place in the American League by one percentage point in defeating the Senators today, 7 to 4. The victory was St. Louis's second in a row over 'Washington, which dropped into the cellar.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4 -- The Wcstchester County Defense Council announced today that in many communities of the county an average of 70 per cent of the men, women and children qualified for home defense work had registered and signified willingness to serve as emergency firemen, policemen, first aid workers, guards and defense helpers in other fields.

BERLIN, June 4 -- The report contained in a North American Newspaper Alliance article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES declaring that Adolf Hitler was planning to proclaim a "United States of Europe" was termed "a product of fantasy" by authoritative German quarters today.

Of interest to many members of society here and on the North Shore of Long Island will be the annual showing of the rose gardens and estate of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field at Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L.I., on the afternoon of June 14 for the benefit of Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, of which Mr. Field is president.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -- J.W.Y. Martin's Abrasion, which had failed to hold his own in keener competition in last Saturday's Wilmington Handicap at Delaware Park, was a handy winner of the six-furlong Smyrna Handicap today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Plans to step up production of finished 100-octane aviation gasoline to 50,000 barrels daily in the next eighteen months, to meet mounting military demands of the United States and British air forces, were reported today by the Office of Production Management.

Degrees, certificates, prizes and medals will be awarded to 236 graduates of the Institute of Technology, Night School of Engineering and Day and Night Art Schools of Cooper Union at that institution's eighty-second annual commencement exercises at 8 P.M. today.

English and Americans, Catholics, Protestants, Jews and even a few Moslems prayed together yesterday at a solemn Pontifical Mass celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral for the suffering people of Britain. It was a unique and moving service, a community of sympathy and supplication.

Councilman Louis Cohen, chairman of the Council committee investigating Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, announced yesterday that supervising physicians at the city institution would be subpoenaed to testify before the committee next Wednesday on complaints of negligence and discrimination at the hospital.

VICHY, June 4 -- It was noted that Marshal Petain accompanied Ambassador Leahy to the elevator after their conference this morning in the marshall's office on the third floor of the Hotel du Parc and that their leave-taking appeared very cordial.

Norton, having had a good response to the three recent books on "what the citizen should know" about the Navy, Army and Coast Guard, is going on with the series. Four new titles will be brought out this August -- one on civilian defense, others on the Marines, the merchant marine and on arms and weapons.

Representative William P. Lambertson of Kansas is making an attempt to obtain a hearing before the Dies committee in behalf of the seven members of the Actors Equity council, the union's governing board, whom he named as Communists or fellow-travelers, according to word received from Washington yesterday.

The four-story apartment house for sixteen families at 1521 West Seventh Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Gussie Shapiro to William Berg in one of three deals arranged by Sidney Levine, broker. The property is on a plot 40 by 100 feet and is said to be fully rented.

LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- Nazis bandaged and limping like wounded soldiers and others carrying suitcases labeled with big J's to disguise them as Jewish refugees were reported arriving in French-mandated Syria today. Germany is hurrying forces by air, sea and land to strengthen the vanguard already in Syria, said a dispatch by Reuters, British News Agency, from the Syrian border.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- Fourteen "non-operating" railroad labor organizations, representing more than 800,000 workers, decided today to seek wage increases of 30 to 34 cents an hour.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 (AP) -- Egypt listed Syria as "German-occupied territory" and broke off all trade and other relations with that French mandate today. The order did not apply to adjoining French Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a long-distance telephone rate reduction agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company effective July 10, which, it was said, represented annual savings of $14,000,000 to telephone users.

Officials of Milwaukee County, Wis., will award today an issue of $7,500,000 of poor relief bonds on the basis of bids received yesterday. At the request of county officials tenders were submitted for two different maturities: (1) the obligations all due on April 1, 1942, and callable in whole or in part on or after Feb. 1, 1942, and (2) with the bonds due serially on April 1, 1942 to 1948.

Arthur A. Ballantine, as trustee of the Continental Securities Corporation, and John Gerdes and James D. Carpenter Jr., as trustees of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., applied yesterday to the Supreme Court, for appointment of a receiver for the interest of Clarence K. Reynolds in the brokerage firm of Granberry Co. and for all property held by Mr. Reynolds in this State.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP) -- Alva Bradley, president of the Indians, tonight expressed regret at the loss of Coach Luke Sewell, and added he felt sure the former catcher would "make good" as manager of the Browns. Bradley said he had given permission to the Browns to deal with Sewell before Luke went to St. Louis last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES last Sunday "Manufacturer" has a letter so misleading that it should be corrected. It is misleading because it presents the beauty, the justice and the democracy of universal small business and industry prevailing formerly as of today, instead of considering things as they are, resulting from steam power and the big machine.

VICHY, France, June 4 -- The Petain government tonight officially accused Great Britain of preparing "a plan of action" against Syria, where French defenses, strengthened with consent of the Axis, were said to be strong enough to hurl back any attempted invasion.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The name of The Chicago Banker, forty-three-year-old local banking weekly publication, will be changed soon to Finance, which will be published as a national magazine covering the general field of banking and finance.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $4,000,000 of Chicago Sanitary District construction bonds on a bid of 101.519 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, dated June 1, 1941, and due on July 1, 1960, callable from Jan. 1, 1943, to July 1, 1960, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.60 to 2.15 per cent, according to the optional dates.

For the first time in twenty-five years, rain canceled the annual Anniversary Day parades of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union yesterday in twenty-eight borough neighborhoods. The celebration of the 125th anniversary of the founding of the union and its 112th annual parade, which heretofore attracted 100,000 adults and children, was confined to simple ceremonies in Protestant churches in all parts of the borough.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Southern Natural Gas Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering $13,000,000 of first mortgage pipe-line sinking fund 3 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1956 and 234,858 shares of $7.50 par value common stock.

THOMAS MANN'S "The Transposed Heads"* is the story of a supernal triangle. The scene is legendary India in some unfathomable long ago. The writing is probingly ironic, filled with wit, gore and timeless parallels to our own or any other day.
MOSCOW, June 5 (AP) -- John Scott, 29-year-old son of the American leftist educator-writer, Scott Nearing, received tonight an extension until June 11 of the expulsion order against him.

The exercise of priority ratings by manufacturers of defense goods has caused some disruption of deliveries to commercial customers in certain industrial cotton goods lines, it was reported yesterday, and there was some belief that this condition may become more acute in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- The first month's sales of new defense savings bonds and stamps raised enough money to pay for four battleships or 1,000 long-range bombers, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A prediction that the country would demand that corporations contribute "a liberal share of their profits" to help pay for the defenses of this country was made today by Secretary Morgenthau in connection with yesterday's rejection by the Ways and Means Committee of the Treasury's plan for excess profits taxes.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, June 5 (AP) -- Japan's prolonged efforts to draw from the Indies great quantities of such war essentials as rubber, oil and tin tottered tonight on what the chief Japanese negotiator himself called "the edge of a precipice."

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Revision of installment sales terms to require larger down payments and a shorter maximum payment period to minimize credit losses and maintain continued consumer purchasing power was called for in a resolution adopted here today by the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goodg Association at the conclusion of the mid-year convention of the organization.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A top age limit of 27 years for men drafted for military service was advocated today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The wheat market had a short period of strength in the fore part of today's session, when prices moved well above the previous close, but there was a lack of recent outside absorption and of the mill buying which has been a strengthening influence, and the market turned weak around midday more for lack of new buying than of heavy selling.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he would move his staff from City Hall to the Arrowbrook Country Club building in Forest Hills, Queens, for the Summer as soon as the building was ready for use as a Summer City Hall.

CRETE, Ill., June 5 (AP) -- Those who got aboard Meadow Money in the eighth race at Lincoln Fields today collected the longest price paid on an American track since Feb. 4, 1938, when Playmay, a 335-to-1 shot, came through at Santa Anita.

A double-decked bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, heading toward Manhattan yesterday with its morning load of Queens commuters, swerved to avoid an automobile on Roosevelt Avenue, near Sixty-second Street, Jackson Heights and crashed into an elevated pillar, killing the bus driver and injuring thirty-seven passengers, ten of them seriously.

LONDON, June 5 (AP) The statement of the Bank of England for the week ended on June 4 showed an increase in note circulation of u5,917,000. Currency in circulation has continued to reach record proportions each week for almost three months.

Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, resigned yesterday from membership in the American Iron and Steel Institute and withdrew his company from corporate membership in the trade organization, it was said yesterday by Dow, Jones Co., financial news agency.

ROME, June 5 -- The Holy See permitted the Qsservatore Romano today to issue one of its tacit rebukes to the illustrious guest of the Italian Government, Dr. Ladislaus de Bardoasy, the Hungarian Premier and Foreign Minister, who was received by the Pope at noon.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 5 -- Despite one of the strictest censorships since the days of former Vice Premier Pierre Laval on all details concerning the present negotiations of Vichy, it has become known here that a serious split exists between General Maxime Weygand, Commander in Chief of the French forces in Africa, representing the army, and the Vice Premier, Admiral Francois Darlan, representing the naval faction of the Franco-German "collaborationists."

Depressed since the death of his wife two years ago, Henry Blum, president of the Caruso Restaurants, Inc., operators of a chain of spaghetti places, hanged himself yesterday in the bedroom of his apartment on the sixth floor of the Alden Hotel, 225 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Every sign points more and more precisely to an early showdown between the United States Government and that at Vichy. The closer France is fitted to the gears of the German war machine, the nearer Washington must come to a decision concerning French possessions in the Western Hemisphere, and that decision -- to which severance of diplomatic relations is only incidental -- is expected soon.

A new low in thievery was recorded early yesterday when burglars broke into two Department of Welfare offices in Brooklyn, forced open three safes and stole $39,102 worth of food stamps that were slated to be distributed to needy families.

Despite the war, the draft and difficulties in finding employment, 63 per cent of the seniors at City College's School of Business declared yesterday in their annual class poll that they thought their opportunities of getting ahead were as good as those of their parents twenty years ago.
FORT WORTH, Texas, June 5 -- Denny Shute was the No. 1 man in the golf parade today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- Sheriff Denton J. Quick, crusader who led the raids that broke up the German-American Bund's Camp Nordland, and two Treasury agents are among eighteen persons indicted here on charges involving a tri-state bootleg ring.

The Board of Estimate deferred approval yesterday of the retirement of John J. Halleran, Queens Commissioner of Public Works, after Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen gave the board an affidavit alleging that improper payments of $2,250 had been made to "J.H." and to "Halleran" by one of the concerns involved in the city paving rings.

A program of international cooperation, "free from all considerations of imperialism and nationalism," and a common ground for discussion by business leaders and government officials of this nation's internal economic policies, were advocated at a seminar of "economic and social trends" held yesterday under the auspices of the New York chapter of the American Society of Chartered life Underwriters.
CLEVELAND, June 5 -- Thousands of American families are worrying about thiamin chloride, the nerve vitamin (B-1).

Seven. New York City teachers, named by previous witnesses as members of the Communist party, refused to testify in their own behalf yesterday at the open hearings of the Rapp-Coudert committee and now face possible contempt proceedings in addition to outright dismissal from their school posts.

After a hearing lasting an hour and a half, in which the five jurists themselves took an active part by questions and interpolations, the Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on the city's appeal from Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan's decision invalidating as arbitrary and unreasonable the Police Department regulations excluding interstate and interufban buses from the midtown area.

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- The Western Association of Railway Executives said tonight that the nation's railroads could not yield to the "unreasonable demands" of its employes for pay increases because they involved about $750,000,000.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 5 (AP) -- Turkish anxiety over the alleged German infiltration into Syria on her southern border grew today as fresh reports from the frontier told of the arrival at Latakia and another port of a second freighter, which landed Nazi military technicians with anti-aircraft guns and airplane parts.

Excess reserves of the thirty-six member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $340,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,195,000,000, the lowest leve since April 12, 1939, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in its report on banking operations in this district.

Benito Mussolini's own newspaper has addressed an open letter to you, Deanna, chiding you gently for succumbing to the wiles of the President. He is leading American youth into a war in which they will be defeated, Benito warns you sadly. You don't realize how hard it will be, Deanna, for rosy lips like yours to try to gnaw at the Axis.

A decision banded down yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley in the estate of Thomas Cochran, partner in the firm of J.P. Morgan Co., in which the court upheld the trustee's contention that interest on an unpaid pledge should be charged to income and not to principal, brought to light a pledge made by Mr. Coohran during his life to Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., of a sum in excess of $700,000.

Supplies of most classes of traefer meats were moderate to light at some points yesterday, but very light at others. Demand was fair to good and prices were higher on most cuts Pork and lamb were the best sellers, although demand for steer beef cuts showed some improvement at steady to higher prices.

BOWLING GREEN, Va., June 5 -- Opposing armies in the "Battle of Caroline County" were confronted tonight with a tactical situation before an intensive three-day manoeuvre that will test the efficiency of both units.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Although the recent sharp upswing in wholesale commodity prices has slackened considerably, except for marked rises in petroleum products and leather, the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics continues to go higher.

One would wish that all international relations could be conducted in the friendly atmosphere which marked the dinner given here by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce in honor of the new Japanese Ambassador, Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura. Admiral Nomura himself expressed the conviction that "the Pacific must remain peaceful and that the conflagration now raging elsewhere must not spread to that ocean."

The American people must build minds, bodies and souls as well as weapons to combat the malign forces new loose in the world, Herbert Hoover declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore, bringing to a close the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Boys Clubs of America.

BERLIN, June 5 (UP) -- The German High Command announced today that "the number of prisoners and the amount of booty in Crete are increasing further" and that German batteries fired effectively on concentrations of vehicles near Tobruk, in Libya, as well as on several British transports in the harbor.

On the forty-fifth anniversary of his graduation from New York University Dr. Chester F.S. Whitney was elected president last night of the N.Y.U. Alumni Federation for 1941-42 at a meeting of the federation's board of directors at alumni headquarters, 22 Washington Square North.

The strike of A.F. of L. ware-house workers spread from New York to Jersey City yesterday, but the strikers saw to it that there was no interruption in the normal flow of food to Army camps and bases. Under an arrangement approved by the union, skeleton crews were assigned to load provisions for the armed forces.
ALBANY, June 5 -- The United States faces two alternatives if Germany defeats England, complete preparedness or the life of "a bug in a bottle," Attorney General Robert H. Jackson said tonight.
CAIRO, Egypt, June (AP) -- A Royal Air Force Middle East communiqe said today:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Restrictions on the use of petroleum products, primarily gasoline, in Atlantic seaboard States within a month were predicted today by Secretary Ickes. He also revealed that the Office of Production Management had asked him to make plans for increasing electricity supplies in excess of 1,000,000 kilowatts by 1943 and 1944 to alleviate a growing shortage of power for defense needs.

Colombian Bonds The Republic of Colombia's formal offer yesterday to holders of its outstanding 6 per cent dollar bonds to exchange them for new 3 per cent government obligations, while looked upon by most observers as inadequate and not in line with that country's ability to pay, nevertheless, caused a ripple of activity in those bonds in the market.
VICHY, France, June 5 -- French citizens, daring punishment, poured letters into the United States Embassy here today protesting against, the swiftly moving pro-German trend of Vichy's policy.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 -- Promotions affecting the merchandising staffs of a number of departments at L. Bamberger Co. were announced today by Harold W. Brightman, vice president and general merchandise manager. Effective Saturday, Miss Tullab Dietz will take over the buying of handbags.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Because of legal difficulties, Metro's "Honky Tonk" has been abandoned and a new scenario has been substituted under the same title to replace the picture on the schedule, the studio announced today. Marguerite Roberts and John Sanford wrote the new script, which is laid in the United States, while the former story utilized a Yukon locale.

Before most of the young men being drafted today become middle-aged they will see a new world created by the application of the industrial capacity of the defense program toward building ease, speed, abundance and a society free from fear, the graduating class of the eighty-second annual commencement of Cooper Union heard last night.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- For nearly two months Japan has been attempting to induce the United States Government to conclude with her a neutrality and non-aggression pact similar to that recently concluded between Tokyo and Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Maritime Commission automatically gained broad powers over shipping and shipyards under the President's proclamation of an unlimited emergency, by virtue of Section 37 of the Shipping Act of 1916, the commission announced today.

A continuous thirty-six-hour rain-fall, between 4:30 A.M. Wednesday and 5 P.M. yesterday, caused deaths and severe floods in Pennsylvania and Northern West Virginia, but in most of the rest of the East appeared more in the nature of a benefit to farmers.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, late tonight called upon 12,000 striking C.I.O. lumber workers in the Puget Sound Douglas fir belt to return to work in accord with recommendations of the National Defense Mediation Board.

The general counsel of the Port of New York Authority defended yesterday alleged immunity of the Port Authority's bonds from Federal taxation in a petition filed with the United States Board of Tax Appeals in Washington.

TOKYO, June 5 -- Ambassador Joseph C. Grew of the United States called on Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today and, it was reported in reliable quarters, protested against the Japanese seizure of United States goods in French Indo-China and the bombing of American property in Chungking, China.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 5 -- In conditions more like football weather than rowing, Yale and Harvard today moved nearer the renewal of the oldest college sporting event in America.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- The Athletics enjoyed two big innings today to rout the White Sox, 9 to 3, and advance within four games of the American League lead.

DETROIT, June 5 -- Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, said at the annual meeting of the association today that the auto industry had nearly completed its preparatory phases of national defense production.

The adaptability of Alaska sealskin for wear with cool weather street, sports and evening dresses was demonstrated yesterday at the second annual preview of American designs for Fall and Winter at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, sponsored by the Fouke Fur Company, agents of the United States Government for the processing and sale of Alaska sealskin.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A pointed warning was issued to the Vichy Government of France by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a statement today of the consequences to Franco-American relations that might flow from a policy of collaboration by Vichy with Germany for the purposes of aggression and oppression.

After one of the most bitterly fought campaigns in recent Equity history, the association will meet at the Hotel Astor today to elect ten councilors for five-year terms and one replacement to serve three years. The annual session will begin at 2 P.M. in the grand bal room, and an exceptionally large attendance is expected.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5 (UP) -- The French High Commissioner, General Henri Fernand Dentz, in a radio proclamation to his Syrian defense forces tonight announced that France had "decided to modify her political line regarding Germany" and called for a grim defense of Syria against any British attack.

BUFFALO, June 5 -- Notice was served today on the utility industry that the Securities and Exchange Commission had no intention of abandoning its "death-sentence" program against holding companies because of the current national defense emergency.

Rear Admiral Adolpbus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District and commander of the North Atlantic Naval Coastal Patrol, will present commissions to 406 members of the graduating class of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School on board the training ship Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River at 10:30 A.M. today.

Bank clearings for the twenty-three leading cities throughout the United States in the five-day week ended on Wednesday rose 43.7 per cent over the transactions in the corresponding period of 1940, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Exchanges in the current week amounted to $6,886,259,000, against $4,791,907,000 last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5 -- A program for revision of the Social Security Act to meet the needs of drafted men and their dependents was presented today in behalf of the American Association for Social Security by Abraham Epstein, its secretary, who is attending the sessions of the National Conference of Social Work.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman reserved decision yesterday on applications by trustees for the Continental Securities Coporation and the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., for appointment of a receiver for funds due to Clarence K. Reynolds from the brokerage firm of Cranberry Co., of which he is senior partner, and for his property in this State.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Roosevelt requested of Con gress in a special message today quick legislation to authorize con struction of the St. Lawrence sea way and power project under an executive agreement of March 19 with the Canadian Government.

After a long delay President Roosevelt gave a bit of patronage to Tammany yesterday by sending to the Senate the nomination of James E. Mulcahy for United States marshal for the Southern District of New York.

DOORN, Occupied Netherlands, June 5 (AP) -- Former Kaiser Wilhelm II left minute instructions for his funeral, it was disclosed today, requesting explicitly that there be no sermon and enumerating Bible verses, church songs and prayers he wished used.
NEW YORK Crown Princess Martha of Norway and her lady-in-waiting, Countess Ragni Ostgaard, left the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday for Washington.

HAIFA, Palestine, June 4 (Delayed) -- Reports coining from Syria are many and varied. Six travelers, recently arrived in Palestine from Beirut, Damascus and Aleppo, expressed at least four different opinions concerning the implications of Vichy's attitude toward Syria and its place in the war situation.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Office of Production Management is taking steps to curtail production of sheet and strip steel for automobile, refrigerator and other non-defense Industries In order to release rolling mill capacity to turn out plates urgently needed for ship-building, railway car building and other defense needs.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter yesterday signed the formal order directing the New York County Sheriff to arrest and imprison Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, until he purges himself of contempt by testifying "responsively and without interruption by comments or interjections" before a private hearing of the City Council committee investigating civil service.

At the direction of Archbishop Edward Mooney of Detroit, chairman of the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, the council of the bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in America, Mgr. Michael J. Ready, general secretary, has officially protested as devious and deceitful the use made by the New York chapter of the America First Committee of a statement issued by the board.

The East Side House, perched atop a hillock overlooking the East River at 540 East Seventy-sixth Street, celebrated its fiftieth anniversary yesterday. It is the third oldest settlement house in this city. Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Mrs. Ogden L. Mills and Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, were guests of honor at the anniversary reception.

The government's deportation case against Richard Krebs, who is known as Jan Valtin, author of the book "Out of the Night," terminated yesterday after a brief hearing on Ellis Island at which the author testified briefly about his activities in aiding the United States Government with information about Communist and Nazi activities in this country.

BERLIN, June 5 (UP) -- German spokesmen and newspapers unleashed a blast at the United States today in which the protest by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles that Yugloslavia had been dismembered by force was described as "grotesque."

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The National Defense Mediation Board today recommended that the wage differential of 40 cents a day between Northern and Southern bituminous coal mines in the Appalachian area be eliminated, and that the contract between the union and all Appalachian operators provide a uniform pay scale of $7 a day, the wage granted by Northern producers.
That items such as carburetors and fuel pumps made from cast iron will cost 25 per cent more on an emergency basis than those from Zinc alloy, because of increased tooling and machine cost.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A bill carrying $9,826,509,492 for the Army for the 1942 fiscal year was approved today by the House Appropriations Committee and sent to the Senate, which immediately began consideration of it.
ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP) -- The Browns and Luke Sewell had cause for rejoicing today as St. Louis defeated the Senators, 4 to 2.

LONDON, Friday, June 6 -- Bombers of the British Royal Air Force carried out heavy raids on Zeebrugge and Boulogne during daylight Wednesday, blasting Nazi shipping and supplies in the occupied ports.
BERLIN, June 5 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, declared yesterday that the electric power companies of the northeastern States, in common with those of other parts of the nation, had been underestimating the power requirements of the expanding national defense program and must be prepared, by the end of 1943, to supply facilities for a "tremendous expansion" of power output.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The rather peculiar situation of foreign funds in this country belonging to nationals or residents of Holland and to Dutch corporations has been brought into the limelight by a decision handed down last week by Justice Shientag of the New York Supreme Court.

LONDON, June 5 (UP) -- The British Fleet tonight was reported moving into battle positions off the coast of French, Syria as Imperial forces, awaiting an order to attack, faced French defense forces across three barricaded frontiers.

With clearing of the skies forecast and an unusual variety of sports and entertainment features scheduled, attendance today at the twenty-first annual field day of the Bond Club of New York at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y., is expected to top the 500 mark and perhaps set a high record for recent years.

In a block facing the Grand Army Park at the corner of Prospect Park in Brooklyn, wrecking crews are busy demolishing a group of six old granite and limestone mansions to clear the site for a new apartment building.

It is of the first importance to understand why Vichy's present policy is what it is. Only by such understanding can we decide how American and British diplomacy and action can most effectively deal with it. Too many of us have been content with moral condemnation of the Vichy course.

KENT, Conn., June 5 -- The Rev. Frederick Herbert Sill of the Episcopalian Order of the Holy Cross, "Pater" to generations of Kent School boys, yielded the active headmastership at Prize Day exercises here today, thirty-five year after he founded the institution.

The Winston Churchill market being exceptionally good, with his own collected speeches, "Blood, Sweat and Tears," high on best seller lists, Rene Kraus's biography steadily selling and even Phyllis Moir's account of being his secretary for a few months doing well, Scribner next month will bring out a new edition of "A Roving Commission: My Early Life," the Prime Minister's story of his correspondent days.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Out of each $100 paid by the public for bond issues in 1940, costs of flotation absorbed $2.40, according to a report on such costs for that year Issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. For $100 of preferred stock, costs were $5.70, and for $100 of common stock they were $9.20.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 5 -- About five miles south of Murfreesboro, where the Confederate cavalryman, General Forrest, played havoc with Union supply trains, and close to the banks of Stone River, where one of the most sanguinary battles of the Civil War was fought, a camouflaged ammunition dump has been hidden, and in historic Murfreesboro, not concealed but safely scattered are three supply stations.

The American Republics liner Argentina is due to sail tonight for Buenos Aires via Barbados, Rio de Janeiro, Santos and Montevideo. Among the 290 passengers are Vice Admiral Jose Machado de Castro e Silva of the Brazilian Navy and Vice Admiral Jose Guisosola of the Argentine Navy.

Criticizing Mayor La Guardia as one who would put the United States into war, the delegates to the city convention of the Socialist party at the Hotel Diplomat last night unanimously nominated a city ticket that will be placed on the ballot by petition.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Disregarding President Roosevelt's request that a billion dollars in non-defense items should be cut from the national budget, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing the Department of Labor and the Federal Security Agencies to spend $1,199,856,000 during the fiscal year 1942.
VICHY, France, June 5 (AP) -- France appeared today to be turning more and more toward the colonial angles of the German Eurafrican collaboration idea.
Donald Budge, Fred Perry and Bill Tilden come back to the Forest Hills stadium today.
The American League next month is going to reconsider its restriction on trading by the champion club, and this time some action is in prospect.

Dull trading and narrow prics movements characterized dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. After fluctuating a few points on either side of Wednesday's closing levels, quotations were off 4 to 5 points on the day. Hedge sales and trade buying were about equal.

TORONTO, June 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., had an operating revenue of $9,755,391, United States currency, in 1940, the annual report issued today discloses. This compares with $9,667,297 in the previous year.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of Brooklyn presented forty-one baccalaureate degrees in arts and sciences last night to the graduating class of St. Francis College at the institution's eighty-third commencement exercises in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place.

BERLIN, June 5 (AP) -- A heavy Nazi aerial attack on Alexandria, Britain's Eastern Mediterranean naval base, was reported officially today almost simultaneously with an authoritative declaration that the British Empire's last and greatest bastions in that vital area are now "touched by the point of the German sword."
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 5 (AP) -- A strike for higher wages closed the North American Aviation Corporation plant today, halting production on $200,000,000 worth of military orders.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 31, which included a holiday, totaled 801,783 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 64,234 cars, or 7.4 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 162,663 cars, or 25.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 238,474 cars, or 42.3 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
