LONDON, Tuesday, June 10 -- Western Germany and the Ruhr were attacked on Sunday night by British bombers in operations which, though not large in scale, were said by the Air Miinstry today to have achieved successful results especially in Essen and Dortmund, where fires were started in the town, docks and railway yards.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Heavy rains over most of the Southwest since Saturday have effectually halted wheat harvest operations for several days, and as a result there was another upturn in prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here today. All deliveries registered new highs for the season.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 9 -- Three convicts who fled April 14 from Sing Sing Prison had spent nine months exploring tunnels of the prison, chiseling iron gratings from foundations, making keys for gates, assembling guns, collecting handcuffs, stealing ropes and receiving visitors who were to handle outside arrangements, District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher told a jury today at the trial of four men on first-degree murder charges.

LONDON, June 9 -- Scouring the North Atlantic with cruisers and aircraft carriers, the British Navy announced today that since the Bismarck sinking five supply ships and aiv aimed trawler had been found and sunk. These ships were said to have been arranged to provide supplies for the Bismarck and Prinz Bugen.

Charles A. Lindbergh denied emphatically yesterday that he had referred to President Roosevelt when he appealed for a "change in leadership" in his speech for the America First Committee in Philadelphia on May 29.

ASHLAND, Va., June 9 (AP) -- Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in the alumni address at Randolph-Macon College today, said that "if Hitler wins this war in Europe, which God forbid, we shall then have full enjoyment of that which the foes of the League of Nations wished us to have."

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, avoided one controversy with the City Council yesterday by testifying responsively before its committee investigating civil service, but got into another dispute by issuing a statement criticizing "Tammany Councilmen and Tammany Supreme Court Justices."

A new branch in the food industry has sprung up rapidly since the start of the year and is beginning to contribute some funds to advertising. It is the soup mix business and at the rate companies are entering the field there will be at least a dozen contenders by the end of the year.
Concerning the Wee Leventhal circuit: Lenore Ulric has been signed to portray Sadie Thompson -- the role made famous by Jeann Eagels -- in "Rain." Miss Ulric's tour will start some time next month.

Supreme Court Justice Church's ruling that the contractual powers of the city in dealing with the subway union must be determined by trial does not alter any basic element in the situation. Justice Church acted in a way that any layman can understand. He wanted to know the facts before issuing an order.

A hobby is a solace. But it also has an insidious way of consuming, gently but gradually, the time and energy of the hobbyist. This is the experience of two brothers, Whose hobby -- cultivation of herbs -- goes all the way back to their boyhood on a tiny island off the coast of Sicily.

The city's transit and legal experts began yesterday to assemble "facts and circumstances" as directed by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church for trial of the city's suit for a declaratory judgment that the Board of Transportation has neither the authority nor the obligation to continue the labor contracts with the Transport Workers Union and two railroad brotherhood unions covering most of the city's transit employes.

AMSTERDAM, via Berlin, June 9 -- Stocks were depressed again today although they rallied near the close. Netherlands Indies shares especially were weak. Amsterdam Rubber dropped 7 3/8 points to 236 1/8; Amsterdam trading 5 1/2 to 383 1/2; tins lost as much as 15 and tobaccos 5.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The text of President Roosevelt's executive order directing the Army to take over and operate the North American Aviation Company's plant at Inglewood, Calif., follows:

The seven stake races at the twenty-one-day Empire City Summer meeting from July 3 to 26 have drawn a total of 434 nominations, eighty-three more than last year, according to an announcement from President George H. Bull yesterday.

Ten American liberals and Socialists who faced fines and imprisonment for their opposition to the World War of 1914 issued a statement yesterday calling upon the United States "to stand ready to do its full and vigorous part toward the defeat of Hitlerism now."

With frequent clashes and heated arguments, the trial of John Kenneth Ackley, suspended City College registrar charged with being a member of the Communist party, opened yesterday before a special trial committee of the Board of Higher Education at the downtown City College building, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- A state of siege, placing this French-mandated State under strict, virtual military rule, was proclaimed today shortly after the announcement that British forces had invaded Syria.

Steps to develop sources of raw materials in this country and it South America to relieve the scarcity of imported essential oils and other materials used in the manufacture of perfumes were emphasized yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the Toilet Goods Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
New records for the month of May and for the first five months of any year were made last month in the sales of motor cars and trucks by the General Motors Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on May 24 was 2,173,810 shares, compared with 2,252,350 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Senator James E. Murray of Montana and Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, director of the State Defense Council, asked last night that the United States join England in its war against Hitler Germany. They spoke before an audience of 500 attending the last-day exercises of the School of Law of New York University in the School of Education Auditorium, 41 West Fourth Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 8 (delayed) (UP) -- Germany was reported in informed diplomatic quarters tonight to be bringing pressure on Russia for permission to move a huge army, already massed near the Black Sea, across Soviet territory to seize Iran and outflank Britain's invasion of Syria.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In these critical times, with thoughts of national defense foremost in our minds, with a great drive on to provide for the comfort of our soldiers, why not give them the one thing they desire above all else? Either lower or completely abolish transportation fares for them.

THOUGH engaged in the more serious business of covering the developments in the strike at the North American Aviation plant at Inglewood, Calif., Mr. Foster Hailey, who used to walk the sports beat, found time to file the following confidential report on some old acquaintances out that way:

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- How undisclosed foreign interests used the American I.G. Chemical Corporation as an investment holding company to retain control of United States chemical operating companies and raised $30,000,000 from the American public by sale of its debentures, only to use most of this money to make loans to or investments in foreign enterprises, was related by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a report presented today to Congress.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 9 -- A judge and a "hookey" officer beat an embarrassed retreat in court here today.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Further gains in the dressed pork market and lowered receipts imparted strength to hog trading today, prices advancing as much as 25 cents to new highs for the year and longer. Opening rounds saw quotations marked up 10 to 15 cents. In later dealings, however, purchasers were forced to bid higher and the market closed active, with most gains Between 15 and 25 cents.
Leading from start to finish, Ralph Beaver Strassburger's Salford II sprang a surprise as Aqueduct opened its reconstructed plant yesterday for the Summer meeting that will continue until July 2.

Arthur Curtiss James, railroad industrialist who died last Wednesday, bequeathed nearly eight-tenths of his extensive estate for the establishment of the "James Foundation," the income of which is to be used to aid charitable, religious and educational institutions.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 6:

Plans for new buildings in Manhattan filed last month called for an aggregate outlay of but $76,500, which veteran employes of the Building Department declare is the lowest for any month since 1902, and possibly earlier.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 9 (AP) -- Jersey City ran its winning streak to three straight games tonight by taking the opener of a three-game series with Buffalo, 3 to 1, before 5,123 fans.

Recommendations designed to improve the bail bond system in the courts and police station houses, including steps that would limit the power of the Police Department and also establish a bail bond court and bureau of information, were contained in a sixty-four-page presentment and report handed up yesterday by the extraordinary grand jury working with Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen in Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Mervyn Leroy and Edward G. Robinson, the director and star of Warners' 1931 "Five Star Final," will be reunited at Metro in another tabloid newspaper film, "New York Story," formerly titled "New York Heartbeat," the studio announced today.

The Pall season in the women's apparel lines got off to its earliest start in years yesterday when several lines of sports wear were opened for the coming season. The number of buyers reported in the market was well ahead of a year ago, with further increases expected today and tomorrow when additional lines of sports wear and costume suits will be shown.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 9 -- Tommy Harmon, Montclair Golf Club professional and Miss Katherine Blondel today won the New Jersey State P.G.A. pro-women's tournament over the Hackensack Golf Club course with 37, 43 -- 80. The brilliant performance on the, outgoing nine was made possible by Miss Blondel's uncauny putting touch.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- First call over other non-defense industries was given the railroads today for deliveries of materials needed in construction and repair of freight cars.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The text of Brigadier General Hershey's telegram to local draft boards regarding reclassification of strikers was as follows:

Approval of 191 entries for the golden anniversary track and field championship meet of the Metropolitan A.A.V., to be held at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island on Saturday, was given by the committee in charge at its meeting at A.A.U. headquarters in the Woolworth Building yesterday.

BOSTON, June 8 -- Predicting an increase in the number of women engaged in supervisory work in offices, the lapsing of the now widely enforced rule against the employment of married women and the "closing of the wage differential" between men and women in clerical jobs, L.C. McKenney, employment manager, Hood Rubber Company, today highlighted some of the problems facing office management "in a mobilizing world."

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 9 -- Tommy Harmon, Montclair Golf Club professional and Miss Katherine Blondel today won the New Jersey State P.G.A. pro-women's tournament over the Hackensack Golf Club course with 37, 43 -- 80. The brilliant performance on the, outgoing nine was made possible by Miss Blondel's uncauny putting touch.
DOORN, German-Occupied Netherlands, June 9 (AP)-- Kaiser Wilhelm II, the last ruler of Imperial Germany, was burled today on the alien soil that was his home in exile for nearly twenty-three years.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 9 -- Christopher Morley told Mount Holyoke graduates this morning that, in the face of "universal jitters," they must draw to themselves some kind of protective vacuum, not as a flight from reality but as a change from one reality to another.

Open-minded Americans have been properly reluctant in the absence of clear evidence to pin the Communist label on any defense strike. In the case of the North American Aviation strike, however, the evidence of Communist inspiration has been mounting to a point where it now leaves little room for doubt.
NEW YORK Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Minister to Yugoslavia, and Mrs. Lane are at the Ambassador.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 9 -- British troops, supported by Imperial and "Free French" forces, are pushing into Syria and Lebanon from several directions, supported by aircraft and naval bombardments along the Mediterranean shore. The Jerusalem radio announced that motorized detachments were nearing Damascus.

Judge John A. Mullen in General Session reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss the indictment accusing Morris U. Sehappes suspended teacher of English in City College, of perjury on March 6 before the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating Communist influence in the public schools and colleges.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Forty-two-year-old Charlie Root coasted to an easy victory today as the Cubs bombarded four Braves' pitchers for twenty-one hits in capturing their third decision of the four-game series, 13-6.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Hope for a delay in execution of the Federal Communications ' Commission's rules directed at monopoly in broadcasting dimmed today in the face of support of the agency's legal position by Senator Wheeler.

VICHY, France, June 9 (AP) -- British naval squadrons were reported tonight to be lying off Beirut and Tripoli, Lebanon's capital and chief port, respectively, holding them under the threat of bombardment.

Wilfred Kurth resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of the Home Insurance Company, after which the board changed its by-laws and abolished the office. Harold V. Smith, president since May 10, 1837, became the chief executive by yesterday's action.

Revivals of "The Captain of Koepenick" and "Streets of Sorrow" have been booked to open at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse, beginning Friday. Both films were produced in pre-Nazi Germany. "The Captain of Koepenick" is a comedy satire from the pen of Carl Zuckmeyer, directed by Richard Oswald and starring the late Max Adelbert, while the co-feature, "Streets of Sorrow," stars Greta Garbo and was produced by G. W. Pabst. . . .

The 1,283 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $55,533,776,568 par value as of May 31, had a total market value of $52,321,710,056, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of April 30 there were 1,287 issues, aggregating $55,678,495,902 par value, which had a total market value of $52,518,036,554.

If Mr. Charles F. Kettering were not a trained scientist and the director of one of our great industrial laboratories his forecast of a new device to master the submarine might be dismissed as another optimistic dream. His assurance that "we have been working with the Navy for six years" indicates plainly enough that he refers not to some sudden inspiration but to something which has been the subject of systematic and earnest experimentation.

VICHY, France, June 9 -- The French protest to Britain over the attack on Syria shows that even now the French Government, while resisting the aggression, does not consider itself at war with Great Britain, but rather in the same position that it was at Mers el-Kebir and Dakar.

A formal request for a charter in the American Federation of Teachers was made last night by a group of anti-Communist teacher organizations led by the Teachers Guild. The group seeks to replace the Teachers Union, Local 5, and the College Teachers Union, Local 537, which were expelled on charges of communism in a national referendum of the federation.

Unopposed by Independent candidates, the regular ticket proposed by the nominating committee of the Chorus Equity Association has been elected, it was announced yesterday at the twenty-first annual meeting of the organization held at 117 West Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Northern and Southern soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America, C.I.O., accepted late today recommendations of the National Mediation Board for adjusting their wage controversy and thus removed the threat of another soft coal stoppage which would have had disastrous effects on defense program production.

Championships continued to change hands in the national title fencing competition as the formidable Salle Santelli team dethroned the New York A.C. as saber team ruler last night on the winner's strips. Salle Santelli won the final, 9-6.

A Brooklyn housewife was seriously wounded by gunfire last night as two policemen fired at a holdup man who had been cornered in a bar room at 317 Chester Street, in the Brownsville area. More than half a dozen shots were exchanged between the police and the thug.

Championships continued to change hands in the national title fencing competition as the formidable Salle Santelli team dethroned the New York A.C. as saber team ruler last night on the winner's strips. Salle Santelli won the final, 9-6.

A Brooklyn housewife was seriously wounded by gunfire last night as two policemen fired at a holdup man who had been cornered in a bar room at 317 Chester Street, in the Brownsville area. More than half a dozen shots were exchanged between the police and the thug.

Offerings of two issues of railroad securities yesterday brought the closest and keenest competitive bidding witnessed in financial circles in several years. The Chicago Union Station Company received eleven bids for an issue of $6,860,000 of one to ten year bonds and at least six tenders were submitted for $2,325,000 of Chicago North Western equipment-trust certificates.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. Universal's "In the Navy" will be the newcomer at Loew's Criterion. The comedy, which has a naval background, is the studio's second service film to feature comedians Bud Abbott and Lou Costello.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- The trial here of Charles (The Bug) Workman for the murder of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, came to an abrupt and dramatic end this aftrnoon when the defendant changed his plea from not guilty to no defense and was sentenced immediately by Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan to life imprisonment in State prison.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A picture of a German-controlled Europe unable to import raw materials | from the rest of the world is drawn in a study of Nazi Europe and world trade made public today by the Brookings Institution.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Domestic consumers of anthracite and bituminous coal were urged by the government today to do their bit for defense, and at the same time save money by purchasing and storing Winter coal at the lower prices which prevail in Summer.
LYMAN, Wyo., June 10 (AP) -- An Army bomber, missing since Sunday afternoon, was found today on a Wyoming plain, its fuselage crushed, its six occupants dead.

With an exhibition that drew high praise from experts Miss Helene Mayer, former German Olympic star and now an American citizen, came back to the Salle Santelli last night to regain the national indoor fencing championship she relinquished. by default last year

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- With the Army Air Corps in full command of the North American Aviation Company plant and more than 5,000 of the normal day shift of 7,000 men back at work, a mass meeting of the strikers who tied up the plant last Thursday and precipitated government control voted this afternoon to go back to work.
BERLIN, June 10 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., June 10 -- H.W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company and chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, urged the seventy-eight members of the graduating class at Wilson College commencement today to renew their allegiance to fundamental principles of American democracy and express that allegiance by active, intelligent participation in government and politics.
VICHY, France, June 10 -- The text of Vice Premier Francois Darlan's speech to the French people today follows:

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday the opening on July 1 of 353 school playyards, twenty-six high school athletic fields and thirty-nine swimming pools for the Summer recreational program in the five boroughs.

After six weeks of bickering over demands for special privileges for the military in Jacob Riis Park and on parkways, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, has complained to Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, in charge of the Second Corps Area, about Major Thomas E. Donelan, commander of Fort Tilden, Rockaway Point.
Pristinely perfect are the squat little jars of jewel-like jams which have come to town from across our friendly northern border.
ROME, June 10 -- The following are textual excerpts from Premier Mussolini's speech today before the Chamber of Fasces and Corporations:

CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 (UP) -- Under the protecting guns of the British fleet and bombing planes of the R.A.F., a British landing force was said tonight to have been put ashore on the Lebanese coast near the Leontes River north of Tyre, about twenty-five miles south of Beirut, to prevent the retreating French from blowing up roads and bridges.

One hundred and fifty-one former employes of the Consolidated Edison and affiliated companies yesterday shared in the distribution of a $300,000 settlement reached between the company and the Amalgamated Utility Workers, C.I.O., after several months of hearings before the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Single persons making less than $800 and married couples earning below $2,000 would continue to be exempt from individual income taxes, under a decision today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Army can break all the strikes it is ordered to, provided the rank and file of American labor is anxious to work, and it probably is, and provided the radical or seditious labor leaders cannot close vital plants in, continuous series, and now they probably can't.

The speed-up in the national defense program is beginning to cause a pinch in exports and in many lines 20 to 50 per cent of foreign orders reaching producers here cannot be filled, foreign traders complained yesterday. To export agents here whose incomes depend upon commissions paid by manufacturers on completed export transactions, the situation is a particular cause of worry.
LONDON, June 10 -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's remarks in today's House of Commons debate on the conduct of the war:

The world needs a right sense of moral obligation, Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre told 270 graduates of the Fordham University College of Arts and Sciences, uptown, when they received their diplomas at the college's commencement exercises last night in the Fordham gymnasium on the Rose Hill campus.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The farmers will not "let the nation down in this time of stress," and the nation will not let the farmers down, R.M. Evans, Administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, assured some 200 official representatives of the country's farm population today.

New York University, largest Institution of higher education in the country, will hold its 109th commencement today at 10:30 A.M. on Ohio Field of the University Heights campus, 181st Street and University Avenue. About 20,000 persons are expected to attend the exercises.

Two ranking officers and eight council members resigned yesterday their positions on the governing board of Actors Equity Association. They had been "repudiated" in last Friday's elections, they said, and felt that in the future they could "best serve the minority which agrees with us from the floor rather than the platform."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House started a sharp debate today on the Belief Appropriations Bill, which proposes to cut the Work Projects Administration budget from $1,350,650,000 to $875,000,000 for the fiscal year 1942.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Much progress has been made in the last month or so in getting small industry into the defense picture and thus making available more of the idle machine tool capacity of the nation, the Senate Defense Committee was told today by Robert L. Mehornay, head of the Contracts Service Division of OPM.

Richard W. Lawrence, chairman of the New York City committee of the United Service Organizations, announced yesterday the formation of seventeen committees in the Commerce and Industry Division, each under a chairman, to organize fund-raising in the drive for $10,765,000 for the operation of service clubs throughout the United States.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Germany today evinced less apparent interest in the military aspects of the British invasion of Syria than the "political, moral and ethical problems" that evolve out of the Anglo-French controversy. This is the present attitude of the Reich, as indicated by the utterances of authoritative quarters and reflected in this evening's newspapers.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation took action yesterday to put into effect a plan of financing which had become known on the preceding day and included in the plan the absorption of two subsidiary coal-producing concerns, the Vesta Coal Company and the Shannopin Coal Company.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Representatives of 1,153,600 organized railway employes formally presented to the nation's rail managements today the unions' demands for wage increases and adjustments in working conditions. Railway executives who have termed the demands "exorbitant" estimated the additional costs to the carriers as high as $750,000,000 annually, but union leaders put the increase at a much smaller figure.

CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- Bob Feller still is in the midst of one of his "hot" streaks. The Senators discovered that today as Rapid Robert held them to four hits for a 4-to-l triumph, his thirteenth, of the season for league-leading Cleveland. It was the Indians' fifth victory in a row, and the eighth straight for the 22-year-old fireballer.

ANDOVER, N.J., June 10 -- Sheriff Denton J. Quick of Sussex County seized today Camp Nordland, scene of German-American Bund activities here for the last four years, in the name of the State of New Jersey, and took custody of the buildings, bungalows and bathing beaches on the 205-acre tract.
The Midtown, Greenwich Village, Riverside Drive and Washington Heights sections were among the areas sharing in apartment renting activity reported by brokers yesterday.

Two nuns from the St. John's University College of Pharmacy, unable to attend their college's commencement exercises tomorrow night, were presented with awards for scholarship yesterday afternoon at the graduation program of the university's Teachers College and Graduate School.
BERLIN, June 10 (AP). -- German sources said today that roundabout reports of the sinking of the American ship Robin Moor were "confusing, unclear and contradictory."

WITH BRITISH FORCES, Somewhere in Syria, June 9 (Delayed) -- Hopes that this war in Syria may mercifully be a phoney one and not entail the grimmest aspects at battle have not so far been shattered, except in a few places where brushes between the invading British and Imperial forces and those commanded to withstand them have developed into sharp, quick encounters.

Several fine private residences on the East Side near Central Park and other properties in that section of the city figured in the deals reported yesterday. Estates and banking and insurance institutions were principals in most of the transactions.

The Polish hospital in Edinburgh, Scotland, for which funds are now being raised in this country, will bear the name of Ignace Jan Paderewski, famous pianist and former Premier of Poland, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Vernon Kellogg, national chairman of the Paderewski Testimonial Fund.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Further strength In dressed pork prices, which advanced to new highs for the year, was reflected in a steady to 10 cents higher hog market today. Opening quotations were somewhat lower in cautious trading. No serious weakness in the price structure was uncovered, however, and in later dealings buyers were forced to bid above yesterday's quotations for swine weighing 240 pounds and more.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- With a view to symbolizing popular support for President Roosevelt's handling of the North American Aviation Company strike, and in order to give him a ready statute to use in like cases in the future, Administration leaders in Congress began pressure today for a law specifically empowering the government to take possession of strike-bound defense plants.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

ROME, June 10 -- Speaking to the Italian nation before the Chamber of Fasces and Corporations at 5 o'clock this afternoon, exactly one year since he proclaimed the war against France and Britain, Premier Mussolini proinised victory but admitted that the United States which, he said, was already in the war, would prolong the conflict.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- Finishing near the end of an opening day field of 195 starters, Alfred M. Morris of the Scarsdale Golf Club posted 38, 38-76 to take the lead in the thirty-seventh annual United States Seniors' Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today.

GREENVILLE, Me., June 10 -- Many of the anglers we have met during the last few days, men who are camped along the shore of Moosehead Lake, have expressed their scorn at the modern fishermen who visit this area and live in heated cabins with hot and cold running water.

Trading in the wholesale market yesterday was slow, which had a tendency to soften selling prices on most rail stock. The market on lamb, veal hindsaddles, kosher lamb and veal foresaddles seemed top-heavy. Kosher steer chucks and plates sold at uneven prices. Steer beef hinds and ribs were mostly steady to strong and other major steer cut prices were unchanged.

BUFFALO, June 10 -- A group of war correspondents, many of whom watched the Royal Air Force wrest from the Nazis mastery of the day-light skies with their Spitfires and Hurricanes, had a close view today of what American aircraft manufacturers are doing to help them keep that mastery and extend it over Nazi territory.

A new book by Hermann Rauschning called "The Conservative Revolution" is planned by Putnam for Aug. 15. Said to tell for the first time why the former President of the Danzig Senate broke with Hitler, and outlining Dr. Rauschning's conception of the "conservative revolution" that he thinks could have been brought about in Germany as opposed to naziism, the book will discuss modern problems and propose a course of action for democracies.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 11-- Withdrawal of the Japanese trade mission from Batavia and therewith the rupture of Japanese-Netherlands Indies negotiations appeared imminent this morning. This was the consensus following detailed consideration of the Netherlands Indies reply to Japan's final note by both Foreign Office deparmental chiefs under Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka and by a joint conference of the Foreign Office and War and Navy Ministries.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Six government witnesses and a mass of documents introduced in evidence today at the first trial of men indicted for failing to register with, the Secretary of State as propaganda agents all tended to show that the Bookniga Corporation of New York was an official offshoot of the government of the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics.

The general death rate in New York City last week continued at the unusually low figures of 9.3 per 1,000 population, Dr. John L. Rice. Health Commissioner, was informed yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

VICHY, France, June 10 -- This morning the British, and de Gaullist forces operating in Syria in three main columns continued their advance after French outposts, notably at El Kuneitra and Sheik Miskin, had fought "brilliant" delaying actions and inflicted "serious losses on the opponent" before withdrawing.

NEW YORK Mrs. John Van Antwerp MacMurray, wife of the United States Ambassador to Turkey, has come from her home in Norfolk, Conn., to the Biltmore on her way to "Washington for the marriage on Saturday of Miss Rose Chatfield-Taylor to her son, Frank MacMurray.
DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- The Tigers came from behind with two runs in the ninth inning today to defeat the Athletics, 4 to 3, for the sixth successive time this season.
A small but select Summer style showing was given by Macy's at the breakfast hour in the store's executive offices yesterday morning.

Its departure delayed for more than three hours because of minor engine difficulty, the Yankee Clipper left for Lisbon yesterday afternoon with thirteen transatlantic and seventeen Bermuda passengers. It was under the command of Captain Audrey Durst.

VICHY, France, June 10 -- Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan's message, broadcast to the French nation tonight, did not mention Syria but was a plea to the people to dominate their defeat, to set aside illusions and to support him in negotiations that would permit a peace with Germany.

For the first time since he testified before the Rapp-Coudert committee three months ago, William Martin Canning, history instructor at City College and self-confessed former Communist, underwent a searching cross-examination yesterday, as the departmental trial of John Kenneth Ackley, suspended City College registrar, continued through its second day.

WASHINGTON, June 10 - The Securitie's and Exchange Commission today called a public hearing for July 9 to determine whether the corporate simplification provisions of the Holding Company Act are applicable to the Northwest Utilities Company.

The golf that won the national open title was aged in the Wood, so to speak. At 39 years of age, Craig became the No. 1 Wood of the United States links and there isn't much golf of any importance being played anywhere else in the world at the moment.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A charge that the strike called yesterday at the Cleveland plant of the Aluminum Company of America appeared to be Communist-inspired was made today by Representative Starnes of Alabama, acting chairman of the Dies Committee, after the committee heard two witnesses say that Alex Balint, one of the strike leaders, was a veteran communist agitator and party member.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Roosevelt's references to the Cape Verde and Azores Islands in his radio speech of May 27 drew a protest and warning from Portugal, which Secretary of State Cordell Hull answered today with, "categorical" assurances that the United States had no aggressive intentions.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 -- The Allied Free French, British and Imperial troops in Syria early today reached a point fifteen miles south of Damascus after advancing thirtyfive miles from the plains west of the Druz Mountains, which had been reached twenty-four hours before, British Middle East headquarters here announced today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

Words Perhaps the conclusion is too sanguine, but the wrinkles in the Internal Revenue Act as it applies to brokerage houses and their successor firms now appear to have been ironed out. The original question concerned the payment of transfer taxes when securities went from Jones Co. to Jones Co. with one partner changed.
The British, in the words of Nathan Bedford Forrest, seem to be "gittin thar fustest with the mostest men."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- Robert Taylor will play the lead in Metro's forthcoming remake of "When Ladies Meet," with Greer Garson and Joan Crawford, and Robert Z. Leonard will direct, the studio announced today. The first screen version of the Rachel Crothers play was produced by Metro in 1933 with Myrna Loy, Ann Harding and Robert Montgomery.

Talks on handling military news were delivered "off the record" to the press and the broadcasters yesterday by Major Gen. Robert C. Richardson Jr. and Rear Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, respectively heads of public relations for the Army and Navy, over the combined wire lines of the National Broadcasting Company, which linked together a coast-to-coast hook-up of 225 stations.

As a special feature of the current exhibition, "Britain at War," the Museum of Modern Art will present evening performances of the British documentary films at 6:30 and 8:30 every Wednesday beginning this evening. These performances are given in addition to the regular daily and Sunday afternoon showings at 2 and 4 o'clock.

Choppy Sea, racing over his home course, scored at Aqueduct yesterday in a driving finish that was an upset to some, but just routine to those who know that Trainer Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons sets great store in running his charges in familiar surroundings.

Cotton futures continued yesterday their advance into new high ground for the last four years. Closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were at the day's best levels, showing net gains of 10 to 14 points.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- Swinging at anchor out in Captain Harbor, off here, tonight was the fleet that will start tomorrow morning in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's cruise. It is the annual three-day event, with a wind-up on Friday at New London, Conn., for the Yale-Harvard rowing regatta.
Rentals in the Fifties with a number of gown and millinery establishments and other retail apparel concerns and with an interior decorator featured the reports of business leasing yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, June 10 (AP) -- Buffalo evened its series with Jersey City at one-all today, defeating the Little Giants, 6 to 5.

MOSCOW, June 10 (UP) -- The Soviet Government today announced the removal of its Commissar for armaments, B.L. Vannikoff, for "failure to cope with his duties" and appointed Dmitri Ustinoff to take over the key post.

Behind the fine pitching of Charley Hastedt, who parted with only two hits and struck out seven, Mount St. Michael High School's baseball team shut out St. Francis Prep, Brooklyn winner and last year's champion, 12 to 0, in a semifinal play-off in the city C.H.S. A.A. title series at Fordham Field yesterday.

It almost happened again yesterday at Ebbets Field. The Dodgers had a 4-0 lead, lost three-quarters of it when Arky Vaughan homered in the eighth and a Ladies' Day crowd of 16,550 fidgeted nervously. The Brooks, beaten three straight by late-inning rallies, found themselves in an uncomfortable position, a habit they had cultivated in the previous three days.

Under the program of higher crop loans the wheat farmers of the country are now assured, according to Secretary of Agriculture Wickard, a return approximately equal to parity -- that is to say, a price which gives the same relative purchasing power to the farmer that existed in the five pre-war years 1909 to 1914.

Banks here were notified yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York of a series of general licenses just issued by the Treasury, lifting trading restrictions on banks in the United States with various branch offices of Netherlands banks in the Dutch East Indies, the Dutch West Indies and in South America.

AMHERST, Mass., June 10 -- Lack of farm labor is threatening New England's harvest. Recent rains have raised expectation of a good crop. Prices are more satisfactory than in decades. Since last August the general price level has advanced 7 per cent, but farm prices have advanced 17 per cent and costs have barely risen 3 per cent.

Order Revoked Paragraph II. Special Order 41, dated May 22, 1911, in so far as it pertains to the Second Section of Engine Co. 76, locating at the quarters of Engine Co. 70 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, is revoked.

The Maritime Commission has requisitioned the entire fleet of ten vessels of the Southern Pacific Steamship Lines for its vast 2,000,000-ton shipping pool being assembled to aid the democracies, it was announced yesterday.

That model of consistency. Fiddler Bill McGee, struck another sour note at the Polo Grounds yesterday -- and it wasn't on his trusty violin. The Fiddler lost his sixth straight game as the Cubs ran up the scoring scale on him for an 11-0 victory, their first over the Giants this year.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- At 11:10 A.M. the right motor of the big two-engined B-25 bomber roared into action. Seconds later the left motor was started, its propeller making a shining ring in the morning haze which the sun had not completely burned away.

Holders of $131,064,000 of bonds of Philadelphia, Pa., will be offered formally today the opportunity to exchange their holdings for bonds of a new refunding issue. This will be one of the largest municipal refinancing operations on record.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A wheat crop of 910,699,000 bushels, surpassed only five times in the country's history, was said by the Department of Agriculture today to be indicated by conditions on June 1. However, reports have told of some local damage from excessive rains since then.

Coiffures for 1942 may be styled to any one's fancy, upswept or down, formal or wind-blown, plus anything from chopsticks and brilliants and hair-braid bows, judging from advance modes presented yesterday by Stani Mars. The hair styles were modeled during luncheon at the St. Regis Hotel by manikins wearing costumes designed by Charles Le Maire and Helen Cookman, which forecast a new glitter era of straight skirts, black satin and sequins.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 10 -- Seventy-six players took part in the New York Newspaper Publishers', Golf tournament at the Century Country Club today with members of the New York Retail Dry Goods Association competing as guests.
ROME, June 10 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -- Lon Warneke had his stuff today and the veteran righthander turned in a brilliant one-hit pitching performance as the first-place Cardinals shut out the Phillies, 3 to 0.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 10 -- French sources here report that French forces have stopped an offensive in South Lebanon, destroying fourteen British tanks, and that French engineers have blocked the coastal road at various points between Saida and Beirut.

Directors of the International Paper and Power Company yesterday authorized declaration of dividends totaling $6.25 on the 5 per cent preferred stock, payable June 28. Of the total, $1.25 is to apply for the current quarter and $5 toward accumulations.

KILLARNEY LODGE, Aigonquin Park, Ont., June 10 -- Two miles distant from their dinners and all snarled up in military red tape, nine American women reporters learned today that as far as the Army is concerned, journalism in Canada is still on the double standard.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 10 -- A plea for national religious unity, with all branches of all faiths guarding the spiritual values of the nation, was uttered in an interview today by Lieut, Col, Samuel Johnson Miller, senior chaplain of the Second Army.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Officials of the" Aluminum Company of America and of the International Die Casters Union, C. I. O., agreed tonight to submit a.formula for settling the twenty-four-hour-old strike at the Alcoa Cleveland plant to the strikers for ratification.

Stockholders of the Continental Baking Company have been called to a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., on July 15 to vote on a plan of recapitalization providing for payment of arrears, retirement of part of the preferred stock and exchanges for other securities of the company.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 10 -- The war-weary men of the Forty-fourth Division, 15,000 strong, returned here this morning from an intensive training inspection by War Department officials in Caroline County, Virginia.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Roosevelt conferred on the strike situation with Attorney General Jackson, Secretary Stimson and Sidney Hillman; met with leaders from Capitol Hill, lunched with Bernard M. Baruch and held his usual press conference.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Slower driving, slower starting and more efficient operation of automobiles were suggested today by the American Automobile Association as a means of saving as much as 20 per cent in gasoline consumption to avoid a threatened petroleum shortage on the Eastern seaboard and make unnecessary drastic regulation of petroleum uses.

The ninety-year-old firm of'Eimer Amend, chemists, has leased the ground floor and mezzanine of the building at 49 East Thirty-fourth Street and will move its pharmacy division there early in July from its original location at Third Avenue and Eighteenth Street, it was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., brokers.

OTTAWA, June 10 (Canadian Press) -- Provided Japan's ''far-reaching demands" on the Netherlands Indies "remain within the bounds of reason," there probably will be "no trouble" In the Far East Foreign Minister E. N. Van Kleffens of the Netherland Government told a luncheon meeting of the Canadian Club today.

CINCINNATI, June 10 (AP) -- Sixteen of the country's top women golfers fought their way through rain and mud today into the second round of match play in the twelfth annual women's Western open golf championship. Favorites triumphed without exception in the opening eighteen-hole matches.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Mutual Broadcasting System does not believe the Federal Communications Commission order directed against monopoly will have any "disastrous effects" on the broadcasting industry, Louis G. Caldwell, counsel to the network, testified today.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, June 10 (UP) -- Vice Admiral Sir Geoffrey Layton said tonight in a radiocast that airplanes and other supplies received from the United States under the lease-lend act were playing a powerful part in strengthening the defenses of Britain's sphere of influence in South-east Asia and added that there was a possibility that Britain's great Singapore naval base might become a base for an "Allied fleet" as well as that of Britain.

June 10...110.0 112.9 108.1 111.9 105.5 113.4 The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Frank McCormick's three two-baggers enabled the Reds to gain the National League's third rung today when they came from behind to defeat the Braves, 4 -- 3. It was the world champions' fifth straight victory and the ninth in their last 11 starts.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- Today's British communiques for the second successive day implied what they did not directly state: that the resistance of the colonial French defenders ordered by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was more formal than hearty.

Several hundred newspapermen and other invited guests saw yesterday the opening by the American Museum of Natural History of its new addition to the Hall of Ocean life -- a pearl divers group depicting the brilliant colors and dramatic setting of a great submarine coral garden of the South Pacific seas.

CLEVELAND, June 10 -- The five large plants of the Aluminum Company of America remained closed tonight pending acceptance by the strikers of the terms agreed on in Washington for submission to them. Pickets still held the entrances and the midnight shift was ordered not to return to work.

GERHART SAENGER'S "Today's Refugees, Tomorrow's Citizens"* is one of the most encouraging and thoroughly American books of the year. Dr. Saenger himself came to America only a few years back, and his subject is the thousands of Germans, Czechs, Austrians, Poles, etc., who have come over as recently, or still more so.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- Mrs. August Ganzenmuller of Great Neck, L.I., the defending champion, started one day after the rest of the field in the sixth annual Manursing Island Club women's invitation tennis tournament and had to play three matches today in order to catch up.
ALBANY, June 10 (AP) -- Governor Lehman called on Americans tonight to lay aside "partisanship and political advantage" to make of this country "a mighty arsenal of democracy."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Labor leaders predicted today a virtual civil war among teamsters as a result of the decision made by representatives of 5,000 American Federation of Labor teamsters in Minneapolis, led by Niles B. Dunn, to secede and seek a charter from the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The controversy over national-local rate differentials in the news-paper field is an old one, but in recent weeks a new development has caused national advertisers in the food field again to become incensed against the granting of local rates to chain stores.

LONDON, June 10 -- Obviously testy and resentful over being forced to discuss the war, Prime Minister Winston Churchill struck back at his critics not only in Parliament but also throughout the country today in a speech through which ran two continuous threads, an explanation of the disaster in Crete and a general reply to critics as a whole.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- As Washington, officials grapple with new defense strikes -- just a fortnight after President Roosevelt's declaration of a national emergency -- a nation-wide survey of American voters shows those with opinions 4 to 1 in favor of the extreme step of forbidding defense strikes altogether.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag told the graduating class of Brooklyn Law School, St. Lawrence University, last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music that "labor must realize that there is no justification at this critical time for strikes due to jurisdictional and internal disputes."

Stimulated both by anticipation of the imposition of a Federal tax on furs and the general desire of retailers to buy earlier, current volume in fur merchandise is the largest for this period in the last ten or fifteen years, according to reports yesterday by both manufacturers and buyers.

Five thousand persons attended the eighty-eighth annual commencement of Manhattan College held yesterday afternoon on the quadrangle of the college. Degrees were presented to 283 students. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, presided, and Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the Supreme Court of New Jersey was the principal speaker.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The Yankee marksmen shot hits all over the place in marching to their fourth straight victory at the expense of Johnny Rigney today. The New Yorkers submerged Jimmy Dykes's White Sox, 8 to 3, to slip into second place.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10 -- June Week ceremonies at the United States Military Academy reached a high point tonight in the relaxation of the annual graduation hop after a day of alumni reunion, and the colorful parade in which members of the first class stepped out from the ranks of cadets to face the world as officers of the United States Army.

Kaiser Co. were the successful bidders yesterday for a total of $4,262,403 State of California registered warrants, paying a total premium of $1,631 for the obligations which bear interest at the rate of one-half of 1 per cent. Dated June 13, 1941, they will mature on or about Feb. 25, 1942, and consist of 51,525,000' of emergencyrelief warrants and $2,737.403 of general-fund warrants.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 10 -- British motorized forces, cutting through the northeastern corner of Syria from Iraq, have captured the village of Kamechlie and reached the Turkish frontier just south of the important Turkish railway junction of Nisibin.

Daily average crude oil production for the nation last week averaged 3,816,700 barrels, an increase of 30,600 over the 3,786,100 for the preceding week according to the American Petroleum Institute. This output was 17,000 barrels above the calculation of 3,799,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for May.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The 5,000-ton ship Robin Moor, flying the American flag, went down in American waters, it was emphasized today at the White House, where President Roosevelt made known his desire to have Americans suspend judgment as to the cause of the sinking May 21 until the full facts, being sought as rapidly as possible by this government, had been obtained.

Lilies of the Field Obviously the priorities have not yet shut down on cotton, wool, silk, linen and other materials out of which Father's Day shirts and sweaters and slacks and sports jackets are made.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 11 -- The British are continuing their efforts to take toll of enemy shipping, for the Air Ministry announced yesterday that on Monday widespread attacks were made on vessels off the coasts of Norway, Belgium and France.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Whatever one may think of Hitler, no one can deny that he is a master propagandist. No one can deny that he is a masted liar. No one can deny that he is a master mind-prisoner. That is, no one except Mr. John Cudahy, our former Ambassador to Belgium, and other simpleminded folk.

Around Allerton and Barker Avenues in the Bronx the news is that "Herbie" is going to get his M.A. at New York University's commencement today. "Herbie" is Patrolman Herbert H. Bungard, 23-year-old career policeman, who yesterday was industriously directing traffic so that his young friends from near-by Public School 89 and Public School 96 could get safely to their homes.

Production of steel in May amounted to 7,101,759 net tons, an output second only to the 7,131,641 tons produced in March, 1941, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The average in May was 1,603,106 net tons a week, or 99.3 per cent of theoretical capacity, against 1,609,851 tons, or 99.7 per cent, two months before.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 10 -- Billy Conn held his boxing session outdoors today, and stepped five rounds. The Pittsburgh boxer who meets Joe Louis for the latter's world heavyweight championship in the Polo Grounds a week from tomorrow night, continued to show the speed that has characterized his ring work since he set up training headquarters here a week ago.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- Playing over familiar terrain, Mrs. James M. Robbins of Mount Kisco, a former Westchester champion, led the field in the thirty-fourth annual women's Eastern medal-play golf championship when she returned 39, 40 -- 79 in the first round on the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.
WASHINGTON June 10 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 9:

A continuation of investment demand, coupled with more normal public participation, produced yesterday a spirited extension of the recovery movement in the stock market. Prices were bid up from 1 to 3 points in what proved to be the largest and broadest session in a month as the volume on the Stock Exchange rose to 825,780 shares from Monday's business of 440,040.

Since the beginning of March the general average of prices has advanced steadily. In the Labor Bureau's compilation of last week the index number was 85.2 (with the average of 1926 given as 100); on March 1 it was 80.5. That is to say, the advance since March 1 has been about the same as the forward movement between the outbreak of war in September, 1939, and the beginning of last month.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions, Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.
VICHY, Fracne, June 10 (AP) -- This communique on the fighting in Syria was issued here today:

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 (AP) -- Newark's George Washburn pitched his first complete game in seven starts tonight to give the Bears an 8-2 victory over the Montreal Royals, which stretched their International League lead to three games.

CAMDEN, N.J. June 10 -- For the second time in a little more than two years Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, treasurer of Atlantic County and for a quarter of a century Republican, leader there, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on income tax evasion charges.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- The first curtailment of advance buying since the European war started by any regional group of purchasing agents was revealed here today, when the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Northern California, Inc., showed that fewer members bought more than six months ahead in May than in April.

A scheme through which the purchasers of some $100,000 in ostensibly gilt-edged investments were persuaded to turn in their certificates in exchange for highly dubious mining stock was charged to ten men and the American Trusteed Funds, Inc., in three Federal indictments yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The War Department today announced the award of contracts totaling $8,286,370.40, including one for $5,607,794 for airplanes and spare parts awarded to the Boeing's Stearman Aircraft Division at Wichita, Kan. Of the total of four awards, two went to New York, as follows:

DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- A strike by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., halted defense production of airplane parts in six plants of the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation today, Edward M. Owen, State labor conciliator, expressed a fear that no settlement would be reached before next week.

Having resided at the Imperial Theatre since May 28 of last year, "Louisiana Purchase" has decided, somewhat regretfully, that the time has come to say good-bye. On Saturday night the musical comedy will be given for the last time, thereby winding up an enviable record of 442 performances.

After the most bitterly contested election in the twenty-six years of the organization's existence. Patrolman Patrick W. Harnedy was elected yesterday to the presidency of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. He defeated Patrolman Joseph. J. Burkard of Traffic E, the incumbent for the last two years, and a half, and two other candidates.

NYACK, N.T., June 10 -- Sculling manfully, now through waters whipped by a fresh nor'wester, now through currents that raced like the proverbial mill stream, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, 65-year-old chaplain of Columbia University, pulled ashore here today on the first leg of a rowing trip up the Hudson from New York City to Poughkeepsie.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- With high styling playing an increasing role in accessory sales and the turnover in all men's clothing running ahead of last year, members of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers are apprehensive lest too drastic curtailment of installment selling affect their revival in business.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Interest in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here lagged today so far as the public was concerned. Prices started fairly steady, but the market softened later, and most of the trading was below yesterday's close.

CHESTER, Pa., June 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, receiving the honorary degree of Doctor of Military Science from Pennsylvania Military College today, cited a paradox in Nazi political and military policies and suggested that the German philosophy in the conduct of war might destroy the philosophy of the political government.

The defense "boom" is making it harder for New York housewives to get domestic help, a survey among public and private employment agencies indicated yesterday. Finding a good cook or maid has been a problem, ever since the immigration quotas went into effect, but no one recalled a year when it was quite as difficult to obtain competent servants as now.
ROME, June 11 -- Interpretations of Premier Benito Mussolini's speech as meaning that Italy considers herself at war with the United States were branded as tendentious today in official circles.

BUFFALO, June 11 (AP) -- Industrial expansion and military needs have burdened transportation facilities so much that newspaper ink shortages may develop, according to James Beckett of New York, representing the International Ink Company.

Captain Gustavs Heiss of the Fencers Club gained his fourth national indoor epee championship at the Salle Santelli last night. In splendid form and as agile as ever. Captain Heiss swept all his five bouts in the final round-robin.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 11 -- The greatest war effort of the Netherlands is taking place in the Netherlands Indies, Baron van Boetzelaer van Oosterhoud, Minister Counselor of the Netherlands Legation in Washington, declared today in a commencement address to the graduates of Hofstra College here.

HOLLYWOOD. Calif., June 11 -- "Whistling in the Dark," first made in 1933 with Ernest Truex, Una Merkel and Edward Arnold will be remade by Metro with Red Skelton, Rags Ragland, Ann Rutherford and Virginia Grey in the leading roles, the studio announced today.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., June 11 -- Mayor Thomas C. McVey, ordered today the removal within ten days of nineteen high-powered binoculars of the vending machine type from a 350-foot bluff on the east side of Ocean Boulevard overlooking Sandy Hook Bay and Fort Hancock.

With the season approaching for meetings of trustees of savings banks to decide on the dividend rates to be voted on July 1, for the second quarter, it was indicated yesterday that fewer mutual savings banks will continue their disbursements at the annual rate of 2 per cent.

LONDON, Thursday, June 12 -- While activity by German bombers over this country was slight Tuesday night, when some bombs were dropped in South Wales and at a point near the coast in Southwest England, the Royal Air Force carried out an attack with "strong force" upon the docks at Brest, where a "Hipper class" cruiser believed to be the Prinz Eugen is taking refuge along with the battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau.

LONDON, Thursday, June 12 -- Richard B. Bennett, former Prime Minister of Canada, who has come to this country to live and to assist in the British war effort, was made a viscount in the birthday honors' list issued today.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 11 -- The last of the bond authorizations by the people in 1937 for construction of State institution buildings will be sold on June 24 by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller. The issue of $15,000,000 is to mature in twenty-five years.

Trading in gray goods was active again yesterday, but volume was held down considerably by the fact that mills were unable to supply wanted deliveries. On some constructions, nothing more than minor scattered lots were available before September.

First Things First It is not doubted in Wall Street that some interests will be hurt by the increasing stringency of priority rules emanating from Washington, but there is general agreement there that sacrifices should be accepted with steadfastness and there is room for plenty of ingenuity in developing substitutes for steel, zinc, aluminum and such metals in the consumer goods industries.

VICHY, France, June 11 -- A new factor has been introduced Into the Syrian situation by the German bombing of the important British base at Haifa, on the very border of Palestine and Syria. It is denied here categorically that, as the British allege, these German planes afterward "returned" to the Aleppo airfield in North Syria, the word "returned" being particularly resented as implying that they had come from there.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Heading a special expedition to the coast of Greenland and other more northern Arctic waters to study the layers of rarified air at heights of from 50 to 300 miles above the earth, Miss Loutse A. Boyd sailed from here today in the schooner "Effie M. Morrissey," which is commanded by Captain Bob Bartlett, leader of many exploring parties in far northern waters.

With a glowing smile and a little shrug peculiarly her own, the charmingly-coiffed, gray-haired owner of a diminutive shop we came upon the other day explained that her confections are "strictly in the European tradition." Flesh-tinted walls, the crescent-shaped counter and gleaming glass shelves create a mood faintly Parisian.

An attack upon the constitutionality of the Wool Labeling Act is contemplated by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America, representing about 90 per cent of the men's and boys' clothing production of the country, it was disclosed yesterday.

A dispute between two members of the Habsburg family, former ruler of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, over various funds alleged to be in the bands of Archduke Otto, claimant to the throne, was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday with the filing of an application by Archduke Leopold of Austria to examine Archduke Otto regarding the alleged funds and the family law governing their disposition.
Three of the most powerful C.I.O. unions have joined in a drive to break the control of left-wing elements over the C.I.O. organization in Los Angeles, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senate action on a measure authorizing President Roosevelt to take over for the government strike-bound defense plants without reliance on his constitutional powers as Commander in Chief of the armed forces was delayed again today as the upper body considered administering an extra slap at striking labor for impeding the rearmament program.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11 -- With the 194th Commencement Week program of Princeton University opening tomorrow, a survey of the occupational prospects of the graduating class made public today gives evidence of how the national defense program is influencing the outlook of students leaving academic halls this season.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Donald M. Nelson, director of purchases in the Office of Production Management, stated today that President Roosevelt has approved a plan for industry-consumer-government co-operation to simplify consumers' goods as a step toward greater efficiency in production and toward "more room" for defense requirements.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's letter transmitting to Congress today his first formal report on the operations of the Lease-Lend Act:

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, conferred today with President Roosevelt upon details connected with taking over foreign ships in American ports.
DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- Federal representatives obtained agreements today ending two strikes interfering with national defense and some 5,000 factory workers prepared to return to work tomorrow.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 11 -- Snapping on canvas under a north wind that did blow, and in seas that sank, swelled and whitened, the racing fleet on the Indian Harbor Yacht Club cruise came on here today from Greenwich, Conn. It was an initial run of twenty-four miles through Long Island Sound, and a splendid one.

Trading in the wholesale market yesterday day was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs sold mostly at steady to strong prices with other major beef cuts generally unchanged. Veal hindsaddle prices were unchanged. Lamb prices were unevenly weak to lower. Fresh pork moved at generally steady to strong prices.

LONDON, June 11 (ANETA) -- A further contraction of economic activity in the German-occupied Netherlands, as the result of a lack of raw materials, and the rapid decline in commodity stocks, is reflected in information reaching Dutch quarters here.

Alexander E. Patterson, vice president of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, has been elected vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, according to the announcement of Lewis W. Douglas, president, issued for release today.

BERLIN, June 11 -- The German High Command tonight released an official recapitulation of the activities of all its armed forces for the first four months of 1941. During that period, it said, 2,235,000 tons of enemy shipping was destroyed and 1,200,000 tons more damaged in the Battle of the Atlantic.
VICHY, France, June 11 (UP) -- A communique from Beirut, Lebanon, announced at noon today, said:

Four floors in the New York Curb Exchange and a floor in the adjacent Hamilton Building, which the Curb owns, are being thrown open for rental for the first time. Declining volume of business on the Exchange has forced a recasting of the institution's budget and the decision to rent has resulted, emphasizing Wall Street's continuing deflation.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A group of sixty-two clergymen, led by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church in New York City, has condemned the anti-monoply report of the Federal Communications Commission as jeopardizing all religious programs on the air.

Fear of Fear One of the regular twenty questions in our editorial section a week ago last Sunday asked the origin of President Roosevelt's recent fireside allusion to "the fear of fear." Our own answer on another page gave the source as Mr. Roosevelt himself in his first inaugural, March 4, 1933.

BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- Dick Merriwell Errickson, a winner only once in seven previous starts, held the Reds to three hits today while pitching the Braves to a 2-0 shutout in an hour and 19 minutes, shortest National League game here this season.

RYE, N.Y., June 11 -- Adding a great 79 to her first clay's 82, Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome, Long Island match and medal play champion, jumped into a tie at 161 with Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, who added an 81 to her earlier 80, as the second round of the women's Eastern golf championship was concluded over the difficult west course of the Westchester Country Club today.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The Radio Manufacturers Association, closing its convention here today, announced the re-election of James S. Knowlson, president of Stewart-Warner Corporation, as president. Other officers elected were Leslie F. Muter, president of the Muter Company of Chicago, treasurer, and the following vice presidents:

VICHY, France, June 11 -- British-de Gaullist columns supported by tanks and airplanes are reported tonight to have reached a point in Syria a few miles south of El Kesweh, halfway between the French defense lines previously announced and the city of Damascus, the invaders' objective in that sector.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- On the Thames River opposite New London is the busy shipyard of the Electric Boat Corppany, which has increased the number of its employes from 2,500 a year ago to 5,500 now and is still looking for 1,000 workmen to help it carry out its part of the Navy's expansion program.

LONDON, June 11 -- Sinkings for May of British shipping -- unofficially said to amount to slightly more than 350,000 tons -- shows that the Battle of the Atlantic has moved westward across the ocean to a point where effective German sub-marine action is more often nearer the North American shores than those of these islands.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 11 -- Today has not brought any perceptible relaxation in the reported Russian-German tension, so far as can be judged from here. According to the most reliable observers, the German pressure is increasing steadily, while the Russians still show no signs of accepting the German demands.
PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, June 11 (UP) -- The Brazilian, steamer Ozorio arrived here tonight with survivors of the sunken United States steamer Robin Moor.

LONDON, June 11 -- Reports that there is growing tension between Russia and Germany and increasing under German forcing methods continued to pour into London today at such a rate and in such volume that they must be taken seriously.

Twenty members of the English Jooss ballet arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Paula from South America after a fourteen-month tour, during which they gave a series of benefit performances for British War Relief, netting $15,000.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., filed a petition in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday appealing the decision of the Securities and Exchange Commission which denied the investment banking firm its compensation in connection with its participation in the underwriting of $25,000,000 of Dayton Power and Light Company first mortgage bonds in February, 1940.

Sixty-three graduates of Cornell Medical College were urged, at commencement exercises yesterday, to turn occasionally from Gray's Anatomy and other medical tomes to lighter literature and the esthetic works of the artist.

Frank R. Phillips, president of the Philadelphia Company of Pittsburgh, one of the principal properties in the Standard Gas and Electric Company's system, announced yesterday that his corporation would receive sealed bids on $60,000,000 worth of new securities, the proceeds of which will be used to retire a like amount of 5 per cent secured indebtedness due in 1967.

Reductions aggregating $330,265,252 in the total of assessed valuations on real estate and special franchises were reported yesterday by William Stanley Miller, president of the Tax Commission, who said the final valuations on real property and franchises totaled $16,223,134,726.

LONDON, June 11 -- The British, who are keeping a close watch on Japan's import and export trades, today paid tribute to the part played by the United States, which is cooperating in the drive to check-mate any Axis attempt to gain a toehold in the Pacific.
NEW YORK Robert H. Jackson, United States Attorney General and Mrs. Jackson will spend the week-end with Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Patterson Jr., at their home in Locust Valley.

The ten officers and council members who resigned Tuesday from the governing board of Actors Equity Association charging it was in control of a "new order" -- meaning communism -- yesterday said the only thing that might make them reconsider would be the resignation, pending a government investigation, of seven other council members who were accused of Communist sympathies a year ago by Representative William P. Lambertson of Kansas.

Twenty-five hundred members of the Teachers Union and the College Teachers Union, which organizations were expelled last week from the American Federation of Teachers after charges of Communistic domination, cheered the assurances of their leaders last night that the locals would fight the expulsion at the federation's national convention in August and that they would carry their campaign against educational retrenchment to the people of New York State.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11 -- Following is the text of the address today by Secretary of War Stimson at the graduation exercises of the United States Military Academy: Gentlemen of the graduating: class:

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- New York's La. Guardia Airfield, one of the largest in North America, was described today as a bottleneck for airplane passenger flying to and from New England, in testimony given at a hearing before a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner on applications of the Trans-Continental and Western Airlines Corporation and United Airlines Transport Corporation to provide additional passenger, mail and express services for New England, New York and Pennsylvania points.

Prince Ludovic Pignatelli wanted $500,000 from Princess Henrietta Pignatelli, and he was willing to adopt her husband if she would give it to him, according to testimony given in Federal Court yesterday. The story was told by three titled witnesses at the trial of Prince Ludovic and "William M. Gibson, accused as a conspirator in the alleged extortion scheme.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our country is spoken of as the richest and strongest nation in the world. We should be very proud, but I believe there are many Americans who would be more genuinely prond and hold their heads higher these days if their country were considered one of the bravest nations as well.

After strenuous objection and accusations against it, the Board of Education yesterday selected George P. Pigott Jr., school principal and administrator of the defense training program in the schools, to fill a vacancy in the Board of Superintendents that has existed since last February.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 11 -- Ray Billows, golf's erstwhile Cinderella Man, today found conditions very much to his liking at the Montclair Golf Club, where the time-honored metropolitan amateur championship got under way.

"Sunny," the new RKO screen version of the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d-Otto Harbach musical comedy, will open this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Anna Neagle portrays the title role and Ray Bolger, Edward Everett Horton, John Carroll, Grace and Paul Hartman, Helen Westley and Frieda Inescort are featured in supportIng roles.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11-- Dr. Owen L. Shinn, Professor of Applied Chemistry at the University ot Pennsylvania, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home in Swarthmore. He had been associated with the university as a student and faculty member for more than fifty years and had received a leave of absence during the academic year of 1940-41 because of illness.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 11 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The House Ways and Means Committee has decided to retain, in the new tax bill the existing schedule of personal exemptions of $800 for a single person and $2,000 for married couples. In this it has followed the specific recommendations of the Treasury Department, while abandoning the principles enunciated by the Treasury's head, Secretary Morgenthau.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- The Army Quartermaster announced today that purchases of large quantities of woolen and worsted fabrics would be made late this month. In all about 17,600,000 yards will be bought, based upon prices to be submitted at the opening of bids on June 26.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11 -- Secretary of War Stimson warned the graduating class of the Military Academy today that the United States "is confronted by the most dangerous threat which has ever faced its political and economic independence" and that "the duty of meeting it may fall in large measure upon your shoulders."

American Brake Shoe and Foundry An extra dividend of 10 cents and another dividend of 40 cents were authorized to common shareholders of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company." On March 31 a 40-cent dividend was paid.

RYE, N.Y., June 11 -- Alvah H. Pierce of the Braeburn Club of Brockton, Mass., today gave the second section of the field in the thirty-seventh annual United States seniors' golf championship a mark of 157 to shoot at starting tomorrow by posting a score of 39, 39 -- 78 at the Apawamis Club to add to the 39, 40 -- 79 he registered yesterday.

A charge that the Communist party sanctions strikes, sabotage and violence in an attempt to spread unrest and disorder in preparation for the forcible overthrow of capitalism was made yesterday by a former party member, appearing as a witness at the departmental trial of John Kenneth Ackley, suspended City College registrar.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 (AP) -- diet Kehn, 19-year-old rookie right-hander, hurled Montreal to a 1-0 victory over the Bears tonight in the finale of a four-game series. Newark won the first three and has a two-game lead over the Royals for first place in the International League.
