WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Roosevelt's order freezing the assets of all continental European countries and providing for a worldwide inventory of foreign assets in the United States, started the screws turning today on the most rigorous economic clamp this government could apply against the Axis Powers.

LONDON, June 14 -- The lessons of Crete as they may be applied to the possibility of the invasion of this island are being studied ever more earnestly these days as bit by bit information is gathered on which to base calculations, it was learned tday.

NORFOLK, Va., June 14 -- War seems closer here than anywhere else in the United States. That was the impression gained today by newspaper men during a visit to this naval base and shipbuilding center which ended a 3,500-mile twelve-day tour of inspection of defense areas arranged by the National Association of Manufacturers for a group of correspondents just back from the war in Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Special certificates of service, which will, it is hoped, serve as "job insurance" papers, and will also be used in place of formal discharge papers, will be issued to all who have served creditably for one year or longer in the Army, according to an announcement by the War Department.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 14 -- Members of society and patrons of racing who arrived before noon at the Piping Rock Club today to accept the crowded indoor tables that had been assigned to them instead of those on the terrace for their parties, were greeted by unexpected sunshine and the club management hastily rearranged to place about 300 of the 600 luncheon guests out of doors as originally planned.

"POETRY," says the compiler of an anthology published in London after the bombing of that city had begun, "comes into its own in wartime," when there is a perpetual reminder of the precariousness of life, when heroism and endurance of all sorts and conditions of men crowd out the trivialities, when there is a desire to escape into a serener air.

VIRGINIA BEACH, VA. -- Bunker Hill Day will be observed here Tuesday by a series of events, including surf sports in the afternoon at the Cavalier Beach Club, a dance that night on the Show Boat deck of the clubhouse and bonfires on the beach.

Delegates to the forty-sixth annual convention of the New York State Association of the National Association of Power Engineers, meeting yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, proposed as a measure of national safety that men like themselves be placed under Federal license.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, cleared up today the strike of 12,000 C.I.O. loggers in the Puget Sound area by persuading the union president, O. M. Orton, to abandon his defiant attitude and send the men back to work under a settlement formula of the National Defense Mediation Board.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Mountain climbing in the White Mountains region is growing constantly in popularity and the facilities for it will be greatly improved over those of last season. The devastation of the hurricane of three years ago extended to many of the trails and peaks where trees were laid low and in some places trails were almost obliterated.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The sinking, according to the State Department, by a German U-boat of the American ship Robin Moor while bound for South Africa promises to lead to a re-examination of the Neutrality Act, this time in a new light.

TRANSPLANTED EYES -- Eyes of salamander kinds have been successfully transplanted, with return of vision, in experiments reported in a lecture recently delivered in New York by Professor L.S. Stone of Yale University School of Medicine.

While bad weather checked the rate of gain, Father's Day promotions fared well in local stores during the week. Estimates indicated department store sales increased from 8 to 10 per cent during the week, although some individual establishments had gains ranging up to 15 per cent for the first four days.

Perhaps it is the zealous enthusiasm of metropolitan cruiser owners to learn more and more about navigation and prepare themselves for emergency national defense service in the reserve forces of the Navy or the Coast Guard. Perhaps, too, near-by skippers are discovering after many a decade that the majestic Hudson River is one of the most fascinating waterways imaginable.

Michael F. Walsh, New York Secretary of State, will be the principal speaker at the thirty-seventh annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York June 25-28 at the Hotel Sagamore, Lake George, John Mar- bach of White Plains, president of the association, announced yesterday.

A Lily Field Day, sponsored by the Lily Committee of the American Horticultural Society (821 Washington Loan Trust Building, Washington, D.C.), will be held on June 28 in Geneva and Ithaca, N.Y. A dinner at the Ithaca Hotel will follow visits to the gardens of G.L. Slate, Donald Simmonds and L.H. MacDaniels and to the Geneva Experiment Station.

IT'S a common ailment about this time of the year. The patient suffers from nostalgia and complains that he sees spots dancing in front of his eyes; the spots resemble little trylons and perispheres. But he shouldn't become despondent.

As another volume of the American Guide Series of State books issues from the presses -- a volume for Missouri -- the finishing strokes are "being put to a research undertaking that will give America its first self-portrait and will also prove of great interest to those vacationists who explore, each Summer, the wonders of their own country.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A cross-country "radio trail" designed to guide airplanes in fog and permit their safe landing has been developed by Dr. Ernst F.W. Alexanderson of the General Electric Company's research laboratories, it is made known in a patent (No. 2,245,246) awarded to the noted inventor.

SOMEWHERE IN ONTARIO, June 14 -- Bundists and other Nazi symapthizers in the United States are pouring a constant stream of money and gifts across the inte national line for the German offcers and enlisted men in the prise camps of Canada.

A comparison of the current ship construction program with the marine achievements of 1917-1918 discloses that we have equaled and in some respects surpassed the pace reached by the Fall of 1918, when the Armistice coincided with the American shipbuilding peak.

To the Drama Editor: YOUR article on Ed Wynn'a experimental efforts at entertainment for the troops has been read with interest. I think you may be interested in a similar effort, under rather different circumstances, made by Americana at the Active Service Canteen on May 25.

The cotton futures market resumed yesterday its advance into new high ground as prices on the New York Cotton Exchange bettered their previous peaks and closed with gains of 6 to 9 points for the day.

NANTUCKET, Mass. -- This year will go down in Nantuckct history as the one in which a host of arriving vacationists took the island resort by surprise on Memorial Day and started the Summer season two weeks ahead of schedule. So mid-June finds many members of the vacation colony already well established with no thought of returning to "America" until late September.

LONDON, June 14 -- Since the beginning of the war British wholesale prices have increased 50 per cent. Though the increase has slowed down this year, the government's reserved price policy has been widely criticized.

In order to compete with Germany's $60,000,000,000 industrial research set-up, which is the most highly integrated machine in the world, the United States must speed up its own research and make it more efficient, Maurice Holland, director of the division of engineering and research of the National Research Council, declared yesterday.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 14 -- When Mike Cestone resumes his letter-carrying duties on Monday those who answer the doorbell should say "Good morning, Champ."

TOKYO, June 14 -- After several days' delay the decision of the Japanese Government on the deadlocked trade negotiations with the Netherlands Indies was dispatched to Kenkichi Yoshizawa, head of the Japanese delegation in Batavia, this afternoon, together with instructions for the course of the delegation.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In much of the discussion of international relations which has occurred since the outbreak of the present European war the real weakness of the League of Nations system has tended to be overlooked. It must not be overlooked in the discussion which is now gathering on war aims and international organization to take the place or the League at the end of this war.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 -- It is clear that the Germans, having stirred up a hornets' nest in the Middle East, intend to leave the Syrian situation alone for the moment. They have already withdrawn most of their aircraft, fifth-column experts and technicians, and they are apparently intending to pursue a role of nonintervention.

"THE citadel of a valiant race, portrayed by its greatest etchers," the subtitle correctly describes this beautiful book. And Muirhead Bone in his "Piccadilly Circus, Night" begins the valuable collection with a reminder of London itself.
BOSTON, June 14 -- The White Sox broke a four-game losing streak today to defeat the Red Sox, 5 to 2, and move within four percentage points of the third-place Bostonians.
LONDON. THERE West End openings in the same week -- two straight playa and one musical -- is more like the good old times than anything I have had to record this year.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- An unusually busy Summer season is in prospect in the Poconos, if early indications are fulfilled. The nearness of this mountain area to many large cities, at a time when requirements of business and industry make long holiday absences inadvisable, is playing a part in this situation.

Mrs. Helen Suzette de Gersdorff, wife of Carl A. de Gersdorff, one of the leaders of the New York bar, and daughter of the late Frederio Crowninshield, mural painter, died yesterday morning, after a brief illness, at her home, 635 Park Avenue.

MUNISHING, Mich. -- Trolling for trout on Lake Superior is attracting sportsmen to Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota shore communities which have been wide awake to the possibilities in this comparatively new fishing pastime and provide boats and other facilities to accommodate sportsmen.
On a broad historic site where the East River bends in to touch, the Grade Square waterfront neighborhood at Ninetieth Street, a vast change is taking place.

The last vestige of organized opposition on the part of the utility holding company industry to the rigid application by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the "death-sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act appears to be slowly, but surely, disappearing.

DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H. -- The Balsams opens its 1941 season on Wednesday and expects a large attendance throughout the Summer because of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the settlement of Dixville Notch.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Prospects for improved weather conditions in the Southwest left the wheat market today with little support, and prices lost about all the gains of yesterday. Short covering was active yesterday, and as outsiders failed today to follow the upturns on the buying side, the market slipped back without much opposition.

OLD BILL, of Bairnsfather fame has returned to the active list. Having done his bit in cartoons and on the stage for the World War, he pops up again to take a part in this one. Old Bill's round phiz and walrus mustache must be familiar to millions.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- From a recreational point of view Newport is going to have a national defense Summer this year. For some time now the city has been growing more and more military minded and with the increase in officers and men of the different military services there are almost as many uniforms noted on the streets as there are men in civilian dress.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 -- German and Russian relations seem to have approached a critical point, according to reliable diplomatic information, and sensational developments may be looked for in a very short time. Various estimates indicate that the crisis will mature perhaps tomorrow, certainly before mid-July.

Bundles for Britain, Inc., nationwide American women's relief organization with headquarters at 745 Fifth Avenue, disclosed yesterday that for the first six months of the fiscal year ended May 31 it had received from all sources $2,636,775 and that in the same period its operating expenses had been $229,830, or 8.8 per cent of total receipts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- A warning that both capital and labor would suffer through selfishness or indifference in this time of emergency was voiced tonight by Justice Owen J. Roberts of the Supreme Court in a Flag Day address in Independence Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Rumors that the government planned to set up early priorities in trucking space to meet a shortage of truck haulage capacity were denied today at the Interstate Commerce Commission and at the office of Ralph Budd, transportation expert.

Creation of redevelopment corporations by private capital is urged In a report of the committee on urban land use of the American Institute of Architects, headed by Frederick Bigger of Pittsburgh as chairman.

Home builders and developers in the popular residential centers in Queens and Nassau Counties, Long Island, report that the demand for medium-priced dwellings since the first of the present month is continuing at the same rate which made May one of the best selling months for Long Island operators in many years.

THE English novelist C.S. Forester, whose fame as a narrator of naval-adventure tales of the Napoleonic epoch reached its high point in the "Captain Horatio Horn-blower" trilogy here, pays tribute to American seafighters of the War of 1812.

DETROIT -- What the automobile price structure is to be is the question now puzzling leaders of the industry here. The request of last Thursday by Leon Henderson, Federal price control administrator, that increases of from $10 to $53 announced by a number of manufacturers on 1941 models be immediately withdrawn has served to make more difficult a problem which already was worrying the industry.

Ten tiny students, in flaming red academic gowns and red Dutch caps, weaved their way up the broad green lawn of the Bartlett Academy yesterday at Douglas Manor, Queens, to be handed sheepskins designating each as a "Bachelor of Arts."

WASHINGTON. SHORTLY after midnight tonight, a plane taking off for Texas will signalize the opening of the magnificent new National Airport at Gravelly Point on the Potomac, three miles from downtown Washington.

THE real American is always a pioneer at heart. In the tranquil shade of the forest, or in the physical ardor of climbing and hiking, he seeks, in biblical phrase, to "restore his soul." So, perhaps against the advice of wife and friends, he sets out to "rough it" for a week in the woods.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 14 (UP) -- The first concrete military measure to aid the United States in South America in case it enters the war took form tonight with an announcement that the Uruguayan Government was preparing a formula under which "in defense of the interests of democracy" any Western Hemisphere nation warring with a country outside the hemisphere would not be considered a belligerent.

The finals of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches in Classes A and B to determine which clubs will hold the titles for the coming year will be held on the Scarsdale Golf Club course tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Communist penetration of organized labor is now a major preoccupation of defense authorities and Federal officials because of the "pattern" of recent defense strikes.
CONCORD, N.H. -- New Hampshire resorts are spruced up and readv for the vacation season of 1941. Many events have been planned for the enjoyment of visitors.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The United States Navy is building its base on the western end of these islands, the Army is at the eastern end, in the St. George's region, British censors have taken over two big hotels in the Hamilton area, a U.S.O. outfit is located in a third hotel.

IN this, the latest book by Mr. Kornitzer, he has again dipped into his very colorful and adventurous past to provide his readers with anecdotes and reminiscences from the life of one who says "Gems were in my blood and in the blood of innumerable ancestors."

LAKE WINNIPESAUKEE, N.H. -- This Summer's mariners will not all be salt-water tars. On the lakes and streams that dot New England fresh water skippers will handle canoes, trim sails and putter round engines. Many of these will cruise the inland waterways of New Hampshire, which has noted for several seasons the increasing aqua-awareness of its visitors.

TAKE GEORGE -- Resort activities will begin in earnest the last of this week with the 1941 reunion of the Constitutional Convention Delegates of 1938 opening the Fort William Henry Hotel on Friday and Saturday. Among New Yorkers expected are Judge Frederick E. Crane, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Senator Robert F. Wagner.

ONE of these fine days that unsung hero, the orchestrator and arranger of vocal numbers, will emerge from musical oblivion and receive a distinctive credit line. "Maybe the radio announcer at the end of the number will say, 'What you have just heard 'has been arranged by so and so,' " ventures Paul Baron, one of the most active members of the craft in radio.

Difficult structural and engineer- ing problems were successfully solved in the construction of the large addition to the E.R. Squibb Sons plant recently completed on Columbia Heights and Furman Street, Brooklyn, points out J. Archer Turner, president of the Turner Construction Company, contractors.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 14 -- There are still few facts available here regarding the Russian-German tension that one is allowed to send from Stockholm, but most qualified observers here are convinced that German pressure will start tomorrow or Monday if an amicable solution has not been reached.

Formal opening-today of a fortyacre tract for medium priced homes in the Fairlawn section of Bergen County, N.J., is announced by the Skillman Homes Corporation, which is planning to construct 250 houses on the property. Four dwellings, fully furnished, representative of the architectural types selected for the development will be ready for inspection and twenty additional houses are nearing completion.

The sports world will do its bit for the Greater New York Fund in the grand manner at the Polo Grounds today, when a notable array of star athletes, including Miss Alice Marble, Greg Rice, Sid Luckman, Hugh Mulcahy, Paul Runyan and Lou Nova, gives exhibitions of skill in Macy's "Father's Day Sports Parade."

Not even an ostrich, so far as we know, ever thought of hiding his feet in the sand; but just that may be the impulse of more than one beach beauty when first she brings her Winter feet into the bright, clear light of the Summer sun. She need not feel too humiliated.

An "all-out" campaign in which grocery manufacturers will act as allies of wholesalers and retailers in an attempt to force national chains in the grocery field to separate their manufacturing and retailing activities appeared to be building up here last week as a result of the growing number of private brands sponsored by chains.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Teachers who desire to acquaint themselves better with Latin America will find greatly increased opportunities in United States colleges and universities during the coming Summer. Responses to an inquiry on this subject sent by United States Commissioner of Education to more than 700 Summer school directors have just been analyzed.

FIVE days of technical session and protracted committee meetings within their own body and with officers of the armed services marked this year's Summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers recently concluded at the Hotel Greenbrier, at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

USUALLY when lists are made up of the season's "bests" in whatever field, they consist exclusively of finished works and finished artist which, is a logical enough approach, in all conscience. Just for the sake of novelty, however, it might be well once in a while to draw up roll of honor on the basis of future accomplishment.

MODERN art (using the term in its now well-established historic connotation) remains still demonstrative as our season drifts toward Summer somnolence.

FOR use where it is necessary to provide instantaneous illumination over a very large area, the Wabash Photolamp Corporation has just introduced a new high-powered superflash bulb. Known as the No. 3X, the bulb is said to have a light output of 4,500,000 peak lumens that are developed in a broad-peak instantaneous flash of 110,000 lumen-seconds.

On the third floor of Washington's glistening, many-windowed Social Security Building are the offices of the National Defense Mediation Board. The board, set up last March by President Roosevelt to serve as a "Supreme Court" for labor problems arising out of the defense effort, has been heavily taxed by a press of disputes which since Jan. 1 have caused a loss of 2,370,716 man-hours in War Department contracts alone.

It was inevitable that important questions of policy and methods of procedure would arise in the application of the rule for compulsory competitive bidding recently promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of public utility securities.

With the end of the current academic year next week, City College will celebrate the fifth anniversary of the founding of the House Plan Association, unofficial social center for students, alumni and members of the teaching staffs.

Plans for the construction of two super-drydoeks on which the United states Navy will build two 58,000-ton battleships were disclosed yesterday by Captain Harold V. McKittrick, captain of navy yard, operations, at farewell ceremonies for picturesque, century-old Wallabout Market on the Brooklyn waterfront.

"THE LETTERS OF JONATHAN OLDSTYLE" were contributed to The Morning Chronicle in 1802 by Washington Irving when he was a young man of 19, and Colonel Aaron Burr used to cut them out of his paper and send them to his beloved daughter, Theodosia, for whom his amazingly frank day-to-day diary was written.

RICHMOND. Va. -- Virginians believe that the Shenandoah National Park In the Blue Ridge Mountains of their State, through which runs the famous Skyline Drive, will probably establish an all-time high for patronage during the present travel year.

Parasang set a new track record at Aqueduct yesterday in winning the' $9,000 Carter Handicap with his master, C.V. Whitney present, but it is more likely that the young owner of some of the country's greatest horses would rather have won the fourth race, even though it was only for a $1,500 purse.

Parcel post for Egypt, Palestine, Portuguese East Africa, Saudi Arabia, South Africa and other African countries.

The picture of America nearly three weeks after the President's fighting fireside talk is not one of a nation doing all that needs to be done in preparation for defense and for increased aid to Britain. To some extent the President is responsible for this because he has not followed up his decisive speech with equally decisive action.

ELISABETH NEILSON was born into a liberal household in Southern Germany in the Eighteen Eighties, and she lived with her family in a small provincial town there until her marriage to a Scottish-American college professor in 1906.

Residential sales in Westchester County have shown a marked advance during the present year over 1940 and brokers in many localities report that the demand for well situated properties is steadily increasing. According to the firm of Prince Ripley the best record of residential sales has been made this season since 1933.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. -- Though the charm and beauty of the little sea-girt isle nine miles long and three miles wide, lying midway between Montauk and Point Judith where it dominates the Sound, still remains unchanged, the 1941 vacationist will find many improvements.

Winner of the 1941 P.G.A. Championship THIS is the time of the year when that great "green army" of golfers is getting firmly entrenched in the field for the Summer campaign. Clubs are being wielded, some with deadly precision, others with equally deadly indecision; divots are flying through the air like chips of shrapnel, and many a golf ball is taking a cruel slashing.

The amnesia story usually begins with the state of amnesia, when the victim does not know who he is. "The Black Curtain" starts at another moment in its hero's misadventure. Frank Townsend knows perfectly who he is, where he lives, all the rest of it.

Two New York schoolboys of other years will match strides on the Pacific Coast this week-end in what may be the stellar attraction of the annual National Collegiate A.A. track and field championships, which will be staged at Palo Alto on Friday and Saturday.

LONDON, June 14 -- A good place to get guidance on the perplexing course of Vichy politics these days would be an imaginary spot midway between Britain and the United States high enough up so that one could see events north and west of Africa and even as far as Syria.

WASHINGTON. A QUARTER century ago, when a world was at war and the United States was trying to hold on to a precarious neutrality, one of the country's most promising young business executives was prevailed upon to leave his chosen field and assume the presidency of Dartmouth College.

PRACTICALLY everybody is on a committee of some kind these days. Or a subcommittee, at least. When a big drive is on, the sports field isn't overlooked. That's where some of the subcommittees function. There was the Finnish Relief Campaign and the drive to get money for the valiant Greeks. There are all sorts of committees to collect funds and bundles for Britain.

A fleet of record size is prophesied for the twelfth annual intercollegiate and interscholastic out-board championships on the Raritan River at New Brunswick, N.J., Saturday and Sunday. Both defending individual champions, Frank J. Desmond of Villanova in the college ranks and Winthrope Wickwire of Phillips Andover Academy in the schoolboy division, face serious threats to their titles.

GOOD beach photography today is something more than mere snapshooting. There was a time when any recognizable snapshot taken on the beach was hailed with acclaim, but to be successful now one must produce pictures which show people doing something rather than posing frigidly, appearing spontaneous rather than static.

The American committee of Lloyd's Register of Shipping named John D. Reilly as chairman for a two-year term at the annual meeting of the group last week at 17 Battery Place. He succeeds L.H. Korndorff, president of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

IN the pages of a single might book called "Darwin, Marx, Wagner: Critique of a Heritage," by Jacques Barzun (Littie, Brown Co.), we are afforded a "new" interpretation of those three worthies of the nineteenth century in a way which permits no doubt whatever of the falsity of their reputations and their deleterious effect upon our age, in it doubt and its materialism.

A title for a travel book, "Here's to Canada" has obviously a double significance: to its first meaning as a toast is added the happy suggestion of invitation and promised guidance. And a parallel phrase may similarly be used in two senses in beginning a review of the book: here's to it -- a toast to excellence and counsel for perusal.

MONTGOMERY, Ala. -- Alabama is expecting its greatest Summer tourist season this year, as relatives and friends of boys in training at four military posts in this State turn Southward to visit the soldiers. To accommodate this influx of visitors, a vast expansion program in State parks and other recreation areas is nearing completion.

Correction of discriminatory features of the exchange control systems of both Uruguay and Argentina should be primary considerations in any reciprocal trade agreements this country negotiates with those nations, according to foreign traders here last week.

IN Singapore's Raffles Hotel I met an American businessman who overnight became the talk of the town because of his baggage: a passport with the imprints of the world's principal harbors, traveler's checks, and a tiny brief case with the most necessary personal effects and six toothbrushes.

A usual, some one was complaining the other day. He said that the theatre and the theatre's critics are too full of social significance. After a hard day at the office, worrying about the state of the world, he wants to laugh and relax.

For the second successive-week stocks rose last week and for the second Friday in a row they sold off a little under pressure of possible week-end developments. Yesterday they continued that moderate week-end evening-up process, giving up few of the gains that they had made in nine of the preceding eleven sessions.

'VICTORY': Fifteen thousand men of the Forty-fourth Division, United States Army, marched wearily last week into Fort Dix, N.J. They were returning home from manoeuvres in Caroline County, Va. They had "defeated" units of the Ninth Division and had suffered only one casualty -- Private Joseph Gricko, who suffered a fractured leg when struck by a civilian car in Maryland.

ARTISTS, writers, tourists and photographers without numher have returned from Ball with tales of its beauty, its civilization and the charm of its people, but probably none has come back with more convincing proof than Colin McPhee, who has brought back, not passages of lyrical prose or mere visual representations, but the island's music.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Davis of Washington and St. Louis have arrived at the Ritz Tower.
Another of the imposing group of town houses erected about a generation ago in the Fifth Avenue section east of Central Park is about to assume a new role in the realty world.

ST. LOUIS, Mo. -- Forty blocks of the older business and industrial area of St. Louis have now been cleared of buildings in preparation for the creation of the new Jefferson National Expansion Memorial, to be dedicated to Thomas Jefferson, third President of the United States, under whom, in 1803, the vast Louisiana Territory was acquired from France.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America will ordain twelve rabbis and confer thirty-six degrees, diplomas and certificates at its fifty-fourth annual commencement exercises at 4:30 P.M. today in the seminary quadrangle, Broadway and 122d Street.

More than 600 bank officials and executives representing forty-two States and the District of Columbia will assemble at New Brunswick, N.J., tomorrow for the opening of the annual resident session of the Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University, under the auspices of the American Bankers Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- "Miss Atlantic City," the young lady who will be hostess to the forty-eight contestants in the Miss America beauty and talent contest in September, will be selected at a grand ball in the Hotel Traymore Saturday night.

Opponents of the present leadership of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers sent telegrams yesterday to national leaders of tne American Federation of Labor urging them to support a movement to "clean Communists out of control of the council" in the union's annual election June 28.

On Flag Day Americans should consecrate themselves anew to those principles of democracy and freedom for which Old Glory stands and should resolve to do all in their power to preserve those ideals from the attack of dictators, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 14 -- After a lapse of twenty-four years, racing returned to the Piping Rock Club today with the Springy meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association. A gathering of 5,000 society folk viewed the program that was featured fay the Piping Rock Cup, won by Harold E. Talbott's Brother Jones.

Charles J. Pannill, president of the Radiomarine Corporation of America, announced yesterday that the concern had received orders for installing the latest type marine radio equipment on nearly a hundred new vessels being built here for operation under the American flag.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made effective a declaration of the Central United States Utilities Company and the Pennsylvania Electric Company regarding the issuance and sale by Pennsylvania Electric of 6,873 shares of no-par value common stock to Central for $2,000,000 in cash.

THERE were eleven children in the parsonage, and they were -- in both senses of the word -- a handful. The parson, it must be admitted, was a handful, too. Shoes and clothes and discipline were unremitting problems. Mother Powelson certainly never had a moment to call her own.

WHAT fun it is to begin a review with three rousing cheers! And the cheers' "rousing" element is of literal intention -- to stir up your enthusiasm for a top-flight mystery tale. Waste no time, reader, in beginning "The Deadly Truth" -- you'll certainly waste no time in finishing it.

American investments in Germany which may be "jeopardized" by yesterday's executive order freezing German credits here are estimated at $475,000,000 to $500,000,000 or more, excluding the debt of the German Government and its subdivisions, which amounted to $517,786,000 at last reports.

The largest small home development planned thus far in the metropolitan area under the insured mortgage system of the FHA will be started in the New Hyde Park section of Long Island within the next three weeks, FHA State Director Thomas G. Grace announced yesterday.
Poor building construction, declares State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, must not be allowed to result from the present, demand for rapid building of homes.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Although the expenditure of billions for defense has brought about the greatest number of employed in United States history, Congressional leaders have come to the conclusion that if the social aims of the New Deal are retained in anything like the present status, the Work Projects Administration will become a permanent organization.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14 -- A gray, chilly day ended in a crimson glow tonight as one of the best varsity crews that has ever rowed here set the final seal on Harvard's fourth straight clean sweep in its regratta with Yale on the Thames.

Under the direction of eleven instructors, nearly 100 engineering students are living and working in Cooper Union's newly completed Green Engineering Camp in the Ramapo Mountains, near Ringwood, N.J. The 150-acre tract, which includes twenty farm buildings and tenant houses, will ultimately serve as the Summer educational and year-round recreational center for 2,500 students and teachers in the Union's schools of art and engineering.

Belated though it may be, the pamphlet "Battle of Britain" issued by the British Ministry of Air Information is of importance because of the light that it throws on the possibility of subduing Great Britain with bombs. For fury and persistence, the attacks which began on Aug. 8, 1940, and continued with few interruptions until Oct. 6 stil stand apart.

Here is a Caribbean mystery tale with an odd quality of distinction; an odd quality of horror too. When Karen Peterson impulsively gives up her job in Cuba, to leave the ship at Riquezas and be hostess in Mr. Fernandez's hotel, she steps into what cannot exactly be described as a horror story, but is certainly touched with troubling strangeness throughout its puzzling course.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- This century-old coastal and mountain resort is planning a varied calendar for the Summer months, marked by yachting, golf, tennis, swimming and a full round of social events. Acadia National Park, offering an unusual combination of ocean, lake and mountain scenery and outdoor division, will again be host to thousands of vacationists from all parts of the country.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 14 -- Major Coffey was stricken on Wednesday afternoon after he had hit a home run in a softball game between the regiment's two battalions. Always an enthusiastic athlete, he was a member of Cornell University's boxing team.

IN "The Golden Skylark," which brings together twelve separate stories, some new, a few reprinted from magazines, Miss Goudge has, unwittingly, presented a unique opportunity for a reviewer to evaluate the writings that have flowed from her pen in a constant but never hurried stream of beautiful prose, since 1936.

PERHAPS the most impressivie showing yet made by the Index of American Design, WPA Art Project, is the exhibition current in the Eighty-third Street foyer of the Metropolitan Museum through June. One hundred examples of work by artists on the Index have been assembled, accompanied In many cases by originals from the museum's own collection -- glass, furniture, rugs and the like.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- The weather played a rather mean trick on the Giants and Reds today as they prepared to open their four-game series which aims to determine immediate occupancy of third place in the National League.

In the first three chapters of this book Ogden Farlow is forced, under, torture, to confess to the murder of Peter van Dervelpen, and his confession is, to all appearances, fully confirmed. And there, in a Niagara City jail, we leave Ogden Farlow while we follow the adventures of Joe LongBuffalo, a British-born American Indian who goes to Chicago, and to the very toughest section of that city, in search of information about his brother-in-law.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles, commenting at a press conference on a German spokesman's statement that every ship carrying contraband to England would be sunk if caught, declared today that "the people of the United States never have been impressed with what they regarded as bluster or threats."

Nearly five centuries ago the capture of Constantinople by the Turks drove Byzantine scholars, familiar with the ancient treasures of Greek learning, into Western Europe. This migration was one of the wellsprings of the Renaissance and a lasting contribution to Western culture.
BACK from the "West Coast, and practically a month, of touring up and down it, Lawrence Langner has some matters of considerable moment to report, in this fashion:

TRAVEL LINES: St. Louis' Municipal Opera has started its twenty-third successive season of popular musical plays presented in the beautiful natural amphitheatre (seating 10,000) in Forest Park. Tourists journeying West stop over frequently to see the outdoor performances.

Only a slight Improvement over the first quarter of 1940 was shown in the combined earnings of food, apparel, cosmetic and related consumers' goods industries in the first three months of 1941, with higher taxes and costs offsetting a larger sales volume in virtually all Instances.

OTTAWA, June 14 -- With the government on the defensive against a succession of critics of its conduct of the war, the Canadian parliament adjourned today until November unless circumstances should necessitate an earlier meeting.

War conditions are again making home vegetable gardens popular. Regardless of whether the gardens are a few square yards in size or larger, more substantial ones an unseen horde of insect and disease pests are waiting to sweep down on the plants.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- An early demand for cottages and estates, an encouraging advance seasonal reservation at leading hotels and various sports and social activities announced by private clubs now open indicate the liveliest Summer this and adjacent resorts have experienced in many years.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Big-game fishing will hold a dominant position in the Summer Sports parade of Miami Beach this year and an elaborate schedule will be available for vacationists.

LONDON. THE publication of a translation of the New Testament in Basic English has applied to this linguistic innovation -- of which I gave some account in my letter of Sept 3, 1939 -- the most searching test it has yet received.
MISS RATCHFORD has written the most important book about the Brontes since Mrs. Gaskell laid down her pen eighty-three years ago. She calls a halt to insane speculations and wild surmises.

Unless governmental restrictions on installment selling intervene, retail credit sales this year may reach a new peak of around $16,500,000,000, according to J. Anton Hagios, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
PLANES shipped to Great Britain from the United States are getting into action faster with the aid of a new dehydrating chemical that protects engines in transit from moisture and rust.

City College will confer degrees on 2,400 young men and women at Its ninety-fourth annual commencement exercises on Wednesday evening at the college's Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. Eighteen thousand parents, members of the faculty and alumni are expected to attend.

WITH a design in gray surrounoled by a black border, a Finland 2.75-markka commemorates the death of President Kyosti Kallio last Dec. 19. His name is inscribed across the top and "In Memoriam" along the base, and the date, "19 XII 1940" is given.

Theodora DuBois is the wife of a research man at Yale Medical School; which suggests an explanation for the destiny which is forever snaring Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey McNeill in criminal complications of scientific involvement.

FOR Alfred P. Sloan, top man in General Motors, to call himself a white-collar man, just like that, may savor a bit of understatement. It gives somewhat the sound of an American success story in the Horatio Alger style, which this book is not intended to be.

HAVANA -- Cuba's Ministry of Communications will release on June 25 two stamps to mark the centenary of the birth of Guillermo Moncada, one of the patriots in Cuba's wars against Spanish rule. A 3-centavos (quantity, 1,000,000) presents philately's first likeness of Moncada, and a sword and the republic's lone-star symbol are at left.

SYDNEY. THERE are many in Australia who deplore the passing of her pioneering stage, and with it some-thing of the hardy spirit that sustained the early settlers in their struggle against grim and often hostile elements.

VACATION days are a good time to take stock and to look ahead. For young people of energy and ambition they offer an opportunity to find out, through, practical experience or by inquiry and reading, what a world in which there are more professions and vocations open than ever before offers in the way of a rewarding and useful future.

LONDON, Sunday, June 15 -- For the third night in succession bombers of the British Royal Air Force pounded the industrial Ruhr region of Germany over Friday night and other strong R. A. F. units again attacked Brest, where the Nazi battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau and a Hipper-class cruiser, possibly the Prinz Eugen, have been sheltering.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A group of American and foreign liberals and progressives will meet here tomorrow in a conference for democratic victory.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The shipbuilding stabilization committee of the Office of Production Management submitted to fifty-five Atlantic Coast yards today a master labor compact designed to standardize wages and working conditions and insure industrial peace for two years.

ROME, June 14 -- An Indirect attack against the Pope was published today in Roberto Farinacci's newspaper Regime Fascista giving the text of the Vatican broadcast of May 26 in which the Pope was quoted as urging the Poles to resist German propaganda.

Even with the advent of Summer, many flower-lovers like to have growing plants inside as well as outside, and there are always the city-bound who must perforce enjoy nature indoors. To the aid of these the modern designer has come, originating many new ideas for plant stands and flower-pot arrangements.

COLLEGE COLORS The boat races at New London yesterday brought out perhaps the oldest blossoming of college colors -- the crimson of Harvard and the blue of Yale. Six China silk handker-chiefs bought in a Boston department store started off the tradition.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Three Supreme Court nominations were sent last week to the United States Senate. They forecast new faces on the Supreme Bench when the court assembles next Fall for its regular sessions. Harlan F. Stone, an Associate Justice for more than sixteen years, has been named for the mantle laid aside by Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 -- The British and French Fleets swung into action near Saida, Lebanon, today, with British warships shelling the road south of Saida and French warships supported by bombers attacking the British land and sea forces near the beleaguered city, according to reports tonight from military and diplomatic sources.

The charge that the major oil companies may be taking advantage of the tanker shortage to build up a panic among fuel oil distributors and the public, as a prelude to a request that the oil industry be given immunity from certain Anti-Trust Law provisions to meet the emergency situation, was made yesterday by N.R. Skaggs of Skaggs Walsh, Inc., president of the New York Oil Heating Association.

The part which landlords, builders and their agents may play in the national defense effort will be ona of the main topics to be discussed at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers, which, opens tomorrow in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- All aliens of European nationality, including German and Italian refugees, who are on the payroll of American concerns engaged in legitimate enterprise will continue to receive their salaries under general licenses already issued by Secretary Morgenthau with regard to nationals of countries covered by previous freezing orders, Treasury officials said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Twenty -one more companies of the Civilian Conservation Corps are to be assigned to administrative duties at nine new Army general hospitals and twelve Army replacement centers. This will bring to a total of 12,500 the number of CCC workers engaged in national defense activities at sixty-seven different locations.

HANOVER, N.H., June 14 -- Wendell L. Willkie and Secretary Knox will receive honorary Doctorates of Laws at the 172d commencement of Dartmouth College tomorrow, as will Chairman Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and Stanley E. Qua, '01, Justice of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts.

STEP a litle closer, please," said Dante, and raised a ghostly arm over the rim of chaos. The frightened little band of observers from the tipper regions edged closer, shielding their faces with copy paper which slowly turned a crisp brown.

TOKYO, June 14 -- The resignation of Agriculture Minister Tadaatsu Ishiguro and his immediate replacement with Vice Minister Sekisai Ino again directed attention to Japan's economic structure and the effects on it of the "China incident" and the defense program.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5 -- The immediate future of Argentine politics, and consequently of Argentina's foreign policy, may depend upon the health of one man -- Roberto M. Ortiz, who still occupies the official residence of the President of the republic though not wielding the powers of that office.

BURLINGTON, Vt.-Vermonters are expecting to be hosts to an unusual number of visitors in the Green Mountains this Summer, partly because of the growing popularity of the State as i vacation land, especially with the restrictions on foreign travel, and partly because this is the 150th anniversary of Vermont's admission to the Federal Union.

THERE are cruises in variety this Summer, with frequent sailings and ample deck and stateroom space. Despite large-scale commandeering of ships by the government and the establishment of overseas forbidden acnes, sea trips ranging from a few days to six weeks or so are offered, with all the customary cruise trimmings, at normal rates.

MRS. JONES was enjoying her favorite broadcast program when the telephone rang. Over the wire a pleasant feminine voice, after explaining that a "radio reporter" was calling, went on to ask her exactly four questions:

WINTHROP, Me.-- Atlantic salmon, landlocked salmon, chinook salmon. Brook trout, black bass, brown trout, rainbow trout, lake trout. The fishermen are after them again this year in Maine and getting them too.

NOT for a long time -- not, perhaps, since Stewart Edward White concluded his series of novels about Andy Burnett -- has any one turned out a more readable or more truthfully flavored novel about the American frontier.

LONDON, June 14 -- Successful attacks on German and Italian shipping in Mediterranean waters by British submarines were announced tonight in an Admiralty communique stating that four Italian schooners, an armed trawler, a fully laden supply ship and a large supply lighter were known to have been sunk, and two tankers and an armed merchant cruiser torpedoed.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In THE TIMES of' June 2, under the heading, "Dry Bills in Congress Face Doom as Stimson and Knox Fight Them," there appears a Washington dispatch by Hallett Abend quoting some sentences from a letter by Secretary Stimson to the Military Affairs Committee of the Senate.

OTTAWA, Ont. -- Breakfast for two at the Hotel Royal York in Toronto was $1.75, but the waiter brought $9.25 in change from the "sawbuck." It's one of the pleasantest aspects of visiting the Dominion these days, to tender a ten-dollar bill in United States currency and get back $11 with a hearty thank you.
FORT DIX, N.J., June 14 -- Tomorrow, six days before the official arrival of the Summer solstice, the 26,000 soldiers of Fort Dix will herald Sumer with changes in uniform.

VACATION fever, now that Summer's come, is epidemic. Puzzling mixture of hypnosis, primal urge and sleeping sickness, it stirs the clerk and the tycoon, sets them to dreaming of far horizons, deep cool valleys, snowy peaks, lonely beaches and sunny waters.

ROCHESTER., N.Y., June 14 -- Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of Great Britain, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the annual commencement exercises of the University of Rochester on Monday and will accept in a ten-minute radio address to the United States.

LEWISBURG, Pa. -- The attention of travelers through Central Pennsylvania is frequently drawn to the curious geometrical designs which decorate the barns. They are always the same-a stylized' star within a circle-are painted in bright colors and are always kept bright and clean.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) -- Chairman Jerry Giesler of the California Horse Racing Board today cited eleven owners of nine racing stables to appear on June 23 in connection with an investigation of stimulating horses at Hollywood Park.

THE traditional conception of music, as defined by Plato and restated for the past two thousand years, has beer rapidly disappearing: from view The ancients placed music beside arithmetic, geometry and astron omy in the quadrivium of the liberal arts.

HOLLYWOOD. THE split between Universal and Joe Pasternak, producer of the Deanna Durbin films, which startled the town when it was announced the other day, involved far more sentiment and much, less acrimony than is generally attendant upon Hollywood partings.

When Gerald M. Livingston, president of the Westminster Kennel Club, presented to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross last month a check for nearly $5,000 as the proceeds of the sixty-fifth annual dog show of his organization, he stated that the proceeds exceeded those of any previous year.

The Grand Circuit harness-racing season will get under way over the one-half mile Roosevelt Raceway course at Westbury, L.I., tomorrow night. It will mark the first time in thirty-two years that a Grand Circuit meet has been held in the New York area, the big league sulky pullers having last competed at the Empire City track in Yonkers.

In a record graduation for adults, 1,000 students from 17 to 81, representing seventy-five nationalities, received their diplomas yesterday for completion of evening elementary school work under the direction of the Board of Education in this city.

KATONAH, N.Y., June 14 -- Two fine representatives of the terrier group captured the chief awards early tonight as the annual North Westchester Kennel Club's all-breed show, second largest outdoor canine exhibition in the country, was concluded while darkness descended on Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt's estate.

RESORT lines: Old Orchard Beach, Me., announces trotting races every day except Sunday, from July 14-26. . . . Ocean City, Md., sponsors the fourth annual boat parade, June 22, starting a round of seasonal activities. . . . Sparhawk Hall at Ogunquit, Me., opens its forty-second season June 28 with a dance. . . .

Committees have been organized here in the interests of a benefit garden party and entertainment to be held on the afternoon and evening of June 22 at Foxhead Lodge, the Peekskill (N.Y.) estate of Mr. and Mrs. I.J. Fox. Proceeds of the fete will augment the British War Relief Society's fund for emergency aid after air raids in Britain.
BERLIN, June 14 -- The tendency on the Boerse was firm all through today's session, with closing quotations maintained at the highest levels.

More Summer cottages are nearing completion in the Putnam Lake community, a few miles from Brewster in Putnam County, N.T., than has been the case at this time in any previous year, states Bernard Frank, manager of the development.

SOME eighty-seven years ago a carpenter on Long Island carried in his lunch pail for noon hour reading a book written by a lecturer who lived in Concord, "and from that time he took with him no other writer." The tools of the laborer were laid down, the thoughts of the philosopher pondered.

Present unsettled conditions are creating new opportunities for young men starting in business, according to Major Frederick W. Nichol, vice president and general manager of the International Business Machines Corporation, speaking yesterday at the commencement exercises of Babson Institute, Wellesley Hills, Mass.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- "Vermont remembers 1791 in 1941" is the slogan round which this State is building her Sesquicentennial observance this year. With historical exhibits, drama and oratory she is recalling the old days in such a way that no citizen or visitor is likely to forget the significance of the events that led up to her entry into the Union.

MURRAY BAY, Que. -- The Summer season will officially open here on June 25 when the flag is raised over the Manoir Richelieu, marking the opening of that hotel resort. The occasion will be celebrated with a dinner dance attended by guests of the Manoir and members of the cottage colony.

GABRIEL PASCAL is definitely going to establish his production headquarters in Canada. A couple of weeks back it was noted here that the producer of the George Bernard Shaw films, "Pygmalion" and "Major Barbara," was in Canada to survey the possibilities of reestablishing the Revina Studio in Toronto, which now is being used as a roller-skating rink.

Reports that collier operators would be asked to contribute some of their ships to President Roosevelt's 2,000,000-ton shipping pool were questioned here last week by John A. Lennon, secretary of M. J. Tracy, Inc., operators of six colliers carrying coal from Hampton Roads, Va., to New York.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 14 -- Frank Campbell finally lost a, boat race. It happened in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Y.R.A. championship regatta today and the Larchmont ace was second with the black menace of the Star class, Rascal, after winning five straight, three of them in championship events.

Evenings, when a girl is dressed up, are the time to wear or carry some gadget or accessory that is pretty dramatic, especially if she has a dress that is minus trimmings. A long fantastically shaped cigarette holder, an improbable doodad in the hair, an evening bag that is a bit on the crazy side, usually have good glamour value.

RIO BE JANEIRO AN orchestral series of five concerts which opened this year's music season in Rio de Janerio was entrusted to the French conductor Albert Wolff who is resident in South America. The selection of programs he presented were in a way an experiment.

FOR several years the historical novels of Frank O. Hough have been receiving excellent reviews, but have been pretty much snubbed by book buyers. A happier ending now seems in view. His latest novel, "The Neutral Ground," is adding a good record of popular response to the as usual good reviews.

If President Roosevelt's executive order can be made effective it will prevent Germany and Italy from accumulating and using dollar balances in this country, according to financial, sources, and will end the heretofore legal business of repatriating assets, highly profitable not only to German industry but also to the Reich.

Of more than 3,000,000 notes representing a value slightly in excess of $1,300,000,000 insured by the FHA under Title I of the National Housing Act, about 128 claims for $32,000,000 on defaulted loans, or less than 2 1/2 per cent of the amount of loans insured, has been paid by the FHA since its inception, it was announced yesterday.

LEWISBURG, Pa. -- The attention of travelers through Central Pennsylvania is frequently drawn to the curious geometrical designs which decorate the barns. They are always the same-a stylized' star within a circle-are painted in bright colors and are always kept bright and clean.

THIS "portrait" of Marian Anderson is set forth in the personal recollections of her Finnish accompanist, the pianist and composer who has been the professional associate of her ten years of triumph. The book is thus the story of the singer's career from a decade ago.

ONE of the most significant movements in music in this country at present is the fostering of native composition, and an influential group in Philadelphia, headed by Mrs. Herbert C. Morris, has now joined in the movement.

The Dramatic Workshop of the New School for Social Research, established in January, 1940, as a new approach in preparing young people for the theatre, has just completed its first full course. In his third catalogue and report Erwin Piscator, director, reviews the progress made to date and outlines briefly the new developments planned for next year.

Reports that collier operators would be asked to contribute some of their ships to President Roosevelt's 2,000,000-ton shipping pool were questioned here last week by John A. Lennon, secretary of M. J. Tracy, Inc., operators of six colliers carrying coal from Hampton Roads, Va., to New York.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 14 -- Frank Campbell finally lost a, boat race. It happened in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Y.R.A. championship regatta today and the Larchmont ace was second with the black menace of the Star class, Rascal, after winning five straight, three of them in championship events.

A long fantastically shaped cigarette holder, an improbable doodad in the hair, an evening bag that is a bit on the crazy side, usually have good glamour value.

FOR several years the historical novels of Frank O. Hough have been receiving excellent reviews, but have been pretty much snubbed by book buyers. A happier ending now seems in view. His latest novel, "The Neutral Ground," is adding a good record of popular response to the as usual good reviews.

If President Roosevelt's executive order can be made effective it will prevent Germany and Italy from accumulating and using dollar balances in this country, according to financial, sources, and will end the heretofore legal business of repatriating assets, highly profitable not only to German industry but also to the Reich.

Of more than 3,000,000 notes representing a value slightly in excess of $1,300,000,000 insured by the FHA under Title I of the National Housing Act, about 128 claims for $32,000,000 on defaulted loans, or less than 2 1/2 per cent of the amount of loans insured, has been paid by the FHA since its inception, it was announced yesterday.

Two newcomers in national chess circles, who will make their debuts in the forthcoming invitation masters tournament at Ventnor City, N.J., July 5-13, are Ariel A.A. Mengarini of Washington, D.C. and Robert Durkin of Milwaukee. Both have built up reputations in their respective communities and will go to the shore resort strongly recommended.

Improvement of the Bronx River for navigation purposes is now nearly half completed and the entire job is expected to be completed by July 4, the Bronx Board of Trade announced yesterday on the basis of information obtained from Army engineers in this city.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Reports of expectation in New York City of an increase in the price of bread because of the higher costs of ingredients, chiefly eggs and butter, are declared by officials here to have no reasonable foundation.

COOPED up as we are this year in the Western Hemisphere, thousands of girls are going to be traveling about this country and points north and south in a couple of suitcases on their Summer vacations. In packing those suitcases there is one absolute rule that the expert sticks to in spite of all temptation to break it.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated June 13:
Our air power will continue to teach the German homeland that war is not all loot and triumph.

A collection of rare paintings, etchings, prints, drawings and books, described as the finest of its kind and valued at more than $2,000,000, has been presented to the Boston Public Library by Albert H. Wiggin, New York financier.

A parcel of forty lots at Utica and Fillmore Avenues in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn has been purchased by I. Silverstein, builder, from the Home Life Insurance Company and will be improved with one-family homes, it was announced yesterday.
CEDARMURST, L.I., June 14 -- The annual invitation doubles tennis tournament, delayed several hours because of the condition of the courts, got under way today at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

TODAY the echo of the Old West, like the echo of Tennyson's famous bugle note, is dying ... dying ... dying. But who need care? Certainly not the person who wants to spend his vacation on a dude ranch in the "West.

Last week the Museum of Modern Art observed the tenth anniversary of the establishment of its traveling loan exhibitions. Since the museum sent out its first show in 1931, an "International Exhibition of Modern Architecture," 8,000,000 persons in all parts of the United States have seen these displays.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Travelers in New Mexico show a great diversity of tastes, with more than half of them taking advantage of the scenic grandeur and recreational facilities offered by the forests, parks and monuments.

VICHY, France, June 14 -- The new status for Jews in France, printed in detail in the Official Journal today, bears out yesterday's forecasts, complemented by a law ordering a census of all Jews in the country.

BY 1944, if all goes according to schedule, the New York City Housing Authority will have built enough low-rent apartment houses -- well-planned and equipped, interspersed with acres of playgrounds and gardens -- to rehouse 33,000 slum families.

THANKS: Clothing Appreciated I have been working in several rest centers since last October and in each. I have found proof of the thoughtful generosity of the American public, as shown in the splendid consignments of clothes and other comforts sent by the American Red Cross.
STAMFORD, N.Y. -- This quaint little Summer resort village nestled between the wooded slopes of Mount Utsayantha is fast coming to life in preparation for what promises to be a successful season.

At last we are getting around to welcoming Bud Abbott and Lou Costello to the screen -- a recognition almost as belated as an Edward Everett Horton double-take For the Messrs. Abbott and Costello are by now a couple of household by-words, known throughout the country for their madness on radio and screen.

WORD came from London last-week that Qa'aiti and Kathiri will soon enter the family of philatelic governments. Protected States within Great Britain's Crown Colony of Aden, each is to be accorded the privilege of having its own postal paper.

VICHY, June 14 (UP) -- French authorized circles replied to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today with the assertion that Franco-German collaboration is a policy that France has adopted on her own initiative, acting as the "sole judge of what her aspirations are in the realm of her liberties and traditions."

SHANGHAI, June 14 -- Foreign observers here are carefully watching developments in the Far East, especially the Japanese negotiations with the Netherlands Indies and Wang Ching-wei's trip to Japan. It is feared in some circles that Japan's failure to achieve economic domination of the Indies might result in action by Japanese extremists.

LIKE Desdemona's handkerchief and Melisande's ring, it was an earring whose loss proved the undoing of Elfride Swancourt and brought about her tragic end in "A Pair of Blue Eyes." None of these famous relics has been recovered, but in the case of Thomas Hardy's story we have the original upon which the episode was based.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va. -- Headed by Commodore Garland C. Clay of Richmond, members of the Hampton Yacht Club have completed arrangements for a full week of entertainment in honor of yachtsmen who will participate in the ocean sailing face from New London, Conn., to Old Point Comfort next Saturday, Sunday and Monday, under the joint sponsorship of the local club and the Storm Trysail Club of New York City.

RICHMOND, Va. June 14 -- The cornerstone laying ceremonies of the Belgian Friendship Building and the Robert L. Vann Memorial Tower on our campus last week, was a historic milestone in the progress of Negro education in America.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- An explosion heard for miles lifted the bow of the 3,000-ton Venezuelan oil tanker Caroni out of the Schuylkill early today, injured five members of the crew and caused damage likely to keep the vessel from service for three months.

SCHROON LAKE -- The Summer program at this Adirondack resort will be punctuated by many major events which promise to attract a large number of visitors from various Eastern cities as well as Summer colonists from near-by resort communities.

No hardy border or perennial garden, no matter how lovely, need be an object of envy for the amateur gardener. Given good seed wisely selected, intelligent care and planning, the most beautiful garden in existence can be raised from seed for an unbelievably small outlay of time and money.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Montreal got brilliant pitching from Tex Carleton and Ed Head today and captured both ends of a double-header from Jersey City, 2 -- 1 and 1 -- 0, to take the series two games to one.

Today marked the opening of the bass season in New Jersey lakes and streams, and according to the State Fish and Game Commission the waters are well-stocked with largemouth and smallmouth members of this family.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 14 The latent rivalry between Russia and Germany is believed in diplomatic circles here to have reached a point where political-military developments are expected at any moment.

CINCINNATI, Ohio -- "Steamboat coming round the bend!" That cry which sends barbershop loungers racing to the levee for choice vantage points echoes again in Mississippi River towns as three of the famous old packets are put back into service.
A strike of 800 vorkers in nine bottling plants of the Coca-Cola Company threatened yesterday to make "the pause that refreshes" a long and thirsty one for residents of the metropolitan dis.

JERUSALEM, June 14 -- The proclamation issued at Cairo last Sunday by General Georges Catroux, Free French commander in the Middle East, and which was endorsed by the British Government, promising complete independence and freedom to the peoples of Syria and Lebanon, has had a very favorable effect in Arab public opinion, it was indicated here today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- The Newark Bears uncorked a twelve-hit attack in the nightcap of a double-header today to earn an 8-to-3 decision and an even break with the Buffalo Bisons. The visitors took the opener, 3 to 2, on a ninth-inning home run by pinch-hitter Ollie Carnegie with two out and one on.

The President from time to time, but not less frequently than once every ninety days, shall transmit to the Congress a report of operations under this act, except such information as he deems incompatible with the public interest to disclose.

SAN FRANCISCO -- This year, California has more than ever to offer the visitor. Besides all that goes with fun at the beaches and in the mountains, man and nature have joined forces to provide an additional abundance of things to see, both in town and country, with at least one more sport, ordinarily limited to the Winter scene, to enjoy deep into the Summer.

NEWLY published by the United States Children's Bureau is a pamphlet, "The Child Health Conference," setting forth principles and working practice for health supervision in the community. Parents may be interested in one recommendation, to staff physicians:

SOME indication that the first rush of consumer buying built on the defense boom has moderated was found last week in retail quarters. This phase featured the refurbishing of homes which had become quite threadbare in the days of depression and relief.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Roosevelt ordered today the immediate freezing of the assets in the United States of Germany and Italy and all invaded or occupied European countries whose funds and investments had not previously been frozen, including Albania, Austria, Czecho-Slovakia, Danzig and Poland.
