Lists of new rentals in apartment buildings issued by brokers and agents over the week-end indicate a continuance of the demand for suites in scattered sections of the city. Buildings in the Greenwich Village area and at London Terrace attracted many of the new tenants.

Coming at this time the President's order freezing Axis assets in the country will naturally be taken as, in part at least, a reply to the increasingly truculent attitude Germany has taken over the sinking of the Robin Moor. But it is not a suddenly extemporized move.

New York's fathers celebrated their day in a somber mood yesterday in exercises on the mall in Central Park as they heard their sons pledged to fight in defense of the nation. Five thousand persons attended the ceremonies, sponsored by five posts of the New York County American Legion.

Confidence in the ultimate federating of all nations of the world in a union with the attendant abolishing of war was expressed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee, in his last sermon is pastor of Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.

TOKYO, June 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Motoyuki Yamashita, head of the Japanese military mission to the Axis powers, was quoted by the Berlin correspondent of the newspaper Nichi Nichi as saying in an interview:

AMHERST, Mass., June 15 -- As the need for fighters increases in urgency, "our need for more educated men and women becomes more vital than ever," Governor Saltonstall told the graduating class at Amherst College tonight.

Expenditures of national advertisers in newspapers, magazines, farm journals and chain radio last year totaled $420,479,424, of which newspapers received $160,838,784, or 38 per cent, according to the annual study on national advertising expenditures by classifications which will be issued today by the research and promotion department of the bureau of advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

BERLIN, June 15 -- The stock market reacted by price declines ranging from 2 to 5 points to Minister of Economics Walther Funk's Vienna address of Thursday in which he reminded his audience that his promise made exactly three months ago to subject dividends in excess of 6 per cent to "prohibitive taxation" still held good.

Although the La Guardia administration hopes to adjust its controversy with the Transport Workers Union without any strike on the city's unified transit lines, it has mapped out a comprehensive plan for emergency service on its subway, elevated, street car and bus lines if there should be a walkout, it was disclosed yesterday.

The store and second floor in 1600 Broadway, northeast corner of Forty-eighth Street, have been leased by Howard Clothes, chain of men's clothing shops, which will move about Oct. 1 from its present store at Broadway and Fiftieth Street.

A strong, conscious and resolute American democracy is the true "wave of the future," Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, said at the baccalaureate service yesterday in the college assembly hall, 695 Park venue.

A Modern Fable Legends concerning the prehistoric land of Uz are, of course, mythological and and have to be taken with a grain of salt. Still, they make good reading for an idle hour. The tale of the destruction of Uz and the extinction of Uzzan civilization is one of them.

Crowding into a single afternoon more sports personalities than the average fan could hope to see in a year or more, the Macy's Father's Day Sports Parade provided some 15,000 spectators with nearly six hours of entertainment at the Poll Grounds yesterday.
VICHY, France, June 15 (AP) -- The following communique from Syrian Headquarters was issued here tonight:

Life, to achieve its fullness, must have the north wind of adversity and disillusionment blow through it, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Two major crises in the war are developing rapidly.

The way was cleared yesterday for the chartering of two new anti-Communist teachers' unions in this city to replace the Teachers' Union, Local 5, and the College Teachers Union, Local 537, which were expelled from the American Federation of Teachers on charges of Communist domination.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 15 (UP) -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, made a plea today for national unity of purpose behind an Army which "presents a remarkable example of the people of this democracy in its spirit and uncomplaining ways."

HANOVER, N.H., June 15 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie received an honorary degree today at Dartmouth College, whose president told him that "in political defeat you have become a greater force for unity than would have been possible for you in victory."
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Detroit and Washington, broke even in a double-header today, the Senators taking the first game, 7 -- 5, and the Tigers a six-inning nightcap, 4 -- 2.

Philip Ruhle, 43 years old, of 70-35 Sixty-fourth Street, Glendale, Queens, drives a pie truck for the Paradise Baking Corporation. But on a Sunday you're pretty sure to find him out fishing in the 32-foot cabin cruiser Anna B, with his 12-year-old son Philip Jr.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 15 -- Stale from brigade and division manoeuvres, the soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division will begin a course in preliminary marksmanship or "dry firing" tomorrow in preparation for firing of all weapons on the target ranges during the next few weeks, Lieut. Col. Edward J. Maloney, division operations and training officer, announced today.
NEW YORK Major William L. Ritchie, U.S.A., and Mrs. Ritchie of Washington are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 15 -- The apparent intention of the Government of Uruguay to repeat its 1917 policy of granting full naval facilities to the United States in wartime is regarded as likely to bring a showdown throughout South America on the question of continental defense.

The problem of Jewish education, its techniques and its need for wider support is a challenge that must be faced by intelligent Jewish leadership, Dr. Abram L. Sachar, national director of B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundations at American Universities, declared yesterday at the sixteenth annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion in its auditorium, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

RYE, N.Y., June 15 -- The only tennis player in history to score a grand slam, who stood invincible against all comers from 1937 through 1940, suffered defeat today at the hands of a California professional who was comparatively unknown in the East until this year.

A two-story store building will be erected at the northeast corner of George and Albany Streets, New Brunswick, N.J., to replace a row of old frame houses sold by the New Brunswick Trust Company to the S.I. Building Corporation of Newark.
SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J., June 15 -- The south wind that held during the last few days brought lower temperatures to the inshore waters, and the surf casters took a few striped bass over this week-end.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Congress will rush work this week on all remaining appropriation bills so as to meet the July 1 deadline when the new fiscal year starts.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 92.8 to 93.4. The individual increases were confined chiefly to the farm products, foodstuffs and textile products subgroups, but were fairly evenly distributed among the three major group classifications.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 15 -- For the first time since the beginning of the Russian-German tension, the Swedish press mentions today that some reservists have been called for military exercises in Finland.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 15 -- An honorary degree of Doctor of Municipal Administration, awarded for the first time, was given by Wesleyan University at its commencement exercises tonight to Jasper McLevy, Socialist Mayor of Bridgeport.

A little oasis of rusticity in the midst of a sophisticated city is the jolly shop whose shelves support a row of those comfortable, clumsy cooky crocks that once upon a time enticed small boys with pennies in their pockets in through the doorway of the country store.

Cotton prices advanced sharply last week to register their best levels since April, 1937. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected net gains for the week of 53 to 62 points, with the most marked gains in the distant months.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 15 -- Anything can happen on Long Island Sound. Today it was fog, and the eighty craft that turned out for the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's special distance regatta had a merry time groping their way around in the murk.

LONDON, June 15 -- What, in the City's opinion, appeared on first sight to be a fully justified criticism of the British failure to hold Crete has been distinctly modified since the debate in Parliament concerning the military operations on the island.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Hidden in a back corridor of the Munitions Building is the nerve center of the Air Corps branch just created to speed delivery of American airplanes to Great Britain.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- An eight-run outburst in the sixth inning gave the Phils an 8-4 victory over the Cubs in the second game of a double-header today after the Chicagoans had taken the opener, 6 to 0, behind Claude Passeau's steady pitching.

Five midtown motion - picture houses will present new shows this week; Wednesday the Rialto will bring in Damon Runyon's latest, "Tight Shoes," which Universal made with John Howard, Broderck Crawford, Binnie Barnes and Leo Carrillo in the lead roles.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Coincident with continuing reports from various European cities that Germany is bringing military and diplomatic pressure to bear against Soviet Russia, diplomatic circles here were interested today in unconfirmed reports that Germany and Japan, acting in concert, were attempting to induce Moscow to consent to measures that would virtually disarm Russia on the Pacific.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With profound regret and some astonishment I read the interview with Prince Consort Bernhard of the Netherlands in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 13 under the heading "No German Rebirth After "War Defeat, Asserts Bernhard."

AFTER years of research among books and old parchments here and abroad, Garrett Mattingly has written a fascinating biography* of the most famous divorcee in English history: the Queen named Catherine who was divorced by the King named Henry.

American Navy officers serving in London as observers and as attaches at the embassy cast aside all Blitzkrieg anxieties yesterday to hold two-way radio conversations with their thirteen children back home on such homely subjects as spinach, little girls' curls and fingernails, the family dog, school examinations and vacation time, swimming and dancing, to say nothing of the bother of vaccination.

Alfred J. Talley, former General Sessions judge, who is being considered as the Tammany candidate for Mayor in the next election, sharply criticized Mayor La Guardia yesterday as responsible for Communist and Nazi "infiltration into key positions of the city government."

NEW ORLEANS, June 15 -- Consolidating its gains as the week progressed, the cotton futures market here last week moved up to new high levels for the season as a daily habit. Trading was not so heavy as in previous weeks, but inflationary ideas spread, along with continued good demand for spot cottion, another huge domestic consumption for May and unfavorable crop reports from wide areas of the belt.

WEEK ENDED JUNE 14, 1941 Not much happened in the foreign exchange market last week to distinguish it from preceding trading periods. Business was small and only unimportant price changes were recorded.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The wheat market last week was distinctly a weather affair. Prices, after scoring upturns to new highs for the season on rains over the preceding weekend, sold off about 3% cents a bushel from the tops, but again turned strong on forecasts that the next four or five days would be showery in the Southwest, especially in those parts of Oklahoma and Texas where harvest already has been retarded.

CINCINNATI, June 15 -- The Reds, abounding in patience and perseverance, outlasted even the weather today to thrash the Giants in a double-header while 24,868 onlookers, who braved hours of rain, thunder and lightning, bellowed approval.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 15 -- The vital Jimma area of Ethiopia, long a center of Italian resistance in the western region, is being surrounded by native patriot forces while British Imperial troops continue their advance toward the town from the east, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Office of Civilian Defense has drafted plans for a vast emergency volunteer fire-fighting organization in New York and all major Atlanti seaboard cities to guard agains fire-bomb attack.

Governor Lehman, speaking yesterday at commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, declared that there could be no compromise between the freedom of democracy and the slavery of dictatorship.

Ireland as a peaceful nation that Has contributed "a Christian heritage of faith, hope and love" to the family of nations was extolled yesterday at a solemn pontifical mass celebrated by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman in St. Patrick's Cathedral for the suffering people of Ireland.

PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- Possible fortification of additional everyday foods with vitamins is a subject uppermost in the minds of members of the Institute of Food Technologists, gathering here for their second annual conference, which is scheduled to open tomorrow morning.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15 (AP) -- The Newark Bears took a firmer grip on first place in the International League today by whipping the Jersey City Giants in both ends of a double-header, 9 to 3 and 3 to 0, before 10,538 fans.

LONDON, June 15 -- While the short-term fluctuations in the stock markets still are governed by daily developments in the war situation, the main trend here reflects the monetary situation caused by the release of fresh funds for reinvestment and a continued shortage of stock as a result of the thinness of important selling.
LONDON, June 15 -- Alterations in rank, coupled with more favorable pay conditions for the Auxiliary Territorial Service, were announced today by the War Office.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 15 (AP) -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-secretary of War, said in an interview here tonight that Army forces would be withdrawn from the North American Aviation Company plant in Los Angeles "in a few days."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Monday, June 16 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Defense expenditures of the Netherlands Indies for 1941-42 were estimated officially today at the equivalent of $250,000,000. This was made known by the Finance Department in submitting its budget estimates to the People's Council.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 -- There were plenty of excitement, some excellent polo and hard luck in the games at Bostwick Field and Meadow Brook today. The excitement and good polo were at both places, the hard luck at Bostwick Field when John Armstrong, here from Texas with his father and brother to play through the Meadow Brook championships which start next week, broke his right arm in a spill in the sixth period.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 15 (AP) -- The following is the text of today's communique from the British Middle East Command:

As a site for improvement with eleven two-family houses, a plot 225 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Seabury Street and Fifty-seventh Avenue, Elmhurst, L.I., was purchased by the Sollee Realty Company. The houses will be from plans by A.H. Salkowitz, architect, and are to be ready about Sept. 1 according to Lee Harris Co brokers in the sale of the land.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A total of 204,000 soldiers could sit down simultaneously to watch the latest moving pictures in 265 theatres at Army posts in the United States, Alaska and Atlantic Base Commands, according to War Department figures compiled today.

The Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, preaching yesterday at the Broadway Presbyterian Temple, Broadway at 114th Street, assailed colleges and universities as destroyers of the religious faith of young people. Many denominational colleges were among the worst offenders, he said.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 15 -- Rumanian sources reported tonight that Russia had ordered general mobilization and had canceled all leave for reservists.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Advances in the retail prices of foodstuffs are bound to occur in the next few months, but the rises will be moderate and will come in an orderly manner, officials of the National Association of Retail Grocers asserted here tonight on the eve of the association's forty-fourth annual convention, opening at the Palmer House tomorrow and continuing through Thursday.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Announcement that the government would hold corn taken on loans between a 69-cent minimum and a 75-cent maximum, thus virtually fixing a priceceiling not far from current quotations, did not have much effect on this grain last week.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- If his health permits, President Roosevelt will attend alumni exercises at Harvard University Thursday symbolizing Anglo-American unity.

ABOUT the only item missing from the customary preliminaries for the big fight is that neither Conn nor Louis has rescued some hapless child from drowning. Otherwise the recognized traditional order of events has been followed.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 15 -- Making one of the speediest best-in-show decisions of the current season, Townsend Scudder of Greenwich, Conn., today picked the imported whippet bitch Champion Flornell Glamorous for top honors in the ninth annual Longshore allbreed exhibition at the Longshore Beach and Country Club, bordering Long Island Sound.

VICHY, France, June 15 -- After a week of fighting in Lebanon and Syria, the towns of Saida and Abu Kemal are in British hands and French Air Force units have been sent from France as reinforcements. These are the salient points in the French communique issued here tonight.

The Progressive Committee to Rebuild the American Labor Party and the party's New York County Committee joined yesterday in issuing a call for a city-wide convention to designate anti-war candidates for Mayor and other city offices.

Second-guessing being infallible, it can be stated that the Indians started the wrong pitcher before 43,962 fans at the Stadium yesterday. Jim Bagby Jr. was touched by the Yankees for four hits and all their runs in three and a third innings, but Lefty Al Smith yielded only one freak safety the rest of the way.

To avoid serious congestion of the traffic that is expected to flow between Atlantic Avenue, now undergoing a $23,000,000 grade-crossing improvement, and the Belt Parkway, Park Commissioner Robert Moses will submit to Mayor La Guardia today a request for the widening of Conduit Boulevard in Brooklyn and Queens at an estimated cost of $2,200,000.

BERLON, June 15 -- While no official reaction or comment by banking circles to President Roosevelt's decision to freeze German and Italian balances in the United States was obtainable tonight, former utterances by authoritative financial circles indicated that the German Government had not been taken unaware.

Yesterday, the 726th anniversary of the sealing of the Magna Carta at Runnymede on June 15, 1215, was observed at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine with special prayers for freedom by Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, both at the 11 o'clock holy communion service and at rites that followed before the ancient shaft of the Abbey of Bury St. Edmunds.

Last week's rise on the Stock Exchange, which by Thursday had brought the averages nearly 5 points above the beginning of the month, was clearly attributable to the Federal Government's intervention in the strike at the aviation company's Pacific Coast plant.
PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- New steel specifications continued to pour into the mills last week, while the industry clamped down tighter controls over distribution of available steel supplies.

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, who is coordinator of the State Defense Council, said yesterday that his organization would "go after" employers or union officials who discriminated against minority groups in defense industry jobs.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 15 (UP) -- Informed neutral diplomats, reporting intense military activity on both sides of the Soviet-German frontiers, asserted tonight that a Nazi attack on Russia was "inevitable" unless Russia agreed to help feed the Nazi-occupied countries of Europe.

"With our national resources, our productive capacity and the genius of our people for mass production, we will help Britain to outstrip the Axis Powers in munitions of war." With these words President Roosevelt transmitted to Congress his report on the lease-lend operations.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Twelve experts in research pertaining to finance and trade have been chosen by the Department of Commerce to act as business consultants in its offices in the 12 Federal Reserve cities.

The Rockefeller Foundation has granted $40,000 to finance a twoyear research project into the status of labor, working conditions and social and economic controls in Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia, according to announcement yesterday by Dr. Alvin Johnson, dean of the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science of the New School for Social Research.

BERLIN, June 15 -- Instead of pinning false hopes on a long-range economic blockade of Europe, the United States should realize the opportunities offered to the Western Hemisphere for the expansion of its trade with the European Continent, consolidated under German leadership.
BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Red Sox thrilled a capacity crowd of 34,500 today by winning a double-header with the White Sox, 8 -- 6 and 6 -- 4.

BERLIN, Monday, June 16 (UP) -- Informed sources said today that "nothing is known here" of Stockholm reports of a new German-Russian economic agreement and of German ships being recalled from Baltic ports.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN SYRIA, June 15 -- From a hilltop today a group of correspondents watched the final shelling that drove French forces beyond Saida. Three French planes appeared and machine-gunned the party, which had returned from a visit to British columns pushing toward Damascus, up the River Jordan and along the coast.
LONDON, Monday, June 16 -- The British Royal Air Force had by far the upper hand over the Nazi Air Fleet over the week-end, according to Air Ministry reports early today.

ROME, June 15 -- Italy replied swiftly today to the freezing of Italian funds in the United States by taking similar measures which, it is indicated, go beyond President Roosevelt's action. However, either through design or carelessness, the official communique issued this afternoon makes puzzling reading.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 -- Assailing Lon Warneke and Howard Krist for a dozen hits, the Dodgers scored an 8-1 triumph over the Cardinals in the first game of a twin bill today and came up to the nightcap with a chance to replace St. Louis in the National League lead.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently I returned from a business trip which took me across New York and Pennsylvania. It was immediately after the President made his now famous "emergency" speech which was shown rather fully in the newsreels. I saw and heard this speech in Little Falls, N.Y., Buffalo and Pittsburgh.

GIRARD, Ohio, June 15 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner, a steady money winner but never before first in a major tournament, waded over the rain-soaked Mahoning Country Club golf course today to win the $5,000 Mahoning Valley open with a fourunder-par 276.
PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- The Braves defeated the Pirates, 5 -- 1, in the first game of a double-header today and rain won the decision in the afterpiece.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Stating that he had received complaints of nation-wide discrimination against Negroes in defense industries, President Roosevelt called upon the Office of Production Management today to take immediate steps to deal effectively with this "grave" situation.

VICHY, June 15 -- Application of the different features of the government's social program is going forward rapidly. A law has just been published authorizing the Agricultural Fund to accord individuual long-term credits to rural proprietors for construction or improvements for the housing of farm workers.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Soy beans sold off sharply early last week, but recovered strongly later, with buying becoming fairly general on the announcement that the government would support beans at $1 a bushel on the farms.

For twelve years Walter Goiterman, 44 years old, of 979 Summit Avenue, the Bronx, has been taking courses at City College to occupy his spare time and to satisfy an intense curiosity about things in general.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., June 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Pearson gave a reception last night at Estamos, Great Barrington, in compliment to their guests, Miss Mary Louise Schick of Fort Knox, Ky., and Lieutenant Paul Crawford Root Jr., whose engagement has just been announced.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 15 -- Addressing a Tufts commencement gathering of more than 4,000 persons, including 484 in the graduating class, Dr. Vannevar Bush, director of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and chairman of the National Defense Research Committee, today lashed out at strikes in defense industries, asserting that the rearmament program was a race against time.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., June 15 -- The most intensive Army mineplanting exercises since World War days will be opened by officers and men of the special mine command of the Seventh Coast Artillery, Fort Hancock's "home regiment," tomorrow.

McKEESPORT, Pa., Monday, June 16 (UP) -- A strike of unionized municipal employes, which is expected to cripple essential services in this city of 57,000 with the exception of police and fire protection, became effective automatically at midnight.

SUFFERN, N.Y., June 15 -- With a guard of honor consisting of representatives of the Boy Scouts of America, to which organization Daniel Carter Beard had devoted his life, a simple funeral service was conducted here for him this afternoon.

In view of the broad nature of President Roosevelt's order freezing Axis assets in the United States it was expected in banking circles here last night that New York banks would exercise broad discretion in restraining withdrawals from questionable accounts in the coming week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- "Gwangi," a fantastic story of life discovered on a lost mesa by a band of cowboys, has been written for RKO by Jerry Cady, and the studio has scheduled it for August production on "an unlimited budget with a six-month shooting schedule."

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Citizens of sixteen nations, many of them former government officials of high rank in their countries, met here today as individuals to organize a coordinating body of believers in collective security. No name was chosen, but it will be called something like "the Free World Association,"and will have international headquarters in New York City.

CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (UP) -- The United States gunboat Tutuila was slightly damaged, the office of the American military attache was wrecked and the United States Navy canteen was damaged today when twenty-seven Japanese planes raided the Chinese capital.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Six Danish ships will be physically taken over tomorrow by the United States Maritime Commission, thus marking the first completion of steps toward taking over the eighty-four foreign ships in American harbors which became subject to Federal jurisdiction under the Ship Requisition Act.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- A majority of a mounting number of selective-service registrants who have taken appeals to President Roosevelt have been upheld and put in deferred classifications.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 15 -- By a vote of sixty-four to two, union representatives of 50,000 workers in East Coast shipyards today endorsed the two-year no-strike agreement proposed by the Office of Production Management.

ITHACA, June 15 -- "We are in the midst of a revolution so much vaster than wars now raging that it is quite possible that the nation or nations which win the war may lose the revolution," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Church, New York City, said this afternoon in the baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of Cornell University.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Oswald Garrison Villard argues in a circle in taking up the cudgels for Charles A. Lindbergh's and John T. Flynn's strange agitation for "new leadership in the White House."

There was a between-seasons lull in ready-to-wear lines last week, as manufacturers prepared for the influx of Fall merchandise buyers beginning today. Early showings took the center of the stage and retailers were busy with plans for new selections.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses. Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- Unlimbering their war clubs in the eighth inning, the Athletics came from behind today to down the Browns, 10 to 4, in the first game of a scheduled double-header. A heavy rainstorm at the end of the first contest washed out the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Full support of President Roosevelt in his declaration of an unlimited national emergency was expressed by ninety-nine officials of A.F.L. and C.I.O. unions in a statement issued here today through the Fight for Freedom Committee.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra gave a special pre-season concert last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, to raise money for a series of band concerts which will be given this Summer for the fourth consecutive year in parks and playgrounds of "musically underprivileged" sections of the city.

One thousand ministers of Protestant denominations in all parts of the United States have recorded their "unalterable opposition" to the "present threatened belligerency" of the United States and have pledged themselves not to use their ministry to "bless, sanction or support war," according to an announcement yesterday by the Rev.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 15 (UP) -- Utilities of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation in the, Southeast will begin tomorrow a rationing program which calls for a one-third reduction in electrical power consumption by industries not manufacturing defense materials.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- Members of A.F. of L. and C.I.O. machinists unions today voted down proposals for return to work at eleven San Francisco Bay area shipyards to end a strike which has been in progress for five weeks.
One campaign in the 1941 phase of the Battle of France is being fought by an army of democratic spies and fifth columnists.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The search by industry for successful substitutes for aluminum, stainless steel, zinc and nickel has flooded the offices of the Porcelain Enamel Institute with inquiries, it was learned here today from Charles S. Pearce, managing, director.
BERLIN, June 15 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:...
PALO ALTO, Calif., June 15 (AP) -- Monopoly in private business and the closed shop in labor were classified in the same category today by President Ray Lyman Wilbur of Stanford University.

It is not easy to analyze our "balance of foreign trade," since the leaselend act deferred to a future date payment on so great a part of it. The fact that our import of gold in May was only $34,830,000, as against $171,992,000 in April, may have some direct bearing on the question.

BERLIN, June 15 (AP) -- Nearly 300,000 tons of British and British-used shipping have been sent to the bottom in the first two weeks of June, bringing ship losses to nearly 12,000,000 tons in twenty-one months of warfare, D.N.B., official German news agency, said tonight.

The pilot training program of the Civil Aeronautics Administration has set an enviable record for safety. During the Summer of 1940, with an enrollment of 26,080 there were eight fatalities, eight hospital cases and twenty-one minor injuries. During the Fall program, with 30,798 students enrolled, there were ten fatalities, but only four hospital cases and fourteen minor injuries.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A National Advisory Council on Real Estate to assist the Heal Estate Section of the Construction Division, Office of the Quartermaster General, in the acquisition of land for defense projects was named today by the War Department and nine zone real estate directors were appointed.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Seventy-five per cent of the sales made or services performed by commercial establishments must be retail to qualify them for exemption from the Wage Hour Law, instead of 50 per cent as hitherto, the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department stated in a ruling issued today.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 15 -- One of the outstanding junior equestrians in the East, 15-year-old William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., added to his laurels today as the twelfth annual Bronxville Riding Club horse show was held in its outdoor ring.

BERLIN, June 15 -- Rear Admiral Luetzow, one of Germany's leading naval publicists, explains to the German people in this week's issue of the Reich what happens when a German auxiliary cruiser meets the United States patrol service.

ROME, June 15 (AP) -- Some observers pointed out today that the Italian action in freezing United States funds might even be the prelude to a diplomatic break in relations with the United States, which at least one Borne newspaper seemed to suggest.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

BALTIMORE, June 15 -- The first test flight of a new bomber being built for Britain showed it to be "about as fast as most of the pursuit planes flying in Europe," the Glenn L. Martin Company disclosed today.

FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga., June 15 -- On the fields of Chickamauga, where Bragg confronted Rosecrans in 1863, the much-heralded "Hell-on-Wheels" Second Armored Division, the first such in the history of the United States to engage in combat manoeuvres, against infantry divisions at full war strength, is preparing tonight for its assault upon the forces of Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear's Second Army in Middle Tennessee, early next week.

LONDON, June 15 -- The fresh currency created by the increase in the fiduciary note issue in the six last weeks is now going into active use. In the last week, the Bank of England's circulation rose u1,700,000 to a new high record, u637,168,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 6 -- Argentines hope that the negotiations for a trade treaty now going on in Washington will result in greater United States purchases of their meats.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Foreign Policy Association said today that Germany had sufficient oil to meet her immediate war and industrial needs, but could not hope to organize Europe's economy successfully without additional oil resources.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- Reminding members of Harvard's graduating class that "this is no usual commencement," for they must "listen to a direct call for assistance by the national government," President James B. Conant, in the baccalaureate sermon that opened the college's 290th commencement exercises today, urged the seniors to plan their lives not for the frustration of their hopes but for "the long years ahead."

DETROIT, June 16 -- The majority of purchasing agents in this area continued to place orders for six months or more ahead in May, according to the monthly report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit, issued today. Orders for a year ahead were being placed by 4 per cent of the members as against 3 per cent in April and 1 per cent in March.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The long smouldering desire for a separate Air Corps conducted by an administration of its own is expected to come into the open with the introduction of a bill today by Senator Patrick McCarran, providing such a force under a Secretary of Military Aviation.

It is not wholly an accident that reports of an impending clash between Russia and Germany coincide with the arrival in London of Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's Ambassador to Moscow. s early as last February Sir Stafford made no secret of his belief that Germany would attack Russia this Summer, probably before the end of July.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters were Joe DiMaggio and Lefty Gomez, baseball players, who leased penthouse apartments in 400 West End Avenue and 825 West End Avenue respectively through the Apartment Leasing Service, brokers.

Traders and investors scurried to a safe position yesterday as relations between the United States and the Axis tightened to the point where Washington ordered the closing of all of the Reich's consular establishments and the leading semi-official agencies in this country.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Ken Chase scored his first victory in two months by pitching Washington to a 3-to-1 triumph over the Tigers today. The Senators took the series, two games to one.

An invitation for a six-man United States track and field squad to compete in meets in Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina next September has been received and accepted by Daniel J. Ferris, the secretary-treasurer of the National A.A.U. announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Young Jake Mooty pitched the Cubs to a 3-to-1 victory over the Phils today. He was aided by three double plays.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The United States today ordered Germany to close all of its consulates, as well as specified travel and propaganda agencies in this country by July 10, a step just short of breaking diplomatic relations.

TORONTO, June 16 -- Synchronization of the manifold activities of Canadian women's organizations in support of this nation's war effort is long overdue but should evolve speedily now that Joseph Thorson has been named the new Minister for War Service, American newspaper women were told today at a tea at the Women's University Club here.

Mayor La Guardia and Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn spent four minutes early yesterday afternoon earnestly aiming an oxy-acetylene torch at a longitudinal girder of the doomed Fulton Street elevated structure just opposite Brooklyn Borough Hall.

The sale of scrap metal at the Army Base in Brooklyn, at a time when the government is collecting such material, was explained yesterday as the disposal of "junk" not worth salvaging for defense purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 11. Increases of $58,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $80,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, $64,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and $183,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $67,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 16 -- Russo-German relations continued to be the chief subject of speculation in the press and in foreign diplomatic quarters here today.

THAT big, sorrel-thatched Don Padgett is a handy gent to have on a ball club. The Cardinals have used him behind the bat, in the outfield and at first base. He prefers the outfield, but he doesn't always cast the deciding vote on any given afternoon. It's at bat that he really shines. As the players say, he puts a lot of wood on the ball.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Moscow News, official Soviet weekly newspaper published in English, was distributed to more than 120 newsstands in New York City south of Forty-second Street at a fairly large annual loss to Amkniga Corporation, predecessor to Bookniga Corporation, it was indicated today at the trial of three of the officers for failure to register with the State Department as propaganda agents of a foreign principal.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Dr. G. Krause-Wichmann, German consul in Chicago, said tonight that his office had received no official word of the State Department's order to close all German consulates, and until official word was received, the Chicago consulate would function on a business-as-usual basis.

There was thankfulness and joy in the hearts of relatives of the Robin Moor survivors in New York and other cities as the news came from Cape Town yesterday that all passengers and crew members of the torpedoed ship were safe.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Landlords and agents of thousands of commercial and apartment buildings in New York have set in motion the machinery for protection of their properties against air raids and sabotage and within a few days tenants by tens of thousands will be organized to receive instructions in their emergency duties, New York realty leaders revealed here today at the opening of the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The New York City women's division of the United Service Organizations opened 120 booths throughout the five boroughs yesterday to further the drive for $10,765,000 with which to operate clubhouses for soldiers and sailors.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 16 -- The first of the debutante parties of the North Shore "Little Season" took place here tonight at The Salutations, home of Mr. and Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan on West Island, their daughter, Miss Anne Morgan, being introduced to society at a dinner and dance for 500 friends of the family, including many of the young set home from college.

Quakertown, carrying the George D. Widener silks, became the shortest-priced winner of the Aqueduct meeting when he finished first yesterday before 12,772 spectators who backed him almost to the exclusion of all else in a field of seven. The pay-off was $2.70 for $2 on an afternoon that saw $719,923 pass through the totalizator.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Roosevelt, although recovered from his sore throat, canceled today a plan to attend the Harvard commencement exercises.

BERLIN, June 16 (UP) -- Neutral quarters believed tonight that Germany would retaliate promptly for the closing of Reich consulates and the freezing of Axis assets in the United States, but authorized Nazi spokesmen flatly declined to comment on the latest strain imposed on German-American relations.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Thirty-one canning companies, three organizations and thirty-five individuals were indicted by a special Federal grand jury today on a charge of conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law by controlling the production and price of canned peas.

An underwriting group headed by Reynolds Co. and E. H. Rolling Sons, Inc., will offer today 153,331 shares of common stock of the International Machine Tool Corporation. The stock, of $1 par value, will be priced at $10.80 a share. Of the shares to be offered, 114,998 will represent new financing by the company and the balance of 38,333 is to be sold by present stockholders.

TORONTO, June 16 (Science Service) -- Electrical engineering studies of the human body were described here this morning at the opening session of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. These indicate that life and death are very closely connected with electrical activity, said Dr. Robert S. Schwab of the Brain Wave Laboratory of the Massachusetts General Hospital and the Harvard Medical School.

Transocean News Service, the German Library of Information and the German Railroads Information Office, now ordered removed from the United States for activities inimical to the welfare of this country, have been under official scrutiny for many months.

Four areas in downtown Brooklyn are particularly suited for improvement under the Urban Redevelopment Bill enacted at the last session of the Legislature, the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement reported yesterday.

MONTREAL, June 16 (Canadian Press) -- Miss Jacqueline Cochran, the American aviatrix, was at an Eastern Canadian airport today, waiting to fly the Atlantic as first officer on a bombing plane ferried to Britain.

There was little action in yesterday's wholesale markets. Supplies of some classes were light and others were mostly normal. Price trends were uneven. Steer beef hinds and ribs sold at steady to strong prices. Lamb carcasses and wholesale cuts went at mostly steady prices with the exception of hindsaddles, where some sales were made at 51 lower rates.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 16 -- Clarence Doser, Scarsdale Golf Club pro competing in his first event of the Westchester season, and young Doug Ford of Green Valley, New York State junior titleholder, shared honors with Tony Tiso, pro at Hickory, and Saul Lantzis of Fenway, best-ball victors, in the Westchester County Golf Association one-day tournament at the Tamarack Country Club today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 --The 6,646-ton freighter Azuma Maru, flying the Japanese flag, arrived in port here yesterday and had planned to start loading lubricating oil tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16 -- The Independent Order of Brith Abraham voted today to contribute a total of $50,000 to the Jewish section of the British War Relief Society, the United Jewish Appeal and the United Service Organizations.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (AP) -- Sales of large quantities of morphine-bearing cough syrup to ten stables racing horses on California tracks are being investigated by the State Narcotics Division, it was disclosed today. Paul E. Madden, chief of the Narcotics Division, declined to name the stables involved, pending additional investigation.

Eighty-seven graduates and senior students at City College will receive medals, scholarships and prizes at the college's ninety-fourth, annual commencement exercises tomorrow night in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 -- The actuality of secret German-Russian negotiations, which are taking place in both Moscow and Berlin, is affirmed here by diplomatic sources as well as by German circles in Istanbul. No secret is made of the fact that tension between the two powers is growing, but the belief is spreading that in the end the Soviet will accede to any and all German demands under the guise of some face-saving formula.

Retail Sales Here Rise 10% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent for the week ended June 14, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase was in line with expectations.

The number of books brought out by all American publishers in the first five months of this year closely matched the figures for the same period last year. Combined new books and new editions totaled 4,738 against 4,782, according to compilations prepared by Publishers Weekly.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today signed John M. Stahl to a two-year contract as a producer-director, giving him the right to select his own pictures. His first venture will be an adaptation of the novel, "Another Spring," by H. M. Thornman, which he has owned for some time.
